
ENTRY:1
HEAD:ā 阿
MC:Middle Chinese: ʔâ
	[T] ONW ʔɑ
	A vernacular prefix added to kinship terms, personal names and personal pronouns, e.g.
	Mand. ā-mǔ 阿母 ``mother'' [Han texts], ā-nú  阿奴 ``younger brother'', ā-shuí  阿誰 ``who'', ā-nǐ 阿你 ``you'' (Norman 1988: 113); Yuè-Guǎngzhōu a³³-ma⁵⁵ (ʔaᶜ¹-maᴬ¹) 阿媽 ``mother, mama'', a³³-ma²¹ (ʔaᶜ¹-maᴬ²) 阿嫲 ``grandmother''.
	[E] ST: PTB *ʔa- is a prefix for kinship terms, body parts or nouns in general, depending on the language (STC: 121-123), e.g. WB ə-tʰaŋ ``thought'' < tʰaŋ ``think'', ə-pʰuiᴮ ``grandfather''; WT ʔa-kʰu ``uncle, husband''.
>:PTB *ʔa- is a prefix for kinship terms, body parts or nouns in general, depending on the language , e.g.
>:WB ə-tʰaŋ ``thought'' < tʰaŋ ``think'', ə-pʰuiᴮ ``grandfather''
>:WT ʔa-kʰu ``uncle, husband''

ENTRY:2
HEAD:ā 阿 ~ yú 於
MC:Middle Chinese: ʔjwo 
LH:Later Han: ʔɨɑ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *ʔa
	Occurs already in Zuǒzhuàn prefixed to the Chǔ dialect word for {hǔ₁ 虎} ``tiger''.
	Unger (Hao-ku 33, 1986) suggests that certain words with MC initial ʔ-  might be the result of a fusion of this prefix with the following stem ({§5.11}).

ENTRY:3
HEAD:ā-nú 阿奴
MC:Middle Chinese: ʔâ-nuo
	[T] ONW ʔɑ-no
GLOSS:"Younger brother" [Jìn Dyn.] (Norman 1988: 113).
	[E] For phonological and semantic reasons, this word is prob. not related to rú 孺 *no ``child'' (under {rú₄ 懦臑} ``weak''), nor to {rǔ₃ 乳} ``milk''. It may be connected to PTB *naːw (STC no. 271): Lushai nauᴴ < nau ``child, younger brother or sister, younger cousin'' etc., JP kə³¹-nau³³ ``younger brother / sister'', WT nu-bo ``man's younger brother''.
	The putative OC final *ā cannot be reconciled with PTB *āːw, though; perhaps the CH word has been re-etymologized, or only committed to writing after *a > MC o.
::WT	nu-bo	``man's younger brother''
>:For phonological and semantic reasons, this word is prob. not related to rú 孺 *no ``child'' , nor to {rǔ₃ 乳} ``milk''. It may be connected to PTB *naːw :
>:Lushai nauᴴ < nau ``child, younger brother or sister, younger cousin'' etc.
>:JP kə³¹-nau³³ ``younger brother / sister''
>:WT nu-bo ``man's younger brother''

GLOSS:"To pity" [Shi] is prob. a sound-symbolic word.

GLOSS:"White-haired, old" [Shi], possibly related to TB items under {yuè₁ 月}
GLOSS:"moon", but the vowels do not agree.
	[T] Sin Sukchu SR ŋaj (去)
	[T] MGZY ŋay (去) [ŋaj]

ENTRY:8
HEAD:ài₂ 愛
MC:Middle Chinese: ʔậiᶜ 
LH:Later Han: ʔəs 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *ʔə̂s 
OCB:Baxter Old Chinese: *ʔəts
	[D] PMin *ʔuəiᶜ
GLOSS:"To love, to grudge" [Shi] > Mand.
GLOSS:"to like, be fond of".
	[T] Sin Sukchu  SR ʔaj (去)
	[T] MGZY ’ay (去) [ʔaj]
	[T] ONW ʔɑiᶜ
	[E] ST: PKaren *ʔai (Matisoff BSOAS 63.3, 2000: 364).
	[E] Or MK *sʔəəc, *sʔaac ``to love, pity'' (Shorto 2006 #798a).
::MK	*sʔəəc, *sʔaac	``to love, pity''
>:PKaren *ʔai
>:Or MK *sʔəəc, *sʔaac ``to love, pity''

ENTRY:11
HEAD:ài₅ 礙
MC:Middle Chinese: ŋậiᶜ 
LH:Later Han: ŋəᶜ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *ŋə̂kh
GLOSS:"Obstruct, hinder" [Lie].
	[T] Sin Sukchu  SR ŋaj (去)
	[T] MGZY ngay (去) [ŋaj]
	[T] ONW ŋɑiᶜ
	[E] ? ST: WT ’geg(s)-pa, bkag, dgag ``to hinder, prohibit, shut'' ⪤ ’gag ``obstruction, stoppage'' (Bodman 1980: 72); PLB *ʔgak ``obstruct, block up''. TB voiced stops do occasionally correspond to Chinese initial nasals ({§5.12.2}).
	Alternatively, WT could be compared with {gù₁ 固}.
	CH ài may be related to {yí₁₃ 疑} ``hesitate''.
>:WT ’geg-pa, bkag, dgag ``to hinder, prohibit, shut'' ⪤ ’gag ``obstruction, stoppage''
>:PLB *ʔgak ``obstruct, block up''. TB voiced stops do occasionally correspond to Chinese initial nasals

ENTRY:12
HEAD:ān₁ 安
MC:Middle Chinese: ʔân 
LH:Later Han: ʔɑn 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *ʔân 
OCB:Baxter Old Chinese: *ʔan
GLOSS:"Be calm, peaceful, still, steady, take one's leisure" [BI, Shi].
	[T] Sin Sukchu SR ʔɔn (平)
	[T] PR ʔan
	[T] LR ʔan
	[T] MGZY ’an (平) [ʔan]; ONW ʔɑn.

ENTRY:13
HEAD:ān₁ 安 ⪤ àn 按
MC:Middle Chinese: ʔânᶜ 
LH:Later Han: ʔɑnᶜ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *ʔâns
GLOSS:"To push down with the hand" [SW],
GLOSS:"to stop, repress" [Shi],
GLOSS:"lay hand on, seize" [Xun]; ``stool, tray'' 案 [Zhouli].
	[<] exoactive of ān ({§4.3}), lit. ``cause to be settled, calmed''.
	[C] Boltz (1994: 95ƒƒ) includes additional words which are written with this phonetic (GSR 146), such as {ān₃ 鞍}. A parallel stem ({§2.5}) is {yàn₁ 宴燕} (Wáng Lì 1982: 543). {yǎn₅ 偃} is prob. a different etymon.

ENTRY:14
HEAD:ān₂ 安
	interrogative particle
	{wū₅} 惡

ENTRY:15
HEAD:ān₃ 鞍
MC:Middle Chinese: ʔân 
LH:Later Han: ʔɑn 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *ʔân
GLOSS:"Saddle" [Guanzi] is cognate to {ān₁ 安} acc. to Boltz (1994: 95f), lit.
GLOSS:"seat". Following the Shìmíng, Pulleyblank has suggested a connection with è 頞 (ʔat)
GLOSS:"bridge of the nose" [Meng] (Boltz 1994: 98).

ENTRY:16
HEAD:ān₄ 喑
MC:Middle Chinese: ʔậm 
LH:Later Han: ʔəm 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *ʔə̂m
GLOSS:"Dumb, silent" [Mo].
	[E] ST *ʔum: PTB *um ``hold in the mouth'' (STC: 181) > WT ʔum ``a kiss'' (cf. ʔu ~ ʔo ``a kiss''); Lepcha ŭm ``receive into the mouth without swallowing'', Mikir om ``mouthful'', Nung im ``mouthful'' (HST: 95). Perh. also connected with PTB *(m-)uːm (STC: 181 n. 479). {cǎn 噆} is perhaps a derivation.
::Nung	im	``mouthful''
>:ST *ʔum:
>:PTB *um ``hold in the mouth''  >
>:WT ʔum ``a kiss''
>:Lepcha ŭm ``receive into the mouth without swallowing''
>:Mikir om ``mouthful''
>:Nung im ``mouthful'' . Perh. also connected with PTB *uːm . {cǎn 噆} is perhaps a derivation

ENTRY:17

GLOSS:"Hold in the mouth, put in the mouth" [GY].
	[T] ONW ʔɑm.
	[<] endoactive of ān 喑 ({§4.5}).

ENTRY:18
HEAD:ān₄ 喑 ⪤ yìn 喑

GLOSS:"Pent up" [Zhuang].
	[<] exopass. of ān 喑 ({§4.4}), lit. ``be held back in the mouth'', but the role of MC div. III is not clear ({§9.1.2}).

ENTRY:23
HEAD:àn₂ 岸 ⪤ hàn 厂
MC:Middle Chinese: xânᶜ 
LH:Later Han: hɑnᶜ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *hŋâns
GLOSS:"Cliff" [BI, SW],
GLOSS:"high river bank" [Liù shū běnyì 六書本義].

ENTRY:24
HEAD:àn₂ 岸 ⪤ hǔ 滸
MC:Middle Chinese: xuoᴮ 
LH:Later Han: hɑᴮ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *hŋâʔ
GLOSS:"River bank" [Shi].
	[<] These are all nouns derived from the stem *ŋaʔ ``oppose, resist'' ({yù₁₇ 禦}), i.e. ``the thing that resists the river's flow, keeps the river in its bed''. The voiceless initial in hàn and hǔ denotes a noun referring to a natural object ({§5.2.4}), the final *-n in hàn and àn marks nouns in general ({§6.4.3}).
	The role, if any, of tone C is not clear.
	For an overview of similar and related words, see under {yà₂ 御迓訝}.

LH:Later Han: ʔəmᴮ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *ʔə̂mʔ
	[T] ONW ʔɑmᴮ
GLOSS:"A deep black" [SW].

ENTRY:26
HEAD:àn₃ 黯 ⪤ àn 暗闇
MC:Middle Chinese: ʔậmᶜ 
LH:Later Han: ʔəmᶜ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *ʔə̂ms
GLOSS:"Be dark" 暗 [Guoyu]; 闇 (also read QY ʔậmᴮ) [Li] > Mand.
GLOSS:"dim, gloomy".
	[T] Sin S. SR ʔam (去)
	[T] PR ʔan
	[T] MGZY ’am (去) [ʔam], ONW ʔɑmᶜ.
	[<] perhaps exoactive of àn 黯 ({§4.3}), here noun > verb.
	[C] A probable allofam is {yīn₅ 陰} (so Wáng Lì 1982: 602).

>:Khmer ’āṅa /ʔaaŋ/ ``a type of large, wide-mouthed earthen jar, cistern, tank''

ENTRY:31
HEAD:áo₂ 嗷
MC:Middle Chinese: ŋâu 
LH:Later Han: ŋɑu 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *ŋâu
GLOSS:"To cry, clamor" [Shi].
	[E] Perh. cognate to PTB *ŋuw > WT ŋu-ba ``to weep, roar'', WB ŋui ``cry, weep'', PL *ŋo¹ ``cry'' (HST: 60). This identification is somewhat doubtful as the vowels and the meanings are not very close.
::PL	*ŋo¹	``cry''
>:Perh. cognate to PTB *ŋuw >
>:WT ŋu-ba ``to weep, roar''
>:WB ŋui ``cry, weep''
>:PL *ŋo¹ ``cry'' . This identification is somewhat doubtful as the vowels and the meanings are not very close

ENTRY:32

GLOSS:"To fry" [Zhouli],
GLOSS:"roast" [Li].

>:ST *ŋau:

>:WT rŋod-pa, brŋos ``to parch, roast, fry''
>:Chepang ŋāw
>:Mikir arŋu ``roast, fry''
>:JP gə³¹-ŋau³³ ``fry''

GLOSS:"bay, cove" was acc. to Guō Pú (ca. 300 AD) a Jiāngnán (southern) word.
	[T] Sin Sukchu SR ʔaw (去)
	[T] MGZY ’aw (去) [ʔaw]
	[T] ONW ʔɑu
	[D] This word is still used in Mǐn dialects: Fúzhōu oᶜ¹-tʰauᴬ², Xiàmén uᶜ¹
	[E] MK: Viet ao ``pool, pond'', WrMon ``o, o ‘cove, small bay'' (Norman 1983: 205).
>:Viet ao ``pool, pond''
>:WrMon ``o, o ‘cove, small bay''

CH ⇒ Tai: PT *p-: S. pɛɛtᴰ¹ᴸ is obviously a CH loan (otherwise we should find an /r/ in the Tai initial).

ENTRY:37
HEAD:bā₃ 笆
MC:Middle Chinese: baᴮ,pa
GLOSS:"A kind of bamboo from southwest China" [GY].
	[E] The word's place of origin (SW China) and late appearance suggest that it is a loan from a TB language: PTB *pa [STC no. 44; Matisoff LL 1.2, 2000: 140] > WT spa ~ sba ``cane''; WB waᴮ ``bamboo''; JP kə⁵⁵-wa⁵⁵, wə³¹ ``bamboo'', Lushai ruaᴴ (rɔᶠ) (< *r-wa) ``a kind of bamboo'' (HST: 38).
::Lushai	ruaᴴ  	``a kind of bamboo''
>:The word's place of origin  and late appearance suggest that it is a loan from a TB language:
>:PTB *pa  >
>:WT spa ~ sba ``cane''
>:WB waᴮ ``bamboo''
>:JP kə⁵⁵-wa⁵⁵, wə³¹ ``bamboo''
>:Lushai ruaᴴ   ``a kind of bamboo''

ENTRY:40
HEAD:bā₅ 豝
MC:Middle Chinese: pa 
LH:Later Han: pa 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *prâ
GLOSS:"Wild pig, pig" [Shi].
	[E] Bā is assumed to be a ST word related to PTB *pᵂak > WT pʰag; PLB *wak > WB wak; JP waʔ³¹ ``pig'' (STC no. 43; Matisoff LL 1.2: 2000: 157f). But the OC and TB forms are phonologically not very close.
	OC medial *r corresponds also to a TB pre-initial, but TB forms for ``pig'' do not have one, therefore one needs to assume some kind of CH innovation which led to medial *r.
	An OC open syllable corresponding to TB final -k is not common ({§6.9}).
	Alternatively, Wa-Lawa-Bulang *bras ``wild boar'' is semantically and phonologically close to the OC form.
	CH ⇒ Miao languages npa⁴, npua⁴ ``pig'' (Strecker LTBA 10.2, 1987: 51: Benedict, Wáng Fúshì).
::Miao	languages npa⁴, npua⁴	``pig''
>:Bā is assumed to be a ST word related to PTB *pᵂak >
>:WT pʰag
>:PLB *wak >
>:WB wak
>:JP waʔ³¹ ``pig'' . But the OC and TB forms are phonologically not very close

	{fǎ₃} 髮

>:Lushai pɔtᴸ / pɔʔᴸ ``to pull, pull up, out''. Allofams may include {fā 發} and {fèi₆ 廢} ``cast aside''

ENTRY:45
HEAD:bá₂ 茇
MC:Middle Chinese: puât 
LH:Later Han: pɑt 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *pât
GLOSS:"Roots of grass" [Huainan, SW].
GLOSS-NOTE:SW 377 considers this word related to {fā 發}
GLOSS:"lift up / out" and {fá₂ 伐}
GLOSS:"to plow" as the plow exposes the roots of the grass.
	An allofam may be {bá₃ 茇} ``to camp'', and perhaps bá 跋 ``foot, base''.
	[E] Etymology not clear. Comparanda may include JP (n³¹-/niŋ³¹-) pot³¹ ``root; origin''; or see {bá₃ 茇}.
::JP	pot³¹	``root; origin''
>:Etymology not clear. Comparanda may include JP  pot³¹ ``root; origin''
>:or see {bá₃ 茇}

ENTRY:46
HEAD:bá₃ 茇
MC:Middle Chinese: buât 
LH:Later Han: bɑt 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *bât 
OCB:Baxter Old Chinese: *bat
GLOSS:"To camp on grassland" [Shi, Zuo].
	[E] This is likely a specialized meanings of a MK etymon: MK *kɓat, *ɓat ``grass'' (Shorto 2006 #1034). Possibly, {bá₂ 茇} ``roots of grass'' could be related.
>:This is likely a specialized meanings of a MK etymon:
>:MK *kɓat, *ɓat ``grass'' . Possibly, {bá₂ 茇} ``roots of grass'' could be related

ENTRY:47
HEAD:bá₃a 跋
MC:Middle Chinese: buât 
LH:Later Han: bɑt 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *bât
GLOSS:"To trample on (with feet), trudge" [Shi],
GLOSS:"foot, base" (of a torch) [Li];
GLOSS:"the end of an arrow" [Shi].
GLOSS-NOTE:Possibly related to {bá₂ 茇}
GLOSS:"roots (of grass)", but that would be rather strained.

HEAD:bá₄ 拔
	{bá₁} 犮

	{bá₂} 茇

	{pá₂,bá} 耙杷

ENTRY:51
HEAD:bǎ 把
MC:Middle Chinese: paᴮ 
LH:Later Han: paᴮ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *prâʔ
GLOSS:"A handful" [Guoyu],
GLOSS:"grasp" [Meng].
	[T] Sin Sukchu SR pa (上)
	[T]  MGZY: suppl. ba (上) [pa])
	[E] ST: WT spar-ba ``the grasping hand, paw, claw, a handful'' (Unger Hao-ku 35, 1986: 36). Matisoff (2000: 155f) connects this word with PTB *r-pa-k ``palm / sole and leaf''.
	For the r-metathesis, see {§7.7.3}.
	This word may be related to {pá₂,bá 耙杷} ``rake''.
	Given its TB cognates, it is prob. not related to {fú₃ 扶} ``breadth of two fingers''.
	Wáng Lì (1982: 173) relates this wf to {bǐng₂ 秉} ``grasp''.
::PTB	*r-pa-k	``palm / sole and leaf''
>:WT spar-ba ``the grasping hand, paw, claw, a handful'' . Matisoff  connects this word with PTB *r-pa-k ``palm / sole and leaf''

ENTRY:52
HEAD:bà₁ 垻

GLOSS:"Flat valley".
	This word from SW China is a Tai loan: S. paaᴮ¹ < *paᴮ  ``meadow'' (Li F. 1976: 46; Mei Tsu-lin, AAS 1980).

ENTRY:56
HEAD:bái₁ 白
MC:Middle Chinese: bɐk 
LH:Later Han: bak 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *brâk
GLOSS:"Be white" [OB, BI, Shi] always has been a basic color term (Baxter JCLTA 19, 1983), also applied to silver.
	[T] Sin Sukchu SR bəj (入)
	[T] LR bəjʔ
	[T] MGZY pay (入) [baj]
	[T] ONW bëk
	[N] The graph represents an acorn, note the element 白 in the original graphs for {lè₃ 樂} ({yuè₉ 樂}) = lì 櫟 ``oak'' and zào 皂 ``acorn''. It is not clear why the graph has been selected for ``white''. (Unger Hao-ku  29, 1984).
	[E] ST: Most plausibly, bái is a CH kēxtension ({§6.1}) of the ST root *bar ``white'' and thus cognate to {pó₃ 皤} ``white'' (so Wáng Lì 1982: 292), hence OC < *bar-k: PTB *pwaːr > Lushai vaarᴴ ``be white, light'', PKaren *ʔ(b)wa ``white'' (Matisoff LL 1.2, 2000: 145).
	Tai: S. pʰɨak < *pʰr/l- ? ``white, albino'' (Li F. 1976: 44) may be a CH loan.
	<> AA ``silver'' may be related: Nyah-Kur prak, PVM *prak.
	Alternatively, note this area word for ``white'' without medial r which is, however, difficult to reconcile with MC: MK *kɓɔɔk ``white, gray'' (Shorto 2006 #369a); PTB *bok (?): S. Kuki bok ``white'', Garo gibok ~ gipok, Dimasa *g-pʰuk.
	[C] Possible cognates are {bó₁ 伯} ``elder''; {bó₂ 帛}; {pò₄ 魄}, {pò₅ 霸魄}.
::Kuki	bok	``white''
>:Most plausibly, bái is a CH kēxtension  of the ST root *bar ``white'' and thus cognate to {pó₃ 皤} ``white'' , hence OC < *bar-k:
>:PTB *pwaːr >
>:Lushai vaarᴴ ``be white, light''
>:PKaren *ʔwa ``white''

ENTRY:57
HEAD:bái₂ 白
	[D] Min: Fúzhōu paiʔ⁷, Amoy bat⁷ ``to know'', borrowed from AA: Viet biẽt ``to know, recognize'', also PMY *p¹ai¹ᴬ ``to know'' (Norman / Mei 1976: 298).
::PMY	*p¹ai¹ᴬ	``to know''

GLOSS-NOTE:The OB graph is similar to, but not identical with, {bái₁ 白}
GLOSS:"white" (Unger Hao-ku  29, 1984).

	[T] MGZY bay (入) [paj]

	CH ⇒ PTai *p-: Lóngzhōu paakᴰ¹ᴸ is obviously a CH loan (otherwise we should expect an r in the initial and almost certainly an open syllable).

ENTRY:59
HEAD:bǎi₂ 捭
MC:Middle Chinese: paɨᴮ

GLOSS:"To open" [Guiguzi].
	[E] ST *prai: WB praiᴮ ``to gape, expand, flare'' ⪤ pʰraiᴮ ``to pull open, make gap''; Chepang pre-ʔak-sa ``to separate'' (intr.).
	A derivation is {bò₃ 擘} (pɛk).
	Possibly related to {zhā 奓} *trai ``to open''.
	For an overview of similar items, see {Table P-1} under {pī₃ 披}.

ENTRY:60
HEAD:bài₁ 敗
MC:Middle Chinese: paiᶜ 
LH:Later Han: pas 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *prâts
GLOSS:"To ruin, destroy" [Shi].
	[T] Sin Sukchu SR pai, bai (去)
	[T]  MGZY  bay, pay (去) [paj ~ bɑj]
	[E] Etymology not certain, but Tai: S. prap⁴ ``to subdue, conquer'' is the same etymon and indicates a PCH form *praps > OCM *prâts. (The phonetic {bèi₂ 貝} is also connected to foreign -p). The direction of borrowing is undetermined, yet Tai is prob. not the ultimate source of CH. More likely, the etymon is a ``medial r'' causative derivation ({§7.5}) with the addition of the redundant exoactive final *-s ({§4.3}).
	AA is the most likely source of OC: OMon pop /pop/ ``to give way to'', Khmer -pap /-bɑɑp/ ``be beaten, subdued, routed'' ⪤ paṁpapa /bɑmbɑɑp/ ``to crush'' (opposition), ``break down'' (resistance). (Note that MK has a causative r-infix).
	<> ST: WT ’brab-pa ``to beat, scourge (e.g. with thorns), scatter'' (e.g. grain for offering) is semantically somewhat removed.
	Alternatively, bài may be derived from {fèi₆ 廢} ``reject, fall''; however, {fèi₆ 廢} ⪤ fá 乏 = WT bab ``fall down'' is semantically different from bài 敗 = AA pap ``be beaten'', hence we consider these two distinct wfs.
	Acc. to Wáng Lì (1982: 500) an allofam is {bì₁₀ 敝弊斃} ``worn out''.
	Pulleyblank (1962: 215) relates this wf to {pí₇ 罷疲}.
	See {fèi₆ 廢} for additional comments.
::AA	pap	``be beaten''
>:Etymology not certain, but Tai:
>:S. prap⁴ ``to subdue, conquer'' is the same etymon and indicates a PCH form *praps >
>:OCM *prâts. . The direction of borrowing is undetermined, yet Tai is prob. not the ultimate source of CH. More likely, the etymon is a ``medial r'' causative derivation  with the addition of the redundant exoactive final *-s

OCB:Baxter Old Chinese: *ɦprats
GLOSS:"To go to ruin, defeat" [OB, Shi].
	[<] endopass. of bài 敗 (paiᶜ) ({§4.6}).

ENTRY:63
HEAD:bài₃ 粺
MC:Middle Chinese: baiᶜ 
LH:Later Han: bɛᶜ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *brêh 
OCB:Baxter Old Chinese: *bres
GLOSS:"Fine rice" [Shi].
	[E] This etymon is close to {lì₂₁ 糲} *ras ``coarse grain'' and its possible cognates, both hail perhaps from the some foreign source. This word bài and {mǐ₁ 米} ``rice'' can on occasion be connected with the same foreign comparandum.
	The following items look similar to bài: Kharia pɛʔ, Khmer paj < *paih, *pih ``rice'', PNB *pʰe ``husked rice''.
	Note also Mru rai ``a species of rice'', Lushai ṭaiᶠ < traih (< *-s) ``species of early rice'' [Löffler 1966: 132]; the Lushai word has also been associate with WT kʰre ``millet'' (Sagart ms 2002: 8).
::WT	kʰre	``millet''
>:This etymon is close to {lì₂₁ 糲} *ras ``coarse grain'' and its possible cognates, both hail perhaps from the some foreign source. This word bài and {mǐ₁ 米} ``rice'' can on occasion be connected with the same foreign comparandum

ENTRY:64
HEAD:bān₁ 班
MC:Middle Chinese: pwan 
LH:Later Han: pan 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *prân
GLOSS:"To distribute" [BI, Shu] >
GLOSS:"spread out, scatter" [Zuo] >
GLOSS:"to arrange, classify" [Meng].
	[T] Sin Sukchu SR  pan (平)
	[T]  MGZY  ban (平) [pan]
	[E] ? ST *pral: WT ’pʰral-ba ``to separate, part'' ⪤ ’bral-ba ``be separated, lose'', WB praᴮ ``be divided into several parts, various'', JP pə³¹-ran³¹ ``be separate, sort out'' (for JP allofams, see {lí₁₀ 離}). In HST: 65, the WT item is associated with {bàn₂,biàn 釆}, and with {bàn₁ 半} by Bodman (1980: 147), while Karlgren (1933: 92f) combines all of these into one wf (no. 26-37).
	<> AA has an alternative comparandum which is semantically closer to OC, even the initial *p- could represent an AA trans. / caus. prefix: Khmer rāla /ríiəl/  intr. ``to spread, extend, distribute'' ⪤ brāla /príiəl/  tr. ``to spread''.
	A cognate is prob. *(C-)ral {lí₁₀ 離} *rai with the occasional ST *-l > OC *-i shift ({§8.3}). {bān₂ 斑} is perhaps the same word.
	For an overview over similar items, see {lí₁₀ 離} and {Table P-1} under {pī₃ 披}.
::JP	pə³¹-ran³¹	``be separate, sort out''
>:? ST *pral:

>:WB praᴮ ``be divided into several parts, various''
>:JP pə³¹-ran³¹ ``be separate, sort out'' . In HST:

ENTRY:76
HEAD:bàn₄ 瓣
MC:Middle Chinese: bănᶜ 
LH:Later Han: bɛnᶜ ?
GLOSS:"Petals of a flower" is a late word [14th cent. AD].
	The MC reading applies to the meaning ``sections of a fruit'' (under {bàn₂,biàn 釆}).
	In the QYS, the rimes ān  and -ăn seem to have been confused on occasion; therefore -ăn could also go back to *-rân.
	[E] ``Petals'' is possibly the same word as bàn 瓣 ``section of fruit'' (under {bàn₂,biàn 釆}). Alternatively, it could be the same etymon as {pā 葩} ``flowers, blossoms'' and prob. related to ``burn'' {fán₅ 燔}, note the WT word me-tʰog ``flower'', lit. ``fire-top''.
>:``Petals'' is possibly the same word as bàn 瓣 ``section of fruit'' . Alternatively, it could be the same etymon as {pā 葩} ``flowers, blossoms'' and prob. related to ``burn'' {fán₅ 燔}, note the WT word me-tʰog ``flower'', lit. ``fire-top''

HEAD:bāo₃ 剝

OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *prôk.
GLOSS:"To cut up, peel, pluck" [Shi].
	[D] Guǎngzhōu mɐk⁷ ``to peel'' (Sagart 1999: 80), Zhōngshān mɔk⁵⁵ ``to undress''.
	[E] Perhaps connected with MK, but the OC medial *r poses a problem: MK *pɔɔk ``to peel'' (Shorto 2006 #347) ⇒ Tai: S. pɔɔkᴰ¹ ``to peel''; note also PTai *dlɔɔk: S. lɔɔkᴰ² ``to skin, peel'' ⪤ plɔɔkᴰ¹ ``an encasement, slipcover, sheath'' (Manomaivibool 1975: 120). This word is thought to be related to {lù₁ 彔} ``carve'', but ``carve'' and ``peel'' are rather different procedures.
>:Perhaps connected with MK, but the OC medial *r poses a problem:
>:MK *pɔɔk ``to peel''  ⇒ Tai:
>:S. pɔɔkᴰ¹ ``to peel''
>:note also PTai *dlɔɔk:
>:S. lɔɔkᴰ² ``to skin, peel'' ⪤ plɔɔkᴰ¹ ``an encasement, slipcover, sheath'' . This word is thought to be related to {lù₁ 彔} ``carve'', but ``carve'' and ``peel'' are rather different procedures

ENTRY:86
HEAD:bǎo₁ 保
MC:Middle Chinese: pâuᴮ 
LH:Later Han: pouᴮ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *pûʔ
GLOSS:"To take care of" (a baby by wrapping it in swaddling cloth) [Meng], (people) [Shu];
GLOSS:"preserve, protect, maintain" [Shi].
	[T] Sin Sukchu SR paw (上)
	[T] MGZY baw (上) [paw]
	[E] Etymology not certain. Following Táng Lán, Qiu Xigui (2000: 212f) interprets an OB form of the graph as well as an occurrence in Shūjīng 17,10  as ``to carry (a baby) on the back'', thence ``take care of'' etc.; bǎo would then be the OC cognate of the TB items under {fù₁₁ 負}.
	However, in no textual occurrence, including Shūjīng, has bǎo the unequivocal meaning ``carry on the back''.
	Alternatively, this could be the s. w. as {bǎo₃ 寶} ``precious'' used in a putative sense, lit. ``consider something precious'', and then act accordingly.
	It is not clear if / how {bāo₁ 包} ``wrap, contain'', and WT pʰru-ma ``fortified camp, palace, fort'' (HST: 164) may be related.
::WT	pʰru-ma	``fortified camp, palace, fort''
>:Etymology not certain. Following Táng Lán
>:Qiu Xigui  interprets an OB form of the graph as well as an occurrence in Shūjīng 17,10  as ``to carry  on the back'', thence ``take care of'' etc.
>:bǎo would then be the OC cognate of the TB items under {fù₁₁ 負}

ENTRY:87
HEAD:bǎo₁ 保 = bǎo₁ 葆
MC:Middle Chinese: pâuᴮ 
LH:Later Han: pouᴮ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *pûʔ
	(What protects, shields:) ``secure'' (residence, land) 葆 [Shu]; ``fort, stronghold'' 保 [Li]; ``cover'' for a chariot 葆 [Lun Heng].

ENTRY:88
HEAD:bǎo₁ 保 = bǎo₁ 褓
MC:Middle Chinese: pâuᴮ 
LH:Later Han: pouᴮ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *pûʔ
GLOSS:"The cloth" (in which children are carried on the back) [Lüshih],
GLOSS:"swaddling cloth" [Liezi], used in the expression qiǎng bǎo 繈 or 襁褓 (qiǎng, MC kjaŋᴮ,
GLOSS:"string, cord", here prob. ``strap''); apparently bǎo refers to the protective swaddling cloth, not to the notion of carrying a baby on the back.

	Sagart (1999: 58) considers bǎo possibly related to fù 富 (under {fú₁₉ 福}).

	[E] CH ⇒ Tai-Wuming plønᶜ¹ ``volume'' (Bodman 1980: 108). If indeed the Wuming -l- should go back to OC, then the final -n  in běn would not be the result of the sound change ST *-l > OC *-n, but be the PCH nominal n-suffix attached to *pul ({§6.4.3}).

::WT	sbun ~ spun	``stalk of a plant''

>:OC *-n, but be the PCH nominal n-suffix attached to *pul

ENTRY:128
HEAD:bī₁ 屄
MC:Middle Chinese: pjie 4 < *pe,*pet
GLOSS:"Vulva", a late word which could, however, be old since such items are not mentioned in classical texts.
	[D] Mǐn: Amoy tsiᴬ¹-paiᴬ²
	[D] with final consonant Kèjiā: Dōngguān ³³tsiᴬ¹-²²petᴰ¹ 支北. Yuè dialects have ⁵⁵hɐiᴬ¹ (Guǎngzhōu) which is a Tai loan (Benedict LTBA 5.1, 1979), but apparently also found in some TB languages: Limbu hira ``vagina'', Tangkhul Naga hai.
	[E] ST *bet ?, PTB *b(y)et (HPTB: 375): PLB *b(y)etᴸ ``vulva'', Kanauri pʰɛːts; also Tamang and Baro pi-si [Benedict LTBA 5.1, 1979: 30; LTBA 14.1: 143-6; R. Bauer LTBA 14.1: 147-165]. Benedict [LTBA 14.2, 1991: 151] derives this etymon from a root ``hidden'', WT sbed-pa, sbas, sba ``to hide, conceal'', but a WT root with a as in sba does normally not correspond to one with vowel e / i in Chinese; see also {bì₁₂ 蔽}.
	[<] Derived from ``to open'' pì 闢 (under {pī₃ 披}), final *-t marks nouns of naturally occurring objects ({§6.2.1}), hence lit. ``opening''. Syn. {zhì₆ 膣}.
::WT	sbed-pa, sbas, sba	``to hide, conceal''
>:ST *bet ?
>:PTB *bet :
>:PLB *betᴸ ``vulva''
>:Kanauri pʰɛːts
>:also Tamang and Baro pi-si . Benedict  derives this etymon from a root ``hidden''
>:WT sbed-pa, sbas, sba ``to hide, conceal'', but a WT root with a as in sba does normally not correspond to one with vowel e / i in Chinese
>:see also {bì₁₂ 蔽}

ENTRY:130
HEAD:bí 鼻
MC:Middle Chinese: bjiet 4 Tang period: col.
	Shāzhōu *bir *bit
GLOSS:"Nose"
	[D] Mand. bízǐ 鼻子. This form in final *-t  is found in modern central and northern dialects as well as in the medieval Shāzhōu dialects in the NW, e.g.
	Gàn pʰitᴰ, Línchuān pʰitᴰ².
	Acc. to Baxter (1992: 319) this word may reflect an early loss of final *-s  (in *-ts, *-ks) which seems to have occurred in the northwest area; or it may reflect a dialectal change from earlier *-s to *-t (Pulleyblank JAOS 118.2, 1998: 204f).
	[E] Perh. cognate to WT sbrid-pa ``to sneeze'' (HST: 113), but CH has no trace of an r.
::WT	sbrid-pa	``to sneeze''
>:Perh. cognate to WT sbrid-pa ``to sneeze'' , but CH has no trace of an r

	[T] Sin Sukchu SR pi (上), PR pəj, LR pi
	[T] MGZY  bi (上) [pi]
	[T] MTang pɨ, ONW pii
	[<] endoactive of bì 比 *pih ({§4.5}).
	[E] ST: Lepcha bín ``follow closely, belong to, be with, be next to'' (Geilich ibid.); WT pʰyi ``behind, after'' ⪤ pʰyi-ma ``later, subsequently'' ⪤ pʰyid ``after, following'' ⪤ pʰyin ``later, afterwards''. The wf {bīn₂ 濱} either belongs to the same root, or two ST roots, *pi ``edge, outside'' and *pi ``next to, follow, after'' have partially converged in CH and WT.
::ST	roots, *pi	``edge, outside''

>:WT pʰyi ``behind, after'' ⪤ pʰyi-ma ``later, subsequently'' ⪤ pʰyid ``after, following'' ⪤ pʰyin ``later, afterwards''. The wf {bīn₂ 濱} either belongs to the same root, or two ST roots, *pi ``edge, outside'' and *pi ``next to, follow, after'' have partially converged in CH and WT

ENTRY:141
HEAD:bǐ₆ 筆
MC:Middle Chinese: pjet 3 
LH:Later Han: pɨt 
OCB:Baxter Old Chinese: *prjut
GLOSS:"Writing brush" [Li].
	[T] Sin Sukchu SR pi (入)
	[T] MGZY bue (入) [puɛ]
	[T] ONW pit
	[N] Baxter (1992: 280) reconstructs the OCB form on the basis of div. III chóngniǔ vocalism and the phonetic series which implies *-ut.
	[E] SW (Shuōwén jiězì gǔlín: 1271) says that bǐ is a word from the region of Qín 秦 (NW), and that in Chǔ 楚 the word is yù 聿 (jiuet) ONW iuit (?), in Wú 吳: bù-l  不律 (pjəu-ljuet) ONW pu-luit, and in Yān 燕 (NE) fú 弗 (pjuət) ONW put (discussed by Sagart ICSTLL 1990: 7). The word has been borrowed by Middle Korean (pwut), Old Japanese (pude), and Viet. bút (pre-Sino-Viet.) (Miyake 1997: 189, 192).
	All these data point to an initial cluster *pr-  or *pl-  and an OC rime *-ut.
	If derived from {lǐ₄ 理里} (ljɨᴮ) ``lines'' ⪤ WT ’bri-ba, bris ``to draw, write'' as is sometimes proposed, one needs to assume the loss of a PCH medial *w in the latter items.
	Benedict compares bǐ with PAN *bulut ``fiber'' (STC p. 178f).
	WT bir ``writing brush'' is a MC loan (MC final -t > WT -r).
	Baxter's OC form can be related to TB ones which are mentioned under {shuā 刷}.
	Perh. {fú₉ 拂} ``to brush off'' may belong here.
	For an overview of similar etyma, see {Table S-2} [ Brush, comb, scrape ] under {shuā 刷}.
::WT	bir	``writing brush''
>:SW  says that bǐ is a word from the region of Qín 秦 , and that in Chǔ 楚 the word is yù 聿  ONW iuit , in Wú 吳:
>:bù-l  不律  ONW pu-luit, and in Yān 燕  fú 弗  ONW put . The word has been borrowed by Middle Korean
>:Old Japanese , and Viet. bút

ENTRY:171
HEAD:bì₂₆ 篳
MC:Middle Chinese: pjiet 4 
LH:Later Han: pit 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *pit
GLOSS:"Fence, hedge" [SW],
GLOSS:"wicker door" (made with interlaced branches) [Zuo, Li]; 篳路
GLOSS:"fuel cart" (Giles) or ``wooden cart'' (Legge) [Zuo].
GLOSS-NOTE:The association with with {bì₂₄ 畢}
GLOSS:"wooden fork, hand-net" (which is prob. the s.w.) and with PLB *pyik
GLOSS:"thicket, jungle" (Bodman 1980: 158; HST: 148), is closer than Karglren's (1933: 94) association with {fú₁₁ 茀} ``screen, cover''.

ENTRY:172
HEAD:bì₂₇ 彃
MC:Middle Chinese: pjiet 4 
LH:Later Han: pit 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *pit

ENTRY:204
HEAD:bīn₂ 濱
MC:Middle Chinese: pjien 4 
LH:Later Han: pin 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *pin
GLOSS:"Shore, bank" [Shu].
	[E] ST: Lepcha bí ``edge, border'', lyaŋ bí ``utmost limit of a place''; WT pʰyi ``outside'' (including the notion ``at the outer edge'' as in pʰyi žiŋ ``the field outside'') ⪤ pʰyin ``outside''. The wf {bǐ₁ 比} either belongs to the same root, or two ST roots: *pi ``edge, outside'' and *pi ``next to, follow, after'' have partially converged in CH and WT. In either case, these nouns would be n-nominalizations of a stem *pi ({§6.4.3}).
	If there should be a connection with AN: PMal.-Pol. *te(m)biŋ ``bank, shore'' (Thurgood 1999:10), a substrate may possibly have influenced the semantic development of the CH item.
>:Lepcha bí ``edge, border'', lyaŋ bí ``utmost limit of a place''
>:WT pʰyi ``outside''  ⪤ pʰyin ``outside''. The wf {bǐ₁ 比} either belongs to the same root, or two ST roots:
>:*pi ``edge, outside'' and *pi ``next to, follow, after'' have partially converged in CH and WT. In either case, these nouns would be n-nominalizations of a stem *pi

ENTRY:212
HEAD:bīng₂ 冰 ⪤ líng 凌
MC:Middle Chinese: ljəŋ

OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *rəŋ 
OCB:Baxter Old Chinese: *b-rjəŋ
	[T] ONW liŋ
GLOSS:"Ice" [Shi].
	[E] If the connection between OCB prjəŋ and *b-rjəŋ is correct, then this wf could have come from AA, although the meanings are not very compelling: Khmer preṅa /preŋ/ ``to become hard, solid'' < -reṅa /-réeŋ/ ``to dry up'' [Jenner / Pou 1982: 269; 523] (there are many vocalic and other variants of this etymon). The unusual initial alternation p ~ r also speaks for a non-ST origin.
	OC *ə = Khmer /e/ has parallels.
>:If the connection between OCB prjəŋ and *b-rjəŋ is correct, then this wf could have come from AA, although the meanings are not very compelling:

	[T] ONW bėŋ
	[E] ? ST: Chepang bʰiŋ- ``be close together (as object, friends), double up''.
	A similar TB etymon may be related, but the medial *r is unexplained: Chepang breŋʔ- ``be close together, side by side'', WB hrañ ~ hyañ (< hriŋ or hreŋ) ``put together side by side'' ⪤ ə-hrañ ``a pair'', Lushai ṭʰiaŋᴴ / ṭʰianᴸ ``side by side (only of two), in a pair''.
	However, Lepcha byer, byăr ``be in juxtaposition'' ⪤ byek ``interval of time / space'' may belong to WT bar ``intermediate''.
::WT	bar	``intermediate''
>:Chepang bʰiŋ- ``be close together , double up''

ENTRY:228
HEAD:bō₂ 缽
MC:Middle Chinese: puât 
LH:Later Han: pɑt
	[T] ONW pɑt
GLOSS:"Alms bowl", also written with radical 金 [GY], or with an altogether different graph which acc. to GY, quoting the commentator Yán Shīgǔ 顏師古, occurs first in Hànshū. Bō derives from Skt. pātra which also has been loaned into Middle Korean (pali) and Old Japanese (pati) (Miyake 1997: 186).

ENTRY:230
HEAD:bó₁ 伯
MC:Middle Chinese: pɐk 
LH:Later Han: pak 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *prâk
GLOSS:"Be the eldest" (as father, brother, sister) [Shi],
GLOSS:"elder, lord, clan head" [Shi], a feudal title (``earl, count'') [BI], measure word for persons above commoners [BI]; later and in Mand.
GLOSS:"father's elder brother, uncle", in dialects also ``father'', as in Gàn-Wǔníng  pɑʔᴰ¹ (~ pɑᴬ¹).
	[T] Sin S. SR pəj (入), LR pəjʔ
	[T] MGZY bay (入) [paj]
	[T] ONW pëk
	[E] ? Area word: Mru rak, Kukish prak ``eldest brother'' (Löffler 1966: 140); LB-Lahu phâ ``god, lord'' <- Siam. pʰráʔ <- Khmer [Matisoff D. Lahu: 883]. Since Kuki-Chin languages have incorporated MK loans, this etymon may ultimately be AA. Among alternative proposals is derivation from {bái₁ 白} ``white'', hence bó ``the white-haired one'' (so Karlgren 1956: 10), note the semantics of {pó₃ 皤} ``white > white-haired'' – but this is prob. a folk etymology.
::Kukish	prak	``eldest brother''
>:? Area word:
>:Mru rak
>:Kukish prak ``eldest brother''
>:LB-Lahu phâ ``god, lord'' < - Siam. pʰráʔ < - Khmer . Since Kuki-Chin languages have incorporated MK loans, this etymon may ultimately be AA. Among alternative proposals is derivation from {bái₁ 白} ``white'', hence bó ``the white-haired one'' , note the semantics of {pó₃ 皤} ``white > white-haired'' – but this is prob. a folk etymology

	[D] PMin *p̆uoᴮ ``to mend'': Jiànyáng vio³ derives perhaps from a pre-nasalized initial (for the medial i in Jiànyáng, compare W-Wēnzhōu pəu⁴⁵), note Yao bia³ (< *nb-), PMY *npa² (Downer 1982) ``to patch, repair'' (Norman 1986: 382).

	[C] Perh. connected with {fú₂ 扶} ``assist''.

ENTRY:259
HEAD:bù₁ 不
MC:Middle Chinese: pjəuᴮ/ᶜ 
LH:Later Han: pu 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *pə 
OCB:Baxter Old Chinese: *pjə
	[T] ONW pu
GLOSS:"Not" [OB, Shi].
GLOSS-NOTE:The irreg.
	Mand. reading in b- (no dentilabial f-) belongs to the popular stratum, the regular development from QYS and OC is represented by fǒu 否 below.
	Although bù is the normal negative in literary Chinese from the OB down, it is now confined to Mand. dialects.
	In the OB, negatives with initial *p- negate actions which are beyond the control of living persons (Takashima 1996: 365ƒƒ).
	[E] <> Tai: S. bɔ(ɔ)ᴮ¹ < *ʔb- ``not'', Saek booᴮ¹ ``negative, no''.
	[C] Allofams: {fēi₁ 非}, {fěi₁ 匪棐}.
::Saek	booᴮ¹	``negative, no''
>:Tai:
>:S. bɔᴮ¹ < *ʔb- ``not''
>:Saek booᴮ¹ ``negative, no''

MC:Middle Chinese: pjəuᴮ etc. same word as above
GLOSS:"Not, be wrong" [OB, BI, Shi], same word as above. This is the expected Mand. reading of the negative 不 based on  QY pjəu(ᴮ/ᶜ).
	[T] Sin Sukchu SR fəw (上)
	[T] MGZY Hwuw (上) [fuw]

ENTRY:261
HEAD:bù₁ 不 ⪤ fú 弗
MC:Middle Chinese: pjwət 
LH:Later Han: put 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *pət
GLOSS:1:``Cannot, do not want to, not'' [OB, Shu] (DEZC p. 48; {§6.2.2}), later also
GLOSS:"resist".
GLOSS:2:``Not (verb) him / her / it'' [Shu], fusion of bù with the obj. pronoun zhī  之.
	[T] MTang pfur, ONW put. – The later forms for bù 不 in final -t really reflect this word: Sin Sukchu SR pu (入)
	[T]  MGZY bu (入) [pu].

ENTRY:262
HEAD:bù₂ 布
MC:Middle Chinese: puoᶜ 
LH:Later Han: pɑᶜ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *pâh
GLOSS:"Cloth" [BI, Shi].
	[T] Sin Sukchu SR pu (去)
	[T] MGZY bu (去) [pu]
	[T] ONW po
	[D] Min *pioᶜ (from poᶜ via pəoᶜ? This is the regular form up the coast in Wēnzhōu).
	[E] Prob. AA, but it could alternatively be the same etymon as ``spread out'' ({bù₃ 布}).
	A Han dyn. loan is jià-bù 幏布 < QYS ka(ᶜ)-puoᶜ ``cotton, cotton cloth'' from the ``Mán and Yí barbarians'' on the middle Yangtze River [SW, Hòu Hànshū]. A later loan (ca. 430 AD) is gǔ-bèi 古貝 ONW koᴮ-pɛiᶜ < -pɑs (Baxter, 1989: ``An AA word for cotton in Chinese'', Chicago Early China Conference).
	AA forms: *k-rn-paːs, e.g.: Khmer krɑbaah, Bahnar ko’paih (< -s), PVM *k-paːs (Ferlus), Chrau paih (< -s), Khasi kṇpʰaːt.
	<> Tai: S. pʰaaᶜ¹ < *pʰ- ``cloth'' (Li F. 1976: 46).
	From AA into ⇒ Skt. kārpāsaṁ ``cotton, cotton cloth'', ⇒ Greek kárpasos.
	In turn, bù may have been loaned into Middle Korean pwoy ``hemp cloth'' (Miyake 1997: 188).
::Korean	pwoy	``hemp cloth''
>:Prob. AA, but it could alternatively be the same etymon as ``spread out''

ENTRY:263
HEAD:bù₃ 布
MC:Middle Chinese: puoᶜ 
LH:Later Han: pɑᶜ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *pâh
	[T] ONW po
GLOSS:"To spread out" (a mat) [Li],
GLOSS:"display, announce, disperse" [Zuo].
GLOSS-NOTE:{bù₂ 布}
GLOSS:"cloth" is often thought to be the same word.
	[D] PMin *pyoᶜ ``set out'' (rice seedlings).
	[<] exoactive of a root *PA(ʔ) ({§4.3}).
	[E] ST: Lushai pʰaʔᴸ (< phah) ``to spread'' (as cloth), ``place flat on the ground''. CH ⇒ Tai: S. pu¹ ``to spread out, lay or stretch out (carpet)''.
::PMin	*pyoᶜ	``set out''
>:Lushai pʰaʔᴸ  ``to spread'' , ``place flat on the ground''. CH ⇒ Tai:
>:S. pu¹ ``to spread out, lay or stretch out ''

ENTRY:269
HEAD:bù₅ 哺
MC:Middle Chinese: buoᶜ 
LH:Later Han: bɑᶜ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *bâh
GLOSS:"Have food in the mouth" [Zhuang].
	[D] This is the Mǐn word for ``to chew'': PMin *boᶜ, but Jiàn’ōu piɔ⁴⁴ (prob. from *boᶜ via bəoᶜ).
	[<] endopass. of bū 餔 pɑ ``to eat'' ({§4.6}).
	[E] ST: PTB *wa (or *pa) ``bite, chew'' (STC no. 424; CVST I: 119; Weidert 1987: 138) > WB waᴮ ``to chew'', JP gə³¹-wa⁵⁵ ``to bite''.
	It is not clear if / how the following may be connected: Lushai baarᴴ ``to stuff food into one's own mouth'' ⪤ barʔ ``to stuff food into the mouth of another'' (tones?) (Unger Hao-ku  35, 1986: 34).
	Note also Tiddim Chin baːkᶠ / baʔᴸ ‘to feed forcibly (from baarh ?); and Khmer p̈ana / -pɑɑn/ ‘to feed by introducing premasticated or other food into the mouth of (infant, chick, etc.). ⇒ Tai /pɔ̂ɔn/.
::Lushai	baarᴴ	``to stuff food into one's own mouth''
>:PTB *wa  ``bite, chew''  >
>:WB waᴮ ``to chew''
>:JP gə³¹-wa⁵⁵ ``to bite''

ENTRY:273
HEAD:cái₁ 才材財
MC:Middle Chinese: dzậi 
LH:Later Han: dzə 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *dzə̂
GLOSS:"Be well endowed" [Shi],
GLOSS:"ability" 才 [Zuo];
GLOSS:"material, talent" 材 [Shu]; ``value'' 財 [BI, Shu].
	[T] Sin S. SR dzaj (平)
	[T] MGZY tsay (平) [dzaj]
	[T] ONW dzɑi (dzɛi ?)
	[E] Etymology not certain. Matisoff (1995: 42f) proposes cognation with PTB *(t)saːy ⪤ *(d)zaːy with the basic meaning ``property, livestock, talent''.
	The TB and OC vocalisms are difficult to reconcile, though; some of the TB words are here associated with {xī₁₁ 犀} ``rhinoceros''.
	Alternatively, cái may have an AA origin: Khmer ceḥ /ceh/ ``to know …, know how, be able'' ⪤ caṃṇeḥ /cɑmnèh/ ``knowledge … ability, competence, proficiency, aptitude, experience'' (there are other cases where Khmer /e/ = OC *ə).
	Most likely, this word is derived from ST *tsə ``come forth'' (as child, seedling, {zǐ₁ 子}); for the semantic connection between ``birth'' and ``natural characteristic / endowments'', compare {shēng₂ 生} ``give birth, live'' ⪤ {xìng₂ 性姓} ``what is inborn: one's inner nature; one's name''.
	Thus a WT cognate of cái is prob. mtsʰan ``name'' ⪤ mtsʰan(-ma)  ``shape and peculiar characteristics of separate parts of the body; genitals; mark, token, symptom'' (with the nominalizing n-suffix {§6.4.3}).
::ST	*tsə	``come forth''
>:Etymology not certain. Matisoff  proposes cognation with PTB *saːy ⪤ *zaːy with the basic meaning ``property, livestock, talent''

ENTRY:274

LH:Later Han: dzə 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *dzə̂
	[T] ONW dzɑi (dzɛi ?)
GLOSS:"Only when / at (time)" [Hou Hanshu].
GLOSS-NOTE:Matisoff (1995: 74f) suggests that this is cogn. to Lahu šā and šē.

	To the same stem may belong {cái₁ 才材財}, {zǐ₁ 子}.
	Alternatively, note WT tsʰod-ma ``vegetable'', the vocalic correspondence would be parallel to {cǎi₂ 采} ``color'' (see {§12.9[3]}).
::WT	tsʰod-ma	``vegetable''
>:Etymology not certain. Perh. from ST *tsə:
>:WT btsa ``fruit'', btsas ``harvest, to reap''
>:PLB *tsyakᴴ ``to pluck''

ENTRY:285
HEAD:cāng₂ 凔
MC:Middle Chinese: tṣʰjaŋᶜ,tsʰâŋ

OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *tshraŋ(h)

	[D] LH tsʰɑŋ is an old Wú dialect word in Shìshuō xīnyǔ
	[D] it is still used in Mǐn dialects: Fúzhōu tsʰeiŋᶜ¹, Xiàmén tsʰinᶜ¹, Jiànyáng tʰoiŋᶜ¹ ``cold (of weather)'' (Norman 1983: 207). Unrelated to {qìng₁ 凊} ``cold''.

ENTRY:286
HEAD:cāng₃ 蒼

GLOSS-NOTE:This may be an old dialect variant of {qīng₁ 青} (Baxter, JCLTA 19, 1983), note Mǐn tsʰaŋ for qīng 青 and its use for
GLOSS:"sky, heaven" in the ancient Yuè area (later Mǐn) of the Han period [Yuèjuè shū].
	In the form cāng-láng 蒼浪 / 狼 / 筤 (tsʰâŋ-lâŋ) the initial l- is the reduplicative syllable onset ({§2.7}).

ENTRY:300
HEAD:cè₄ 冊策筴
MC:Middle Chinese: tṣʰɛk 
LH:Later Han: tṣʰɛk 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *tshrek
	[T] ONW tṣʰëk
	(``Bamboo slips'':) ``to document, write down'' (on bamboo slips) [OB, BI, Shu] > n. ``document'' [BI], 策 [Zuo], ``book'' in M-Xiàmén lit. tsʰikᴰ¹, col. tsʰeʔᴰ¹; ``Achilea stalks used for divination'' (the radical implies bamboo 筴). Sagart (1999: 214) suggests a possible further connection with {jī₉ 積} ``collect, accumulate''.
	OTib. gtsigs ``document, official text, decree'' is perhaps a CH loan.

ENTRY:301
HEAD:cè₅ 簎
MC:Middle Chinese: tṣʰɐk 
LH:Later Han: tṣʰak 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *tshrâk
GLOSS:"To spear" (fish) 簎 [Zhouli],
GLOSS:"a kind of lance" 矠 [SW].
	[E] This is probably a vocalic variant of the synonym {chuō 擉} (tṣʰåk) [tṣʰɔk] *tshrok; note MK *cuk, *cuuk, *cuək, cak, *ciik, *c(i)ək ``to prod, pierce'' (Shorto 2006 #292) > OKhmer cāk /cak/ ``to pierce, stab, jab, ….'' For the CH retroflex initial, see {§5.10.3}. Variants or syn. are {chuō 擉}, {zé₆ 矠}.
>:This is probably a vocalic variant of the synonym {chuō 擉}   *tshrok
>:note MK *cuk, *cuuk, *cuək, cak, *ciik, *cək ``to prod, pierce''  >
>:OKhmer cāk /cak/ ``to pierce, stab, jab, ….'' For the CH retroflex initial, see {§5.10.3}. Variants or syn. are {chuō 擉}, {zé₆ 矠}

ENTRY:302

	{chán₂} 漸

ENTRY:303

	{zēng} 曾增

ENTRY:304
HEAD:chā₁ 叉
MC:Middle Chinese: tṣʰai,tṣʰa 
LH:Later Han: tṣʰɛ or tṣʰai 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *tshrê or *tshrâi
GLOSS:"A fork" [SW].
	[T] Sin Sukchu SR tʂ'a (平)
	[T] ONW tṣʰä
	[E] ? MK: The reference to the eastern end of the Yangtze River may support an AA connection: Khmer cēka /chaaɛk/ ``to be divided, split, cleft, forked, bifurcated, ….'' This AA etymon may also be represented in {xī₄ 析} ``split''. For the absence of final -k in CH, see {§6.9}.
	Alternatively, chā may be the s. w. as {chā₂ 差} ``divergence'' (< ``branch off''), but see there.
	The SW glosses the graph chā 叉 as ``crossing hands'', thereby implying a basic meaning ``branches crossing each other''; this suggests a connection with {cuò₃ 錯} ``crossing, mixing'', also JP gə³¹-tʃai⁵⁵ ``intersect''.
::JP	gə³¹-tʃai⁵⁵	``intersect''
>:The reference to the eastern end of the Yangtze River may support an AA connection:
>:Khmer cēka /chaaɛk/ ``to be divided, split, cleft, forked, bifurcated, ….'' This AA etymon may also be represented in {xī₄ 析} ``split''

ENTRY:305
HEAD:chā₁ 叉 ⪤ chà 杈

GLOSS:"branch" (Wáng Lì 1982: 440).

ENTRY:306
HEAD:chā₂ 差
MC:Middle Chinese: tṣʰa 
LH:Later Han: tṣʰai 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *tshrâi
GLOSS:"Divergence, difference, distinction" [Shu],
GLOSS:"mistake" [Xun] (cf. {cuò₄ 錯}
GLOSS:"mistake").
	[T] Sin Sukchu SR tʂ'a (平)
	[T] ONW tṣʰä (~ tṣʰëi)
	[E] The etymology is not clear, perhaps the s. w. as {chā₁ 叉} ``fork'', lit. ``branch off'' > ``diverge'', but the semantic field of this wf points in a different direction (``graduated'').
	[E] Or perhaps AA: Khmer cāya /caaj/ ``give out, scatter, disperse'' ⪤ OKhmer /cŋaaj/ ``be separated, apart, far away, be different''.
	Or ST: WT sre-ba ``to mix with, mingle''.
	[C] Allofams are perhaps {chá₃ 察} ``examine'', and {cuō₃,chī 𪙉} ``uneven teeth''.
::WT	sre-ba	``to mix with, mingle''
>:The etymology is not clear, perhaps the s. w. as {chā₁ 叉} ``fork'', lit. ``branch off'' > ``diverge'', but the semantic field of this wf points in a different direction
>:Or perhaps AA:
>:Khmer cāya /caaj/ ``give out, scatter, disperse'' ⪤ OKhmer /cŋaaj/ ``be separated, apart, far away, be different''

ENTRY:311
HEAD:chá₁ 茶
MC:Middle Chinese: ḍa 
LH:Later Han: ḍa 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *d-lâ
GLOSS:"Tea" [Han period].
	[T] Sin Sukchu SR  dʐa (平)
	[T] ONW dä
	[E] Sagart (1999: 188) suggests that chá is a loan from Loloish (TB) *la ``leaf, tea'', PLB *s-la ``leaf / tea'' (HPTB: 48), as tea may have originated in Sìchuān (Lolo area); this word has wider distribution, also in Zhuang (Tai) la⁴ means ``tea'', the ultimate source seems to be PAA *sla ``leaf''. Alternatively, Qiu Xigui (2000: 326) considers ``tea'' with its bitter leaves a semantic extansion of tú 荼 ``name of a bitter plant'' (Sonchus oleraceus).
::Xigui	considers	``tea''
>:Sagart  suggests that chá is a loan from Loloish  *la ``leaf, tea''
>:PLB *s-la ``leaf / tea'' , as tea may have originated in Sìchuān
>:this word has wider distribution, also in Zhuang  la⁴ means ``tea'', the ultimate source seems to be PAA *sla ``leaf''. Alternatively
>:Qiu Xigui  considers ``tea'' with its bitter leaves a semantic extansion of tú 荼 ``name of a bitter plant''

ENTRY:312
HEAD:chá₂ 槎

ENTRY:321
HEAD:chái₃ 儕
MC:Middle Chinese: dẓăi
	The graph is used to write the Mǐn dial. word for ``many'': PMin *d̯zeᶜ > Yǒngān tseᶜ¹, Jiànyáng laiᶜ², Fúzhōu saᶜ², Amoy tsueᶜ².
	Yue Hashimoto (CAAAL 6, 1976: 1) relates this word to Tai: Zhuang (Lóngzhōu) laːiᴬ¹ ``many'' < PTai *hlaiᴬ¹.
	The Tai word is related to {duō 多}.

ENTRY:322
HEAD:chài 蠆

LH:Later Han: ṭʰas 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *rhâ(t)s

GLOSS:"walk" suggests that the OC initial was *rh- rather than a dental stop.
	[<] Chài is derived from {lì₁₅ 厲} ``sharp'' with the nominalizing ST s- / aspiration ({§5.2.4}); there may also be a connection with zhé 蜇 (ṭjät) LH ṭiat, *trat (?) ``to sting'' [Liezi].

ENTRY:348
HEAD:cháng₅ 場
MC:Middle Chinese: ḍjaŋ 
LH:Later Han: ḍɑŋ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *d-laŋ
GLOSS:"Vegetable garden, a (pounded) threshing area" [Shi 154, 7 etc.]; this word also means
GLOSS:"meadow" (in the mountains) [BI] (related?).
	[E] Etymology not certain, perhaps ST: WT ra-ba ``enclosure, fence, wall, yard, courtyard, pen'', and related to {zhù₁,chú 宁} [ḍɨɑ(ᴮ)]; for the initials see {§7.1.4}, for the finals see {§6.5.2}. The basic meaning would then be an ``enclosed area or yard''.
	Shī Xiàngdōng (2000: 32) relates cháng to WT tʰaŋ ``high plain'', but see {chǎng 敞}.
::WT	tʰaŋ	``high plain''
>:Etymology not certain, perhaps ST:
>:WT ra-ba ``enclosure, fence, wall, yard, courtyard, pen'', and related to {zhù₁,chú 宁}
>:for the initials see {§7.1.4}, for the finals see {§6.5.2}. The basic meaning would then be an ``enclosed area or yard''

	WT gžaŋ (< *gryaŋ? *glyaŋ?) ``anus'' prob. belongs to {gāng₆ 肛} ``lower intest., anus''.

ENTRY:359
HEAD:chē 車
MC:Middle Chinese: tśʰja 
LH:Later Han: tśʰa 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *k-hla
GLOSS:"Chariot" [OB, BI, Shi] >
GLOSS:"wheel" as in fǎng-chē 紡車
GLOSS:"spinning wheel".
	[T] Sin Sukchu SR tʂ'je (平)
	[T] MGZY chÿa (平) [tʂ'jɛ]
	[T] ONW tśʰa
	[D] PMin *tšʰia
	[D] in some southern dialects ``to mill'', e.g. Y-Guǎngzhōu tsʰɛ⁵³-mɐi¹³ 車米 ``mill rice''.
	[E] Horse and chariot were introduced into China around 1200 BC from the west (Shaughnessy HJAS 48, 1988: 189-237). Therefore, this word is prob. a loan, apparently from an IE language (V. Mair, EC 15, 1990: 45ƒƒ; Robert Bauer, Sino-Platonic Papers 47, 1994): Toch.
	A kukäl, Tocharian_B kokale, note Greek kýkla or kýkloi (``wheels'':) ``wagon'' [Pokorny IG etym. Wörterbuch I: 640]; an older variant survives in Northern Mand. gū-lū ``wheel'' (so Bauer).
	Alternatively, acc. to Baxter / Sagart (1998: 48) chē is a derivation by k-prefix from {yú₁₁ 舁譽} ``lift up'' ({§5.4}); note the WT semantic parallel tʰeg-pa ``vehicle, carriage, riding beast'' < id. ``to lift, raise, hold, support''.
::WT	semantic parallel tʰeg-pa	``vehicle, carriage, riding beast''
>:Horse and chariot were introduced into China around 1200 BC from the west . Therefore, this word is prob. a loan, apparently from an IE language :
>:Toch

ENTRY:360
HEAD:chē 車 ~ jū 車
MC:Middle Chinese: kjwo 
LH:Later Han: kɨɑ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *ka
	[T] ONW kio ? > kø
GLOSS:"Chariot" (a piece in a chess game), lit. for
GLOSS:"carriage" (as in Tang poetry: Branner T’ang Studies 17, 2000: 44).
	For a similar phonological doublet, note {chǔ₃ 處} ~ {jū₂ 居}.
	Different readings of 車 are discussed by Baxter (1992: 480; 862 n. 356).
	Shìmíng states that the reading in MC -jwo is the older one; this is prob. based on a scribal error in a Shījīng version (Baxter 1992: 360; 480).
	On the other hand, Baxter points out that therefore the reading MC kjwo may be a lexicographical ghost, while a reading MC kʰjwo mentioned in JDSW seems closer to MC tśʰja with its aspiration.
	However, MC kjwo has enjoyed to this day general currency while MC kʰjwo is unknown apart from this sound gloss.
	[C] Possible allofam {kù₁ 庫}.

ENTRY:361
HEAD:chè₁ 坼
	{chǐ₁} 拸

ENTRY:362
HEAD:chè₂ 徹撤
MC:Middle Chinese: ḍjät,ṭʰjät 
LH:Later Han: ḍat,ṭʰat 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *drat,*thrat 
OCB:Baxter Old Chinese: *thrjet
	[T] ONW tʰat
GLOSS:"To remove, take away, clear away" 徹 [BI, Shi], 撤 [Lunyu].
	[<] r-causative of shì 逝 ({§7.5}) (Sagart 1999: 111). This word looks like a derivation from {chú₂ 除} [ḍiɑ] ``remove'' with a t-suffix ({§6.2.2}). However, the phonetic of 徹撤 implies a T-like initial consonant whereas the phonetic of 除 implies an L-like initial ({§12.1.2}).

ENTRY:370
HEAD:chén₂ 沈
MC:Middle Chinese: ḍjəm 
LH:Later Han: ḍim 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *d-ləm
GLOSS:"To sink" [Shi],
GLOSS:"submerged" [Guoce],
GLOSS:"submerge" something as a sacrifice [OB] > ``put poison in liquid'' [Zhouli]; ``deep'' [Zhuang] (~ Chuci {zhàn₁ 湛} [ḍɛmᴮ] *drə̂mʔ ``deep''). Acc. to Downer (1959: 282), the intr. ``to sink'' is read in tone A, while the causative ``to drown, immerse'' [Zuo] is read in tone C acc. to ancient commentators.
	[T] Sin Sukchu SR dʐim (平), PR, LR dʐin
	[T] MGZY chim (平) [dʐim]
	[T] ONW dim
	[<] derived from {yín₃ 淫} *ləm; the OC initial may have been *rl- as Baxter suggests; note the Khmer form below.
	[E] Area etymon: MK *ləm, *ləəm ``to sink'' (Shorto 2006 #1403): Khmer ralāṃ /rloəm/ ``be soaked, drenched, drowned''. Katuic *[s/c]əlim, *[t/d]əlɨm ``to sink''. PMonic *[_]ləm ``to immerse sth.'' > OMon tulum ``to drown'' (oneself) , Mon *kəla̱ə̯m, Nyah-Kur *chələ̤m; Mon tanim ``be inundated'', Mon tinlum ``to sink''  [Diffloth 1984: 221]. <> TB: Chepang: klyum- ``submerge, be hidden'' ⪤ klyumʔ- ``bury, submerge, cover''.
	[C] Allofams are prob. {yín₃ 淫}, and perhaps {chěn₂ 瀋沈} ``a liquid'', {hán₄ 涵}, {zhàn₁ 湛}. Similar looking word in final -m include: {dān₅ 耽湛}, {jiān₉ 熸}, {jiān₈ 漸瀸湛}, {lín₃ 淋霖}, {shēn₃ 深}, {zhān₂ 沾霑}, {zhēn₂ 斟}, {rǎn₁ 染}.
	Languages in the area have  similar words, but they are difficult to match with potential OC relations:
	AA: PNBahn. *krăm, PSBahn. *kəram ``sink''.
	AA: Khmer /srə̀m/ ``to sink slowly into water, drop slowly out of sight''.
	AA: PMonic *hoom ``to take a bath'' ⪤ caus. *p-hoom ``bathe, wash''; PVM *tʰămᴮ ``bathe'' [Thompson], perhaps PSBahn. *ʔum ``bathe''.
	KT: Saek ramᴬ² ``be wet'' (⪤ ramᴬ¹ ``black''); PKS *ʔram¹ ``sink''.
	Tai čʰumᴮ¹ ``wet'', čumᴮ¹ ``soak, immerse''; Lóngzhōu tumᴬ² ``wet''.
	TB: WT tʰim-pa ``disappear, being absorbed, evaporate, be melted, to sink'' (e.g. into unconsciousness) ⪤ stim-pa, bstims ``to enter, penetrate, be absorbed''.
	TB: Chepang ɉyomʔ- ``to sink in, be pressed down''.
::Chepang	ɉyomʔ-	``to sink in, be pressed down''
>:Area etymon:
>:MK *ləm, *ləəm ``to sink'' :
>:Khmer ralāṃ /rloəm/ ``be soaked, drenched, drowned''. Katuic *əlim, *əlɨm ``to sink''. PMonic *ləm ``to immerse sth.'' >
>:OMon tulum ``to drown''
>:Mon *kəla̱ə̯m
>:Nyah-Kur *chələ̤m
>:Mon tanim ``be inundated''
>:Mon tinlum ``to sink''  . < > TB:
>:Chepang:
>:klyum- ``submerge, be hidden'' ⪤ klyumʔ- ``bury, submerge, cover''

LH:Later Han: tśʰɨŋ

	[T] ONW tśʰiŋ
GLOSS:"To lift, raise, set forth, display" [OB, BI, Shu].
GLOSS-NOTE:``To weigh'' {chēng₂ 稱}.

ENTRY:394
HEAD:chéng₅ 裎
MC:Middle Chinese: ḍjäŋ 
LH:Later Han: ḍeŋ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *dreŋ
GLOSS:"Naked" [Meng].
	[E] This is prob. related to Mikir -reŋᴸ angseᴴ ``naked'', WT sgren-mo ``naked'' (WT rǰen ``naked'' is a dialectal backform: Beyer 1992: 146), JP krin³¹ ``naked'', Lushai ṭeenᴿ  ``be bare'' (as a hill side) (Unger Hao-ku 38, 1992: 82). This word could ultimately belong to {luǒ₂ 裸}, all based on a ST root *roi; see {Table L-1} [ Naked, red ] for an overview of related and similar etyma. A derivation is {chēng₁ 赬} ``red'' (so Karlgren 1933: 69) as ``naked'' is associated with ``red''.

ENTRY:400
HEAD:chī₂ 吃
	(?)  Sin Sukchu SR k'i (入) LR tʂ'iʔ; MGZY khi (入) [k'i]
GLOSS:"To eat" [Xīnshū 新書, spurious?], has been since the 18th cent. the ordinary Mand. word for
GLOSS:"to eat" [Kāngxī zìdiǎn, Hóng Lóu Mèng] (Sino-Platonic Papers 98, Jan. 2000: 75ƒƒ). Phonetically the MC form does not agree with Mand., nor does the alleged older variant graph {chī₃ 喫}.
	Etymology therefore unknown, perhaps it is the same word as ``stutter'' (``eat one's sounds''?) (Norman 1988: 76, n. 6).

ENTRY:401
HEAD:chī₃ 喫
MC:Middle Chinese: kʰiek
	[T] MTang kʰɨk ONW kʰėk
GLOSS:"To eat" 喫 [ONW, Yupian], said to be a variant graph for {chī₂ 吃}, etymology unknown; neither 喫 nor 吃 can be connected with Mand. chī phonetically (Norman 1988: 76, n. 6).

ENTRY:402
HEAD:chī₄ 魑离螭
MC:Middle Chinese: ṭʰjie 
LH:Later Han: ṭʰɑi 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *rhai
GLOSS:"Mountain demon" 离 [SW], 魑 [Zuo], 螭 [Lü] occurs in texts only in the compound chī-mèi 魑魅; chī has been extensively discussed by Carr (LTBA 13.2: 136ƒƒ.).
	[E] ST: WT ’dre < ɴdre ``goblin, demon, evil spirit'' ⪤ gre-bo / -mo ``species of demon''; KN *t/s-rai [IST: 23]: Tangkhul raiᴴ ``unclean spirit'', Bodo ráj ``devil''. This is distinct from WT sri, Lushai hriᶠ ``evil spirit which causes sickness''.
	Note also PKS *laːi⁴ ``devil, ghost'' which may be a CH loan because of the initial *l-.
::PKS	*laːi⁴	``devil, ghost''
>:WT ’dre < ɴdre ``goblin, demon, evil spirit'' ⪤ gre-bo / -mo ``species of demon''

>:Bodo ráj ``devil''. This is distinct from WT sri

ENTRY:411
HEAD:chǐ₁ 拸
MC:Middle Chinese: ṭʰjeᴮ 
LH:Later Han: ṭʰɑiᴮ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *rhaiʔ
	[T] ONW tʰe
GLOSS:"To cleave, separate, take away" [OB, Zhuang].
	The original graph 多 shows two separate pieces of meat, hence ``separate'', although the conventional interpretation of the graph is ``2 pieces of meat'' = ``many''.
	Since 多 occurs already in the earliest OB, but only as a loan for {duō 多} ``many, all'', the donor word ``cleave, separate'' must already have existed at the beginning of writing.
	[E] ST: WT ral ``rent, cleft'' ⪤ ral-ba ``torn'' (clothes) ⪤ ’dral-ba, dral / ral ``to rip up, tear to pieces'' ⪤ hral-ba ``to rent, tear up'' ⪤ sgral-ba ``to cut to pieces''.
>:WT ral ``rent, cleft'' ⪤ ral-ba ``torn''  ⪤ ’dral-ba, dral / ral ``to rip up, tear to pieces'' ⪤ hral-ba ``to rent, tear up'' ⪤ sgral-ba ``to cut to pieces''

ENTRY:415

	For a listing of similar words and possible allofams, see {lí₁₀ 離}.

ENTRY:416

	WT čʰe-ba, čʰen-po ``great'' < *te (HST: 88) seems to be a different etymon; chǐ₃ 侈 may be the s. w. as {chǐ₁ 拸} ``to ‘separate''.

ENTRY:421
HEAD:chǐ₅ 恥
MC:Middle Chinese: ṭʰɨᴮ 
LH:Later Han: ṭʰəᴮ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *nhrəʔ ? 
OCB:Baxter Old Chinese: *hnrjəʔ
	[T] MTang tśʰi ONW tʰiə
GLOSS:"Shame" [Shi],
GLOSS:"disgrace" [Zuo].
GLOSS-NOTE:Pulleyblank (1973: 121) relates chǐ to words meaning
GLOSS:"shame" with initial *n- and different rimes, see {xiū₃ 羞}.
	Psychologists tend to associate ``guilt'' often with auditory admonition (Eberhard (1967: 12), therefore {ěr₁ 耳} ``ear'' is possibly not only part of the graph for mental association, but chǐ may even be cognate to ``ear''.
	For the *r in the OC initial, note the *r- prefix in TB lgs; MC ṭʰj- derives from a complex initial nasal cluster also in chǒu 丑.

	[D] PMin *kʰiᴮ¹ ~ tʃʰɨᴮ¹
	[E] The etymology is not clear; chǐ is not related to WT mčʰe-ba ``canine tooth'', see {diān₃ 齻} ``eyetooth'', but may be the same word as PMin *kʰiᴮ ``tooth''. An AA etymon for ``tooth'' looks vaguely similar: e.g.
	Khmer khnae ``tusk, spur'' (Shorto 1971: 85), Mon inscr. gnis > gnih ``eyetooth, canine'' (AA medial n often disappears in CH).

ENTRY:425
HEAD:chì₃ 赤
MC:Middle Chinese: tśʰjäk 
LH:Later Han: tśʰak 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *k-hlak 
OCB:Baxter Old Chinese: *KHjAk
	[T] ONW tśʰek
GLOSS:"Red" [BI, Shi] is from earliest times the basic term for
GLOSS:"red" (Baxter JCLTA 1983), rivaled only by {zhū₁ 朱}. The OC initial is suggested by *hl- in the phon. series.
	<> Tai: S. tʰɨakᴰ¹ ``red'' may be a pre- or early Han loan.
	[D] PMin *tsʰiak
	[E] Etymology not clear. The phonetic series implies an OC L-like initial, also the graph 赤 writes a word ``expel'' with incontrovertible OC *l- ({shě₂ 舍捨}).
	There are no TB comparanda with a close phonological fit; one could cite WT kʰrag ``blood'' (HST: 123) which is here associated with {hè₄ 赫}; or PTB *tsyak = *tśak ``red'' (cognate acc. to STC no. 184; p. 168 n. 452), Lushai čak ``red'', as well as the TB items under {hè₄ 赫} ``red'' with which it may possibly be connected.
	Perh. the following word may be related; like chì₃ 赤, it had apparently a complex initial cluster in OC:
::Lushai	čak	``red''
>:Etymology not clear. The phonetic series implies an OC L-like initial, also the graph 赤 writes a word ``expel'' with incontrovertible OC *l-

ENTRY:427
HEAD:chì₄ 翅
MC:Middle Chinese: śjeᶜ 
LH:Later Han: śeᶜ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *lheh ?
GLOSS:"Wing" [Guoce].
	[T] Sin Sukchu SR tʂ’ʅ, ʂi (去), PR ʂʅ, LR tʂ’ʅ
	[T] MGZY shi (去) [ʂi]
	[T] MTang śi, kie (?)
	[N] The Mand. form is apparently derived from MC śjeᶜ with irregularly affricated initial. Mǐn kʰek  may suggest an OC velar element in the initial.
	The origins and connections between the disparate forms are obscure (GSR 864). ``Leaf'' {yè₄ 葉} can apparently also mean ``wing'' in some dialects.

ENTRY:432
HEAD:chōng₃ 舂

ENTRY:433

ENTRY:440
HEAD:chōu₁ 盩抽
MC:Middle Chinese: ṭʰjəu 
LH:Later Han: ṭhʰu 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *thru or *t-hlu ?
	[T] MTang ṭʰeu < ṭʰu ONW tʰu
GLOSS:"Take out, pull out, remove" (e.g. draw weapons, remove thorns from a branch) 抽 [Shi],
GLOSS:"pull out (liver)" 盩 [Lü].
	[C] 盩 is said to be the older graph for the word (ZWDCD 6: 1032); accordingly 抽 is apparently a later simplified way of writing chōu. OCM could therefore have been either *thru, or a rare *t-hlu or the like which the phonetic may imply. 盩 zhōu (ṭjəu) *tru is the reading for the name of a county.
	[E] An outside connection is not certain. If OCM were *t-hlu, the word could be related to Chepang klu- ``pull out'' (hair) ⪤ glu- ``pull out (larger) weeds, cultivate crop'' ⪤ blu- ``remove, root out''.
	<> Tai: S. tʰa-lokᴰ¹ ``id.'' (Manomaivibool 1975: 149, but the Tai final stop is unexplained).
	<> Alternatively, if OCM were *thru, the word could be compared to MK *tɗus, *tɗuəs ``to pull out, off, back'' (Shorto 2006 #1904a) which is however not widely represented in the MK family.
	It is possible that a MK post-initial dental stop is reflected in OC as a medial *r, but the MK final *s should have left a trace in OC.
::MK	*tɗus, *tɗuəs	``to pull out, off, back''
>:An outside connection is not certain. If OCM were *t-hlu, the word could be related to Chepang klu- ``pull out''  ⪤ glu- ``pull out  weeds, cultivate crop'' ⪤ blu- ``remove, root out''

ENTRY:441

LH:Later Han: ṭʰu,leu 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *rhiu,*riû
GLOSS:"To improve, get cured, recover" [OB, BI, Shi],
GLOSS:"harm" [Guoyu] is prob. cognate to {liào₃ 療樂}.

ENTRY:442

OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *k-hu

::WB	hru	``breathe, draw into the nose, mouth''
>:The basic meaning of this etymon is ``breathe in'':
>:WB huik ``pant, be out of breath''
>:it is not clear if or how WB hru ``breathe, draw into the nose, mouth'' ⪤ hruik  ``draw into lungs with protracted effort'' are related

ENTRY:447
HEAD:chóu₃ 儔
MC:Middle Chinese: ḍjəu 
LH:Later Han: ḍu 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *dru
	(``Counterpart'':) ``mate, companion'' [Shu], (``equal items'':) ``class, category'' [Shu], ``equal'' [Guiguzi]. Syn. qiú 仇 (gjəu) ``mate, companion, antagonist'' [Shi].
	[E] ST: WT do ``two, a pair, a couple, an equal, match, companion, mate'' ⪤ dod ``an equivalent'', WB tu ``be like, similar'' (CVST 2: 14). On the other hand, note PWMiaoA ntrau⁶ ``husband, lover''.
::PWMiaoA	ntrau⁶	``husband, lover''
>:WT do ``two, a pair, a couple, an equal, match, companion, mate'' ⪤ dod ``an equivalent''
>:WB tu ``be like, similar'' . On the other hand, note PWMiaoA ntrau⁶ ``husband, lover''

ENTRY:448
HEAD:chóu₃ 儔 ⪤ chóu 讎
MC:Middle Chinese: źjəu 
LH:Later Han: dźu 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *du
	[T] MTang źeu < dźu ONW dźu
	(``To counter'':) ``to pay back, reply, opponent, enemy'' [Shi]; ``pledge with wine a second time'' 酬 [Shi], ``requite'' 醻 [Shu], ``recompense with gifts'' 酬 [Zuo].
	[E] ST: Lushai doᴴ ``be at enmity with, be hostile'', doᴴ ``to counter contributions …''; but Lushai ``be at enmity with'' may equally well belong to {dòu₆ 鬥} ``quarrel''.
>:Lushai doᴴ ``be at enmity with, be hostile'', doᴴ ``to counter contributions …''
>:but Lushai ``be at enmity with'' may equally well belong to {dòu₆ 鬥} ``quarrel''

ENTRY:454
HEAD:chǒu₁ 丑
MC:Middle Chinese: ṭʰjəuᴮ 
LH:Later Han: ṭʰuᴮ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *thruʔ or *rhuʔ ? 
OCB:Baxter Old Chinese: *hnrjuʔ
	Cyclical sign for ``ox'' [OB].
	[E] MK (Mei 1980; Norman 1985: 87): PVM *c-luː > kluː / tluː ``buffalo'' > Viet. trâu [ṭəw]. For the *l > *r shift, see {§7.3}.
	However, a different MK synonym seems to be a closer fit for OC, although it enjoyed no wide distribution: *ruuk ``ox'' (Shorto 2006 #396): Biat nɗroːk (< kuən ruuk by contraction).
	The meaning ``ox'' has been obsolete since the beginning of writing, but {láo₁ 牢} ``calf'' may belong to the same root. 丑 is the original graph for ``claw, finger'' {niǔ₁ 狃丑}.
>:MK :
>:PVM *c-luː > kluː / tluː ``buffalo'' >
>:Viet. trâu

ENTRY:455

GLOSS:"foul" (under {chōu₃ 犨}), also in its meaning

ENTRY:461
HEAD:chū₂ 出
MC:Middle Chinese: tśʰjuət 
LH:Later Han: tśʰut
	[T] ONW tśʰuit
GLOSS:"Nephew, sister's son" [EY] is related to PTB *tu ~ *du
GLOSS:"nephew" (STC: 158). A word with initial *t- could prob. be written with a graph which earlier represented a cluster *kl- (chū₂ 出).
	Sagart 1999: 167f derives this word from {chū₁ 出} ``come out'' in the sense of ``be born'' which would be parallel to {shēng₃ 甥} ``nephew''.

ENTRY:465
HEAD:chú₂ 除
MC:Middle Chinese: ḍjwo 
LH:Later Han: ḍɑ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *d-la
GLOSS:"To remove, clear out" tr. [Zuo, Hanshu].
	[T] Sin S. SR dʐy (平)
	[T] MGZY cÿu (平) [dʐy]
	[T] MTang ḍy < ḍø
	[T] ONW dø < dio (?)
	[D] M-Xiàmén lit. duᴬ²
	[<] r-caus. of shū 抒 (dźjwoᴮ) ({§7.5}).
	[E] Perh. an area etymon: WT ’dag-pa ``clear away, remove'' (HST: 124). <> AA: Khmer ṭaka /dɑɑk/ ``to pull or wrench out, uproot'' ⪤ raṭaka /rdɑɑk/ ``be pulled or torn out … removed''.
	Alternatively, cognation with WB hraᴮ ``remove out of the way'' is phonologically also possible.
	The AA forms may be closer to OC because of the r-affix and the loss of final consonant after long vowel ({§6.9}).
	A derivation with t-suffix may be {chè₂ 徹撤} ``remove'', but that is doubtful.
::WB	hraᴮ	``remove out of the way''
>:Perh. an area etymon:
>:WT ’dag-pa ``clear away, remove'' . < > AA:
>:Khmer ṭaka /dɑɑk/ ``to pull or wrench out, uproot'' ⪤ raṭaka /rdɑɑk/ ``be pulled or torn out … removed''

ENTRY:477
HEAD:chù₁ 觸
MC:Middle Chinese: tśʰjwok 
LH:Later Han: tśʰok 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *tʰok
	[T] ONW tśʰuok
GLOSS:"To butt" [Yi],
GLOSS:"knock against" [Zuo].
	[D] Mǐn Xiàmén lit. tsʰiokᴰ¹, col. tsʰikᴰ¹
	[E] ST *tok WT tʰogs-pa ``to strike, stumble, run against'', Lushai tɔɔkᴴ ``to knock (against)'', Mikir tòk- ``to strike, beat''.
	TB parallel stem with initial affricate: Mikir chòk ``beat, hit, strike'' (STC: 53), WT ’tsʰogs-pa ``to hew, chop'', note also Kuki-Naga *tsjuk ``knock against''.
	Further cognates and/or parallel stems are listed in {Table C-1}.
	Li F. (1976: 41) associates Tai-S. tʰuukᴰ¹ᴸ < *tʰ- ``right, cheap, to touch'' with chù₁ 觸, but the S. word is only in its last sense a loan from ST ({zhù₇ 注} ``touch''), while ``right, cheap'' belongs with WB tʰuik ``be worth, have a certain value, be worthy, be fit'' and with Mon tʰɔik ``be good, right''.
::Mon	tʰɔik	``be good, right''
>:ST *tok WT tʰogs-pa ``to strike, stumble, run against''
>:Lushai tɔɔkᴴ ``to knock ''
>:Mikir tòk- ``to strike, beat''

ENTRY:478
HEAD:chù₂ 絀

OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *trut
GLOSS:"Bend" [Xun].

ENTRY:480

	[E] Etymology not clear, but prob. ST: PTB *hu ``rear, raise, nourish'': PLB *hu³, Abor-Miri u, Qiang (Mawo) χu [HPTB: 58]. Perh. related to {hǎo 好}.
	Alternative affiliation:
	ST: JP kruʔ⁵⁵ < kruk⁵⁵ ``to sprout'', kʰruŋ³³ ``be alive'', WT ’kʰruŋ-ba ``be born, come up, to sprout'' (HPTB: 285).
	See {Table C-2} [ Birth, sprout, nourish ] for synonyms.
	Zhengzhang relates WT lug ``sheep'' to this word (Sagart 1999: 195), this would be parallel to {yáng₁ 羊} ``sheep'' ? ⪤ {yǎng₂ 養} ``raise''; however, WT lug is prob. related to {dú₆ 犢}. ◇

ENTRY:481
HEAD:chù₄,xù 畜 ⪤ chù,xù 畜

ENTRY:482
HEAD:chuān₁ 川
MC:Middle Chinese: tśʰjwän 
LH:Later Han: tśʰuan ~ tśʰon 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *k-hlun
GLOSS:"River" [BI, Shi].
	[E] Area word: PTB *kluːŋ (STC no. 127) > WT kluŋ ``river''; Kachin kruŋ ``valley, dale'', OBurm. kʰloŋ [IST: 353], WB kʰyuiŋᴮ ``stream''; perhaps also Lushai luaŋᴴ / luanᴸ < luaŋ / luanh (< luaŋs) ``to flow'' (water, river) (so Unger Hao-ku 50, 1995: 156). This etymon may ultimately be connected with {jiāng₁ 江} (*kruŋ ~ *kluŋ?).
	Like OC, PWa has both forms for ``river'': *klɔŋ ``river'' and *krɔŋ ``large river, sea''.
	STC (p. 131f. n. 129) suggests that the WT root may be separate from the AA one, and considers it to be a variant of shuǐ 水 ``water, river''.
	<> Tai: S. kʰlɔɔŋᴬ² ``canal'' is unrelated, see {táng₁ 唐}.
::Lushai	luaŋᴴ / luanᴸ < luaŋ / luanh 	``to flow''
>:Area word:
>:PTB *kluːŋ  >
>:WT kluŋ ``river''
>:Kachin kruŋ ``valley, dale''
>:OBurm. kʰloŋ
>:WB kʰyuiŋᴮ ``stream''
>:perhaps also Lushai luaŋᴴ / luanᴸ < luaŋ / luanh  ``to flow''  . This etymon may ultimately be connected with {jiāng₁ 江}

ENTRY:483
HEAD:chuān₂ 穿

LH:Later Han: tśʰuan ~ tśʰon 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *thon

	[T] MGZY chwÿan (平) [tʂ'yɛn]
	[T] ONW tśʰuan

ENTRY:484

>:WT rdol-ba, brtol ``to come out, break out, sprout''

ENTRY:485
HEAD:chuán₁ 船
MC:Middle Chinese: dźjwän 
LH:Later Han: źuan ~ źon 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *m-lon
GLOSS:"Boat" [Mo].
	[T] Sin Sukchu SR dʐyen (平)
	[T] MGZY cwÿan (平) [dʐyɛn]
	[D] PMin *d̯žiun ~ *d̯žion
	[N] The word appears in texts later than {zhōu₁ 舟} and seems to replace it by Han times (Huáng Jīnguì, Shěn Xíróng YYWZX 1987.8: 41-44). FY says that chuán is the word for ``boat'' in western China, and (AA) zhōu and háng are the words common in central and eastern China.
	PMin *d̯ž- suggests a pre-nasalized initial.
	Graphic variants are written with 工 or 公 which are, however, not phonetic, i.e. a word like GY xiāng is spurious (Huáng Jin-guì, Shěn Xí-róng).
	There are more words which have a final -n in CH, but -ŋ in TB and other languages ({§6.4.2}).
	[E] Area etymon of AA origin (Luce acc. to Weidert 1987: 129; Shorto 1972: 15). PMK *lu(u) ~ *l(u)əŋ ``to hollow out'' (Shorto 1972: 15) > OMon dluŋ ``boat'' ⪤ MidMon /kəmløŋ/ ``to hollow out'', Khmer /luŋ/ ``make a hole / pit / cavity, dig, excavate, bore, hollow out'', Bahn.-Sre (daa) törluŋ ``to hollow out'' (Shorto 1971: 31), PSBahn. *pəluŋ ``canoe'', PWa *ʔlɔŋ ``coffin'', Lawa U loːŋ ``boat''.
	The initial in Viet. xuòng [sɯə̀ŋ] < ž- ``boat, canoe'' suggests that this is a CH loan, but the final velar as well as the meaning ``canoe'' point to MK. Related to this root are apparently words for ``inside'' (< from ``hollowed out''): PVM *k-lɔːŋ ``inside'' [Ferlus] > SViet. trăwŋ, PSBahn. *kəluːŋ ``middle'', OKhmer kaṃluŋ /kənluŋ/ ``interior space, inside'', Katuic *kəlhoːŋ ``inside'', Khmuʔ kluaŋ. These items are prob. not connected with {zhōng₁ 中} ``middle''.
	<> PTB *m-loŋ (HPTB: 294) > WB loŋᴮ ``canoe, long boat'', also WB hluiŋ ``excavate, a niche''; Lushai lɔŋᴸ ``boat'' ⪤ lɔŋᶠ ``to take out the heart'' (of a tree), S. Khami mlauŋ, N. Khami pʰlauŋ, Kyaw mlauŋ.
	OC agrees closely with the Kuki-Chin forms *mloŋ; Mikir telòŋ.
	From Southern Mǐn forms like tsuŋ⁵⁵ is derived Malay jong, Java ǰong ``junk'' (Zhāng Yǒng-yán YYWZX 1989.9: 94).
	A semantic parallel (and cognate?) is {yú₁₄ 俞} OC *lo ``scoop out, make hollow, canoe'', see there for further items.
	Syn. {fāng₂ 方}; {háng₄ 航杭}; {zhōu₁ 舟}.
::OC	*lo	``scoop out, make hollow, canoe''
>:Area etymon of AA origin . PMK *lu ~ *ləŋ ``to hollow out''  >
>:OMon dluŋ ``boat'' ⪤ MidMon /kəmløŋ/ ``to hollow out''
>:Khmer /luŋ/ ``make a hole / pit / cavity, dig, excavate, bore, hollow out''
>:Bahn.-Sre  törluŋ ``to hollow out''
>:PSBahn. *pəluŋ ``canoe'', PWa *ʔlɔŋ ``coffin'', Lawa U loːŋ ``boat''

ENTRY:520
HEAD:cì₁ 次佽
MC:Middle Chinese: tsʰiᶜ 
LH:Later Han: tsʰiᶜ or tsʰis 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *tshis/h < *s-nhis ?
GLOSS:"Be second, next following" [Shi],
GLOSS:"to arrange in order, order, sequel" 次 [Zuo];
GLOSS:"well arranged, convenient" 佽 [Shi].
	[T] Sin Sukchu SR ts'ɿ (去)
	[T] MGZY tshhi (去) [ts'ɿ]
	[T] ONW tsʰi
	[E] Since acc. to SW, {èr₁ 二} ``two'' is phonetic in cì, Pulleyblank (1962: 133) derives cì from èr  and postulates an OC cluster of the type s + n- (see comment under {qī₁ 七} ``seven''; {§5.9.2}).
>:Since acc. to SW, {èr₁ 二} ``two'' is phonetic in cì
>:Pulleyblank  derives cì from èr  and postulates an OC cluster of the type s + n-

ENTRY:521
HEAD:cì₂ 朿
MC:Middle Chinese: tsʰieᶜ 
LH:Later Han: tsʰieᶜ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *tshekh
GLOSS:"Thorn" [SW].
	[<] This late (i.e. Han period) word is derived from cì 刺 [tsʰiek] by the general derivation tone C ({§3.5}).
	[E] ST: WT tsʰer-ma ``thorn, thorn bush'' ⪤ gzer-ba ``to bore into'' ⪤ gzer ``nail''. MC initial tsʰ- can regularly derive from ST *k-s-, *k-z- ({§5.9.1}); for the loss of final *r in OC, see {§7.7.5}.
	Khmer jera /céer/ ``to blame, criticise, scold'' which cannot be a CH loan on phonological grounds, suggests that ``stab'' and ``criticise'' are seperate etyma which have converged in OC. A similar sound symbolic item is also found in MK: OKhmer cāk /cak/ ``to pierce, stab, prick'' (or CH loan?).
::OKhmer	cāk /cak/	``to pierce, stab, prick''
>:WT tsʰer-ma ``thorn, thorn bush'' ⪤ gzer-ba ``to bore into'' ⪤ gzer ``nail''. MC initial tsʰ- can regularly derive from ST *k-s-, *k-z-
>:for the loss of final *r in OC, see {§7.7.5}

ENTRY:522
HEAD:cì₂ 朿 ⪤ cì 刺
MC:Middle Chinese: tsʰieᶜ,tsʰjäk 
LH:Later Han: tsʰieᶜ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *tshekh
GLOSS:"To criticize" [Shi],
GLOSS:"attack, satirize" [Zuo];
GLOSS:"to kill" [Zuo].
	[T] Sin Sukchu SR ts'ɿ (去)
	[T] MGZY tshhi (去) [ts'ɿ]
	[<] exopass. / exoact. derivation of cì 刺 (tsʰjäk) ({§4.3-4}), lit. ``cause to be stabbed''. Downer (1959: 284) reserves the tone D form LH tsʰiek for the meaning ``stab''.

ENTRY:525
HEAD:cì₄ 賜錫
MC:Middle Chinese: sjieᶜ 
LH:Later Han: sieᶜ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *sekh < *slekh
GLOSS:"To give, to present with" [BI, Shi],
GLOSS:"bring" (tribute) 錫;
GLOSS:"be given, be presented with" 賜 [Lunyu].
GLOSS-NOTE:Xí 錫 is simply a loan graph for cì (Qiu Xigui 2000: 399f).
	[T] Sin Sukchu SR sɿ (去)
	[T] MGZY shi (去) [sɿ]
	[<] This word could be a final *-k form ({§6.1}) of {shī₉ 施} ``give''. Sagart (1999: 71) relates this word to yì 易 ``change'' (under {yí₈ 移}), hence lit. ``exchange''.

ENTRY:527
HEAD:cóng₁ 從
MC:Middle Chinese: dzjwoŋ 
LH:Later Han: dzioŋ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *dzoŋ
GLOSS:"Go along with, follow" [OB, BI, Shi].
	[T] Sin Sukchu SR dzjuŋ (平), PR, LR dzuŋ
	[T] MGZY tsÿung (平) [dzjuŋ]
	[T] ONW dzuoŋ
	[E] Etymology not certain. Perh. related to WT rdzoŋ-ba, (b)rdzaŋ(s) ``to send, expedite, dismiss'' ⪤ rdzoŋ(s)  ``act of accompanying, escorting''.
	Tib. a usually does not correspond to a Chinese back vowel.
	An alternative association could be with WT stoŋs-pa ``to accom- pany''; or perhaps with {sòng₁ 送} (suŋᶜ) ``to escort, follow after, go along''.
::WT	stoŋs-pa	``to accom- pany''
>:Etymology not certain. Perh. related to WT rdzoŋ-ba, rdzaŋ ``to send, expedite, dismiss'' ⪤ rdzoŋ  ``act of accompanying, escorting''

ENTRY:569
HEAD:dá₂ 答

	Other suggestions: HST: 37 relates this word to WT ’debs-pa, btab ``cast, throw, respond''; Matisoff (1995: 44) to {dí₃ 敵} ``opponent, enemy''; Unger (Hao-ku 21, 1983: 183) with reservations to WT tʰab(s)  in kʰyim-tʰab(s) ``husband, wife'' (however, the QY back vowel in duì does normally not correspond to WT a).
	CH ⇒ Tai: S. tɔp⁴ ``to reply, answer''.
::WT	’debs-pa, btab	``cast, throw, respond''
>:Prob. WT ’tʰub-pa ``get the better of, be able to stand or bear, be a match for''  ⪤ gtub-pa ``be able''

ENTRY:573
HEAD:dà,dài 大
MC:Middle Chinese: dâiᶜ 
LH:Later Han: dɑs,dɑᶜ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *dâs 
OCB:Baxter Old Chinese: *lāts
	[T] Sin S. SR daj (去), PR, LR da
	[T] MGZY tay (去) [daj]
	[T] Sui-Tang dɑ(i)ᶜ, ONW dɑC/ᶜ
	[D] PMin *dɑiᶜ
	[D] Y-Guǎngzhōu taiᶜ², Táishān aiᶜ
	[D] K-Méixiàn tʰaᶜ
GLOSS:"Be big, great" [OB, Shi].
GLOSS-NOTE:The diphthong reading dài is traditionally viewed as the correct one, or as the literary one.
	However, already in Han times we find the reading dɑᶜ, Sui-Tang has both dɑᶜ and dɑiᶜ which agrees with the modern pronunciations dà and dài (Coblin TP 1994: 156ƒƒ).
	[E] There are no unambiguous outside cognates. Perh.
	ST: PTB *tay ``big'' (Matisoff 1995a: 53) > WT mtʰe-bo ``thumb'', Nung tʰɛ ``big, large, great'', Mikir tʰè, ketʰè ``id.''; WB tay ``very''; Abor-Miri ta ``large''.
	The TB forms do not have a final *-s, though, but a final *-y which “indicates emergent quality in stative vbs.,” acc. to Matisoff.
	The TB word has also been associated with {duō 多} (Baxter acc. to Matisoff 1995a: 44), but a different etymology for the latter seems preferable.
	Possibly, what has resulted in CH dà and duō has elsewhere converged (HST: 42).
::Abor-Miri	ta	``large''
>:There are no unambiguous outside cognates. Perh

ENTRY:574

GLOSS:"Be too great, very great, excessive", in titles

ENTRY:582
HEAD:dài₆ 待
GLOSS:"wait"
	{děng₁} 等

ENTRY:583
HEAD:dài₇ 帶
MC:Middle Chinese: tâiᶜ 
LH:Later Han: tɑs 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *tâs
GLOSS:"Belt, sash" [Shi],
GLOSS:"string" [Zuo].
	[T] Sin Sukchu SR taj (去)
	[T] MGZY day (去) [taj]
	[T] ONW tɑC
	[E] ST with the basic meaning ``circumference, circumscription'': PTB *m/s-taːy (HPTB: 210), PLB *n-day³: Lahu de ``expanse of terrain'', WT sde ``part, portion (of a country); province, district, territory'', Lushai taiᴿ ``waist'' (Matisoff 1995a: 43). Perh. also OMon taḍay ``middle''.
::OMon	taḍay	``middle''
>:ST with the basic meaning ``circumference, circumscription'':
>:PTB *m/s-taːy
>:PLB *n-day³:
>:Lahu de ``expanse of terrain''
>:WT sde ``part, portion ; province, district, territory''
>:Lushai taiᴿ ``waist'' . Perh. also OMon taḍay ``middle''

ENTRY:584
HEAD:dài₈ 逮
MC:Middle Chinese: dậiᶜ,iᶜ 
LH:Later Han: dəs,jis 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *lə̂(t)s,*lə(t)s
GLOSS:"To come to, reach to" [Shi].
	[E] Baxter (1992) reconstructs OCB *(g-)ləps and relates dài to {tà₂ 眔遝沓}. Sagart (1999: 127) relates it to lì 蒞 ``arrive'' (under {lái₁ 來}).
	Alternatively, this could be an AA substrate word: Lave leć, Sre lot, Stieng luh ``to come''; AA ⇒ Lepcha lat ``to come, reach'' (Forrest JAOS 82, 1962: 333-4).
	Or AA: Riang laic, Palaung hlaeːx, Bahnar klech ``to reach''.
::Bahnar	klech	``to reach''
>:Baxter  reconstructs OCB *ləps and relates dài to {tà₂ 眔遝沓}. Sagart  relates it to lì 蒞 ``arrive''

ENTRY:585
HEAD:dài₉ 戴
MC:Middle Chinese: tậiᶜ 
LH:Later Han: təᶜ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *tə̂h
GLOSS:"To bear, support" [Zuo],
GLOSS:"carry on the head" [Meng].
	[E] AA: (OKhmer *-dai ~ *-dāya /-dəj ~ -daaj/ ``to bear, support'' >) OKhmer dnāy /dnaaj/ ``retainer, king's servant''. AA ⇒ Tai thanaaj ``attorney, representative''; Khmer /pdaaj/ ``to support / base onself on, rely on'' ⪤ Khmer tāṅa /taaŋ/ ``to take the place of, replace, substitute, represent''.
	The semantic development of the Khmer etymon is parallel to the CH word {dài₁ 代} *ləkh with OC initial *l (if our interpretation of OC is correct), rather than *t- which is suggested by Khmer.
	The word belongs to an AA wf which includes {méi₆ 媒禖} ``marriage go-between'' and {pēi₁ 胚} ``pregnant''.
::Khmer	tāṅa /taaŋ/	``to take the place of, replace, substitute, represent''
>:AA:
>:OKhmer dnāy /dnaaj/ ``retainer, king's servant''. AA ⇒ Tai thanaaj ``attorney, representative''
>:Khmer /pdaaj/ ``to support / base onself on, rely on'' ⪤ Khmer tāṅa /taaŋ/ ``to take the place of, replace, substitute, represent''

ENTRY:586
HEAD:dān₁ 丹
MC:Middle Chinese: tân 
LH:Later Han: tɑn 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *tân (or *tlan ?) 
OCB:Baxter Old Chinese: *tān
	[T]  ONW tɑn
GLOSS:"Be red, vermilion, cinnabar" [Shi] has in antiquity been a mineral from the ancient southern states Bā (Yúnnán) and Yuè (Zhèjiāng) [SW].
	[E] KT: PKS *h-lanᶜ ``red'' (Edmondson/Yang). The OC initial and *t- ~ *k- doublets indicate that OC has borrowed this item.
	Perh. {tǎn₁ 袒襢} ``bare'' is related, as skin color tends to be associated with ``red'', but see there.
	Alternatively, HPTB: 177 suggests ST *tja-n (*tya-n) ``red''.
::ST	*tja-n (*tya-n)	``red''
>:KT:
>:PKS *h-lanᶜ ``red'' . The OC initial and *t- ~ *k- doublets indicate that OC has borrowed this item

ENTRY:587

GLOSS:"丹砂 vermilion ore" [Xun],
GLOSS:"ore" [JY] may be a variant of dān, both could theoretically derive from an original foreign *klan, see below.

ENTRY:589
HEAD:dān₂ 單
MC:Middle Chinese: tân 
LH:Later Han: tɑn 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *tân
GLOSS:"Single, unit" [Shi],
GLOSS:"single, simple" [Li];
GLOSS:"unlined garment" 襌 [Li].
	[T] Sin Sukchu SR tan (平)
	[T] MGZY dan (平) [tan]
	[T] ONW tɑn  —
	[D] CDC tan¹
	[E] ST *twar ? : PTB *t(w)ar > WT tʰor-bu ``single, separate'' (Matisoff 1995a: 80); or ST *day ~ *tay ``single'' (Matisoff 1997a: 21). Pulleyblank (in Rosemont 1991: 31) connects dàn with {tǎn₁ 袒襢} ``bare''.
::ST	*day ~ *tay	``single''
>:ST *twar ? :
>:PTB *tar >
>:WT tʰor-bu ``single, separate''
>:or ST *day ~ *tay ``single'' . Pulleyblank  connects dàn with {tǎn₁ 袒襢} ``bare''

ENTRY:595
HEAD:dān₃ 癉 ⪤ duǒ,tuō,tuò 痑
