ENTRY:597
HEAD:dān₅ 耽湛
MC:Middle Chinese: tậm 
LH:Later Han: təm 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *tə̂m
	[T] ONW tɑm
GLOSS:"Abandon oneself (in pleasure)" 耽 [Shi];
GLOSS:"to be sunk in, steeped in (pleasure), rejoice" 湛 [Shi].
	[E] Area word: AA: PVM *tămᴮ ``to drown, sink'' [Thompson]; Wa-Lawa-Bulang *ntɤm ``soak rice''. AA ⇒ Tai: S. dam < *ʔd- ``to dive'' ⪤ damᴮ ``to sink down deeply, to a great depth'' (Unger Hao-ku 36, 1990: 58), tuam³ ``be submerged, overwhelmed''.
	Dān is usually thought to be cognate to {chén₂ 沈} (Wáng Lì 1982: 607).
	OCM  *tə̂m can also derive from a hypothetical *tləm in which case there may be a TB connection instead, but the meanings do not agree closely: Lushai liamᴿ < liamʔ ``to overflow, disappear'', WB hlyamᴮ ``be brimming full'' ⪤ hlyam ``run over, overflow''; WT ltam-pa, gtam-pa ``full'' ⪤ ltem-pa ``full, overflowing''.
	<> PTai *tl-: S. temᴬ¹ ``full''.
::WT	ltam-pa, gtam-pa	``full''
>:Area word:
>:AA:
>:PVM *tămᴮ ``to drown, sink''
>:Wa-Lawa-Bulang *ntɤm ``soak rice''. AA ⇒ Tai:
>:S. dam < *ʔd- ``to dive'' ⪤ damᴮ ``to sink down deeply, to a great depth'' , tuam³ ``be submerged, overwhelmed''

ENTRY:598
HEAD:dān₆ 擔
MC:Middle Chinese: tâm 
LH:Later Han: tɑm 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *tâm < *tlam
	[T] ONW tɑm.
GLOSS:"To carry on the shoulder" [Guoce].
	[D] PMin *t̯ɑm ``to carry''
	[D] acc. to Norman (1986: 382) the Northern Min ``softened initial'' *t̯- points to OC prenasalization which is supported by Yao daam¹ < *nd-, PMY *ntam¹ ``to carry''.
	[E] Area word: WB tʰamᴮ ``to carry on the shoulder'' (Bodman 1980: 112), JP tʰam⁵⁵ ``carry'', Dulong ɑtɑm. <> PMY *ntam¹ ``to carry'', Yao daam¹ < *nd-.
	<> Perhaps the MK items are also related: MK: Khmer dāṃ /toəm/ ``to bear'' ⪤ drāṃ /troəm/ ``to support patiently'' [Jenner / Pou 1982: xlix]. Khmer drāṃ ⇒ Kam-Tai: PT *tʰr-: S. haamᴬ¹ ``two or more people carry'' (Li F. 1976: 45), Saek raam² (< hr-?) ``two or more carry''.
	A variant with initial *kl-: MK *klam, *kləm ``to carry on shoulder'' (Shorto 2006 #1406): Khmu klam ``carry on the shoulder'', PWa *klɐm (for the initials, see {§8.2.1}).
::Khmu	klam	``carry on the shoulder''
>:Area word:
>:WB tʰamᴮ ``to carry on the shoulder''
>:JP tʰam⁵⁵ ``carry''
>:Dulong ɑtɑm. < > PMY *ntam¹ ``to carry''
>:Yao daam¹ < *nd-

ENTRY:601
HEAD:dǎn₂ 膽
MC:Middle Chinese: tâmᴮ 
LH:Later Han: tɑmᴮ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *tâmʔ < *tlamʔ
GLOSS:"Gall" [Xun].

>:MK *t1ləəm, *t1luəm ``liver'' :
>:Khmer thlaəm
>:PNBahn. *klàm ``liver''
>:PVM *lɔːm . As in the case of {dān₆ 擔}, there is an alternative form with initial *t-:
>:Palaunic *kt1uəm ``liver''

GLOSS:"To know" [FY 1.1] is a Han period Chǔ dialect word. Two possible etymologies: (1) This may be compared to PTB *m-taŋ > WB tʰaŋ
GLOSS:"visible" ⪤ ə-tʰaŋ
GLOSS:"thought", WT mtʰoŋ-ba ``to see, perceive, know, understand'', Kanauri taŋ ``to see''. (2) A southern dialect form of dǒng 懂 ``understand'' with the typical shift to a (J. Norman).

ENTRY:632
HEAD:dǎo₃ 擣
MC:Middle Chinese: tâuᴮ 
LH:Later Han: touᴮ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *tûʔ
GLOSS:"To pound" (as rice) [Li], still used in southern dialects, e.g. Yuè-Táishān au⁵⁵-mbai⁵⁵ 搗米;
GLOSS:"to beat" [Hanshu].
	[E] ST *tu: JP tʰu⁵⁵ ``push'', WB tuiᴮ ``push, butt, shove against'' ⪤ tʰuiᴮ ``thrust, stab, strike''. A TB parallel stem is Lushai čʰuᴴ / čʰutᴸ ``to strike'' (with rod), ``pound, stamp, knock, tap''.
	For ST cognate and/or parallel stems, see the table under {chù₁ 觸} for an overview.
::Lushai	čʰuᴴ / čʰutᴸ	``to strike''
>:ST *tu:
>:JP tʰu⁵⁵ ``push''
>:WB tuiᴮ ``push, butt, shove against'' ⪤ tʰuiᴮ ``thrust, stab, strike''. A TB parallel stem is Lushai čʰuᴴ / čʰutᴸ ``to strike'' , ``pound, stamp, knock, tap''

ENTRY:633
HEAD:dǎo₄ 禱
	{zhù₁₀} 祝

ENTRY:634
HEAD:dào₁ 到
MC:Middle Chinese: tâuᶜ 
LH:Later Han: tɑuᶜ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *tâuh
GLOSS:"To arrive" [Shi].
	[E] Perh. ST, yet the TB rime is different from OC: WT gtug-pa ``to reach to, touch'' (e.g. putting the forehead against the breast of an image) ⪤ tʰug-pa ``to reach, arrive at, come to, meet, touch'';  WB tuiŋ ``to arrive, reach, attain'', JP du³¹ ``arrive''.
	However, these TB items could just as well belong to {zhǔ₈ 屬}.
::JP	du³¹	``arrive''
>:Perh. ST, yet the TB rime is different from OC:
>:WT gtug-pa ``to reach to, touch''  ⪤ tʰug-pa ``to reach, arrive at, come to, meet, touch''
>:WB tuiŋ ``to arrive, reach, attain''
>:JP du³¹ ``arrive''

ENTRY:635
HEAD:dào₂ 道
MC:Middle Chinese: dâuᴮ 
LH:Later Han: douᴮ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *lûʔ
GLOSS:"Road, way, method" [BI, Shi].
	[T] Sin Sukchu SR daw (上去)
	[T] MGZY taw (上) [daw]
	[T] ONW dɑu
	[<] either an endoactive noun ``the thing which is doing the conducting'' ({§4.5.1}) derived from the following word (dào 道導), or the latter is a LOC general tone C derivation from ``way'' ({§3.5}).
	[E] Pulleyblank (1973: 120) believes that dào ``talk'' is cognate to {tán₈ 談}. Gong Hwang-cherng (1995: 61) presents parallels which suggest a pattern of OC *əm > *u. 道 is shared with Yao klăuᴮ ``road'' (Haudricourt 1950: 559; but Downer 1982 *kau²).
::Yao	klăuᴮ	``road''
>:Pulleyblank  believes that dào ``talk'' is cognate to {tán₈ 談}. Gong Hwang-cherng  presents parallels which suggest a pattern of OC *əm > *u. 道 is shared with Yao klăuᴮ ``road''

ENTRY:636
HEAD:dào₂ 道 ⪤ dào 道導
MC:Middle Chinese: dâuᶜ 
LH:Later Han: douᶜ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *lûh
GLOSS:"To go along, bring along, conduct" 道 [Zuo], 導 [Meng] >
GLOSS:"explain" [Li] >
GLOSS:"talk about" 道 [Lao, Meng].
GLOSS-NOTE:The Han period dialect of Eastern Qi has the words yù 裕 [joᶜ] *lokh and yóu 猷 [ju] *lu or *ju (?)
GLOSS:"road" [FY 3.23] which may be related.

ENTRY:637
HEAD:dào₃ 盜
	{tōu₂} 偷 {yú₁₇} 愉

ENTRY:638
HEAD:dào₄ 稻
MC:Middle Chinese: dâuᴮ 
LH:Later Han: douᴮ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *lûʔ
GLOSS:"Unhusked rice" [Shi].
	[D] PMin *tiuᴮ² 粙 (corresponds to QYS ḍjəuᶜ [JY], LH ḍuh) may possibly be a variant (Norman, p.c.).
	[E] Etymology is not certain. The word could belong to the wf {yóu₄ 油} ``overflow'' (i.e. the notion of a flooded rice field).
	More likely, it is an area word (rice culture originated in the south): PMY *nblauᴬ (Bodman 1980: 112).
	The relationship with similar-looking MK words is ambiguous, we find PVM *ʔa-lɔːʔ ``unhusked rice'', Viet. lúa ``paddy'' [Ferlus], but Khmuic *lɔʔ ``glutinous rice'' (Ferlus 31st  ICSTLL, 1998: 90) whose meaning seems to connect the MK etymon with {nuò₄ 糯}.
::Khmuic	*lɔʔ	``glutinous rice''
>:Etymology is not certain. The word could belong to the wf {yóu₄ 油} ``overflow''

ENTRY:639
HEAD:dé₁ 得
MC:Middle Chinese: tək 
LH:Later Han: tək 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *tə̂k
GLOSS:"To get" [BI, Shi].
	[T] Sin Sukchu SR təj (入), LR təjʔ
	[T] MGZ  dhiy (入) [təj]
	[T] ONW tək
	[D] Dé is Mand. col., Gānsù dei (Demiéville 1950: 52)
	[D] dé is sometimes thought to be an allofam of {dé₂ 德} ``virtue''.
	[E] Based on his theories on OC phonology, Pulleyblank (EC 16, 1991: 50) believes that dé and {dé₂ 德} are cognate to WT tʰub-pa ``be able, cope with'', but see {dá₂ 答}.
::WT	tʰub-pa	``be able, cope with''
>:Based on his theories on OC phonology
>:Pulleyblank  believes that dé and {dé₂ 德} are cognate to WT tʰub-pa ``be able, cope with'', but see {dá₂ 答}

	[C] An allofam is perhaps {zhí₂ 直} ``straight''.
::WT	tʰub 	``a mighty one, having power''

ENTRY:641
HEAD:de₃ 的
GLOSS:"genitive particle" in Mand., appears for the first time in a Song document (Coblin p.c.) and later in an inscription of 1238 (Mei Tsu-Lin BIHP 59.1, 1988).
	It is thought to be a col. archaism of the classical ``genitive particle'' {zhī₁ 之}.

ENTRY:642
HEAD:dēng₁ 登

LH:Later Han: təŋ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *tə̂ŋ
	[T] ONW təŋ
GLOSS:"To rise, ascend, mount, raise" [Shi, Shu],
GLOSS:"to ripen" [Meng];

ENTRY:660

	It could be either a derivation from {yóu₁₀ 滺油} *liu ``flow'', or be related to {zhuó₁₁ 濯} *d-lauk ``be clean'' (but the OC rimes do not agree).

ENTRY:666
HEAD:dì₁ 地
MC:Middle Chinese: diᶜ 
LH:Later Han: diᶜ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *lâih ? 
OCB:Baxter Old Chinese: *lrjajs ?
GLOSS:"Earth, ground" [Shi].
GLOSS-NOTE:The QYS reading is unique and puzzling.
	[T] Sin S. SR djej (去), PR, LR di
	[T] MGZY ti (去) [di]
	[T] ONW dii
	[E] Etymology not certain. Since the OC initial was L-like, it may be compared with PTB *mliy ``earth'' (STC no. 152) > WB mre ``earth, ground'', Mikir mili ``bare ground'', Nung məli ``ground, mountain''.
	However, this TB etymon rather seems to belong to {shì₁₃ 室} ``house''.
	On the other hand, there are AA words which resemble Chinese: Munda ɔte ``field, land'', Khmer ʈi ``earth, soil'', Mon ʈi ``land, earth'', PSBahn. *(nə)təh ``earth''.
	Neither of these possibilities agrees phonologically with OC; perhaps these two etyma have converged.
::Mon	ʈi	``land, earth''
>:Etymology not certain. Since the OC initial was L-like, it may be compared with PTB *mliy ``earth''  >
>:WB mre ``earth, ground''
>:Mikir mili ``bare ground''
>:Nung məli ``ground, mountain''

ENTRY:682
HEAD:diān₂ 顛傎
MC:Middle Chinese: tien 
LH:Later Han: ten (tein) 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *tîn < *tlin ?
	[T] MTang tian < tɨan ONW tėn
GLOSS:"To topple, fall down, be overthrown" 顛 [Shi], 傎 [Guliang].
	[E] Area word: WB lañᴮ ~ laiᴮ < lin/ŋ ``fall''; Miao gliŋ ``to fall''. This etymon is prob. not related to the wf {diān₁ 顛巔} ``top of the head'' whose initial is a simple dental stop in ST. For inital CH t- = foreign gl-, see {§8.2.1}.
>:Area word:
>:WB lañᴮ ~ laiᴮ < lin/ŋ ``fall''
>:Miao gliŋ ``to fall''. This etymon is prob. not related to the wf {diān₁ 顛巔} ``top of the head'' whose initial is a simple dental stop in ST. For inital CH t- = foreign gl-, see {§8.2.1}

ENTRY:698
HEAD:dié₃ 跌

	[D] PMin *buɑt ``stumble'' is possibly related in light of the TB cognates.
	[E] ST: PTB *ble ``to slip'' (STC no. 141; HPTB: 203f), TGTM *pleːᴮ ``slippery''; PKaren *pʰle³ ~ *ʔble²  ``id.'' (STC: 139 n. 375), JP gə³¹-pʰrai⁵⁵ ``to slip'', Digaro ble ``slippery''; Mikir -iŋlìt < m-lìt ``be slippery''; WT ’byid-pa ``to slip'' < mlit ?, Lepcha flut ~ flit ``to slip from'' ⪤ plut ``let slip'' [Bodman ICSTLL 1987: 21]. Lushai has a possible cognate (medial l does not occur after labial stops): pʰetᴸ / pʰeʔᴸ < pʰeʔ/h ``to trip up, slip away'', also pialᴿ < pialʔ ``to slip'' may be connected.
	<> This etymon is also found in Tai: S. pʰlaatᴰ²ᴸ < *blat ``to slip and fall'', Dioi śwat¹ [Maspero 1912: 86]. HST: 140 associates this word with WT ldig-pa ``to fall and sink through''.
	[C] It is not clear if dié is connected with {yì₁₃ 泆溢}. This word is apparently distinct from, and parallel to, the syn. {zhì₁₆ 疐} *tri(t)s; see {Table D-1} [ To slip, slippery, trip ] for an overview. ◇

ENTRY:703
HEAD:dié₇ 牒
MC:Middle Chinese: diep 
LH:Later Han: dep 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *lêp
	[T] ONW dėp

	CH ⇒ Tai: S. *tʰɛɛpᴰ¹ᴸ ``classifier for long, flat, narrow objects''.
	[N] These two words (dié₇ 牒 and {dié₈ 褶疊}) have distinctly different meanings and TB cognates, perhaps two different words have converged phonologically in OC. Furthermore, this etymon is a syn. of {zhé₇ 摺}, but the roots are different (*Clep ~ *Cliap vs. *tap); perhaps some of the WT items (ldab, ltab) are a conflation of the two roots.
	[C] ``Butterfly'' {hú₆-dié 胡蝶} may belong to this wf, but see there. Allofams are perhaps {yè₄ 葉}, {xiè₄ 屧}; {xí₂ 習}.

>:PTB *lyap  >
>:WT ldeb ``leaf, sheet''

>:Lushai depᶠ ``flat''

ENTRY:712
HEAD:dǐng₃ 鼎
MC:Middle Chinese: tieŋᴮ 
LH:Later Han: teŋᴮ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *têŋʔ
	A three or four-legged ``tripod, cauldron'' [BI, Shi]. A large one is called {nài₄ 鼐}.
	[T] Sin Sukchu SR tiŋ (上)
	[T] MGZY ding (上) [tiŋ]
	[T] ONW tėŋ
	[D] The south has preserved the original meaning ``cooking pot, pan'': Old South tâŋᴬ 鐺 [San-guo zhi] (Ho Dah-an, BIHP 1993: 869), but PMin *tiaŋᴮ with medial -i- is from a later stratum: Jiànyáng tiaŋᴮ, Fúzhōu tiaŋᴮ, Xiàmén tiãᴮ (Norman 1988: 231).
	[E] Most likely, this old area word is related to Mru teŋ ``sacrificial tripod'' (Löffler ZDMG 116.1, 1966: 141), Wa-Lawa-Bulang *dɐŋ, *(n-)dɑŋ ``cooking pot'' (or are these CH loans?) Alternatively, Benedict (STC: 178 n. 472; 1976: 98) connects this word with PT and PKS *gliaŋᴬ ``tripod'', perhaps related to Wa-Lawa-Bulang *klɐŋ ``basin'', PPalaung (AA) geŋ ``tripod''; note also PTai *giŋᴬ ``tripod''. But these last forms present phonological difficulties.
::PTai	*giŋᴬ	``tripod''
>:Most likely, this old area word is related to Mru teŋ ``sacrificial tripod''
>:Wa-Lawa-Bulang *dɐŋ, *dɑŋ ``cooking pot''  Alternatively
>:Benedict  connects this word with PT and PKS *gliaŋᴬ ``tripod'', perhaps related to Wa-Lawa-Bulang *klɐŋ ``basin''
>:PPalaung  geŋ ``tripod''
>:note also PTai *giŋᴬ ``tripod''. But these last forms present phonological difficulties

	{tíng₁} 亭

ENTRY:714
HEAD:dìng₂ 定顁
MC:Middle Chinese: tieŋᶜ 
LH:Later Han: teŋᶜ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *têŋ < *tleŋ ?
GLOSS:"Forehead" 定 [Shi 11, 2], 顁 [Erya 2, 146].
GLOSS-NOTE:{dìng₁ 定} is an OC T-series ({§12.1.2}); however, this type of initial with QYS div. I/IV can also correspond to an earlier *tl- from a foreign cluster with medial -l- (OCM *tleŋh, see {§8.2.1}).
	[E] Most likely MK *t₁n₁iəŋ ``forehead'' (Shorto 2006 #599): Mon tneŋ ``forehead'', Wa-Lawa-Bulang *k/sṇtɑŋ ``forehead''. Alternatively, a connection with {diān₁ 顛巔} ``top of the head'' could also be possible.
	The source of Kadai *C-dəŋᴬ ``forehead'' is not clear (CH?).
	Syn. {tí₁ 提堤題}, é 額 and yán 顏 (both under {yà₂ 御迓訝}), {sǎng 顙}, {yáng₈ 揚鍚}.
::Wa-Lawa-Bulang	*k/sṇtɑŋ	``forehead''
>:Most likely MK *t₁n₁iəŋ ``forehead'' :
>:Mon tneŋ ``forehead''
>:Wa-Lawa-Bulang *k/sṇtɑŋ ``forehead''. Alternatively, a connection with {diān₁ 顛巔} ``top of the head'' could also be possible

ENTRY:715
HEAD:dìng₃ 町
MC:Middle Chinese: dieŋᴮ 
LH:Later Han: deŋᴮ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *dêŋʔ
GLOSS:"Small boundary banks between fields" [Zuo] is perhaps a variant or cognate of {zhěn₃ 畛} (so Lau 1999: 342). Furthermore (or alternatively), dìng could originally have referred to a trampled path, hence cognate to tǐng-tuǎn 町畽 (tʰieŋᴮ-tʰuânᴮ) *thêŋʔ-thônʔ
GLOSS:"be trampled down (fields)" [Shi] (so Karlgren GSR 833g). Finally, there may be a connection with {tí₁ 提堤題}
GLOSS:"raise".

ENTRY:719
HEAD:dōng₃ 涷
MC:Middle Chinese: tuŋᴬ/ᶜ 
LH:Later Han: toŋ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *tôŋ < *tloŋ ?
GLOSS:"Violent rain" [Chǔci].
	[E] MY: The source of this word is apparently a form similar to Yao *bluŋ⁶ ``rain''; Wáng FS has PYao < PMY *mblɒəŋ⁶, but almost all individual Yao languages have a back vowel: blŭŋ⁶, bjŭŋ⁶, bŭŋ⁶, biŋ⁶ (Huáng Shù-xiān YYYJ 1989.2: 113, see also Wáng F. 1995: 126). Perh. ultimately related to the AA etymon under {píng₄ 萍} ``rain master''; note a back vowel form PEKatuic *piloŏŋ ``sky'', perhaps also Kharia tɔ-bluŋ ``above'' [Pinnow 1959: 405]. MY back vowels tend to correspond to other languages’ front vowels and vice versa.
	The word is a loan in CH because it first appears in the late Zhanguo / early Han text Chǔcí (songs from the southern state of Chǔ), is identified as a Jiāng-dōng (Wu-Yue) dialect word in FY; it has a narrower specialized meaning in CH, it is rare in CH while it is the common word for ``rain'' in MY; and finally it lacks a CH etymology.
	For *t- < *Cl-, see {§8.2.1}.
	For syn. and semantics, see {fēn₂ 雰氛}.
::Kharia	tɔ-bluŋ	``above''
>:MY:
>:The source of this word is apparently a form similar to Yao *bluŋ⁶ ``rain''
>:Wáng FS has PYao <
>:PMY *mblɒəŋ⁶, but almost all individual Yao languages have a back vowel:
>:blŭŋ⁶, bjŭŋ⁶, bŭŋ⁶, biŋ⁶ . Perh. ultimately related to the AA etymon under {píng₄ 萍} ``rain master''
>:note a back vowel form PEKatuic *piloŏŋ ``sky'', perhaps also Kharia tɔ-bluŋ ``above'' . MY back vowels tend to correspond to other languages’ front vowels and vice versa

ENTRY:727
HEAD:dòu₃ 荳
MC:Middle Chinese: dəuᶜ 
LH:Later Han: doᶜ
GLOSS:"Soybean".
	[E] Etymology not certain, prob. area word: PTB *tu-ŋ ``bean'' (LaPolla 1994: 171); MK *t1uh, t1əh ``bean'' (Shorto ɐ2002). Unger (Hao-ku 24, 1984) raises the possibility that this is the same word as ``a round vessel'' {dòu₂ 豆} and is derived from {tóu₃ 頭} (dəu) ``head''.
	STC: 195 draws attention to similarity with PMY *dop and {dá₃ 荅} (tập) ``a kind of pulse''.
>:Etymology not certain, prob. area word:
>:PTB *tu-ŋ ``bean''
>:MK *t1uh, t1əh ``bean'' . Unger  raises the possibility that this is the same word as ``a round vessel'' {dòu₂ 豆} and is derived from {tóu₃ 頭}  ``head''

	{zhú₄} 躅

ENTRY:729
HEAD:dòu₅ 脰
MC:Middle Chinese: dəuᶜ 
LH:Later Han: doᶜ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *dôh
GLOSS:"Neck" [Zuo].
	[D] An old Qí dial. word (acc. to Hé Xiū ca. 180 AD)
	[D] it is still used in Mǐn dialects: Fúzhōu tauᶜ²-kaukᴰ¹, Jiànyáng loᶜ² (Norman 1983: 207).
	[E] ST: PTB *tuk ⪤ *du(k) ``neck, head'' (STC no. 392; Matisoff 1978: 64f): JP duʔ³¹ ``neck'', Garo gitok, Mikir tśethok, Lepcha tŭk-tok ``neck''. See also {dú₈-lóu 髑髏}.
::Lepcha	tŭk-tok	``neck''

HEAD:dòu₆ 鬥

LH:Later Han: toᶜ

	[T] ONW tou

ENTRY:739
HEAD:dú₆ 犢
MC:Middle Chinese: duk 
LH:Later Han: dok 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *lôk ?
	[T] ONW dok
GLOSS:"Calf" [Li].
	[E] Etymology not certain. (1) It could be a ST word: Kanauri luk ``calf'', WT lug ``sheep'', lu-gu ``lamb, calf'', TGTM *g-luk ``sheep''. (2) Boodberg (1937: 359) suggests cognation with WT pʰrug ``calf'' (not likely). (3) Alternatively, it could be a loan from Altaic acc. to Norman (1988: 18): Mongol tuɣul, Manchu tukšan, Evenki tukučə̄n ``calf'', Lamut tu- ~ tuɣu- ``to give birth to a calf''. (4) It could be related to {chù₄,xù 畜}. Dú may be connected with yú 羭.
::Lamut	tu- ~ tuɣu-	``to give birth to a calf''
>:Etymology not certain.  It could be a ST word:
>:Kanauri luk ``calf''
>:WT lug ``sheep'', lu-gu ``lamb, calf''

>:Mongol tuɣul
>:Manchu tukšan
>:Evenki tukučə̄n ``calf''

ENTRY:742
HEAD:dú₈-lóu 髑髏
MC:Middle Chinese: duk-ləu 
LH:Later Han: dok-lo 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *dôk-rô
GLOSS:"Skull" [Zhuang, GY].
GLOSS-NOTE:Li Fang Kuei (1976: 44) who relates this word to Tai: S. (kra-) duukᴰ¹ᴸ < *-ʔdl/ruok (actually *ʔluok ?), considers this a reduplication from a hypothetical OC *dlug.
	This bisyllabic word appears in more variants (tóu-lú 頭顱 and dú-lú 頓顱).
	[E] These variants are partially composed of syllables meaning ``head'' (tóu) of ST stock (Loloish languages have cognates in compound words for ``head'': Matisoff 1978: 64). Dú 髑 is a ST item which is prob. related to {dòu₅ 脰} ``neck'': PTB *du(k) ``neck, skull'' > Abor-Miri a-tuk, Atong dək-əm, Kaike tʰoppā (< tʰok-pa) ``head'' (Matisoff ibid. p. 65).
	One may speculate that the second syllable is related to lóu 婁 [lo] with a hypothetical meaning ``empty'' or ``dried'', hence lit. ``dried head'' as in Lushai. More likely, though, the second part is a reduplication syllable starting with *r/*l ({§2.7}).
	Similar-looking items include {lú₄ 顱}; Khmer rɔliə ``shell, skull'' (from earlier rɔ-laː ?).
::Khmer	rɔliə	``shell, skull''
>:These variants are partially composed of syllables meaning ``head''  of ST stock . Dú 髑 is a ST item which is prob. related to {dòu₅ 脰} ``neck'':
>:PTB *du ``neck, skull'' >
>:Abor-Miri a-tuk
>:Atong dək-əm
>:Kaike tʰoppā  ``head''

ENTRY:743
HEAD:dú₈-lóu 髑髏 ⪤ tóu-lú 頭顱
MC:Middle Chinese: dəu-luo 
LH:Later Han: do-lɑ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *dô-râ
GLOSS:"Skull" [Guoce].
GLOSS-NOTE:This form is reminiscent of Lushai luᶠ-roᴴ
GLOSS:"skull" (lit.
GLOSS:"dried head") and luF-ruʔᴸ ``skull'' (lit. ``head-bone''), just as in CH the first syllable is ``head''.

ENTRY:744
HEAD:dú₈-lóu 髑髏 ⪤ dú-lú 頓顱
MC:Middle Chinese: dâk-luo 
LH:Later Han: dɑk-lɑ > dɔk-lɔ (?)
GLOSS:"Skull" [SW, GY], today in Shānxī
GLOSS:"forehead". This late form seems to be the s. w. as {dú₈-lóu 髑髏} above, but committed to writing when OC *a had become more back like *ɑ or *o.
	An additional MC variant is ṭɐk- / ṭʰɐk- [GY] which seems close to KS words for ``bone'': *tlaːk⁷ (Thurgood) or *k-laːkᴰ (Edmondson/Yang); yet these latter have entered Chinese as {gé₅ 骼} ``bone''.

ENTRY:752
HEAD:dù₂ 渡
MC:Middle Chinese: duoᶜ 
LH:Later Han: dɑᶜ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *dâkh
GLOSS:"To ford" [Guoce].
	[E] ST: WT ’da-ba, das ``to pass over'' (HST: 116).Dù occurs also in Tai *daaᴮ: S. tʰaaᴮ² ``wharf, landing'', but ``river'' in most other Tai lgs. (Li Fang Kuei 1976: 40). The semantic connection of ``ford'' with ``river'' has perhaps a parallel, see {hé₄ 河}.
	The virtual phonological identity of the Tai form with late OC (Chinese tone C = Tai tone B), as well as the restriction of this word to the Tai branch of the KT family suggest a Chinese loan.
	The AA syn. is {jì₁₅ 濟}.
>:WT ’da-ba, das ``to pass over'' .Dù occurs also in Tai *daaᴮ:
>:S. tʰaaᴮ² ``wharf, landing'', but ``river'' in most other Tai lgs. . The semantic connection of ``ford'' with ``river'' has perhaps a parallel, see {hé₄ 河}

ENTRY:763
HEAD:duī 堆
MC:Middle Chinese: tuậi 
LH:Later Han: tuəi 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *tûi
GLOSS:"Mound" [Chuci].
	[E] The first textual appearance in Chǔcí suggests a foreign word. MK has several roots with the meaning ``hill, mound'': MK *dul ``hill'' (Shorto 2006 #1741), and MK *bt1u[u]l, *bt1uəl ``swelling, mound, hill'' (Shorto 2006 #1738); OKhmer dul ``to bulge'', OKhmer /duuəl/ ``knoll, hillock, mound'', PVM *dolᴬ ``hill'', PSBahn. *tul ~ *nətul ``anthill''. Also MK *[d][o]r ``hill'' (Shorto 2006 #1626). <> A similar looking Tai and MY etymon is probably not related because of the post-initial liquid: PTai *ʔdl/rɔiᴬ: S. dɔɔiᴬ¹ ``mountain'', Saek rɔɔyᴬ¹, PMY *glaɨᴰ ``mountain''.
	The word {tún₁ 屯} ``hill'' seems to represent a variant, foreign items cited here could equally well apply to that word.
::PMY	*glaɨᴰ	``mountain''

ENTRY:771
HEAD:duì₇ 隊
MC:Middle Chinese: duậiᶜ 
LH:Later Han: duəs 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *lûs
GLOSS:"Troops" [Zuo].
	[E] Sagart (1999: 85) relates duì to yù 遹 ``follow'' (under {suì₂ 遂}), hence lit. ``followers''. Because of the OC L-like initial, the word cannot be related to {tún₂ 屯窀} and the TB items there, nor to AA: Khmer dāba /toəp/ ``armed forces, troops, army''.
>:Sagart  relates duì to yù 遹 ``follow'' , hence lit. ``followers''. Because of the OC L-like initial, the word cannot be related to {tún₂ 屯窀} and the TB items there, nor to AA:
>:Khmer dāba /toəp/ ``armed forces, troops, army''

	[T] ONW ton
	[E] ST: HST: 67-68 relates this word to WT rtul-po ``dull, blunt'' and adds WT dul-ba ``soft, mild, tame'' ⪤ ’dul-ba, btul ``to tame, conquer, subdue''; Chepang dyulh- ``be blunt, worn'' (edge of tool). ENTRY:783
HEAD:duō 多
MC:Middle Chinese: tâ 
LH:Later Han: tɑi 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *tâi < *tlai
GLOSS:"There are many, have many, all the …" [OB, BI, Shi].
GLOSS-NOTE:For the initial, see {§8.2.1}.
	[T] Sin Sukchu SR tɔ (平), LR tɔ, twɔ
	[T] MGZY do (平) [tɔ]
	[T] ONW tɑ
	[D] Y-Guǎngzhōu ⁵⁵tɔᴬ¹, K-Méixiàn tɔᴬ¹, PMin *tɑiᴬ¹
	[E] KT: PTai *hlaiᴬ¹ ``many'', PHlai *ɬʔooi¹ ``(how) many'' (Thurgood 1991: 38; Baxter a. Sagart 1998: 53); the Tai item is also suggested to be the source of the Mǐn word for ``many'', see {chái₂ 儕} ({chái₃ 儕}).
	Others connect duō with the TB items under {dà,dài 大}.
::PHlai	*ɬʔooi¹	`` many''
>:KT:
>:PTai *hlaiᴬ¹ ``many''
>:PHlai *ɬʔooi¹ `` many''
>:the Tai item is also suggested to be the source of the Mǐn word for ``many'', see {chái₂ 儕}

ENTRY:784
HEAD:duō 多 ⪤ zhū 諸
MC:Middle Chinese: tśjwo 
LH:Later Han: tśɑ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *ta
	[T] MTang tśy ONW tśø < tśo
GLOSS:"Many, all", forms plurals, especially for persons to whom respect is due [BI, Shi].
GLOSS-NOTE:Zhū replaced earlier OB duō 多 in this sense, e.g.
	OB  duō yǐn 多尹 ``all the administrators'' [OB Yib. 867] > 諸尹 [BI]. In BI both duō and zhū occur.
	Subsequently in Shījīng, duō is rare in the sense ``all'', zhū becomes the norm: zhū hóu 諸侯 ``all the feudal lords'' [Shi 6,34]. Therefore, it is conceivable that zhū had branched off from duō 多 (tâ) *tlai in the sense ``all'' as the pre-nominal proclitic adjectival use, due to the loss of final *-i in *tlai 多 in this position, hence *tlai winʔ 多尹 > *tla winʔ > *ta winʔ (Baxter acc. to Matisoff 1995a: 54).
	Alternatively, Karlgren (1956: 17) connects zhū with the wf {zhǔ₆ 貯褚} ``collect''; Graham (1973: 294ƒƒ) considers zhū a dependent (``non-adjunctive'') pronoun.
::OB	duō yǐn 多尹	``all the administrators''

ENTRY:785
HEAD:duō 多 ⪤ dōu 都
GLOSS:"all" which is the Mand. col. form of zhū.

ENTRY:786
HEAD:duō 多 ⪤ shù 庶
MC:Middle Chinese: śjwoᶜ 
LH:Later Han: śɑᶜ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *lha(k)h < *thla(k)h ?
GLOSS:"Be many, abundant" [Shi], adj.
GLOSS:"the many, all" [BI, Shi], syn. of zhū and duō: in Shūjīng occurs shù yǐn 庶尹, for example. Thus
GLOSS:"all the administrators" can be duō yǐn 多尹, zhū yǐn 諸尹 or shù yǐn 庶尹.
	Given the OC phonological similarity of these three words, it is therefore likely that shù is cognate to duō; the initial can be explained as a devoiced *lh- ({§5.5}) after loss of the *t- which was felt to be some sort of pre-initial.

ENTRY:792
HEAD:duǒ₁ 朵

LH:Later Han: toiᴮ
	The second syllable in the modern word for {ěr₁ 耳} ``ear'': Mand. ěr-duǒ 耳朵; Y-Táishān ³³ŋgiᴬ¹-⁵⁵tuɔiᴮ¹; K-Cónghuà ²¹ãiᴮ-³⁵tiɔᴬ².
	This is perhaps related to the word tuǒ 橢 (tʰuâᴮ) ``oblong, oval'' [Chuci]. It is also reminiscent of an MK word for ``ear'': PSBahn. *toːr ``ear''.
	[T] Sin S. SR tɔ (上), LR tɔ, twɔ
	[T] MGZY dwo (上) [twɔ]
	[T] ONW tuɑᴮ

ENTRY:800

GLOSS:"Slanting" [Shi].

	[E] ST has *ŋ(w)aj ~ *nwaj  parallel stems ({§2.5}; {§5.12.1}) for this etymon:
GLOSS:1:*ŋaj > 俄 OCM *ŋâi, WB ŋaiᶜ
GLOSS:"to lean, be inclined to one side" (Matisoff 1995a: 85) ⪤ hŋaiᶜ

ENTRY:801
HEAD:é₂ 娥 (in héng-é 姮娥)
MC:Middle Chinese: ɣəŋ-ŋâ 
LH:Later Han: gəŋ-ŋɑi 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *gə̂ŋ-ŋâi
	Name of the moon goddess [Huainan, Hou Hanshu], later cháng-é 常娥 because the Hàn emperor Wéndì's personal name was Héng (180-164 BC). For the legends and variant forms, see Maspero 1924: 14ƒƒ.
	[E] Prob. area etymon: PTai *hŋaiᴬ¹ ``moonlight'', S. dɨanᴬ¹-ŋaaiᴬ¹ ``full moon'', Po-ai *looŋᴮ²-haaiᴬ¹ ``moonlight'' (acc. to Gedney CAAAL 6, 1976: 70, ŋaaiᴬ¹ originally meant ``to lie face up'', perhaps connected with AA: Khmer /ŋə́əj/ ``to raise or hold up the head''). <> Note also Tamang ³ŋia ``full moon''.
	The semantic extension ``to face'' > ``moon'' is parallel to {wàng₄ 望}; thus é₂ 娥 may perhaps be the s. w. as {é₁ 俄}.
	[C] The first syllable may be related to {gèng₁ 恆} ``waxing'' (of the moon).
::Tamang	³ŋia	``full moon''
>:Prob. area etymon:
>:PTai *hŋaiᴬ¹ ``moonlight''
>:S. dɨanᴬ¹-ŋaaiᴬ¹ ``full moon''
>:Po-ai *looŋᴮ²-haaiᴬ¹ ``moonlight'' . < > Note also Tamang ³ŋia ``full moon''

ENTRY:810

GLOSS:"Aquatic reptile" [SW],
GLOSS:"salt-water crocodile".
	[E] Etymological possibilities are discussed by Carr (LTBA 13.2, 1990: 132ƒƒ); è has been related to words for ``fear'' ({è₆ 愕} 鄂噩), and to {è₄ 咢} ``beat the drum'' because some drums had crocodile / alligator skins. Note also PTai *ŋɨek ``mythological sea monster, dragon'' (Li F.; but Chamberlain *ŋwak); è is distinct from {tuó₃ 鼉} ``alligator''.
::PTai	*ŋɨek	``mythological sea monster, dragon''
>:Etymological possibilities are discussed by Carr
>:è has been related to words for ``fear'' , and to {è₄ 咢} ``beat the drum'' because some drums had crocodile / alligator skins. Note also PTai *ŋɨek ``mythological sea monster, dragon''
>:è is distinct from {tuó₃ 鼉} ``alligator''

ENTRY:828
HEAD:ér₁ 而
MC:Middle Chinese: ńźɨ 
LH:Later Han: ńə 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *nə
	[T] ONW ńə
GLOSS:"Whiskers" of an animal [Zhouli].
	[E] This word may be a cognate of {xū₄ 須鬚} ``beard'' (Pulleyblank EC 16, 1991: 43). After labial initials, there has been some dialectal confusion of OC *-o (母) and *-ə   (每) in the Shījīng, and this looks like a similar case which is strengthened by ér's use as a phonetic element in words with *-o (需) and *-on (耎).
	Alternatively, ér could perhaps be related to PTB *(r-)ney  or *-nəy ``hair'' (of head) (STC no. 292) > Gyarung rni ``head hair'', Garo kʰəni, Nung (t)əni.
	In either scenario the vowel correspondences are problematic, though.
	[C] Allofam: {sāi 思} (sɨ, sậi) ``bearded'' or ``white-haired'' [Zuo] (Pulleyblank).
::Gyarung	rni	``head hair''
>:This word may be a cognate of {xū₄ 須鬚} ``beard'' . After labial initials, there has been some dialectal confusion of OC *-o  and *-ə    in the Shījīng, and this looks like a similar case which is strengthened by ér's use as a phonetic element in words with *-o  and *-on

ENTRY:829
HEAD:ér₂ 而
MC:Middle Chinese: ńźɨ 
LH:Later Han: ńə 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *nə
	A common particle which links verbs (Norman 1988: 122), a resumptive emphatic particle [Shi] which originated perhaps as an unstressed variant of {rú₁ 如} ``be like'' (Pulleyblank 1995: 148) with the basic meaning ``-like, -ly'' ({§11.2.1}).
	[T] Sin S. SR ri (平), PR, LR rʅ
	[T] MGZY  Zhi (平) [ri]
	[T] ONW ńə
	[E] ST: This particle ér is possibly shared with WT: ni  an emphatic marker for nouns and nominal phrases (HST: 71); however, WT has no equivalent of rú from which ni might have been derived.
>:This particle ér is possibly shared with WT:
>:ni  an emphatic marker for nouns and nominal phrases
>:however
>:WT has no equivalent of rú from which ni might have been derived

ENTRY:830
HEAD:ér₃ 而

	{ěr₅} 爾

ENTRY:831
HEAD:ér₄ 兒
MC:Middle Chinese: ńźie 
LH:Later Han: ńe 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *ŋe 
OCB:Baxter Old Chinese: *ŋje
GLOSS:"Child, baby" [Shi] as young human being in general (Sagart 1999: 164).
	[T] Sin S. SR ri (平), PR, LR rʅ
	[T] MGZY  Zhi (平) [ri]
	[T] ONW ńe
	[E] Use as a diminutive suffix developed somewhat later than {zǐ₁ 子}, was widespread by the Tang dyn. (Norman 1988: 114). In Mǐn and other southern dialects, this suffix has almost disappeared except perhaps for traces in nasalization and in ``irreg.'' tones (Chen Zhongmin 1999, On the diminutives in Mǐn dialects, JCL monograph 14).
	Acc. to Chao (1968: 46) the Mand. suffix ér has 3 sources: (1) lǐ  裡 ``therein'' (e.g. zài zhèr ``here''); (2) rì 日 ``day'' (e.g. jīnr ``today''); (3) ér 兒.
	Syn. {zǐ₁ 子}.
>:Use as a diminutive suffix developed somewhat later than {zǐ₁ 子}, was widespread by the Tang dyn. . In Mǐn and other southern dialects, this suffix has almost disappeared except perhaps for traces in nasalization and in ``irreg.'' tones

ENTRY:832
HEAD:ér₄ 兒 = yá 伢
	[D] This is a div. I (j-less) southern dialect form ({§9.1.1}): Hénán ``child''
	[D] Yuè ⁵³ŋAː ᴬ¹ ``baby'' (Yue Hashimoto Phonology of Cantonese 1972: 322), Chángshā ŋa ``boy''.
	Also, the unique Kèjiā words for ``son'' mentioned under {zǐ₁ 子} may have developed from an OC form.
	Southern dial. have additional words for ``son'': K-Méixiàn laiᶜ, Huái naiᶜ (same etymon as ér 兒?).
	[E] Area word: TB: JP ʔŋai³³, tʃə³³-ʔŋai³³ ``baby'', Mru ŋia ``child'' (Löffler 1966: 146). AA: PSBahn. *ŋe ``baby'', Khmer ṅā /ŋíiə/ ~ /ŋaa/  ``be tender, delicate, lovable'', dialectal kūna ŋ̈āː ``baby'' (kūna ``child''); OMon ṅāk /ŋaik/ ``baby'', kwon ŋaak ``young child'' (kwon ``child'').
	Note also PMY *ŋau² ``child'', but Lushai also has a similar word.

ENTRY:837

	TB has the same root *na for both ``ear'' and ``nose''.

	A suffix forming adverbs ``-wise'' (< ``like'') [Shu] (DEZC: 147), derived from {rú₁ 如} with the suffix -i (Matisoff 1995a: 77); e.g. shì-ěr 適爾 (``happening-wise'':) ``by chance''. See {rú₁ 如} for allofams.

MC:Middle Chinese: bjwɐt 
LH:Later Han: buɑt 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *bat
GLOSS:"To plough, furrow" 坺 [Guoyu];
GLOSS:"earth thrown up by a ploughed furrow" 伐 [Zhouli].
GLOSS-NOTE:Perh. the s. w. as {fá₃ 伐罰} which includes the notions of
GLOSS:"chop, hack", as the earliest form of
GLOSS:"ploughing" was hacking with a hoe.
	[E] Commentators, including SW, consider this etymon to be the s. w. as {fā 發} ``come out'', hence ``lift out / up'' (earth). Alternatively, it may possibly be related to {fá₃ 伐罰} ``cut off, hew out'' (Qiu Xigui 2000: 294); and/or to {bá₂ 茇} ``roots of grass'' and id. ``to camp''.
>:Commentators, including SW, consider this etymon to be the s. w. as {fā 發} ``come out'', hence ``lift out / up'' . Alternatively, it may possibly be related to {fá₃ 伐罰} ``cut off, hew out''
>:and/or to {bá₂ 茇} ``roots of grass'' and id. ``to camp''

HEAD:fá₂ 伐 ⪤ fá 發

LH:Later Han: puɑt 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *pat
GLOSS:"To plough" (fields) tr. [Shi] is cognate or may simply be a graphic loan for LH buɑt.

ENTRY:853

GLOSS:"to cut" as in: to cut (i.e. make) an axehandle, spokes etc. [Shi] (Qiu Xigui 2000: 294). {fá₂ 伐} may be the same word.

ENTRY:867
HEAD:fán₄ 凡
MC:Middle Chinese: bjwɐm 
LH:Later Han: buɑm 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *bam (from earlier *bam or *bom)
GLOSS:"General(ly)" [Zuo],
GLOSS:"common" [Meng],
GLOSS:"every, all" [Shi]; ``general rule, pattern'' [Xun] (Harbsmeier 1981: 153).
	[T] Sin Sukchu SR vam (平) PR van
	[T] MGZY Hwam (平) [vam]
	[T] MTang bvuam < buam, ONW bam
	[E] ST: Lushai pumᴴ ``whole, all, everywhere''; WB pum ``form, model, pattern''. This word is usually thought related to Tai: S. pʰrɔɔmᶜ² ``together'' (under {xián₃ 咸}), but this is doubtful in light of the likely TB cognates without medial *r.
	[E] ST: WT byibs < bibs ``shape, figure, form'' (Simon, W. MSOS 32, 1929: 241). Alternatively, Yú Mǐn (1989: 20, see Jeon 1996: 103) related the CH word to WT babs ``shape, form, appearance''.
	Cognation of fǎ with fán is suggested by the semantic range of the former.
	For the vocalic differences, note the common ST *-im/p ~ *-um/p alternations ({§11.5.1}).
	OC and TB can be reconciled if we assume furthermore the common *u ~ *o variations ({§11.5.1}).
::WT	babs	``shape, form, appearance''
>:Lushai pumᴴ ``whole, all, everywhere''
>:WB pum ``form, model, pattern''. This word is usually thought related to Tai:
>:S. pʰrɔɔmᶜ² ``together'' , but this is doubtful in light of the likely TB cognates without medial *r
>:WT byibs < bibs ``shape, figure, form'' . Alternatively
>:Yú Mǐn  related the CH word to WT babs ``shape, form, appearance''

Matisoff (1997: 44f; LL 1.2, 2000: 144ƒƒ) sets up a large ST wf that includes also {huī₂ 煇輝暉}.
	The TB semantic field suggests that {bàn₄ 瓣} ``petals of a flower'' and {pā 葩} ``flowers, blossoms'' are the same etymon, but that {fén₃ 焚} is unrelated.

ENTRY:882
HEAD:fāng₂ 方
MC:Middle Chinese: pjwaŋ 
LH:Later Han: puɑŋ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *paŋ
GLOSS:"Two boats lashed side by side" [SW] > vb. tr.
GLOSS:"to lash (boats chuán 船 / zhōu 舟) together" – in order to cross a river [Zhuang],
GLOSS:"to cross (a river) by raft" [Shi].
	[E] The meaning ``raft'' seems to derive naturally from {fāng₁ 方} ``square'' (Egerod CAAAL 6, 1976: 58). Yet a boat is not necessarily square, and the special reading pwâŋᶜ also sets this word apart from ``square''.
	This etymon is an area word for ``raft'': WB pʰoŋ, bʰoŋ ``raft, float'', Kachin pʰoŋ  id., perhaps also Mikir -pʰán ``raft''.
	<> Tai: S. pʰuaŋᴮ² < *b- ``pontoon, raft''.
	<> The ultimate source is AA and AN: Mon kɓaŋ ``sea-going vessel, ship''; PAN *qaBaŋ ``boat'' (Blust; Peiros and Starostin CAAAL 22, 1984: 125; Mahdi 1999: 147f).
	To the same AA word belongs {háng₄ 航杭}.
::Mon	kɓaŋ	``sea-going vessel, ship''
>:The meaning ``raft'' seems to derive naturally from {fāng₁ 方} ``square'' . Yet a boat is not necessarily square, and the special reading pwâŋᶜ also sets this word apart from ``square''

ENTRY:886
HEAD:fāng₄ 方
MC:Middle Chinese: pjwaŋ 
LH:Later Han: puɑŋ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *paŋ
GLOSS:"Method" [Lunyu, Shiji],
GLOSS:"law, norm, standard" [Xun].
GLOSS-NOTE:This may be the s. w. as {fāng₁ 方}.
	[E] Etymology not certain, perhaps ST: WT byaŋ-ba ``skill, experience'' ⪤ sbyoŋ-pa, sbyaŋs ``to train, exercise, study, learn, practice'' (HST: 143). Alternatively, the items may belong to AA: Khmer brāṅa /príiəŋ/ ``to represent the shape of, to sketch, design …'' < rāṅa /ríiəŋ/ ``body build, form, shape, figure'' (Jenner / Pou 1982: 233); if related, this group seems to belong to an AA wf which includes {zhuàng₁ 狀} ``form, shape''. ``Law, norm, standard'' etc. is a common semantic extension of ``form, shape, pattern'', cf. fǎ 法 ({fán₄ 凡}).

>:Khmer brāṅa /príiəŋ/ ``to represent the shape of, to sketch, design …'' < rāṅa /ríiəŋ/ ``body build, form, shape, figure''
>:if related, this group seems to belong to an AA wf which includes {zhuàng₁ 狀} ``form, shape''. ``Law, norm, standard'' etc. is a common semantic extension of ``form, shape, pattern'', cf. fǎ 法

ENTRY:890

::OKhmer	pnaṅ /pnɔŋ/ 	``screen, partition, covering''
>:Etymology not certain, prob. ST:
>:WT baŋ-ba ``storeroom, storehouse''
>:WB waŋᴮ ``fence''
>:alternatively WT braŋ ``dwelling, house'' in pʰo-braŋ, braŋ-kʰaŋ

ENTRY:896
HEAD:fēi₁ 非

	[T] ONW pui
	[E] Fēi 非 is a fusion of bù wéi 不維 ({bù₁ 不}, {wéi₂ 惟}) which is still found in the OB for the later fēi: QY pjəu-jiwi 4, *pə-wi. Fēi is rare in Shījīng where {fěi₁ 匪棐} is used instead.

ENTRY:902
HEAD:fēi₄ 飛

	[D] PMin *̆̆̆p̆ye
GLOSS:"To fly" [Shi].
	[E] Area word: PTB *pur ~ *pir (STC no. 398) > WT ’pʰur-ba ``to fly''; Nung əpʰr ``to shake'' (cloth), kʰoŋ-pʰr ``moth''. <> AA: PVM *pər ``to fly'' [Ferlus]; PMonic *par, Munda apir ``to fly''; Wa-Lawa-Bulang *pɤr, PNBahn. *păr.
	For ST *-r > OC *-i, see {§7.7.4}; fēi is related to {fēn₆ 翂} ``to fly'', prob. also {fǒu₁ 不} (pjəuᴮ) ``to soar'' (ST *-r > OC open syllable, {§7.7.5}).
	However, {fān₁ 弁拚翻} ``to fly'' is unrelated.
	Boltz relates this word, which is also written 蜚, to the wf {fēi₁ 非} (JAOS 120.2, 2000: 220).

ENTRY:912
HEAD:fèi₃ 肺
MC:Middle Chinese: pʰjwɐiᶜ

GLOSS-NOTE:CH aspiration is symbolic for breathing {§5.8.5}.
	[T] ONW pʰei > pʰuei
	[E] The OC form is close to items found in various languages in the area, but the exact relationships are elusive due to the uncertainty of the PCH form and the sound-symbolic nature of the word: PVM *p-soːs > p-hoːc > poːc / pʰoːc ``lungs''. <> Tai: S. pɔɔtᴰ¹ᴸ < *pɨɔt ``lung'' (Li F. 1976: 43) ⪤ S. pʰɔɔtᴰ¹ ``breathe, inhale'' (Manomaivi bool 1975: 124), prob. a CH loans.
	Matisoff (1978: 113ƒƒ) sets up, among others, a ST form *p-(r-)wap: PL *(ʃ-)papᴸ; Chepang pop (Bodman 1980: 115), which corresponds to the final in a different root: WT glo-ba < glop ``lungs, side''; TMTG *glwap²/¹ ``lung''.
::TMTG	*glwap²/¹	``lung''
>:The OC form is close to items found in various languages in the area, but the exact relationships are elusive due to the uncertainty of the PCH form and the sound-symbolic nature of the word:

ENTRY:915
HEAD:fèi₆ 廢
MC:Middle Chinese: pjwɐiᶜ 
LH:Later Han: puɑs 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *pats
GLOSS:"To remove, reject, disregard, neglect, fail" [Shi],
GLOSS:"to fall" [Zuo] >
GLOSS:"to expel noxious influences, purify" 祓 [Zuo].
GLOSS-NOTE:This word is hardly derived from {fā 發} (so Karlgren 1956: 11), but is certainly related to {fá 乏}.
	[E] ST: WT ’bab-pa, babs ``to move downward, fall down'' ⪤ ’bebs-p, pʰab ``to throw down, cast, down'' (Bodman 1980: 49). <> Tai: S. bap⁴ ``weak, exhausted, worn out''.
	This wf and {bài₁ 敗} ``destroy'', {pí₇ 罷疲} ``exhausted'', {bì₁₀ 敝弊斃} ``worn out'' with the stems *pap(s), *pal ~ *pai(ts) are phonetically and semantically similar and flow into each other, note the partial synony mity of fá ``exhausted'' with pí (Pulleyblank 1962: 215 and Wáng Lì 1982: 500 consider some or all of them cognates).
	Lushai paiʔᴸ < pais ``to throw away, discard, annul'' where final *-s could derive from *-s, *-ts or *-ps, is synonymous with fèi, but formally similar to {bì₁₀ 敝弊斃} *be(t)s < *bai(t)s. {bài₁ 敗} looks like a possible derivation from this wf, and the AA comparanda cited there may also be connected with it.
	JP prai³³ ``be effaced, settled and forgotten (feud), healed'' (old sore), WB prai ``be wasted, become weak'' [Matisoff 1974: 161] also may belong to one of these stems. Additional allofams may be {biǎn₄ 貶} (so Karlgren 1956: 18); {bá₁ 犮}.
::WB	prai	``be wasted, become weak''
>:WT ’bab-pa, babs ``to move downward, fall down'' ⪤ ’bebs-p, pʰab ``to throw down, cast, down'' . < > Tai:
>:S. bap⁴ ``weak, exhausted, worn out''

ENTRY:916
HEAD:fèi₆ 廢 ⪤ fá 乏
MC:Middle Chinese: bjwɐp 
LH:Later Han: buɑp 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *bap
GLOSS:"To lack" [Zuo],
GLOSS:"exhaust" [Meng],
GLOSS:"neglect, disregard" [Zhuang] (Yú Mǐn 1948: 44). In BI, the character fǎ 法 (pjwɐp) [puɑp] *pap also occurs in the meaning ``neglect, disregard'' (Baxter 1992: 350) where it prob. stands for the present fá 乏.
	[T] MTang bvuap, ONW buap < bap

ENTRY:917
HEAD:fēn₁ 分
MC:Middle Chinese: pjuən 
LH:Later Han: pun 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *pən (prob. < *pun)
GLOSS:"To divide, separate" [BI, Shu].
GLOSS-NOTE:The graph shows a thing cut in two with a knife.
	Acc. to Downer (1959: 284) commentators to the Zuǒzhuàn read the word in tone C when meaning ``distribute, give relief'' (exoactive {§4.3}).
	[T] Sin Sukchu SR fun (平), PR fən
	[T] MGZY H(w)un (平) [fun ?]
	[T] ONW pun
	[E] ST *pun: JP pʰun⁵⁵ ``part'' (unit of weight) ⪤ pʰun³³ ``part'' (monetary unit), Lushai buŋᴴ / bunᴸ ``to cut, break or divide into two or more pieces for'' (? ⪤ buulᴸ / bulʔᴸ ``be broken off, lopped off'', see {běn 本}); WB puiŋᴮ ``divide, sever'' ⪤ ə-puiŋᴮ ``division, part'' (there is no final -uin in WB [the counterpart of PTB *-un], therefore the final may have shifted in this and a few other etyma to -uiŋ [< PTB *-uŋ], see {§6.4.2}). The word {běn 本} ``tree stump / trunk'' may be cognate.
	Some TB words in final *-l are sometimes associated with fēn: Lushai pualᴴ ``lot, share, portion''.
	WT ’bul-ba, pʰul ``to give'' something to someone of higher rank, represent, report, offering, gift’ is semantically somewhat distant but could also belong to this wf.
	Some foreign items under {bàn₁ 半} are sometimes associated with the present etymon.
::WT	’bul-ba, pʰul	``to give''
>:ST *pun:
>:JP pʰun⁵⁵ ``part''  ⪤ pʰun³³ ``part''
>:Lushai buŋᴴ / bunᴸ ``to cut, break or divide into two or more pieces for''
>:WB puiŋᴮ ``divide, sever'' ⪤ ə-puiŋᴮ ``division, part'' . The word {běn 本} ``tree stump / trunk'' may be cognate

ENTRY:918
HEAD:fēn₁ 分 ⪤ fèn 分

LH:Later Han: bunᶜ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *bəns
	[T] ONW bun

GLOSS:"share" [Liji].
	[<] exopass. of fēn 分 ``divide'' ({§4.4})

ENTRY:919
HEAD:fēn₂ 雰氛
MC:Middle Chinese: phjuən 
LH:Later Han: pʰun 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *phən 
OCB:Baxter Old Chinese: *phjən
GLOSS:"Mist" [Yupian; GY],
GLOSS:"hoar-frost" 雰 [Chuci] >
GLOSS:"inauspicious vapors" (as evil omen) 氛 [GY 112].
	[E] Prob. several distinct etyma have coalesced in this wf fēn and in {fěn 粉} ``flour'', but the various sources are phonologically and semantically ambiguous and difficult to disentan gle, as words of the shape LH pun and their possible outside relations have meanings ranging from sky - weather - clouds - mist - snow - hoarfrost to flour - dust. Any foreign syllable pə/un, pə/ur, pə/ul, as well as pan/r/l could correspond to LH pun.
GLOSS:1:PMY *mpanᶜ [Wáng FS; Downer 1982 *ɴpəːn³]
GLOSS:"snow", PY *ɴbwon⁵  [Purnell]
GLOSS:"cloud, snow". MY ``snow'' occurs in Chǔcí, while CH ``mist'' agrees with Yao ``cloud''.
	Sagart (ICSTLL 1994: 7) relates this word to {fēn₄ 紛} ``mixed'' and argues that the MY word is likely to have been borrowed from CH
GLOSS:2:Tai: S. bonᴬ¹ < PTai *ʔb-
GLOSS:"sky, above", Saek bɯnᴬ¹
GLOSS:"sky, weather", PKS *ɓun¹ ``sky''; Benedict (in Edmondson / Solnit 1988: 329f.) suggests wider connections with AN.
GLOSS:3:Lushai vaanᴸ (v- corresponds to labial stops in other lgs.)
GLOSS:"sky, heaven".
GLOSS:4:PTB *s-pᵂa(l)
GLOSS:"frost, snow" > WT ba-mo
GLOSS:"snow", Amdo wal, Dulong tɯ³¹-wăn⁵³ ``snow'' etc. [Matisoff LL 1.2, 2000: 147].
GLOSS:5:Lushai vuurᴴ
GLOSS:"hoar-frost, ice, snow".
GLOSS:6:PKiranti pʰùl
GLOSS:"flour", WB pʰun
GLOSS:"dust" (CVST 1: 7), n³¹-bun⁵⁵ ``dust''; perhaps also WT spun-pa ~ sbur-ma ``chaff, husks'', but spun is prob. cognate to bud- etc. ``to blow'', spur- to spur-ba ``make fly up''.
	<> PVM *buːlʔ  ``dust'' may also be related, then also Tai: S. monᴮ¹ ``dusty'', Saek mulᴬ² ``dust''.
GLOSS:7:{fěn 粉}
GLOSS:"peeled (rice), flour", PMY *mpanᴮ
GLOSS:"flour".
	Haudricourt / Strecker (TP 77, 1991: 339) believe that the CH word is a loan from PMY *mpanᴮ ``flour'', Sagart (ICSTLL 1994: 7) argues the opposite.
	For the close semantic relationship between ``sky'' (item 2) and ``cloud, mist'' (item 1) see {wù₁₂ 霧}.
	The Shìmíng (Shì tiān) compares fēn 雰 ``hoarfrost'' to {fěn 粉} ``flour'', the two MY words (item 1 and item 7) would parallel the CH forms.
::PMY	*mpanᴮ	``flour''
>:Prob. several distinct etyma have coalesced in this wf fēn and in {fěn 粉} ``flour'', but the various sources are phonologically and semantically ambiguous and difficult to disentan gle, as words of the shape LH pun and their possible outside relations have meanings ranging from sky - weather - clouds - mist - snow - hoarfrost to flour - dust. Any foreign syllable pə/un, pə/ur, pə/ul, as well as pan/r/l could correspond to LH pun

ENTRY:920
HEAD:fēn₂ 雰氛 ⪤ fēn,fén 氛
MC:Middle Chinese: bjuən 
LH:Later Han: bun 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *bən
GLOSS:"Ominous vapors or clouds in the sky" (inauspicious in the Zuǒzhuàn passages) [Zuo, Xiang 27, 5; Zhao 15, 2; SW 211];
GLOSS:"auspicious vapors" [GY 110]; the GY assigns different meanings to MC bjuən and pʰjuən (above) which may be a later attempt to differentiate the two.

ENTRY:924

	{fēn₂} 雰雰 {fēn₃} 雰雰

GLOSS:"tangled").
	[E] ST *pol (?) : Lushai pɔɔlᴴ ``to associate with, keep company with, have sexual intercourse; group, party, herd'' ⪤ pɔlʔᴸ ``to mix, mingle, together'' (CVST 1: 62).

ENTRY:932
HEAD:fén₄ 墳
MC:Middle Chinese: bjuən

OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *bən
	[T] MTang bvun ONW bun
GLOSS:"Big (head, drum), big-horned" >
GLOSS:"greatness" 墳 [Shi],
GLOSS:"big drum" 鼖 [Shu]; ``well-set (fruit)'' 蕡 [Shi]; ``ram'' 羒 [SW], ``sheep-shaped demon'' 羵 [Guoyu]; ``tumulus'' 墳 [Li]; in most modern dialects ``a grave''. ``Raised bank, bank of a river'' {fén₅ 墳濆} may be the same word, unless it is a vocalic variant of pín 頻 ``river bank, edge'' (so Wáng Lì 1982: 541) of the bin ~  bun type alternations (see under {bīn₂ 濱}; {§11.5.1}).
	[E] Area etymon: Lushai tiᴸ-puunᴴ ``to increase (as water, wound). <> OKhmer vva(n)i, Khmer būna /puun/ ‘to amass, accumulate, to heap, stack, pile''.

ENTRY:940
HEAD:fěn 粉
MC:Middle Chinese: pjuənᴮ 
LH:Later Han: punᴮ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *bənʔ
GLOSS:"Peeled (rice)" [Shu],
GLOSS:"flour" [Li].
	[E] There are several possible etymologies (see {fēn₂ 雰氛} for additional considerations): (1) ST *pul: PKiranti pʰùl ``flour'', WB pʰun ``dust'' etc., see {fēn₂ 雰氛} item (6). — (2) Haudricourt / Strecker (TP 77, 1991: 339) believe that the CH word is a loan from PMY *mpanᴮ ``flour''; Sagart (ICSTLL 1994: 7) argues the opposite. Both in MY and CH ``flour'' and {fēn₂ 雰氛} ``mist, hoarfrost'' may be cognate.
::PMY	*mpanᴮ	``flour''
>:There are several possible etymologies :
>:ST *pul:
>:PKiranti pʰùl ``flour''

>:Sagart  argues the opposite. Both in MY and CH ``flour'' and {fēn₂ 雰氛} ``mist, hoarfrost'' may be cognate

ENTRY:955
HEAD:fēng₇ 風
MC:Middle Chinese: pjuŋ 
LH:Later Han: puŋ < puəm 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *pəm 
OCB:Baxter Old Chinese: *p(r)jə/um
GLOSS:"Wind, air, tune" [Shi].
GLOSS-NOTE:Dèng Xiǎo-huā 鄧曉花 (YYWZX 1994.9: 142) suggests that the word fēi-lián 飛廉, glossed 疾風
GLOSS:"ill wind" in Shǐjì, is actually a dialect variant of fēng.
	[T] Sin Sukchu SR fuŋ (平)
	[T] MGZY hwung (平) [fuŋ]
	[T] MTang pfuŋ, ONW puŋ
	[D] PMin *piɔŋ
	[E] ``Wind'' fēng is thought to be connected with Tai: S. lomᴬ² < *dlu̯omᴬ² ``wind'', PKS *hlwum¹ (Benedict 1976: 99); a 12th cent. Korean word for ``wind'' is read pallam  (Zhāng Xīngyà YWYJ 1996.4: 9) which also suggests a possible medial *l in a proto-form.
	The Wa-Lawa-Bulang word *p-hom ``air'' is closer to OC, but may be a loan.
	TB languages have a word with final velar as in MC: KN *m-puŋ ``air, wind'' [IST: 27]. {fān₂ 帆} ``sail'' is prob. cognate.
::KN	*m-puŋ	``air, wind''
>:``Wind'' fēng is thought to be connected with Tai:
>:S. lomᴬ² < *dlu̯omᴬ² ``wind''
>:PKS *hlwum¹
>:a 12th cent. Korean word for ``wind'' is read pallam   which also suggests a possible medial *l in a proto-form

ENTRY:967
HEAD:fǒu₁ 不
MC:Middle Chinese: pjəuᴮ 
LH:Later Han: puᴮ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *pəʔ 
OCB:Baxter Old Chinese: *pjəʔ
GLOSS:"To soar" [Lü, SW] is first attested in the (ca. 239 BC) Lüshì chūnqiū; it appears therefore to be a late word. However, the original OB graph has been interpreted as a soaring bird (so SW; Karlgren GSR no. 999a) in which case the word would be very old.
	Fǒu is a cognate of {fēn₆ 翂} ``to soar'' (ST *-r > OC zero final, {§7.7.5}) and prob. related to PTB *pur ~ *pir ``to fly'' ({fēi₄ 飛}).
::PTB	*pur ~ *pir	``to fly''

ENTRY:968
HEAD:fǒu₂ 否
	{bù₁} 不
	(fu1)  □ A Min dial word for ``scum, froth'':
	Fúzhōu pʰuoʔ⁸, Fúān pʰutᴰ², Amoy pʰeʔᴰ², is from a MK substrate: Viet. bọt ``scum, bubbles, froth'' (Norman / Mei 1976: 298).
	There may also be a connection with Lushai pʰuulᴴ ``scum, foam''.
::Lushai	pʰuulᴴ	``scum, foam''

ENTRY:969
HEAD:fū₂ 夫
MC:Middle Chinese: pju 
LH:Later Han: puɑ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *pa
GLOSS:"Man, husband"; suffix for men of various occupations, e.g. nóng-fū 農夫
GLOSS:"farmer, farm laborer" (to be distinguished from nóng-fù 農父
GLOSS:"minister of agriculture", see {fù₁ 父}); measure word for ordinary and low ranking people [BI, Shi].
	[T] Sin Sukchu SR fu (平)
	[T] MGZY Hwu (平) [fu]
	[T] MTang pfu < pfuo, ONW puo
	[E] ST: PTB *pa (STC: 174 n. 463: *(p)wa; Matisoff LL 1.2, 2000: 153ƒƒ) > WT suffix -pa for nouns, especially male concepts as opposed to female ones. JP wa³³ ``man'' (male), ``male'', Lushai paaᴸ ``male person''.
	This word prob. belongs to the same root as {fù₁ 父} ``father'' (so Matisoff op. cit.).
::Lushai	paaᴸ	``male person''
>:PTB *pa wa
>:Matisoff LL 1.2, 2000:
>:153ƒƒ) >
>:WT suffix -pa for nouns, especially male concepts as opposed to female ones. JP wa³³ ``man'' , ``male''
>:Lushai paaᴸ ``male person''

ENTRY:973
HEAD:fú₁ 夫
MC:Middle Chinese: bju 
LH:Later Han: buɑ (or puɑ ?) 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *ba or *pa ?
GLOSS:"That" [Shi, Zuo].
GLOSS-NOTE:Pulleyblank (1995: 165) suggests that the earlier initial might have been *p- since bǐ 彼 is derived from fú; the reading fú OC *ba
GLOSS:"introductory particle" (Graham BSOAS 35,1: 85-110) may have been applied to the rare word fú
GLOSS:"that".
	[E] ST: PL *m-ba¹, WT pʰa ``beyond, onward'' (HST: 147).
::WT	pʰa	``beyond, onward''
>:PL *m-ba¹
>:WT pʰa ``beyond, onward''

ENTRY:981
HEAD:fú₄ 伏服 ⪤ fù 伏
MC:Middle Chinese: bjəuᶜ 
LH:Later Han: buᶜ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *bəkh
GLOSS:"To hatch" [Li] is an allofam of fú (so Karlgren 1956: 12). It is still current in Mǐn: Fúzhōu pouᶜ², Xiàmén puᶜ².
	This word has several variants: fú 孚桴 (pʰju) [pʰuo] *pho ``to hatch'' [Dadai Liji]; bào 菢 (bâuᶜ) [GY]. Fù has been borrowed by Tai: S. vakᴰ² ``to hatch'' (Manomaivibool 1975: 129).
	[<] exoactive / transitive of fú 伏服 (bjuk) ({§4.3}).
	[E] ST: Chepang bhyuk-sa ``to hatch''.
	[C] Possible allofams: {fù₁₄ 蝮} ``snake'', {bó₁₀ 踣} ``prostrate'', perhaps also {pá₁ 爬} ``crawl''.
>:Chepang bhyuk-sa ``to hatch''

ENTRY:985
HEAD:fú₈ 弗
MC:Middle Chinese: pjuət 
LH:Later Han: put 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *pət 
OCB:Baxter Old Chinese: *pjut
GLOSS:"Gust of wind" [Shi].
	[E] A sound-symbolic area word: ST: WT ’bud-pa, bus ``to blow'' intr. ⪤ ’bud-pa, pʰus, dbu ``to blow'' tr. ⪤ bud ``cloud of dust'' ⪤ sbud-pa ``bellows''.<> MK *puut, *p[əə]t ``to blow'' (Shorto 2006 #1023). The source of the Tai word (MK?, OC?) had the vowel ə: PT *b-: S. pʰatᴰ².
	Many TB languages have initial m- in words for ``blow'' as WB hmut ``blow with the mouth''; but these items seem to be unrelated and derived from ``mouth'', see {wěn₁ 吻}.
	CVST 1: 8 adds words for ``dust'' which may be related to the WT etyma: WB pʰut ``dust'', Lushai pʰutᴸ ``flowery, powdery''.
::Lushai	pʰutᴸ	``flowery, powdery''
>:A sound-symbolic area word:

>:WT ’bud-pa, bus ``to blow'' intr. ⪤ ’bud-pa, pʰus, dbu ``to blow'' tr. ⪤ bud ``cloud of dust'' ⪤ sbud-pa ``bellows''.< > MK *puut, *pt ``to blow'' . The source of the Tai word  had the vowel ə:

ENTRY:986
HEAD:fú₉ 拂
MC:Middle Chinese: pʰjuət 
LH:Later Han: pʰut 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *phət
GLOSS:"To brush off, shake off" [Li, Zuo].
GLOSS-NOTE:CH aspiration is associated with forceful motion {§5.8.5}.
	[E] The etymology is not certain: (1) fú may be an area word: PYao *pʰwot ``sweep, clear away''. It is not clear if and how these are related to Tai: S. patᴰ¹S < *p- ``to wipe off, brush off'' (Li F. 1976: 43); PKS *phjit⁷ (i?) ``to sweep''; IN pat’pat’ ``to shake, clear'' (Benedict AT: 403).
	<> Wa-Lawa-Bulang *(n)-pʰɔs ``to brush off'' comes closest to OC semantically and phonologically. (2) It could be related to {fú₁₀ 茀} ``eliminate''. (3) It could be a ST item from a root *prut ``to brush'', OC *phut could theoretically derive from earlier *sprut (aspiration from loss of causative *s, medial r hardly ever occurs after aspirated initials), see {Table S-2} [ Brush, comb, scrape ] under {shuā 刷} for an overview. Finally, this word may be connected with {bǐ₆ 筆} ``writing brush''.
::Wa-Lawa-Bulang	*(n)-pʰɔs	``to brush off''
>:The etymology is not certain:
>:fú may be an area word:
>:PYao *pʰwot ``sweep, clear away''. It is not clear if and how these are related to Tai:
>:S. patᴰ¹S < *p- ``to wipe off, brush off''
>:PKS *phjit⁷  ``to sweep''
>:IN pat’pat’ ``to shake, clear''

ENTRY:990
HEAD:fú₁₃ 沸
MC:Middle Chinese: pjwət 
LH:Later Han: put 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *pət
	[T] ONW put
GLOSS:"Be gushing, rushing" (as spring, water, wind) [Shi].
	[E] ST: PTB *brup ~ *prup  (STC no. 151) ``to gush forth'': WT ’brup-pa ``cause to overflow, gush, spout forth'' (Bodman 1985: 150), JP ’pʰrup³¹ ``to squirt'' (as water from mouth). It is not clear if and how the following may be related: Kachin bɔp  ``foam, froth'' (= swelling water), Rawang (Nung) thi bɔp ``bubble'' (thi ``water'') (STC: 20 n. 72).
	Matisoff links this etymon to TB words for ``calf of leg'' etc.
	For the difference in final consonants, see {§6.7}.
	Although this word is prob. related to {fèi₄ 沸} ``bubble up'' (Bodman 1985: 150), the final consonants of the respective TB cognates differ (-p vs. -t).

ENTRY:991
HEAD:fú₁₄ 韍芾
MC:Middle Chinese: pjuət 
LH:Later Han: put 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *pət (= *put)
GLOSS:"Ceremonial apron" as knee cover,
GLOSS:"knee cover" 芾 [Shi], 韍 [Li].
	[E] ST: PTB *put > WT pus-mo ~ pis-mo ``knee'' (STC: 181; HPTB: 368), Purik puksmo, Amdo *pig-mo < PTib *pu(t)s-mo ~ *puks-mo (from *puts ?), *pi(t)s-mo (Beyer 1992: 33); Nung pʰaŋ-pʰit ``knee'', ur-pʰut ``elbow''; JP pʰut³¹ ``to kneel'', lə³¹-pʰut³¹ ``knee''. Bodman (1980: 116) connects the CH word to WT pʰub ``shield''.
	The basic meaning could be ``vertical cover'' (> ``screen, knee cover, knee''), then the word would be the same etymon as {fú₁₁ 茀} ``screen, cover'' and perhaps {fú₁₅ 黻茀} ``emblem-adorned''.
	Perh. also related to {bìn₃ 髕臏} ``kneecap''.
	Partial syn. are {bì₂₂ 髀} ``thighbone'', nor to {féi₂ 腓} ``calf of leg''.
::WT	pʰub	``shield''
>:PTB *put >
>:WT pus-mo ~ pis-mo ``knee''

>:Amdo *pig-mo <
>:PTib *pus-mo ~ *puks-mo , *pis-mo

ENTRY:1011
HEAD:fǔ₅ 甫
MC:Middle Chinese: pjuᴮ 
LH:Later Han: puɑᴮ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *paʔ
	An honorific suffix attached to names of high-ranking men, marks also respected persons engaged in a certain activity, e.g. cóng-fǔ 從父 (= 甫) ``followers'' (of a respected clan) [BI, Shi]. This suffix is written {fù₁ 父} in the BI and seems to be a variant or cognate of same.
	Some TB languages have parallel developments where the cognate PTB *-pa is a nominalizing suffix, e.g.
	WT tʰa-ga-pa (< *tak-a-pa) ``weaver'' from tʰag-pa ``to weave'' [LaPolla, LTBA 17.1, 1994: 77].
::WT	tʰa-ga-pa (< *tak-a-pa)	``weaver''

ENTRY:1012
HEAD:fǔ₆ 甫
	{bù₃} 布

ENTRY:1013
HEAD:fǔ₇ 甫
MC:Middle Chinese: pjuᴮ 
LH:Later Han: puɑᴮ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *paʔ
GLOSS:"To begin" [Zhouli] is cognate to {fāng₃ 方} (Pulleyblank 1962: 233).

ENTRY:1014
HEAD:fǔ₈ 輔
	{fú₂} 扶

ENTRY:1015
HEAD:fǔ₉ 膚
MC:Middle Chinese: pju 
LH:Later Han: puɑ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *pa
GLOSS:"Human skin" >
GLOSS:"skin" figuratively [Shi].
	[E] This word is usually considered cognate to PTB *s-pak > WT -lpags ``skin'' (Bodman 1980: 132; HST: 134), and to Tai-S. plɨakᴰ¹ᴸ < *pl- ``husk, bark'' (Li F. 1976: 41), also PSBahn. *pəloːk ``skin''. However, the WT word may instead be related to pò 䨣 (pʰâk) *phlak ``hide soaked in rain'' [SW], which, however, could be just a dictionary word (the SW definition looks like a description of the graph, implying that its real etymology and meaning was a matter of speculation for Xǔ Shèn). Note also luò 𩊚, LH lɑk ``raw skin, hide'' [Lü] which may be connected.
::LH	lɑk	``raw skin, hide''
>:This word is usually considered cognate to PTB *s-pak >
>:WT -lpags ``skin'' , and to Tai-S. plɨakᴰ¹ᴸ < *pl- ``husk, bark'' , also PSBahn. *pəloːk ``skin''. However, the WT word may instead be related to pò 䨣  *phlak ``hide soaked in rain'' , which, however, could be just a dictionary word . Note also luò 𩊚
>:LH lɑk ``raw skin, hide''  which may be connected

ENTRY:1018
HEAD:fù₁ 父

LH:Later Han: buɑᴮ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *baʔ

	[T] Sin Sukchu SR fu (上)
	[T] MGZY hwu (上) [vu]
	[T] MTang bvu < bvuo, ONW buo,
	[N] Mand. bà-bà 爸爸 may be the col. version. As suffix it has the same function as the {fǔ₅ 甫} (prob. cognate), e.g. nóng-fù 農父 ``minister of agriculture'' (to be distinguished from nóng-fū 農夫 ``farmer, farm laborer'', see {fū₂ 夫}); or the suffix fù may simply be intended to write fǔ, especially in the BI. {fū₂ 夫} may be from the same root.
	[E] ST: a common onomatopoetic word ``father'': PTB *pa (STC: 174 n. 463) > WT pʰa, WB ə-bhaᶜ, ə-phaᶜ; JP wa⁵¹; Lushai paᶠ < paaʔ . <> PTai *b-: S. pʰɔɔᴮ² ``father''.
>:a common onomatopoetic word ``father'':
>:PTB *pa  >
>:WT pʰa
>:WB ə-bhaᶜ, ə-phaᶜ
>:JP wa⁵¹
>:Lushai paᶠ < paaʔ . < > PTai *b-:

ENTRY:1020
HEAD:fù₃ 付
MC:Middle Chinese: pjuᶜ 
LH:Later Han: puoᶜ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *poh
	[T] MTang pfu < pfuo ONW puo
GLOSS:"To hand over, give" [BI, Shu].
	[<] exoactive of fǔ 府 (pjuᴮ) ``accumulate'' ({§4.3}).

ENTRY:1021
HEAD:fù₃ 付 ⪤ fǔ 府
MC:Middle Chinese: pjuᴮ 
LH:Later Han: puoᴮ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *poʔ
GLOSS:"Store-house" >
GLOSS:"repository" [Zhouli],
GLOSS:"treasury" [Lunyu], ``magazine'' 府 [Zuo] > ``the bowels'' 腑 [Huainanzi]; ``accumulate'' 府 [Shu] (Karlgren 1956: 6). GY says 腑 is the s. w. as fǔ 府, Wáng Lì (1982: 200) points to the semantic parallel zàng 藏 (dzâŋᶜ) ``storehouse'' >  臟 ``intestines'' (under {cáng 藏}).
	However, 腑 may be a separate word, belonging to {fù₄ 胕}.

GLOSS:"symbol, to tally".
	[<] tone A nominalization derived from fù 附垘 below ({§3.1}).

ENTRY:1023

	[<] perhaps endopass. of fù 付 (pjuᶜ) ({§4.6}).

ENTRY:1024

OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *boh

	[E] ST and area word: PTB *(s-)pu ⪤ *(s-)bu ``belly, stomach'' (Matisoff LL 1.2, 2000: 165). On the other hand, this word may belong to {fù₃ 付} (note 腑 ``bowels'').
	Perh. related to {fù₁₃ 腹}.

ENTRY:1028
HEAD:fù₇ 阜
MC:Middle Chinese: bjəuᴮ 
LH:Later Han: buᴮ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *buʔ 
OCB:Baxter Old Chinese: *b(r)juʔ
	[T] MTang bvu ONW bu
GLOSS:"Big mound, earthen hill" [Shi]; prob. =
GLOSS:"be big and fat, ample" {fù₈ 阜}.
	[E] Prob. the same etymon as {fù₈ 阜}. For wider relations see {§2.5.1}.
	This group prob. does not belong to the wf. {bèi₄ 倍} ``double'' (so Wáng Lì 1982: 103), although in a Khmer parallel, the notion ``swelling mass, heap, mound, add on'' are expressed by the same stem /bòok/ ``swelling mass'', baṃnūka /pumnuuk/ ``heap, pile, stack, rick'' < -būka /-puuk/ ``mass, mound, group''.
	AA ⇒ Lepcha bok ``to heap up'' (Forrest JAOS 82, 1962: 334); Proto-Koch *bok ``to swell'' [Burling 1959: 444].
	If not connected with {fù₈ 阜}, then perhaps cognate to AA: PSBahn. *buəj ``hilltop''.
	For CH tone B for foreign -k, see {§3.2.2}.
::Proto-Koch	*bok	``to swell''
>:Prob. the same etymon as {fù₈ 阜}. For wider relations see {§2.5.1}

GLOSS:"Large", abstract as in
GLOSS:"largest thing possible" [Zhuang].
	[E] ST: WB pʰuᶜ ``to swell'' ⪤ pu ``to bulge'', WT ’bo-ba, ’bos ``to swell (up), rise, sprout'', perhaps also JP pu⁵⁵ ``to bloom, bud'', WT ’bu-ba, ’bus ``to open, unfold'' (flower) (CVST 1: 88). ENTRY:1034
HEAD:fù₉ 婦
MC:Middle Chinese: bjəuᴮ 
LH:Later Han: buᴮ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *bəʔ 
OCB:Baxter Old Chinese: *bjəʔ
GLOSS:"Woman, wife" [OB, BI, Shi].
	[T] Sin Sukchu SR vu (去), vẃ (上), LR vu (去)
	[T] MGZY Hwow (上) [vɔw]
	[T] MTang bvu, ONW bu
	[D] M-Xiàmén puᶜ². Acc. to Norman (1986: 382) the Northern Mǐn ``softened initial'' *b̯- points to OC prenasalization which is supported by Yao bwaaŋ⁴ < *nb- ``daughter-in-law''.
	[E] Two possible etymologies: (1) Connectable with Tai *baaᴬ ``wife'', Tianbao paaᴬ² < *b- which acc. to Li (HCT: 66) is a northern Tai word (hence a CH loan?). (2) Alternatively, traceable back to AA: Kharia bui ``girl'', Munda bui ``vocative of address to little girls'', Mon mbuiy ``female onomastic prefix'', note also Aslian forms (Malay Penins.) like mabɛh, baboʔ etc. ``woman''. For the lack of final -j in CH, see {§6.9}.
::Mon	mbuiy	``female onomastic prefix''
>:Two possible etymologies:
>:Connectable with Tai *baaᴬ ``wife''

>:Kharia bui ``girl''
>:Munda bui ``vocative of address to little girls''

ENTRY:1036
HEAD:fù₁₁ 負
MC:Middle Chinese: bjəuᴮ 
LH:Later Han: buᴮ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *bəʔ 
OCB:Baxter Old Chinese: *ɦpjə(k)ʔ
	[T] MTang bvu ONW bu
GLOSS:"To carry on the back, support" [BI, Shi].
	[E]  The OC and TB words cited in this wf are encountered widely in the area: PMK *tɓaʔ: Bahn. *bʌʔ, Katuic baʔ ``carry (on the back)''; PPal. *bɔ, Khmu bɔʔ, PWa *bɔʔ ``carry child on back'' (Shorto 1972). MK ⇒ ST *bə, PTB *ba (HPTB: 24): WT ’ba-ba ``to bring, carry''.
	MK ⇒ NNaga *baʔ > *baᴮ ``carry on the back'', Nung ba ``carry'' (on shoulder).
	MK ⇒ PTai *baaᴬ: S. pʰaaᴬ².
	Even though the OC vowel / rime was clearly *-ə (not *-u), fù could also, or instead, be connected with a synonymous etymon *bu or *bwə, because after labials earlier *u and *ə may have merged on occasion in OC ({§11.10.4}), unless the TB items should belong to {bǎo₁ 保} instead, see there.
	PTB *buw or *bəw ``carry on back or shoulder'' (STC no. 28; p. 22; HPTB: 199; HST: 52; Weidert 1987: 138) > Chepang buy- ``carry on back'' ⪤ bus- ``carry on back''; Mikir, Meitei pu; Lepcha bŭ ``bear, carry, burden, load''; PLB *buw² [Matisoff D. of Lahu: 827] > WB puiᴮ ``bear on the back'', Lushai pua / pɔ / puak (tone?) ``carry on the back'' (as a child) , prob. also Lushai puᴴ / putᴸ ``carry on the shoulder'', pʰurᴴ ``carry a load on the back, to bear''; Lepcha buk ``back, wrong side''.
::Lepcha	buk	``back, wrong side''
>:The OC and TB words cited in this wf are encountered widely in the area:

A variant is prob.

ENTRY:1046

ENTRY:1047

GLOSS-NOTE:The MC div.
	III syllable of this type is unique (labial initial, rime -jak).
	[T] MTang bvuak, ONW buak < bak
	[D] PMin *buk > Amoy bakᴰ², Fúzhōu puoʔᴰ², Jiànyáng poᴰ² ``to tie''.
	[E] AA: Khmer p̈ā’ka /pak/ ``to enlace, entwine, embroider'' ⪤ /bɑmnak/ ``to enlacing, stitching together''; Mon /pa̤k/, WrMon buik ``to put round lower half of the body'', Semai /bək/, Temiar /bəg/ ``to bind''. The PMin form is closer to Tai than to MC. Alternative ly, note S. pʰuukᴰ¹ < *bl-/br- ``to bind, tie'' (Manomaivibool 1975: 128).
	The AA semantic range suggests that the following word is prob. related:
::Temiar	/bəg/	``to bind''

ENTRY:1056
HEAD:gān₂ 干
MC:Middle Chinese: kân 
LH:Later Han: kɑn 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *kân
GLOSS:"River bank" [Shi].
	[E] The etymology is not certain. The graph might simply have stood for the word {àn₂ 岸} ``river bank''.
	Or gān may be a variant of {kǎn₆ 顑} with aberrant final.
	Finally, it could be the same word as {gān₁ 干} in the sense that a bank is a protection against the water; a semantic parallel is found in the wf {yà₂ 御迓訝}.
>:The etymology is not certain. The graph might simply have stood for the word {àn₂ 岸} ``river bank''

GLOSS:"flag pole" (of slender bamboo) 干 [Shi];
GLOSS:"bamboo slip" (for writing) 竿 [Zhuang].
GLOSS-NOTE:This is apparently not a carrying pole, cf. {hè₁ 何荷}.

ENTRY:1063
HEAD:gān₅ 肝
MC:Middle Chinese: kân 
LH:Later Han: kɑn 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *kân
	[D] PMin *kanᴬ¹
GLOSS:"Liver" [Li]
	[E] Etymology not certain. Perh. derivation from {kǔ 苦} ``bitter'', semantically parallel to {xīn₂ 辛} (STC: 158 n. 428), note TB: Garo bi-ka ``liver''; however, a liver is not noted for being unusually bitter.
	On the other hand, gān may correspond to PTB *m-kal ``kidneys'' (STC no. 12): WT mkʰal-ma, Lushai kalᴿ < kalʔ, Chepang gəl.
	The TB etymon blends into words for ``lower back'' ({hè₁ 何荷}).

LH:Later Han: kɑmᴮ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *kâmʔ (< kwam ?)
GLOSS:"Dare, take the liberty, presume" [BI, Shi].
	[T] Sin Sukchu SR kam (上), PR kan
	[T] MGZY  gam (上) [kam]
	[T] ONW kɑm
	[E] ST *k-wam: PTB *hwam (STC no. 216) ``to dare'': Lushai huamᴴ, WB wamᶜ, JP wam³³ ``dare''; perhaps also WT ’gam-pa ``to try''. TB and OC can be reconciled if we assume an original *kwam > OC *kâm (labial dissimilation, STC: 168 n. 449), but ~ *k-wam > PTB *hwam (devoicing of the initial with loss of voiceless pre-initial).
	If or how Viet. dám (< y-), Tai: S. h-yam² ``dare'' [Maspero 1912: 69] are connected is not clear.

>:JP wam³³ ``dare''

>:PTB *hwam

ENTRY:1100
HEAD:gē₁ 戈

>:Perh. area word:
>:WB kʰwan ``long-handled chisel''  < - Tai:
>:S. kʰwanᴬ¹ ``an axe, hatchet''  < - AT gwal ~ qwal . Possibly related to huà 𢦚  ``thrust'', and huá 划  ``to punt''

ENTRY:1109
HEAD:gé₂ 隔 = gé 膈
MC:Middle Chinese: kɛk 
LH:Later Han: kɛk 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *krêk
GLOSS:"Membrane".
	Unger (Hao-ku 51, 1995) suggests that mò 膜 (mâk) ``membrane'' which he sets up as OC *mrāk is a morphological variant of this word.
	Alternatively, gé may be a variant of, or the same etymon as {gé₁ 革} (kɛk) ``hide, skin'', although the OC rimes are different (*-ək vs. *-ek).

::WT	kʰoŋ ~ goŋ	``a final syllable in names of important persons such as ministers and government officials''
>:Tai:
>:S. luŋᴬ² < *l- ``parent's elder brother, uncle''. The difference in the OC and Tai initials may be explained by a MK origin:

ENTRY:1148
HEAD:gōng₇ 肱
MC:Middle Chinese: kwəŋ 
LH:Later Han: kwəŋ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *kwə̂ŋ
GLOSS:"Arm, upper arm" [Shi], gǔ gōng 股肱
GLOSS:"legs and arms" (metaphor for a ruler's ministers).
	[E] As the meaning of hóng (arms resting on an armrest are usually bent) illustrates, gōng implies the upper arm or whole arm bent at the elbow, i.e. bow-shaped, therefore this etymon which has apparently no outside cognate is prob. derived from {gōng₂ 弓} ``bow''.
>:As the meaning of hóng  illustrates, gōng implies the upper arm or whole arm bent at the elbow, i.e. bow-shaped, therefore this etymon which has apparently no outside cognate is prob. derived from {gōng₂ 弓} ``bow''

ENTRY:1149
HEAD:gōng₇ 肱 ⪤ hóng 鞃
MC:Middle Chinese: kwəŋ, kʰwəŋ 
LH:Later Han: kwəŋ, kʰwəŋ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *k(h)wə̂ŋ
GLOSS:"Armrest" on a carriage [BI, Shi].

ENTRY:1150
HEAD:gōng₈ 宮
MC:Middle Chinese: kjuŋ 
LH:Later Han: kuŋ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *kuŋ
	[T] ONW kuŋ
GLOSS:"Palace, mansion" [BI, Shi],
GLOSS:"temple" [Shi 300, 1].
GLOSS-NOTE:(Meanings discussed by Shaughnessy 1991: 199-201).
	[E] HST: 98 relates the CH word to WT kʰoŋ-pa ``inside'', STC (p. 182 n. 479) and Bodman (1980: 124) to PTB *k-yim ~ *k-yum ``house'' (STC no. 53; HPTB: 504; for the difference in finals, see {§6.7}); but see {gōng 公}.
	[E] Area word: MK: Mon gloŋ ``citadel, palace'', Khmer khluə̀ŋ ``treasury, storehouse'' [Shorto 1971: 88]. Khmer ⇒ Tai: S. kluaŋᴬ¹ ``house, abode of a prince(ss)''.
::Khmer	khluə̀ŋ	``treasury, storehouse''
>:HST:
>:98 relates the CH word to WT kʰoŋ-pa ``inside''
>:STC  and Bodman  to PTB *k-yim ~ *k-yum ``house''
>:but see {gōng 公}
>:Area word:
>:MK:
>:Mon gloŋ ``citadel, palace''
>:Khmer khluə̀ŋ ``treasury, storehouse'' . Khmer ⇒ Tai:
>:S. kluaŋᴬ¹ ``house, abode of a prince''

ENTRY:1152
HEAD:gōng₉ 觥
MC:Middle Chinese: kwɐŋ 
LH:Later Han: kuaŋ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *kwrâŋ
	[T] ONW (kuëŋ)
GLOSS:"Drinking vessel" of buffalo horn [Shi].
	[E] PMY *krɔŋᴬ ``horn'' <- PTB (*kruŋᴬ ~) *k-rwaŋᴬ (Benedict LTBA 10.2, 1987: 17), PTB *ruŋ ~ *rwaŋ ``horn'' (STC no. 85): Tsangla wa-roŋ ``horn'' (of wa bovine); Chepang roŋʔ ``horn of animal''; PTani *rəŋ ``horn'', Garo, Dimasa groŋ ``horn'', Lepcha aróŋ, Vayu, Bahing ruŋ (CVST V: 160), JP ruŋ³³- ``horn'', also koŋ³³ ``tusk''; Ge-man Deng kɹăŋ³⁵. This word belongs to the same root *(k-)ru ~ *(k-)rwa as {jiǎo₅ 角} ``horn''.
	Shorto 1972 considers an AA origin likely: PMK *draŋ.
::JP	ruŋ³³-	``horn''

	An allofam may perhaps be {gòng₂ 貢}.

ENTRY:1163
HEAD:gōu₁ 句鉤枸區 ⪤? yǔ 傴
MC:Middle Chinese: ʔjuᴮ 
LH:Later Han: ʔɨoᴮ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *ʔoʔ
GLOSS:"Bend the body" [Zuo],
GLOSS:"humpback" [Li].
GLOSS-NOTE:However, not (directly) related to {gōu₁ 句鉤枸區}.
	[E] ST: WT dgu-ba ``to bend'' ⪤ dgur ``something bent''; OC *-o can derived from ST *u or *o. Syn. and likely cognate is {qū₁ 曲}, perhaps also to {quán₃ 卷拳} and/or {quán₄ 䟒}, {qū₂ 屈}, {jú₆ 鞠鞫} ``bend''.
	This wf is perhaps also related to {lóu₂ 僂}.
	Syn. {yū₁ 迂紆}; {hú₈ 弧}.
>:WT dgu-ba ``to bend'' ⪤ dgur ``something bent''
>:OC *-o can derived from ST *u or *o. Syn. and likely cognate is {qū₁ 曲}, perhaps also to {quán₃ 卷拳} and/or {quán₄ 䟒}, {qū₂ 屈}, {jú₆ 鞠鞫} ``bend''

ENTRY:1165
HEAD:gōu₃ 篝
	{gòu₃} 冓

ENTRY:1166
HEAD:gǒu 狗
MC:Middle Chinese: kəuᴮ 
LH:Later Han: koᴮ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *kôʔ < *kloʔ
GLOSS:"Dog" [Meng],
GLOSS:"puppy dog, cub of bear or tiger" [Erya] (also written with other radicals).
	[D] PMin *k̯əuᴮ
	[E] Wáng Lì (1982: 182f) believes that the following are variants of this word (doubtful):  (1) {jū₇ 駒} (kju) ``young horse''. (2) hǒu 𤘽 (xəuᴮ) ``calf'' is a dialectal variant for gǒu, acc. to Guō Pú. (3) {gāo₄ 羔} is an ancient NE dialect word for gǒu ``young of dog, bear, tiger'' which suggest that gāo ``lamb'' is the same etymon.
	Actually, gǒu is a loan or substrate word from PMY *klu² [Purnell] ``dog'' which in turn is AA: PMon *clur, Mon *klə, WrMon cluiw, kluiw [kløw] (Haudricourt 1966; Norman / Mei 1976: 279-280; Norman 1988: 17), perhaps also Bahnar kŏ ``dog'' (K. Smith LTBA 2.1 [n.d.]: 7). For the initials, see {§8.2.2}.
	Some Himalayish forms, e.g.
	TB- Bahing k’li ``dog'' (STC no. 159) may derive from the same root of presumably wide prehistoric distribution.
	Acc. to W. Eberhard (1968: 43-50), the dog play a significant role in Yáo mythology.
	Customs in the ancient state of Zhèng 鄭 in Hénán (adjecent to the Shāng and Zhōu dynasty heartland) suggest to Eberhard that their inhabitants belonged originally to the Yáo culture (ibid. p. 36).
::Bahing	k’li	``dog''
>:Wáng Lì  believes that the following are variants of this word :
>:{jū₇ 駒}  ``young horse''.  hǒu 𤘽  ``calf'' is a dialectal variant for gǒu, acc. to Guō Pú.  {gāo₄ 羔} is an ancient NE dialect word for gǒu ``young of dog, bear, tiger'' which suggest that gāo ``lamb'' is the same etymon

ENTRY:1167

	[T] MTang kəu ONW kou
GLOSS:"Filth" [Shi].

	[E] This wf may be related with WB kyuᶜ ``filthy, dirty, foul'', all words from a ST stem *klo-?
::WB	kyuᶜ	``filthy, dirty, foul''
>:WT bsgo-ba ``to soil, stain, defile, infect'' . See also {gòu₂ 詬}
>:This wf may be related with WB kyuᶜ ``filthy, dirty, foul'', all words from a ST stem *klo-?

ENTRY:1169
HEAD:gòu₂ 詬
MC:Middle Chinese: xəuᶜ,kʰəuᶜ,kəuᴮ 
LH:Later Han: hoᶜ,kʰoᶜ,koᴮ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *(k)hôh,kôʔ
GLOSS:"Disgrace, insult, revile" [Zuo].
	[E] ST: WT ’kʰu-ba ``insult, offend'' (HST: 98). Unger (Hao-ku 36, 1990: 50) considers this to be the s. w. as {gòu₁ 垢} (kəuᴮ) ``filth''.
>:WT ’kʰu-ba ``insult, offend'' . Unger  considers this to be the s. w. as {gòu₁ 垢}  ``filth''

ENTRY:1170
HEAD:gòu₃ 冓
MC:Middle Chinese: kəuᶜ 
LH:Later Han: koᶜ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *kôh
	This root means basically ``interlacery, trelliswork'' (Karlgren GSR 109): zhōng-gòu 中冓 ``inner chamber''; ``to fabricate, build'' 構 [Shu]. The original graph gòu 冓 shows apparently a wicker fish trap.
	[E] ? ST: JP ku³¹ ``bed, furniture'' (i.e. wooden frame).
	Karlgren (GSR 109) believes that all words with the phonetic 冓 are cognate, meaning ``intertwine, interlace''; possible allofams {gòu₅ 購} ``to present''; {gòu₄ 遘覯姤} ``come across''.
	However, the word {hù₃ 互枑} agrees with gòu in all but the vowel; possible TB cognates also indicate that hù is a separate root.
>:JP ku³¹ ``bed, furniture''

ENTRY:1171
HEAD:gòu₃ 冓 ⪤ gōu 篝
MC:Middle Chinese: kəu 
LH:Later Han: ko 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *kô
GLOSS:"Bamboo cage" [Chuci].

ENTRY:1172
HEAD:gòu₄ 遘覯姤
MC:Middle Chinese: kəuᶜ 
LH:Later Han: koᶜ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *kôh
GLOSS:"To come across, meet with" 覯 [Shi];
GLOSS:"meet with" 遘 [Shi];
GLOSS:"to cross, join (weapons)" 搆 [Meng]; ``come in conflict with'' 構 [Shi]; ``second marriage, favor'' 姤 [Yi].
GLOSS-NOTE:This may be the s. w. as {gòu₃ 冓} (so Karlgren), q.v. for possible allofams.
	[E] ST: PTB *gow (STC no. 318) > WB kuᴮ ``cross over, transfer'', JP gau³³ ``pass over'';  possibly also JP koʔ⁵⁵ ``to ford'', WT kʰug-pa ~ kʰugs-pa ``to find, get, earn'' (i.e. ``come across'') (HST: 72). WB *kruik ``meet with'', Chepang krus-sa ``to meet'', WT ’kʰrug-pa ``fight, disturb'' represent perhaps parallel stems.
	Note that MC is ambiguous as to the presence or absence of OC medial *-r-.
	Karlgren (GSR 109) believes that all words with this phonetic are cognate, basically meaning ``intertwine, interlace''.
::WT	’kʰrug-pa	``fight, disturb''
>:PTB *gow  >
>:WB kuᴮ ``cross over, transfer''
>:JP gau³³ ``pass over''
>:possibly also JP koʔ⁵⁵ ``to ford''
>:WT kʰug-pa ~ kʰugs-pa ``to find, get, earn''  . WB *kruik ``meet with''
>:Chepang krus-sa ``to meet''
>:WT ’kʰrug-pa ``fight, disturb'' represent perhaps parallel stems

ENTRY:1180
HEAD:gǔ₁ 古
MC:Middle Chinese: kuoᴮ 
LH:Later Han: kɑᴮ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *kâʔ
GLOSS:"Antiquity, of old" [OB, BI, Shi].
	[T] Sin Sukchu SR ku (上)
	[T] MGZY gu (上) [ku]
	[T] ONW ko
	[E] ST: PTB *r-ga ``old'' (STC no. 445) > WT rga-ba ``be old, aged''; JP ləga ``old''. Boltz (OE 35, 1992: 36ƒƒ) relates gǔ to a wf ``hard, durable'' which includes {gù₁ 固} ``secure, strong'', but WT cognates suggest that these etyma have separate ST origins.
	Boltz also includes {kǔ 苦} ``duress, suffer'', et al.
	[C] Shī Xiàngdōng (2000: 120) adds hú 胡 LH gɑ or ɣɑ ``advanced in years'' [Zhoushu].
>:PTB *r-ga ``old''  >
>:WT rga-ba ``be old, aged''
>:JP ləga ``old''. Boltz  relates gǔ to a wf ``hard, durable'' which includes {gù₁ 固} ``secure, strong'', but WT cognates suggest that these etyma have separate ST origins

ENTRY:1183
HEAD:gǔ₃ 牯
MC:Middle Chinese: kuoᴮ
	[T] ONW ko
	[D] PMin *k̯oᴮ
GLOSS:"Male of bovine, steer" [Yupian, GY], a post-classical word. Prob. not cognate to {gǔ₇ 羖}
GLOSS:"ram".
	[E] MK: Mod. Khmer kloḥ ``male, virile'' ⪤ kamloḥ ``young man''; Chrau ``male'' ⪤ si-klo ``husband''; Bahnar klo ``male'', Stieng klau, klo ``male'' ⪤ sarlau ``husband'', Sre klau ``man, male''.
	Also the Yuè dialect word lau ``boy'' may ultimately go back to this MK etymon.
::Sre	klau	``man, male''

	CAAAL 22, 1984: 119f); some TB words have final -k: Mikir arlók < r-lók ``valley''.

ENTRY:1187
HEAD:gǔ₆ 股
MC:Middle Chinese: kuoᴮ 
LH:Later Han: kɑᴮ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *kâʔ

	[E] KT: Tai: S. kʰaaᴬ¹ < *kʰ- ``leg, thigh'' (Li F. 1976: 44), PKS *kwa¹ ``leg''. The Tai word is prob. not related to {qiāo₁ 骹} (kʰau) ``foot''.
::PKS	*kwa¹	``leg''
>:KT:
>:Tai:
>:S. kʰaaᴬ¹ < *kʰ- ``leg, thigh''
>:PKS *kwa¹ ``leg''. The Tai word is prob. not related to {qiāo₁ 骹}  ``foot''

ENTRY:1188
HEAD:gǔ₇ 羖
MC:Middle Chinese: kuoᴮ 
LH:Later Han: kɑᴮ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *kâʔ
GLOSS:"Ram" [Shi].
	[E] Wáng Lì (1982: 126) relates this word to {gǔ₃ 牯} ``male of bovine, steer'', as well as to the wf {jiā₈ 豭} ``boar'', therefore gǔ 羖 meant originally ``male animal''. However, jiā and gǔ differ in MC vowel and tone, therefore gǔ prob. means basical ly ``ram'' and is cognate to {jié₄ 羯} ``ram''.
>:Wáng Lì  relates this word to {gǔ₃ 牯} ``male of bovine, steer'', as well as to the wf {jiā₈ 豭} ``boar'', therefore gǔ 羖 meant originally ``male animal''. However, jiā and gǔ differ in MC vowel and tone, therefore gǔ prob. means basical ly ``ram'' and is cognate to {jié₄ 羯} ``ram''

ENTRY:1189
HEAD:gǔ₈ 骨
MC:Middle Chinese: kuət 
LH:Later Han: kuət 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *kût
GLOSS:"Bone" [OB].
	[T] Sin Sukchu SR ku (入)
	[T] MGZY gu (入) [ku]
	[T] ONW kot
	[D] PMin *kot
	[E] Outside relations are not obvious; gǔ is usually compared to PTB *rus ``bone'': WT rus, Lushai ruʔ (< rus), Khami lgs. (Kuki-Chin) *hrut, Rengmitca kh(r)u, Areng haw (prob. from voiceless *hr-)  (Löffler Anthropos 55, 1960: 547); Lepcha a-hrăt ``bone''; Karen k(h)rut (STC: 155 n. 419). But we could be more confident about these associations if there were a trace of an OC medial *r.
	WT rus ``clan'', see {lèi₂ 類}.
::WT	rus	``clan''
>:Outside relations are not obvious
>:gǔ is usually compared to PTB *rus ``bone'':
>:WT rus
>:Lushai ruʔ
>:Khami lgs.  *hrut
>:Rengmitca khu, Areng haw
>:Lepcha a-hrăt ``bone''
>:Karen krut . But we could be more confident about these associations if there were a trace of an OC medial *r

ENTRY:1190
HEAD:gǔ₉ 鼓
MC:Middle Chinese: kuoᴮ 
LH:Later Han: kɑᴮ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *kâʔ < *klaʔ
	[D] PMin *koᴮ.
GLOSS:"The drum, to drum, strike (a musical instrument)" [BI, Shi];
GLOSS:"musician > blind man" 瞽 [Shi] (Karlgren 1956: 4).
	[E] Area word: PTai *klɔŋᴬ¹ ``drum'' (Li F. 1976: 40), Saek tlɔɔŋᴬ¹, PHlai *laŋ¹, PWa *kloʔ ``bronze-drum''. For the finals, see {§3.2.4}.
::PWa	*kloʔ	``bronze-drum''
>:Area word:
>:PTai *klɔŋᴬ¹ ``drum''
>:Saek tlɔɔŋᴬ¹
>:PHlai *laŋ¹
>:PWa *kloʔ ``bronze-drum''

ENTRY:1191

	{gǔ₉} 鼓

ENTRY:1192
HEAD:gǔ₁₁ 賈
MC:Middle Chinese: kuoᴮ 
LH:Later Han: kɑᴮ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *kâʔ
GLOSS:"To sell" [Shi 264, 4],
GLOSS:"to buy" [Zuo] >
GLOSS:"merchant" [Shu 35, 5; Zuo].
	[E] This word could be a cognate or variant of gǔ above, but the same graph also writes a word hù (ɣuoᴮ) ``overnight wine'' [Shi 302, 2] with which it may be related since gū means ``buy wine''. Karlgren (GSR 49b’) has assigned readings to meanings as given above, yet traditional commentaries and dictionaries don't agree which reading, gū or hù, goes with which meaning.
	[C] Perh. cognate to {jià₄ 賈價}. Syn. {dí₆ 糴}; {mǎi 買}; {shòu₂ 售}; {yù₂₃ 賣}.
>:This word could be a cognate or variant of gǔ above, but the same graph also writes a word hù  ``overnight wine''  with which it may be related since gū means ``buy wine''. Karlgren  has assigned readings to meanings as given above, yet traditional commentaries and dictionaries don't agree which reading, gū or hù, goes with which meaning
