LH:Later Han: kouk ~ kiauk ? 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *kâuk ~ *kiauk ?
GLOSS:"Husk of grain" [Lü, GY].
GLOSS-NOTE:GY also has a reading zhuó (tśjak).
	[E] ST: PTB *kok (STC no. 342) >  PLB *ʔkuk ~ *ʔguk ``outer covering, bark, skin'' > WB ə-kʰok; WT skog-pa ~ kog-pa ``shell, peel, rind'' ⪤ ’gog-pa, bkog ``to tear away, take away, peel, rob'' ⪤ gog-pa ``to scale off'' (Bodman 1980: 128); Lushai kʰok ``peel off'' (STC: 74). The CH distinction between {kuò₄ 鞹} *khwak ``leather'' (< ``skin''?) and gǔ *kûk ``husk'' is difficult to disentangle in TB languages.

ENTRY:1199
HEAD:gǔ₁₅ 盬
MC:Middle Chinese: kuoᴮ 
LH:Later Han: kɑᴮ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *kâʔ
GLOSS:"Salt" [Zhouli],
GLOSS:"salty marsh" [Zuo].
	[E] <>  PTai *klɨoᴬ¹ ``salt'' (Li 1976: 45), Saek tluaᴬ¹ > truaᴬ¹. Acc. to Li F., gǔ is possibly connected with {lǔ₁ 鹵} (luoᴮ) ``salty'', which is supported by modern forms like Jin dialectal kəʔᴰ²-louᶜ (Zhāng Xīng-yà YWYJ 1996.4: 10).
	Possible variants or allofams are {chì₁ 斥}, {xì₄ 潟}.
>:PTai *klɨoᴬ¹ ``salt''

ENTRY:1200
HEAD:gǔ₁₆ 蠱
MC:Middle Chinese: kuoᴮ 
LH:Later Han: kɑᴮ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *kâʔ
GLOSS:"A poison which serves as a magic charm" [OB, Yi, Zuo]; SW and Zhōulǐ say it is an animal in the stomach. Eberhard (1968: 149-153) says: People south of the Yangtze prepare gǔ by putting into a pot five poisonous vermin, such as a centipede, a snake, etc., which devour each other; the one left is crushed and made into a medicine which is used as a magic charm (e.g. love charm; evil magic to obtain subservient spirits, and the like).

ENTRY:1202
HEAD:gù₁ 固
MC:Middle Chinese: kuoᶜ 
LH:Later Han: kɑᶜ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *kâh
GLOSS:"Be solid, secure, sure" [Shi].
	[T] Sin Sukchu SR ku (去)
	[T] MGZY  gu (去) [ku]
	[T] ONW ko
	[C] Boltz (op. cit.) adds among others of the following: {kū₁ 枯} ``wither'', {hú₁ 胡} ``dewlap'', {gù₂ 固錮} ``persistent'', {hù₂ 怙} ``rely on'', {gǔ₁ 古} ``old''; {gù₃ 故} ``reason''.
	[E] Several parallel or synonymous stems have partially converged and are difficult to disentangle, unless they should all be prolific variants and derivations from one ST source ({Table G-0}); for an overview see {Table G-1} [ Hard, congeal, dry (A) ] ; {Table J-1} (B) under {jiān₂ 堅}. As often, MK words are also mixed into this wf complex, but the nature and history of their connection with OC and TB is not certain (substrate?). ◇

ENTRY:1217
HEAD:guǎ 寡 ⪤ guān 鰥

	[E] ST: WT dgon-pa ``solitary place, desert, wilderness, hermitage'' (n-nominalization) ⪤ sgos ``private, individual''. OC *-r- can reflect different foreign elements in the initial ({§7.4}), therefore WT is the exact counterpart of OC, except that the WT noun refers to a place, the OC noun to a person.
>:WT dgon-pa ``solitary place, desert, wilderness, hermitage''  ⪤ sgos ``private, individual''. OC *-r- can reflect different foreign elements in the initial , therefore WT is the exact counterpart of OC, except that the WT noun refers to a place, the OC noun to a person

ENTRY:1220
HEAD:guà 挂
MC:Middle Chinese: kwaiᶜ 
LH:Later Han: kuɛᶜ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *kwrêh or *kwêh
GLOSS:"To suspend, hang" [Yili].

This etymon is reminiscent of PMonic *wak ``to hang'' (sth. to a nail) ⪤ *k-wak ``to hook and pull, hang sth. by its hook'' (tr.) [Diffloth 1984: 167], but MK is phonologically rather distant. Prob. {xuán₄ 縣懸} and {qìng₃ 磬} are related.
::PMonic	*wak	``to hang''

ENTRY:1227
HEAD:guān₃ 棺
MC:Middle Chinese: kuân 
LH:Later Han: kuɑn 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *kwân/*kôn ?
GLOSS:"Coffin" [Zuo].
	[E] ST, area word: Lushai kuaŋᴴ ``coffin, trough, groove'', Kukish *r-kuaŋ ``coffin, boat'' [IST: 47], perhaps also WB kʰoŋᴮ ``trough, canoe'', yet see {kōng 空} ``empty'' to which all these etyma may belong. Coffins and boats used to be hollowed tree trunks, hence some languages have the same word for both.
	For the discrepancy in final nasals see {§6.4.2}.
::WB	kʰoŋᴮ	``trough, canoe''

>:Kukish *r-kuaŋ ``coffin, boat'' , perhaps also WB kʰoŋᴮ ``trough, canoe'', yet see {kōng 空} ``empty'' to which all these etyma may belong. Coffins and boats used to be hollowed tree trunks, hence some languages have the same word for both

ENTRY:1234
HEAD:guān₇ 觀 ⪤ guàn 觀
MC:Middle Chinese: kuânᶜ 
LH:Later Han: kuɑnᶜ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *kôns
	[T] ONW kuɑn
GLOSS:1:``To cause to see, show'' [Zhouli].
	[<] exoactive / caus. of guān 觀 (kuân) ({§4.3.2}).
GLOSS:2:``Aspect, scene'' [Guan].
	[<] exopass. of guān 觀 (kuân), lit. ``what is looked at'' ({§4.4}); in guàn tái 觀薹 ``look-out tower'' [Zuo]; tone C occurs because the word is part of a compound (Downer 1959: 289).
	[E] This stem *kon is derived from the root under {hóu₁ 侯}. Often the form in final -n seems to have the same meaning as the base form.
>:This stem *kon is derived from the root under {hóu₁ 侯}. Often the form in final -n seems to have the same meaning as the base form

ENTRY:1258
HEAD:guǐ₁ 鬼
MC:Middle Chinese: kjwəiᴮ 
LH:Later Han: kuiᴮ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *kuiʔ
GLOSS:"Spirit, ghost" [OB, Shi]; originally: the ghost of a deceased who has returned to haunt (terrorize) the living (E. Childs-Johnson EC 20, 1995: 79ƒƒ).

	[T] MGZY  gue (上) [kuɛ]
	[T] ONW kui  —
	[D] PMin *kyiᴮ
	[E] Two etymolo gies have been proposed: (1) Derived from {wēi₄ 威} ``to overawe, terrorize'' (Childs-Johnson) with k-nomina li zation ({§5.4}; Baxter / Sagart 1998: 48; 59), and endoactive tone B, lit. ``the thing which is doing the overawing'' ({§4.5.1}). (2) Or related to {guī₃ 歸} ``return'' (SW; Carr CAAAL 24, 1985: 61).
>:Two etymolo gies have been proposed:

ENTRY:1260
HEAD:guǐ₃ 簋
MC:Middle Chinese: kjwiᴮ 3 
LH:Later Han: kwɨᴮ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *kwrəʔ 
OCB:Baxter Old Chinese: *kᵂrjuʔ
	Name of a bronze ritual vessel, a ``tureen'' (Shaughnessy) [OB, BI, Shi], originally prob. some kind of basket or bamboo container.
	[E] Possibly ST: PLB *kᵂiy¹ ``receptacle, container'' > Lahu phɨ, in some languages ``nest'' [Matisoff D. of Lahu: 917]. CH ? ⇒ Tai: S. kuay ``basket''.
	The name and shape of this vessel is reminiscent of ``turtle'' {guī₄ 龜} LH kwɨ.
	The homophone guǐ 匭 ``box, chest'' [Shu] is prob. unrelated (under {kuì₁ 匱}; however, acc. to SW, 匭 it is also the old graph for 簋).
>:Possibly ST:
>:PLB *kᵂiy¹ ``receptacle, container'' >
>:Lahu phɨ, in some languages ``nest'' . CH ? ⇒ Tai:
>:S. kuay ``basket''

ENTRY:1271
HEAD:guó 國
MC:Middle Chinese: kwək 
LH:Later Han: kuək 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *kwə̂k 
OCB:Baxter Old Chinese: *k-wək
GLOSS:"State" [BI, Shi].

	[T] MGZY  gue (入) [kuɛ]
	[T] ONW kuək
	[<] k-prefix derivation of yù 域閾 (jwək) ({§5.4}) (Baxter / Sagart 1998: 48).
	[E] Guó has no obvious outside cognates. It may be related to either WB kwak ``a circle or round spot …, confined within a local area'' (as rain); or alternatively to WT yul ``country''.
	One could perhaps connect the latter with yòu: WT initial y- can have dissimilated from ST *wu ({§12.9[2]}); the addition of the Chinese final *-k ({§6.1}) has preempted the putative ST final *-l; however, invoking too many rare correspondence patterns deminishes the likelihood of such an etymology.
::WT	yul	``country''
>:Guó has no obvious outside cognates. It may be related to either WB kwak ``a circle or round spot …, confined within a local area''
>:or alternatively to WT yul ``country''

ENTRY:1278
HEAD:guǒ₃-luǒ 蜾蠃
MC:Middle Chinese: kuâᴮ-luâᴮ 
LH:Later Han: kuɑiᴮ-luɑiᴮ ~ koiᴮ-loiᴮ

GLOSS:"Species of small wasp" [Shi].
	[E] ST, area word: PTB *k(l)wa-y  ⪤ g(l)wa-y  (STC n. 144) > WB kwaiᴮ ``dammer bee''; PNorthern Naga *C-guay, Lushai kʰuaiᴴ ~ kʰɔiᴴ ``bee, wasp'', Tangkhul Naga kʰui, Thakali koy ``bee'', Chepang kway ``bee''. Matisoff (1995: 64) suggests that the final *-i/-y is a ST diminutive suffix.
	<> Kadai: Hlai koːi, kuai, kaːi.
	<> MK: PVM *kweːʔ ``bee'' [Ferlus], a Chinese loan? Semai (Aslian branch of MK) lwey [All forms from Matisoff 1995a]. Note that none of the TB forms cited by Matisoff and in STC no. 157 have a medial r or l (HST: 41).
	Therefore the bisyllabic OC form is not the result of dimidiation, but simply a reduplicative compound of the common type CV-lV or *CV-rV ({§2.7}).
::PVM	*kweːʔ	``bee''
>:ST, area word:
>:PTB *kwa-y  ⪤ gwa-y   >
>:WB kwaiᴮ ``dammer bee''
>:PNorthern Naga *C-guay
>:Lushai kʰuaiᴴ ~ kʰɔiᴴ ``bee, wasp''
>:Tangkhul Naga kʰui
>:Thakali koy ``bee'', Chepang kway ``bee''. Matisoff  suggests that the final *-i/-y is a ST diminutive suffix

ENTRY:1279
HEAD:guò 過
MC:Middle Chinese: kuâᶜ 
LH:Later Han: kuɑiᶜ ~ koiᶜ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *kôih
	[T] ONW kuɑ
GLOSS:"To pass" [Shi],
GLOSS:"transgress" [Lunyu], derived from guō next (Unger Hao-ku 21, 1983: 175).
	[E] Prob. ST although the vowels do not agree (WT rgal could theoretically derive from ST *gwal, but Lushai and WB forms speak against this), perhaps guò may involve an unusual OC a > o shift: WT rgal-ba, brgal ``to step over, pass over, travel through, ford'', Lushai kaiᴴ / kaiᴸ ``to cross over, go across'' ? ⪤ kalᴴ ``walk, travel, proceed, pass by'', WB kaiᴮ ``exceed, surpass, excel''.
::WB	kaiᴮ	``exceed, surpass, excel''
>:Prob. ST although the vowels do not agree , perhaps guò may involve an unusual OC a > o shift:
>:WT rgal-ba, brgal ``to step over, pass over, travel through, ford''
>:Lushai kaiᴴ / kaiᴸ ``to cross over, go across'' ? ⪤ kalᴴ ``walk, travel, proceed, pass by''
>:WB kaiᴮ ``exceed, surpass, excel''

ENTRY:1283
HEAD:hǎi₁ 海
MC:Middle Chinese: xậiᴮ 
LH:Later Han: həᴮ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *hmə̂ʔ 
OCB:Baxter Old Chinese: *hməʔ
GLOSS:"Ocean, sea" [BI, Shi].
GLOSS-NOTE:The absense of medial w is unexpected.
	[T] Sin Sukchu SR xaj (上)
	[T] MGZY hay (上) [xaj]
	[T] ONW hɑi
	[E] Prob. related to {huì₇ 晦} *hmə̂ʔ ``dark''; in numerous Zhou texts hǎi is described as huì. In OC they were (near?) homophones in spite of the difference in MC medial w.
	Semantic parallelism with {míng₃ 溟冥} ``ocean'' = {míng₂ 冥} ``dark'' supports this etymological connection.
>:Prob. related to {huì₇ 晦} *hmə̂ʔ ``dark''
>:in numerous Zhou texts hǎi is described as huì. In OC they were  homophones in spite of the difference in MC medial w

ENTRY:1284

OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *hwə̂ʔ ?
GLOSS:"Boneless meat sauce" [Shi], or
GLOSS:"meat which has been dried, minced and pickled" (GSR 995n). Bodman (1980: 133) compares this to WT smig
GLOSS:"purple, color of clotted blood", smug-ma ``stale meat, getting rotten'' [Das].

ENTRY:1285
HEAD:hài₁ 亥
MC:Middle Chinese: ɣəiᴮ 
LH:Later Han: gəᴮ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *gə̂ʔ
	The 12th of the Earthly Branches identified with the pig [OB] (the graph is the drawing of a pig), acc. to Norman (1985: 89) a loan from AA, note Viet. gȯi ``pig'' (obsolete), Khmer kol (sp. ko[r]) ``pig'' (in names of years).

ENTRY:1288

ENTRY:1289
HEAD:hán₁ 含函
MC:Middle Chinese: ɣậm 
LH:Later Han: gəm 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *gə̂m
	[T] ONW ɣɑm
GLOSS:"Have in the mouth" [Zuo] >
GLOSS:"hold back, bear resentment" 含 [Shu];
GLOSS:"to hold inside, contain" (as life in grain) [Shi], (as life force {qì₈ 氣} in people) 函 [Hanshu] > ``cuirass'' 函 [Meng] > ``envelop''.
	[D] The Northern Min softened initial in 含 *ğɑm may indicate OC prenasalization which is confirmed by Yáo gjɔm² < *ng- ``hold in the mouth'' (Norman 1986: 383).
	[E] The final -m in etyma with these types of meanings is sound-symbolic ({§2.9}). The meanings of the OC allofams are also paralleled in some TB and AA words: ``Have / keep in the mouth'':
	MK: Khmer /-kam/ ``bite'' ⪤ /kham/ ``clamp or cut with teeth or jaw …, bite'', /kum/ ``be resentful''.
	<> Chepang kəmh- be speechless’. ``Put / take into the mouth'':
	ST: PTB *gam (STC: 166; 183) > WT ’gam ``put into the mouth'', gams, bgams ⪤ ’kʰam-pa ``put into the mouth'', also WT sgam ``box'', sgam-po ``profound''; Mru kʰam ``take in the mouth, suffer'' ⪤ kʰam ``box'' [Löffler 1966: 140], Miri gam ``seize with the teeth'' (as a tiger), PTani *g(j)am ``bite''.
GLOSS:"Jaw":
	ST: Mru kam ``chin'', Chepang kəm-pət ``gills'' (fish), ``gill fins''; Lepcha kam ``jaw''.
	<> MK *dgam, *dgaam ``molar tooth, jaw'' (Shorto 2006 #1318): Forrest (JAOS 82, 1962: 334) cites Khmer thkéam, Stieng gam ``jaw'', Short additional words, including Biat gam ``molar'', Viet. căm ``chin''.
	It is not clear if the following ``molar'' belongs to this root (note WB amᴮ, not gamᴮ):
	ST: PTB *gam (STC no. 50) > Chepang magam ``molar'', Thakali kəm-sə, Lepcha fo-gam (fo ``tooth''), Limbu hema ``molar''; Garo wa-gum ``tooth'' (STC: 183 n. 482; HST: 99), WB amᴮ ``molar''.
	The notion ``keep in the mouth'' is a common metaphor for emotions, therefore {kān₂ 堪} ``endure'' is prob. cognate, note also the Mru field of meaning.
	This wf could be related to many additional items: {xián₁₁ 銜} ``a horse's bit'' (Bodman) and to {qián₂ 柑箝} ``wooden gag''.
	Furthermore, Wáng Lì (1982: 605) believes it to be related to {qiǎn₃ 慊} ``dissatisfied''.
	Perh. {dàn₅ 啖啗} is somehow connected with this root.
::WB	amᴮ	``molar''
>:The final -m in etyma with these types of meanings is sound-symbolic . The meanings of the OC allofams are also paralleled in some TB and AA words:
>:``Have / keep in the mouth'':
>:

ENTRY:1291
HEAD:hán₁ 含函 ⪤ hàn 頷
MC:Middle Chinese: ɣậmᴮ 
LH:Later Han: gəmᴮ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *gə̂mʔ
GLOSS:"Jaw" [Gongyang].
	[<] endoactive of hán 含函 (ɣậm) ({§4.5}) (so Bodman 1980: 110), lit. ``the thing that holds / keeps something in the mouth''. Although a regular derivation in OC, it may have been influenced by AA words for ``jaw'' (Shorto 1972), see below.

ENTRY:1301
HEAD:hàn₆ 暵
MC:Middle Chinese: xân[ᴮ/ᶜ]  <wow value=' LH:' color='invert' gloss='Later Han'/> hɑnᴮ/ᶜ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *hânʔ/s
GLOSS:"To scorch" [Shi].
	[E] The phonology and hence etymology is not certain. Prob. not related to {rán₁ 然} *nan ``burn'' because the phonetic element in hàn has originally been chosen for its meaning ``distress'', not for its sound (so GSR 144).
	Baxter apparently considers 熯 a graphic loan for a word OCB *njanʔ.
	The difference in the initial consonants (*h- vs. *k-) makes cognation with the syn. {gān₉ 乾} unlikely.
>:The phonology and hence etymology is not certain. Prob. not related to {rán₁ 然} *nan ``burn'' because the phonetic element in hàn has originally been chosen for its meaning ``distress'', not for its sound

ENTRY:1310
HEAD:háng₃ 頏
MC:Middle Chinese: ɣâŋ 
LH:Later Han: gɑŋ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *gâŋ
	[T] ONW ɣɑŋ
	Occurs in Shi 28 together with jié 頡 (jié … háng); SW glosses both ``stretch the neck'', this word is thus perhaps a variant of {xiàng₄ 項}, and derived from {gāng₁ 亢} (kâŋ) ``neck''.
	On the other hand, commentators interpret these words as ``flying up and flying down'' (of birds).

ENTRY:1311
HEAD:háng₄ 航杭
MC:Middle Chinese: ɣâŋ 
LH:Later Han: gɑŋ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *gâŋ
GLOSS:"Go by boat" 杭 [Shi],
GLOSS:"boat" 航 [GY], 斻 [SW].
GLOSS-NOTE:Whereas acc. to Yìjīng a {zhōu₁ 舟}
GLOSS:"boat" was originally a hollowed tree trunk (canoe), háng was two boats combined into one, as canoes lashed together (so SW, although Liú Yǐ-gāng YYYJ 1986.1: 169 thinks a háng was probably constructed of boards).
	Acc. to FY, háng is used for zhōu 舟 east of the Passes.

ENTRY:1312
HEAD:háng₄ 航杭 ⪤ huáng 艎, bàng 艕
MC:Middle Chinese: ɣwâŋ, pwâŋᶜ
GLOSS:"Ancient Wú words for boat" [Yupian] are variants acc. to Mahdi (1994: 456). Egerod (CAAAL 6, 1976: 58) believes that this is the same etymon as {xíng₁ 行}
GLOSS:"to go to", but it prob. has an AN origin (via AA?) *qaBaŋ
GLOSS:"two boats lashed together" (Mahdi 1999: 147f). {fāng₂ 方} is prob. the same etymon.
	Syn. {chuán₁ 船}.

ENTRY:1335
HEAD:hé₄ 河
MC:Middle Chinese: ɣâ 
LH:Later Han: gɑi 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *gâi
GLOSS:"River, Yellow River" [OB, Shi].
	[T] Sin Sukchu SR ɣɔ (平), LR ɣɔ
	[T] MGZY Xo (平) [ɣɔ]
	[T] ONW ɣɑ
	[E] Three etymologies have been suggested for this northern word: (1) cognate to WT rgal-ba ``to pass or ford a river'' (Coblin 1986), for a parallel semantic connection of ``ford'' with ``river'', see {dù₂ 渡}. (2) An Altaic loan, cf. Mongol ɣol (Norman). (3) Derived from hú 湖 (ɣuo) ``lake'' (Matisoff 1995a: 71).
	Note also JP kʰaʔ³¹ < kʰak ``water, river'', but the final does not agree with OC.
::JP	kʰaʔ³¹ < kʰak	``water, river''
>:Three etymologies have been suggested for this northern word:
>:cognate to WT rgal-ba ``to pass or ford a river'' , for a parallel semantic connection of ``ford'' with ``river'', see {dù₂ 渡}.  An Altaic loan, cf. Mongol ɣol .  Derived from hú 湖  ``lake''

ENTRY:1336
HEAD:hé₅ 合
MC:Middle Chinese: ɣập 
LH:Later Han: gəp 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *gə̂p 
OCB:Baxter Old Chinese: *gop
GLOSS:"To be together, joined, harmonious" intr. [Shi, Shu] > caus.
GLOSS:"to put together, match, a companion, a mate" [BI, Shi],
GLOSS:"harmony, concordance" [Shi, Shu]; ``agree with'' [Meng], ``to answer'' [Zuo]; ``close, shut'' [Guoce]; later hé 盒 ``box with a lid''. The graph shows an inverted open mouth facing down onto an opening.
	[T] Sin Sukchu SR ɣa (入)
	[T] PR, LR ɣɔʔ
	[T] MGZY Xo (入) [ɣɔ]
	[T] ONW ɣɑp.
	[D] M-Amoy hapᴰ² ``to join, unite, shut, to fit, agree''.
	[E] Three unrelated etyma hé 合 *gə̂p, {hé₈ 盍蓋} *gâp, and {huì₁ 會} *gwâts have partially converged in OC. The root kp ``fit together, cover, meet'' (including *kap {hé₈ 盍蓋}) is widely encountered in the area:
	Area etymon *kup.
	Lushai kʰupᴸ ``to cover with anything concave side downwards, cover with an inverted vessel …'', JP kʰup³¹ ``capsize, turn over'' (boat), Chepang kʰup- ``cover head''.
	The TB items agree semantically with the OC root *kap (> Mon kɔp), but phonologically with *kup.
	MK *[p]kup, *pkap (and more variants) ``inverted, face down'' (Shorto 2006 #1238): PMonic *p[]kap, Nyah-Kur pəkap, Mon həkɔp ``to turn sth. face down, to join an obj. face to face, face down''; Khmer gwpa /kúuəp/ ``to join, bring together, unite'', ga’pa /kup/ ``to join, unite, meet with, visit often'', Mon inscr. sakuip /səkøp/ ``lid'', also PVM *kəp ``to cover'' [Ferlus]. Note also MK *gap, *gaap, *gup ``fit, fitting, sufficient'' (Shorto 2006 #1240).
	Karlgren adds {xī₁₈ 翕} (xjəp) ``to bring / get together, concordant'' [BI, Shi], but the initials are difficult to reconcile.
::PVM	*kəp	``to cover''
>:Three unrelated etyma hé 合 *gə̂p, {hé₈ 盍蓋} *gâp, and {huì₁ 會} *gwâts have partially converged in OC. The root kp ``fit together, cover, meet''  is widely encountered in the area:

ENTRY:1346
HEAD:hé₈ 盍蓋
MC:Middle Chinese: ɣâp 
LH:Later Han: gɑp 
OC:Old Chinese: *gâp 
OCB:Baxter Old Chinese: *ɦkap
	(``To put cover / lid on'':) ``to cover (person, house), thatch'' 蓋 [Zuo]; ``wooden leaf door'' 闔 [Zuo], ``door leaf'' 盍 [Xun], ``to shut'' (mouth, door and the like) 嗑, 闔 [Yi]. The meaning 盍 ``join, unite'' (actually ``close in on'', as crowds of friends) [Yi] is somewhat uncertain; see Shaughnessy 1997: 90f; 301.
	[E] Area etymon. Items under hé₈ 盍蓋 here and under {hé₅ 合} are dificult to sort out.
	WT ’gebs-pa, bkab … ``to cover'', sgab-pa ``to cover'', kʰebs < *keps or *kaps ``a cover'' (Bodman 1980: 49); PKiranti *kapt ~ *kap ``to thatch, cover with bedclothes'' [van Driem 1995: 252], JP mə³¹-kap³¹ ``lid'' ⪤ gap³¹ ``to cover'' (house) (see also HPTB: 142). Perh. also WB kap ``join, unite, adhere'', JP kap⁵⁵ ``to stick, adhere to, join a group''.
	MK *ckup, *ckəp, *ckap (and more variants) ``to cover'' (Shorto 2006 #1237): Mon gap ``be fit for, fit to, pleasing to'', Khmer gā’pa /koəp/, OKhmer gap ``to meet, strike, fit, suit, match, agree, please, be pleasing …''
	The tone C derivative gài (LH kɑs, not kuɑs or kos) makes it clear that the OC rime was not *op.
	The three unrelated etyma {hé₅ 合} *gə̂p, hé₈ 盍蓋 *gâp, and {huì₁ 會} *gwâts have partially converged in OC.
::OKhmer	gap	``to meet, strike, fit, suit, match, agree, please, be pleasing …''
>:Area etymon. Items under hé₈ 盍蓋 here and under {hé₅ 合} are dificult to sort out

	This etymon is distinct from PTB *m-kal ``kidney'' ({gān₅ 肝}), and Tiddim Chin xaːl³, Lushai ṭʰaalᴸ < *kraals ``groin''; WB kʰaᴮ ``loins''.

	[C] An allofam is prob. {qí₆ 騎} ``ride''.

ENTRY:1354
HEAD:hè₄ 赫
MC:Middle Chinese: xɐk 
LH:Later Han: hak 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *hrâk 
OCB:Baxter Old Chinese: *xrak
GLOSS:"Glowing red" (face),
GLOSS:"brilliant" >
GLOSS:"to manifest, fiery" (drought) [Shi], ``fiery red'' [SW].
	[E] The phonologically most plausible affiliation is with PTB *s-ryak > Kan. Bunan śrag ``ashamed'', WT šags ``joke, jest'' (at other's expense) < *rhjak.
	Without medial *j: PTB *s-rak ~ *k-rak: PL *s-rakᴸ, WB hrak ``be ashamed, shy'', Mikir tʰèrák < s-rak ? ``shy, bashful''.
	With initial k-: Magari kʰa-rak ``be ashamed'' (STC no. 431), WT kʰrag ``blood''; loaned into PWa sə[ŋ]-krak ``red''. These forms may furthermore be related to TB ones with the root *jak: Lushai zakᴸ / zaʔᴸ < jak, Kachin kəjaʔ ``be ashamed, shy'' (STC no. 452 p. 113; p. 106, 108).
	The OC form goes back to a ST stem without medial *j.
	These TB items have also been connected with {chì₃ 赤} ``red'' and {sè₁ 色} ``color'' (STC no. 431, 458).
	An allofam may be {xiá₄ 赮瑕霞騢} (ɣa) ``red''.
	A semantic extension of this word is perhaps {hè₅ 赫} ``be scary''.
::Kachin	kəjaʔ	``be ashamed, shy''
>:The phonologically most plausible affiliation is with PTB *s-ryak >
>:Kan. Bunan śrag ``ashamed''
>:WT šags ``joke, jest''  < *rhjak

	This wf may be a semantic extension of {hè₄ 赫} ``red'' already on the ST level: ``red'' > ``red in the face'' > ``angry, scary'' / ``ashamed''.
::OTib	skrags	``fear''

ENTRY:1362
HEAD:hēi 黑
MC:Middle Chinese: xək 
LH:Later Han: hək 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *hmə̂k
GLOSS:"Black" [Shi].
GLOSS-NOTE:This is a relatively late OC word which replaced {xuán₁ 玄}
GLOSS:"black" during the Zhou period.
	[T] Sin Sukchu SR xəj (入), LR xəjʔ
	[T] MGZY hiy (入) [xij]
	[<] Hēi is perhaps derived from mò ``ink'' (it cannot be the other way around: *hm- is secondary, *m- primary) meaning originally ``to mark with ink'' (as a criminal's face), ``having dark markings'' (Baxter 1983); thus this word might originally have been the regular caus. of mò 墨 ``ink, black'' ({§5.2.2}).
	[E] ST: WT smag ``dark, darkness'', mog-pa ``dark-colored''; Limbu mak ``black, dark'' (of color, also the color of blood) ⪤ makt- ``to become night'', JP maʔ³¹ < mak³¹ black’. WB hmaŋ ``ink'' is not a CH loan but a loan translation, it belongs to {méi₉ 煤} ``soot'' (note that WT also has a loan translation for ``ink'': snag).
	On the basis of Chinese, at least two ST roots need to be distinguished: (1) *mək ``black, dark'' ? ⪤ *mə(k) ``soot, black'', and (2) *mak/ŋ ``dark'' (HPTB: 522); these have converged in PTB *mak/ŋ (in some TB languages also ``color of blood > dark red > red'').
	Items of the type *mak/ŋ in CH include: {mò₈ 莫瞙暯} (mâk) ``obscure'', {mù₄ 莫暮} (muoᶜ) ``evening'', {mù₅ 墓} (muoᶜ) ``tomb''; perhaps also {máng₃ 芒茫} ``obscure'', {máng₄ 盲} (mɐŋ) ``blind''.
	Etyma meaning ``silent'' may belong to this complex as well, including mò 莫嗼 (mɐk), mò 莫寞漠 (mâk), {mò₁₅ 默嘿} (mək) (perhaps s. w. as mò 墨 ``ink, black'' above).
	The word {huì₇ 晦} ``dark'' is prob. unrelated.
	There are additional words with initial m- and almost any rime which mean ``cover, dark, blind, confused, obscure''; relations may even extend to etyma meaning ``covering vegetation: luxuriant, weeds'' ({wú₅ 蕪廡}).
	An allofam is prob. {méi₉ 煤} ``soot''.
::WB	hmaŋ	``ink''
>:WT smag ``dark, darkness'', mog-pa ``dark-colored''
>:Limbu mak ``black, dark''  ⪤ makt- ``to become night''
>:JP maʔ³¹ < mak³¹ black’. WB hmaŋ ``ink'' is not a CH loan but a loan translation, it belongs to {méi₉ 煤} ``soot''

ENTRY:1372
HEAD:hóng₁ 虹
MC:Middle Chinese: ɣuŋ 
LH:Later Han: goŋ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *gôŋ < *gloŋ
GLOSS:"Rainbow" [Li].
	[D] Dialect forms are very irregular: PMin *ghioŋᴮ, but Jiànyáng leŋᶜ¹, G-Shànggāo dial. has lɑnᴮ-luŋᴴ (Sagart 1993: 196).
	[E] <> PY *kluŋᴬ ``rainbow'' (Haudricourt 1950: 559). Benedict (1986: 58) and Carr (LTBA 13.2, 1990: 105) suggest that hóng is related to {lóng₃ 龍} ``dragon'' and {hóng₂ 紅} ``red''.
	[E] The wide range of forms, including dì-dōng (below), speaks for a non-ST source for this etymon. <> Kam-Tai: Zhuang lgs. have tu²-tuŋ² ``rainbow'' and the like, where tu² is a prefix added to animals and persons.
	Li Xu-lian (1997) reconstructs this prefix as PT *ta, among others based on forms like Wuming ta⁶ and Bama tiə⁶.
	Luó Yǒngxiàn (MKS 27: 1997: 272) reconstructs PTai *Druŋ: S. ruŋᶜ² ``rainbow''.
	Dōng (*tloŋ) is prob. a variant of hóng (*kroŋh).
>:PY *kluŋᴬ ``rainbow'' . Benedict  and Carr  suggest that hóng is related to {lóng₃ 龍} ``dragon'' and {hóng₂ 紅} ``red''
>:The wide range of forms, including dì-dōng , speaks for a non-ST source for this etymon. < > Kam-Tai:
>:Zhuang lgs. have tu²-tuŋ² ``rainbow'' and the like, where tu² is a prefix added to animals and persons

	[E] MK: Khmer khvēṅa /kwaaɛŋ/ ``to cross, intersect, be diagonal, crisscross'' (⇒ Tai: S. kwaŋ² ``to lie athwart, transverse, crosswise'') < vēṅa /wɛɛŋ/ ``cut across, traverse, intersect''. The derivative gravēṅa /krɔwɛɛŋ/ ``turn, hurl overhead …'' agrees phonologically with OC.

	This stem is prob. distinct from {hòu₁ 后} ``sovereign''.

ENTRY:1390
HEAD:hóu₄ 喉
MC:Middle Chinese: ɣəu 
LH:Later Han: go 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *gô
GLOSS:"Throat" [Shi].
	[E] Etymology not certain, but note Chepang guk ``throat''. AA has similar items: PMK *kɔʔ ``neck'' (Shorto 1976: 1062) > PMonic *kɔɔʔ ``neck, narrow part of a long object'', PSBahn. *nəkɔː ``neck'', Viet. ko’ ``neck'', Khmer kɑɑ [Huffman 1975]. <> Tai S. kʰɔɔᴬ² < *ɣ- ``neck, throat'' (Li F. 1976: 42), Saek ɣɔɔᴬ².
	Alternatively, this word may possibly be related to WT mgul(-pa) ~ ’gul ``neck, throat'' (< ’gul-ba ``to move''), or mgur ``throat, neck, voice'' (so Unger Hao-ku 35, 1986: 33).
	HST 112 connects WT mgul with gěn 䫀 (kənᴮ) ``neck'' [GY].

ENTRY:1391
HEAD:hóu₅ 猴
MC:Middle Chinese: ɣəu 
LH:Later Han: go 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *gô
	[D] PMin *ğəu < *ɴgo ?
GLOSS:"Monkey" [Zhuang].
	[E] ST: PL *ʔ-ko²/¹. The first syllable in mǔ-hóu 母猴, mù-hóu 沐猴 ``macaque'' may perhaps be an old pre-initial (Unger Hao-ku 31, 1985: 308).
	This may be supported by the PMin form whose softened initial derives from an earlier pre-nasalized one acc. to Norman 1986.
	V. Blazek (in Pinault et al. 1997: 236f) notes LB-Akha mjo kʰœ ``monkey'' which he derives from PL *mjok and suggests is the source of the CH word, which in turn, citing Lüders, might possibly have been the source of IE-PTocharian *moko.
	For syn. see {yóu₈ 猶}.
::LB-Akha	mjo kʰœ	``monkey''

ENTRY:1392

	{hòu₁} 后

ENTRY:1393
HEAD:hòu₁ 后
MC:Middle Chinese: ɣəuᴮ/ᶜ 
LH:Later Han: goᴮ/ᶜ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *gôʔ/h
	(``Head'' in society:) ``sovereign, lord'' [Shi], ``queen'' [Zuo].
	[E] {hóu₁ 侯} ``target > archer, feudal lord'' is often considered cognate (e.g. Mei Tsu-Lin in Thurgood 1985: 335f).
	Though possible, these two words seem to represent two different concepts and thus derive from different roots.
	This is supported by the consistent distinction of these near synonyms in literature.
	The hòu 后 under consideration here has the basic meaning ``head''; it is thus a ST etymon *go which is cognate to WT go ``headman'' ⪤ mgo ``head''.
	This word is prob. a tone B derivation from the following items, lit. ``the person which is functioning as head''.
	This stem may perhaps also be cognate to {yuán₁ 元} ``head''.
::WT	go	``headman''
>:{hóu₁ 侯} ``target > archer, feudal lord'' is often considered cognate

ENTRY:1394

LH:Later Han: go,goᶜ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *gô(h)
GLOSS:"Arrow with metal point" [Shi].
GLOSS-NOTE:In Shījīng the word rimes both in *-o and in *-oh (Baxter 1992: 763).
	[D] Acc. to FY 9,4, this is a Han period Yangtze-Huái dialect word for ``arrow''.

ENTRY:1421
HEAD:hǔ₁ 虎
MC:Middle Chinese: xuoᴮ 
LH:Later Han: hɑᴮ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *hlâʔ (hl-!) 
OCB:Baxter Old Chinese: *hlāʔ
GLOSS:"Tiger" [OB, Shi].
GLOSS-NOTE:The name of this dangerous animal is subject to taboo.
	It was there-fore apt to be replaced by a different word, or at least undergo some modification.
	One way is to add a prefix or word which indicates respect, hence Mand. lǎo-hǔ 老虎 ``old (= venerable) tiger''; the prefix yú < *ʔa in yú-tù etc. served the same purpose in the OC dialect word, see below and {ā 阿}.
	The other method is to distort the pronunciation by using a dialect word as in hǔ whose phonology indicates a possible rural or vulgar origin (voiceless *lh- > MC x-, {§5.6}).
	[D] The regular OC equivalent of foreign *kl- is expected to be a voiceless *lh- > MC śj- or tʰ-. Such forms are found in old dialects (Pulleyblank 1983: 427): (1) yú-tù 於兔/菟 (ʔjwo-tʰuoᶜ) [ʔɨɑ-tʰɑh] OCM *ʔa-lhâk is a Chǔ dialect word recorded in the 5th cent. BC Zuǒzhuàn.
	The Hòu Hànshū has a variant yú-shì 於檡 (ʔjwo-śjäk) [ʔɨɑ-śiak] OCM *ʔa-lhak. The FY has a further graphic variant yú-tù 於䖘 to which Guō Pú adds that south of the Yangtze, the pronunciation of tù is like gǒu-dòu 苟竇 (kəuᴮ-dəuᶜ), i.e. a hypothetical OCM *kôʔ-lôh which comes close to AA forms.
	Some modern interior Min dialects have *kʰoᴮ, but the stop feature is prob. secondary.
	[E] PAA *kalaʔ ``tiger'' > PMK *klaʔ (Shorto 2006 #197) > OKhm *klaa (> later Angkorian Khmer khlaa; ⇒ Tai: S. kla²), PMonic *klaaʔ [Diffloth 1984], Munda kula, Kharia ki’ɽɔʔ (Norman a. Mei 1976: 286-288; Benedict 1976: 97; Pulleyblank 1983: 427).
	PVM *k-haːlʔ, Khmer khaːl ``tiger'' (in the name of a year) could be related.
	<> MK ⇒ PTB *k-la (Matisoff 1995a: 52), PL *k-la², OBurm. kla, WB kyaᴮ (IST: 334), Monpa khai-la looks similar to PVM.
::Khmer	khaːl	``tiger''
>:PAA *kalaʔ ``tiger'' >
>:PMK *klaʔ  >
>:OKhm *klaa
>:PMonic *klaaʔ
>:Munda kula
>:Kharia ki’ɽɔʔ

ENTRY:1422

	[T] ONW ɣo
	[E] ST: PTB *m-ka ``opening, mouth'' (HPTB: 173) > PLB *ʔga¹ ⪤ *ga³ ``open, divaricate, spread'' [Matisoff D. of Lahu: 230], WB tam-kʰaᴮ ``door'', NNaga *gaᴬ ``door'', WT sgo ``door'' (HST: 66; WT o can derive regularly from TB *a). ENTRY:1426
HEAD:hù₃ 互枑
MC:Middle Chinese: ɣouᶜ 
LH:Later Han: gɑᶜ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *gâh
GLOSS:"Intertwining, crossing, barrier, a stand" (of crossing sticks) [Zhouli];
GLOSS:"each other" 互;
GLOSS:"railings, fence" 枑 [Zhouli].
	[E] ST: Lushai kʰaarᴿ < kʰaarʔ ``a dam or weir, roughly constructed of leafy bows or bamboo lattice-work'' (sometimes used for catching fish); WB ka ``make a barrier, cover on the side, put up fence'' ⪤ ə-ka ``side of building, external part''. For TB final r, see {§7.7.5}.
	The wf {gòu₃ 冓} agrees with hù in all but the vowel.
	Putative TB cognates seem to confirm that these are two separate roots.
>:Lushai kʰaarᴿ < kʰaarʔ ``a dam or weir, roughly constructed of leafy bows or bamboo lattice-work''
>:WB ka ``make a barrier, cover on the side, put up fence'' ⪤ ə-ka ``side of building, external part''. For TB final r, see {§7.7.5}

ENTRY:1434
HEAD:huā 花
MC:Middle Chinese: xwa
GLOSS:"Flower", originally a noun (see Wáng Lì 1982: 142 for a discussion of this wf).
	The graph (whose OC rime should be *-ai) has been borrowed for an etymon in OC *-a).
	[T] Sin Sukchu SR xwa (平)
	[T] MGZY hwa (平) [xwa]
	[T] ONW xuä
	[E] TB languages often alternate initial labial stops *p, *b with *w, also in the root for ``blossom, flower'' *bar ({pā 葩}, {bàn 瓣}) (Matisoff LL 1.2, 2000: 144-146). Huā may be an example of the ST *bar ~ *war variation (for the metathesis of the final *r, see {§7.7.3}).
	Alternatively, note OKhmer /pkaa/ ``flower''; the complex AA initial might have been the reason for the CH development.
::OKhmer	/pkaa/	``flower''
>:TB languages often alternate initial labial stops *p, *b with *w, also in the root for ``blossom, flower'' *bar  . Huā may be an example of the ST *bar ~ *war variation

ENTRY:1443
HEAD:huà₄ 畫

LH:Later Han: ɣuɛᶜ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *wekh or *(g)wrekh
GLOSS:"Painted, with a design" adj. [BI, Shu] >
GLOSS:"to draw a design, depict" [Meng].
	[T] MGZY Xway (去) [ɣwaj]
	[T] ONW ɣuä
	[<] exopass. of huò 畫 (*wek) ({§4.4}).
	[E] MK: OKhmer gur ~ gvar ``to draw a line, make a drawing'' [S. Lewitz, AA Studies 2, 1976: 742], with OC final -k added which caused the metathesis of the MK final r ({§6.1}): *gwer + k > gwrek. Alternatively, *wek alone could be the simplest OCM form ({§9.1.4}).
	The vocalic discrepancy has parallels, see {§11.1.3}.
>:OKhmer gur ~ gvar ``to draw a line, make a drawing'' , with OC final -k added which caused the metathesis of the MK final r :

ENTRY:1463
HEAD:huāng₁ 衁
MC:Middle Chinese: xwâŋ 
LH:Later Han: huɑŋ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *hmâŋ
GLOSS:"Blood" [Zuo, Xi Gong 15, quoting Yi 54,6].
GLOSS-NOTE:This rare word's occurrence in a traditional saying indicates that it is not part of the active vocabulary of OC, but a survival from a substrate language.
	[E] MK *jhaam, *jhiim ``blood'' (Shorto 2006 #1430): PNorth Bahnaric *maham, PMnong *mham, Asli maham (Benjamin 1976: 103), Khmu maːm < *mh-; without m-infix: PVM *ʔa-saːmʔ, Khmer jham, PMonic *chim, Katuic *ʔə(ŋ)haːm, Mundari maj̃ɔm. The MK root was *jhaːm (Diffloth 1977: 50), or -TSɑm (Ferlus, MKS 7, 1978: 18). ⇒ PMY *ntšhjaamᴮ (Mei 1980; Bodman 1980: 120).
	CH has final -ŋ because initial and final m are mutually exclusive.
	The OC initial was probably a voiceless *m- which can derived from, among others, a prehistoric cluster with either *h or *s.
>:MK *jhaam, *jhiim ``blood'' :
>:PNorth Bahnaric *maham
>:PMnong *mham
>:Asli maham
>:Khmu maːm < *mh-
>:without m-infix:
>:PVM *ʔa-saːmʔ
>:Khmer jham
>:PMonic *chim
>:Katuic *ʔəhaːm, Mundari maj̃ɔm. The MK root was *jhaːm , or -TSɑm . ⇒ PMY *ntšhjaamᴮ

HEAD:huáng₁ 皇

GLOSS:"royal, imperial".

	Bodman 1980: 107 connects huáng with {wáng₂ 王} ``king''.
::Khmer	luːəŋ	``king, royal''

OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *hmai
GLOSS:"Signal flag" [Zuo],
GLOSS:"to signal" [Shi].
	[E] The area word {xuè₂ 𥄎} ``wink with eyes'' has prob. influenced the CH meaning of huī 麾. Huī 麾 *hmai looks like a conflation of huī 撝 *hwai ``to signal'' (under {wēi₂ 逶}) and huī 徽 *hməi ``to signal''.
>:The area word {xuè₂ 𥄎} ``wink with eyes'' has prob. influenced the CH meaning of huī 麾. Huī 麾 *hmai looks like a conflation of huī 撝 *hwai ``to signal''  and huī 徽 *hməi ``to signal''

GLOSS:"To signal, display" [Shu],
GLOSS:"a flag" [Li] is apparently a vocalic variant.
	[E] ST: PTB *s-mwəy (HPTB: 195) > WB hmweᶜ ``whirl about, twirl'', Lushai hmuiᴿ < hmuiʔ ``spinning wheel''.
::Lushai	hmuiᴿ < hmuiʔ	``spinning wheel''

ENTRY:1481
HEAD:huī₆ 墮隳 ⪤ huǐ 毀燬
MC:Middle Chinese: xjwieᴮ 
LH:Later Han: hyɑiᴮ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *hmaiʔ ?
GLOSS:"To destroy, ruin" [Shi],
GLOSS:"perish" (people) [Hanfei],
GLOSS:"lose" (e.g., teeth) 毀; ``destroy'' (by fire), ``blazing fire'' 燬 [Shi].
GLOSS-NOTE:This is an ancient dialect word for
GLOSS:"fire" in Qí 齊 [FY 10: 6 — written 𤈦 but pronounced 毀]. This word also occurs in Tai: S. maiᶜ¹ < *hm-
GLOSS:"to burn".

ENTRY:1482
HEAD:huī₆ 墮隳 ⪤ huǐ 𤈦
MC:Middle Chinese: xjweiᴮ 
LH:Later Han: huiᴮ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *hməiʔ
GLOSS:"To burn" [SW: Shi], a phonological variant of huǐ above (Baxter 1992: 417). See also  {huǒ₁ 火}
GLOSS:"fire".

ENTRY:1483
HEAD:huí 回
MC:Middle Chinese: ɣwậi 
LH:Later Han: ɣuəi 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *wûi
	[T] ONW ɣuɑi
GLOSS:"To revolve, swerve, deflect" [Shi],
GLOSS:"go round by" [Zuo];
GLOSS:"go up against a stream" 洄 [Shi].
GLOSS-NOTE:Also written 迴徊.
	Downer (1959: 285) reads ``go around, go by way of'' in tone C which implies an ``effective'' meaning.
	[C] Allofams are {guī₃ 歸} ``return''; {wéi₆ 違} ``turn against'' from which huí is derived.
	[E] Many CH and TB words for ``round, turn'' look similar. Most have initial *w- and foreign final -n, -l, -r, or -i, and therefore they are difficult to sort out, so that Bodman, Karlgren, Wáng Lì and other investigators have connected them in different ways.
	The merger of earlier final *-l and *-r into either OC *-n or *-i makes it impossible at the moment to find a rational way of associating foreign with OC items:
GLOSS:1:OC *-wan > MC rime -uan, -jwɐn / -jwän < OC *-uan, *-wan, *-on can derive from earlier ST or foreign -wan, -war, -wal, -(w)on, -(w)or, -(w)ol; given the latitude of sound correspondences, the vowels could in some words even have been e or u, beside a and o.
	See {yuán₅ 員圓圜}, {yuán₇ 園}, {huán₁ 桓垸}, {huán₃ 還}, huán 環鐶寰 (under {yíng₄ 營}).
GLOSS:2:OC *-wən or *wun  MC rime -uən / -jwən < OC *-un / *-wən can derive from earlier ST or foreign -un, -wun, -wən, -ul, -wul, -wəl, -ur, wur, -wər; given i ~ u interchanges when in contact with labials, the foreign rime could also have been -win, -wil, -wir.
	See {yún₅ 雲}, {yùn₂ 運暈}
GLOSS:3:OC *-wəi or *-wui  MC rime -uậi / -jwei < OC *-wəi or *-(w)ui  can derive from earlier ST or foreign -ui, -wui, -wəi, -ul, -wul, -wəl, rarely also from -ur, wur, -wər.
	See huí 回 (above), {wéi₆ 違}, {guī₃ 歸}; {wéi₅ 圍}, {wèi₇ 衛}
GLOSS:4:Unusual (``marked'') rimes can be associated with outside cognates somewhat more confidently:
	OC *-weŋ See {yíng₄ 營}, {yǒng₇ 禜}; and {yíng₅ 縈}, {yīng₄ 嬰}
	OC *-win See {jūn₂ 鈞}
	TB languages have additional words of this general shape and meaning, often with initial k.
	This k complicates the process of etymological identification even further because it may or may not have been a removable element, like a prefix.
	Such items include: (1) Lushai kuaiᴸ / kɔiʔᴸ ``bend, pull down'', WB kweᴮ ``bend around''. (2) Lushai kualᴸ ``coil'', WB kʰweᴮ. (3) Lushai kulᴴ / kulʔᴸ ``be bent''. (4) Lushai kʰɔɔrᴿ ``double up, roll up'' ({quán₃ 卷拳?}). (5) WT ’kʰor ``circle, turn'', Lepcha var, vor, note also Khmer vāra /wíiər/ ``go around, circle, revolve''. (6) Lushai inᴸ-kʰerʔᴸ ``twisted together''. (7) Lushai hrual ``roll up in the hand'' ? ⪤ Lepcha rol ``roll''.
	Furthermore, note AA: PVM *veːl ``return'' ⪤ *k-veːl ``village'', Bru kəwir ``to stir'' [Huffman 1975: 13].
::Bru	kəwir	``to stir''
>:Many CH and TB words for ``round, turn'' look similar. Most have initial *w- and foreign final -n, -l, -r, or -i, and therefore they are difficult to sort out, so that Bodman
>:Karlgren
>:Wáng Lì and other investigators have connected them in different ways

ENTRY:1484
HEAD:huí 回 ⪤ huí-yù 回遹

LH:Later Han: ɣuəi-ju(i)t 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *wûi-wit ?
GLOSS:"Be awry, crooked, perverse" [Shi].

ENTRY:1485
HEAD:huǐ₁ 虫虺
MC:Middle Chinese: xjweiᴮ 
LH:Later Han: huiᴮ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *hmuiʔ ?
GLOSS:"Snake" 虺 [Shi], 虫 [OB, SW, Shanhaijing],
GLOSS:"reptile-amphibian" [Western Han] (Yates EC 19, 1994: 91 [apparently not
GLOSS:"insect"]). Since 虫 is a basic graph, the word must be very old.
	[E] ST: PTB *b-ruːl (STC no. 447) > WT sbrul < s-mrul?, PLB *m-r-wiy¹ [Matisoff D. of Lahu: 1338] > WB mrwe ``snake'', KN *m-ruul, Lushai ruulᴴ < ruul (Shī Xiàngdōng 2000: 196), Chepang ru ``snake''. MC xjweiᴮ is a regular equivalent for TB / ST protoforms like *s-mrul, *ʔmrul or *hmrul.
	As to foreign initial b- for CH m-, see {§5.12.2}.
	PWa *mɔy ``cobra'' looks like a loan from a LB language.
	The syn. and ordinary word {shé₂ 蛇} ``snake'', lit. ``the winding thing'', is due to taboo (see {hǔ₁ 虎} ``tiger'' for another tabooed animal).
::PWa	*mɔy	``cobra''
>:PTB *b-ruːl  >
>:WT sbrul < s-mrul?
>:PLB *m-r-wiy¹  >
>:WB mrwe ``snake''
>:KN *m-ruul
>:Lushai ruulᴴ < ruul
>:Chepang ru ``snake''. MC xjweiᴮ is a regular equivalent for TB / ST protoforms like *s-mrul, *ʔmrul or *hmrul

ENTRY:1489
HEAD:huì₁ 會
MC:Middle Chinese: ɣuâiᶜ 
LH:Later Han: guɑs 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *gwâ(t)s or *gô(t)s 
OCB:Baxter Old Chinese: *gots < *gops
GLOSS:"To join, come together" (two rivers, people) [Shi] > caus.
GLOSS:"to bring together, join" [BI, Shi].
GLOSS-NOTE:{huì₂ 會}
GLOSS:"lid" is a late semantic extension.
	[T] Sin Sukchu SR ɣuj (去)
	[T] MGZY Xue (去) [ɣuɛ]
	[T]  MTang guɑi, ONW ɣuɑC
	[<] endopass. of guì 會襘 (kuâiᶜ) ({§4.6}).
	[E] This group is derived from {kuò₁ 括} *kot or *kwat (Sagart 1999: 56). The basic ST meaning seems to be: put arms / belt / band around something and connect / tie it.
	The three unrelated etyma {hé₅ 合} *gə̂p, {hé₈ 盍蓋} *gâp, and huì 會 *gwâts have partially converged in OC.
>:This group is derived from {kuò₁ 括} *kot or *kwat . The basic ST meaning seems to be:
>:put arms / belt / band around something and connect / tie it

ENTRY:1490
HEAD:huì₁ 會 ⪤ guì 會襘
MC:Middle Chinese: kuâiᶜ 
LH:Later Han: kuɑs 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *kwâ(t)s or *kô(t)s
GLOSS:"Keep together (hair)" tr. 會 [Shi],
GLOSS:"bind up hair in a knot" 鬠 [Yili] (also MC ɣuât; also written with the phonetic of {kuò₁ 括}); (adding up:)
GLOSS:"calculation, account" 會 [Li] (Karlgren 1956: 10); ``joining point of the two ends of a collar or belt'' 襘 [Zuo] (Wáng Lì 1982: 487).

ENTRY:1491
HEAD:huì₂ 會
MC:Middle Chinese: ɣuâiᶜ 
LH:Later Han: guɑs 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *gwâ(t) or *gô(t)s
	[T] MTang guɑi ONW ɣuɑC
GLOSS:"Lid, cover" [Yili].
	[E] This is a late [Yili] semantic extension from {huì₁ 會} ``join, come together'', formed in analogy to the common association of ``join'' with ``close, lid'' in the wfs {hé₅ 合} and {hé₈ 盍蓋}. The former {hé₅ 合} *gəp is related to PTB *kup (hence PCH *gup > *guəp > *gəp), the latter {hé₈ 盍蓋} to PTB *gap (hence PCH, OC *gap).
	There is no ST, AA or PCH simplex *gop from which huì might have been derived.
>:This is a late  semantic extension from {huì₁ 會} ``join, come together'', formed in analogy to the common association of ``join'' with ``close, lid'' in the wfs {hé₅ 合} and {hé₈ 盍蓋}. The former {hé₅ 合} *gəp is related to PTB *kup , the latter {hé₈ 盍蓋} to PTB *gap

ENTRY:1497
HEAD:huì₇ 晦
MC:Middle Chinese: xwậiᶜ 
LH:Later Han: huəᶜ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *hmə̂ʔ ! 
OCB:Baxter Old Chinese: *hmə(k)ʔ(s)
GLOSS:"Be dark, darkness" (of sky, clouds) > metaphorical
GLOSS:"dark" [Shi],
GLOSS:"night time" (vs. míng 明 ``day time'') [Guoyu], ``last day of the lunar month'' [Chunqiu].
GLOSS-NOTE:Shījīng rimes indicate tone B (Mattos 1971: 309).
	[E] Prob. MK: OKhmer kmval /kmuuəl/ ``be cloudy, overcast, dark, beclouded, be as black as a cloud''.
	For the absence of final *-l in CH after a MK long vowel, see {§6.9}.
	Since the word refers primarily to meteorological and natural conditions, and seems to be related to a synonymous and (mutatis mutandis) homophonous MK etymon, it is prob. not related to ST {méi₉ 煤} ``soot'', {hēi 黑} ``black'', {mén₃ 悶} ``unconsciously''.
	A cognate is prob. {hǎi₁ 海} ``ocean''.
>:Prob. MK:
>:OKhmer kmval /kmuuəl/ ``be cloudy, overcast, dark, beclouded, be as black as a cloud''

ENTRY:1498

GLOSS:"numerous" [Shi].
GLOSS-NOTE:If related to {lèi₂ 類}, this may perhaps be a form which has treated the initial *r as a prefix and dropped it ({§10.1.3}).
	The same graph huì also writes {huì₉ 彙} ``porcupine'' which has possibly a similar variant in the initial.

ENTRY:1499
HEAD:huì₉ 彙
MC:Middle Chinese: jweiᶜ 
LH:Later Han: wus 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *wəs (< *wus?)
GLOSS:"Porcupine" [SW].
GLOSS-NOTE:The same graph also writes a word {huì₈ 彙}
GLOSS:"category" which is perhaps a variant of a word with initial l-: {lèi₂ 類} ({§10.1.3}).
	[E] Perhaps from MK *[r]kus, *[r]kuus, *[r]kuəs, *[r]k[iə]s ``porcupine'' (Shorto 2006 #1883; p.33) >  Lushai kuʔᴸ < kus ``porcupine, quill of a p.'' In CH the foreign initial k was perhaps ignored as a prefix. Cantonese has the curious form lœyᶜ² (Bodman 1980: 89).
>:Perhaps from MK *kus, *kuus, *kuəs, *ks ``porcupine''  >
>:Lushai kuʔᴸ < kus ``porcupine, quill of a p.'' In CH the foreign initial k was perhaps ignored as a prefix. Cantonese has the curious form lœyᶜ²

ENTRY:1500
HEAD:huì₁₀ 顪喙
MC:Middle Chinese: xjwɐiᶜ 
LH:Later Han: hyɑs 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *hwats
	[T] ONW hueiᶜ
GLOSS:"Beard of chin" 顪 [Zhuang], GY also:
GLOSS:"jiá 頰 jaw, cheek";
GLOSS:"snout" 喙 [Zuo; JDSW xjwɐiᶜ], ``mouth'' [SW] (the last graph has additional readings which prob. belong to the meaning ``to pant''). For MC x-, see {§5.6}.
	The meanings of these homophonous graphs slide gradually into each other (``jaw'' written with ``beard''), therefore this seems to be one etymon, although ``beard'' might have entered OC via KT (note the identical meanings), while ``snout'' might have been inherited from ST, unless it is a TB loan.
	For semantics, note that a ``schnauzer'' is not noted for its snout (which all dogs have), but for its striking mustache.
	[E] KT: S. nuatᴰ¹ᴸ < *hn- ``beard'' which appears to have come ultimately from some Burmese-like TB lg.: WB hnut ``mouth, womb'', used in composits for ``beard''. Since there is no hint of a nasal initial in OC, Tai is unlikely to have been the borrower.
	Huì seems to be related in a roundabout way to {xū₄ 須鬚}, see there for more TB cognates.
>:KT:
>:S. nuatᴰ¹ᴸ < *hn- ``beard'' which appears to have come ultimately from some Burmese-like TB lg.:
>:WB hnut ``mouth, womb'', used in composits for ``beard''. Since there is no hint of a nasal initial in OC
>:Tai is unlikely to have been the borrower

ENTRY:1503
HEAD:hūn₁ 婚
MC:Middle Chinese: xuən 
LH:Later Han: huən 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *hmə̂n
	[T] ONW hon
GLOSS:"Relations by marriage, wife, in-laws" [BI, Shi];
GLOSS:"wife's father" [EY, Zuo],
GLOSS:"wife's family" [SW]; hūn-yīn 婚姻 ``relatives'' [Shi], ``marriage'' [Li].
GLOSS-NOTE:Wáng Lì (1982: 508) quotes from Han-period literature:
GLOSS:"wedding" is called hūn because the ceremony takes place at dusk hūn 昏 (under {mén₃ 悶}) [SW, Shiming, Baihu tong], but this looks like a folk etymology. One may speculate instead that hūn
GLOSS:"dark" signifies ``female'', like its synonym {yīn₅ 陰} ``dark''.

ENTRY:1507
HEAD:hún₁ 魂
MC:Middle Chinese: ɣuən 
LH:Later Han: ɣuən 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *wûn
GLOSS:"Spiritual soul" [Zuo] as opposed to {pò₄ 魄}
GLOSS:"animal soul". Since pò is the
GLOSS:"bright" soul, hún is the ``dark'' soul and therefore cognate to {yún₅ 雲} ``cloud'' (Carr, CAAAL 24, 1985: 62), perhaps in the sense of ``shadowy'' because some believe that the hún soul will live after death in a world of shadows (Wolfram Eberhard Guilt and Sin in ancient China, 1967: 17).

ENTRY:1512

	[T] Sin Sukchu SR k'un (去)
	[T] MGZY khun (去) [k'un]
	[T] ONW kʰon
	[E] Perh. related to Mand. kùn 睏 ``sleepy''. Alternatively, this word may be derived from {kùn₁ 困} ``obstruct'' [Yi], as emotions are often expressed by concrete notions, but this is not likely in light of hùn 溷慁 above. HST: 63 related this word to WT kʰur ``burden, load''.
	A further cognate may be {jiǒng₄ 窘} in which case this and the doublet of hún point to a PCH final *-uŋ.

ENTRY:1517
HEAD:huǒ₁ 火 ⪤ huǐ 𤈦
MC:Middle Chinese: xjweiᴮ 
LH:Later Han: huiᴮ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *hməiʔ
	This is a Han-period dialect word for ``fire'' in Wú 吳 [Xù Fāngyán p:4]. See also {huī₆ 墮隳}.
	[E] ST: PTB *mey (STC no. 290) > WT me, OTib. smye; Chepang hmeʔ; PLB *ʔmey² [Matisoff], PL *C-mi²  [Bradley], WB miᴮ, Lushai meiᴿ < meiʔ. The relationship with {huī₆ 墮隳}, if any, is not clear (dialect? convergence?).
>:PTB *mey  >
>:WT me
>:OTib. smye
>:Chepang hmeʔ
>:PLB *ʔmey²
>:PL *C-mi²
>:WB miᴮ
>:Lushai meiᴿ < meiʔ. The relationship with {huī₆ 墮隳}, if any, is not clear

ENTRY:1518
HEAD:huǒ₂ 夥
MC:Middle Chinese: ɣuâᴮ 
LH:Later Han: guɑiᴮ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *gwâiʔ or *gôiʔ
GLOSS:"Many", an old Han-period dial. word in the outlying areas of Qí and Sòng and in the region between Chǔ and Wèi [FY 1.21].
GLOSS-NOTE:It survives in Mǐn dialects: PMin *oiᶜ ~ *uaiᴮ
GLOSS:"many" (Norman 1983: 204).

ENTRY:1545
HEAD:jī₁₄ 機璣
MC:Middle Chinese: kjei 
LH:Later Han: kɨi 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *kəi
	[T] ONW ki
GLOSS:"Mechanical device" 機 [Zhuang], 璣 [Shu].
GLOSS-NOTE:Karlgren (1956: 5) considered this the s. w. as {jī₁₂ 幾} which is glossed as
GLOSS:"small", but jī 幾 really means
GLOSS:"be imminent, close to, first sign, detail".
	Instead, jī is perhaps cognate to {qǐ₇ 綮}, thus meaning originally a contraption with hinges or joints, i.e. with moveable parts.

ENTRY:1559
HEAD:jí₆ 疾
MC:Middle Chinese: dzjet 
LH:Later Han: dzit 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *dzit
GLOSS:"Be sick, suffering, defect, evil" [OB, Shi].
	[T] Sin Sukchu SR dzi (入)
	[T] MGZY tsi (入) [dzi]
	[T] ONW dzit
	[E] ST *tsik ``to smolder'' > ``burn'' / ``be ill, illness'' / ``anger'', PTB *m-(t)sik ``burn, angry'' [HPTB], WT ’tsʰig-pa ``to burn, destroy by fire, glow; to be in rut, be inflamed, feverish'' (Bodman 1980: 158); perhaps Chepang ɉik- ``be sick, injured, hurt''. Prob. not related to jì 癠 ``sick'' (under {jǐ₅ 擠}).
	Less likely comparanda: WT sdig-pa ``sin, wickedness'' (Bodman 1980: 158).
	AA items look somewhat similar: PBahn. *ɉiʔ, Wa-Lawa-Palaung *sɨʔ ``sick''.
	STC (170 n. 455) relates this word to PTB *tsa ``hot, pain'', but the vowels differ (i vs. a), see {zāi₁ 災}.
::PTB	*tsa	``hot, pain''
>:ST *tsik ``to smolder'' > ``burn'' / ``be ill, illness'' / ``anger''
>:PTB *m-sik ``burn, angry''
>:WT ’tsʰig-pa ``to burn, destroy by fire, glow; to be in rut, be inflamed, feverish''
>:perhaps Chepang ɉik- ``be sick, injured, hurt''. Prob. not related to jì 癠 ``sick''

ENTRY:1565
HEAD:jí₇ 即 ⪤ nì 昵
MC:Middle Chinese: ṇjet 
LH:Later Han: ṇit 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *nrit
	[T] ONW nit
GLOSS:"Familiarity" [Shu], (a ruler's)
GLOSS:"favorite" (person) [Shu].
GLOSS-NOTE:The homophones {nì₂ 昵}
GLOSS:"glue" and {nì₄ 衵}
GLOSS:"underwear" are prob. not related.
	[E] MK: Khmer jaṃnita /cumnit/ (i.e. etymologically ɉ-n-it) ``nearness, closeness, proximity, familiarity with, intimacy''. The AA nominal n-infix is taken in CH for the root initial, perhaps because of the original voiced initial and the paronomastic attraction to {ěr₇ 邇} (ńźieᴮ) ``near''.
	The CH words jí and nì are thus allofams in an AA wf.
	[C] A possible allofam could be {qīn₅ 親}. Syn. are {ěr₇ 邇}, {ní₁ 尼}, {nì₉ 暱}.
>:Khmer jaṃnita /cumnit/  ``nearness, closeness, proximity, familiarity with, intimacy''. The AA nominal n-infix is taken in CH for the root initial, perhaps because of the original voiced initial and the paronomastic attraction to {ěr₇ 邇}  ``near''

GLOSS:"masonry" is spurious (Pulleyblank 1999: 166), therefore there is no connection with WT rtsig-pa
GLOSS:"to wall up, a wall, masonry" (Bodman 1980: 158).

ENTRY:1570

ENTRY:1572
HEAD:jí₁₃ 集輯
MC:Middle Chinese: dzjəp 
LH:Later Han: dzip 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *dzəp 
OCB:Baxter Old Chinese: *dzjup
	[T] ONW dzip
GLOSS:"Come together and settle (of birds), perch" [Shi] > caus.
GLOSS:"to collect together, unite, settle, achieve" 集 [BI, Shi], 輯 [Shi].
	[E] MK: Khmer cwpa /cùuəp/ ~ jwpa /cúuəp/ ``to join'', intr. ``to meet, come together, encounter'' ⪤ prajcwpa ``to meet one another''. <> The following is prob. a different etymon with the basic meaning ``close'': PTB *tsup > PLB *tsup ~ *ʔtsup [Matisoff 1972: 40] > WB cʰup ``clench fist'', Kachin tsup ``to gather'' (as mouth of sack), ``close hands'' (as in catching a ball) (HST: 84). KN-Lai fuu / fuut ``to perch'' [LTBA 21.1: 18].
	[C] This wf has perhaps converged with {jì₁₀ 揖}. Baxter (1992: 350) adds cuì 萃 (dzwiᶜ) ``collect'' (under {zāo₂ 遭}).
::KN-Lai	fuu / fuut	``to perch''
>:Khmer cwpa /cùuəp/ ~ jwpa /cúuəp/ ``to join'', intr. ``to meet, come together, encounter'' ⪤ prajcwpa ``to meet one another''. < > The following is prob. a different etymon with the basic meaning ``close'':
>:PTB *tsup >
>:PLB *tsup ~ *ʔtsup  >
>:WB cʰup ``clench fist''
>:Kachin tsup ``to gather'' , ``close hands''  . KN-Lai fuu / fuut ``to perch''

ENTRY:1579
HEAD:jí₁₆ 踖
MC:Middle Chinese: tsjäk 
LH:Later Han: tsiak 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *ts(i)ak
GLOSS:"Walk reverently" [Lunyu].
GLOSS-NOTE:This may be the same etymon as {jí₁₅ 蹐}, see {§11.3.2}.
	[E] ST *tsjak: WT ’čʰags-pa, bčags ``to tread, walk, move''. Perh. also connected with MK *jak ``to tread, step out, set out'' (Shorto 2006 #301): Semai /jak/, ``to trample'', WrMon jak ``to march, travel'', Sre jaʔ ``to tread on, trample'' (``j'' = dž, ``c'' = tš).
	The ST medial *-ia- (*-ja-) explains the *tsiak ~ *tsek doublets ({jí₁₅ 蹐}; {§11.3.2}).
	The same doublets are found in ``footprint, track'' {jì₂₁ 蹟} which may be cognate.
::Sre	jaʔ	``to tread on, trample''
>:ST *tsjak:
>:WT ’čʰags-pa, bčags ``to tread, walk, move''. Perh. also connected with MK *jak ``to tread, step out, set out'' :
>:Semai /jak/, ``to trample''
>:WrMon jak ``to march, travel''
>:Sre jaʔ ``to tread on, trample''

GLOSS:"To cultivate" (field, garden, rice) [OB, Zuo] >
GLOSS:"perform the ploughing ceremony" [OB] >

::Praok	ciak	``to dig, break ground by digging''

GLOSS:"Louse" [Hanfei] is also an old dialect word for

ENTRY:1600
HEAD:jì₂ 妓
MC:Middle Chinese: kje 3, also gjeᴮ 3; (Wei-Jin) kɨe,gɨeᴮ
GLOSS:"A small and weak woman" [SW] (物 wù
GLOSS:"thing" in the SW gloss is thought to be an error for 弱 ruò
GLOSS:"weak"), perhaps a euphemism for the later attested meaning ``singing girl, prostitute'' [Jinshu, i.e. post-Han].
GLOSS-NOTE:A hypothetical OC form may have been *kre.
	[E] This appears to be a loan from early Vietnamese (the ancient Yuè in southern China): PVM *keːʔ ``woman'' > Viet. cái / gái ``feminine'' [Ferlus]; elsewhere in MK: PWa *krih ``girl'', PNBahn. *kadrì ``female'' [K. Smith 1972: 64]. Alternatively, Wáng Lì (1982: 108) following earlier commentaries relates this word to jì 技 (gjeᴮ) ``skill'', but this may be folk etymology.
	Also other foreign words for ``girl, woman'' refer to a someone of low standing, see {bì₂₀ 嬖}, {tái₃ 嬯臺}.
>:This appears to be a loan from early Vietnamese :
>:PVM *keːʔ ``woman'' >
>:Viet. cái / gái ``feminine''
>:elsewhere in MK:
>:PWa *krih ``girl''
>:PNBahn. *kadrì ``female'' . Alternatively
>:Wáng Lì  following earlier commentaries relates this word to jì 技  ``skill'', but this may be folk etymology

OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *kri or *krəi ?
GLOSS:"To hope" 冀 [Zuo];
GLOSS:"to long for" 覬 [Zuo] is prob. cognate to {xī₁₂ 希睎} (so Wáng Lì 1982: 393).
	[E] Perh. ST: WT bkri-ba ``try to acquire, search for'' (CVST 5: 66).
::WT	bkri-ba	``try to acquire, search for''
>: WT bkri-ba ``try to acquire, search for''

ENTRY:1616
HEAD:jì₁₅ 濟
MC:Middle Chinese: tsieiᶜ 
LH:Later Han: tseiᶜ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *tsə̂ih 
OCB:Baxter Old Chinese: *tsəjs
	[T] ONW tsėi
GLOSS:"To ford, to cross" (a river) vb. [Shi] >
GLOSS:"to help across, help over" (e.g. difficulties) [Shu] >
GLOSS:"to help" (people) [Lunyu], ``contribute'' [Zuo], ``achieve'' [Yi].

ENTRY:1617
HEAD:jì₁₅ 濟 ⪤ jīn 津
MC:Middle Chinese: tsjen 
LH:Later Han: tsin 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *tsin
GLOSS:"A ford" n. [Shu].
	[<] nominal n-suffix derivative from {jì₁₅ 濟} ``to ford'' ({§6.4.3}).
	[E] MK: Mon inscr. cnis [cnøs] > cnih ``a ghat, place of access to river …, landing place'' < n-infix nominalization of cis [cøs] ``to go down, descend'' vb. (e.g. down the bank to the river, also general). The Mon vowel is closer to CH than the Khmer cognate: cuḥ [cuh] ``go down'', perhaps also Viet. xìu [sìu] < ž- ``go down''. Thus both Mon and OC derived a noun from the verb with a nominalizing affix, Mon with the MK n-infix > cnis ``ghat'', OC with the ST n-suffix jīn 津 ``a ford''.
	Perh. {xī₂ 西栖} ``nest, west'' belongs to this wf.
	The ST syn. for ``ford, cross'' is {dù₂ 渡}.
::ST	n-suffix jīn 津	``a ford''
>:Mon inscr. cnis  > cnih ``a ghat, place of access to river …, landing place'' < n-infix nominalization of cis  ``to go down, descend'' vb. . The Mon vowel is closer to CH than the Khmer cognate:
>:cuḥ  ``go down'', perhaps also Viet. xìu  < ž- ``go down''. Thus both Mon and OC derived a noun from the verb with a nominalizing affix
>:Mon with the MK n-infix > cnis ``ghat''
>:OC with the ST n-suffix jīn 津 ``a ford''

ENTRY:1618
HEAD:jì₁₆ 懠
MC:Middle Chinese: dziei,dzieiᶜ 
LH:Later Han: dzei(ᶜ) 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *dzî(h) or *dzə̂i(h)
GLOSS:"Angry" [Shi].
GLOSS-NOTE:Etymology not certain.
	The notion ``angry'' can derive from ``rise'' (cf.
	Mand. qǐ 起), hence perhaps cogn. to {jī₁₁ 隮} ``rise''.
	Or jì could derive from ``sick'' and be related to jì 癠 (under {jǐ₅ 擠}).

ENTRY:1623
HEAD:jì₂₁ 蹟
MC:Middle Chinese: tsjäk 
LH:Later Han: tsiek 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *tsek
GLOSS:"Footprint, track" [BI, Shi].
	[N] In Han and Wei-Jin poetry these two words rime in *-ek  (Luo / Zhou 1958; Ting 1975), but *tsiak occurs in Shījīng. See {§11.3.2}.
	The root initial was OCM *j- as the phonetic of 跡 (GSR 800) and TB cognates indicate ({§9.2}); a ST medial *-ja- (*-ia-) explains the OC *-iak ~ *-ek doublets.
	Possible allofams are {jí₁₅ 蹐} and {jí₁₆ 踖} ``walk, step'', prob. as a result of paronomastic attraction.
	[E] ST *C-jak: Limbu yok² ``trace, track'', Lushai hniakᴴ ``footprint, hoof-mark''.
::Lushai	hniakᴴ	``footprint, hoof-mark''
>:ST *C-jak:
>:Limbu yok² ``trace, track''
>:Lushai hniakᴴ ``footprint, hoof-mark''

ENTRY:1639
HEAD:jiā₈ 豭
MC:Middle Chinese: ka 
LH:Later Han: ka 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *krâ
GLOSS:"Male pig, boar" [Zuo, SW]; a Northeastern dialect word for {zhū₄ 豬} [ṭɑ] *tra
GLOSS:"pig" [FY].
GLOSS-NOTE:Given the homophone jiā
GLOSS:"male deer" [SW], this may be a more general etymon for
GLOSS:"male" of an animal and may also be cognate to {gǔ₇ 羖} ``ram'' (so Wáng Lì 1982: 126). If SW is correct that 豭 is an abbreviated phonetic in {jiā₇ 家} *kra
GLOSS:"house", then the word must be much older than Zuǒzhuàn, while zhū may be an early dialect word.

ENTRY:1664
HEAD:jiān₇ 兼
MC:Middle Chinese: kiem(ᶜ) 
LH:Later Han: kem(ᶜ) 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *kêm(s)
	[T] ONW kėm
GLOSS:"To combine, at the same time" [Shu, Yi],
GLOSS:"grasp, hold together, all-embracing" [Meng, Mozi].
	[E] MK *ckiəm, *ckəm, *ckaim ``grasp, hold'' (Shorto 2006 #1312): PMonic *ckiəm, OMon ckem ``to grasp, pick up'' [Diffloth 1984: 215], OMon ``handful'' ⪤ pkom ``to collect together'', Aslian cəkam  etc. ``hold'' [Benjamin 1976: 109]; PVM *gəmᴬ ``to hold'', Khasi kem ``to arrest, seize, wrestle''. MK ⇒ Lushai kimᴿ ``entire, be complete''.
	Perh. {qín₅ 擒} is connected.
::Lushai	kimᴿ	``entire, be complete''
>:MK *ckiəm, *ckəm, *ckaim ``grasp, hold'' :
>:PMonic *ckiəm
>:OMon ckem ``to grasp, pick up''
>:OMon ``handful'' ⪤ pkom ``to collect together''
>:Aslian cəkam  etc. ``hold''
>:PVM *gəmᴬ ``to hold''
>:Khasi kem ``to arrest, seize, wrestle''. MK ⇒ Lushai kimᴿ ``entire, be complete''

GLOSS:"to moisten, enrich, benefit" 瀸 [Lü],
GLOSS:"to soak" [Liji].
	[E] MK: Khmer jāṃ /coəm/ (darkened by water:) ``wet, soaked, permeated, steeped'' (also ``dark''). Khmer ? ⇒ Tai: S. čomᴬ¹ ``to sink, submerged'', Saek cɔm / camᴬ¹ ``to sink''.
::Saek	cɔm / camᴬ¹	``to sink''

ENTRY:1674
HEAD:jiǎn₁ 囝
MC:Middle Chinese: kjänᴮ 3,kjɐnᴮ 
LH:Later Han: kɨɑnᴮ
GLOSS:"Child, son" [JY].
	[E] AA: PVM *kɔːn ``son'', Viet con [Ferlus]; Mon kon ``child'' (Norman 1988: 231). It is a substrate word in Mǐn and other southern dialects: PMin *kiɑnᴮ > Jiàn’ōu kyeŋᴮ¹, Fúzhōu kiaŋᴮ¹, Xiàmén kiãᴮ¹.
	According to Chén Zhōngmǐn (LTBA 22.2, 2000: 21ƒƒ) jiǎn was used instead of the northern {zǐ₁ 子} and {ér₄ 兒} as a diminutive in Mǐn and other southern dialects where occasionally it left traces only in the tone.
	Syn. {zǐ₁ 子}; {kūn₂ 昆}.
>:AA:
>:PVM *kɔːn ``son''
>:Viet con
>:Mon kon ``child'' . It is a substrate word in Mǐn and other southern dialects:

ENTRY:1694
HEAD:jiàn₈ 劍
MC:Middle Chinese: kjɐmᶜ 
LH:Later Han: kɨɑmᶜ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *kam
	[T] ONW kam
GLOSS:"Sword" [Zuo, under the year 650 BC].
	[E] Etymology not certain. This mid Zhou period word could be derived from {yǎn₄ 剡覃} ``sharp'' (implied by Wulff, Geilich 1994: 110, 263), the initial k- would then be a nominalizing prefix ({§5.4}).
	Alternatively, swords seem to have originated in the ancient southern state of Wú (Sūzhōu area), which was famous for its sword smiths.
	From there the word, of unknown provenance, may have entered OC as well as PVM as *t-kɨəm [Ferlus].
>:Etymology not certain. This mid Zhou period word could be derived from {yǎn₄ 剡覃} ``sharp'' , the initial k- would then be a nominalizing prefix

ENTRY:1707
HEAD:jiāng₁ 江 ⪤ gǎng 港

LH:Later Han: kɔŋᴮ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *krôŋʔ
GLOSS:"Smaller river which flows into a larger river, lake or sea" [Náncháo period, 6th c. AD].
	[T] Sin Sukchu SR kjaŋ (上)
	[T]  MGZY  gyang (上) [kjaŋ]
	[D] An ancient Wú dialect word which spread into the Chǔ region
	[D] the word survives in river names in the former Wú-Chǔ area (Jiāngsū, Jiāngxī, Zhèjiāng, Anhuī, Húběi, Húnán)
	[D] the Huái River marks the northern limit of this word
	[D] later > ``harbour'' (Lǐ Xiǎofán / Chén Bǎoxián, FY 2002.3: 201-216). The irregular Mand. form originated in southern dialects where velars have not palatalized.
	The role of tone B is not clear.

ENTRY:1716
HEAD:jiàng₁ 匠
MC:Middle Chinese: dzjaŋᶜ 
LH:Later Han: dziɑŋᶜ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *dzaŋh
GLOSS:"To fashion, cut out, make" vb. (as a sculpture, out of wood or the like) [Chuci] >
GLOSS:"to form, cultivate" (one's personality through education) [Huainan], jiàng-rén 匠人 (``woodworking man'':)
GLOSS:"carpenter" [Meng]; 匠 ``carpenter'' n. [Zuo] > ``artisan'' [Lunheng]; also ``stone cutter'' (as a name in Zhuāngzǐ implies); jiàng-rén 匠人 ``official in charge of woodworkers'' [Zhouli].
	[T] Sin Sukchu SR dzjaŋ ( 去)
	[T] MGZY (tsÿang >) tsyang (去) [dzjaŋ]
	[E] MK: Khmer cāṃṅa /caŋ/ ``to dress (wood, stone), rough out, trim …''. The verbal function in Khmer makes it unlikely that this is a loan from CH where the typical use is nominal.
	Jiàng is sometimes thought to be related to WT byaŋ-pa ``skilled, experienced'' ({fāng₄ 方}) (Bodman 1980: 150), therefore the MC initial is conjectured to derive from *sb-, but this would be unusual and improbable; nor are the semantics compelling.
::WT	byaŋ-pa	``skilled, experienced''
>:Khmer cāṃṅa /caŋ/ ``to dress , rough out, trim …''. The verbal function in Khmer makes it unlikely that this is a loan from CH where the typical use is nominal

ENTRY:1717
HEAD:jiàng₂ 降
MC:Middle Chinese: kåŋ 
LH:Later Han: kɔŋ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *krûŋ
	[T] ONW käŋ
GLOSS:"To descend, get down" [BI, Shi], e.g. cattle from hills, person from carriage; metaphorically: send down blessings, misfortune etc.
	[E] There are no unambiguous outside cognates. Some languages have initial l-: Tai: S. loŋᴬ² < *dl- ``to descend''.
	<> Chepang glyuŋh- ~ gruŋ- ``to descend'' ⪤ gruŋʔ- ``droop, drop down (object in flight), descend (in angle)''.
	It is not clear if / how the following may be related: Lai trùm / trúm ``descend'' ⪤ tʰrúm / tʰrumʔ ``to put down'' [VanBik LTBA 25.2, 2002: 99] (KN tr- can derive from *kr-). Sino-Viet xuóng [suə́ŋ] ``to descend'' is an OC loan (SV s- < *kr-).
::Sino-Viet	xuóng [suə́ŋ]	``to descend''
>:There are no unambiguous outside cognates. Some languages have initial l-:
>:Tai:
>:S. loŋᴬ² < *dl- ``to descend''

ENTRY:1729

GLOSS:"gather firewood" [Shi],
GLOSS:"to burn" (fuel) intr. [Gongyang].
	[<] endopass. of jiāo tr. ({§4.6}), i.e. ``something that burns itself''.
	[D] This is the Mǐn word for ``wood, firewood'': PMin *dzʰau: Xiàmén lit. tsʰaiᴬ², col. tsʰaᴬ² ``grass and trees for fuel'', Jiàn’ōu tsʰauᴬ². This word is conventionally written {chái₁ 柴}.

GLOSS:"Status / rank in the nobility, dignity" [BI, Shi] seems to be related to the above (i.e. rank defined by agricultural revenues, i.e. food?). The semantic field

ENTRY:1738
HEAD:jiǎo₁ 烄
MC:Middle Chinese: kauᴮ 
LH:Later Han: kauᴮ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *krâuʔ
GLOSS:"Burn on a pyre" [OB, SW], esp. in a rain ceremony.
	[E] SW implies that jiǎo is related to {jiāo₁ 交} ``cross'', i.e. a pyre of crossed logs, but the semantic connection with ``crossed'' may be due to the graphic element. TB cognates suggest that jiǎo actually means ``dry over fire, burn'': WB kro ~ kyo ``to fry'', JP krau³³ ``dry up, overdry'' ⪤ kə³¹-rau³³ ``dry over a fire''.
	Jiǎo may be cognate to {liào₂ 燎} ``burn''.
::JP	krau³³	``dry up, overdry''
>:SW implies that jiǎo is related to {jiāo₁ 交} ``cross'', i.e. a pyre of crossed logs, but the semantic connection with ``crossed'' may be due to the graphic element. TB cognates suggest that jiǎo actually means ``dry over fire, burn'':
>:WB kro ~ kyo ``to fry''
>:JP krau³³ ``dry up, overdry'' ⪤ kə³¹-rau³³ ``dry over a fire''

ENTRY:1744
HEAD:jiǎo₅ 角
MC:Middle Chinese: kåk 
LH:Later Han: kɔk 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *krôk
	[T] ONW käk
	[D] PMin *kok ‘horn
	[D] male’
GLOSS:"Horn" [Shi],
GLOSS:"sharp angle, corner". Zhāng Xīngyà (YWYJ 1996.4: 9f) has collected archaistic bisyllabic dialect words for
GLOSS:"horn", including Wú-Sūzhōu, Níngbō, Shàoxìng kɔʔlɔʔ.
	[E] ST stem *kru to which OC has added a final *-k ({§6.1}): PTB *kru(w) > WB kʰyui, kʰrui ``horn'' (STC no. 37); the root is PTB *ru ~ *rwa as in WT ru ~ rwa ``horn''. A TB final *-ŋ variant is reflected in {gōng₉ 觥}.
	Bodman (1980: 167) compares the TB word with qiú 觩 (gjəu) ``long and curved, horn-like'' [Shi] (under {qiú₇,jiū 虯觓觩}) which, however, is derived from the meaning ``twist''; HST: 58 relates jiǎo to WT kʰug ``corner, angle'' (but see {jú₆ 鞠鞫}). Sagart (1999: 161) relates jiǎo to {lù₁₁ 鹿} ``deer''; lù is a rare reading for 角.
	<> PTai *khəuᴬ¹ ``horn'' has apparently no connection with CH.
::PTai	*khəuᴬ¹	``horn''
>:ST stem *kru to which OC has added a final *-k :
>:PTB *kru >
>:WB kʰyui, kʰrui ``horn''
>:the root is PTB *ru ~ *rwa as in WT ru ~ rwa ``horn''. A TB final *-ŋ variant is reflected in {gōng₉ 觥}

ENTRY:1771
HEAD:jiē₅ 嗟 ~ jiè 唶
MC:Middle Chinese: tsjaᶜ 
LH:Later Han: tsiah
GLOSS:"Sigh" [Hou Hanshu] which is prob. a graphic loan for 嗟. Jiè means also the
GLOSS:"sound of singing" (of birds) [Huainan]; also read zuò (dẓɐk)
GLOSS:"loud sound" (as of laughing) [SW, Shiji].

OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *tsəi or *tsi
GLOSS:"To sigh, moan, oh, alas!" [Shi].

ENTRY:1778
HEAD:jié₂ 捷
MC:Middle Chinese: dzjäp 
LH:Later Han: dziap 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *dzap
GLOSS:"Victory" [Shi],
GLOSS:"booty" [Zuo].
	[E] MK *cap, *ciəp, *cip, *cup ``to seize'' (Shorto 2006 #1243): OKhmer cā’pa /cap/ ``to grasp …, seize, catch, take or seize by conquest'' ⪤ Khmer caṃṇā’pa /cɑmnap/ ``detainee, prisoner, hostage''; Pearic čap² ``to catch''. MK ⇒ Tai: S. čiap⁴ ``to plunder, rob, steal''.
	The MK etymon is usually thought to belong to zhí 摯鷙 ``to seize'' (under {zhí₅ 執}) instead, but the OC and MK initial consonants are different.
::Khmer	caṃṇā’pa /cɑmnap/	``detainee, prisoner, hostage''
>:MK *cap, *ciəp, *cip, *cup ``to seize'' :
>:OKhmer cā’pa /cap/ ``to grasp …, seize, catch, take or seize by conquest'' ⪤ Khmer caṃṇā’pa /cɑmnap/ ``detainee, prisoner, hostage''
>:Pearic čap² ``to catch''. MK ⇒ Tai:

ENTRY:1780
HEAD:jié₂a 睫
MC:Middle Chinese: tsjäp 
LH:Later Han: tsiap 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *tsap
GLOSS:"Eyelashes" [Zhuang].
	[D] Y-Guǎngzhōu tsaap⁷ᴮ ``wink, blink'' (R. Bauer).
	[E] This word is associated with widely distributed phonaesthetic etymon ``wink, blink'' in East and SE Asia with the rime *-ap and initial various initials (see R.Bauer LTBA 15.2: 151-184 for an exhaustive collection). TB: WT tsʰab-tsʰab ``to blink''.
>:This word is associated with widely distributed phonaesthetic etymon ``wink, blink'' in East and SE Asia with the rime *-ap and initial various initials . TB:
>:WT tsʰab-tsʰab ``to blink''

ENTRY:1788
HEAD:jié₉ 節
MC:Middle Chinese: tsiet 
LH:Later Han: tset 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *tsît
	[D] PMin *tsat
	(``Cut'' >) ``regular division'' [Li], ``knots or joints on bamboo or other plants'' [Shi], ``degree, rank'' [Shu].
	[T] Sin Sukchu SR tsje (入)
	[T] MGZY dzÿa (入) [tsjɛ]
	[T] MTang tsiar < tsɨar, ONW tsėt
	[E] ST *tsik: PTB *tsik (STC 64): WT ’tsʰigs ``joint, knot, knee''; Garo tśik, Lepcha tśak ``joint''; PLB *ʔdzik > WB cʰac ``a joint'' (Bodman 1980: 139).
	Perh. not related to jié 截 (dziet) [dzet] *dzêt  (``To cut, trim'' >) ``restrain, govern'' [Shi] (Unger Hao-ku 39, 1992) because of the different OC vowels. An allofam may be {xī₁₃ 膝} *sit ``knee''.
::Lepcha	tśak	``joint''
>:ST *tsik:
>:PTB *tsik :
>:WT ’tsʰigs ``joint, knot, knee''
>:Garo tśik
>:Lepcha tśak ``joint''
>:PLB *ʔdzik >
>:WB cʰac ``a joint''

ENTRY:1790
HEAD:jié₁₀ 櫛
MC:Middle Chinese: tṣjɛt 
LH:Later Han: tṣɛt 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *tsrit
GLOSS:"Comb, to comb" 櫛 [Shi],
GLOSS:"to scrape" 楖 [Zhouli].
	[E] The several words for ``comb'' in CH and TB look somewhat similar, but precise phonological correspondences are elusive. Jié appears to be close to PTB *m-si(y) ``comb'' (STC no. 466) > JP pə⁵⁵-si⁵⁵ ``comb, rake'' ⪤ məsìt ``to comb, rake, brush''; Mikir iŋtʰi < msi ``comb'', Lepcha pŭr-šit [pər-sit] ``brush'' [Bodman ICSTLL 1987: 17]. Although an additional final consonant like -t here is not unusual for CH, the initials are rather different.
	Syn. {shū₃ 梳}.
::Lepcha	pŭr-šit 	``brush''
>:The several words for ``comb'' in CH and TB look somewhat similar, but precise phonological correspondences are elusive. Jié appears to be close to PTB *m-si ``comb''  >
>:JP pə⁵⁵-si⁵⁵ ``comb, rake'' ⪤ məsìt ``to comb, rake, brush''
>:Mikir iŋtʰi < msi ``comb''
>:Lepcha pŭr-šit  ``brush'' . Although an additional final consonant like -t here is not unusual for CH, the initials are rather different

	{jié₁₀} 櫛

ENTRY:1792
HEAD:jié₁₂ 絜
MC:Middle Chinese: kiet,ɣiet 
LH:Later Han: ket,get 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *kêt,*gêt
GLOSS:"To put around and measure" (e.g. a tree) [Zhuang].
	[E] This wf belongs to the ST root *ke ``concave'' (of body parts etc.), see {jǐng₂ 頸} ``neck'' and {Table J-2} there.
	ST *ket ``waist > put around the waist > belt'': WT rked-pa ``the waist, loins, middle'' (IST: 66), rked-rgyan ``belt ornament''; JP ʃiŋ³¹-kjit⁵⁵ ``waist''.
	CH xié OCM *khet, Tibetan *rket and JP *s-kit may all go back to the same ST etymon *s/r-ket.
	Without final *-t: Tamang (¹)keː ``belt''.
	Lepcha a-rek ``girdle'' cannot be related unless it is a mangled loan from a WT word like rked which has undergone a metathesis of the type described in {§2.8.3} (*rket > *reket > rek).
::Lepcha	a-rek	``girdle''
>:This wf belongs to the ST root *ke ``concave'' , see {jǐng₂ 頸} ``neck'' and {Table J-2} there

OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *khêt,*gêt
GLOSS:"Belt" [Zhuang].
GLOSS-NOTE:Alternatively, this word could belong to {jié₆ 結} *kît
GLOSS:"to tie" (Unger Hao-ku no. 74, 11. 2001), though the vowels do not agree.

HEAD:jiě 解
MC:Middle Chinese: kaɨᴮ

GLOSS:"To loosen" [Meng],
GLOSS:"explain" [Zuo],

	[T] MGZY gyay (上) [kjaj]
	[T] ONW këi
	[E] ? Area stem *C-re: Chepang greh- ``to sever, chop off, cut cleanly'', perhaps also PLB *priy² ``unfasten, untie'' > WB pʰre ``untie, unroll, appease'' ⪤ ə-pʰre ``answer to question, key''. <> Perh.
	MK: Khmer rāya /ríiəj/ ``to break up, scatter, disperse, divide up ….'' ⪤ srāya /sraaj/ ``to undo (knot), untie, loose … untangle, unravel, solve, clarify, interpret'' (dream).
	The MK - OC vowel correspondence is regular, and a MK origin could account for the differences in initial consonants.
::Khmer	rāya /ríiəj/	``to break up, scatter, disperse, divide up ….''

LH:Later Han: kɛs

GLOSS:"To increase, become great" (of army, blessings, old age, person) [Shi].

GLOSS:"be large", and perhaps derived from {jiǎ₂ 假嘏} *kraʔ

	[C] Prob. not related to {qiān₇ 牽} ``pull tight'' and {jiān₂ 堅} ``solid, strong''.

ENTRY:1820
HEAD:jīn₆ 祲
MC:Middle Chinese: tsjəm(ᶜ) 
LH:Later Han: tsim(ᶜ) 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *tsəm(s)
GLOSS:"Halo around sun" [Zuo] appears to be related to WT kʰyim
GLOSS:"halo around sun" ⪤ ’kʰyims-pa
GLOSS:"be encircled by a halo" ⪤ ’gyim-pa ``circumference'' (Bodman 1980: 58). However the initials are difficult to reconcile.

ENTRY:1821
HEAD:jǐn₁ 緊
MC:Middle Chinese: kjienᴮ 4 
LH:Later Han: kinᴮ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *kinʔ
GLOSS:"To bind tight" [Chuci, SW].
GLOSS-NOTE:Acc. to SSYP: 211, this is the only word with a velar initial k- in chóngniǔ div.
	IV and is prob. a southern (note Chuci!) non-palatalizing dialect variant of the regular palatalized form zhěn 紾 (tśjenᴮ) ``to twist (someone's arm)'' [Meng] (so Yupian; Schuessler 1996, JCL 24.2).
	[T] Sin Sukchu SR kin (上)
	[T] MGZY gÿin (上) [kjin]
	[T] ONW kiin
	[E] ST: Lushai kʰirʔᴸ < *kʰirh ``to tie / bind arms behind the back; carrying cords twisted around a load'', NNaga *C-kʰyin ``to tie''. Perh. also connected with WT ’khyil-ba ``to wind, twist''.
	Prob. unrelated is the TB etymon WT ’gril-ba ``be twisted, wrapped around'', WB kʰyañ ``bind, fasten'' ⪤ kʰyañᴮ ``thread'' (< *krin) (note also cañᴮ ``bind, tie together''), JP kren³³ ``to tighten'' (a rope).
	An allofam is perhaps {qiān₇ 牽}.
::JP	kren³³	``to tighten''
>:Lushai kʰirʔᴸ < *kʰirh ``to tie / bind arms behind the back; carrying cords twisted around a load''
>:NNaga *C-kʰyin ``to tie''. Perh. also connected with WT ’khyil-ba ``to wind, twist''

ENTRY:1840

	[D] This is the word for ``to fear'' in southern dialects: PMin 惊 *kiaŋ > Amoy kiãᴬ¹, Fúzhōu kiaŋᴬ¹ ``be afraid''.
	[E] ? MK provides an etymological explanation: Khmer rēṅa /rɛɛŋ/ ``be stiff, rigid, hard'' > OKhmer krēṅa /krɛɛŋ/ ``be stiff or rigid with fear, to fear, afraid of''. Khmer ⇒ Tai: S. kreeŋᴬ¹ ``to fear'' (alternative: Manomaivibool 1975: 168).

ENTRY:1851
HEAD:jǐng₂ 頸
MC:Middle Chinese: kjäŋᴮ,gjäŋ 
LH:Later Han: kieŋᴮ,gieŋ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *keŋʔ,*geŋ
GLOSS:"Neck" [Zuo], unlike {lǐng 領} also figuratively
GLOSS:"neck" of a vessel, jug etc.
	[D] Y-Guǎngzhōu ³⁵kɛŋᴮ¹, Táishān ⁵⁵kiaŋᴮ¹, but Mand. bózǐ 脖子 ``neck''.
	[E] Wáng Lì (1982: 321) considers this wf cognate to {gāng₁ 亢} ``neck'' and the allofams there. PMY *klaːŋᴬ ``neck, throat'' is prob. related to the latter rather than to jǐng.
	Since there is no trace of an *r in the OC initial, jǐng is prob. not related to {lǐng 領} ``neck'', but belongs most likely to the ST root *ke to which also belongs {jié₁₂ 絜}.
	ST *ke(-C) ``concave'' (of part of the body and the like): WT rke-ba ``lean'' ⪤ rked ``waist'' (Beyer 1992: 117), see {jié₁₂ 絜} for more; JP keʔ⁵⁵ < kek⁵⁵ ``concave'' (of the neck, a jug) (STC no. 251), ``indentation, pit''; Chepang kəyk ~ kek ``neck''; NN *C-geŋ ``waist'', SChin-Khami (Awa) ken ``waist'', Chepang keŋʔ- and kiŋh- ``be constricted, narrow-waisted'' ~ kiŋʔ- ``be constricted, narrow'' (waist).
	See {Table J-2} for synopsis. ◇
::Chepang	kəyk ~ kek	``neck''
>:Wáng Lì  considers this wf cognate to {gāng₁ 亢} ``neck'' and the allofams there. PMY *klaːŋᴬ ``neck, throat'' is prob. related to the latter rather than to jǐng

ENTRY:1866

MC:Middle Chinese: ɣiweŋᴮ 
LH:Later Han: ɣueŋᴮ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *wêŋʔ
GLOSS:"Distant" 泂 [Shi], 迥 [SW] (also read xiòng; GY also has kiweŋᴮ for 迥).
	[E] MK: Khmer vēṅa /wɛɛŋ/  ``be far, distant, long'' ⪤ lveṅa /lwéeŋ/ ``be far off, distant, remote'' ⪤ chveṅa /cwèeŋ/  ``be situated in the off side, be abnormal, queer, excentric, unorthodox, left (hand)''. For a possible semantic parallel in OC, see {kuáng 狂}.
	The root is perhaps also encountered in PTB *wiy > WB weᴮ ``far'', PL *we² ``be far, dull''; possibly also Kanauri rwi ``high''.
	The relationship with {jiǒng₃ 憬} and {yǒng₁ 永}, if any, is not clear.
::Kanauri	rwi	``high''
>:Khmer vēṅa /wɛɛŋ/  ``be far, distant, long'' ⪤ lveṅa /lwéeŋ/ ``be far off, distant, remote'' ⪤ chveṅa /cwèeŋ/  ``be situated in the off side, be abnormal, queer, excentric, unorthodox, left ''. For a possible semantic parallel in OC, see {kuáng 狂}

ENTRY:1869

GLOSS:"Far away" [Shi] is prob. a variant of the stem as final nasals can alternate after front vowels ({§6.4.1}).

ENTRY:1870
HEAD:jiǒng₃ 憬
MC:Middle Chinese: kjwɐŋᴮ 
LH:Later Han: kyaŋᴮ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *kwaŋʔ or *kwraŋʔ ?
GLOSS:"Be far away" [Shi].
GLOSS-NOTE:The relationship with similar items {jiǒng₂ 泂迥} and {yuǎn₁ 遠} is not clear.
	Sagart (1999: 104) derives jiǒng from {yǒng₁ 永} ``be long, distant''.
	A derivation may be {kuáng 狂}, although the MC vowels do not agree.

ENTRY:1876
HEAD:jiū₂ 鳩
MC:Middle Chinese: kjəu 
LH:Later Han: ku 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *ku 
OCB:Baxter Old Chinese: *k(r)ju
	[T] MTang keu < kiu ONW ku
GLOSS:"Pigeon, dove" [Shi] is today's meaning, but what bird it referred to in ancient texts is not certain.
	[D] For taboo considerations, some southern dialects have an aspirated initial (A. Yue Hashimoto, p.c.): Y-Guǎngzhōu and Hongkong kɐuᴬ¹ ~ kʰɐuᴬ¹, Fóshān, Nánhǎi et. al. kʰ-
	[D] also M-Xiàmén kiuᴬ¹ ~ kʰiuᴬ¹.
	[E] ST: Because of *ku's onomatopoetic nature there are variant forms in ST, some with medial -r-, some without: PTB *kuw (STC no. 495) ``dove'' > Miri pəkü, Meithei kʰu-nu, ``pigeon'' (STC: 185; HST p. 118); PTB *m-krəw: PLB *N-kruw² > WB kʰui ~ kʰyui ~ kʰrui, Kuki *m-kʰru > Khami iŋ məkʰru. The Tai word looks like a loan from a Yuè dialect, yet PTai also had a medial *-r-: S. khauᴬ¹ < *khr-, *hr- ``dove''.
>:Because of *ku's onomatopoetic nature there are variant forms in ST, some with medial -r-, some without:

>:Meithei kʰu-nu, ``pigeon''
>:PTB *m-krəw:
>:PLB *N-kruw² >
>:WB kʰui ~ kʰyui ~ kʰrui

ENTRY:1880
HEAD:jiǔ₃ 糾
MC:Middle Chinese: kjieuᴮ 4 
LH:Later Han: kiuᴮ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *kiuʔ 
OCB:Baxter Old Chinese: *k(r)jiwʔ
GLOSS:"To twist, plait" [Shi],
GLOSS:"unite" [Zuo].
	[E] <> KT: The outside connections suggest an original *klju: PTai *kliəuᴬ¹ (?): S. kliauᴬ¹ ``to wind around, twist a string'', Saek tlɛɛuᶜ¹; note however PTai *kiəuᶜ¹ : S. kiauᶜ¹ ``to wind around, twist''.
	This wf is perhaps ultimately ST: WT gčud / lčud-pa, gčus / lčus,  gču / lču (< *hlju?) ``to twist, twine, plait, braid'' ⪤ gčus ``screw'', WB kʰyu ``twist off (fruit) with pole'', Lushai kiiuᴸ ``elbow'' [Weidert 1975: 8].
	Many variants are found under GSR 1064 and 1069.
	Baxter (1992: 513) adds {miù₁ 謬} ``to lie'' to this group.
	Allofams are {qiú₇,jiū 虯觓觩}, and perhaps {jiǎo₃ 絞}.

ENTRY:1883
HEAD:jiǔ₅ 酒
MC:Middle Chinese: tsjəuᴮ 
LH:Later Han: tsuᴮ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *tsiu(ʔ)
	[D] PMin *tsiuᴮ > Xiàmén Fúzhōu tsiuᴮ
GLOSS:"Wine" 酉 [OB, BI], 酒 [Shi].
GLOSS-NOTE:The word was also read in tone A in Shījīng (Mattos 1971: 309).
	[T] Sin Sukchu SR tsiw (上)
	[T] MGZY dziw (上) [tsiw]
	[T] MTang tseu < tsiu, ONW tsu
	[N] The MC tsj- ~ j- alternation in 酒 ~ 酉 (GSR 1096) has parallels and points to an original OC root initial *j- (not *l-) in such series (see {§9.2}). Curiously, in its sense of ``cyclical character'', yǒu's 酉 Tai counterparts (Tai rau) and Han dynasty paronomastic glosses indicate an OC *r- initial.
	This has led to the identification of (yǒu /) jiǔ ``wine'' with PTB *ru ``wine''.
	However, the latter belongs to {láo₃ 醪} *ru ``wine''.
	[E] ST *ju: PTB *yu(w) ``wine'' (STC no. 94), BG-Tiwa chû ``rice beer''.
::BG-Tiwa	chû	``rice beer''
>:ST *ju:
>:PTB *yu ``wine''
>:BG-Tiwa chû ``rice beer''
