GLOSS:"old wine" [Zhouli, SW] (Karlgren 1956: 11). This is a tone A nominalization derived from jiǔ ({§3.1}).

ENTRY:1885
HEAD:jiù₁ 臼
MC:Middle Chinese: gjəuᴮ 
LH:Later Han: guᴮ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *guʔ
GLOSS:"Mortar" [Yi].
	[D] PMin *gʰ- > Xiàmén kʰuᶜ², Fúzhōu kʰouᶜ². In some Mǐn dialects the word for ``mortar'' is the Mand. equivalent jiù-kū 臼窟 where kū means ``depression'', then kū is re-interpreted as ``mortar'' and jiù acquires the meaning ``pestle'' (Branner 2000: 109).
	[E] MK *ɡuul ``mortar for pounding rice'': Proto-Semai *ɡuul, (Khmuic) Kammu-Yuan kwùal, Thin ɡuɤ̆l [Shorto 2006 # 1715]; perhaps also PVM *t-koːlʔ > Viet. côí ``rice mortar'' [Ferlus] (for absence of the coda in OC, see {§6.9}).
>:MK *ɡuul ``mortar for pounding rice'':
>:Proto-Semai *ɡuul
>:Kammu-Yuan kwùal
>:Thin ɡuɤ̆l
>:perhaps also PVM *t-koːlʔ >
>:Viet. côí ``rice mortar''

ENTRY:1901
HEAD:jū₇ 駒
MC:Middle Chinese: kju 
LH:Later Han: kɨo 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *ko
	[T] ONW kuo
GLOSS:"Colt, young horse" [BI, Shi].
	[E] Jū is the same etymon as {gǒu 狗} ``puppy dog'' acc. to Wáng Lì (1982: 182); however, gǒu which comes from a non-ST language, is not a homophone of jū. It is more likely that jū is cognate to PTB *ku(r) or *kor ``horse'' (HPTB: 385) in Monpa kur-ta < ku-rta ``horse'' (rta <- WT ``horse''), Tani *kɯ, JP kum-ra < ku-mra[ŋ] ``horse'' (mraŋ ``horse''); Lushai saᴸ-kɔrᴿ ``a horse, pony'' (but acc. to Lorrain p. 400 this word is derived from kɔrᴿ ``coat''), Mru kor-ŋa [Löffler 1966: 123]. For the loss of final *-r, see {§7.7.5}.
	Alternatively, one may consider jū cognate to {qū₄ 驅} *kho ``to drive'' (a horse), ``gallop''.
::JP	kum-ra < ku-mra	``horse''
>:Jū is the same etymon as {gǒu 狗} ``puppy dog'' acc. to Wáng Lì
>:however, gǒu which comes from a non-ST language, is not a homophone of jū. It is more likely that jū is cognate to PTB *ku or *kor ``horse''  in Monpa kur-ta < ku-rta ``horse''
>:Tani *kɯ
>:JP kum-ra < ku-mra ``horse''
>:Lushai saᴸ-kɔrᴿ ``a horse, pony''
>:Mru kor-ŋa

LH:Later Han: kuk 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *kuk
GLOSS:"To nourish, suckle" (a child) [Shi].
	This is prob. a vocalic variant of the wf {gǔ₁₄ 穀} ``suckle'', see {Table C-2} (under {chù₄,xù 畜}) for parallel stems.

ENTRY:1909
HEAD:jú₆ 鞠鞫
MC:Middle Chinese: kjuk 
LH:Later Han: kuk 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *kuk
GLOSS:"To bow, bend" (the body) 鞠 [Lun],
GLOSS:"concave side of river bend" 鞫 [Shi].
	[E] ST *kuk: PTB *kuk ~ *guk > WT ’gug(s)-pa, bkug, dgug ``to bend'' ⪤ dgu id., Bahing kuk- ``to bend'' tr. ⪤ guk- ``to bend'' intr., PLB *gok ``crooked, bent; return, go back'', WB kok ``crooked, not upright'' ⪤ ə-kok ``a crook'' (Matisoff TSR no. 2; STC: 77, 125, 159; HST: 41-42); Kuki-Naga *m-kuːk ``knee'' (STC: 120). The Chinese items could also be cognate to WT ’kʰyog-po ~ kʰyog-po ``crooked, bent'' ⪤ gyog-pa ``curved, crooked'' (so Bodman 1980: 161).
	Prob. related to {gōu₁ 句鉤枸區}.
	A variant with OC rime  *-ok is {qū₁ 曲}.
	Another wf with OC *o ~ *u variation is {rú₄ 懦臑}.
::WT	’kʰyog-po ~ kʰyog-po	``crooked, bent''
>:ST *kuk:
>:PTB *kuk ~ *guk >
>:WT ’gug-pa, bkug, dgug ``to bend'' ⪤ dgu id.
>:Bahing kuk- ``to bend'' tr. ⪤ guk- ``to bend'' intr.
>:PLB *gok ``crooked, bent; return, go back''
>:WB kok ``crooked, not upright'' ⪤ ə-kok ``a crook''
>:Kuki-Naga *m-kuːk ``knee'' . The Chinese items could also be cognate to WT ’kʰyog-po ~ kʰyog-po ``crooked, bent'' ⪤ gyog-pa ``curved, crooked''

	Another derivation from the same root is {cān₂ 餐}.

ENTRY:1913
HEAD:jǔ₁ 咀 ⪤ cān₂ 餐
MC:Middle Chinese: tsʰân 
LH:Later Han: tsʰɑn 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *tshân
GLOSS:"To eat" [BI, Shi],
GLOSS:"food" Guoce],
GLOSS:"meal" [Zhuang].
	[T] Sin Sukchu SR ts'an (平)
	[T] MGZY  tshan (平) [ts'an]
	[<] nominal n-suffix derivation from the ST root *dza.
	[E] ST: PTB *dza ``to eat''> WT bzan ``food'', gzan-pa ``to eat'' (STC: 159 n. 428). Alternatively, cān could be  cognate to WT ’tsʰal-ba (< N-tsal) ``to eat'' ⪤ tsʰal-ma ``breakfast'' (so Unger Hao-ku 35, 1986: 30; HST: 69).
	Since MC tsʰ- = WT gs- ({§5.9.1}), the first possibility seems preferable (WT aspiration as in tsʰal is non-phonemic).
::WT	’tsʰal-ba 	``to eat''
>:PTB *dza ``to eat''>
>:WT bzan ``food'', gzan-pa ``to eat'' . Alternatively, cān could be  cognate to WT ’tsʰal-ba  ``to eat'' ⪤ tsʰal-ma ``breakfast''

ENTRY:1920
HEAD:jǔ₅ 柜 ⪤ qú 渠
MC:Middle Chinese: gjwo 
LH:Later Han: gɨɑ or gyɑ ? 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *gwa ?
GLOSS:"Canal" [Li] may be the s. w. as {qú₅ 衢}
GLOSS:"crossroads" (note the TB / ST field of meaning below). We should expect MC gju which is implied by the phonetic jù 巨 and the cognates, but the MC rimes -ju ~  -jwo have merged in almost all dialects and have already mingled in some phonetic series.

ENTRY:1923
HEAD:jǔ₆ 舉
MC:Middle Chinese: kjwoᴮ 
LH:Later Han: kɨɑᴮ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *kaʔ ?
	[T] MTang ky < ONW kø < kio (?)
GLOSS:"To rise, surge, start; lift, promote" [Shi].
	[E] This may be cognate to WT ’kʰyog-pa, kʰyag ``to lift, carry'' (HST: 103) ⪤ skya-ba, bskyas ``to carry''. Alternatively, Baxter / Sagart (1998: 48) relate this word to {yú₁₁ 舁} ``to lift''.
	If the root should be *ka or *kja, then {jiē₇ 揭} and {jiǎn₉ 攓} may represent forms with additional final consonants.
	However, a root *ka is so common that many a meaning can be associated with it, and ``lift'' is also a rather broad concept.
::WT	’kʰyog-pa, kʰyag	``to lift, carry''
>:This may be cognate to WT ’kʰyog-pa, kʰyag ``to lift, carry''  ⪤ skya-ba, bskyas ``to carry''. Alternatively

GLOSS-NOTE:This may be the same word as {jué₁ 決}.
	[E] ST: WB kyuiᴮ ``be broken'' ⪤ kʰyuiᴮ ``to break in two'' ⪤ kʰuiᶜ ``defective, wanting, incomplete'' (Matisoff ICSTLL 1978: 150). Allofam {quē 缺} ``break, splinter''.
>:WB kyuiᴮ ``be broken'' ⪤ kʰyuiᴮ ``to break in two'' ⪤ kʰuiᶜ ``defective, wanting, incomplete'' . Allofam {quē 缺} ``break, splinter''

ENTRY:1958
HEAD:jué₇ 厥
MC:Middle Chinese: kjwɐt 
LH:Later Han: kyɑt 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *k(i)ot ?
	Third person pronoun ``he, she, it, they, his, her …'' [BI, Shi, Shu], occasionally it also serves as possessive for the first and second persons in classical Chinese (Takashima JAOS 119.3, 1999: 404-431). Bodman (JAOS 68, 1948: 52-60; 1980: 161) relates this word to WT kʰyod ``you''.
::WT	kʰyod	``you''

GLOSS:"To wake up" intr. [Zuo: Cheng 10, 5] is supposedly the reading of this graph in the sense of
GLOSS:"wake up" intr. in Shījīng, Zuǒzhuàn and elsewhere, but the Shījīng rime requires OCM *-k, not *-kh (Baxter 1992: 611), which would agree with the intr. use. The tone C reading may therefore be a later innovation.

ENTRY:1972
HEAD:jūn₂ 鈞
MC:Middle Chinese: kjiuen 4 
LH:Later Han: kwin 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *kwin
GLOSS:"Potter's wheel" [Zhuang].
	[<] k-prefix noun of xún 旬 *s-win ``all round, cycle'', lit. ``the rotating thing'' ({§5.4}).
	[E] This wf could equally well belong to either ST *wir ({yún₅ 雲}) or PAA *wil, the two may have converged in China. PAA *wil seems on balance more likely given the field of meaning in OC and AA (including 'go everywhere, roam, patrol'), and the prehistoric Lóngshān culture origin of the pottery wheel in eastern China (AA?).
	Khmer /vil/ ``to turn, revolve, rotate'' ⪤ /kravil/ ``ring, circle, loop'' ⪤ kravēla /krawaaɛl/ ``to revolve, go around, go to and fro, roam, patrol, explore'' ⪤ chvēla /cwaaɛl/ ``to turn, spin, go back and forth, come and go''; Santali gɛrwɛl ``ring''.
	This root **wil is prob. connected with {wéi₅ 圍} *wel.
	Jūn may possibly be the same word as {jūn₁ 均鈞} ``well balanced''.
	For an overview of synonyms, see under {huí 回}.
::Santali	gɛrwɛl	``ring''
>:This wf could equally well belong to either ST *wir  or PAA *wil, the two may have converged in China. PAA *wil seems on balance more likely given the field of meaning in OC and AA , and the prehistoric Lóngshān culture origin of the pottery wheel in eastern China

ENTRY:1973
HEAD:jūn₂ 鈞 ⪤ xún 旬

LH:Later Han: zuin 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *s-win
GLOSS:"Everywhere, all round" [Shi] >
GLOSS:"ten day cycle, ten (days)" [OB, Shu], e.g. xún yǒu wǔ rì 旬有五日 (ten / and / five / days)

	[<] s-iterative of a root *win ``rotate'' ({§5.2.3}). ``Rotate'' as a metaphor for cyclical time like the ``ten day cycle, week'' has parallels in TB languages, e.g. Lahu qhɔ̀ ``return'' > ``year'' (Matisoff D. of Lahu: 310).
	For synonyms, see under {huí 回}.
::Lahu	qhɔ̀	``return''

ENTRY:1989
HEAD:kān₄ 戡
MC:Middle Chinese: kʰậm 
LH:Later Han: kʰəm 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *khə̂m
GLOSS:"To kill, execute" 戡 [Shu].
	[D] Mand. ``to suppress'' (a rebellion)
	[D] M-Xiamen kʰamᴬ¹ ``id.''
	[E] ST *kum with the core meaning ``be above, be on, on top'': Lushai kʰumᶠ adv. ``upon, on top of, inside, against, over …'', vb. ``to put on, wear'' ⪤ kʰuumᶠ vb. ``to surpass, excel, beat, over, beyond''; WT ’gum-pa, bkum ``to kill'' ⪤ ’gum-pa, gum ``to die'' (STC: 175 n. 464).
	This word is prob. not related to {kǎn₃ 砍} ``chop'' (tree, wood).
	It is also distinct from the homophone {kān₂ 堪} ``equal to'' as shown by the TB cognates.
	A relation ship with {tān₂ 貪} OCM *rhə̂m ``kill'' is excluded because of the difference in initial consonants.
	CH aspiration is associated with forceful motion {§5.8.5}.
::OCM	*rhə̂m	``kill''
>:ST *kum with the core meaning ``be above, be on, on top'':
>:Lushai kʰumᶠ adv. ``upon, on top of, inside, against, over …'', vb. ``to put on, wear'' ⪤ kʰuumᶠ vb. ``to surpass, excel, beat, over, beyond''
>:WT ’gum-pa, bkum ``to kill'' ⪤ ’gum-pa, gum ``to die''

HEAD:kǎn₁ 坎埳
MC:Middle Chinese: kʰậmᴮ 
LH:Later Han: kʰəmᴮ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *khə̂mʔ
GLOSS:"Pit" 坎 [OB, Yi];

GLOSS:"uneven, bumpy road" [Hanshu].
GLOSS-NOTE:For the aspirated initial which marks hollow objects, see {§5.8.6}.
	[D] Mand. ‘a pit, hole, depression
	[D] a snare, danger’. M-Xiàmén hıŋ⁵⁵/³³-kʰam⁵¹ 胸坎 ``chest, breast''.
	[E] Prob. connected with PTai *kʰumᴬ¹: S. kʰumᴬ¹ ``ditch, pit, walled-in well'' (Unger Hao-ku 76, 2002: 72), possibly also with Tai sumᴬ¹ < kʰr-? (Li 1977: 197), Ahom kʰrūm ``well'', which could suggest that 坎 and 埳 wrote two distinct words **khə̂m ``pit'' and **khrə̂m ``well'' respectively (the phonetic in 埳 writes words with an OC medial *r; and medial -r- may disappear in Tai, first in ordinary speech, later also in writing).
	[C] Similar etyma are {qǐn₁ 坅}, {tàn₂ 窞}, {xiàn₃ 陷錎}; they are here tentatively grouped according to connections which emerge in {Table K-1}. Syn. {kēng₁ 坑阬}. ◇
::Ahom	kʰrūm	``well''
>:Prob. connected with PTai *kʰumᴬ¹:
>:S. kʰumᴬ¹ ``ditch, pit, walled-in well'' , possibly also with Tai sumᴬ¹ < kʰr-?
>:Ahom kʰrūm ``well'', which could suggest that 坎 and 埳 wrote two distinct words **khə̂m ``pit'' and **khrə̂m ``well'' respectively

ENTRY:1993
HEAD:kǎn₃ 砍
MC:Middle Chinese: kʰậmᴮ
GLOSS:"To sound kham-kham", the sound of cutting wood’ 坎 [Shi];
GLOSS:"to chop" (wood, a tree),
GLOSS:"decapitate" 砍 (ZWDCD 6: 1275f), a late word [e.g. Shuǐhúzhuàn].
	[D] PMin *kʰamᴮ 砍 ``to fell a tree, slash, chop''
	[E] Words with the meaning ``chop, hew, cut'' tend to have the sound-symbolic shape kʰ N; aspiration is associated with forceful motion {§5.8.5}; a similar word is {kān₁ 刊}.
	[E] ST *kəm: Chepang kʰamh- ``fell tree''. This is possibly an area word, note Khmer khtɔ̀əm ``to split''.
	Prob. not related to {kān₄ 戡} whose ST root is *kum.

>:a similar word is {kān₁ 刊}

>:WT mkʰan-po ``professor, abbot''

ENTRY:2019
HEAD:ké₁ 咳欬
MC:Middle Chinese: -- 
LH:Later Han: kʰək
	[D] Mand. ``to cough''
	[D] M-Amoy lit. kʰekᴰ¹, ``sound of coughing''.
	[E] These sound-symbolic items are derivable from an OC stem *khə̂k. CH aspiration is associated with forceful outward motion {§5.8.5}.
	Area word.
	Because foreign /a/ is reflected in both OC *a and *ə, it is impossible to sort out which CH form, 咳欬 or {kè₄ 喀}, is the direct cognate of the foreign words: PTB  *kaːk (STC no. 323) (or rather *khaːk ?) > Mikir tśiŋ kʰak ``cough up, phlegm'', Lushai kʰaakᴴ ``eject forcibly from the throat'' ⪤ kʰaakᴿ ``phlegm'', WT kʰogs ``cough'', WB hak ``to hawk, raise phlegm''; Sgaw Karen kəhaʔ ``phlegm''.
	<> Tai: S. kʰaakᴰ¹ ``to spit out'', Saek kʰaak⁶ ``cough up phlegm''.
	In some lgs. like Karen and WB, the initial is analyzed as a cluster k + h-, as in AA (see under {kè₄ 喀}).
::Saek	kʰaak⁶	``cough up phlegm''
>:These sound-symbolic items are derivable from an OC stem *khə̂k. CH aspiration is associated with forceful outward motion {§5.8.5}

ENTRY:2021

LH:Later Han: kʰɔk 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *khrôk

GLOSS:"hollow" [Lie], i.e.

	[D] M-Xiàmén lit. kʰokᴰ¹, col. kʰɑkᴰ¹, Y-Guǎngzhōu ³³hɔkᴰ. In some modern dialects ké is the second syllable in the word for ``head'' {tóu₃ 頭}.
	[E] In sound and meaning, this item partially overlaps with {gǔ₁₂,zhuó 穛} *kûk ``husk''. It makes the impression of being derived from {jiǎo₅ 角} *krôk ``horn'' by aspiration which characterizes hollow objects ({§5.8.6}).

ENTRY:2027
HEAD:kè₄ 喀

LH:Later Han: kʰak 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *khrâk
GLOSS:"To spit out, vomit" [Lie].
GLOSS-NOTE:Chinese aspiration is associated with forceful outward motion {§5.8.5}.
	[D] Mand. kā 喀 ``noise made in coughing or vomiting'' ⪤ kǎ 咯 ``cough up phlegm'', M-Amoy kʰakᴰ² and keʔᴰ¹ ``clear the throat'' ⪤ kʰakᴰ¹ ``expectorate, bring up phlegm''.
	[E] A variant of the onomatopoetic area word for ``cough'' is {ké₁ 咳欬} (see there for cognates). The MC form kʰak could have an irregular div.
	II vowel for an OC *a (not    *-ra-), but considering PMV *krhaːk (< *k-haːk with r-infix) ``to spit, spittle'' [Ferlus], it is prob. derived from OCM *khrâk. In this case, kè seems to be a MK etymon: PMonic *kʰaak ``to kawk, clear the throat'' [Diffloth 1984: 171]; PSBahn. *haːk ~ *hɔːk ``vomit''.
	[C] Perh. this word is related to {luò₁ 咯}.
::PMonic	*kʰaak	``to kawk, clear the throat''

ENTRY:2044
HEAD:kòu₁ 扣叩

LH:Later Han: kʰoᴮ/ᶜ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *khôʔ/h
GLOSS:"To strike, attack" 叩 [Lunyu].
	[E] Prob. area word. ST: WB kʰok < kʰuk ``knock, rap'' (HST: 142).
	<> MK: Khmer goḥ /kóh/ ``to strike, hit, beat, knock'' (also used in sense of stiking a gong).
	CH aspiration is associated with forceful motion {§5.8.5}.
	[C] Perh. cognate to {kòu₂ 寇} ``rob''. Wáng Lì 1982: 185 adds to this wf: kǎo 考 (kâuᴮ) ``to beat'' (instrument) [Shi], et al.
::Khmer	goḥ /kóh/	``to strike, hit, beat, knock''
>:Prob. area word. ST:
>:WB kʰok < kʰuk ``knock, rap''

ENTRY:2078
HEAD:kuāng₄ 筐
MC:Middle Chinese: kʰjwaŋ 
LH:Later Han: kʰyɑŋ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *khwaŋ 
OCB:Baxter Old Chinese: *kᵂhjaŋ
GLOSS:"Square basket" > vb.
GLOSS:"put into a square basket" [Shi];
GLOSS:"get boxed in" (in a military maneuver) [BI]; kuāng-chuáng 筐床 ``bed'' (which is rectangular) [Zhuang] (chuáng ``bed''). From the Yìjīng 54 line  女承筐無實 nǚ chéng kuāng wú shí  ``the woman holds a basket, it has no fruit'' (implying she is barren) derives the euphemism chéng-kuāng ``vagina'' (Shaugh nessy JAS 51.3, 1992: 591); this is perhaps also the connotation in Shījīng 161.1.
	[E] A final -ŋ derivation from the stem under {jǔ₃ 矩} ``square'' ({§6.5.2}). Alternatively, Baxter / Sagart (1998: 48) derive this word with k-prefix ({§5.4}) from {fāng₁ 方} ``square''.
	If true, loss of a post-initial consonant could explain the aspiration.
>:A final -ŋ derivation from the stem under {jǔ₃ 矩} ``square'' . Alternatively
>:Baxter / Sagart  derive this word with k-prefix  from {fāng₁ 方} ``square''

ENTRY:2089
HEAD:kuí₃ 夔
MC:Middle Chinese: gjwi 3 
LH:Later Han: guɨ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *grui or *gwrə ?
	A large mythical animal of various descriptions, with one foot [Guoyu], in one version ``as strong as an ox'' 夔 [Shanhaijing], ``a large buffalo'' in the mountains of Shǔ (Sìchuān) 犪 [Shanhaijing].
	[E] Area word. Chinese kuí 夔 is a loan from a KT source: PTai *ɣwaiᴬ ``buffalo'' (Mei Tsu-Lin, AAS paper 1980); Sui kwiᴬ² < gwiᴬ ``buffalo'' (Hansell 1988: 269).
	Note also PAN *kəbaw (Dempwolff), Tagalog kalabao, Malay kĕrbao, Fiji karavau (Benedict AT: 45; Mahdi 1994: 200).
>:Area word. Chinese kuí 夔 is a loan from a KT source:
>:PTai *ɣwaiᴬ ``buffalo''
>:Sui kwiᴬ² < gwiᴬ ``buffalo''

ENTRY:2090

GLOSS:"Wild buffalo" [Erya, Yupian].
GLOSS-NOTE:This is not a pre-Han word.
	[E] This is ultimately the same etymon as kuí, but the source might have been a TB language: PTB *lwaay ``buffalo'', JP ʔu³³-loi³³, ŋa³³-loi³³ (ŋa³³ ``bovine''), WB kywai < klway (STC no. 208; Matisoff 1974 no. 262).
>:This is ultimately the same etymon as kuí, but the source might have been a TB language:
>:PTB *lwaay ``buffalo''

>:WB kywai < klway

ENTRY:2091
HEAD:kuǐ 跬
MC:Middle Chinese: kʰjweiᴮ 
LH:Later Han: kʰyeᴮ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *khweʔ
GLOSS:"A stride, distance covered by lifting one leg" (as opposed to {bù₄ 步} ‘stride of two legs) [Li].
	[E] ST: WB kwaiᴮ ``be divided, split, parted'' ⪤ kʰwaiᴮ ``divide, split'', JP gai³¹-gai³¹ ``walk with legs spread wide''. There might have been a *-wa ~ *-wai variation already on the ST level (see {kuà 跨}) because both OC and WB have these doublets.
	[C] This etymon may be related to {qīng₄ 傾頃} ``slanting'', both are connected at least in the minds of those writers who borrowed 頃 for kuǐ [Liji]. Wáng Lì (1982:  107) relates {kuà 跨} (kʰuaᶜ) ``to step over, pass over'' to this word family.
::JP	gai³¹-gai³¹	``walk with legs spread wide''
>:WB kwaiᴮ ``be divided, split, parted'' ⪤ kʰwaiᴮ ``divide, split''

ENTRY:2093
HEAD:kuì₁ 匱

ENTRY:2095
HEAD:kuì₂ 餽饋
MC:Middle Chinese: gjwiᶜ 3 
LH:Later Han: gwɨs (饋) or gwɨh (餽) ? 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *gwəs or *gwəh ?
GLOSS:"Food" 饋 [Shi],
GLOSS:"to eat" [Huainanzi] > caus.
GLOSS:"to present food" 餽饋 [Meng].
	[E] This word looks like a cognate of {yí₁₂ 遺} (jiwi 4) ``hand down, present''. However, one would expect a MC div. 4 final, not the div. 3 final which is confirmed by Mand. kuì (we would expect Mand. ji or qi in div. 4 syllables of this type).
	Also, the meanings ``food'' and ``present'' suggest different etyma, the meaning ``to present'' for both is an accidental convergence.
>:This word looks like a cognate of {yí₁₂ 遺}  ``hand down, present''. However, one would expect a MC div. 4 final, not the div. 3 final which is confirmed by Mand. kuì

ENTRY:2096

	[T] ONW kon
GLOSS:"Elder brother" [Shi].
	[E] Etymology is not clear. STC: 158 n. 428 relates kūn to the same PTB root *kəw ``maternal uncle'' to which belongs {jiù₂ 舅}.
	Alterna tively, note MMon ko² / ko/ ``elder brother'', CH could have added the nominal -n ({§6.4.3}).
::MMon	ko² / ko/	``elder brother''
>:Etymology is not clear. STC:
>:158 n. 428 relates kūn to the same PTB root *kəw ``maternal uncle'' to which belongs {jiù₂ 舅}

ENTRY:2114
HEAD:là₂ 辣
MC:Middle Chinese: lât
	[D] Mǐn: Amoy loáh [loaʔᴰ²] lit. loát ``pungent''.
GLOSS:"Hot, spicy", a late word which seems to have a Tai counterpart: Saek thaat < d-
GLOSS:"peppers, spicy, hot", Poai šaatᴰ²ᴸ < ǰ-,
GLOSS:"hot, peppery", Dioi (Yay) śat¹ (< *b-lat¹) [Maspero 1912: 87].

ENTRY:2115
HEAD:là₃ 臘
MC:Middle Chinese: lâp 
LH:Later Han: lɑp 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *râp
	[T] Sin Sukchu SR la (入)
	[T] ONW lɑp
GLOSS:"Year end sacrifice" to the spirits of the dead and the household, performed in the 12th (last) month’ [BI; Zuo, year 655 BC] (Bodde 1975: 49).
	[E] Zhèng Xuán comments that “là is a designation for the sacrifice made of animals which have been caught in a hunt liè 獵 (ljap)” [Shi] (Bodde ibid. 57), thus considering là and liè cognates. Boltz (JAOS 99, 1979: 429) relates là to a much later word written with the same phonetic ``to cut off, terminate'' (i.e. a year) [GY].
	There is a ST alternative.
	The wf {yè₄ 葉} *lap encompasses the meanings ``leaf > foliage > year > generation''.
	The present root *râp ``new year / change of year'' seems to be a parallel etymon which also has a WT cognate rabs ``generation'', Mikir rap, Rawang rəp ``family'' [Bodman 1980: 86].
::Rawang	rəp	``family''
>:Zhèng Xuán comments that “là is a designation for the sacrifice made of animals which have been caught in a hunt liè 獵 ”  , thus considering là and liè cognates. Boltz  relates là to a much later word written with the same phonetic ``to cut off, terminate''

::WB	kʰrip	``lac''
>:Maru rap ``lac insect''
>:Nung k’ə-rap ``wax''
>:WB kʰrip ``lac''. Viet. sáp ``wax'' belongs to those few words which have SV s-  for MC l-

ENTRY:2117
HEAD:lái₁ 來
MC:Middle Chinese: lậi 
LH:Later Han: lə 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *rə̂k/ʔ > *rə̂ 
OCB:Baxter Old Chinese: *C-rə(k)
GLOSS:"To come" [OB, Shi].
	[T] Sin Sukchu SR laj (平), LR laj
	[T] MGZY lay (平) [laj]
	[T] ONW lɑi
	[N] Rimes in the oldest parts of Shījīng (Dàyǎ and Xiǎoyǎ) indicate a final *-k or *-ʔ  for this word, but in the later Guófēng sections the rimes indicate an open syllable (Baxter 1992: 337).
	[E] ST *rə: Kanauri ra ``to come'', Kuki-Chin *ra: Tangkhul ra, ``come'', Lai  raa / rat  ``to come'', PLB *ra³ ``win, overcome'', WB raᶜ, Lahu g̈a ``get, obtain''; with TB final *-k: Meithei lak, Dulong lɔ̆k (Matisoff 1995a: 49f). The range of meanings in TB (come > arrive > succeed > overcome > strength, power [Matisoff D. of Lahu: 1113]) connect lái etymologically with {lì₁ 力} ``strength''. The ST level had apparently already doublets *lə ({dài₄ 迨}) ~ *rə ``arrive''.
::ST	level had apparently already doublets *lə  ~ *rə	``arrive''
>:ST *rə:
>:Kanauri ra ``to come''
>:Kuki-Chin *ra:
>:Tangkhul ra, ``come''
>:Lai  raa / rat  ``to come''
>:PLB *ra³ ``win, overcome''
>:WB raᶜ, Lahu g̈a ``get, obtain''
>:with TB final *-k:
>:Meithei lak
>:Dulong lɔ̆k . The range of meanings in TB  connect lái etymologically with {lì₁ 力} ``strength''. The ST level had apparently already doublets *lə  ~ *rə ``arrive''

ENTRY:2129
HEAD:lán₅ 藍
MC:Middle Chinese: lâm 
LH:Later Han: lɑm 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *râm 
OCB:Baxter Old Chinese: *g-ram
	[T] ONW lɑm
GLOSS:"Indigo" [Shi].
	[E] Area word whose source may have been SE Asia: PAN *taɣum ``indigo'' (Benedict AT: 112; STC: 155 n. 420, 421); PTai *gramᴬ² ``indigo'' (Li F. 1976: 45) would be a backloan from OC (Egerod CAAAL 6, 1976: 56). WT rams ``indigo'' is a CH loan (Laufer TP 17, 1916: 503).
	This word occurs also in other TB languages, note Mru charam ``indigo'' (Löffler 1966: 140).
	Alternatively, Xie Caide (YWYJ 1999.10: 124) suggests that WT ram(-pa) ``quick grass'' may be cognate to CH.
::WT	ram(-pa)	``quick grass''
>:Area word whose source may have been SE Asia:
>:PAN *taɣum ``indigo''
>:PTai *gramᴬ² ``indigo''  would be a backloan from OC . WT rams ``indigo'' is a CH loan

ENTRY:2148
HEAD:làng 浪
MC:Middle Chinese: lâŋᶜ 
LH:Later Han: lɑŋᶜ
	[T] Sin Sukchu SR laŋ (去)
	[T] MGZY lang (去) [laŋ]
	[T] ONW lɑŋ
	[N] The basic meaning is perhaps ``let go and disperse''. Through the Han period, làng occurs in combination with other words: 謔浪 ``ridicule'' [Shi, Karlgren transl.], 波浪 ``wave'' [Nan-Bai chao, GY] (Huáng Jīnguì, Shěn Xíróng YYWZX 1987.8: 44f). Huáng and Shěn suggest that làng is a colloquial variant of {lán₈ 瀾}.
	Prob. not related to WT (dba’-) kloŋ ``wave'', see {róng₃ 溶}.
::WT	(dba’-) kloŋ	``wave''

ENTRY:2150

ENTRY:2152

	The KT forms do not belong to {jiǔ₅ 酒}.
	It is not clear if and how zhòu 酎 (ḍjəuᴮ), LH ḍuᴮ, *druʔ ``new spirits'' [Liji] could be related. ENTRY:2153
HEAD:lǎo 老

	[T] ONW lɑu
GLOSS:"Be old, grow old" [BI, Shi], the Northern Mǐn initial s- as in Jiàn’ōu seᶜ² may be due to loss of a pre-initial which might have been a velar considering the XS contact with kǎo 考
GLOSS:"old age" (Mei / Norman 1971: 99). Old Sino-Viet. reu (Pān Wùyún 1987: 28).
	[E] Etymology not certain. The meanings or vowels of the following TB comparanda are not close to OC: PTB *raw (STC no. 268) > WT ro ``corpse''; Lep hryu ``be dry, dead'' (of leaf); Lushai roᴴ ``be dry, dead''; WB ro ``very old'' ⪤ rwat ``old, tough'', NNaga *rəw ``old'' (of person).

ENTRY:2154
HEAD:lào₁ 酪
MC:Middle Chinese: lâk 
LH:Later Han: lɑk 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *râk < *g-rak
	Fermented thick liquid: ``a kind of acid soy made of rice or millet'' [Li] (so GSR 766p); ``fermented milk, yoghurt, sour milk, kumiss'' [SW]. This is a loanword from a Central Asian language, note Mongol ayiraɣ < *aɣɨraɣ ``fermented milk'' (Pulleyblank 1962: 250-3).
	This area word appears with the meaning ``milk'' in Greek (tò gála, gen. gálaktos) and Latin (lac, lactis) (Karlgren Deutsche Literaturzeitung 1926).
	The fermented drink ``arrack'' may be a different etymon, a loan from Arabic ``araq ‘fermented juice'' (so Pulleyblank 1962: 250 contra Karlgren 1926).
::Mongol	ayiraɣ < *aɣɨraɣ	``fermented milk''

ENTRY:2155
HEAD:lào₂ 癆
MC:Middle Chinese: lâuᶜ 
LH:Later Han: lɑuᶜ
	A Northeastern (Cháoxiān 朝鮮) dialect word of the Han period for ``medicinal poison'', acc. to FY 3 and SW, and in modern Xiāng dialects the col. word for ``to poison'' which may be related to {liào₃ 療樂} ``to cure''.
	Sagart (1995: 210) considers this word to be cognate to {dú 毒} ``poison'', but Starostin (JCL monograph 8, 1995: 402) points out that lào is rather cognate to TB: Lushai ru ``the bark, root, leaves etc. used for fish poisoning'', JP mə-rau ``fishing by stupefying fish by poisonous vines'', Burmese rəu ``fish poison'', etc. (Starostin's notations).
::Burmese	rəu	``fish poison''

ENTRY:2168
HEAD:lèi₁ 淚
MC:Middle Chinese: ljwiᶜ 
LH:Later Han: lus (luis) 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *r(i)uts
GLOSS:"Tears" [Chuci].
	[T] Sin Sukchu SR luj (去)
	[T] MGZY lue (去) [luɛ]
	[E] Lèi is a late OC word. For phonological reasons it can hardly be related to {qì₅ 泣} *khrəp ``weep''.
	The closest TB comparandum might be WB re < *ri ``water'', JP mə³¹-riʔ⁵⁵ ``dew'', if we assume a ST *rwi (with regular loss of medial w).
	Most likely, this is a t-suffix derivation (nouns for naturally occurring things {§6.2.1}) of {liú₃ 流} *l(i)u ``to flow'', hence lit. ``the things that are flowing''.
	TB cognates suggest a ST and PCH medial *-j-; WT rgyun ``the flow, current, stream''.
::WT	rgyun	``the flow, current, stream''
>:Lèi is a late OC word. For phonological reasons it can hardly be related to {qì₅ 泣} *khrəp ``weep''

ENTRY:2174
HEAD:lí₁ 狸
	{lí₃} 貍

ENTRY:2175
HEAD:lí₂ 梩
	{jī₆} 箕

ENTRY:2176
HEAD:lí₃ 貍
MC:Middle Chinese: ljɨ 
LH:Later Han: liə > lɨ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: (*pʰrə ~ *pʰə-rə >) *rə ?
	[T] ONW liə
	Mand. ``raccoon dog'', also the second syllable in Mand. húlí 狐狸 ``fox'', the latter already in Zuǒzhuàn and Mèngzǐ.
	But in Shūjīng, 狐貍 refers to two different animals where the ``cat'' radical in lí as well as the association with {pí₅ 貔} (bji 4) ``leopard'' imply a ``wild cat'' of approximately fox size.
	[D] Acc. to FY 8.2, lí is a dialect word for the region west of the Passes (Wèi valley and around Xī’ān), whereas other regions have the following forms (discussed by Sagart ICSTLL 1990: 7): lái 𧳟 (lậi) LH lə in Chén (modern Hénán) and Chǔ (modern Húběi) and between the Yangtze and Huái rivers
	[D] pī 𧳏 (pʰjɨ 3) LH pʰiə in northern Yān (Héběi, Liáoníng) and in northern Korea
	[D] pī-lí 𧳏貍 (pʰjɨ 3-ljɨ) south of the Yangtze at Guō Pú's time (d. 324 AD). Zhào Zhēnfēng and Huáng Fēng suggest a connection with Miao ple, pli ``cat'' (YWYJ 1998.10: 76-79).
	FY and Guō Pú consider all these to be dialect words for {pí₅ 貔} which is, however, a different word.
	The Northern Mǐn initial s- in 貍 as in Jiàn’ōu sɛᴬ² may be due to loss of a preinitial labial (Mei / Norman 1971: 99).
	[E] Perh. ST: Mru pri ``kind of leopard'' (Löffler 1966: 147).
	If WT ži-mi ``cat'' (also žim-bu ~ žum-bu) should derive from a hypothetical *ryi-mi, it could be cognate to lí.
	WT bi-ši (< -ži ?) ``cat'' may then even be the equivalent of the CH dialectal pʰ-initial forms.
	In this case, the original CH word could have been a compound pí-lí 貔貍 ``(large) cat'' + ``small cat''.
	But all this is uncertain, also because of possible Indic influence on WT words, see {pí₅ 貔}.
::WT	bi-ši (< -ži ?)	``cat''
>: Mru pri ``kind of leopard''

LH:Later Han: liə

ENTRY:2183
HEAD:lí₁₀ 離
MC:Middle Chinese: ljie 3 
LH:Later Han: liɑi 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *rai
	[T] ONW le
GLOSS:"To leave, depart from, be dispersed" [Shi],
GLOSS:"divide, distribute" [Li].
GLOSS-NOTE:It has been suggested that pǐ 仳 (pʰiᴮ / biᴮ) LH pʰiʔ / biʔ which occurs in Shījīng in the combination pǐ-lí
GLOSS:"be separated" represents an old pre-initial, note WT ’bral-ba
GLOSS:"be separated" (under {bān₁ 班}) (so Dǒng Wéiguāng et al.
	CAAAL 22, 1984: 112f).
	Old Sino-Viet. rɐi (Pān Wùyún 1987: 28).
	[E] ST *ral: Mru ria < ral ``separated from'' (Löffler 1966: 146; 134), JP ran³³ ``be apart, separated, divided'' ⪤ mə³¹-ran³¹ ``to place apart'' ⪤ pə³¹-ran³¹ ``be separate, sort out'' ⪤ gə³¹-ran⁵⁵ ``to divide, distribute'' ⪤ ra³¹ ``be parted, separated'' (Wolfenden 1937: 646). Another derivation from the ST stem *(C-)ral is {bān₁ 班} with the common ST *-l > OC *-n shift.
	For an overview of similar items, see {Table P-1} under {pī₃ 披}.
	Some of the many similar ST roots could be related:
	1. *pai  ``break'' {pò₁ 破}
	2. *pai ``separate, open'' {pī₃ 披}
	3. *brai  ``open'' {bǎi₂ 捭}, {bò₃ 擘}
	4. *trai  ``open'' {zhā 奓}, {zhé₆ 磔}
	5. *pral ``separate'' {bān₁ 班}
	6. *ral  ``separate, leave''    lí  離 (this entry)
	7. *hral  ``split'' {chǐ₁ 拸}
	8. *p(r)ək  ``split'' {pì₇ 副}
	9. *k-hlai  ``separate'' {chǐ₂,chí 誃}
	Perhaps the stems in *-ai (1-4) form one large wf, as do perhaps the forms in *-ral (5-7).
::JP	ran³³	``be apart, separated, divided''
>:ST *ral:
>:Mru ria < ral ``separated from''
>:JP ran³³ ``be apart, separated, divided'' ⪤ mə³¹-ran³¹ ``to place apart'' ⪤ pə³¹-ran³¹ ``be separate, sort out'' ⪤ gə³¹-ran⁵⁵ ``to divide, distribute'' ⪤ ra³¹ ``be parted, separated'' . Another derivation from the ST stem *ral is {bān₁ 班} with the common ST *-l >
>:OC *-n shift

ENTRY:2189
HEAD:lǐ₁ 李

LH:Later Han: liəᴮ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *rəʔ
	[T] ONW liə
GLOSS:"Plum" (Prunus salicina) [Shi], a fruit tree which originated in North China; the Northern Mǐn initial s- as in Jiàn’ōu sɛᶜ² may be due to loss of a pre-initial, PMin *ḷəiᴮ (Mei / Norman 1971: 101).

ENTRY:2190
HEAD:lǐ₂-ěr 李耳
MC:Middle Chinese: ljɨᴮ-ńźɨᴮ 
LH:Later Han: liəʔ-ńiəʔ > liʔ-ńiʔ
	Acc. to FY 8.1, this is a Chǔ dialect word for ``tiger'' [FY, Yijing]. Zhào Zhēnfēng and Huáng Fēng (YWYJ 1998.10: 76-79) suggest a connection with the Tǔjiā words li-pa ``male tiger'' and li-ni ``female tiger''.
	The last syllable -ni could be related to Khmer ɲiː ``female'', unless it is a regional word for ``mother'', then prob. the same etymon as {nǎi₄ 嬭}.
::Khmer	ɲiː	``female''

ENTRY:2191
HEAD:lǐ₃ 里
MC:Middle Chinese: ljɨᴮ 
LH:Later Han: liəᴮ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *rəʔ
	[T] ONW liə
GLOSS:"Village" [Shi]
	[E] Prob. ST *rwə: PTB *rwa > WB rwa ``town, village''; WT ra-ba ``fence, enclosure, wall, pen''.
	For the loss of ST medial *w in OC and WT, see {§10.2.1}.
	Note the Germanic semantic parallel Engl. town ⪤ German Zaun ``fence''.
	The synonym PTB *gwa ``village'' may belong to CH {qiū₂ 丘}.
	<> Tai: S. ruaᶜ² < *r- ``fence'' (Li F. 1976: 43) may also belong to this etymon.
	Alternatively, this word may belong to {lǐ₄ 理里} ``divide into equal sections'', but pre- and early historic Chinese villages prob. were not systematically planned and plotted.
::PTB	*gwa	``village''
>:Prob. ST *rwə:
>:PTB *rwa >
>:WB rwa ``town, village''
>:WT ra-ba ``fence, enclosure, wall, pen''

ENTRY:2192
HEAD:lǐ₄ 理里
MC:Middle Chinese: ljɨᴮ 
LH:Later Han: liəᴮ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *rəʔ
	[T] MTang li ONW liə
GLOSS:"Cut jade according to its veins" [Guoce],
GLOSS:"to divide fields into sections, boundaries" 理
	[Shi]; ``a mile'' 里 [Shi]. The basic meaning is ``cut in a regular way, divide into equal sections''.
	[E] ST: This etymon is often considered to be related to PTB *riy ``draw, paint, write, delimit'' etc. (STC no. 429; HST: 66) > Lushai riᴿ ``boundary, frontier, limit, line of demarcation'', NNaga *rəy ``thread, boundary'', and WT ’bri-ba, bris ``to draw, write'' ⪤ ris ``figure'', WB reᴮ ``write, delineate, paint'', Mru pri ``to scratch'' [Löffler 1966: 133]. However, OC *ə corresponds normally to PTB *a, only rarely, if ever, to *i ({§11.2.2}).
::Mru	pri	``to scratch''
>:This etymon is often considered to be related to PTB *riy ``draw, paint, write, delimit'' etc.  >
>:Lushai riᴿ ``boundary, frontier, limit, line of demarcation''
>:NNaga *rəy ``thread, boundary'', and WT ’bri-ba, bris ``to draw, write'' ⪤ ris ``figure''
>:WB reᴮ ``write, delineate, paint''
>:Mru pri ``to scratch'' . However, OC *ə corresponds normally to PTB *a, only rarely, if ever, to *i

ENTRY:2193
HEAD:lǐ₄ 理里 ⪤ lè 泐阞勒扐仂
MC:Middle Chinese: lək 
LH:Later Han: lək 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *rə̂k
	[T] ONW lək
GLOSS:"Vein or duct in soil; fraction" 阞 [Zhouli],
GLOSS:"split according to the veins" (stone) 泐 [Zhouli] >
GLOSS:"engrave" 勒 [Li]; ``space between fingers'' 扐 [Yi] > ``a tenth'' 仂 [Li].
GLOSS-NOTE:{lè₁ 勒}
GLOSS:"reins" may be the s. w.
	This item and {lǐ₅ 理} are usually thought to be the same etymon: ``divide into sections > regulate''.
	Baxter (1992: 473) relates these to {pì₇ 副}.

ENTRY:2194
HEAD:lǐ₅ 理
MC:Middle Chinese: ljɨᴮ 
LH:Later Han: liəᴮ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *rəʔ
GLOSS:"To regulate, reason" [Yi];
GLOSS:"administer" [Lüshi] is prob. related to {lí₄ 釐}
GLOSS:"regulate", and possibly also to {lǐ₆ 理} ``envoy''. This item and {lǐ₄ 理} are usually thought to be the same word, which is possible: ``divide into sections > regulate''.
	Middle Viet. mlẽ, mnhẽ ``reason'' [Maspero 1912: 78] could perhaps be a CH loan. A possible cognate may be {jì₈ 紀}.

ENTRY:2195
HEAD:lǐ₆ 理
MC:Middle Chinese: ljɨᴮ 
LH:Later Han: liəᴮ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *rəʔ
GLOSS:"An envoy" [Zuo],
GLOSS:"jail official" [Guanzi],
GLOSS:"marriage go-between" [Chuci].
	This is perhaps the s. w. as {lǐ₅ 理} ``to administer'' [Lüshi].
	[E] AA: OKhmer (7th cent. AD) *re /rəə ~ ree/ ``to move, change position …'' has the derivative OKhmer pre /prəə/ ``to send'' (on an errand or commission), ``to order, assign, appoint, delegate, use, make, employ'' ⪤ OKhmer paṃre ``to serve; servant, delegate, representative, minister; service, duty''.
	Initial p- is the Khmer causative prefix, which OC has replaced with the ST / POC causative prefix *s-.
	Alternatively, Unger (Hao-ku 36, 1990: 56) and CVST 2: 77 derive shǐ 史使 from {lǐ₄ 理里} (ljɨᴮ) ``to mark, draw lines'', hence lit. ``scribe''.
	However, though perhaps cognate to WT ’bri-ba ``to write'', lǐ never seems to mean ``to write, record'' in OC. Matisoff (D. of Lahu: 498) relates shǐ 史使 to PLB *ʔ-dziy¹ > WB ce ``send on business, employ''.
	This wf may belong to a larger group which includes {shì₂ 士仕} (dẓɨᴮ).
	The issue is further complicated by the question of the position of {shì₁ 士} (dẓɨᴮ) in the overall picture.
::WB	ce	``send on business, employ''
>:AA:
>:OKhmer  *re /rəə ~ ree/ ``to move, change position …'' has the derivative OKhmer pre /prəə/ ``to send'' , ``to order, assign, appoint, delegate, use, make, employ'' ⪤ OKhmer paṃre ``to serve; servant, delegate, representative, minister
>:service, duty''

ENTRY:2229

>:JP ren³¹ ``place in a long, even row''
>:WB rañ-tu ``be equal'', hrañ ``put together, side by side''
>:Mikir ren ``line, range, row'' . Unger  relates the CH word to WT ’brel-ba ``connection, conjunction''
>:the final -n in the other TB languages could derive from *-l as well
>:Gong  relates it to WT gral ``row, series, class''

(1976: 40) associates the Tai word with CH {yú₅ 余} ``I'' for which he reconstructs OC *rag (OCM *la). (2) Cognate to PTB *s-raŋ > WT sraŋ ``pair of scales, weight''. ENTRY:2266
HEAD:liàng 亮
MC:Middle Chinese: ljaŋᶜ 
LH:Later Han: liɑŋᶜ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *raŋh 
OCB:Baxter Old Chinese: *C-rjaŋs
GLOSS:"Light" n. [Shi, Shu], of moon et al.; liàng refers to pale light, while {lǎng 朗} refers to brilliant light.
	[E] Apparently a member of an MK wf: MK *raaŋʔ ``light, to shine'' (Shorto 2006 #660) > Palaung raŋ ``lamp'', Bru rliaŋ, Katu baruaŋ ``moonlight'', Khmer -rāṃṅa ``be light, bright'' ⪤ srāṃṅa /sraŋ/ ``be pale, colorless''.
	Allofam is prob. {shuǎng₁ 爽}, possibly also {liáng₁,làng 俍}, {lǎng 朗}, {jǐng₃ 景} (so Karlgren 1956: 12) and perhaps {yīng₁ 英}.
	Baxter relates this word to {míng₆ 明} OCB *mrjaŋ and {jìng₆ 鏡}.
	Items of the Khmer wf can be associated with individual CH words, this would explain the different OC initial consonant which seems to have no recognizable OC morphological function:
	(a) Khmer -rāṃṅa ``be light, bright''
	liàng 亮 (ljaŋᶜ) OCB *C-rjaŋs  ``light''
	(b) Khmer srāṅa /sraaŋ/ (intr., of first light of day) ``to be dim, faint, weak''
	{shuǎng₁ 爽} (ṣjaŋᴮ) *sraŋʔ ``twilight'' (of dawn)
	(c) Khmer brāṅa /príiəŋ/ intr. ``to grow light'' (after dark)
	{bǐng₁ 炳昺邴} (bjɐŋᴮ) OCB *brjaŋʔ ? ``bright''
	(d) Khmer paṃbrāṅa /bampríiəŋ/ ``to shed a pale light'', Kuy mphrìːaŋ [sai] ``moon''
	{míng₆ 明} (mjwɐŋ) OCB *mrjaŋ  ``become bright, enlightened''
::OCB	*mrjaŋ 	``become bright, enlightened''
>:Apparently a member of an MK wf:
>:MK *raaŋʔ ``light, to shine''  >
>:Palaung raŋ ``lamp''
>:Bru rliaŋ
>:Katu baruaŋ ``moonlight''
>:Khmer -rāṃṅa ``be light, bright'' ⪤ srāṃṅa /sraŋ/ ``be pale, colorless''

ENTRY:2271
HEAD:liáo₅ 膋
MC:Middle Chinese: lieu 
LH:Later Han: leu 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *riâu
	[T] ONW lėu
GLOSS:"Fat round intestines" [Shi, Li], 膫 [SW]; zhī-liáo 脂膫
GLOSS:"tallow, grease" (Giles).
	[E] Etymology unknown because the following comparanda are too far removed from OC: WT rgyu-ma < r-yu ``intestines, entrails''. Alternatively, liáo may be connected with AA: note Semai (NW) lʔuus ``animal grease'' [Diffloth 1976: 211], Lawa laʔauk, U raʔaus ``grease'' [Diffloth id.: 218]. PTai *lauᴬ² ``pork fat, grease'' (only in northern and central Tai) looks like a loan from CH liáo.
::PTai	*lauᴬ²	``pork fat, grease''
>:Etymology unknown because the following comparanda are too far removed from OC:
>:WT rgyu-ma < r-yu ``intestines, entrails''. Alternatively, liáo may be connected with AA:
>:note Semai  lʔuus ``animal grease''
>:Lawa laʔauk
>:U raʔaus ``grease'' . PTai *lauᴬ² ``pork fat, grease''  looks like a loan from CH liáo

ENTRY:2279

	Allofams are {yào₄ 藥} (jiak) *iɔk ``to cure'', and prob. also {chōu₂,liáo 瘳} (ṭʰjəu, lieu) *rhiu, *riû ``get cured, recover''.
	If yào should be a member of this wf, the OC initial *r- in liào is a former pre-initial, hence yào < *r-jauk, liào < *rjauk(h).
	See also {lào₂ 癆}.

	Perh. ``a sharp sensation on the skin'' > ``to blaze, broil'' (meat) [Shi] > (A) ``illustrious, splendid'' [Shi, YiZhou] > ``brilliant deed, brilliance'' [BI, Shu]; > (B) (``A burning-like sensation'') > ``cool'' (of a spring) 冽 [Shi]; ``violent winds'' 烈風 [Shu] > ``violent, bad wind'' 颲 [SW, Yupian] (Karlgren GSR 291). ENTRY:2287
HEAD:liè₅ 躐
MC:Middle Chinese: ljäp 
LH:Later Han: liap 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *rap
GLOSS:"To tread, trample" [Li].
	[E] ST: PTB *rap (LaPolla 1994: 166) > KN-Lushai rapᴸ / raʔᴸ ``to tread (upon), trample upon'', WT skrab-pa ``to stamp (the ground), tread'' ⪤ ’kʰrab-pa ``to strike, stump, thump''. However, the initial k- in the WT cognates skrab, ’kʰrab  could theoretically derive from an earlier initial *ʔ-, note the initial *ʔr- in the putative OC cognate {yā₃ 壓} OC *ʔrap ``press down, stamp'', as well as the absence of velar initials in the other TB languages; perhaps also connected with dié 蹀 (diep) ``to trample, stamp'' [Lie] (so Sagart 1999: 127), and possibly also to {niè₇ 躡} OC *nrap ``trample''.
::OC	*nrap	``trample''
>:PTB *rap  >
>:KN-Lushai rapᴸ / raʔᴸ ``to tread , trample upon''
>:WT skrab-pa ``to stamp , tread'' ⪤ ’kʰrab-pa ``to strike, stump, thump''. However, the initial k- in the WT cognates skrab, ’kʰrab  could theoretically derive from an earlier initial *ʔ-, note the initial *ʔr- in the putative OC cognate {yā₃ 壓} OC *ʔrap ``press down, stamp'', as well as the absence of velar initials in the other TB languages
>:perhaps also connected with dié 蹀  ``to trample, stamp''  , and possibly also to {niè₇ 躡} OC *nrap ``trample''

ENTRY:2292
HEAD:lín₁ 林 ⪤ sēn 森
MC:Middle Chinese: ṣjəm 
LH:Later Han: ṣɨm 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *srəm
GLOSS:"Forest, dense thicket" [Han text] (Baxter 1992: 553), prob. an intensive derivative of lín ({§5.2.3}), possibly influenced by AA parallels; see below.
	[T] Sin Sukchu SR ʂəm (平)
	[T] MGZY shhim (平) [ʂəm]
	[T] ONW ṣim.
	[E] ST or area etymon: PTB *ram (HPTB: 299) > Northern Naga *C-ram ``forest, jungle'', Lushai ramᴴ ``forest, jungle, country, land'', Mikir iŋrám-àw < m-ram ``be woodsy, dark''. Perh. also shared with AA: Khmer rāma /ríiəm/ ``to gather, be clustered > gallery forest, inundated forest …'' ⪤ OKhmer /rnaam/ (i.e. r-n-aam) ``dense forest in low-lying areas …'' ⪤ /sɑmraam/ (i.e. s-m-raam) ``ground under shrub, tract of undergrowth'' (note the close agreement with OC); mod.
	Mon rāṃ /rèm/ ``copse, patch of woodland''.
	In light of this AA etymology, the wf {lín₂ 林} ``numerous'' could possibly be related.
	Other comparanda are unrelated (the vowels do not agree with OC): Mru rüm ``forest'' (Löffler 1966: 144), WB ə-rum ``cluster, clump'' (of trees) ⪤ kʰrum ~ kʰyum ``cluster, clump''.
	The second part of Garo bol-grim ``forest'' (bol ``tree'') prob. means ``dark'': WT rum ``darkness, obscurity'', JP n³³-rim³³ ``dusk'' ⪤ rim³¹ ``dusk'' [STC no. 401]; also Tai: S. khrɨmᴬ² < *gr- ``jungle'' ⪤ khrɨmᶜ² ``shady, lush'' (Manomaivibool CAAAL 13, 1980: 168). PYao k²em¹ 2 ``forest'' [Purnell] is not related to any of the above.
::PYao	k²em¹ 2	``forest''
>:ST or area etymon:
>:PTB *ram  >
>:Northern Naga *C-ram ``forest, jungle''
>:Lushai ramᴴ ``forest, jungle, country, land''
>:Mikir iŋrám-àw < m-ram ``be woodsy, dark''. Perh. also shared with AA:
>:Khmer rāma /ríiəm/ ``to gather, be clustered > gallery forest, inundated forest …'' ⪤ OKhmer /rnaam/  ``dense forest in low-lying areas …'' ⪤ /sɑmraam/  ``ground under shrub, tract of undergrowth''
>:mod

ENTRY:2300
HEAD:lǐn₁ □
MC:Middle Chinese: QYS analog,Perh. ljenᴮ
	is a southern dial. word for ``penis'': Kèjiā linᴮ, Y-Guǎngzhōu ³⁵lɐnᴮ¹, Táishān ⁵⁵linᴮ¹; M-Taipei lanᶜ¹-tsiauᴮ.
	Benedict (1976: 190) relates this to PTB *(m-)li ``penis'', Karen *lin ``vagina'', but it may simply be a survival from a Tai substratum: Tai S. lɨŋᴬ¹ (R. Bauer [CAAAL 28, 1987: 61f] who, however, believes that the Tai word is a CH loan). Some Mǐn dialects have a different word: PMin *nɔi.
::Karen	*lin	``vagina''

ENTRY:2311
HEAD:líng₇ 陵泠凌

LH:Later Han: lɨŋ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *rəŋ
	(``Step on/over''?:) ``Ascend'' [Guoce], ``transgress'' [Li], ``encroach upon, usurp, oppress, insult'' 陵 [Zuo]; ``surmount'' 泠 [Chuci]; ``maltreat, oppress'' 凌 [Chuci].
	[C] {líng₆ 陵} ``hill'' may be the s. w. This etymon is prob. cognate to the near homo- nym {píng₇ 馮憑} ``walk across'', just as there are doublets líng 凌 ~ {bīng₂ 冰} ``ice''.
	Furthermore, this stem may be connected with {chéng₇ 徵懲} ``suppress''.

ENTRY:2312
HEAD:líng₈ 霝零
MC:Middle Chinese: lieŋ 
LH:Later Han: leŋ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *rêŋ ~ rîn
GLOSS:"To fall" (of rain) 霝 [OB], 零 [Shi],
GLOSS:"drop the leaves" 蘦 [Chuci].
GLOSS-NOTE:The graph originally consisted of 雨
GLOSS:"rain" with
GLOSS:"drops" (not ``mouths'') underneath.
	[T] MTang lieŋ < lɨŋ, ONW lėŋ
	[E] Etymology not clear. Perh. from AA and related to the items under {píng₄ 萍} ``rain master''.
	Or note JP mă³¹-raŋ³³ ``rain'', raŋ³¹-ga³¹ ``violent rain'' (CVST 2: 53).
	There is a remote possibility of a connection with {yǔn₂ 隕殞霣} ``drop, fall, rain'' if one assumes a ST root *rwe- whose initial cluster is simplified to OC *re- and *we- respectively ({§10.1.3}).
	WB lañᴮ < *liŋᴮ ``to fall'' belongs to {diān₂ 顛傎} ``fall over''.
::WB	lañᴮ < *liŋᴮ	``to fall''
>:Etymology not clear. Perh. from AA and related to the items under {píng₄ 萍} ``rain master''

ENTRY:2313
HEAD:líng₉ 靈
MC:Middle Chinese: lieŋ 
LH:Later Han: leŋ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *rêŋ < *C-reŋ
GLOSS:"Divine > felicitous, auspicious > excellent, intelligent" [BI, Shi];
GLOSS:"spirit (of Heaven)" [Hanshu] >
GLOSS:"ghost (of a deceased)" [Hou Hanshu]  > ``female shaman, shaman'' [Chuci].
GLOSS-NOTE:For semantics, cf. mó 魔 (< Indic Mara) both
GLOSS:"witch" and
GLOSS:"demon".
	[T] Sin Sukchu SR liŋ (平)
	[T] MGZY ling (平) [liŋ]
	[T] ONW lėŋ
	[E] MY: PMiao *qɭeŋᴬ (Wáng FS) ``ghost''. ``Ghost'' and {líng₈ 霝零} ``rain'' are etymologically distinct, although in the meaning ``prayer for rain, rainmaster'', the two converge. On the other hand, weather phenomena are divine portents, see {fēn₂ 雰氛}.
	CH ⇒ Viet thiêng (via s-, from Cr-) (Maspero 1912: 84).
>:MY:
>:PMiao *qɭeŋᴬ  ``ghost''. ``Ghost'' and {líng₈ 霝零} ``rain'' are etymologically distinct, although in the meaning ``prayer for rain, rainmaster'', the two converge. On the other hand, weather phenomena are divine portents, see {fēn₂ 雰氛}

ENTRY:2314

OCB:Baxter Old Chinese: *C-rĕŋʔ

GLOSS:"collar" [Li] > (``take by the neck'' [Karlgren]:)
GLOSS:"to lead, direct" [Li].

	[T] MGZY ling (上) [liŋ]
	[T] ONW lieŋ
	[D] ``Collar'' in PMin *liaŋᴮ: Fúzhōu liaŋᴮ¹, Xiàmén niãᴮ¹
	[E] ST: Lushai riŋᶠ ``neck''; possibly also WT mgrin-pa ``neck, throat''. This is prob. a variant of  PTB *m-liŋ ``neck'' (Matisoff 1995a: 51): WB lañ, Nung liŋ; WT mǰiŋ-pa ~ ’ǰiŋ-pa < *mliŋ or *mriŋ ``neck'' (HST: 112).
	Benedict connects the TB word with *(g-)liŋ ``tube'' (French 1983: 525).
	The synonym {jǐng₂ 頸} is prob. not related.
::PTB	*m-liŋ	``neck''

ENTRY:2315
HEAD:lìng 令
MC:Middle Chinese: ljäŋ(ᶜ) 
LH:Later Han: lieŋ(ᶜ) 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *reŋ(h) ~ *rin(s)
GLOSS:"To order, command" [Shi].
	[T] Sin Sukchu SR liŋ (平去)
	[T] MGZY ling (平去) [liŋ]
	[T] ONW lieŋ
	[N] In the OB and BI, 令 writes actually {mìng 命} ``order'' to which it is usually thought to be related (so Wáng Lì 1982: 329). Acc. to Downer (1959: 286), ``to command'' [Zuo] is read in tone C, ``to cause'' [Zuo] in tone A.

ENTRY:2316

	[D] M-Xiàmén, Fúzhōu lauᴬ². The Northern Mǐn initial s- as in Jiànyáng seuᴬ² may be due to loss of a pre-initial: PMin *ḷəu (Mei / Norman 1971: 100).

ENTRY:2317
HEAD:liú₂ 劉

LH:Later Han: lu 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *ru
GLOSS:"To slaughter, kill" [OB, Shi]; a Han period dialect word for
GLOSS:"to kill" in Qín, Jìn, Sòng and Wèi [FY 1, 16].
	[N] In the OB, this word was written with the graph for the cyclical sign mǎo 卯 (mauᴮ) < *mruʔ which seems to have been intended for writing ``slaughter'' as it shows perhaps two pieces of meat which have been cut apart.

	[T] MTang leu < liu, ONW lu < lu
	[D] The Northern Mǐn initial s- as in Jiànyáng seuᴬ² may be due to loss of a pre-initial (Mei / Norman 1971: 101).
	[E] Perh. ST: KC-Tiddim gou⁵³ / gɔʔ¹¹ < rouh / rɔʔ/h ``to kill, slaughter''.

ENTRY:2325
HEAD:lóng₁ 隆
MC:Middle Chinese: ljuŋ 
LH:Later Han: luŋ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *ruŋ 
OCB:Baxter Old Chinese: *g-rjuŋ
GLOSS:"Eminent" [Zuo],
GLOSS:"high" [Guoce].
	[E] AA: Khmer ruŋ ``be big, tall, mighty, pre-eminent'' ⪤ sruŋ ``be long enough to cover'' [Jenner / Pou 1982: xli] ⪤ /sroŋ/ ``big, full''.
	[E] MK *jruuŋ, *jruŋ ``high, long'' (Shorto 2006 #690): Khmer /croŋ/ ``to raise up, re-establish …'' ⪤ crūṅa /cròoŋ/ ``be upright''; Riang tsərɔŋ, Khasi jrōŋ ``high''. AA ⇒ Lepcha kroŋ ``high'' (Forrest JAOS 82, 1962: 334).
	An AA substrate wf would explain the odd initial interchange *r- ~ *dzr- which is unusual in a Chinese wf.
	A syn. or parallel stem with initial OC *l is {sōng₂ 崧嵩} ``high'' (mountain).
	The meaning chóng ``high'' (of a mountain) may be due to paronomastic attraction from sōng, or from MK: Khmer cuṅa /coŋ/, OKhmer cuṅ /cuŋ/ ``farthest point, end, tip, top, peak …''; perhaps Lushai čuŋᴿ (Lorrain chung) ``roof, top, summit, high up'' is related (Khmer loan?)
::OKhmer	cuṅ /cuŋ/	``farthest point, end, tip, top, peak …''
>:AA:
>:Khmer ruŋ ``be big, tall, mighty, pre-eminent'' ⪤ sruŋ ``be long enough to cover''  ⪤ /sroŋ/ ``big, full''
>:MK *jruuŋ, *jruŋ ``high, long'' :
>:Khmer /croŋ/ ``to raise up, re-establish …'' ⪤ crūṅa /cròoŋ/ ``be upright''
>:Riang tsərɔŋ
>:Khasi jrōŋ ``high''. AA ⇒ Lepcha kroŋ ``high''

ENTRY:2328
HEAD:lóng₃ 龍

LH:Later Han: lioŋ

OCB:Baxter Old Chinese: *C-rjoŋ
GLOSS:"Dragon" [OB, Shi] (discussed by Carr LTBA 13.2, 1990: 101 etc.).

	Most likely is a connection with SE Asian words: AA: Viet. rôǹg ``dragon'', Muong hông ~ ròṅ, Khmer roŋ ~ rôŋ, and KT: Siam. maḥroŋ ~ măroŋ. (CH ⇒ ?) Viet thuồng (via s- from Cr-) (Maspero 1912: 84).

ENTRY:2335

GLOSS:"small mound" east of the Passes (i.e. central China) [FY 13, 154].
GLOSS-NOTE:Lóu is usually the 2nd syllable of a compound, see under {fù₇ 阜}.

ENTRY:2336
HEAD:lóu₂ 僂
MC:Middle Chinese: ləu,ljuᴮ 
LH:Later Han: lo,lioᴮ

	[T] ONW lou
GLOSS:"Bend" [Xun],
GLOSS:"hunchbacked" [Zuo].

	Alternatively, lóu could belong to {zhǒu₁ 肘} ``elbow'', or even be the s. w. as {lóu₁,lǒu 婁塿} ``mound''.

ENTRY:2340
HEAD:lòu₁ 漏 ⪤ lù 漉䍡
MC:Middle Chinese: luk 
LH:Later Han: lok 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *rôk
GLOSS:"To strain, drip" [Guoce],

	However, Lepcha may again be one of many AA loans, and WT may not be related. ``Net'' may perhaps be a different word related to Mru lok ``net'' (Löffler 1966: 142), but the initial consonants do not agree.

ENTRY:2345
HEAD:lú₃ 蘆
MC:Middle Chinese: ljwo 
LH:Later Han: liɑ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *ra
GLOSS:"Madder plant", in Shījīng rú-lú 茹蘆 (nźjwo-ljwo).
	Because of the compound pú-lú 蒲蘆 (buo-ljwo; {pú₄ 蒲}) it has been suggested that the OC form had a pre-initial labial whose loss may account for the initial s- in Northern Mǐn forms (Mei / Norman 1971: 98).

ENTRY:2346
HEAD:lú₄ 顱
MC:Middle Chinese: luo 
LH:Later Han: lɑ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *râ
GLOSS:"Head", a late word [Xin Tangshu], can be compared to Tai: S. pʰaak < *pʰr/l-
GLOSS:"forehead"; see also {dú₈-lóu 髑髏}.

ENTRY:2349
HEAD:lǔ₁ 鹵
MC:Middle Chinese: luoᴮ 
LH:Later Han: lɑᴮ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *rāʔ
GLOSS:"Salty, rock salt" [BI, Zuo].
GLOSS-NOTE:Li F. (1976: 45) draws attention to a possible connection with {gǔ₁₅ 盬}
GLOSS:"salt".
	[E] ST: PTB *s-la ``salt'' > Miri əlo, PKaren *hla. Acc. to Matisoff (1995: 52), Baxter suggests a connection with the place name Lǔ 魯 which was a salt-marsh region in ancient times.
	The meaning ``rustic, coarse'' [Zhuang] is sometimes thought to be connected with ``salt'', but HST: 55 separates the two and relates ``coarse'' to WT rags-pa ``coarse, thick, gross''.
::WT	rags-pa	``coarse, thick, gross''
>:PTB *s-la ``salt'' >
>:Miri əlo
>:PKaren *hla. Acc. to Matisoff
>:Baxter suggests a connection with the place name Lǔ 魯 which was a salt-marsh region in ancient times

ENTRY:2352
HEAD:lù₁ 彔
MC:Middle Chinese: luk 
LH:Later Han: lok 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *rôk 
OCB:Baxter Old Chinese: *C-rok
GLOSS:"Carve wood" [SW] (Li 1977: 62, 125, 277; Baxter 1992: 504f; 543).
	[E] ST: WT ’bru-ba, brus, and ’brud-pa ``to dig, chisel, carve, cut''; Nung ə-ru ``carve, write'' (Benedict HJAS 4, 1939: 220); perhaps also JP krok⁵⁵ ``to carve'' (wood) (for the CH final -k, see {§6.1}). Unger points to the morphological parallelism with WT:
	鏤 OCM *rô  <>  WT  ’bru < ɴ-bru
	鏤 OCM *rôh < *rôs  <>  WT  brus
	This wf is considered to be related to {bāo₃ 剝} ``peel'', but ``carve'' and ``peel'' are rather different activities.
::JP	krok⁵⁵	``to carve''
>:WT ’bru-ba, brus, and ’brud-pa ``to dig, chisel, carve, cut''
>:Nung ə-ru ``carve, write''
>:perhaps also JP krok⁵⁵ ``to carve''  . Unger points to the morphological parallelism with WT:
>:

	[T] ONW lo
	[D] W-Wēnzhōu løy²¹
	[D] M-Yǒng’ān tiɯᶜ¹, Jiànyáng tiɔᶜ², Fúzhōu tuoᶜ²
	[E] Unless it is related to {gé₄ 格} ``go, come'' (Baxter 1992: 329), it has no obvious ST etymology. It may be an AA word instead: PVM *k-raːʔ ``way, path'', PWa *kraʔ ``road'', Pearic kʰraː ``road, path'', and Yao kla³.

	[T] ONW lo

ENTRY:2361
HEAD:lù₈ 露
MC:Middle Chinese: luoᶜ 
LH:Later Han: lɑᶜ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *râkh 
OCB:Baxter Old Chinese: *g-raks
GLOSS:"Dew, to condense into droplets" (clouds) [Shi].
	An OC pre-initial may explain the initial s- in some Northern Mǐn dialects, thus PMin *ḷoᶜ > Jiàn’ōu su⁴⁴ (Mei / Norman 1971: 98).
	In a few dialects it means ``fog'': W-Sūzhōu mi²⁴/²²- ləu²¹/⁴⁴.
	[E] Derived from {luò₇ 落} ``to fall, drop'', the Khmer stem also has the semantic extension ``cover from above, drip''. An allofam is {xǔ₁ 湑} ``to drip''.
>:Derived from {luò₇ 落} ``to fall, drop'', the Khmer stem also has the semantic extension ``cover from above, drip''. An allofam is {xǔ₁ 湑} ``to drip''

ENTRY:2374
HEAD:lǚ₂ 驢
MC:Middle Chinese: ljwo 
LH:Later Han: liɑ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *ra
GLOSS:"Donkey" [SW].
	[T] Sin Sukchu SR ly (平)
	[T] MGZY lÿu (平) [ly]
	[N] Unger (Hao-ku 13, 1989) points out that the donkey must have been known in China before its first mention during the Han dynasty because ``mule'' luó 騾 (luâ) (Sin Sukchu SR lɔ (平); MGZY lwo (平) [lwɔ]) occurs already in Lshì chūnqiū. Related are WB laᴮ ``mule'', Tiddim laːᶠ < laːh ``mule'', but MC l- usually corresponds to PTB *r.
	Perh. the TB items are Han period or later loans.
::Tiddim	laːᶠ < laːh	``mule''

ENTRY:2375
HEAD:lǚ₁ 旅呂
MC:Middle Chinese: ljwoᴮ 
LH:Later Han: liɑᴮ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *raʔ
	Anything lined up in a regular fashion: ``one after the other'' [Li], ``line up in a row > set forth; troop, multitude'' [OB, Shi]; ``spine'' [Shi, Zhuang], ``pitch-pipe'' 呂 [Li] > (``spine of a roof'' >) ``beam supporting rafter of a roof'' 梠 [SW].
	[T] Sin Sukchu SR ly (上)
	[T] MGZY lÿu (上) [ly]
	[T] ONW lio
	Perh. ⪤ lú  臚 (ljwo)  LH  liɑ, OCM  *ra
GLOSS:"To display, expose, arrange" [Guoyu].
	[E] ST: WT gra-ma ``the awn, bristles or ears of cereals; bones or skeleton of a fish, lattice, trellis, frame'' (Bodman 1980: 165; HST: 138); Matisoff (1999: 6) adds JP n³¹-rut⁵⁵ n³¹-ra³³ ``skeleton bones'' (n³¹-rut⁵⁵ ``bones''), Tangkhul a-ra, Nocte a-ra. Perh. also WT gras ``class, order, rank, tribe'' (Bodman 1980: 132) which is plausible in light of WT rus ``bone'' ~ ``clan''.
	Unger (Hao-ku 39, 1992) connects the WT word with {liè₁ 列} (ljät) ``series''.
::WT	rus	``bone''
>:WT gra-ma ``the awn, bristles or ears of cereals; bones or skeleton of a fish, lattice, trellis, frame''

ENTRY:2377
HEAD:lǚ₃ 旅

GLOSS-NOTE:This word has several possible etymologies: (1) cognate to {lǚ₂ 旅}
GLOSS:"guest, traveller". (2) An endoactive derivation ({§4.5}) of {lú₂ 廬}
GLOSS:"hut". (3) It could possibly belong to the ST stem *s-jak ~ *r-jak ``24 hr. day, spend the night'', see {xī₁ 夕} for suggestive Lushai cognates.

ENTRY:2379
HEAD:lǜ₁ 律
MC:Middle Chinese: ljuet 
LH:Later Han: lut (luit) 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *rut
	(``To follow'':) ``to follow a model'' [Li], ``law, rule'' [Yi], ``row'' [Shi] > ``to comb'' [Xun] (Karlgren GSR 502c).
	[T] Sin Sukchu SR ly (入)
	[T] MGZY lÿu (入) [ly]
	[T] ONW luit
	[E] Baxter (1992: 280 and 842 n. 196) derives ``rule'' from the same root as {bǐ₆ 筆} ``brush, writing pencil'', both deriving from the notion ``draw a line, ruler''; but see bǐ  for an alternative etymology.
	[E] ST: KN-Lushai hruaiᴴ < hruai ``to lead, guide, conduct'', Lai hruaj / hruaʔj ``to lead'', NNaga *ruaːy. Although this KN etymon looks suggestively similar to CH, the KN final -uaj is rather different from the OC final, perhaps in OC some vocalic levelling had taken place after the addition of the final -t.
	For additional possible cognates, see {suì₂ 遂}.
::Lai	hruaj / hruaʔj	``to lead''
>:Baxter  derives ``rule'' from the same root as {bǐ₆ 筆} ``brush, writing pencil'', both deriving from the notion ``draw a line, ruler''
>:but see bǐ  for an alternative etymology
>:KN-Lushai hruaiᴴ < hruai ``to lead, guide, conduct''
>:Lai hruaj / hruaʔj ``to lead''
>:NNaga *ruaːy. Although this KN etymon looks suggestively similar to CH, the KN final -uaj is rather different from the OC final, perhaps in OC some vocalic levelling had taken place after the addition of the final -t

ENTRY:2383

ENTRY:2384
HEAD:lǜ₄-liáo 膟膋
MC:Middle Chinese: ljuet- 
LH:Later Han: l(i)ut (luit) 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *rut
	[T]  ONW luit-
	The commentaries on the relevant passages in Lǐjì are ambiguous.
	One says ``blood and fat round intestines'', another simply ``fat r. i.'' A parallel passage in Shi 210,5 has 血膋 ``blood and fat r. i.''; therefore the commentary to Li may have omitted or lost the reference to ``blood'', consequently it appears that l means ``blood'' (Unger Hao-ku 39, 1992).
	If this is the case, l would be a loan from PTai *lɨetᴰ²ᴸ ``blood'' (rather than PKS *pʰlaːt⁷, Kadai *platᴰ).
	If, on the other hand, lǜ should be a homonym of liáo ``intestines'', either or both could be connected with Viet-Muong: Viet. ruột, Muong rɔc ``intestines'' [Pulleyblank JCL 22.1, 1994: 82].
::Muong	rɔc	``intestines''

ENTRY:2385
HEAD:lǜ₅ 繂率
MC:Middle Chinese: ljuet 
LH:Later Han: l(i)ut (luit) 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *rut (or *riut ?)
GLOSS:"Rope" made of hemp or bamboo 繂 [SW],
GLOSS:"leather band" 率 [Zuo].
	[E] ST: WT rgyud < r-yut ``string, cord'' (of bow, musical instrument), ``connection'' ⪤ rgyud-pa ``to fasten, file'' (on string) (Unger Hao-ku 39, 1992); if WB kruiᴮ ``thread, string, chain'' should be related, the etymon needs to be analyzed differently. This is apparently a variant of {yù₂₆ 繘}, both from PCH **rjut ~ **r-jut ({§9.2.1}).
::WB	kruiᴮ	``thread, string, chain''
>:WT rgyud < r-yut ``string, cord'' , ``connection'' ⪤ rgyud-pa ``to fasten, file''
>:if WB kruiᴮ ``thread, string, chain'' should be related, the etymon needs to be analyzed differently. This is apparently a variant of {yù₂₆ 繘}, both from PCH **rjut ~ **r-jut

ENTRY:2391
HEAD:luàn 亂
MC:Middle Chinese: luânᶜ 
LH:Later Han: luɑnᶜ ~ lonᶜ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *rôns 
OCB:Baxter Old Chinese: *C-rons
GLOSS:"To rebel, disorder" [Shi].
	[T] Sin Sukchu SR lwɔn (去)
	[T] MGZY lon (去) [lɔn]
	[T] ONW luɑn
	[E] Area word of AA origin: Khmer prwla /prùuəl/  ``be agitated, disturbed, in uproar'' < rwla /rúuəl/ ``to boil quickly, cook, grill''; also Khmer /kaṃraaəl/  ``to run amok, get excited, agitated'' < /róol/  ``to burn, blaze, roar''.
	AA ⇒ WB broŋᴮ ~ byoŋᴮ ~ prunᴮ ~ runᴮ ``tumultuous''; WT kʰral-kʰrul ``confusion, disorder'' (the stem is krul).
	CH ⇒ Middle Vietnamese tlọn > trộn (Maspero 1912: 78).
	Old Sino-Viet ron (Pān Wùyún 1987: 28).
	Baxter (1992: 365) thinks it likely that this word is cognate to {biàn₄ 變} *prjons ``change''.
::WT	kʰral-kʰrul	``confusion, disorder''
>:Area word of AA origin:
>:Khmer prwla /prùuəl/  ``be agitated, disturbed, in uproar'' < rwla /rúuəl/ ``to boil quickly, cook, grill''
>:also Khmer /kaṃraaəl/  ``to run amok, get excited, agitated'' < /róol/  ``to burn, blaze, roar''

ENTRY:2398
HEAD:lún₂ 輪
MC:Middle Chinese: ljuen

OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *run

GLOSS:"Wheel" [Shi].
GLOSS-NOTE:Acc. to Robert Bauer (Sino-Platonic Papers 47, 1994) perhaps a PIE loan whose source may ultimately be the same etymon as the one for {chē 車}.

ENTRY:2401
HEAD:luō 捋
MC:Middle Chinese: luât 
LH:Later Han: luɑt ~ lot 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *rôt
GLOSS:"Gather, pluck" [Shi];
GLOSS:"to pull (up sleeves), to scrape off (sweat), milk (cows)".
	[E] <> PTai ruutᴰ² ``to scrape off (mud from limbs), strip off (grains from stalk)'' (Manomaivibool 1975: 139). There are two possible TB cognates: Lushai loᴿ / lɔʔᴸ (< *lɔs) ``to pluck, pick'', but the initial consonants do not agree.
	Or WT ’drud-pa ``to rub, file, rub off, grind''.
	[C] Allofam is perhaps {guā₃ 刮} ``scrape off''. Perhaps also related to {duó₄ 掇} (tuât, ṭjwat) ``pick, gather''.
::WT	’drud-pa	``to rub, file, rub off, grind''
>:PTai ruutᴰ² ``to scrape off , strip off '' . There are two possible TB cognates:
>:Lushai loᴿ / lɔʔᴸ  ``to pluck, pick'', but the initial consonants do not agree

ENTRY:2415
HEAD:luò₇ 落
MC:Middle Chinese: lâk 
LH:Later Han: lɑk 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *râk 
OCB:Baxter Old Chinese: *g-rāk
GLOSS:"To fall, drop, die" [Shi].
	[T] Sin Sukchu 洛 SR law (入), LR lawʔ
	[T] MGZY 洛 law (入) [law]
	[T] ONW lɑk
	[D] PMin *ḷək ``to fall''
	[E] ST: PTB *kla (STC 123): Lushai tlaᴸ / tlaakᶠ ``to fall from, go down'' ⪤ tʰlaakᶠ ``throw off, drop''; WB kyaᶜ ``to fall, become low'' ⪤ kʰyaᶜ ``to throw down'', Mikir kló < kla ``fall down'', JP kʰrat³¹ ``to fall'', also mə³¹-loʔ⁵⁵ ``to fall off'' ⪤ lok⁵⁵ describes ``falling off'' (Matisoff 1995a: 46f; Bodman 1980: 145). OC has *r instead of the expected *l (TB) in the initial probably due to pronomastic attraction to AA: Khmer gra’ka /kruk/ (vowel /u/ instead of /a/ because of the voiced initial) ``be low, debased'' < -ra’ka /-ruk/ ``to fall, be low, cover from above''.
	Allofams with OC *r-: {xià₁ 下} ``descend'', {lù₈ 露} ``dew''; allofam with ST L-like initial: {tuò₄ 蘀} *lhâk ``fallen leaves''.
::JP	kʰrat³¹	``to fall''
>:PTB *kla :
>:Lushai tlaᴸ / tlaakᶠ ``to fall from, go down'' ⪤ tʰlaakᶠ ``throw off, drop''
>:WB kyaᶜ ``to fall, become low'' ⪤ kʰyaᶜ ``to throw down''
>:Mikir kló < kla ``fall down''
>:JP kʰrat³¹ ``to fall'', also mə³¹-loʔ⁵⁵ ``to fall off'' ⪤ lok⁵⁵ describes ``falling off'' . OC has *r instead of the expected *l  in the initial probably due to pronomastic attraction to AA:
>:Khmer gra’ka /kruk/  ``be low, debased'' < -ra’ka /-ruk/ ``to fall, be low, cover from above''

ENTRY:2417
HEAD:luò₉ 駱
	{luò₈} 雒

ENTRY:2418
HEAD:mā₁ 媽
	Mand. ``mother'', also in other dialects, e.g.
	G-Wǔníng mɑᴬ¹, but this particular dialect also has a form mɑʔᴰ¹ ``mother'' which is parallel to pɑʔᴰ¹ 伯 ``father'' (Sagart 1993: 171).
	In some southern dialects, this etymon also means ``female'' (of animals): e.g.
	M-Jiàn’ōu kai⁵⁴-ma²² 雞嫲 ``hen''.

ENTRY:2419
HEAD:ma₂ 嗎
	Interrogative final particle in modern dialects, probably the same etymon as {wú₄ 無} *ma ``not'' with parallels in other languages, including TB, as in Lhasa ma, Hakha Lai (KC) -maa or -moo.

GLOSS:"sesame".

	[T] ONW mä
	[D] PMin *maiᴬ²: Xiàmén muãᴬ², Jiànyáng moiᴬ², Jiàn’ōu mũɛᶜ¹, Fúzhōu muaiᴬ²
	[E] Etymology not clear, however PKS *ʔŋra¹ ``sesame'' looks remotely similar to OC.
::PKS	*ʔŋra¹	``sesame''
>:Etymology not clear, however PKS *ʔŋra¹ ``sesame'' looks remotely similar to OC

ENTRY:2421
HEAD:mǎ₁ 馬
MC:Middle Chinese: maᴮ 
LH:Later Han: maᴮ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *mrâʔ
GLOSS:"Horse" [OB].
	[T] Sin Sukchu SR ma (上)
	[T] ONW mä
	[E] ST: PTB *mraŋ  (STC no. 145): > OTib. rmaŋ, Kan. *s-raŋ, WB mraŋᴮ, JP gum³¹-ra³¹ ~ -raŋ; JR (m)bro < mraŋ. For the OC ~ TB difference in finals, see {§3.2.4}.
	STC (p. 43 n. 139) relates PTB *mraŋ to a PTB root *raŋ ``high'' ({líng₆ 陵}).
	Horse and chariot were introduced into Shang period China around 1200 BC from the west (Shaughnessy HJAS 48, 1988: 189-237).
	Therefore this word is prob. a loan from a Central Asian language, note Mongolian morin ``horse''.
	Either the animal has been known to the ST people long before its domesticated version was introduced; or OC and TB languages borrowed the word from the same Central Asian source.
	Middle Korean mol also goes also back to the Central Asian word, as does Japanese uma, unless it is a loan from CH (Miyake 1997: 195).
	Tai maaᶜ²  and similar SEAsian forms are CH loans.
::Mongolian	morin	``horse''
>:PTB *mraŋ  :
>:> OTib. rmaŋ
>:Kan. *s-raŋ
>:WB mraŋᴮ
>:JP gum³¹-ra³¹ ~ -raŋ
>:JR bro < mraŋ

ENTRY:2427
HEAD:mǎi 買 ⪤ mài 賣
MC:Middle Chinese: maɨᶜ 
LH:Later Han: mɛᶜ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *mrêh
GLOSS:"To sell" [Zhouli].
GLOSS-NOTE:The graph was originally distinct from {yù₂₃ 賣}, see SW 2679.
	[<] exoactive of mǎi 買 (maɨᴮ) ({§4.3.1}).
	[E] ST: PTB *b-rey (STC no. 293  n. 207) > WT rǰe-ba < ɴ-rje ?) ``to barter'', JP ma³¹-ri³³ ``to buy'', Garo bre, Dimasa barai. As to foreign initial b- for CH m-, see {§5.12.2}.
	Alternative suggestions: Haudricourt a.
	Strecker (TP 77, 1991: 340) propose that mǎi and mài are loans from MY maiᴮ and maiᶜ, derived from a MY word ``to have''.
	Acc. to Benedict, this is a common area word, perhaps of Austro-Tai origin (Benedict, AT *(m)baḷi).
	This set is more recent than {shē₁ 賒} ``trade, sell'' which is parallel to PTB *leyʔ.
	Syn. {dí₆ 糴}; {gǔ₁₁ 賈}; {shòu₂ 售}; {yù₂₃ 賣}.
::JP	ma³¹-ri³³	``to buy''
>:PTB *b-rey  >
>:WT rǰe-ba < ɴ-rje ?) ``to barter''
>:JP ma³¹-ri³³ ``to buy''
>:Garo bre
>:Dimasa barai. As to foreign initial b- for CH m-, see {§5.12.2}

ENTRY:2428
HEAD:mài₁ 脈
MC:Middle Chinese: mɛk 
LH:Later Han: mɛk 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *mrêk
	[D] PMin *ṁak ~ *mek
GLOSS:"Vein" [Zuo].
	[E] ST: Lushai marᴴ < mar ``the pulse''. As often, CH has added a final -k ({§6.1}): The OC form is derived from *mer-k or perhaps rather *mər-k, since OC *ə would agree with PTB *a (MC -ɛk can derive from both OC *-rək and *-rek); mài does not occur in early rimes which would decide the issue.
>:Lushai marᴴ < mar ``the pulse''. As often
>:CH has added a final -k :
>:The OC form is derived from *mer-k or perhaps rather *mər-k, since OC *ə would agree with PTB *a
>:mài does not occur in early rimes which would decide the issue

ENTRY:2431
HEAD:mài₄ 麥
MC:Middle Chinese: mɛk 
LH:Later Han: mɛk 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *mrə̂k 
OCB:Baxter Old Chinese: *mrək
GLOSS:"Wheat" [Shi] is often considered to be related to lái 來 below (so Wáng Lì 1982: 92; Baxter 1992: 328).
	[D] PMin *mak > Amoy beʔᴰ², Fúzhōu maʔᴰ²
	[E] Acc. to Pulleyblank (EC 25, 2000: 23), 來 is the original graph for mài, while 麥 (with the element ``foot'') was originally intended for the much more common lái ``come'', hence lái ``wheat'' is spurious. However, TB cognates PLB *g-ra² ``buckwheat'' [Matisoff D. Lahu: 1116], WT gro ``wheat'' are phonologically closer to lái.
::WT	gro	``wheat''
>:Acc. to Pulleyblank , 來 is the original graph for mài, while 麥  was originally intended for the much more common lái ``come'', hence lái ``wheat'' is spurious. However
>:TB cognates PLB *g-ra² ``buckwheat''
>:WT gro ``wheat'' are phonologically closer to lái

ENTRY:2447

	[E] ? ST. Bodman (1980: 170) compares this word to WT mdoŋs ``white spot on horse's forehead, eye in peacock's feather'', but WT is prob. related to WB uᶜ-doŋᴮ ``peacock'' (STC no. 341). More likely, the OC form could instead be related to WB kroŋ ``be of various colors, as a tiger''.

ENTRY:2453
HEAD:mào₁ 冃帽
MC:Middle Chinese: mâuᶜ 
LH:Later Han: mouᶜ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *mûh
	[T] ONW mɑu
GLOSS:"Head scarf, head cover" of the southern Màn-Yí people 冃 [SW], 帽 [Shiming];
GLOSS:"scepter cover" 瑁 [Zhouli];
GLOSS:"hat" 冒 [Hanshu].
	[E] This is a late word. The SW allusion to a southern origin suggests that this is the same etymon as the MK {móu₅ 鍪} ``helmet''; on the other hand, mào cannot be separated from the homophone ST {mào₂ 冒} ``to cover''.
	Foreign ``hat'' has prob. been reinterpreted as {mào₂ 冒} ``cover'' because of parallelism with the syn. {bèi₆ 被} ``cover > headdress''.
>:This is a late word. The SW allusion to a southern origin suggests that this is the same etymon as the MK {móu₅ 鍪} ``helmet''
>:on the other hand, mào cannot be separated from the homophone ST {mào₂ 冒} ``to cover''

ENTRY:2454
HEAD:mào₂ 冒
MC:Middle Chinese: mâuᶜ 
LH:Later Han: mouᶜ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *mûh 
OCB:Baxter Old Chinese: *muks
	[T] ONW mɑu
GLOSS:"To cover" (without contact, spread overhead, as sky covers the earth, a king's efforts extend over the world) [Shi]; later >
GLOSS:"to cover" (e.g. a corpse with cloth) [Li], (body with skin) [Hanshu];
GLOSS:"hat" [Hanshu], but see {mào₁ 冃帽}; (``cover the eyes'') > ``reckless'' [Zuo], ``be jealous'' 媢 [Li].
GLOSS-NOTE:In Lshì chūnqiū the word rimes apparently with dǎo 倒 *dauʔ/h (no final *-k, vowels differ), GY has an alternate reading for 媢 in tone B (< *-ʔ), hence no OC final -k.
	[E] ST: WB muiᴮ ``cover without contact, spread overhead, be chief'' ⪤ ə-muiᴮ ``roof, a chief'' (WB also hmû ``be chief'' ⪤ ə-hmû ``chief''). To this root belongs also the common TB word for ``sky'': WB muiᴮ (written miughᴮ) ``sky, rain'', OTib. mu ``sky'' (HST), WT dmu, rmu, smu ``sky'' (Hoffmann 1979: 96); TGTM ¹hmu, Nung mu; JP lə³¹-mu³¹ ``sky'' ⪤? mu⁵⁵ ``lightning''.
	The syn. word for ``sky, {tiān₁ 天}, belongs to a root ‘above''.
::WT	dmu, rmu, smu	``sky''

ENTRY:2463
HEAD:méi₁ 沒
MC:Middle Chinese: muət
GLOSS:"Not have, there is no, not yet" Mand.; MC muət  may be a col. variant of wú 勿 or wèi 未, which later fused with, or was influenced by, {yǒu₂ 有} (Norman 1988: 126).
	This late word is not derived from {mò₄ 沒} ``dive''.

ENTRY:2464

GLOSS:"chip, counter" > classifier for every category of noun in the Nánběicháo period, now obsolete (Lü Shūxiāng; Norman 1988: 115).
	[E] MK: OKhmer mēk [mɛɛk] ``branch, bow, limb, twig'' > ``numeral classifier for elephant tusks'' (Jenner / Pou 1982: 215). After a foreign long vowel OC often drops the coda, see {§6.9}.

ENTRY:2465
HEAD:méi₃ 眉湄楣
MC:Middle Chinese: mji 3 
LH:Later Han: mɨ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *mrəi 
OCB:Baxter Old Chinese: *mrjəj
GLOSS:"Edge, bank, coast, from the moment of" 湄 [BI, Shi] >
GLOSS:"eyebrow" 眉 (``edge / border of the eye'' [Shi] (so Karlgren 1956: 5; Wáng Lì 1982: 428),
GLOSS:"lintel of door or window" 楣 [Yili].
GLOSS-NOTE:For a semantic parallel
GLOSS:"edge" >
GLOSS:"rim" (of eye), see {yá₃,ái 崖涯睚}.
	[E] Etymology not clear. Méi ``eyebrow'' is prob. not related to PTB *(s-)mil ~ *(s-)mul ``body hair'' because it is the s. w. as ``edge, rim''  – unless the semantic development should have been ``eyebrow'' > ``edge, bank'' (unlikely).
	TB has somewhat similar comparanda: WT mu ``border, boundary, limit, edge''; or Lushai hmɔɔrᴴ ``border, edge, point, end'' (but see {mò₁ 末}).
	For more words with initial *m- and the notion ``edge, lip'' etc, see {wěn₁ 吻}.
::Lushai	hmɔɔrᴴ	``border, edge, point, end''
>:Etymology not clear. Méi ``eyebrow'' is prob. not related to PTB *mil ~ *mul ``body hair'' because it is the s. w. as ``edge, rim''  – unless the semantic development should have been ``eyebrow'' > ``edge, bank''

ENTRY:2466
HEAD:méi₄ 梅
MC:Middle Chinese: muậi 
LH:Later Han: mə 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *mə̂ and *mə̂ʔ (Mattos 1971: 309)
GLOSS:"Japanese apricot" (Prunus mume),
GLOSS:"plum", Mand. méizǐ 梅子, seems to be related to Old Japanese ume²
GLOSS:"plum" (Shibatani 1990: 120; Miyake 1997: 188).
	There are other tree names which have a possible Japanese connection: {sōng₁ 松} ``pine''; {nài₁ 奈柰} ``some kind of pear'' and {zhè₁ 柘} ``some kind of mulberry tree''.
	The source of these words is unknown.

ENTRY:2468
HEAD:méi₆ 媒禖
MC:Middle Chinese: muậi 
LH:Later Han: mə 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *mə̂
	[D] PMin *moi
GLOSS:"Marriage go-between, match-maker" [Shi],
GLOSS:"god of fecundity" 禖 [Li].
GLOSS-NOTE:A semantic extension is perhaps {méi₈ 腜}
GLOSS:"prolific".
	[E] MK: Khmer dhmāya [tmíiəj] ``agent, representative'' > ``marriage go-between'', derived from [*-dəj] ``bear, support'' ({dài₉ 戴}) with the infix -m- which forms agental derivatives (Jenner / Pou 1982: xlvi f). The AA infix was treated like the word initial in OC ({§2.6}).
>:Khmer dhmāya  ``agent, representative'' > ``marriage go-between'', derived from  ``bear, support''  with the infix -m- which forms agental derivatives . The AA infix was treated like the word initial in OC

ENTRY:2469
HEAD:méi₆ 媒禖 ⪤ gāo-méi 高禖
	[kɑu-mə] *kau-mə̂ [Lüshi] ji–āo-méi 郊禖 [kau-mə]
	A fecundity rite which was performed at an altar outside of town jiao 郊 where sexual intercourse ({jiāo₁ 交}) was involved (Jensen EC 20, 1995: 420ƒƒ).
	While gāo merely transcribed a pre-initial, jiāo reflects re-etymologization.
	[E] AA: Khmer ghmāya [kmíiəj] ``marriage broker'', by alteration of the (root-) initial from [tmíiəj] above (Jenner / Pou 1982: 138). This etymon belongs to an AA wf which includes {pēi₁ 胚} ``pregnant'', {dài₉ 戴} ``to bear''.
>:AA:
>:Khmer ghmāya  ``marriage broker'', by alteration of the  initial from  above . This etymon belongs to an AA wf which includes {pēi₁ 胚} ``pregnant'', {dài₉ 戴} ``to bear''

	{méi₆} 媒禖

ENTRY:2472

LH:Later Han: mə

GLOSS:"Soot" [Lü].

GLOSS:2:Lushai maŋᴿ / manᴸ < maŋʔ / maŋs
GLOSS:"be sooty, grimy" ⪤ maŋᴴ < maŋ
GLOSS:"partially burnt wood"; rather than being a CH loan, WB hmaŋ ``ink'' appears to be a loan trans- lation of mò 墨 ``ink'' (made of soot) (under {hēi 黑} ``black'').
	[C] Possible derivations are {huī₁ 灰} ``ashes'', {wén₁ 文} ``black marks'', {hēi 黑} ``black'' (Wáng Lì 1982: 409). Wáng Lì adds méi 黴 (mji 3) ``moldy, grimy'' which appears in SW and Chǔcí as the first syllable of binomes (黴黧, 黴黑).
	Unrelated to {huì₇ 晦} ``dark''.
::WB	hmaŋ	``ink''
>:ST, but etymology not certain.  Lahu mū <

ENTRY:2474
HEAD:měi₂ 每
MC:Middle Chinese: mwậiᴮ 
LH:Later Han: məᴮ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *mə̂ʔ (dialectal *moʔ ?)
GLOSS:"Each, every" [Shi].
	[T] Sin Sukchu SR muj (上), PR, LR məj
	[T] MGZY mue (上) [muɛ]
	[T] ONW mɑi
	[E] This may possibly be the AA word for ``one'': MK *muəy (Shorto 1976: 1054) > Khmuʔ mooy, OKhmer moy /mooj/ (⇒ Tai mui), combination form mɔ; PMon muə̯ ``one'' [Diffloth 1984: 141], OMon moy; OKhmer and OMon mimoy /məmooj/ ``each'' < /mooj/ ``one'' (Jenner / Pou 1982: 522). For the absence of final -j in CH after a foreign long vowel (note Khmer), see {§6.9}.
	We should expect OC *o instead of *ə which is implied by the phonetic {mǔ₂ 母} *moʔ; OC Shījīng dialectal merger of *Po with *Pə (Baxter 1992: 466) would explain the later vowel.
	Chinese and Khmer associate the notion ``each, every'' with ``single, one'', note CH zhī zhī yǒu wěi 隻隻有尾 ``each one has a tail'' (zhī 隻 ``single, one'') (Giles p. 233 no. 1869); Mand. yī gè yī gède 一個一個的 ``one by one, each''.
::OMon	mimoy /məmooj/	``each''
>:This may possibly be the AA word for ``one'':
>:MK *muəy  >
>:Khmuʔ mooy
>:OKhmer moy /mooj/ , combination form mɔ
>:PMon muə̯ ``one''
>:OMon moy
>:OKhmer and OMon mimoy /məmooj/ ``each'' < /mooj/ ``one''

	[D] PMin *ṁyaiᶜ (or *ṁueᶜ)

	[T] Sin Sukchu SR muj (去), PR, LR məj

	[E] ? ST: WB maᶜ ``sister''; alternatively note Kuki hmei ``woman'', Lushai hmeiᴸ < hmeih ``concubine'', Miju ku-mai-, WT bud-med ``woman''. For b- vs. m-, see {§5.12.2}.

>:alternatively note Kuki hmei ``woman''
>:Lushai hmeiᴸ < hmeih ``concubine''
>:Miju ku-mai-
>:WT bud-med ``woman''. For b- vs. m-, see {§5.12.2}

ENTRY:2495
HEAD:méng₂ 氓
MC:Middle Chinese: mɛŋ 
LH:Later Han: mɛŋ 
OC:Old Chinese: *mrə̂ŋ or *mrâŋ
GLOSS:"Population, people" 氓 [Shi], 甿 [Zhouli],
GLOSS:"subjects" [Meng] (commentators have suggested that méng refers to
GLOSS:"settlers from the outside", but that cannot be the meaning in Meng 5B, 6) > Mand. méng ``the common people'', but liúmáng (!) 流氓 ``hooligan'' is perhaps a different etymon. QYS mɛŋ normally goes back to OC *mrəŋ (so Li F.) or *mreŋ; the phonetic as well as the graph substitution mèng 孟 (mɐŋᶜ) *mraŋh (Karlgren Gl. 176) favor OC *mraŋ.
	This word is not related to {mín₁ 民} ``people'' as is sometimes suggested (e.g.
	Wáng Lì 1982: 372).
	[E] ST: WT dmaŋs ``common people, crowd'' ⪤ ’baŋs ``subjects'' (Benedict 1976: 173; HST: 116).
>:WT dmaŋs ``common people, crowd'' ⪤ ’baŋs ``subjects''

ENTRY:2498
HEAD:méng₅ 夢矇

LH:Later Han: moŋ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *môŋ
GLOSS:"Blind" 矇 [Shi] >
GLOSS:"be blind to, unenlightened" 夢 [Shi] >

	It is not clear if and how the wf {máng₃ 芒茫} may be related.

ENTRY:2501
HEAD:méng₇ 濛
MC:Middle Chinese: muŋ 
LH:Later Han: moŋ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *môŋ
GLOSS:"Darkening" (e.g. sky by rain) [Shi].
GLOSS-NOTE:TB cognates suggest that this is not derived from the same ST etymon as {méng₅ 夢矇}
GLOSS:"blind".
	[E] ST: PTB *muːŋ (STC no. 362) > WB hmuiŋ ``dull, downcast'' ⪤ hmuiŋᴮ ``very dark''; JP muŋ³³ ``overcast''. Alternative: WT rmoŋ-ba ``be obscured'', WB hmoŋ ``very dark, darkness''.
	Many words could be combined into a large wf ``cover, dark, blind'': {méng₆ 蒙}, {méng₅ 夢矇}, {mén₃ 悶}.
	However, ``blind'' {méng₅ 夢矇} points to a medial *l, whereas there is no evidence for this in the WB words for ``dull, dark''.

ENTRY:2516

	[T] MGZY mi (上) [mi]
	[D] PMin *ṃiᴮ² ``husked rice''.
	[E] Prob. an area word, but a relative with unambiguous phonological agreement is elusive; most likely cognate: PTB *ma-y (STC no. 305) > Garo mi ⪤ me, Dimasa mai ``rice, paddy'', Karen Sgaw me ``boiled rice''; Tangkhul Naga ma ``paddy'', Lushai mɔiᴴ beginning to form in the bud’ (rice); JP n³³-moi³³ ``blossom'' (of grain) (HST: 125). However, this connection presupposes an OCM *mə̂iʔ.
	Matisoff (1995: 66) suggests that the final *-i /-y  is a ST diminutive suffix.
	<> Yao ṃɑi³ (Wáng Fúshì).
	AN imay ``rice'' (Benedict AT).
	Alternatively, Li Fang Kuei (1976: 45) associates the CH word with S. ma-letᴰ²S < *ml- ``seed'', S. met / let ``seed, kernel'', Saek mlɛk/tᴰ², and refers also to WT ’bras < ɴbras ``rice'' (which belongs to {lì₂₁ 糲}, though), and to ’bru ``grain, seed'' (cognate to {wù₅ 物}, however).
	Egerod 1976 cites Miao mblei.
	See also {shí₁₂ 實} ``fruit''.

ENTRY:2518
HEAD:mǐ₃ 羋
MC:Middle Chinese: mjieᴮ 4 
LH:Later Han: mieᴮ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *meʔ
	The clan name of the rulers of the ancient state of Chǔ, in CH translation Xióng 熊.
	Mǐ is a KT word for ``bear'' (Yan Xuequn CAAAL 21, 1983: 135): PKS *muːi¹-fi, PTai *hm-: S. miiᴬ¹, Po-ai muuiᴬ¹; Hlai mui⁴ [Matisoff 1988c: 310] (a medial w/u does not occur after acute initials in CH); farther afield we note AN: e.g. PEastern Formosan *Cumey ``bear'' [Li Jen-kuei LL 5.2, 2004: 368]. The graph represents a sheep and writes the sound of its bleating (?).

HEAD:mǐ₄ 弭敉
	{mí₃} 彌

LH:Later Han: mieᴮ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *meʔ

ENTRY:2521
HEAD:mǐ₆ 靡
MC:Middle Chinese: mjeᴮ 3

OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *maiʔ

	[T] Sin Sukchu SR mi (平), mjej (上), PR məj (平)
	[T] MGZY  mue (平 上) [muɛ]
	[N] This PCH and pre-classical word ``not have, there is no'' (the more common synonym was {wáng₁ 亡}) was replaced by {wú₄ 無} starting only in late WZhou, so that mǐ survived only as a semantic derivative ``squander, exhaust''.
	[<] tone B derivation from {wú₄ 無} *ma ({§3.3.2}); Matisoff (1995: 76f) suggests that the final *-i is a suffix.
	[E] Prob. ST via the root *ma, perhaps mǐ corresponds more directly to WT med-pa ``not have, there is no'' (from *may-t – alternatively, med-pa (STC p. 183; HST: 61) is thought to derive from WT ma or mi ``not'' + yod-pa ``have'').
	It is not clear how the following may be related: Tai-Siam. maiᶜ¹ ``no, not''; Pearic may ``do not''.
	Alternatively, the MC form could theoretically derive from a PCH *malʔ (not *maiʔ); in this case, the Dulong word màl ``NEG + have'' [LaPolla, LTBA 24.2: 35 et al.] may be a direct cognate.
	[C] A derivation is {miè₂ 蔑} ``not have''. Possibly the s. w. as {mǐ₇ 靡} ``small''.
::Pearic	may	``do not''
>:Prob. ST via the root *ma, perhaps mǐ corresponds more directly to WT med-pa ``not have, there is no''  is thought to derive from WT ma or mi ``not'' + yod-pa ``have'')

ENTRY:2522
HEAD:mǐ₇ 靡
MC:Middle Chinese: mjeᴮ 3 
LH:Later Han: mɨɑiᴮ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *maiʔ
GLOSS:"Small, tiny" (e.g. grass) [Yi, Li].
	[E] Etymology not certain. Given its late Zhou occurrence, it may be a semantic extension of the earlier word {mǐ₆ 靡} ``not have'' (i.e. > ``become nothing, negligible, small''?).
	Acc. to HST: 62, it could be cogn. to {mí₆ 糜} ``crush''.
	Or it could be a vocalic variant of a syn. {wéi₈ 微} *məi.
>:Etymology not certain. Given its late Zhou occurrence, it may be a semantic extension of the earlier word {mǐ₆ 靡} ``not have''

OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *maiʔ

::Lushai	pʰiʔ	``wash''
