ENTRY:2539
HEAD:miǎn₂ 娩
MC:Middle Chinese: mjänᴮ 3 
LH:Later Han: mɨanᴮ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *mranʔ
	[T] ONW man
GLOSS:"To give birth" [OB (acc. to Guo Moruo), Guóyǔ: Yuèyǔ; Wénxuǎn, GY], GY adds some other readings; a Qí 齊 (Shandong) dialect word acc. to a commentary to Wénxuǎn (Wáng Lì 1982: 585).
	[E] This word appears to form a ST-like *mra/enʔ ~ *sre/anʔ pair with {chǎn₃ 產} *sre/anʔ ``produce'' ({§2.4.3}), hence miǎn seems to be a ST etymon. Nevertheless, miǎn and chǎn could equally well belong to MK: Khmer samrāla /sɑmraal/ (s-m-raal) ``to give birth to, deliver'' < rāla /ríiəl/ ``to increase, … distribute, propagate''.
	Perhaps AA has been the source of OC *mranʔ which then coincided with the ST s- ~ m- pattern.
>:This word appears to form a ST-like *mra/enʔ ~ *sre/anʔ pair with {chǎn₃ 產} *sre/anʔ ``produce'' , hence miǎn seems to be a ST etymon. Nevertheless, miǎn and chǎn could equally well belong to MK:
>:Khmer samrāla /sɑmraal/  ``to give birth to, deliver'' < rāla /ríiəl/ ``to increase, … distribute, propagate''

ENTRY:2551
HEAD:miè₁ 滅
MC:Middle Chinese: mjiät 4 
LH:Later Han: miat 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *met 
OCB:Baxter Old Chinese: *mjet
	[T] ONW miat
GLOSS:"To drown" [Yi],
GLOSS:"extinguish, destroy" [Shi].
	[E] ST: PTB *mit (STC no. 374) > Chepang hmit- ``disappear, become extinct'', hmat- ``(almost) disappear''; Abor-Miri mit ``destroy'', Lushai mitᴸ / miʔᴸ < mit / miʔ/h < mits ``to go out, die out, be extinguished'' ⪤ tiᴸ-mitᴸ/ tiᴸ-miʔᴸ caus. ``to extinguish, destroy'', Mikir met < mit ``destroy'', JP myit⁵⁵ ``be destroyed''.
	The problem with this set is the vocalic discrepancy OC *et vs.
	PTB *it (an OC syllable of the type *mit does occur; {§11.3.4}).
	Perh. reanalysis as derivation from {huī₆ 墮隳} *hmai ``destroy'' is responsible (*hmai + t > hmet).
	The direct phonological counterpart of PTB *mit may be {mò₄ 沒} *mut ``disappear, die; perish in water or fire'', but see there (for *mit ~ *mut variation, see {§11.5.1}).

ENTRY:2555
HEAD:miè₃ 衊
MC:Middle Chinese: miet 
LH:Later Han: met
GLOSS:"Blood" [SW].
GLOSS-NOTE:The meaning
GLOSS:"to sully, soil, besmirch" (reputation of an ancestral house) 衊 [Hanshu] >
GLOSS:"sore eye, troubled eyesight" 䁾 [Lüshi], ``blood shot'' (eye) [Shiming] could be a semantic extension of either {miè₂ 蔑} ``not have''. The Hànshū phrase wū miè 污衊 has prob. led to the SW (2145b) gloss wū xuě 污血 ``sully with blood'' which implies a meaning ``blood'' for miè and which has been copied into later dictionaries as ``blood''.
	Nevertheless, the notion ``blood'' seems closely associated with this word; note also the expression xuě-miè 血衊 ``to stain with blood''; Sagart (1999: 153) relates miè to Tujia mie⁵³ ``blood'' [Huáng Bùfán, TB Lexicon no. 129].
::Tujia	mie⁵³	``blood''

LH:Later Han: mɨᴮ, mɨnᴮ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *mrəʔ
GLOSS:"Exert oneself, diligent" [BI, Shi].
GLOSS-NOTE:A form in final -n begins to emerge only in the Han period (Luó and Zhōu 1958: 18).

ENTRY:2569
HEAD:mǐn₁ 閔 ⪤ mín 泯
MC:Middle Chinese: mjenᴮ 3 
LH:Later Han: mɨn(ᴮ) 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *mrən(ʔ)
GLOSS:"To destroy, ruin" [Zuo].
	[E] ? AA: Khmer riana [ríiən] ``to exert oneself, endeavor …''. <> Tai: S. manᴮ¹ < *hm- ``diligent'' (Manomaivibool 1975: 239) is perhaps a CH loan.
>:? AA:
>:Khmer riana  ``to exert oneself, endeavor …''. < > Tai:
>:S. manᴮ¹ < *hm- ``diligent''  is perhaps a CH loan

ENTRY:2570
HEAD:mǐn₂,mín 閩
MC:Middle Chinese: mjen 3 [tone!] [GY]  <wow value=' LH:' color='invert' gloss='Later Han'/> mɨn
	Name of today's Fújiàn area, its major river, and the non-Han people who used to live there [Zhouli]. Mǐn does not mean ``snake'' (Zev Handel, p.c.), the ``snake'' radical [SW] is sometimes used in the names of barbarians. Acc. to JDSW (and following it, JY), the graph has other readings: wén, and mán; the composition of the graph 閩 indicates that the Zhōulǐ and Han time reading was not mán.

ENTRY:2571
HEAD:mǐn₃ 敏暋敃
	{mǐn₁} 閔

	{mín₄} 痻

ENTRY:2573
HEAD:mǐn₅ 皿
MC:Middle Chinese: mjwɐŋᴮ 
LH:Later Han: mɨaŋᴮ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *maŋʔ ?
GLOSS:"Vessel, dish, bowel" [Zuo], the word is much older than Zuǒzhuàn because its graph prob. goes back to the beginning of writing. Bodman (1980: 121) compares this to Viet. mâm, PVM *ʔbəmᴬ
GLOSS:"food tray" [Thompson].
GLOSS-NOTE:Initial and final m are incompatible in CH, hence final -ŋ.

ENTRY:2575
HEAD:míng₁ 名 ⪤ mìng 命
MC:Middle Chinese: mjɐŋᶜ 
LH:Later Han: mieŋᶜ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *mrin ~ *mreŋ > *mreŋh 
OCB:Baxter Old Chinese: *mrjiŋ[s]
GLOSS:"To name, give a name (to a person)" [Zuo: Min 2, 5],
GLOSS:"to order, command; order, decree > fate, lot > life" 令 [OB, BI], 命 [Shi].
GLOSS-NOTE:The word was read in tone A in Shījīng (Mattos 1971: 309).
	In the OB and BI (except late WZhou BI) only the graph {lìng 令} ``order'' occurs, while the received texts write 命, i.e. 令 with kǒu 口 ``mouth'' added to indicate that 令 is a phonetic or semantic loan.
	Because mìng is the ordinary word for ``to order'', and because the break between 令 (early inscriptions) and 命 (later texts) is quite abrupt, 令 must have stood for 命 in all Shang and Western Zou inscriptions.
	[T] Sin Sukchu SR miŋ (去)
	[T] MGZY ming (去) [miŋ]
	[T] ONW meŋ
	[D] PMin *miaŋᶜ ``life'' > Amoy miãᶜ², Fúzhōu miaŋᶜ²
	[<] Possibly an r-causative / trans. derivation from the noun míng 名 *min ~ *meŋ ``name'' ({§7.5}); later an exoactive *-s / -h was added ({§4.3.2}).
	[E] If related (so Wáng Lì 1982: 329), {lìng 令} ``order'' may have preserved a ST or PCH pre-initial *r-, hence *mreŋ < *r-miŋ which makes it a homophone of PTB *r-miŋ ``name'' (so STC: 155 n. 419; Granet 1948: 292). WB minᶜ ``command'' (a CH loan?) is prob. also related.
::WB	minᶜ	``command''
>:If related , {lìng 令} ``order'' may have preserved a ST or PCH pre-initial *r-, hence *mreŋ < *r-miŋ which makes it a homophone of PTB *r-miŋ ``name'' . WB minᶜ ``command''  is prob. also related

ENTRY:2576
HEAD:míng₁ₐ 銘
MC:Middle Chinese: mieŋ 
LH:Later Han: meŋ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *mêŋ
	[T] MTang mieŋ < mɨŋ ONW mėŋ
GLOSS:"Inscription" [BI, Liji].
	[E] Míng 銘 is commonly thought to be related to {míng₁ 名}, but the semantic link is not compelling. Phonologically, this word agrees with WT byaŋ-ma / -bu ``inscription, direction, label, tablet'' (on which an inscription is written); for OC *m- = WT b-, see {§5.12.2}; for OC *-e- = WT -ya-, see {§11.3.2}.
	If related, the WT item must be a very old CH loan because there was no writing on the ST level.
::WT	byaŋ-ma / -bu	``inscription, direction, label, tablet''
>:Míng 銘 is commonly thought to be related to {míng₁ 名}, but the semantic link is not compelling. Phonologically, this word agrees with WT byaŋ-ma / -bu ``inscription, direction, label, tablet''
>:for OC *m- = WT b-, see {§5.12.2}
>:for OC *-e- = WT -ya-, see {§11.3.2}

	[D] PMin *maŋᴬ² ``night''

	The nature of the relationship between ST *me/iŋ ``dark'' and SEAsian *maŋ ``night'' is not clear (loans from southern CH dialects?).
	<> PTB *miŋ > WB mañᴮ ~ maiᴮ ``dark, black''.

ENTRY:2578
HEAD:míng₃ 溟冥
MC:Middle Chinese: mieŋ 
LH:Later Han: meŋ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *mêŋ
GLOSS:"Ocean" [Zhuang, Lie], as in běi míng 北冥
GLOSS:"northern ocean", nán míng 南冥
GLOSS:"southern ocean".
	[E] Commentators explain that míng ``ocean'' is the s. w. as {míng₂ 冥} ``dark, black'' (of water) (likely in light of parallelism with the unrelated {hǎi₁ 海}). There is an outside chance, though, that the etymon is instead connected with PTB *mlik >  OBurm. mlac ``river'', WB -mrac, Arakanese mreik ``sea'', SChin-Daai mlik (tui) ``big water, river, sea'' (tui ``water'').
::SChin-Daai	mlik 	``big water, river, sea''

>:WB -mrac
>:Arakanese mreik ``sea''
>:SChin-Daai mlik  ``big water, river, sea''

ENTRY:2579
HEAD:míng₄ 瞑
MC:Middle Chinese: mieŋ 
LH:Later Han: meŋ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *mêŋ
GLOSS:"Close the eyes" [Zuo].
GLOSS-NOTE:Karlgren relates míng to {míng₂ 冥}
GLOSS:"dark".
	[E] GY makes a phonetic distinction between {mián₁ 瞑} ``sleep'' (< ST *mel) and míng 瞑 ``close eyes'' and treats these as two separate words. This is not an example of an occasional *-ŋ ~ *-n variation because ST *-l is not known to show up as CH -ŋ.
	Also, WB distinguishes hminᴮ ``have the eyes shut'' and myañᴮ ``to sleep'' < *mel.
	Here and in the next two items the etyma míng ``dark'', míng ``close eyes'' and mián ``sleep'' have bled into each other so that they are difficult to separate out:
::WB	distinguishes hminᴮ	``have the eyes shut''
>:GY makes a phonetic distinction between {mián₁ 瞑} ``sleep''  and míng 瞑 ``close eyes'' and treats these as two separate words. This is not an example of an occasional *-ŋ ~ *-n variation because ST *-l is not known to show up as CH -ŋ

ENTRY:2594
HEAD:mò₁ 末

ENTRY:2596
HEAD:mò₂ 末
MC:Middle Chinese: muât 
LH:Later Han: mɑt 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *mât
	A negative particle [Lunyu] which is a final *-t form derived from {wú₄ 無} ``not have'' ({§6.2.2}). Its function is similar to {miè₂ 蔑} (Pulleyblank 1995).

ENTRY:2611
HEAD:mò₁₅ 默嘿
MC:Middle Chinese: mək 
LH:Later Han: mək 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *mə̂k
GLOSS:"Silent" [Zuo] is thought to be cognate to
GLOSS:"black" {hēi 黑} (Karlgren GSR 904d), also mò 莫寞漠
GLOSS:"tranquil" (below) has a homophone {mò₈ 莫瞙暯} ``obscure'', as does the Lushai form below. See under {hēi 黑} for possible wider relations.
	This sound-symbolic notion includes many synonyms with initial *m-:
	• mò 莫嗼 (mɐk)  LH  mak, OCM  *mrâk
GLOSS:"Be reverently quiet, settled" (of a population) [Shi]
	• mò 莫寞漠 (mâk)  LH  mɑk, OCM  *mâk
GLOSS:"Tranquil" (of population) 莫 [Shi],
GLOSS:"quiet, still" 寞漠 [Zhuang].
GLOSS-NOTE:Is this merely a graphic variant of 莫嗼 (mɐk)?
	• mì 密 (mjet 3)  LH  mɨt, OCM  *mrit
GLOSS:"Silent, quiet" [Shi],
GLOSS:"secret" [Yi].
GLOSS-NOTE:<> Tai: Saek mit
GLOSS:"quiet".
	• mì 謐 (mjet 4)  LH  mit, OCM  *mit
GLOSS:"Gentle, mild" [Shu, Hou Han].
	[E] ST: Lushai muukᶠ ``quiet, reserved, serious; dull'' (of colors), Lepcha myak ``be silent'' (Geilich 1994: 139; 159;  she includes in this wf the TB items under {wàn₂ 曼}); also MK *mɔk, *mɔɔk ``to sit still'' (Shorto 2006 #379), PSBahn. *mɔʔ ~ *mɔk ``silent''. For the common i ~ u alternation, see {§11.5.1}.
::MK	*mɔk, *mɔɔk	``to sit still''
>:Lushai muukᶠ ``quiet, reserved, serious; dull''
>:Lepcha myak ``be silent''
>:also MK *mɔk, *mɔɔk ``to sit still''
>:PSBahn. *mɔʔ ~ *mɔk ``silent''

ENTRY:2616
HEAD:móu₅ 鍪
MC:Middle Chinese: mjəu 
LH:Later Han: mu 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *mu
GLOSS:"Helmet" [Guoce].
	[E] MK *muuk, *muək ``hat'' (Shorto 2006 #381): MidMon /kəmhok/ ``wide-brimmed conical hat or helmet'' (⇒ WB kʰa-mok), Spoken Mon həmok ``Shan hat'', Palaung hmoʔ ``woman's cap'', Wa-Lawa-Bulang *hmok ``straw hat''; Khmer mùək ``hat'' (⇒ Tai: S. muakᴰ¹ < *hm- ``hat, cap'' [for the traditional etymology, see Li F. 1976: 41]). For the loss of -k, see {§6.9}.
	The source of WT rmog ``helmet'' is not clear (also AA?).
	[C] {mào₁ 冃帽} ``hat'' may perhaps be related, {mào₂ 冒} ``cover'' may not. The earlier syn. was {zhòu₃ 冑}.

ENTRY:2619
HEAD:mǒu₂ 某
MC:Middle Chinese: məuᴮ 
LH:Later Han: moᴮ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *môʔ
GLOSS:"Someone, a certain, so and so" [Shu].
	[T] Sin Sukchu SR məw, mu (上), LR mu
	[T] MGZY  muw (上) [muw]
	[T] ONW mouᴮ
	[E] This may possibly be of AA origin: Mon mu, moʔ /mɯʔ/ ``what, why'', in cognate languages the etymon also means ``who, what''. Note the semantic connection between interrogative and indefinite pronouns in many lgs., including Mandarin, e.g. 沒甚麼 ``it is nothing''.
>:This may possibly be of AA origin:
>:Mon mu, moʔ /mɯʔ/ ``what, why'', in cognate languages the etymon also means ``who, what''. Note the semantic connection between interrogative and indefinite pronouns in many lgs., including Mandarin, e.g. 沒甚麼 ``it is nothing''

ENTRY:2620
HEAD:mòu 瞀

LH:Later Han: mɔk,moᶜ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *mrôk(h)
GLOSS:"Troubled eyesight" [Zhuang].

>:WT rmogs-pa ``eyes heavy with sleep, inert, languish''. Mòu may be cognate to {wù₁₂ 霧} , but TB keeps the two roots distinct

ENTRY:2621
HEAD:mǔ₁ 牡
MC:Middle Chinese: məuᴮ 
LH:Later Han: moᴮ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *mûʔ 
OCB:Baxter Old Chinese: *m(r)juʔ
GLOSS:"Male" (of quadrupeds) [OB, Shi], opposite {pìn,bì 牝}
GLOSS:"female".
	[E] AA: OKhm jmol [cmọọl] ``male of animals'', Aslian lgs. (Malay Penins.) lemol, remol, limo, simo  etc. ``male''; OMon jmur, kmur ``male'' (elephant), MMon jmu / həmù ``strong, male'', PWa *kəmɔy ``ox, wild buffalo'', Jarai təno, təmo ``male animal'' (Lewitz 1976: 768); PVM *mɔlᴮ ``person, people''. For the absence of a coda in CH after a foreign long vowel, see {§6.9}.
	The OB graph for this word shows a vertical stick on a horizontal ground (inverted T).
	The explanation may be that it was intended for an obsolete homophone, a cognate of PVM *c-mɔːlʔ ``digging stick''. ``Male'' and ``digging stick'' are derivatives from a stem represented in OKhmer cval /cuuəl/ ``to enter, penetrate, (of animals) copulate'', Khmu cmɔɔl ``planter du riz au plantoir'' ⪤ crmɔɔl ``plantoir'' [Ferlus MKS 7, 1978: 20-22]; from ``digging stick'' to ``ploughing'' to ``acre'' are simple steps, hence mǔ ``male'' and {mǔ₅ 畝} ``field'', though not homophones in OC, may well go back to the same AA etymon.
::Khmu	cmɔɔl	``planter du riz au plantoir''
>:AA:
>:OKhm jmol  ``male of animals''
>:Aslian lgs.  lemol, remol, limo, simo  etc. ``male''
>:OMon jmur, kmur ``male''
>:MMon jmu / həmù ``strong, male''
>:PWa *kəmɔy ``ox, wild buffalo''
>:Jarai təno, təmo ``male animal''
>:PVM *mɔlᴮ ``person, people''

ENTRY:2622
HEAD:mǔ₂ 母
MC:Middle Chinese: məuᴮ 
LH:Later Han: moᴮ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *môʔ
GLOSS:"Mother" [OB, Shi].
	[T] Sin Sukchu SR mu, məw (上), LR mu
	[T] MGZY muw (上) [muw]
	[T] ONW mouᴮ
	[E] This word has two possible TB cognates. (1) Mǔ is either derived from a hypothetical ST *məʔ: PTB *ma ``mother'' > WT ʔa-ma, Chepang ma (*məʔ) (so HST: 110).
	[E] Or (2) OC *moʔ is cognate to PTB *mow ``woman, bride'' (STC no. 297) > WT  -mo ``female suffix'', Chepang mo ``wife'', Lushai mooᴴ ``bride, daughter-in-law'' (so Bodman 1980: 136; Baxter 1992: 469).
	In languages of the area words for ``mother, woman, female, daughter'' have initial *m- followed by almost any vowel: OC *môʔ ``mother'', WT mo, ma ``female'', ma generally ``mother'', LB ma ``female, girl, woman'', WB maᶜ ``sister'', OC *məs ? ``younger sister'', LB mi² ``female'' ⪤ miᶜ ``mother, madam, daughter''; MMon mi, OKhmer me ``mother''.
	See also {hóu₅ 猴}
::OKhmer	me	``mother''
>:This word has two possible TB cognates.  Mǔ is either derived from a hypothetical ST *məʔ:
>:PTB *ma ``mother'' >
>:WT ʔa-ma
>:Chepang ma
>:Or  OC *moʔ is cognate to PTB *mow ``woman, bride''  >
>:WT  -mo ``female suffix''
>:Chepang mo ``wife''
>:Lushai mooᴴ ``bride, daughter-in-law''

GLOSS:"An acre" [BI, Shi].
	[T] Sin Sukchu SR mu, məw (上)
	[T] MGZY muw (上) [muw]
	[D] In many dialects, including some Mandarin ones, ``acre'' is not a homophone of mǔ 母 ``mother'': W-Sūzhōu col. mᶜ², Wēnzhōu mɛᴮ²
	[D] X-Chángshā mɤuᴮ
	[D] G-Nánchāng mɛuᴮ
	[D] Y-Guǎngzhōu mauᴮ²; M-Xiàmén bɔᴮ. However, ``acre'' and ``mother'' are homophones in most Mand. dial. and sporadically elsewhere.
	[E] ? ST: WT rmo-ba, rmos ``to plough'' (Bodman 1980: 136) ⪤ rmod ``the ploughing'' ⪤ rmon-pa ``plough ox'',  Mikir -mò classifier for strips of fields. However, if this word should go back to an AA root (see {mǔ₁ 牡}), then the nature of the CH - TB relationship is not clear.

ENTRY:2627
HEAD:mù₂ 目
MC:Middle Chinese: mjuk 
LH:Later Han: muk 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *muk
GLOSS:"Eye" [OB, Shi].
	[T] Sin Sukchu SR mu (入)
	[T] MGZY wu (入) [vu]
	[T] ONW muk
	[D] Mù has been replaced by yǎn 眼, already in Han times (acc. to SW, GY), in all dialects except Mǐn: PMin *ṃokᴰ², but the NEMin forms go back to *mit ~ *met (Norman CLAO 13.2, 1984: 175ƒƒ).
	[E] ST: PTB *mik ~ *myak (STC no. 402) > WT dmig ``eye'', and *mik in almost every TB language, including JP myiʔ³¹, Mikir mék; a variant is PLB *(s-)myak > WB myak (HST: 76).
	The OC vowel is not certain since mù is not a rime word in Shījīng.
	If OC *muk, the word would be directly related to the PTB form *mik by way of the ST *u ~ *i alternation ({§11.5.1}).
	If OC *miək, the word would be directly related to the PLB form *myak.
	[C] {móu₃ 眸} ``pupil of the eye'' is sometimes thought to be related to mù (so Wáng Lì 1982: 312).
>:PTB *mik ~ *myak  >
>:WT dmig ``eye'', and *mik in almost every TB language, including JP myiʔ³¹
>:Mikir mék
>:a variant is PLB *myak >
>:WB myak

ENTRY:2629
HEAD:mù₄ 莫暮
MC:Middle Chinese: muoᶜ 
LH:Later Han: mɑᶜ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *mâkh
	[T] ONW mo
GLOSS:"Late" (in a season, year’) 莫 [Shi],
GLOSS:"evening" 暮 [Meng].
	[E] Two possible etymologies: (1) the original meaning is ``late''. (2) Or this word is related to ``dark, cover'' {mò₈ 莫瞙暯} ``obscure''. See under {hēi 黑} for possible wider relations.
	Since TB roots are inconclusive as to their ST source, Limbu makt- ``to become night'' may either be a direct cognate of mù 莫暮 (not very likely given the frequent semantic connection ``dark'' ~ ``night'' – not ``late'' ~ ``night''), or ⪤ Limbu mak ``black, dark'' (which may equally well be a cognate of {hēi 黑}).
	Related may also be Lepcha ma ``be secret, concealed, disappear''.
::Lepcha	ma	``be secret, concealed, disappear''
>:Two possible etymologies:
>:the original meaning is ``late''.  Or this word is related to ``dark, cover'' {mò₈ 莫瞙暯} ``obscure''. See under {hēi 黑} for possible wider relations

HEAD:mù₅ 墓

OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *mâkh.
GLOSS:"Tomb, graveyard" [BI, Shi].
GLOSS-NOTE:In most other modern dialects, the word for
GLOSS:"grave" is {fén₄ 墳}.

	[D] PMin *ṁioᶜ

	If ``tomb'' should be a derivation, one source could be {mò₈ 莫瞙暯} ``obscure''; see there and under {hēi 黑} for possible wider relations.
	Alternatively, the root could be {wú₄ 無} ``not'' from which is derived sāng 喪 ``mourning, burial, corpse'' (under {wáng₁ 亡}).

GLOSS:2:ST *mak: Lepcha mák
GLOSS:"long for", WB mak
GLOSS:"covet, wish to enjoy", JP mak³¹ ``desire to eat''. (HST: 105; Unger Hao-ku 51, 1995).
	[E] Wáng Lì (1982: 176) relates this wf to {fǔ₁₀ 撫} ``lay hands on, soothe'' (unlikely). Forms like rak ``love'' in Tai and AA lgs. derive from Indic rāga ``passion''.

ENTRY:2638
HEAD:nà₃ 那
MC:Middle Chinese: nâᶜ
GLOSS:"That" Mand. (Norman 1988: 119).
	[T] Sin S. SR nɔ (去), PR, LR na
	[T] MGZY no (去) [nɔ]
	[T] ONW nɑ
	[E] Nà prob. belongs to demonstratives in non-ST languages, note especially PAA *na ``this'' a “very frequent type” in AA [Pinnow 1965: 33]: Khmuʔ naa ``3rd person pronoun'', Khmer nai (nāi) ``there'', Munda na, naa ``this''; also Viet ṇo ``this'' [Maspero 1912: 63]. KT forms are not as close to CH: Tai: S. niiᶜ² < *n- ``this'', S. nanᶜ² < *n- ``that''; Nung nayᶜ², Wuming naiᶜ² etc. ``this'' (HCT: 113).
	Mand. nà corresponds to an OC *naih > nâᶜ.
	The OC pronominal n-suffix ({§6.4.5}) is probably derived from one of these forms.
::Viet	ṇo	``this''
>:Nà prob. belongs to demonstratives in non-ST languages, note especially PAA *na ``this'' a “very frequent type” in AA :
>:Khmuʔ naa ``3rd person pronoun''
>:Khmer nai  ``there''
>:Munda na, naa ``this''
>:also Viet ṇo ``this'' . KT forms are not as close to CH:
>:Tai:
>:S. niiᶜ² < *n- ``this''
>:S. nanᶜ² < *n- ``that''
>:Nung nayᶜ²
>:Wuming naiᶜ² etc. ``this''

ENTRY:2645
HEAD:nǎi₄ 嬭
MC:Middle Chinese: nieiᴮ 
LH:Later Han: neiᴮ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *nêʔ
GLOSS:"Mother" [BI, QY, Guangya], a Chǔ dialect word [GY], also nǐ 妳; the modern col. form is nǎi 奶
GLOSS:"breasts, milk, suckle" (Unger Hao-ku 5, 1982).
	[D] Mǐn: Xiàmén lit. lãiᴮ, col. lẽᴮ
	[E] Etymology is not clear, but PMY *niaʔ²ᴰ ``mother'' could be related. Similar words in the area are WT a-ne, ne-ne ``paternal aunt'' (HST: 164); or Khmer ɲiː ``female'', see {lǐ₂-ěr 李耳} ``female tiger''.
::Khmer	ɲiː	``female''
>:Etymology is not clear, but PMY *niaʔ²ᴰ ``mother'' could be related. Similar words in the area are WT a-ne, ne-ne ``paternal aunt''
>:or Khmer ɲiː ``female'', see {lǐ₂-ěr 李耳} ``female tiger''

ENTRY:2646
HEAD:nài₁ 奈柰

LH:Later Han: nɑs
GLOSS:"Some kind of pear" (3rd cent.
	AD).
	Japanese (kara)nashi 梨 could be the analogue to OC *nas and thus be related (Unger Hao-ku 22, 1983).
	See comment under {méi₄ 梅}.

ENTRY:2647
HEAD:nài₂ 奈
MC:Middle Chinese: nâiᶜ 
LH:Later Han: nɑs 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *nâs
	A late classical col. variant of {rú₁ 如} (or prob. rather MC nźjwoᶜ) in the classical expression rú hé 如何 = nài hé 奈何 (occurrence of nài in Shūjīng is spurious, a later gloss) (Unger Hao-ku 22, 1983).
	Pulleyblank (BIHP 59.2, 1988: 339ƒƒ) derives nài hé from ruò zhī hé 若之何.
	See {rú₁ 如} for allofams.

ENTRY:2650
HEAD:nán₁ 南
MC:Middle Chinese: nậm 
LH:Later Han: nəm 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *nə̂m
GLOSS:"South" [BI, Shi].
GLOSS-NOTE:The OB graph depicts something that looks like a house; in light of this it is interesting to note PMK *nəm
GLOSS:"house".
	[T] Sin Sukchu SR nam (平)
	[T] PR, LR nan
	[T] MGZY nam (平) [nam]
	[T] ONW nɑm
	[E] Etymology not certain. Benedict (ICSTLL 1989: 7) relates this to PTB *nam (his *nəm) ``sun, day, sky'' > PTib. *g-nam ``sky'' ⪤ nam ``night'', also ``rain, god'' in other TB languages.
	This etymology finds support in the old CH tradition which associates the south with the sunny side {yáng₉ 陽}, the north with {yīn₅ 陰} ``the dark side'', {míng₂ 冥} ``darkness, night'', shuò 朔 (ṣåk) ``new moon, north'' (under {nì₆ 逆}), hence nán could originally have been the counterpart to the dark north.
::PTB	*nam 	``sun, day, sky''
>:Etymology not certain. Benedict  relates this to PTB *nam  ``sun, day, sky'' >
>:PTib. *g-nam ``sky'' ⪤ nam ``night'', also ``rain, god'' in other TB languages

ENTRY:2659
HEAD:náo₂ 猱獶夒獿
MC:Middle Chinese: nâu 
LH:Later Han: nou 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *nû
GLOSS:"Monkey" 猱 [Shi], 獶 [Li], 夒 [OB, SW], 獿 [SW] (ZWDCD 2: 1359; 6: 260).
	[E] Etymology is elusive, the closest fit is AA: PMon *knuuy ``macaque, general term'', Mon *[k]hn—ui ``monkey''. This word is unique to Monic and may be a derivation by n-infix (Diffloth 1984: 67).
	The loss of foreign final -y/-i  in OC has parallels ({§6.9}).
	However, the Mon word could be a Pali loan instead: khanoi (Shorto).
	Alternatively, the word may be connected with KD: Be ma³-lu² ``monkey'', PHlai nok [Matisoff 1988c: 311]; cf. PTB *mruk, PLB *myok (several Loloish dialects have n-) [Matisoff]. Syn. {yù₉ 禺} ``monkey''.
::Be	ma³-lu²	``monkey''

>:PMon *knuuy ``macaque, general term''
>:Mon *hn—ui ``monkey''. This word is unique to Monic and may be a derivation by n-infix

ENTRY:2673
HEAD:nèn,nùn 嫩
MC:Middle Chinese: nuənᶜ
	[T] ONW don (!)
GLOSS:"Tender, delicate", a late word [GY, JY].
	[E] Etymology is not clear. Perh. a variant of {ruǎn 耎軟} (ńźjwänᴮ).
	Alternatively, it may be ST, related to WB nunᴮ ``weak, exhausted from illness'', but this meaning barely overlaps with nèn ``soft to touch''.
	<> PMY *-on, individual lgs. have forms like lun⁵, gun⁵, ɳtʃoŋ⁵ (Wáng Fúshì).
	Finally, nèn is reminiscent of AA items: PMonic *lʔun ``be flexible, soft to touch'' (of body part etc.), and/or PVM *k-rn-ɔːn ``young, tender'' > Viet. non (acc. to Ferlus, an infix derivation from *kɔːn ``son'').

ENTRY:2677
HEAD:ní₁ 尼
MC:Middle Chinese: ṇi 
LH:Later Han: ṇi 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *nri or *ni ?
GLOSS:"Near, close" [Shizi], a relatively late word.
	[T] Sin Sukchu SR njej (平), PR ni

	[T] ONW ni
	[E] Etymology not certain. This stem could simply be a variant of {ěr₇ 邇} ``near'', just as Mand. nǐ ``you'' is a col. variant of ěr ``you''.
	Or it could be a conflation of {ěr₇ 邇} and nì 昵衵 *nrit (under {jí₇ 即}).
	Finally, there is a possible TB cognate: KN-Khimi kă-ni, Haka hni ``petticoat'' [IST: 207], the meaning of these items agrees with 昵衵, though. Syn. is also {jí₇ 即}, {nì₉ 暱}.
::Haka	hni	``petticoat''

	[T] ONW nit

	The meaning has been transferred to xiè 褻 (under {ěr₇ 邇}).
::Haka	hni	``petticoat''

ENTRY:2689
HEAD:nì₅ 䵒
	{nì₂} 昵 ``glue''

ENTRY:2690
HEAD:nì₆ 逆
MC:Middle Chinese: ŋjɐk 
LH:Later Han: ŋɨak 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *ŋrak 
OCB:Baxter Old Chinese: *ŋrjak
GLOSS:"Go to meet, go against" [Shu],
GLOSS:"rebellious" [Shi],
GLOSS:"receive" [Yili], ``anticipate'' [Lunyu].
	[T]  Sin Sukchu SR i (入), PR ŋi
	[T] MGZY ngi (入) [ŋi]
	[T] ONW ŋek
	[<] This is the final -k counterpart to the cognate {yíng₁ 迎}, or the div. 3 counterpart to the cognate {yà₂ 御迓訝} (if one assumes an OC medial *r like Baxter; otherwise it is derived from {yù₁₇ 禦}).
	[E] The word LH ṣak is derived from nì 逆 ``go to meet'' (above), i.e. on that day the moon turns and moves toward the full moon (Matisoff, ICSTLL 1978: 13-14: Boltz, Diss.). This is an iterative s-prefix form ({§5.2.3}), hence lit. ``turn again towards to meet''.
	The puzzling MC reading ṣåk < *srok ? is attested already in Lùnyǔ where the graph is borrowed for shuò 數 (ṣåk) ``account'' (under {shǔ₄ 數}).
	Alternatively, shuò ``north'' may be related to NNaga *swər ``night'', Bodo-Garo *war, Mru war (with final CH *-k with the metathesis of final *r, see {§6.1}, resulting in OC *srak ~ *srok from *sruak) and thus be the opposite of {nán₁ 南} ``south'' < ST ``day, sun''.
	Possibly, distinct etyma for ``north'' and ``new moon'' have merged.
::NNaga	*swər	``night''
>:The word LH ṣak is derived from nì 逆 ``go to meet'' , i.e. on that day the moon turns and moves toward the full moon . This is an iterative s-prefix form , hence lit. ``turn again towards to meet''

ENTRY:2691
HEAD:nì₆ 逆 ⪤ shuò 朔
MC:Middle Chinese: ṣåk 
LH:Later Han: ṣak ? / ṣɔk 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *sŋrâk ? / *srôk
GLOSS:"First day of the new moon" [Shi, SW] >
GLOSS:"beginning" [Li]; (dark side >)

ENTRY:2704
HEAD:niàn₂ 晛

LH:Later Han: nenᶜ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *nêns or *nîns ?
GLOSS:"Sunlight" (which melts snow) [Shi].
GLOSS-NOTE:Karlgren GSR 1250e considers this word cognate to {rán₁ 然}
GLOSS:"burn" LH ńian, but the OC vowels do not agree.
	It may possibly be related to {rì 日} ``sun'' instead.
	The reading xiàn 晛 (ɣienᴮ) LH genᴮ has prob. been transferred from the graphic element 見 LH genᶜ, or from xiàn 睍 (ɣienᴮ) LH genᴮ.

ENTRY:2706

LH:Later Han: teuᴮ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *tiûʔ
GLOSS:"Bird" [Shi].
	[T] Sin Sukchu SR njew (上)
	[T] MGZY dÿaw (上) [tjɛw]
	[N] Niǎo is a late pronunciation (or word?) which came into use because of a taboo. Nevertheless, the word niǎo does not come out of thin air; it could be connected with the KT word for ``bird'': Tai: S. nukᴰ²S < *nl/rok; PKS *mluk⁸.
	For Chinese tone B for foreign final -k, see {§3.2.2}.
	The old form survives in some dialects as ``penis'', e.g.
	Mand.-Jǐnán tiɔ⁵⁵ = tone B, Y-Guǎngzhōu tiu³⁵/ᴬ¹.
	[E] ST *t(j)oʔ ? STC (192 n. 491) connects MC tieuᴮ with Garo *doʔ [Joseph / Burling, LTBA 24.2, 2001: 45], Karen *to ``bird'', note also KN *m-tow ``to fly'' (for CH medial i, see {§9.1.3}).
::KN	*m-tow	``to fly''
>:ST *toʔ ? STC  connects MC tieuᴮ with Garo *doʔ
>:Karen *to ``bird'', note also KN *m-tow ``to fly''

HEAD:niē 捻
MC:Middle Chinese: niep 
LH:Later Han: nep 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *nêp or *nîp
GLOSS:"To pinch, nip with fingers" [SW Xīnfù, JY].
	[E] ST: PLB: *nip ~ *ʔnip ~ *ʔnyit ``to squeeze, press''. CH ⇒ Tai: S. niipᴰ¹ (WrSiam hniːʔb) ``grasp (with pincers), pinch between'' (Manomaivibool 1975: 163).
	This ST root *nip is distinct from *njap ({shè₁₀ 攝} ``grasp''), although they may ultimately be related as their TB cognates seem to be: PTB *nip ``press, pinch'' ~ *nyap ``to press, squeeze'' (HPTB: 112; 339).

ENTRY:2720
HEAD:niè₁₀ 糱

LH:Later Han: ŋɨɑt 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *ŋrat
GLOSS:"Malt" [Li] (not
GLOSS:"yeast", so Unger Hao-ku 39, 1992). Shìmíng explains:
GLOSS:"soak wheat and let it sprout").
	Acc. to Unger, the basic meaning of this stem is ``sprout'', hence the items below are the s. w.
	Unger suggests a derivation from yá 芽 ``sprout'' which, however, is the s. w. as {yá₁ 牙} ``tooth''.
	If true, ``tooth'' would then be the ultimate origin of this wf.
	[E] ST: Lushai ŋaanᴴ < ŋaan ``malt'' (Unger).

ENTRY:2730
HEAD:niú 牛
MC:Middle Chinese: ŋjəu

(so Bodman 1980: 153). A parallel stem ({§2.5}) may be WT: nor ``wealth, cattle'', Lepcha a-nór ``herd, flock, troop, numbers, quantities'' ({§5.12.2}).
	<> Tai: S. ŋuaᴬ²  < *ŋwue ? ``ox''.
	Because of the restricted geographic distribution, STC suspects CH niú to be a Tai loan, also Li Fang Kuei (1976: 42) concludes the Tai item is not a CH loan because it is not found in northern Tai dialects.
::Lepcha	a-nór	``herd, flock, troop, numbers, quantities''

ENTRY:2732
HEAD:niǔ₂ 紐

LH:Later Han: ṇuᴮ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *nr(i)uʔ 
OCB:Baxter Old Chinese: *nrjuʔ
GLOSS:"A knot" (that can be opened) [SW],
GLOSS:"knot" (on a sash) [Liji] >
GLOSS:"button" 鈕 > any type of button or knob by which, for example, a ring can be fastened. The basic meaning could be some kind of fastener that can be easily undone.
	Conversely, ``button'' could also have been the original meaning from which the others derived, in which case this word may be the same as {niǔ₁ 狃丑} ``fingernail'' > ``finger-nail-shaped'' > ``button''.

	[T] MTang noŋ, ONW nɑuŋ
	[E] Prob. ST and cognate to {nòu 耨} ``to weed'' (Lushai hnuᶠ ``work finished, weeded or harvested area'').
	The final *-ŋ in nóng could be the terminative suffix ({§6.5.1}): nòu ``to weed, hoe'' > nóng ``get a field hoed'', i.e. ``cultivated''.
	[C] {nóng₂ 儂} ``person, I'' (< ``peasant'') may be the same word; a possible allofam may be {nóng₄ 穠} ``thick vegetation''.
>:Prob. ST and cognate to {nòu 耨} ``to weed''

ENTRY:2737
HEAD:nóng₂ 儂
MC:Middle Chinese: nuoŋ
GLOSS:"Person, I, me" in south-eastern dialects: Coastal Mǐn *noŋ, Fúzhōu nøiŋᴬ², nøiŋᴬ²-kaᴬ¹ 儂家
GLOSS:"I, myself"; Xiàmén laŋᴬ²
GLOSS:"person"; Wú: ā-nóng  阿儂 ``I''.
	Xiàmén lanᴮ ``we'' (inclusive) is laŋᴬ²  + a pronominal suffix -n which in turn is derived from nóng; Fúzhōu iᴬ¹-nøiŋ ``they''.
	Acc. to Norman (1983: 208), the semantic development is ``peasant'' ({nóng₁ 農}) > ``person'' > pronoun ``I, me''.
	Alternatively, since a syllable noŋ occurs in some Zhuang (Tai) dialects in forms for the first person pronoun, Pān Wùyún and Chén Zhōngmǐn (JCL 23.2, 1995) suggest that nóng is a substrate word from the earlier ``Hundred Yuè'' 百越 where nóng was a clan name and ethnonym, then > ``person'' > ``I, me''.

ENTRY:2738
HEAD:nóng₃ 濃醲膿
MC:Middle Chinese: ṇjwoŋ,nuŋ 
LH:Later Han: ṇoŋ,nouŋ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *nroŋ,*nôŋ
GLOSS:"Thick, rich (dew)" [ Shi];
GLOSS:"thick, strong (drink)" 醲 [Hanfei];
GLOSS:"pus" (< ``thick matter'')  膿 (only MC nuoŋ) [Hanfei].
GLOSS-NOTE:This item may be related to {nóng₄ 穠}
GLOSS:"thick growth" (so Wáng Lì 1982: 610).
	[T] MTang noŋ, ONW nɑuŋ  —
	[D] PMin *ṇəŋ(ᶜ)
	[E] CH ⇒ Tai: PTai *hn- > S. nɔɔŋᴬ¹ ``pus''.
	[E] ST: WT rno-ba, rnon-po ``sharp, acute'' (of taste, intellect); KN-Lushai nuᴴ / nutᴸ  ``muddy'' (of liquids); however, the Lushai item may instead be connected to {ní₂ 泥}.
	[C] Allofam is perhaps {rú₅ 濡}.
>:CH ⇒ Tai:
>:PTai *hn- >
>:S. nɔɔŋᴬ¹ ``pus''
>:WT rno-ba, rnon-po ``sharp, acute''
>:KN-Lushai nuᴴ / nutᴸ  ``muddy''
>:however, the Lushai item may instead be connected to {ní₂ 泥}

ENTRY:2745
HEAD:nú₁ 奴
MC:Middle Chinese: nuo 
LH:Later Han: nɑ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *nâ
GLOSS:"Slave" [Lun].
	[T] Sin Sukchu SR nu (平)
	[T] MGZY nu (平) [nu]
	[T] ONW no
	[E] Etymology not certain. Perh. cognate to Mru nar ``servant'', SChin-Awa tana [Löffler, Anthropos 55, 1960: 530]. Ferlus (LTBA 22.2, 1999: 5) relates this word to {nǚ₁ 女} ``woman''; this has semantic parallels, especially among foreign loans.
	Unger (Hao-ku 36, 1990: 44) relates it to a wf with the basic meaning ``tense'' (including {nǔ₁ 弩}, {nǔ₂ 努}), hence ``press into service''.
::Mru	nar	``servant''

ENTRY:2748
HEAD:nǔ₁ 弩
MC:Middle Chinese: nuoᴮ 
LH:Later Han: nɑᴮ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *nâʔ
GLOSS:"Crossbow" [Zhouli].
	[T] Sin Sukchu SR nu (上)
	[T] MGZY nu (上) [nu]
	[T] ONW no
	[E] AA (Norman and Mei MS 32, 1976: 293-295; Benedict AT 1975: 110; 1976: 89): MK *snaʔ ``crossbow'' (Shorto 2006 #97): PVM *s-naːʔ ``bow, crossbow'' [Ferlus], PMnong *so’na, Khmer snaa, PSBahn. *sənaː ``crossbow'', Pearic tʰənaː ``crossbow''. Unrelated are PMonic and OMon *tŋaaʔ, Mon *hŋaʔ ``crossbow'' (Diffloth 1984: 119).
	The word is widely distributed in E and SE Asia: Rawang (Nung) thəna, Dulong t–ɑn–ɑ, Moso (LB) tăna.
	<> PTai *hnaaᶜ: S. naaᶜ¹ (-maiᶜ²) ``crossbow'' (Li F. 1976: 43); in NTai naaᴮ¹ ``arrow'' (particularly of a crossbow) (Manomaivibool 1975: 138), Sui hna; note also S. sa-nao ``crossbow'' (<- Khmer?).
	<> PMY *nhaᴮ ``crossbow''.
	<> PAN *panaq ``bow, arrow'' (Sagart JCL 21.1, 1993: 23), *panah ``shooting weapon''.
	Alternatively, Unger (Hao-ku 36, 1990: 44) suggests that nǔ is related to {nǔ₂ 努} which basically means ``to tense''.
	Gernet (acc. to Ferlus LTBA 22.2, 1999: 17) suggests that the homophone nǔ 砮 ``stone used for arrowheads'' has been extended to ``crossbow''.
::PAN	*panaq	``bow, arrow''
>:AA :
>:MK *snaʔ ``crossbow'' :
>:PVM *s-naːʔ ``bow, crossbow''
>:PMnong *so’na
>:Khmer snaa
>:PSBahn. *sənaː ``crossbow'', Pearic tʰənaː ``crossbow''. Unrelated are PMonic and OMon *tŋaaʔ, Mon *hŋaʔ ``crossbow''

ENTRY:2749
HEAD:nǔ₂ 努
MC:Middle Chinese: nuoᴮ 
LH:Later Han: nɑᴮ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *nâʔ
	[T] ONW no 努力 ``to exert one's strength'' [Han commentators], 怒臂 ``tense / stem one's arms'' [Zhuang].
	[E] ST *nwar: TB: Lushai nɔrᶠ < nɔɔrʔ ``press, push'' ⪤ Lushai nuarᴴ / nɔrʔᴸ < nuar < nɔrʔ/h ``be displeased, disgruntled'' (Unger Hao-ku 36, 1990: 44), Khami *nuar ``get angry'' [R. Shafer ZDMG 102, 1952: 275]. For the OC final, see {§7.7.7}.

ENTRY:2752
HEAD:nǚ₁ 女
MC:Middle Chinese: ṇjwoᴮ 
LH:Later Han: ṇɑᴮ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *nraʔ < *C/r-naʔ ?
GLOSS:"Woman, wife, girl, daughter, female" [BI, Shi], opposite {shì₁ 士}, {nán₂ 男}. See also {niáng 孃娘}.
	[T] Sin Sukchu SR ny (上)
	[T] MGZY ñÿu (上) [ãy]
	[T] ONW nø < nio
	[D] nǚ-ér 女兒 ``girl, daughter'', in Wú dialects nø¹³ (Mand. nān) 囡 ``small child, girl, daughter'', also nø¹³- ŋ¹³ 囡五
	[D] ``female'' of animals in Yuè dialects, e.g. Guǎngzhōu ma¹³-na³⁵ 馬 [也+母] ``female horse''.
	[E] Perh. ST *na: WT mna’(-ma) ``daughter-in-law'' (Unger Hao-ku 33, 1986), ña-mo ``mistress of the house, housewife'' (HPTB: 173f), and/or the marginal West Tib. ñag(-mo) ``woman'' (Simon acc. to Bodman 1980: 133), for tone B in CH, see {§3.3.1}; JP ʔna³³ ``older sister, sister-in-law'' (wife of brother), address for older woman by a younger one; WB hnaᶜ-ma ``sister'' (STC: 187 n. 487), NNaga *ʔ-ɲaᴬ ``elder sister'' [French 1983: 271]. However, the fundamental meaning of the TB items is ``sister'', not ``woman, girl''.
	Alternatively, Ferlus (LTBA 22.2, 1999: 5) connects the word with AA: Khmu kmbraʔ ``wife'' < kmraʔ, OC from k-N-raʔ.
	He adds {nú₁ 奴} ``slave'' to this wf.
	There is a similar MK etymon, see {tái₃ 嬯臺}.
::Khmu	kmbraʔ	``wife''
>:Perh. ST *na:
>:WT mna’ ``daughter-in-law'' , ña-mo ``mistress of the house, housewife'' , and/or the marginal West Tib. ñag ``woman'' , for tone B in CH, see {§3.3.1}
>:JP ʔna³³ ``older sister, sister-in-law'' , address for older woman by a younger one
>:WB hnaᶜ-ma ``sister''
>:NNaga *ʔ-ɲaᴬ ``elder sister'' . However, the fundamental meaning of the TB items is ``sister'', not ``woman, girl''

ENTRY:2763
HEAD:nuó 儺
MC:Middle Chinese: nâ 
LH:Later Han: nɑ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *nâi
GLOSS:"To expel demons of illness" [Lunyu, GY].
	[E] Etymology not certain. Nuó is perhaps related to {nán₃ 難} ``difficult'' (so Karlgren 1956: 18; Boltz JAOS 99.3, 1979: 430).
	But it also, or instead, belongs to PTB *na ~ *nat ``ill'': WB na ``be ill, be in pain'' ⪤ nat ``demon, spirit'' < PLB *nat (Benedict HJAS 4, 1939: 228).
	Perh. this is not a cognate but a TB loan because there is no obvious OC word with the meaning ``illness'' from which nuó could have been derived ({nà₄ 𤸻} ``sick'' is a medieval word, and the etymology of {shǔ₂ 癙} ``painful'' is not certain); the OC rime *-ai creates difficulties for a genetic relationship as well.
::WB	na	``be ill, be in pain''
>:Etymology not certain. Nuó is perhaps related to {nán₃ 難} ``difficult''

ENTRY:2775
HEAD:pā 葩
MC:Middle Chinese: pʰa
GLOSS:"Flowers, blossoms" [post-Han].
	[E] ST: PTB *baːr (STC no. 1): Lepcha bor ``to bloom'', a-bor ``blossom'' (Unger Hao-ku 35, 1986: 36); Lushai paarᴴ ``flower, blossom'' ⪤ parʔᴸ ``to open'' (as flower) ⪤ pʰarʔᴸ ``to open'' (as hand, flower), KN-Khami par ``flower'' (Löffler 1966: 146); WB panᴮ ``flower'' [Matisoff 1974: no. 149]; JP ¹nam-²pan [Weidert 1987: 132], WT ’bar-ba ``to blossom, to burn, catch fire, beam, radiate''. This etymon is prob. related to ``burn'' {fán₅ 燔}.
	WT also shows the relationship between ``burn, fire'' and ``flower'': me-tʰog ``flower'' means lit. ``fire-top''.
	[C] This word is perhaps the same etymon as {bàn₄ 瓣} ``petals of a flower''.
::WT	’bar-ba	``to blossom, to burn, catch fire, beam, radiate''

>:JP ¹nam-²pan
>:WT ’bar-ba ``to blossom, to burn, catch fire, beam, radiate''. This etymon is prob. related to ``burn'' {fán₅ 燔}

ENTRY:2776
HEAD:pá₁ 爬
	(a late word not in GY, JY, the MC form would be ba)
GLOSS:"To crawl" [Xin Fangyan],
GLOSS:"to climb", an col. archaism of the next item: pú-fú  匍匐.
	[E] The first syllable is reduplication (Norman 1988: 87). SW separates the two syllables: (1) pú (OCM *ba) ``手行也'', i.e. ``to crawl'' [SW], pú = pú-fú [GY]; (2) fú = 伏 (bjuk) ``to lie on the ground'' (ZWDCD 2: 89, 91). Thus pú ~ pá (above) follows pú-fú as an independent word, while fú, taken for a mere variant graph of 伏, becomes obsolete.
	<> This is perhaps a ST item: Chepang bah-sa ``to crawl''.
::Chepang	bah-sa	``to crawl''
>:The first syllable is reduplication . SW separates the two syllables:
>:pú  ``手行也'', i.e. ``to crawl'' , pú = pú-fú
>:fú = 伏  ``to lie on the ground'' . Thus pú ~ pá  follows pú-fú as an independent word, while fú, taken for a mere variant graph of 伏, becomes obsolete

ENTRY:2778
HEAD:pá₂,bá 耙杷
MC:Middle Chinese: ba(ᶜ) 
LH:Later Han: ba(ᶜ) 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *brâ(h)
	[T] ONW bä
GLOSS:"A harrow" (Mand. bà),
GLOSS:"a rake" 杷 (Mand. pá) [Zhuang].
	[E] Etymology not certain. This word may be derived from {bǎ 把} ``handful, grasp'', hence a claw-like instrument.
	Alternatively, pá could be MK: Khmer pāra /baar/ ``to scrape, scuff, rake …'' (for the r-metathesis, see {§7.7.3}).
	In light of these possibilities, cognation with PTB *pra (STC no. 132) is less likely: Kanauri bra ``forked'' (road) ⪤ pra ``spread, stretch'', WB praᴮ ``divided into several parts'', JP braʔ⁵⁵ < brak⁵⁵ ``be forked'' (CVST 1: 58).
::JP	braʔ⁵⁵ < brak⁵⁵	``be forked''
>:Etymology not certain. This word may be derived from {bǎ 把} ``handful, grasp'', hence a claw-like instrument

ENTRY:2779
HEAD:pà 怕

GLOSS:"To be afraid" [(Tang) Han Yu].
GLOSS-NOTE:The graph occurs first in SW, but with a different meaning (Wáng Lì 1958: 576).
	Perh. an archaic colloquialism of the next item (so Wáng Lì 1982: 176): pù 怖.
	[E] Note Lushai pʰɔɔkᶠ (Lorrain phâwk) ``to startle, frighten''; perhaps also PMon *phiic ``be afraid'' (for the vowels, see {§11.1.3}).
::PMon	*phiic	``be afraid''
>:Note Lushai pʰɔɔkᶠ  ``to startle, frighten''
>:perhaps also PMon *phiic ``be afraid''

HEAD:páng 旁傍
MC:Middle Chinese: bwâŋ 
LH:Later Han: bɑŋ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *bâŋ

ENTRY:2790

ENTRY:2791
HEAD:pàng₂ □
GLOSS:"Hollow" in Min dialects: PMin *pʰaŋᶜ ~ *pʰoŋᶜ.
	<> Tai: Saek phooŋᶜ² ``hollow, hole'' (in a tree, bamboo); PSBahn. *pɔːŋ ``hollow, flattened''.
	Words with the notion ``hollow'' tend to be aspirated ({§5.8.6}).
::Saek	phooŋᶜ²	``hollow, hole''

ENTRY:2794
HEAD:pēi₁ 胚
MC:Middle Chinese: pʰuậi 
LH:Later Han: pʰə 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *phə̂
GLOSS:"One month pregnant" [SW].
	[E] AA: OKhmer /pdəj/ ``burden'' > ``pregnancy'' > ``vaulted'' (surface of earth), ``stomach, abdomen'' (Jenner / Pou 1982: 156). The word belongs to an AA wf which includes {méi₆ 媒禖} ``match-maker'' and {dài₉ 戴} ``to bear''.
	Wáng Lì (1982: 105) already connected this word with {méi₆ 媒禖}.
	Alternative: PTB *paːy ``pregnant'' [HPTB: 210], but the finals do not agree.
::PTB	*paːy	``pregnant''
>:AA:
>:OKhmer /pdəj/ ``burden'' > ``pregnancy'' > ``vaulted'' , ``stomach, abdomen'' . The word belongs to an AA wf which includes {méi₆ 媒禖} ``match-maker'' and {dài₉ 戴} ``to bear''

ENTRY:2807
HEAD:péng₅-lái 蓬萊
MC:Middle Chinese: buŋ-lậi 
LH:Later Han: boŋ-ləi ?
	A legendary island of the immortals (xiān 仙) in the eastern sea [Shānhǎijīng, Shǐjì], usually identified as the Bohai sea. Etymology not clear.
	However, resemblance to a SE Asian word for ``sea, ocean'' is striking: WB paŋ-lai ``ocean'', JP paŋ³³-lai³³ id.
	This etymon looks like a loan, possibly from MK: Khmer dhle /tlé/ ``expanse of water'' ⪤ OKhmer danle(y) /dənlee/ ``lake, sea'' (with nasal infix) (Jenner / Pou 1982: 323); Khmer ⇒ Pearic thəleː ``sea'' ⇒ Thai tʰalee id.
	Occasionally, an AA nasal infix (as in /dənlee/) is reinterpreted as the root initial which can lead to a change in the initial consonant such as d > b.
	For an illustration for such reinterpretation and initial consonant substitution in AA, see {§2.6.2}.
::Pearic	thəleː	``sea''

HEAD:péng₆ 篷
	{fān₂} 帆

ENTRY:2812
HEAD:pī₃ 披
MC:Middle Chinese: pʰje 3 
LH:Later Han: pʰɨai 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *phai
GLOSS:"Divide, separate, disperse" [Zuo].
	[E] ST *pai: PL *bay¹ ``to separate''; WT dbye-ba ``parting, division, section, part'' ⪤ dbyen-pa ``difference, discord'' ⪤ ’bye-ba ``to separate, open'' (intr.) (WT medial y  is secondary before e); JP bjek³¹ ``to divide''. Lushai pʰelᴴ ``split, break'' may belong to {bàn₂,biàn 釆}.
	For an overview of similar items, see {Table P-1} [ Separate, open, split, break ]; for possible allofams, see {lí₁₀ 離}. ◇
::Lushai	pʰelᴴ	``split, break''
>:ST *pai:
>:PL *bay¹ ``to separate''
>:WT dbye-ba ``parting, division, section, part'' ⪤ dbyen-pa ``difference, discord'' ⪤ ’bye-ba ``to separate, open''
>:JP bjek³¹ ``to divide''. Lushai pʰelᴴ ``split, break'' may belong to {bàn₂,biàn 釆}

ENTRY:2813
HEAD:pī₄ 劈
MC:Middle Chinese: pʰiek 
LH:Later Han: pʰek 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *phêk
GLOSS:"To split" (wood) [SW].
GLOSS-NOTE:SW glosses it with pò 破 *phâih; Duàn Yùcái, Wáng Lì (1982: 102f) associate this word with {pì₇ 副}
GLOSS:"split".
	[E] ST: JP pʰjaʔ⁵⁵ < pʰjak⁵⁵ ``split open''. Also, or alternatively, this could be an ``abrupt end'' final *-k derivation ({§6.1.2}) from either {pī₃ 披} *phai or {pò₁ 破} *phâih.
	For an overview over similar items, see {Table P-1}; for possible allofams, see {lí₁₀ 離}.
>:JP pʰjaʔ⁵⁵ < pʰjak⁵⁵ ``split open''. Also, or alternatively, this could be an ``abrupt end'' final *-k derivation  from either {pī₃ 披} *phai or {pò₁ 破} *phâih

ENTRY:2814

OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *bai

	[T] ONW be  —
	[D] PMin *pʰueᴬ²
	[E] Wáng Lì (1982: 446), following Shìmíng, relates this word to {bèi₆ 被} ``cover, wear'' which is plausible, see there for the ST etymology. Shafer (IST: 62) relates pí to Kachin pʰyi ``skin, bark'' as well as WT pʰyi ``outside'', but this is doubtful, see {bǐ₁ 比}.
	Syn. {fǔ₉ 膚}.
::WT	pʰyi	``outside''

ENTRY:2819
HEAD:pí₅ 貔
MC:Middle Chinese: bi 4 
LH:Later Han: bi 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *bi
	Prob. ``leopard, panther'' [Shi, SW]. Acc. to FY 8.2 and Guō Pú, pí had ancient dialect variants which are discussed under {lí₃ 貍}.
	In old texts pí refers to a large panther-like cat, whereas {lí₃ 貍} and its dialect variants refer to a small cat-like animal.
	Apparently these two animals were confused by Han and esp. the commentator Guō Pú's time (d. 324 AD) due to lack of familiarity with wildlife.
	[E] Prob. ST: WT dbyi ``lynx'' (IST: 59).
	WT byi in byi-la ~ bi-la, bi-ši ``cat'' seems to be cognate, but it may derive from Indic instead: Hindi billā ``cat'' (Jaeschke: 376), Nepali billi <- Skt biḍālaḥ which comes in turn prob. from a non-Aryan source (Buck 1949, no. 3.62), note Kharia blileg, Dravidian billi et al. (Mei / Norman 1971: 100).
	On the other hand, bi-ši (ši < ži ``cat'' ?) may suggest that byi is a native morpheme after all.
::Hindi	billā	``cat''
>:Prob. ST:
>:WT dbyi ``lynx''

ENTRY:2820

MC:Middle Chinese: bjie 4 
LH:Later Han: bie 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *be
	[T]  ONW bie
GLOSS:"Spleen, bile" [Li].
	[E] ST: PTB *r-pay ``spleen'': JP pāi, Mru pai [Löffler 1966: 148], but Angami Naga ú-prì, Mikir pli-ha < *-i (Matisoff 1995a: 43; also Matisoff 1978: 217: *pay ~ *play), Garo pilai, Chepang leh (Weidert 1987: 29). Note also PTai *ʔbl/riᴬ¹ (Luo 2000: 85).
>:PTB *r-pay ``spleen'':
>:JP pāi
>:Mru pai , but Angami Naga ú-prì
>:Mikir pli-ha < *-i
>:Garo pilai, Chepang leh . Note also PTai *ʔbl/riᴬ¹

ENTRY:2821
HEAD:pí₇ 罷疲
MC:Middle Chinese: bje 3 
LH:Later Han: bɨɑi 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *bai
	[T]  ONW be
GLOSS:"Weary, exhausted" 疲 [Zuo],
GLOSS:"emaciated" [Guan];
GLOSS:"to wear out, exhaust" 罷 [Zuo].
	[E] ST: PTB *bal (STC no. 29) > Bahing bal ``tired, weary''; WB panᴮ ``tired'' (HST: 150) ⪤ pʰaᴮ ``fatigued'' (as horses), JP ba⁵⁵ ``tired'' ⪤ ban³¹ ‘tired. WT brgyal is prob. unrelated, see {lí₁₁ 離}.
	<> The relationship with Tai is not clear: S. pʰliaᴬ² < *b- ``weary, exhausted'' ⪤ plɨaᶜ¹ < *p- ``to wear out, exhaust'' (Manomaivibool 1975: 127f; 206).
	Allofam {bì₁₀ 敝弊斃} (Pulleyblank 1962: 215).
	For additional comments, see {fèi₆ 廢}.
::JP	ba⁵⁵	``tired''
>:PTB *bal  >
>:Bahing bal ``tired, weary''
>:WB panᴮ ``tired''  ⪤ pʰaᴮ ``fatigued''
>:JP ba⁵⁵ ``tired'' ⪤ ban³¹ ‘tired. WT brgyal is prob. unrelated, see {lí₁₁ 離}

ENTRY:2822
HEAD:pǐ₁ 匹
MC:Middle Chinese: pʰjiet 4 
LH:Later Han: pʰit 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *phit
GLOSS:"A pair, a set of male and female" (as husband and wife; as pǐ-niǎo 匹鳥
GLOSS:"mandarin ducks") [Shi] >
GLOSS:"one of a pair, peer" [BI, Shi, EY], ``a mate'' [Liji], ``a single one'' [Meng], ``opponent'' [Zuo] > measure word for horses [BI, Shu]; ``to match'' [Shi, Shu].
	[E] Etymology not certain. There is a remote possibility that pǐ may be related to an AA word for ``two'', *bar, but in Khmer which has similarities with OC: pìː(r) ``two''.
	The final AA -r would be lost in OC after a long vowel ({§6.9}), the OC final -t may represent the nominalizing suffix ({§6.2.1}).
	Alternatively, the Lushai word cited under {bì₂₄ 畢} ``fork'' could belong here instead.
>:Etymology not certain. There is a remote possibility that pǐ may be related to an AA word for ``two'', *bar, but in Khmer which has similarities with OC:
>:pìː ``two''

ENTRY:2823
HEAD:pǐ₂ 匹
MC:Middle Chinese: pʰjiet 4 
LH:Later Han: pʰit 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *phit
GLOSS:"A unit for measuring cloth, equal to four zhàng 丈" [SW].
	[E] Etymology not clear, possibly a special application of {pǐ₁ 匹}. On the other hand, the word is reminiscent of the TB word for ``four'' *bli(s/t).
>:Etymology not clear, possibly a special application of {pǐ₁ 匹}. On the other hand, the word is reminiscent of the TB word for ``four'' *bli

ENTRY:2824
HEAD:pǐ₃ 鴄
MC:Middle Chinese: pʰjiet 4 
LH:Later Han: pʰit 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *phit
GLOSS:"Duck" 匹 [Liji].
	[E] Area word. Tai: S. and Tai lgs in general petᴰ¹ ``duck'' (Manomaivibool 1975: 331).
	<> AA: Viet. vit, NBahn. pĕt, but Bahnar bip, Sedang pèap ``duck'' [K. Smith, LTBA 2.1 (n.d.): 8]. <> TB: Lolo-Zaiwa et al. pje̱t⁵⁵ ``duck'', Geman Deng kɹɑi³⁵-pit⁵⁵, perhaps also JP kʰai³³-pjek⁵⁵, WB bʰaiᴮ ``duck''.
	The source is prob.
	AA. Some of these forms show that this is not the same word as {pǐ₁ 匹} ``a pair''.
::WB	bʰaiᴮ	``duck''
>:Area word. Tai:
>:S. and Tai lgs in general petᴰ¹ ``duck''

ENTRY:2833
HEAD:pì₆ 闢
MC:Middle Chinese: bjiäk 4 
LH:Later Han: biek 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *bek < *bai-k
GLOSS:"To open, open up, enlarge" tr. [BI, Shi].
	[E] ST *pe: WT ’byed-pa, pʰyes, dbye ``to open'' (HST: 114); Lushai pʰenᴿ < pʰenʔ ``to open''; perhaps related to Thakali pʰle ``lɔ ‘to open up''. Also, or alternatively, this could be an ``abrupt end'' (``open up'') final -k derivation ({§6.1.2}) of {pī₃ 披} ``divide''.
	[C] Allofam {bī₁ 屄}. TB cognates indicate that {bǎi₂ 捭} ``to open'' may not be related.
	For an overview over similar items, see {Table P-1} under {pī₃ 披}; for possible allofams, see {lí₁₀ 離}.

>:Lushai pʰenᴿ < pʰenʔ ``to open''
>:perhaps related to Thakali pʰle ``lɔ ‘to open up''. Also, or alternatively, this could be an ``abrupt end''  final -k derivation  of {pī₃ 披} ``divide''

ENTRY:2865
HEAD:pò₁ 破
MC:Middle Chinese: pʰuâᶜ 
LH:Later Han: pʰɑiᶜ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *phâih
GLOSS:"To break" [Shi], in southern dialects it is a synonym of {pī₄ 劈}
GLOSS:"split wood".
	[T] Sin Sukchu SR p'wɔ (去)
	[T] MGZY phwo (去) [p'wɔ]
	[T] ONW pʰɑ
	[<] exoactive of {pī₃ 披} *phai ``separate'' ({§4.3.2}). CH aspiration is associated with forceful motion {§5.8.5}.
	[E] ST: WB paiᶜ ``broken off, chipped, hare-lipped'' ⪤ pʰaiᶜ break off in small pieces’ (Matisoff 1995a: 85); Dhimal bai ``break'', Lushai peʔᴸ < pes ``to break, be broken'' [STC no. 254], JP pʰjai³³ ``break'' ⪤ pʰjeʔ⁵⁵ < pʰjek⁵⁵ ``break'', also JP bjak³¹ ``break''. The rime may in fact have been PTB *ol, if Tamang ¹pʰol ``break up lumps of soil'' [Mazaudon 1973: 130], Lepcha pʰol-pʰol ``brittle, frangible'' (of earth) ⪤ pʰyol-pʰyol ``crumbling, falling to pieces'' [Sun LTBA 16.2: 148] should be related.
	Late Han ⇒ Tai: S. pʰaaᴮ¹ < *pʰ- ``to split, cut'' (Li F. 1976: 41) (a pre-Han loan would have the Tai final *-ai).
	For an overview over similar items, see {Table P-1} under {pī₃ 披}; for possible allofams, see {lí₁₀ 離}.
::Lepcha	pʰol-pʰol	``brittle, frangible''
>:WB paiᶜ ``broken off, chipped, hare-lipped'' ⪤ pʰaiᶜ break off in small pieces’
>:Dhimal bai ``break''
>:Lushai peʔᴸ < pes ``to break, be broken''
>:JP pʰjai³³ ``break'' ⪤ pʰjeʔ⁵⁵ < pʰjek⁵⁵ ``break'', also JP bjak³¹ ``break''. The rime may in fact have been PTB *ol, if Tamang ¹pʰol ``break up lumps of soil''
>:Lepcha pʰol-pʰol ``brittle, frangible''  ⪤ pʰyol-pʰyol ``crumbling, falling to pieces''  should be related

ENTRY:2868
HEAD:pò₄ 魄
MC:Middle Chinese: pʰɐk 
LH:Later Han: pʰak 
OC:Old Chinese: *phrâk
GLOSS:"Vegetative or animal soul" of a person [Zuo] which accounts for growth and physiological functions, for
GLOSS:"life"; as opposed to {hún₁ 魂}
GLOSS:"spiritual soul" which makes a human personality.
	[E] Pò ``soul'' is the same word as {pò₅ 霸魄} ``aspect of the moon''. With the first development of a foetus grows the vegetative soul jì shēng pò 既生魄 [Zuo: Zhao 7], the same phrase is used for phases of the moon. Pò, the soul responsible for growth, is the same as pò the waxing and waning of the moon (Ying-shi Yü JAS 41, 1981: 83).
	The meaning ``soul'' has probably been transferred from the moon since men must have been aware of lunar phases long before they had developed theories on the soul.
	This is supported by the etymology ``bright'', and by the inverted word order which can only have originated with meteorological expressions, see {pò₅ 霸魄}.
	The association with the moon explains perhaps why the pò ``soul'' is classified as Yin (see for example Matisoff 1978: 268) in spite of the etymology ``bright'' (which should be Yang), hún's Yang classification may be due to the association with clouds and by extension sky, even though the word invokes ``dark''. ``Soul'' and ``moon'' are related in other cultures, by cognition or convergence, as in TB: PLB *s/ʔ-la³ ``moon, soul, spirit'' (HPTB: 39), WT bla ``soul'' ⪤ zla ``moon'', PMY *bḷaᴬ/ᶜ ``spirit, soul, moon'' (Benedict ICSTLL 1989: 8).
	Pò is related to {bái₁ 白} ``white'' (Carr CAAAL 24, 1985: 62).
	The connection, if any, with MK comparanda is not clear: Khmer braḥ ``devil, spirit'', Stieng brah, Chrau m’brãh; AA ⇒ Lepcha blyak ``devil, spirit'' (Forrest JAOS 82, 1962: 333).
::Lepcha	blyak	``devil, spirit''
>:Pò ``soul'' is the same word as {pò₅ 霸魄} ``aspect of the moon''. With the first development of a foetus grows the vegetative soul jì shēng pò 既生魄 , the same phrase is used for phases of the moon. Pò, the soul responsible for growth, is the same as pò the waxing and waning of the moon

ENTRY:2869
HEAD:pò₅ 霸魄
MC:Middle Chinese: pʰɐk 
LH:Later Han: pʰak 
OC:Old Chinese: *phrâk
GLOSS:"An aspect of the moon", prob. originally
GLOSS:"brightness": jì shēng pò 既生霸
GLOSS:"after the brightness pò has grown" = ``second quarter of the lunar month'', and jì sǐ pò 既死霸 ``after the brightness has died'' (i.e. prob. ``has started to die'') = ``last quarter of the lunar month'' [BI] (Shaughnessy 1991: 136ƒƒ). In this phrase, the subject pò follows the verb as in meteorological phenomena (note xià yǔ 下雨 ``rain falls'', see Gabelentz 1881,  p. 144).
	[E] This is the same word as {pò₄ 魄} and cognate to {bái₁ 白} ``white'' (Ying-shi Yü JAS 41, 1981: 83; Shaughnessy; Matisoff ``Stars, moon, spirit'', ICSTLL 1978); TB languages also associate ``moon'' with ``white'' [French 1983: 578f].
>:This is the same word as {pò₄ 魄} and cognate to {bái₁ 白} ``white''
>:TB languages also associate ``moon'' with ``white''

GLOSS:"in a natural state, unworked", as in pú 朴

ENTRY:2880
HEAD:pǔ₁ 浦
MC:Middle Chinese: pʰuoᴮ 
LH:Later Han: pʰɑᴮ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *phâʔ
	(The Huái) ``river bank'' [Shi]; ``(bank) on a cove, inlet'' (along the Yangtze river) [Guoce, Yuèjuè shū]. In OC, this is only a reginal word restricted to the east and south of the Huai River, it is to this day found in place names in the same area, i.e. in the ancient Wú, Yuè and Chǔ lands.
	Guō Pú (d. 324 AD) confirms that pǔ ``bay, cove, inlet'' is a Jiāngnán (i.e. a southern dialect) word (Norman 1983: 206).
	[E] MK: Viet phá < pʰaʔ ``inlet, cove'' (Norman). This word is prob. indirectly related to PKS *pwaŋᴮ ``bank, shore'', Tai: Saek viaŋᶜ¹ ``bank of a river'' by way of the *-ʔ ~ *-ŋ alternation ({§3.2.4}).
	Less likely, KT may belong to {fáng₁ 坊防} ``dyke''.
	Pǔ is unrelated to pō 頗坡 (under {bēi₂,bī 陂}).
::PKS	*pwaŋᴮ	``bank, shore''
>:Viet phá < pʰaʔ ``inlet, cove'' . This word is prob. indirectly related to PKS *pwaŋᴮ ``bank, shore''
>:Tai:
>:Saek viaŋᶜ¹ ``bank of a river'' by way of the *-ʔ ~ *-ŋ alternation

ENTRY:2885

MK ⇒ Tai: S. krasípᴰ²-krasâapᴰ².
	[C] Perh. qī 緝 ``to babble'' [Shi] is the same word.

ENTRY:2889

GLOSS:"cold" > hánxīn 寒心
GLOSS:"disheartened".
	[E] Outside etymological connections are not certain, there are several possibilities: (1) WT bsil-ba ``cool'' (CVST 4: 29), JP gă³¹-tsi³³ ``cold'', Lushai sikᴸ < tsik ``cold''. (2) WT (b)ser, gser-bu ``a fresh, cold breeze, feeling cold'', WB chiᴮ (< *-e) ``frost, hoarfrost''. (3) MK *cŋiit ``cold'' (Shorto 2006 #976) (a foreign medial nasal as well as a final consonant after a long vowel are typically lost in Chinese).

ENTRY:2890
HEAD:qī₅ 漆

GLOSS:"Lacquer tree, lacquer, varnish" [Shi].

	The etymology of the apparent WT cognate rtsi ``juice, lacquer'' is ambiguous, though, as that word could also derive from rhji < rhi ({§12.9} (1)) and thus be cognate to Lushai tʰalᴿ-hritᴸ ``lac, sealing wax'' (mentioned by Unger ibid.) and ultimately derive from PTB *ri ``water'' > WB re ``water'' (Gong BIHP 51.3, 1980).

ENTRY:2898
HEAD:qí₆ 騎
MC:Middle Chinese: gjie 3

	[T] Sui-Tang gi < ONW ge

	[E] The word is prob. related to {hè₁ 何荷} ``carry'' (on the back, including on a beast of burden), hence endopass. ({§4.6}) ``let oneself be carried'' (on the back of an animal). Alternatively, the word may be connected with the wf {zhī₄ 支枝肢} ``branch'', hence ``spreading one's legs'', although the OC rimes are different (*-e).

ENTRY:2900
HEAD:qí₇ 其
MC:Middle Chinese: gji 
LH:Later Han: gɨə 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *gə
	Pronoun ``this'' [Shi, Shu] (Dobson, Songs: 168); 3rd person possessive pron. ``his, her, its, their, my, our'' [BI, Shi, Shu].
	[T] Sin Sukchu SR gi (平)
	[T] MGZY ki (平) [gi]
	[T] ONW giə
	[N] Third person possessive is the most common use of qí. In Early Zhou texts it also serves occasionally as a genitive particle, syn. of {zhī₁ 之}.
	[D] Qí has survived as a 3rd person pron. in Wú dialects: Dānyáng, Hángzhōu, Shàoxīng kəʔᴰ¹ or keʔᴰ¹, Sūzh keᴬ¹, Wēnzhōu kiᴰ¹ (Norman 1988: 118, 203).
	[E] The origin of qí is not certain because in the linguistic area pronouns tend to be of the shape KV (K = velar stop). Qí may be ST: Lushai kʰiᶠ < kʰiiʔ ``that'', WT genitive suffix -kyi, -gyi, -’i (Bodman 1980: 185), but we should expect a TB /a/ in this set.
	Alternatively, PAA *ki/ke ~ *ku/ko ``third person pronoun'' whose earliest form is perhaps *kɨ [Pinnow 1965: 38] appears to be phonologically closest to the OC word.
	This word looks like an unstressed ə-vowel form of {qú₂ 渠} ``he'' ({§11.2.1}), but outside cognates as well as its non-clitic use make this unlikely.
::PAA	*ki/ke ~ *ku/ko	``third person pronoun''
>:The origin of qí is not certain because in the linguistic area pronouns tend to be of the shape KV . Qí may be ST:
>:Lushai kʰiᶠ < kʰiiʔ ``that''
>:WT genitive suffix -kyi, -gyi, -’i , but we should expect a TB /a/ in this set

ENTRY:2912

ENTRY:2917
HEAD:qǐ₂ 杞

LH:Later Han: kʰɨəᴮ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *khəʔ
GLOSS:"Willow" [Shi], Lycium chinense, a kind of creeper [Shi].
	Unger (Hao-ku 38, 1992: 76) relates this word to WT kʰri-šiŋ ``a creeper'', lit. ``winding wood'' < ’kʰri-ba ``to wind round''; he adds qí 萁 (gjɨ) ``stalks of pulse'' [Huainan], i.e. ``runner, climber'', and suggests a possible connection with {jī₆ 箕} ``basket''.

ENTRY:2924
HEAD:qǐ₇ 綮 ⪤ qǐ 啟
MC:Middle Chinese: kʰieiᴮ 
LH:Later Han: kʰeiᴮ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *khîʔ 
OCB:Baxter Old Chinese: *khijʔ
	[T] ONW kʰėi
GLOSS:"To open, open up, start, enlighten" [BI, Shi],
GLOSS:"clear (of the sky)" [OB];
GLOSS:"to kneel" [Shi] (< ``bend in the joint''); ``to bow down (the head) to the ground'' 稽 [Zhouli].
GLOSS-NOTE:The fundamental meaning was ‘bend / open something hinged, something with a joint like a door.
	The word qǐ 啟 ``open'' was tabooed after the death of Emperor Jǐng Dì 景帝 in 140 BC and was replaced by {kāi 開}, acc. to JDSW (Sagart 1999: 76).
	[C] A possible allofam is {jī₁₄ 機璣} ``mechanism''.
	[E] Prob. related to Khmer kēka /kaaɛk/ ``to bend out at midpoint'' (horns, arms) ⪤ kēṅa /kaaɛŋ/ ``form or present a sharp angle, bent sharply''; Khmer has no syllable of the type kiik; for the absence of final *-k in OC, see {§6.9}.
::Khmer	kēka /kaaɛk/	``to bend out at midpoint''
>:Prob. related to Khmer kēka /kaaɛk/ ``to bend out at midpoint''  ⪤ kēṅa /kaaɛŋ/ ``form or present a sharp angle, bent sharply''
>:Khmer has no syllable of the type kiik
>:for the absence of final *-k in OC, see {§6.9}

ENTRY:2934
HEAD:qì₇ 葺
MC:Middle Chinese: tsʰjəp 
LH:Later Han: tsʰip 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *tshəp or *tship (< *s-ʔip)
GLOSS:"To thatch a roof, cover, repair" [Zuo, Zhouli].
	[<] *ʔip + ST caus. s-prefix ({§5.9.1}).
	[E] ST: WT skyibs (< *s-ʔips) ``a shelter from above'' (from rain etc.); prob. also cognate to NNaga *ciup ``roof'' One of the sources of WT sk- has been shown to be *s-ʔ-; the etymon is therefore derived from ST *ʔip: WT yib ``eaves, shed'' ⪤ yib-pa ``to hide oneself, place of concealment'', Lushai uupᶠ ``be sheltered from wind, free from draughts''. For the *up ~ *ip alternations, see {§11.5.1}.
	Prob. related to {yì₈ 邑} ``settlement''.
::Lushai	uupᶠ	``be sheltered from wind, free from draughts''

>:prob. also cognate to NNaga *ciup ``roof'' One of the sources of WT sk- has been shown to be *s-ʔ-
>:the etymon is therefore derived from ST *ʔip:
>:WT yib ``eaves, shed'' ⪤ yib-pa ``to hide oneself, place of concealment''
>:Lushai uupᶠ ``be sheltered from wind, free from draughts''

	[N] Phonetic is {rén₁ 人} (ńźjen) ``human being'' (Pulleyblank 1962: 133; Baxter 1992: 223), the initial is parallel to {qī₁ 七}. Alternatively, the tsʰ- initial may anticipate a development which is commonly found in Mǐn dialects, see {xū₄ 須鬚} < *sn- for an example.

	[D] Most Mand. and Wú dialects derive the word from an aspirated velar initial, e.g. W-Wēnzhōu kʰa⁴⁴ because re-etymologization ({§2.8}) may have connected it with qiān 掔 ``solid, hard'' (under {jiān₂ 堅}).

ENTRY:2955

ENTRY:2960
HEAD:qián₉ 錢
MC:Middle Chinese: dzjän 
LH:Later Han: dzian 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *dzan
GLOSS:"Coin" [Guoyu].
	[T] Sin Sukchu SR dzjen (平)
	[T] MGZY tsen (平) [dzɛn]
	[T] ONW dzian
	[E] Early coins had the shapes of spades and knives; therefore qián is a derivation from jiǎn (Qiu Xigui 2000: 259). Alternatively Boltz (1994: 100) explains qián as ``a fragment, token''; Wáng Shèngměi (Song Dyn.) considers qián derived from {qiǎn₂ 淺} ``shallow'' > ``thin'' (Qiu Xigui 2000: 258f).
	Qián is loaned into PMY as *dziɴᴬ (Purnell 1970) ``money'', and OJapanese as zeni (Miyake 1997: 186).
::Boltz	explains qián as	``a fragment, token''
>:Early coins had the shapes of spades and knives
>:therefore qián is a derivation from jiǎn . Alternatively Boltz  explains qián as ``a fragment, token''
>:Wáng Shèngměi  considers qián derived from {qiǎn₂ 淺} ``shallow'' > ``thin''

ENTRY:2962
HEAD:qiǎn₁ 遣
MC:Middle Chinese: kʰjiänᴮ 4 
LH:Later Han: kʰianᴮ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *khenʔ
	[T] ONW kʰian
GLOSS:"To send to, send away" [BI, Shi],
GLOSS:"let go" [Zuo].
	[E] ST: WT skyel-ba ``to send'' (Unger Hao-ku 35, 1986: 30). Loss of a ST pre-initial could be responsible for aspiration {§5.8.1}.
>:WT skyel-ba ``to send'' . Loss of a ST pre-initial could be responsible for aspiration {§5.8.1}

GLOSS:"Satisfied" 慊 [Meng], 愜 [Guoce].
GLOSS-NOTE:Holding something in the mouth can be a metaphor for an emotional state, therefore these words may be derived from qiǎn 嗛.
	[E] There is prob. no connection with {hán₁ 含函} (so Wáng Lì 1982: 605). On the other hand, this wf may belong to {jiān₇ 兼} in the sense of ``holding the jaws together''.
	However, note Lushai kʰamᴿ < kʰamʔ (< *-ʔ) ``be satisfied, satiated; be tired of, stiff'' (but without medial -l-).
::Lushai	kʰamᴿ < kʰamʔ (< *-ʔ)	``be satisfied, satiated; be tired of, stiff''

OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *khams
GLOSS:"To yawn" [Liji].

	[T] MGZY khem (去) [k'ɛm].
	[D] The Cantonese initial in haamᶜ¹ ``to yawn'' is a regular reflex of earlier kʰ-.
	[E] ST *k-ham: (1) PTB *kam: Chepang kamh ``to yawn'', JP gă³¹-kʰam³¹ ``yawn'' [Weidert 1987: 29]. (2) PTB *ham: Lepcha hóm (< *kʰam) ``to gape, yawn'' ⪤ hyóm (< *kʰjam) ``to gasp'' (Bodman 1980: 160); Lushai haamᴸ / hamᶠ (< haams / haamʔ) ``to gape, yawn, to have a gap''. CH aspiration is associated with the meaning ``hollow, empty'' {§5.8.6} and with exhaling {§5.8.5}.

ENTRY:2974

ENTRY:2975
HEAD:qiàn₃ 倩綪 ⪤ xīng 騂
MC:Middle Chinese: sjäŋ 
LH:Later Han: sieŋ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *seŋ
GLOSS:"Red" [Zhouli],
GLOSS:"reddish brown: red horse, red sacrificial animal" [Shi].
	The reason for the different final nasals is not clear (provided these words are cognates).
	It is tempting to relate this wf to Lushai senᴴ ``red'', Tiddim san (so CVST 4: 22); however, the TB etymon derives from PTB *tyan (STC: 15-16 n. 63).
::Lushai	senᴴ	``red''

ENTRY:2976
HEAD:qiāng₁ 羌
MC:Middle Chinese: kʰjaŋ 
LH:Later Han: kʰɨɑŋ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *khaŋ or *khiaŋ ?
	Name of different western TB tribes from Shang OB down to the present.
	The graph implies that these people raised sheep.
	Pulleyblank (1983: 418f) suggests that the name is derived from {yáng₁ 羊} ``sheep'' which is also phonetic, although the SW states that the graph is a semantic compound.
	However, the name Qiāng may be a foreign word which brings to mind WT skyoŋ-ba, bskyaŋs ``to guard, keep, tend'' (animals), PTB *kyoŋ (STC no. 161), Qiāng means then ``herders''.
	The Tib. word is cognate to {yǎng₂ 養} ``nourish, feed, rear''.
	The clan name Jiāng 姜 (kjaŋ)  MTang kiaŋ < kaŋ, ONW kaŋ (of Rong / Zhou provenance) is not necessarily connected to Qiāng, SW says that yáng ``sheep'' is only phonetic (Pulleyblank EC 25, 2000: 16).
::WT	skyoŋ-ba, bskyaŋs	``to guard, keep, tend''

ENTRY:2977
HEAD:qiāng₂ 椌
MC:Middle Chinese: kʰåŋ 
LH:Later Han: kʰɔŋ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *khrôŋ
GLOSS:"A hollow wooden beaten instrument of music" [Li].
	[E] Etymology not certain, perhaps related to Mru kʰoŋ ``wooden drum'' (Löffler 1966: 142). The OC word may be a derivation with caus. *r ({§7.5}) from {kōng 空} ``hollow'', lit. a thing made empty’.
	Alternatively, note Khmer /khòoŋ/ ``be sunken, hollow, concave'' ⪤ /krɑhòoŋ/ ``hollow, hole, rut'' (Jenner / Pou 1982: 397).
	CH aspiration is associated with the meaning ``hollow, empty'' {§5.8.6}.
::Khmer	/khòoŋ/	``be sunken, hollow, concave''
>:Etymology not certain, perhaps related to Mru kʰoŋ ``wooden drum'' . The OC word may be a derivation with caus. *r  from {kōng 空} ``hollow'', lit. a thing made empty’

ENTRY:3015
HEAD:qīn₁ 侵
MC:Middle Chinese: tsʰjəm 
LH:Later Han: tsʰim 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *k-səm ?
GLOSS:"Invade, encroach upon" [Shi].

	[T] MGZY tshim (平) [ts'im]
	[T] ONW tsʰim
	[E] Two ST etymologies are possible: (1) WT stim-pa, bstims ``enter, penetrate'' ⪤ tʰim-pa ~ ’tʰim-pa ``be absorbed, disappear'' (so Bodman 1980: 57). The WT items do agree just as well with {jìn₂ 浸} ``soak'' with which qīn may be related. (2) The CH graph shows a broom, hence perhaps cognate to Nung šim ``to sweep'', Miri səm-pek ``broom'' (pek ``to sweep''), Maru šam < *sim ``to sweep'' (Benedict HJAS 4, 1939: 226f; STC: 170; HPTB: 305).
	CH aspiration is associated with forceful motion {§5.8.5}.

ENTRY:3017
HEAD:qīn₃ 衾
MC:Middle Chinese: kʰjəm 
LH:Later Han: kʰɨm 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *khəm
GLOSS:"A blanket, coverlet" [Shi].
	[E] Etymology not clear. (1) The word could perhaps be  a k-prefix concrete noun derived from {yīn₅ 陰} ``overcast'', i.e. ``covered'' ({§5.9.4}; {§5.4}). Comparanda may include: (2) WB kʰrum ~ kʰyum ``cover, overspread'' (by plants), WT grum-če ``thick woolen blanket'' (CVST 5: 109). (3) WT kʰyim ``house'' (i.e. ``shelter, cover'') which is derived from TB *im; but see {yì₈ 邑}.
::WT	kʰyim	``house''

ENTRY:3020
HEAD:qīn₅ 親
MC:Middle Chinese: tsʰjen 
LH:Later Han: tsʰin 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *tshin < *snhin 
OCB:Baxter Old Chinese: *tshjin
GLOSS:"A close person, parents, affectionate" [Shi, Shu],
GLOSS:"oneself, personally" [Shi, Shu, BI],
GLOSS:"to love" (such as parents, siblings, children) [Meng].
	[T] Sin Sukchu SR ts'in (平)
	[T] MGZY tshin (平) [ts'in]
	[T] ONW tsʰin
	[E] Etymology not certain. One ancient commentator remarks that anciently qīn sounded like qiān 千 *snhîn by which he may, or may not, have been pointing to an n-initial ({§5.9.1}.1); if the word had an n-initial, it could be related to {rén₂ 仁} (so Boodberg 1937: 362), especially considering the overlapping meanings ``to love''.
	More likely, qīn is related to the stem {jí₇ 即} ``approach > be close'' with the nominalizing n-final ({§6.4.3}), then lit. ``persons close to oneself, close ones''; the meaning ``oneself'' is more likely to derive from the notion ``close'' than from ``to love''.
	Furthermore, WT has a semantic parallel: gñen ``a kinsman, relative'' < ñe-ba ``be near, approach''.
>:Etymology not certain. One ancient commentator remarks that anciently qīn sounded like qiān 千 *snhîn by which he may, or may not, have been pointing to an n-initial
>:if the word had an n-initial, it could be related to {rén₂ 仁} , especially considering the overlapping meanings ``to love''

ENTRY:3021
HEAD:qín₁ 秦
MC:Middle Chinese: dzjen 
LH:Later Han: dzin 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *dzin
	[T] ONW dzin
	The western state of Qín and the dynasty.
	Qín is often thought to be the source of ancient European words for ``China'': Lat. ``Sina'' etc., modern Western languages ``China''.
	Also the word for ``silk'' may ultimately be derived from this name: Gr. sērikón, i.e. ``the Chinese one, (the stuff) from China''.
	These ancient loans suggest that the original final was *-r, not *-n (Pulleyblank 1962: 229-230).
	The graph was originally intended for zhēn (tṣjɛn) ``hazel''.

ENTRY:3022
HEAD:qín₂ 堇
MC:Middle Chinese: gjen 3 
LH:Later Han: gɨn 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *grən
GLOSS:"Clay" [SW].

HEAD:qín₃ 勤慬 ⪤ jiān 艱

OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *krə̂n
	[T] ONW kän

	[C] Perhaps cognate to {jìn₆ 饉殣} (gjenᶜ 3), but see there.

ENTRY:3026
HEAD:qín₄ 禽
MC:Middle Chinese: gjəm 
LH:Later Han: gɨm 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *gəm
	[T] ONW gim
GLOSS:"Game bird, bird, fowl" (opposite of {shòu₃ 獸}
GLOSS:"quadruped") [Zuo, EY],
GLOSS:"game" (animal) [Yi].
	[E] Etymology not certain. It appears to be the same word as {qín₅ 擒} ``catch'' (animals etc.) and would thus be parallel to shòu 狩 ``to hunt'' ~ {shòu₃ 獸} ``wild animal''.
	However, the similarity with the common AA word for ``bird'' is striking:
	AA: PVM -ciːm ``bird'' [Ferlus] (the initial of Viet. căm [kəmᴸ] ``bird'' could be the result of interference from OC); PMon *kɲciəm ``bird'' (general term), Kyanzittha OMon (12th cent. AD) kiñcem, Mon *həcem, LitMon gaceṁ, gacem; Nyah-Kur *kəɲciam, some dialects have ŋkyiam and the like [Diffloth 1984: 71]; Wa-Lawa *sem; Chong (Pearic) chiiʔm [Huffman 1985]. <> Note also AN: PEastern Formosan *qayam ``bird'' [Li Jen-kuei LL 5.2, 2004: 369].
	These MK items cannot be late loans from Mandarin.
	It is also unlikely that a language family would borrow a marginal OC word (the CH word for ``bird'' has been (mutatis mutandis) the equivalent of Mand. {niǎo 鳥} throughout the ages).
	Therefore early PMK *kcəm is the source for OC (there are more OC animal names of AA origin).
	The voiced velar initial may have won out in OC because of the semantic association of ``game bird'' with qín ``catch'', so that the two words converged.
	If qín ``catch'' should go back to some early MK word, the two items might have been nearly identical: note OMon ckem ``grasp'' (under {jiān₇ 兼}) vs. a hypothetical *kcem ``bird''.
::OMon	ckem	``grasp''
>:Etymology not certain. It appears to be the same word as {qín₅ 擒} ``catch''  and would thus be parallel to shòu 狩 ``to hunt'' ~ {shòu₃ 獸} ``wild animal''

ENTRY:3027
HEAD:qín₅ 擒
MC:Middle Chinese: gjəm 
LH:Later Han: gɨm 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *gəm ?
	[T] ONW gim
GLOSS:"To catch, capture" (animals, people, booty) [BI, Guoyu].
	[E] Etymology not certain. WT sgrim-pa ``to hold fast, force / twist together, squeeze in'' (Gong in W. Wang 1995: 86) is semantically rather removed from qín; PTamang *kim ``to take'' [S. Georg 1996: 309] should correspond to a MC palatal initial. The word may, however, derive from an AA variant of {jiān₇ 兼} *kêm ``grasp''.
	See also {qín₄ 禽} ``bird''.
::WT	sgrim-pa	``to hold fast, force / twist together, squeeze in''
>:Etymology not certain. WT sgrim-pa ``to hold fast, force / twist together, squeeze in''  is semantically rather removed from qín
>:PTamang *kim ``to take''  should correspond to a MC palatal initial. The word may, however, derive from an AA variant of {jiān₇ 兼} *kêm ``grasp''

ENTRY:3033
HEAD:qīng₁ 青
MC:Middle Chinese: tsʰieŋ 
LH:Later Han: tsʰeŋ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *tshêŋ < *k-sêŋ ?
GLOSS:"Green, blue" [Shi].
	[D] PMin *tsʰaŋ ``raw'' (Norman identifies the PMin form with 青, Nakajima with 生).
	[E] ST *siŋ: WT gsiŋ-ma < *k-siŋ ``pasture land, meadow'', Mikir reŋ-seŋ < *-se/iŋ ``green'', Rawang məsëŋ ``green'', măšiŋ ``blue''. This root *siŋ is identical to the ST root *siŋ ``tree, wood'' ({xīn₄ 薪}) and its CH homophone xīn 新 ``new, renew'', so that these items may also be part of this large wf.
	CH ⇒ PVM: Sách sɛŋ, Viet xanh ``blue-green''.
	A parallel stem is *saŋ, see {cāng₃ 蒼} *tshâŋ ``green''.
	For an overview of the *sriŋ ~ *sraŋ contrasts ({§11.1.3}), see {Table S-1} [ Live, fresh, green (A): *s(r)iŋ ~ *s(r)aŋ ] after {shēng₂ 生}; for an overview of *sriŋ ~ *siŋ contrasts, see {Table Q-1} [ Live, fresh, green (B): *sriŋ ~ *siŋ ] ◇
::Viet	xanh	``blue-green''
>:ST *siŋ:
>:WT gsiŋ-ma < *k-siŋ ``pasture land, meadow''
>:Mikir reŋ-seŋ < *-se/iŋ ``green''
>:Rawang məsëŋ ``green'', măšiŋ ``blue''. This root *siŋ is identical to the ST root *siŋ ``tree, wood''  and its CH homophone xīn 新 ``new, renew'', so that these items may also be part of this large wf

ENTRY:3040
HEAD:qíng₁ 情
MC:Middle Chinese: dzjäŋ 
LH:Later Han: dzieŋ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *dzeŋ
	[T] ONW dzieŋ
GLOSS:"Feelings" [Shi, Zuo],
GLOSS:"proper nature, circumstances" [Meng], or more fundamentally
GLOSS:"quality, attribute, feature" (Boltz JAOS 120.2, 2000: 225ƒƒ). The meaning ``feelings'' has led to attempts to connect the word with ST *s-niŋ ``heart'' (Benedict 1976: 170 n. 8), but the meaning ``proper nature'' suggests that this word is rather cognate to {shēng₂ 生} ``live, life'' (Boltz), although the initials are difficult to reconcile.

HEAD:qiū₄ 秋

	[E] Etymology not clear. Qiū might be cognate to {shōu 收} *nhiu ``to gather, harvest'', the QYS initial tsh- can in some instances derive from a complex pre-literate initial with a voiceless *n, as in {qī₁ 七} *tshit ``seven'' ({§5.9.1}.1).
	Alternatively, qiū might be related to the wf {zú₁ 卒} ``to end'' since vegetation dies in the fall (note that zú also refers to dead vegetation in winter).

ENTRY:3060

OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *gu 
OCB:Baxter Old Chinese: *g(r)ju
GLOSS:"To assemble" (e.g. friends) [BI, Shi] >
GLOSS:"accumulate" (e.g. merits) 逑 [Shi] >
GLOSS:"mate, companion, partner, antagonist" 仇 [Shi].
	[E] ? ST: Chepang  gu, Bodo lʏgʏ ``friend'' [Weidert 1987: 18]. <> Tai: S. kʰuuᴮ² < *g- ``pair'' (Li F. 1976: 42).
	Li suggests a connection with CH yǒu 友 ``friend'' (but see under {yòu₂ 右}) and with WT grogs ``friend'' (but see {kè₃ 客}).
::WT	grogs	``friend''
>:Chepang  gu
>:Bodo lʏgʏ ``friend'' . < > Tai:
>:S. kʰuuᴮ² < *g- ``pair''

ENTRY:3061
HEAD:qiú₅ 裘

GLOSS:"boat" (of inflated hides).
	Tamang ¹kuri ``skin'' looks similar.
::Tamang	¹kuri	``skin''

ENTRY:3062
HEAD:qiú₆ 泅
MC:Middle Chinese: zjəu 
LH:Later Han: ziu 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *s-ju or *s-lu
	[D] M-Xiàmén Fúzhōu siuᴬ² ``to swim''.
GLOSS:"To swim" [Lie].
	[E] Since this word is late, it may simply be a dialect variant of {yóu₆ 游遊}, as in some dialects original *j- becomes a fricative (note Mǐn above). Bodman (1980: 179) draws attention to a Lushai word hlew ``swim''.
>:Since this word is late, it may simply be a dialect variant of {yóu₆ 游遊}, as in some dialects original *j- becomes a fricative . Bodman  draws attention to a Lushai word hlew ``swim''

ENTRY:3063
HEAD:qiú₇,jiū 虯觓觩
MC:Middle Chinese: gjeu,kjeu 
LH:Later Han: giu,kiu 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *giu,*kiu 
OCB:Baxter Old Chinese: *g(r)jiw ?
GLOSS:"Horned dragon" 虯 [Chuci];
GLOSS:"horn-shaped, long and curved" 觓 [Guliang],  觩 [Shi].
	HST: 130 compares ``horned dragon'' with WT klu ``Nagas, serpent spirits'', but see {jiāo₄ 蛟}.
	The most likely etymology is ``twisting, wriggling'' (Carr LTBA 13.2: 151ƒƒ), note {jiǔ₃ 糾} (kjeuᴮ) ``to twist, plait''.
::WT	klu	``Nagas, serpent spirits''

ENTRY:3070
HEAD:qū₄ 驅

	An allofam may be {jū₇ 駒} ``colt''.

HEAD:qú₂ 渠佢

	[T] ONW gio (?) > gø
GLOSS:"He, she, it, they" 3rd person pron., appears in 4th~5th cent.
	AD, survives in many central and southern dialects: G-Línchuān keᴮ¹, Jīxī keᴬ²; X-Qíyáng kiᴬ¹ (Norman 1988: 118 etc), also Yuè kʰøy¹³ ``he''.

ENTRY:3082
HEAD:qù₁ 去
MC:Middle Chinese: kʰjwoᶜ 
LH:Later Han: kʰɨɑᶜ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *khah
GLOSS:"To go away" intr.,
GLOSS:"to leave" tr. [Shi]; already in early OC qù took over the function of qǔ, hence
GLOSS:"to eliminate, do away with" tr. [Zuo].
	[T] Sin Sukchu SR k'y (去)
	[T] MGZY khÿu (去) [k'y]
	[T] MTang kʰy, NW corridor kʰi, ONW kʰø < kʰio (?)
	[N] The OB graph shows a man with a hole marked in his crotch, hence the inventors of writing had perhaps ``anus'' in mind (cf. the TB cognates).
	[<] exopass. (reflexive) of qǔ 去 (kʰjwoᴮ), lit. ``remove oneself'' ({§4.4}).
	[E] ST: The basic ST meaning is ``to get rid of'': WT skyag-pa, bskyags ``to spend, lay out, expend'' ⪤ skyag ~ rkyag ``dirt, excrement''; WB kyaᶜ ``fall, become low, expand'' ⪤ kʰyaᶜ ``throw down, put down'' (? ⪤ kyaŋ ``excrement''); KC-Tiddim kiaᶠ ``to fall ⪤ xiaᶠ (< *kh-) ‘to let fall, fell'', kiatᴿ ⪤ xiatᴿ (< *kh-) ``id.'' (Geilich 1994: 171). For the final consonants, see {§3.2.2}.
	Loss of a ST pre-initial could be responsible for aspiration {§5.8.1}.
	[C] Allofam {qiè₃ 朅} (kʰjät) ``go away''.
>:The basic ST meaning is ``to get rid of'':
>:WT skyag-pa, bskyags ``to spend, lay out, expend'' ⪤ skyag ~ rkyag ``dirt, excrement''
>:WB kyaᶜ ``fall, become low, expand'' ⪤ kʰyaᶜ ``throw down, put down''
>:KC-Tiddim kiaᶠ ``to fall ⪤ xiaᶠ  ‘to let fall, fell'', kiatᴿ ⪤ xiatᴿ  ``id.''

ENTRY:3089
HEAD:quán₃ 卷拳
MC:Middle Chinese: gjwän 3 
LH:Later Han: gyɑn 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *gwan or *gon 
OCB:Baxter Old Chinese: *gᵂrjen ``handsome''
GLOSS:"Be bent, curved, curling" 卷 [Shi] >

	[E] Since OC final *-n can have several sources (ST *-l, *-r, *-n, suffix *-n), a TB cognate is difficult to identify: (1) Bodman (1980: 150) relates this wf to WT kʰyor ``a handful'' ⪤ ’kʰyor ``to warp'', or WT ’kʰor ``circle''. (2) Or note Lushai kʰɔɔrᴿ ``double up, roll up''. (3) Or Lushai kualᴸ ``to coil''. (4) Or perhaps cognate to Lushai hrualᴴ ``roll up in the hand''. (5) These could be n-suffixed forms of {gōu₁ 句鉤枸區}. An allofam is prob. {quán₄ 䟒}.
::Lushai	hrualᴴ	``roll up in the hand''
>:Since OC final *-n can have several sources , a TB cognate is difficult to identify:
>:Bodman  relates this wf to WT kʰyor ``a handful'' ⪤ ’kʰyor ``to warp'', or WT ’kʰor ``circle''.  Or note Lushai kʰɔɔrᴿ ``double up, roll up''.  Or Lushai kualᴸ ``to coil''.
