ENTRY:3117
HEAD:rén₁ 人
MC:Middle Chinese: ńźjen 
LH:Later Han: ńin 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *nin
GLOSS:"Human being, person, man" [OB, Shi] >
GLOSS:"other persons, someone" [Shi].
GLOSS-NOTE:Rén tends to refer to a member of a clan, i.e. upper class (Gassmann JAOS 120.3, 2000: 348ƒƒ).
	[T] Sin Sukchu SR rin (平)
	[T] MGZY Zhin (平) [rin]
	[T] ONW ńin
	[E] Etymology not certain. The TB root *mi ``human being'' occurs in {mín₁ 民} ``people''.
	There are several possible etymologies for rén:
GLOSS:1:It may possibly be the same etymon as PTB *niŋ
GLOSS:"heart, mind", thus literally
GLOSS:"having a mind"; for a semantic parallel note Tib. sems-čan ``having a mind, living creature'' (also Latin animal < animus ``breath, spirit'').
	But this is rather speculative.
GLOSS:2:More likely, rén is related to PMK *ɲah, LitMon ñaḥ
GLOSS:"people" (of either sex) [Diffloth 1984: 13f], Mod. Khmer neə̆ʔ
GLOSS:"specifier for ordinary persons", with fronted vowel in OC ({§11.5.2}) and the addition of the nominal n-suffix ({§6.4.3}), just as in mín  民.
	The Shang dynasty fought wars against eastern AA enemies who are called rén  人.
	It is tempting to consider this their auto-ethnonym (``human beings'') (Sagart 1999: 163 who relates rén to WT ñe-n ``kinsman'', though).
	An allofam is thought to be {rén₂ 仁} which prob. is folk-etymology.
::WT	ñe-n	``kinsman''
>:Etymology not certain. The TB root *mi ``human being'' occurs in {mín₁ 民} ``people''

ENTRY:3118
HEAD:rén₂ 仁
MC:Middle Chinese: ńźjen 
LH:Later Han: ńin 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *nin
GLOSS:"Be kind, good" [Shi, Shu],
GLOSS:"qīn 親 to love" [SWJZGL 3471],
GLOSS:"kind, gentle, humane" (A. Waley) and similar translations [Lunyu, Meng]; ``pit'' (i.e. ``heart''), e.g. of an apricot xìng-rén 杏仁 [Běncǎo; Yánshì jiāxùn, 6th cent. AD] (Baxter p.c.).
	[E] The word's old graph 忎 (qiān 千 *snhîn as phonetic; Boodberg 1937: 338; in the Guōdiàn texts written with shēn 身 instead of qiān above xīn 心 ``heart''; cf. 𡰥), and its SW gloss qīn, suggest that its association with {rén₁ 人} ``human being'' is relatively late (Mengzi) (Pulleyblank 1995: 183; Baxter p.c. 2001); later it acquired the usual interpretation as lit. ``act like a human being'' (Gassmann JAOS 120.3, 2000: 357).
	[E] ST: PTB *s-niŋ (STC no. 367) > PTib. *s-niŋ  > WT sñiŋ ``heart, mind'', sñiŋ-rǰe ``kindness, mercy, compassion'', sñiŋ-po ``chief part, main substance, quintessence'' (e.g. of cream of milk, soft part of a loaf, wick of a lamp) ⪤ ñiŋ ``pith, essence'' (W. Baxter, p.c. 2001); Kanauri *sniŋ > stiŋ ``heart''; PLB *s-nik ~ *s-niŋ ⪤ *s-ni ``heart'' > WB hnac-lumᴮ, Limbu niŋ ``mind'' (HST; Shī Xiàngdōng 2000: 205).
	Possible allofams are {shēn₂ 身} ``body'', {qīn₅ 親} ``to love, relative'', but see there.
	The TB items are sometimes thought cognate to {níng₁ 寧} ``be at peace''.
::Limbu	niŋ	``mind''
>:The word's old graph 忎 , and its SW gloss qīn, suggest that its association with {rén₁ 人} ``human being'' is relatively late
>:later it acquired the usual interpretation as lit. ``act like a human being''
>:PTB *s-niŋ  >
>:PTib. *s-niŋ  >
>:WT sñiŋ ``heart, mind'', sñiŋ-rǰe ``kindness, mercy, compassion'', sñiŋ-po ``chief part, main substance, quintessence''  ⪤ ñiŋ ``pith, essence''
>:Kanauri *sniŋ > stiŋ ``heart''
>:PLB *s-nik ~ *s-niŋ ⪤ *s-ni ``heart'' >
>:WB hnac-lumᴮ
>:Limbu niŋ ``mind''

	[T] Sin Sukchu SR rim (去), PR, LR rin
	[T] MGZY Zhim (去) [rim]

ENTRY:3125
HEAD:rěn₃ 稔
MC:Middle Chinese: ńźjəmᴮ 
LH:Later Han: ńimᴮ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *nəmʔ
GLOSS:"Year" [Zuo].
GLOSS-NOTE:Later
GLOSS:"ripe" (of cereal etc.) [SW],
GLOSS:"harvest" [Hanshu].
	[E] MK *cn1am, *cn1aam ``year'' (Shorto 2006 #1368): PMonic *cnaam ``year'', Mon hnam, Khmer cnam, PVM *c-n-əm ``year'' [Ferlus], Wa-Lawa-Bulang *nɤm (Benedict MKS 18-19, 1992: 9). The AA word is perhaps derived from a root ``to (trans-)plant''  (Ferlus, Diffloth).
	MK ⇒ JP lə³³-nam³³ ``rainy season'' (CVST 2: 31), Lepcha nam ``year''.
	MK ⇒ Saek (Tai lg.) ɲaam⁴ (A1) ``season''.
	The word's earliest occurrences in Zuǒzhuàn in stock expressions like ``not lasting (more than) five years'' give the impression of a relict from a substrate, rather than being part of the active language (similar to AA {huāng₁ 衁} ``blood'').
	The AA sources do not mean ``harvest'' or ``ripe''; therefore it seems that AA ``year'' and {rén₄ 任} *nəm (basic notion: ``burden, carry, bear'') have converged during the Han period (ears of grain ``bearing'' > ``ripe, harvest'') [SW, Hanshu], perhaps with additional interfe- rence from {rèn₂ 荏任} ``soft'' > ``cooked'' and {nián 年} ``year, harvest''. Rěn has perhaps tone B because it was felt to be an endoactive derivation ({§4.5.1}) from ``soft / heavy''.
::Lepcha	nam	``year''
>:MK *cn1am, *cn1aam ``year'' :
>:PMonic *cnaam ``year''
>:Mon hnam
>:Khmer cnam
>:PVM *c-n-əm ``year'' , Wa-Lawa-Bulang *nɤm . The AA word is perhaps derived from a root ``to plant''

LH:Later Han: joŋᴮ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *loŋʔ
	[D] M-Amoy col. yiŋᴮ ``wave''
GLOSS:"To bubble up, gush forth" (as spring) 涌 [Gongyang], 湧 [Lü].

ENTRY:3144
HEAD:róng₃ 溶 ⪤ xiōng 洶
MC:Middle Chinese: xjwoŋ[ᴮ]  <wow value=' LH:' color='invert' gloss='Later Han'/> hɨoŋ(ᴮ) 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *-oŋ(ʔ)
GLOSS:"To rush (as water)" [Chuci].
GLOSS-NOTE:The unexpected initial is perhaps due to some AA form.
	[E] Area etymon. ST: WT loŋ-pa, loŋs ``rise up'' (of water), loŋ-loŋ ``uprising in waves, bulging out'' (Bodman 1980: 101; HST: 126) ⪤ kloŋ ``wave'' (WT prob. not related to {làng 浪} ``wave'').
	<> AA: Khmer /rlóoŋ/ ``to rise, mount, well up'' (of water, tears) ⪤ ghloṅa /klóoŋ/ ``rising movements of waves'', acc. to Jenner / Pou (1982: 332) derivatives from the root under {sōng₂ 崧嵩} ``high''.
	This wf is prob. connected with {hóng₄ 洪} ``great (waters)''.
	It may ultimately belong to {yǒng₄ 踊} ``to jump, leap''.
::Khmer	/rlóoŋ/	``to rise, mount, well up''
>:Area etymon. ST:
>:WT loŋ-pa, loŋs ``rise up'' , loŋ-loŋ ``uprising in waves, bulging out''  ⪤ kloŋ ``wave''

ENTRY:3147
HEAD:róng₅ 戎
MC:Middle Chinese: ńźjuŋ 
LH:Later Han: ńuŋ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *nuŋ
GLOSS:"You" [Shi].
	[T] Sin Sukchu SR rjuŋ (平)
	[T] PR  ruŋ
	[T] MGZY  Zhÿung (平) [rjuŋ]
	[T] ONW ńuŋ
	[E] The etymology is obscure. One possibility would be to invoke the rare (or non-existent?) equation PTB *a = OC *u and thus connect róng with PTB *naːŋ ``you'' (so STC: 160 n. 432; see under {rǔ₂ 汝}) ({§11.9.3}).
	Alternatively, this pronoun could be related to {nóng₁ 農} ``farmer'', just as {nóng₂ 儂} functions as the first person pronoun in Mǐn dialects.
	But these are speculations.
::PTB	*naːŋ	``you''
>:The etymology is obscure. One possibility would be to invoke the rare  equation PTB *a = OC *u and thus connect róng with PTB *naːŋ ``you''

ENTRY:3153
HEAD:róu₁ 柔
MC:Middle Chinese: ńźjəu 
LH:Later Han: ńu 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *nu
GLOSS:"Flexible, soft, mild, gentle" [Shi].
	[E] ST: JP nu³³ ``relaxed, slack'' (e.g. rope) ⪤ nu³¹ ``relax'' (effort, attention); perhaps also WT ñug-pa ``to rub, stroke, caress, besmear'' (HST: 136), Lushai nɔɔkᴴ ``rub against, loll against''. This stem OCM *nu is prob. a ST variant of the synonymous stem OCM *no ({rú₄ 懦臑}).
	Pulleyblank (1973: 121) has pointed out that there are many words with initial *n but different rimes which mean ``soft, weak'', including: {rú₄ 懦臑}, {rù₃ 茹}, {ruǎn 耎軟}, {ruò₅ 弱}; in addition to Pullayblank: {rèn₂ 荏任}.
	Syn. {xuān₂ 暖}.
	An additional allofam is {ròu₁ 肉} ``flesh, meat''.
::Lushai	nɔɔkᴴ	``rub against, loll against''
>:JP nu³³ ``relaxed, slack''  ⪤ nu³¹ ``relax''
>:perhaps also WT ñug-pa ``to rub, stroke, caress, besmear''
>:Lushai nɔɔkᴴ ``rub against, loll against''. This stem OCM *nu is prob. a ST variant of the synonymous stem OCM *no

	[<] exoactive / caus. of róu 柔 ({§4.3.2}).

ENTRY:3156

	[E] Wáng Lì (1982: 236) includes 肉 in the wf {róu₁ 柔} ``soft'' which is the most likely etymology. Other languages have an etymon *na: Tai: S. nɨaᶜ² < *n- ``flesh, meat'' (cogn. acc. to Li F. 1976: 42), also KN-Khami na ``meat, flesh''.
	Possibly ròu is the result of convergence and re-etymologization.
	See there for possible additional allofams.

	Acc. to Downer (1959: 287), the tone C reading belongs to the meaning ``be as good as'' [Zuo].

ENTRY:3161
HEAD:rú₃ 茹

	[D] Acc. to FY 7.27 a Wú-Yuè (i.e. ancient Zhèjiāng-Fújiàn) dialect word for ``to eat'', still current in M-Xiàmén luᴬ² ``to eat''.
	[E] AA: PVM *s-ɲaːʔ ``to chew, masticate'' [Ferlus]; Kharia ɲoʔ ``to eat''. AA ⇒ PMY: *naʔ⁷ ``to swallow''.
	In light of the ultimate AA source and its OC meaning, the OC word seems to have been absorbed through MY.
	Perh. the root of {xiū₄ 羞} ``nourish'' is a vocalic variant.
	Related may be the items under {xiǎng₂ 饟餉}.
	The graph 茹 writes additional words rù.

ENTRY:3162
HEAD:rú₄ 懦臑

GLOSS:"Weak, timid" 懦 [Xun];

	[E] ST: PTB *now ``tender, soft'' (STC no. 274) > PL *C-nu², WB nuᶜ < noᶜ ``young, tender'' ⪤ nuᴮ ``be made soft'' ⪤ hnuᴮ ``make soft, mollify'', Lushai noᴿ < nooʔ ``young, tender, soft, young of animals''. This stem OCM *no is prob. a variant of the synonymous stem OCM *nu ({róu₁ 柔}).

ENTRY:3163
HEAD:rú₄ 懦臑 ⪤ rú 孺
MC:Middle Chinese: ńźjuᶜ 
LH:Later Han: ńoᶜ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *noh
	[T] ONW ńuo
GLOSS:"Child" [Shu].
GLOSS-NOTE:Rú has an unexpected Mand. tone, Pulleyblank (1991: 268) sets up competing variants in tone A and C for the Yuan period.
	In the meaning ``child'', rú occurs in OC usually (always?) as an adjective to zǐ 子 ``child'', hence the phrase means literally ``weak child'', therefore rú is a derivation from rú 懦 above, perhaps even the same word.
	In late Zhanguo texts [Hanfei, Li] rú-rén 孺人 and rú-zǐ 孺子 is the term for the ``wife'' of a low nobleman (大夫).
	[C] Cognates are {xū₄ 須需} ``wait, tarry'', {ruǎn 耎軟} ``soft''; perhaps also {rǔ₃ 乳} ``female breast'', {ruò₅ 弱} ``weak'', {rú₅ 濡} ``moisten''.

ENTRY:3170
HEAD:rǔ₁ 汝
MC:Middle Chinese: ńźjwoᴮ 
LH:Later Han: ńɑᴮ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *naʔ
	[T] ONW ńoᴮ > ńøᴮ
	Rǔ is the name of at least two rivers, one a northern tributary of the Huái in southern Henan, the other of the Hàn river.
	Both were once in the non-Chinese sphere of the ancient state of Chǔ and its neighbors.
	The Chǔ ruling clan Xióng 熊 (``bear'') had the name mǐ 羋 ``bear'' which points to a KT presence (KT mui ``bear'').
	It may therefore possibly be more than a coincidence that the KS word for ``water'' is *ʔnjaᴬ or *k-njaᴬ.

ENTRY:3171
HEAD:rǔ₂ 汝
MC:Middle Chinese: ńźjwoᴮ 
LH:Later Han: ńɑᴮ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *naʔ
GLOSS:"You" [BI, Shi], an independent pronoun ({§3.3.3}). This word survives in col. coastal Mǐn: Xiàmén liᴮ, Fúzhōu nyᴮ (Norman 1988: 234), while most dialects have forms which go back to {ěr₅ 爾}.
	G-Wǔníng ãjɛᴬ² ``you'' (Sagart 1993: 173) does not agree in tone.
	[E] ST: PTB *na ~ *naŋ ``you'' (STC no. 407) > Chepang naŋ ``you'' (sing.), PL *naŋ, WB naŋ ``you'', naŋᶜ ``you, your''; JP naʔ⁵⁵ ``your'', naŋ³³ ``you'' (HST: 163), Lushai naŋᴿ < naŋʔ. For the finals, see {§3.2.4}.
::WB	naŋ	``you''
>:PTB *na ~ *naŋ ``you''  >
>:Chepang naŋ ``you''
>:PL *naŋ
>:WB naŋ ``you'', naŋᶜ ``you, your''
>:JP naʔ⁵⁵ ``your'', naŋ³³ ``you''
>:Lushai naŋᴿ < naŋʔ

ENTRY:3172
HEAD:rǔ₂ 汝 ⪤ nǎi 乃
MC:Middle Chinese: nậiᴮ 
LH:Later Han: nəᴮ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *nə̂ʔ
	[T] ONW nɑiᴮ
GLOSS:"Your" possessive [BI, Shi] is a proclitic (unstressed) form of rǔ 汝
GLOSS:"you" (see {§3.3.3}). Allofam may be {ruò₂ 若}; parallel stems or synonyms {ér₃ 而}, {ěr₅ 爾} and its col. variant {nǐ₁ 你}
GLOSS:"you"; {róng₅ 戎}.

ENTRY:3173
HEAD:rǔ₃ 乳
MC:Middle Chinese: ńźjuᴮ 
LH:Later Han: ńoᴮ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *noʔ
GLOSS:"Nipple, breast" [Zhouli],
GLOSS:"milk, suckle" [Zuo] >
GLOSS:"breed, raise" [Lü] > ``hatch'' [Li].
	[T] Sin Sukchu SR ry (上)
	[T]  MGZY Zhÿu (上) [ry]
	[T]  ONW ńuoᴮ
	[E] The OC vowel *o, as in *noʔ, often corresponds to foreign *u in open syllables ({§11.9.1}). On the other hand, *noʔ also looks like a regular endoactive derivation ({§4.5.1}) from {rú₄ 懦臑} *no ``soft'', lit. ``the thing that is soft'', a possible re-etymologization of the area word.
	[E] ST: PTB *nuw ~ *now (STC no. 419) > WT nu-ma ``breast'' ⪤ nu-ba ``to suck'' ⪤ nud-pa ``to suckle'', Tsangla nu ``milk'', Lushai hnuᴸ-teᴿ < hnuʔ/h ``breast, milk'' ⪤ nuᶠ < nuuʔ ``mother, married woman'', PLB *no³, WB nuiᶜ; JP nu⁵¹ ``mother, mother's sister'' etc. (CVST 2:38), JP gə³¹-nu³¹ ``mother''. <> Perh. an area word: Kharia, Mundari nunu ``female breast'' ⪤ Mundari nu ``to drink'', Wa-Lawa-Bulang *ɲɨʔ, PVM *ɲuːʔ ``drink''.
	AA may be the ultimate source of this word because it is the common word for ``drink'' whereas the meanings in ST are specialized.
	Some TB languages indicate that the protoform was prob. *nuwʔ.
	[C] Perh. cognate to {xū₆ 嬃} *sno ``elder sister''; {ā-nú 阿奴} ``younger brother''.
::PVM	*ɲuːʔ	``drink''
>:The OC vowel *o, as in *noʔ, often corresponds to foreign *u in open syllables . On the other hand, *noʔ also looks like a regular endoactive derivation  from {rú₄ 懦臑} *no ``soft'', lit. ``the thing that is soft'', a possible re-etymologization of the area word

ENTRY:3186
HEAD:ruǎn 耎軟

OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *nonʔ
GLOSS:"Soft, weak" [Guoce],
GLOSS:"weak, timid" 懦 [Zuo].
	[T] Sin Sukchu SR ryen (上)
	[T] MGZY Zhwÿan (上) [ryɛn]
	[E] ST: WB nwai ``stretch along'' ⪤ nwaiᶜ ``bend flexibly'' ⪤ hnwaiᶜ ``bend flexibly'' ⪤ hnwaiᴮ ``procrastinate'', Lushai nuaiᴴ ``rub''. WB final -i and MC nuâᶜ ~ nuânᶜ can be reconciled if we assume an original ST *nwal. ⇒ Old Sino-Viet. nhuyen (Pān Wùyún 1987: 30).
::Lushai	nuaiᴴ	``rub''
>:WB nwai ``stretch along'' ⪤ nwaiᶜ ``bend flexibly'' ⪤ hnwaiᶜ ``bend flexibly'' ⪤ hnwaiᴮ ``procrastinate''

ENTRY:3189
HEAD:ruǐ 繠蕊
MC:Middle Chinese: ńźwieᴮ,ńźnwiᴮ 
LH:Later Han: ńuieᴮ,ńuiᴮ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *noiʔ,*nuiʔ
GLOSS:"Hang down" (as jade pendent from belt) 繠 [Zuo],
GLOSS:"ovary of flower, fruit" 蕊 [Chuci].
	[E] ST: WB nwai ``stretch along, as a creeper''; JP nói ``suspend, hang'' ⪤ ʔənōi ``hang on to'' [notations of HPTB: 215]; possibly WT nar-mo ``oblong'' ⪤ bsnar-ba ``to extend in length, pull out'' from TB *nwar could belong here. Perh. also connected with AA: OMon jnor ~ jnow ``hanging banner'' with the nominalizing n-infix.
	HPTB considers the TB items under {chuí₁ 垂} cognate; further comparanda are {duǒ₁ 朵}, {wěi₂ 委}.
::WT	nar-mo	``oblong''
>:WB nwai ``stretch along, as a creeper''

>:OMon jnor ~ jnow ``hanging banner'' with the nominalizing n-infix

ENTRY:3193
HEAD:ruò₁ 若
MC:Middle Chinese: ńźjak,GY also ńźjaᴮ 
LH:Later Han: ńɑk 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *nak
	(Perhaps: ``Of all possible cases, the one like this'':) ``like this, such, if''  [BI, Shu] > as a full vb. ``to agree, approve'' [OB, BI, Shu].
	[T] Sin Sukchu SR rjaw (入), LR rjawʔ
	[T] MGZY Zhew (入) [rɛw]
	[T] ONW ńak, ńa
	[<] ruò is derived from rú 如 with the distributive suffix *-k (see {§6.1.2}).

ENTRY:3194

	[T] ONW nɑk

	I, see {§9.1.1}.
	[C] See {rú₁ 如} for allofams.

ENTRY:3195
HEAD:ruò₂ 若
MC:Middle Chinese: ńźjak 
LH:Later Han: ńɑk 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *nak
GLOSS:"You" [Yili].
GLOSS-NOTE:Acc. to GY the reading for this graph with the meaning
GLOSS:"you" is with final *-k, not tone B which is an alternate reading, a homophone of rǔ 汝
GLOSS:"you".
	Since tone B belongs to the root and goes back to ST, the final -k may here be a phonological variant ({§3.2.2}), perhaps inspired by the distributive k-suffix in the homophone ruò₂ 若.
	Allofams are listed under {rǔ₂ 汝}.

ENTRY:3196
HEAD:ruò₃ 若
GLOSS:"that"
	{nà₃} 那

ENTRY:3197
HEAD:ruò₄ 箬
MC:Middle Chinese: ńźjak 
LH:Later Han: ńɑk
	A Han period Chǔ dialect word meaning ``bamboo skin'' [SW], today ruò-lì  箬笠 ``hat made of bamboo leaves''; the basic meaning seems to have been ``leaf'' which is still current in Mǐn dialects: PMin *ṇiɔk (Norman 1983: 205).
	[E] ST: PTB *s-nas (HPTB: 432) > Tiddim Chin naʔ ``leaf'', Lushai hnaʔᴸ.
::Chin	naʔ	``leaf''
>:PTB *s-nas  >
>:Tiddim Chin naʔ ``leaf''
>:Lushai hnaʔᴸ

ENTRY:3198
HEAD:ruò₅ 弱
MC:Middle Chinese: ńźjak 
LH:Later Han: ńɑk < ńɑuk 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *n(i)auk ?

ENTRY:3199
HEAD:ruò₆ 爇
MC:Middle Chinese: ńźjwät 
LH:Later Han: ńuat,ńot 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *ŋiot or *niot ?
GLOSS:"To burn" 爇 [Zuo],
GLOSS:"hot, burn" 焫 [Li] (also MC ńźjwäiᶜ).
	[E] Most likely, this is a final -t derivation ({§6.2.2}) from a ST root *nwe: WB nweᴮ, hnweᴮ ``warm'', Lai nwê ``be warm'' [Van Bik LTBA 25.2, 2002: 107]; or, less likely, from {ráo₂ 蕘} ``fuel''. There are parallels for the medial-vowel metathesis, see {něi 餒}, {shuāi 衰}.
	For the n- ~ ŋ- vacilation in the initial, see {§5.12.1}.
	Since ruò is apparently related to {nuǎn 煖} *non ``warm'', its relationship to {rè 熱} *ŋet or *net (?) ``hot'', if any, is not clear.
	Wáng Lì (1982: 494) relates ruò to {rán₁ 然} ``burn''.
::Lai	nwê	``be warm''
>:Most likely, this is a final -t derivation  from a ST root *nwe:
>:WB nweᴮ, hnweᴮ ``warm''
>:Lai nwê ``be warm''
>:or, less likely, from {ráo₂ 蕘} ``fuel''. There are parallels for the medial-vowel metathesis, see {něi 餒}, {shuāi 衰}

ENTRY:3204
HEAD:sāi 思
MC:Middle Chinese: sɨ,sậi
GLOSS:"bearded" or
GLOSS:"white-haired" [Zuo] is an allofam of {ér₁ 而}

ENTRY:3205
HEAD:sài,sāi,sè 塞
MC:Middle Chinese: sək,sậiᶜ 
LH:Later Han: sək,səᶜ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *sə̂k(h)
	[T] ONW sək sɑi
GLOSS:"To stop up, block; a mountain pass" [Shi].
GLOSS-NOTE:Downer (1959: 275) determined that the verb had the reading MC sək, the noun tone C MC sậiᶜ in Zuǒzhuàn.
	[E] Etymology not clear; prob. connected with Khmer suka /sok/ ``to stop up, block, cram …'' ⪤ cuka /cok/ ``to stop up, plug, block, obstruct …'', but the vowels do not agree ({§11.10.5}). Based on his theories on OC phonology, Pulleyblank (EC 16, 1991: 50) believes that sài is cognate to WT sub-pa ``to stop up''.
::WT	sub-pa	``to stop up''
>:Etymology not clear
>:prob. connected with Khmer suka /sok/ ``to stop up, block, cram …'' ⪤ cuka /cok/ ``to stop up, plug, block, obstruct …'', but the vowels do not agree . Based on his theories on OC phonology
>:Pulleyblank  believes that sài is cognate to WT sub-pa ``to stop up''

ENTRY:3214
HEAD:sǎn₂ 糝

ENTRY:3217
HEAD:sāng₂ 桑
MC:Middle Chinese: sâŋ 
LH:Later Han: sɑŋ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *sâŋ
GLOSS:"Mulberry tree" [BI, Shi].
GLOSS-NOTE:Etymology not clear.
	In early literature and folklore, this tree was associated with wild places beyond ordered civilization (Boileau BSOAS 65.2, 2002: 350ƒƒ).

ENTRY:3218
HEAD:sǎng 顙
MC:Middle Chinese: sâŋᴮ 
LH:Later Han: sɑŋᴮ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *sâŋʔ < *smaŋʔ ?
	[T] ONW sɑŋ
GLOSS:"Forehead" [Zuo; SW 3915]; FY 10, 34 says this is an eastern Qí dialect word for central Chinese é 額
GLOSS:"forehead"; it is, however, a common pre-Han word.
	[E] Etymology not clear. Since this word's source is Qí in Shandong which is believed to have been inhabited by AA speakers down to early historic times (Pulleyblank), it may be AA: Kharia sɔmɔŋ, Munda samaŋ ``forehead'', possibly connected with the root OKhmer saṅ /sɔŋ/ ``to raise'', since other words for ``forehead'' are derived from the notion ``lift, high''.
	[C] Syn. {dìng₂ 定顁}, é 額 and yán 顏 (both under {yà₂ 御迓訝}), {yáng₈ 揚鍚}
::OKhmer	saṅ /sɔŋ/	``to raise''
>:Etymology not clear. Since this word's source is Qí in Shandong which is believed to have been inhabited by AA speakers down to early historic times , it may be AA:
>:Kharia sɔmɔŋ
>:Munda samaŋ ``forehead'', possibly connected with the root OKhmer saṅ /sɔŋ/ ``to raise'', since other words for ``forehead'' are derived from the notion ``lift, high''

GLOSS:"To brush, sweep" 埽 [Shi], 掃 [Li].

ENTRY:3228
HEAD:sāo₄ 臊
MC:Middle Chinese: sâu

	[T] ONW sɑu
	[D] Min-Amoy tsʰo⁵⁵

ENTRY:3229
HEAD:sāo₅ 鱢
MC:Middle Chinese: sâu 
LH:Later Han: sɑu,S tsʰɑu 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *sâu ~ *C-sâu ?
GLOSS:"Putrid smell" [Yanzi].
	[D] PMin *tsʰɑu ``rank, fishy''
	[E] ST: PTB *saw (cf. STC: 54) ~ *su > Garo so, Dimasa sau ``rot, decay'', Proto-Bodo *sau ``rotten''; Lushai tʰuᶠ < suʔ ``dried, rotten'', Mikir tʰu ``rot, decay'' [Hanson] < Kuki-Naga *su.
	Wáng Lì (1982: 220) believes that this is the same word as {sāo₄ 臊} ``fat'' which would be parallel with {xīng₄ 腥} (sieŋ) ``raw meat, offensive smell''.
::Mikir	tʰu	``rot, decay''

ENTRY:3232
HEAD:sè₁ 色
MC:Middle Chinese: ṣjək 
LH:Later Han: ṣɨk,S ṣək 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *srək 
OCB:Baxter Old Chinese: *srjək
GLOSS:"Color" [Shi] (as opposed to {cǎi₂ 采}
GLOSS:"pigment") >
GLOSS:"color of face" [Zuo] > ``appearance, countenance, mien'' [Shi] > ``looks''.
	[T] Sin S. SR ʂəj (入), LR ʂəjʔ
	[T] MGZY shhiy (入) [ʂəj]
	[T] ONW ṣik
	[E] ST: Lushai saarᴴ < saar ``prismatic colors'' ⪤ saarᴿ / sarhᴿ ``healthy looking, rosy, ruddy''. The Lushai and CH words both refer also specifically to the healthy attractive color of the face.
	The OC word derives therefore from an earlier *sər-k.
	Alternatively, sè has been connected with TB items under {hè₄ 赫}. {chì₃ 赤} ``red'' may possibly also be connected, but this is doubtful.
	Note also AA: OMon sāk, sek /saik/ ``color'', Khmer sāk ``resemblance, pattern''.
	The twist towards ``good looks / charms of women'' as in hào sè 好色 ``be fond of women'' [Lunyu, Mengzi] > ``sex'' may be due to an AA substrate, note Khmer /srèek/ ``thirst or lust after'' < /réek/ ``enjoy oneself''.
::Khmer	/srèek/	``thirst or lust after''
>:Lushai saarᴴ < saar ``prismatic colors'' ⪤ saarᴿ / sarhᴿ ``healthy looking, rosy, ruddy''. The Lushai and CH words both refer also specifically to the healthy attractive color of the face

::OCB	*srɨ(k)ʔ	``to gather, pluck''

ENTRY:3240
HEAD:shà 翣
MC:Middle Chinese: ṣap 
LH:Later Han: ṣap 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *srap
GLOSS:"Plume-fan" [Zuo]
	[E] This word belongs to a widespread SE Asian assemblage of etyma for ``wink, blink'', including PAN sap ``winnow''; K-Méixiàn sap⁷ ``wink'', Y-Hongkong saap⁷ ``id''. For an exhaustive collection and treatment, see R. Bauer LTBA 15.2: 151-184.
	This word also may be an iterative derivation from {liè₈ 鬣} ``beard, broom'' ({§5.2.3}) due to paronomastic attraction.
::Y-Hongkong	saap⁷	``id''

ENTRY:3242
HEAD:shāi,shī 篩 ⪤ sǎ,shǎi 洒

LH:Later Han: ṣɛiᴮ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *srîʔ

	[E] ST *sri: Lushai hriᴸ / hrikᶠ < hriih / hriik ``to sift, screen'' (CVST 4: 106). This cognate shows that sǎ is unrelated to {xǐ₁ 洗洒} ``wash'' (as suggested by Karlgren 1956: 16).
	There are also forms with TB initial *l which may be cognate: WB hleᶜ ``winnow'', Lushai tʰliᴴ / tʰlitᴸ < slii / slit ``to strain, pour off, winnow''.
	This etymon has nearly converged with {shī₁₂ 釃} *sre, but the Lushai cognates suggest separate etymologies.
::Lushai	tʰliᴴ / tʰlitᴸ < slii / slit	``to strain, pour off, winnow''

	[E] ST *ja ``above'' + ST terminative *-ŋ ({§6.5.1}).
	[E] ST: WT yaŋ  as in yaŋ-rtse ``highest point, summit'', and in yaŋ-mes-po ``great-grandfather'' ⪤ ya ``above, up'' (Bodman 1980: 79), Lushai zoᴴ < jo ``be high'', zaʔᴸ < jas ``to respect, reverence''. TB initial *y- sometimes corresponds to MC źj- < OC *dj- ({§9.3}).
	In light of the TB cognates, an allofam is prob. {shǔ₅ 曙} ``sunrise'', related to WT ⪤ ya ``above, up ⪤ yar ‘up, upward'' > ’čʰar-ba, šar < s-yar ``ro rise'' (of sun, moon).

ENTRY:3274
HEAD:shē₁ 賒
MC:Middle Chinese: śja 
LH:Later Han: śa 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *lha
	[T] ONW śa
GLOSS:"Trade on credit" [Zhouli] (Wáng Lì 1982: 164).
	[E] <> ? Tai: S. laak³ ``to trade, exchange, barter''.
	[E] The word shāng appears earlier than the synonym {mǎi 買}. A possible connection with one or another TB etymon remains speculative: PTB *lay ``change, exchange'' (STC p. 64-66), {yí₈ 移} ``change''.
	Or PTB *b-ley ``barter'' (STC no. 283): Lushai leiᴿ ``buy, barter'', Tiddim leiᴸ / leiᴴ < leiʔ / leih ``to buy'', Chepang leʔ-sa ``to buy''.
	If related to the latter *ley, the CH vocalism might have been influenced by superficially similar words like {shě₁ 舍} ``bestow, give''.
	Alternatively, Bodman (1980: 80) compares this group with WT g-yar ``borrow, lend, hire''.
::WT	g-yar	``borrow, lend, hire''
>:? Tai:
>:S. laak³ ``to trade, exchange, barter''
>:The word shāng appears earlier than the synonym {mǎi 買}. A possible connection with one or another TB etymon remains speculative:
>:PTB *lay ``change, exchange'' , {yí₈ 移} ``change''

ENTRY:3278

ENTRY:3279
HEAD:shé₂ 蛇
MC:Middle Chinese: dźja 
LH:Later Han: źa 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *m-lai ?
GLOSS:"Snake" [OB, Shi].
GLOSS-NOTE:The OB graph seems to depict a cobra.
	[T] Sin Sukchu SR ʐje (平)
	[T] ONW ia (~ źa ?)  —
	[D] PMin *d̯žiɑi
	[E] The etymology is not certain. Some languages have synonyms which look similar: KD-PHlai *ljʔa²: Baoding za², Qiandui ɬa² ``snake''; on the Malay peninsula Radê etc. ala ``snake''; or TB: Lushai ruulᴴ-hlaiᴿ ``sp. of snake'' (ruulᴴ ``snake''), JP pə³³-lai³³ ``a sp. of iguana'' (CVST 3: 6).
	However, the KD forms could be loans from CH, and the cited TB forms appear to be unrelated.
	Most likely, shé is to be associated with an area root: Khmer /-lée/ as in  /rlée/ ``to snake, move sinuously'' (as through water).
	In OC, this root also provides the second syllable in {wēi₁-tuó 委佗}, wēi-yí  委佗 ``winding, compliant, graceful''.
	Shé ``the winding thing'' is then a euphemism for {huǐ₁ 虫虺} ``snake'' < ST *(s)mrul in order to avoid the name of a dangerous creature (for a similar taboo, see {hǔ₁ 虎} ``tiger'').
::JP	pə³³-lai³³	``a sp. of iguana''
>:The etymology is not certain. Some languages have synonyms which look similar:
>:KD-PHlai *ljʔa²:
>:Baoding za²
>:Qiandui ɬa² ``snake''
>:on the Malay peninsula Radê etc. ala ``snake''
>:or TB:
>:Lushai ruulᴴ-hlaiᴿ ``sp. of snake''
>:JP pə³³-lai³³ ``a sp. of iguana''

ENTRY:3280
HEAD:shě₁ 舍
MC:Middle Chinese: śjaᴮ 
LH:Later Han: śaᴮ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *lhaʔ
GLOSS:"To bestow, grant" [BI, Shi],
GLOSS:"give, bestow" [Zuo].
	[E] Prob. AA: MMon salah ``to give away, disburse''.
	[E] A superior person giving something to an inferior is the basic meaning of this wf, whereas the root from which it is prob. derived, {yǔ₉ 與}, means ``to give'' in general. The etyma *lhaʔ ~ *lhai ({shī₉ 施}) are prob. variants.
	A similar triplet of stems is found with the group ``to give up'' ({shě₂ 舍捨}).
	The latter and this set ``bestow'' tend to coalesce, may even derive from the same root (give something < let go of something?).
>:Prob. AA:
>:MMon salah ``to give away, disburse''
>:A superior person giving something to an inferior is the basic meaning of this wf, whereas the root from which it is prob. derived, {yǔ₉ 與}, means ``to give'' in general. The etyma *lhaʔ ~ *lhai  are prob. variants

ENTRY:3281
HEAD:shě₁ 舍 ⪤ shè 舍
MC:Middle Chinese: śjaᶜ 
LH:Later Han: śaᶜ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *lhah
	[T] ONW śa
GLOSS:"Put down, deposit" [Zuo].
	[<] *lhaʔ + s/h-suffix, perhaps exoactive ({§4.3}).

ENTRY:3282
HEAD:shě₁ 舍 ⪤ shǎng 賞
MC:Middle Chinese: śjaŋᴮ 
LH:Later Han: śɑŋᴮ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *lhaŋʔ
	[T] ONW śaŋ
GLOSS:"To award, reward, bestow" [BI, Shu].
	[<] *lhaʔ + terminative -ŋ ({§6.5.1}), i.e. a reward is given for a completed action and is therefore itself a final, concluding act.
	[E] ST: Bodman (1980: 102) compares shǎng to WT sloŋ-mo ``alms''.
::WT	sloŋ-mo	``alms''
>:Bodman  compares shǎng to WT sloŋ-mo ``alms''

ENTRY:3283
HEAD:shě₂ 舍捨
MC:Middle Chinese: śjaᴮ 
LH:Later Han: śaᴮ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *lhaʔ
GLOSS:"To let off" [BI, Shi],
GLOSS:"set aside, leave" [Shi];
GLOSS:"give up, let go" 捨 [Guoyu], ``shoot'' [Shi].
	[T] Sin Sukchu SR ʂje (上)
	[T] MGZY shÿa (上) [ʂjɛ]
	[T]  ONW śa
	[E] Area word, prob. of AA origin: KN-Lushai thlaʔᴸ (< *slas)  tr. ``to let go, release, set free, acquit, quit'' (CVST 3: 53). <> AA: PMonic blah ``be released, go free'' (Nyah-Kur), ``escape, be free from'' (Mon) ⪤ *b[]lah > Nyah-Kur *phəla̤h ``to release'' (Nyah-Kur), > Mon *həlɛ̤ə̯h ``let go, free from, send for''. OKhmer lā /laa/ ``to (de)part, leave, quit (doing), cease'' ⪤ ghlā /klíiə/ ``part, leave, quit …'' <> MK ? ⇒ Tai: S. sa-⁴-la⁴ ``let go''.
	This wf is parallel to {yì₃₅ 繹} in CH as well as AA, the difference being OC final *-ʔ vs.
	OC final *-k.
	As a result, shè 舍 [śah] and shè 赦 [śah] ``let go, pardon'' seem to be the same word written with different graphs. However, the graph 舍 implies OC *lhah (< *lhaʔ+h) and is derived from shě 舍捨 *lhaʔ, whereas the graph shè 赦 implies OC *lhakh.
	The roots *lhaʔ ~ *lhak ~ *lhaiʔ ({shǐ₄ 弛}) are prob. variants with parallel morphological and semantic developments.
	A similar triplet of stems is found with the homophone group ``to give, bestow''({shě₁ 舍}).
	The latter and this set ``let go'' tend to coalesce, may even derive from the same root (give something = let something go?).
::OKhmer	lā /laa/	``to part, leave, quit , cease''
>:Area word, prob. of AA origin:
>:KN-Lushai thlaʔᴸ   tr. ``to let go, release, set free, acquit, quit'' . < > AA:
>:PMonic blah ``be released, go free'' , ``escape, be free from''  ⪤ *blah >
>:Nyah-Kur *phəla̤h ``to release'' , >
>:Mon *həlɛ̤ə̯h ``let go, free from, send for''. OKhmer lā /laa/ ``to part, leave, quit , cease'' ⪤ ghlā /klíiə/ ``part, leave, quit …'' < > MK ? ⇒ Tai:
>:S. sa-⁴-la⁴ ``let go''

ENTRY:3285

ENTRY:3286
HEAD:shè₂ 舍
MC:Middle Chinese: śjaᶜ 
LH:Later Han: śaᶜ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *lhah
GLOSS:"To rest in, stop" (overnight on a trip) [Shi],
GLOSS:"to halt, resting place, a day's stage" [Zuo],
GLOSS:"lodging house" [Zhouli].
GLOSS-NOTE:An R-variant is perhaps {lú₂ 廬}
GLOSS:"resting place".
	[E] Apparently shared with PKS: *s-lwaᴮ ``to rest''. The PCH root must have been *s-lwas, identical to the KS one, with the later regular OC initial *sl- > *lh-; KT tone B is the regular counterpart of MC tone C (< *-s).
	Both CH forms reflect a PCH final *s, shè as suffix, shuì as part of the root.
	The erstwhile PCH medial *w after acute initials survives perhaps in syllables in final -t and -(t)s, as in shuì; however, in open syllables like shè, the OC (? at least MC) phonological structure does not allow a medial *w ({§10.2.1}).
	The ambivalence in the forms, as in the finals in these two words, is typical for loan words.
>:Apparently shared with PKS:
>:*s-lwaᴮ ``to rest''. The PCH root must have been *s-lwas, identical to the KS one, with the later regular OC initial *sl- > *lh-
>:KT tone B is the regular counterpart of MC tone C

ENTRY:3297

CH ⇒ Tai: S. nɛɛpᴰ¹ᴸ < *hn- ``pincers, to hold'' (with pincers).
	This ST root *njap is distinct from the parallel stem *nip ({niē 捻} ``pinch'').
::Mikir	nép	``to catch''

ENTRY:3303
HEAD:shēn₁ 申伸呻
	{yǐn₂} 引

ENTRY:3304
HEAD:shēn₂ 身
MC:Middle Chinese: śjen 
LH:Later Han: śin 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *lhin ? or nhin ? 
OCB:Baxter Old Chinese: *hniŋ
GLOSS:"Body, person, self" [BI, Shi];
GLOSS:"belly" [Yijing 52] (acc. to Qiu Xigui 2000: 182 [quoting Yú Fān]; Shaughnessy 1997: 54 translates
GLOSS:"body", but since shēn contrasts with ``flesh on the spine'', ``belly'' may be more to the point).
	[T] Sin Sukchu SR ʂin (平)
	[T] MGZY shin (平) [ʂin]
	[T] ONW śin
	[N] The alleged meaning ``pregnant'' (Wáng Lì 1982: 538, based on the ancient commentator Yú Fān) is not warranted: yǒu shēn 有身 ``pregnant'' [Shijing] means lit. ``with body'' (cf. Engl. ``with child''; note also the synonymous expressions shuāng shēn 雙身, chóng shēn 重身); or ``belly'' is a euphemism for ``pregnant''.
	Therefore, shēn is not related to {zhèn₃,shēn 娠} ``pregnant''.
	The meaning ``pregnant'' may have been reinforced by the near homophone shèng 𣎜 ``pregnant'' (under {yùn₁ 孕}).
	[E] Etymology not certain. Geilich (1994: 274-277) suggests that shēn 身 ``body'' is related to shēn 申伸呻 ``stretch out'' ({yǐn₂ 引}), then lit. = ``the stretched one'', also related to shī  尸 ``corpse'' (under {yí₅ 夷侇}) which also means ``stretch out''.
	Shēn would then be a nominal n-derivation from the root in question ({§6.4.3}).
	Alternatively, Baxter (p. c. 2001) conjectures that shēn was OCB *hniŋ and cognate to {rén₂ 仁} and the TB items there, because, among other considerations, in the Guōdiàn texts {rén₂ 仁} is written with shēn 身 above xīn 心 ``heart''.
>:Etymology not certain. Geilich  suggests that shēn 身 ``body'' is related to shēn 申伸呻 ``stretch out'' , then lit. = ``the stretched one'', also related to shī  尸 ``corpse''  which also means ``stretch out''

ENTRY:3305
HEAD:shēn₃ 深
MC:Middle Chinese: śjəmᴬ 
LH:Later Han: śim,tśʰim 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *nhəm ?
	[T] ONW śim BTD śim
GLOSS:"Deep" [Shi].
	[D] PMin *tšʰim
	[D] Y-Guǎngzhōu ⁵⁵sɐmᴬ¹
	[E] The OC initial *n- has been suggested by Unger (Hao-ku 47, 1995) because of shěn and possible cognation with {nǎn₂ 揇}. If the OC initial was indeed *n-, then the following TB items are related: PTB *nem (STC no. 348): WB nim ``be low'' ⪤ nim ``be kept low, below''; Lushai hniamᴿ ``be low, sink into'' (land) ⪤ hnimᴴ ``dip into'' tr.; Tankhul Naga kʰənim ``be humble'', WT nems ``sink a little, give way'' (a floor).
	An alternative connection: PKiranti *gʰlàm ``deep'' (van Driem 1995: 254: Starostin); or Chepang j̆jumh-ʔo ``deep''.
	See {chén₂ 沈} for syn. and further comments. {tān₃ 探} may be cognate.
::Chepang	j̆jumh-ʔo	``deep''
>:The OC initial *n- has been suggested by Unger  because of shěn and possible cognation with {nǎn₂ 揇}. If the OC initial was indeed *n-, then the following TB items are related:
>:PTB *nem :

>:Lushai hniamᴿ ``be low, sink into''  ⪤ hnimᴴ ``dip into'' tr.

ENTRY:3322
HEAD:shēng₂ 生
MC:Middle Chinese: ṣɐŋ 
LH:Later Han: ṣɛŋ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *srêŋ
GLOSS:"To live, be alive, fresh" [OB, BI, Shi] > (``cause to live'')
GLOSS:"give birth to, create" [Shi];
GLOSS:"a (live) sacrificial animal" 牲 [BI] > ``domestic animal'' (as beast of burden).

	[T] MGZY shhing (平) [ʂəŋ]
	[T] ONW ṣëŋ
	[E] ST terminative final *-ŋ derivation ({§6.5.1}) from ST *sri ``to be, exist'', hence lit. ``come into existence > give birth > live'': PTB *s-riŋ (*śriŋ) (STC no. 404) > Manchati sriŋ ``to live, alive''; Lushai hriŋᴴ / hrinᴸ ``fresh, green'' ⪤ hriŋᴴ / hrinᴿ ``bear, beget'', NNaga *C-riŋ  ``alive''; Chepang sriŋ- ``open out'' (begin to open, of buds), begin to blossom’, Mikir reŋᴸ ``live, come to life''; JP tsiŋ³³ < rjiŋ  ``weeds, rank grass'' (STC: 85; HST: 104), NNaga *C/V-criŋ ``raw, grass'' [French 1983: 351]. With vowel *a: WB hraŋ ``live, alive''.
	See {Table S-1} [Live, fresh, green (A): *s(r)iŋ ~ *s(r)aŋ ] ◇
::Mikir	reŋᴸ	``live, come to life''
>:ST terminative final *-ŋ derivation  from ST *sri ``to be, exist'', hence lit. ``come into existence > give birth > live'':

>:Manchati sriŋ ``to live, alive''
>:Lushai hriŋᴴ / hrinᴸ ``fresh, green'' ⪤ hriŋᴴ / hrinᴿ ``bear, beget''

>:Chepang sriŋ- ``open out'' , begin to blossom’
>:Mikir reŋᴸ ``live, come to life''
>:JP tsiŋ³³ < rjiŋ  ``weeds, rank grass''
>:NNaga *C/V-criŋ ``raw, grass'' . With vowel *a:
>:WB hraŋ ``live, alive''

ENTRY:3325
HEAD:shēng₅ 聲
MC:Middle Chinese: śjäŋ 
LH:Later Han: śeŋ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *hieŋ ?
GLOSS:"Sound" (especially with respect to volume),
GLOSS:"note, fame" [Shi].
	[T] Sin Sukchu SR ʂiŋ (平)
	[T] MGZY shing (平) [ʂiŋ]
	[T] ONW śeŋ
	[D] PMin *šiaŋ > Xiàmén col. siãᴬ¹, Fúzhōu siaŋ⁴⁴, K-Méixiàn saŋ⁴⁴
	[D] PMin * ~ *tsʰiaŋ > Jiànyáng tshiaŋᴬ¹
	[E] Perh. ST, note a similar-looking Lushai word with identical meaning: tʰaŋᴴ / tʰanᴸ < saŋ ``become known, be renowned; to sound or travel (as sound), resound''.
	However, foreign initial s- is impossible to reconcile with MC śj- which goes back to an OC voiceless continuant, perhaps *hj-, unless we assume *he/iŋ ~ *saŋ parallel stems of the kind which have been suggested for ``odor, smell'', see under {xiāng₂ 香}.
	<> Tai: S. siaŋᴬ¹ ``sound'' looks like a loan from a southern CH dialect.
	[C] A derivation is perhaps {shèng₁ 聖} ``wise''.
>:Perh. ST, note a similar-looking Lushai word with identical meaning:
>:tʰaŋᴴ / tʰanᴸ < saŋ ``become known, be renowned; to sound or travel , resound''

ENTRY:3329
HEAD:shèng₁ 聖

LH:Later Han: śeŋᶜ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *hieŋh ? or *lheŋh ?
GLOSS:"Be wise" [Shi],
GLOSS:"a wise, knowledgeable person" [Hanfei].
	[T] Sin Sukchu SR ʂiŋ (去)
	[T] MGZY shing (去) [ʂiŋ]
	[T] ONW śeŋ
	[E] This word is often related to {tīng₂ 聽} ``hear'' (Boltz 1994: 116) in which case OCM would be *lheŋh. Formally, it looks like a derivation from {shēng₅ 聲} ``sound'', in which case it would be OCM *hjeŋh and literally mean ``be renowned, one who is renowned'' (for his wisdom).
>:This word is often related to {tīng₂ 聽} ``hear''  in which case OCM would be *lheŋh. Formally, it looks like a derivation from {shēng₅ 聲} ``sound'', in which case it would be OCM *hjeŋh and literally mean ``be renowned, one who is renowned''

GLOSS:"strain off" which has a different etymology, though.
	[<] *lai + s-prefix: This etymon is derived from {yí₆ 迤迆} ``slant, deflect'' ST *lai + interative s-prefix ({§5.2.3}). For *ai ~ *e variation, see {§11.3.3}.

	[E] ST *s-lai: Lushai tʰleiᴿ < sleʔ ``to sift'' (by side to side motion) ⪤ tʰleᴸ / tʰleekᶠ < slees / sleek ``to sway / lean to one side''; see under {yí₆ 迤迆} for more Lushai cognates. Bodman (1980: 179) relates this word to Viet. rây ``to strain, sift, sieve''.
	[E] This item has nearly converged with {shāi,shī 篩} *sre, the putative Lushai cognates suggest separate etymologies.

	[T] (ONW śik ?)
GLOSS:"Really" [Shi, Shu].
	[E] ST: PLB *dyak ``truly, very, intensive'', WB tyak-tyak ``very'' (HST: 122), Lushai takᴸ ``real, true''.
::Lushai	takᴸ	``real, true''
>:PLB *dyak ``truly, very, intensive''
>:WB tyak-tyak ``very''
>:Lushai takᴸ ``real, true''

ENTRY:3365
HEAD:shí₁₀ 寔 ⪤ shí 實

	{shí₁₃} 實

ENTRY:3367
HEAD:shí₁₂ 實
MC:Middle Chinese: dźjet 
LH:Later Han: źit 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *m-lit ?
GLOSS:"Fruit" [Shi], also fruit as seat of life, hence
GLOSS:"seed" [Shi 290, 291].
	[T] Sin Sukchu SR ʂi (入)
	[T] MGZY ci (入) [dʐi]
	[T] ONW źit
	[E] Etymology not certain. Most likely, shí is related to a ST or area etymon: Unger (Hao-ku 85, 1992: 93f) relates it to Lepcha lí, lí-m ``be ripe'', lí, a-lí  ``seed''; Mikir lík ``pick, pluck''.
	This may possibly be connected with MK: PVM *p-leːʔ > pleːʔ > tleːʔ ``fruit'' [Ferlus], Khmuʔ pleʔ, PWa *pliʔ, Pear phli, PSBahn. *pəlaj, Khmer phlaɛ. Shí could be equally close to the AA or the TB items because the OC final *-t is a nominalizing suffix for natural objects ({§6.2.1}), and OC *m- for foreign b- has parallels ({§5.12.2}).
	Alternatively, Baxter / Sagart (1998: 52) relate this word to {zhì₁₈ 質} ``essential'' and note a possible relationship with PTai *mlet or *mret ``grain, seed'' [Li F. 1977: 93]; the Tai word could, however, also be connected with {mǐ₁ 米} ``rice''.
::PVM	*p-leːʔ > pleːʔ > tleːʔ	``fruit''
>:Etymology not certain. Most likely, shí is related to a ST or area etymon:
>:Unger  relates it to Lepcha lí, lí-m ``be ripe'', lí, a-lí  ``seed''
>:Mikir lík ``pick, pluck''

ENTRY:3380

GLOSS:"man, male, masculine" is also suggested by the graph which serves as an element in {mǔ₁ 牡}
GLOSS:"male" (of animals).
	[T] Sin Sukchu SR ʐi (上去), PR ʐʅ

	[E] This word is reminiscent of AA synonyms: OKhmer si ``male'', MK languages on the Malay Peninsula have forms like ʔŋsiil, ensir, kəsəy ``male, man'' (Lewitz 1976: 769). Foreign final -r (note ensir) sometimes leaves a trace in the OC initial complex ({§7.7.3}).

ENTRY:3381
HEAD:shì₂ 士仕
MC:Middle Chinese: dẓɨᴮ 
LH:Later Han: dẓəᴮ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *dzrəʔ
	[T] MTang dẓi (?) ONW dẓə (?)
	(``To give or carry out an assignment'':) ``to take office, give an office, serve'' 仕士 [Shi]; ``retainer, knight'' (A. Waley), ``retainers'' [BI, Shi] > ``servant, officer'' [BI, Shi] ``officer'' 士 [BI, Shi]; later ``scholar''.
	It is natural to assume that {shì₁ 士} and shì₂ 士 are the same word with the semantic development ``male > man > servant > to serve''.
	However, the ancient derivation {shì₁₂ 事} (below shì₂ 士仕) and TB counterparts show no association with the notion ``man, maleness'', while ``male'' hardly derives from ``affair, serve''.
	Therefore it seems necessary to separate the present shì₂ 士 ``serve'' from {shì₁ 士} ``male''.
	MK relations of {shì₁ 士}, if valid, would support this distinction.
	[E] These forms are derivatives (corresponding to a hypothetical MK ɉrə) from the root {lǐ₆ 理}, therefore ultimately of AA origin. The MC initial dẓ- normally does not co-occur with MC l- and ṣ- in a ST wf, which confirms a non-ST, i.e.
	AA provenance.
	<> AA or OC ⇒ PTB *ʔ-dzəy¹ ``send on an errand'' (HPTB: 199) > WB ca ``a thing'' (so Gong Hwang-cherng 1999), WT rdzas ``thing, matter, object''.
	TB cognates to this etymon and to {suǒ₁ 所} are difficult to distinguish.
::WT	rdzas	``thing, matter, object''
>:These forms are derivatives  from the root {lǐ₆ 理}, therefore ultimately of AA origin. The MC initial dẓ- normally does not co-occur with MC l- and ṣ- in a ST wf, which confirms a non-ST, i.e

ENTRY:3384
HEAD:shì₄ 氏
MC:Middle Chinese: źieᴮ 
LH:Later Han: gieᴮ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *geʔ ?
	An honorific which is suffixed to place names (fiefs, e.g. 夏氏 ``the Lord of Xia''), kinship terms (舅氏 ``the uncle''), feudal and official titles (仲氏任 ``Lady Zhōng Rèn''): ``lord, lady'' [BI, Shi, Shu] > ``clan'' [Lun].
	[E] The etymology is not clear.
>:The etymology is not clear

ENTRY:3399
HEAD:shì₁₆ 舐 ⪤ shé 舌
MC:Middle Chinese: dźjät 
LH:Later Han: źat 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *m-let ? 
OCB:Baxter Old Chinese: *mlăt
GLOSS:"Tongue" [Shi].
	[T] Sin Sukchu SR ʐje (入)
	[T] ONW źat
	[<] shì 舐 *m-leʔ ``to lick'' + nominal t-suffix for natural objects ({§6.2.1}), lit. ``licker''.
	[D] Some southern dialects have preserved the OC initial *l- in this sound symbolic etymon. The equivalents of shì and shé mean variously ``tongue'' or ``to lick'':
GLOSS:1:Shì: Y-Guǎngzhōu ³¹laiᴮ¹
GLOSS:"lick", Guǎngzhōu leiᶜ²
GLOSS:"tongue"; K-Dànshuǐ liᶜ-maᴬ² ``tongue'' where maᴬ² represents perhaps the KS morpheme maᴬ² ``tongue'' (R. Bauer, CAAAL 28, 1987: 60).
GLOSS:2:Shé: The
GLOSS:"softened" initial in PMin *d̯žiat
GLOSS:"tongue" may indicate prenasalization, hence OCM *m-l-, which is supported by the MY borrowing *nbret (< *mlet ?) (Norman 1986: 383).
	SMin Dōngshāndǎo tsiʔᴰ² ``to lick'', Fúzhōu liakᴰ¹ ``to lick''.
	[E] ST, the stem *m/s-lei means ``to lick'' or (``licker'':) ``tongue'': PTB *m/s-lei (STC no. 281): > Kokborok (Bodo-Garo) šlày [Joseph / Burling LTBA 24.2, 2001: 52], WT lče < lhye, Kanauri-Manchati hle, Gurung le’, Dimasa salai, WB hlya (STC p. 64); JR temeli; Kuki *m-lei > Lushai leiᴴ, SChin Daai mlei ``tongue'' [Hartmann ICSTLL 1999: 2]; Dulong pə̂laì ``tongue'' [LaPolla, LTBA 24.2: 26]. Benedict (LTBA 5.1, 1979: 21) suggests that TB ``penis'', e.g.
	WT mǰe, is the same etymon (``body-tongue'').
	Only few TB languages have forms with final *-t like CH shé; it seems that the t-suffix has not been inherited from ST: Magari milet (or me-leʈ), let, Newari meč ``tongue'', JP ʃiŋ³¹-let³¹.
	Initial *l- is a near-universal sound symbolic feature for ``lick / tongue'', hence similar words in other languages are not likely to be genetically related, such as MK *lait ``lick'' (Shorto 2006: 1075), PVM *laːs ``tongue'' [Ferlus]; Kam-Tai: S. liaᴬ² < *dl- ``to lick'', PKS *lja² ? [Thurgood].
	[C] Matisoff (1995: 71) connects this wf with {shí₄ 食} ``eat'' (whose TB cognates mean ``lick''), and {tián₃ 甜} ``sweet'', all of which have OC initial *l-.
::PVM	*laːs	``tongue''
>:ST, the stem *m/s-lei means ``to lick'' or  ``tongue'':
>:PTB *m/s-lei :
>:> Kokborok  šlày
>:WT lče < lhye
>:Kanauri-Manchati hle
>:Gurung le’, Dimasa salai, WB hlya
>:JR temeli
>:Kuki *m-lei >
>:Lushai leiᴴ
>:SChin Daai mlei ``tongue''
>:Dulong pə̂laì ``tongue'' . Benedict  suggests that TB ``penis'', e.g

ENTRY:3402
HEAD:shì₁₇ 視 ⪤ zhǐ 指

GLOSS:"To point to" [Shi],
GLOSS:"aim" [Shu] > (``pointer'':)
GLOSS:"finger" [Zuo].
GLOSS-NOTE:Tone B is apparently part of the stem, therefore zhǐ is not an endoactive derivation.
	[T] Sin Sukchu SR tʂi (上), PR, LR tʂʅ
	[T] MGZY ji (上) [tʂi]
	[T] ONW tśi

ENTRY:3403
HEAD:shì₁₇ 視 ⪤ chén₁ 臣
MC:Middle Chinese: źjen 
LH:Later Han: gin 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *gin
GLOSS:"Epískopos", one who
GLOSS:"watches" and looks after things/people on behalf of higher authority; an echo of the etymology is a phrase like chén zuò zhèn … ěr mù 臣作朕 … 耳目
GLOSS:"the chén function as my (the ruler's) … ears and eyes" [Shu 5, 12].
GLOSS-NOTE:The graph, a drawing of an
GLOSS:"eye", also connects the word with the notion
GLOSS:"to watch".
	Hence the meanings: ``a subject, servant'', as well as ``minister, person in charge'', ``be subject to, function as a subject of'' [OB, BI], xiǎo-chén 小臣 ``junior minister'' [OB, BI]; with lesser rank ``retainers'', hǔ-chén 虎臣 some kind of body guard; with low rank ``servant, subject'' [BI, Shi], chén-qiè 臣妾 ``servants and maids'' [BI, Shu] (Keightley 1969: 191ƒƒ); ``servant'' > ``I'' (when speaking to a superior).
	[T] Sin Sukchu SR dʐin (平)
	[T] MGZY  zhin (平) [ʐin]
	[T] ONW dźin
	[N] OC initial *g- is supported by GSR 368 which includes qiān 掔 (kʰien), where chén (GSR 377) is phonetic.
	[<] nominal *-n derivation from {shì₁₇ 視} *giʔ ``to see, watch, look after'' ({§6.4.3}), lit. ``a watcher, supervisor''.
	[E] Bodman (1980: 158) relates chén to WT ’gyiŋ-ba ``look down upon, despise''  (for the difference in finals, see {§6.4.1}), but see next:
::WT	’gyiŋ-ba	``look down upon, despise''
>:Bodman  relates chén to WT ’gyiŋ-ba ``look down upon, despise''  , but see next:
>:

	{chè₂} 徹撤

MC:Middle Chinese: źjäiᶜ 
LH:Later Han: dźas 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *da(t)s
GLOSS:"A formal statement, oath, make an oath" [BI, Shi, Shu].
GLOSS-NOTE:Perh. the homophone shì 筮
GLOSS:"divine with milfoil oracle" [BI, Shi] is the same word (<
GLOSS:"make clear"). This etymon may belong to {zhé₃ 哲} ``clear, perspicacious''.

ENTRY:3425
HEAD:shǒu₁ 手
MC:Middle Chinese: śjəuᴮ 
LH:Later Han: śuᴮ,S tśʰuᴮ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *nhuʔ ?, or 
OCB:Baxter Old Chinese: *hjuʔ ?
GLOSS:"Hand" [Shi].
	[T] Sin Sukchu SR ʂiw (上)
	[T] MGZY shiw (上) [ʂiw]
	[T] ONW śu
	[D] PMin *tšʰiuᴮ¹ > Xiàmén tsʰiuᴮ, PWMin *ʃiuᴮ¹.
	[E] The OC form and etymology are a matter of conjecture: (1) Unger (Hao-ku 46, 1995: 133f) reconstructs this word with an OC nasal initial; he bases this on the Shìmíng  (a Han period sound gloss dictionary) gloss xū 須 < *sn-, and the GY graph 杽 for QYS ṇjəuᴮ ~ ṭʰjəuᴮ 杻 (also Wáng Lì 1982: 231). He suggests that shǒu is cogn. to {niǔ₁ 狃丑} ``finger''. (2) Alternatively, shǒu may be derived from {shōu 收} ``take, gather'', tone B would then be the endoactive morpheme: ``hand'' < lit. ``the thing that is doing the taking'' ({§4.5.1}).
>:The OC form and etymology are a matter of conjecture:
>:Unger  reconstructs this word with an OC nasal initial
>:he bases this on the Shìmíng   gloss xū 須 < *sn-, and the GY graph 杽 for QYS ṇjəuᴮ ~ ṭʰjəuᴮ 杻 . He suggests that shǒu is cogn. to {niǔ₁ 狃丑} ``finger''.  Alternatively, shǒu may be derived from {shōu 收} ``take, gather'', tone B would then be the endoactive morpheme:
>:``hand'' < lit. ``the thing that is doing the taking''

ENTRY:3428
HEAD:shǒu₃ 首
MC:Middle Chinese: śjəuᴮ 
LH:Later Han: śuᴮ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *lhuʔ
	[T] ONW śu
GLOSS:"Head" [BI, Shi] may already have become a homophone of shǒu 手
GLOSS:"hand" in a WZhou BI (Yù guǐ  遹簋); shǒu was replaced by {tóu₃ 頭}
GLOSS:"head" by the Zhànguó period (Unger Hao-ku 46, 1995: 133). A tone C derivation is ``to point the head towards'' [Liji] (Downer 1959: 280).
	[E] ST: PTB *lu ``head'': Lushai luᴴ < luu ``head'' (Unger Hao-ku 46, 1995: 133; CVST 3: 43). Less plausible would be a connection with the TB word for ``brain''; although a foreign final -k can regularly correspond to CH tone B ({§3.2.2}), it is phonologically and semantically not close: Lushai thluakᴴ (< *khl- or *sl-), WT glod ``brain''.
	There are also similarities with words outside ST: PTai *kləuᶜ¹ ``head, knot of hair on top of the head'', PKS *kru³-f. ``head''; PVM *k-loːk / *k-lok ``head'', but a relationship with CH is unlikely.
::PVM	*k-loːk / *k-lok	``head''
>:PTB *lu ``head'':
>:Lushai luᴴ < luu ``head'' . Less plausible would be a connection with the TB word for ``brain''
>:although a foreign final -k can regularly correspond to CH tone B , it is phonologically and semantically not close:
>:Lushai thluakᴴ
>:WT glod ``brain''

ENTRY:3432
HEAD:shòu₃ 獸
MC:Middle Chinese: śjəuᶜ 
LH:Later Han: śuᶜ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *-uh
GLOSS:"Wild animal, animal" (i.e. quadruped) [Shi].
GLOSS-NOTE:Opposite {chù₄,xù 畜}
GLOSS:"domestic animal", lit.
GLOSS:"what is raised".
	[T] Sin Sukchu SR ʂiw (去)
	[T] MGZY shiw (去) [ʂiw]
	[<] exopass. of shòu 狩 *-uʔ ``what is hunted'' ({§4.4}) (Wáng Lì 1982: 237). Benedict relates shòu to the widespread TB etymon *sya ``flesh, animal'' (STC: 168 n. 452); however, PTB *a for OC *u (or *o) is unusual (e.g. {ròu₁ 肉} ``meat''), and a foreign sj- never seems to relate to a MC palatal śj-.
	[E] Outside CH, WT ’čʰor-ba, (b)šor ``to hunt'' could theoretically be reconciled with MC if we assume a voiceless palatalized initial *rhj-, *lhj- or *hj-, and loss of ST final *-r which has occurred in a few other words. But this is rather speculative.
::WT	’čʰor-ba, šor	``to hunt''
>:Outside CH
>:WT ’čʰor-ba, šor ``to hunt'' could theoretically be reconciled with MC if we assume a voiceless palatalized initial *rhj-, *lhj- or *hj-, and loss of ST final *-r which has occurred in a few other words. But this is rather speculative

ENTRY:3449
HEAD:shǔ₁ 鼠
MC:Middle Chinese: śjwoᴮ 
LH:Later Han: śɑᴮ ~ tśʰɑᴮ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *nhaʔ ? 
OCB:Baxter Old Chinese: *hjaʔ ?
GLOSS:"Rat" [Shi].
	[T] Sin Sukchu SR ʂy (上)
	[T] MGZY shÿu (上) [ʂy]
	[T] ONW śo > śø
	[D] Southern and NW dialects have variants with affricate initial: PMin *tšʰyᴮ: Xiàmén tsʰuᴮ, Fúzhōu tsʰyᴮ
	[D] Kèjiā *tšʰuᴮ¹: Méixiàn tsʰuᴮ
	[D] W-Wēnzhōu tɕʰi⁴⁵ (Běidà tsʰeiᴮ). NW-Xīníng tʂʰv̆⁵³, Dūnhuáng -tʂʰu⁴², Lánzhōu pfʰu³³.
	[E] Etymology not clear. Note PMon *[c/s]naaʔ in Nyah-Kur ``shrew'' (a shrew is hard to distinguish from a mouse), in Mon ``squirrel''; the PMon word for ``rat, mouse'' is *kniiʔ, PNBahnaric *kane ``rat'' which is an alternate candidate as a source for shǔ if we assume the occasional shift from front vowel to OC *a ({§11.1.3}). <> PKS *kʰ-noᶜ ``rat'' (Edmondson / Yang 1988) may be related.
	The case for OCM *n- in shǔ is suggested by {shǔ₂ 癙} *nhaʔ.
	The TB word for ``rat, mouse'' *yu had acquired the meaning ``weasel'' in Old Chinese ({yòu₉ 鼬}).
::PKS	*kʰ-noᶜ	``rat''
>:Etymology not clear. Note PMon *naaʔ in Nyah-Kur ``shrew'' , in Mon ``squirrel''
>:the PMon word for ``rat, mouse'' is *kniiʔ
>:PNBahnaric *kane ``rat'' which is an alternate candidate as a source for shǔ if we assume the occasional shift from front vowel to OC *a . < > PKS *kʰ-noᶜ ``rat''  may be related

GLOSS:"barley". Both millet and barley were the staple cereals grown in ancient Northern China and Tibet respectively.

ENTRY:3457
HEAD:shǔ₇ 樹
MC:Middle Chinese: źjuᴮ 
LH:Later Han: dźoᴮ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *doʔ
GLOSS:"To plant, place upright" [Shi],
GLOSS:"establish" 樹 [Zuo];
GLOSS:"to stand" [Hou Hanshu], ``be in attendance'' [OB], (someone standing by:) ``attendant'' 豎 [Zuo].
	[T] Sin Sukchu SR ʐy (上)
	[T] MGZY zhÿu (上) [ʐy]
	[E] Area word: Lushai tuʔᴸ < tus ``to plant'' (a seed) (for the vowels, see {§11.9.1}). <> AA: Khmer ṭuh /doh/ ``to grow, sprout …'' ⪤ caus. /pdoh/ ``to plant, grow'' (crops).
	The development to the CH meaning shù 樹 ``tree'' may have been encouraged through interference from AA: PSouthern MK *jhuuʔ or *perhaps *jhɨɨʔ ``wood'' (substance, general) [Diffloth MKS 16-17, 1990: 4] > OKhmer jhe [Jenner / Pou], jhö [Diffloth] ``tree, wood'', also ``fuel'' in Khamuk [Shorto 1971: 117] (Khmer jhe is perhaps more directly reflected in {chái₁ 柴}). Shù is not a loan because PAA *j, *c normally do not correspond to an OC dental stop initial.
	It is not clear if / how the following candidates for cognation are connected: WT bžugs-pa (< *b-dyuk-s?) ``to sit, dwell'' (so HST: 68f), or PTB *dzu[ː]k (STC no. 360) > WT ’dzug-pa ~ zug-pa ``prick or stick into, plant, erect''. Syn. {zhì₂₂ 置}.
::WT	’dzug-pa ~ zug-pa	``prick or stick into, plant, erect''
>:Area word:
>:Lushai tuʔᴸ < tus ``to plant''  . < > AA:
>:Khmer ṭuh /doh/ ``to grow, sprout …'' ⪤ caus. /pdoh/ ``to plant, grow''

	Shù and xù form a ST s- ~ m- set.
	Bodman (1980: 96) has set up a wf which combines all the items in final *-t here with {lǜ₁ 律}.

ENTRY:3471
HEAD:shuāi 衰

LH:Later Han: ṣui 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *srui
GLOSS:"To diminish, decline, decay" [Lun].
	[T] Sin Sukchu SR ʂuj (平), PR ʂwaj
	[T]  MGZY (zhway >) shway (平) [ʂwaj]
	[E] AA has a similar-looking word: Khmer /ríiəw/ ``diminish, decrease, taper (off), slim slender …'' ⪤ /srìiəw/ ``be small-boned and slender'', but the diphthong is the reverse of CH; perhaps a metathesis from *-iu to *-ui took place in OC (a parallel case may be {něi 餒} ``hungry''). An alternative comparandum may be Lushai zuaiᶠ < juaiʔ ``decline'' (in diligence, enthusiasm), but Lushai initial z- usually derives from PTB *y-, and the semantic agreement is not as close.
::Lushai	zuaiᶠ < juaiʔ	``decline''

ENTRY:3482
HEAD:shuǐ 水
MC:Middle Chinese: świᴮ 
LH:Later Han: śuiᴮ,S tśuiᴮ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *lhuiʔ 
OCB:Baxter Old Chinese: *[l]huiʔ ?
GLOSS:"Water, river" [OB, Shi].
	[T] Sin Sukchu SR ʂuj, ʂi (上), PR ʂi, LR ʂuj
	[T] MGZY shue (上) [ʂuɛ]
	[T]  ONW śui
	[D] PMin *tšuiᴮ
	[E] ST: PTB *lwi(y) [STC no. 210] > JP lui³³ ``to flow'' (as water), Lushai luiᴸ < luih, Tiddim luuiᶠ < luuih ``stream, river'' (HST: 158). Perh. this is an area etymon, note possible MK connections: OMon lwuy; Khmer /luj/ ``float, drift''; Viet. lọy ``swim'', Wa-Lawa-Bulang *l[o]y ``swim''. MK ⇒ PTai *hlwəiᴬ¹ ``to flow'' > S. laiᴬ¹ (Li 1977:137; 286); Khmer ⇒ PTai *lɔiᴬ² > S. lɔɔiᴬ² ``to float'' (Li 1977: 134, 288), Saek tlooyᴬ¹ ``to flow''.
	Given the occasional alternation between l and r, the following may also be connected or be parallel etyma: PKS *kruːi³ ``stream'', PTai *xruəiᶜ (?) > S. huaiᶜ¹ ``mountain stream'', Saek rii³ < hriiᶜ¹ ``id.'', perhaps also Tai: S. huui³ ``a stream, creek''.
	Similar-looking MK etyma are prob. not connected: PNBahn. hayŭh, P-Hrê-Sedang riùh ``stream'' [Smith 1972: 52], also PMonic *hiiw ``to flow, drift''.
	Tone B prob. marks the word as an endoactive derivation from a ST root, lit. ``what is flowing'' ({§4.5.1}).
	The voiceless initial may go back to an earlier nominalizing prefix, either *k- ({§5.4}) or *s- which is found in old ST nouns which relate to naturally occurring things ({§5.2.4}).
	Another derivation from the ST root may be {xuàn₁ 泫} *wînʔ ``to flow''.
::PMonic	*hiiw	``to flow, drift''
>:PTB *lwi  >
>:JP lui³³ ``to flow''
>:Lushai luiᴸ < luih
>:Tiddim luuiᶠ < luuih ``stream, river'' . Perh. this is an area etymon, note possible MK connections:
>:OMon lwuy
>:Khmer /luj/ ``float, drift''
>:Viet. lọy ``swim''
>:Wa-Lawa-Bulang *ly ``swim''. MK ⇒ PTai *hlwəiᴬ¹ ``to flow'' >
>:S. laiᴬ¹
>:Khmer ⇒ PTai *lɔiᴬ² >
>:S. lɔɔiᴬ² ``to float''
>:Saek tlooyᴬ¹ ``to flow''

ENTRY:3483
HEAD:shuì₁ 睡
MC:Middle Chinese: źwieᶜ 
LH:Later Han: dźuaiᶜ,dźoiᶜ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *doih or *djoih ?
	[T] ONW dźue
GLOSS:"To sleep" [Guoce].
	[E] Since both CH and WT have a word for ``sleep'' which is nearly homophonous with one for ``droop'', it is probable that shuì is derived from {chuí₁ 垂} *doi ``droop''. The WT cognate seems to be yur-ba ``to slumber'' ⪤ g-yur ``sleep'' (Bodman 1980: 80) ⪤ g-yur-ba ``droop, hang or sink down'' (of fading flowers etc.), but phonologically, the OC items are closer to a parallel stem in rime *-ol, see {chuí₁ 垂}.
>:Since both CH and WT have a word for ``sleep'' which is nearly homophonous with one for ``droop'', it is probable that shuì is derived from {chuí₁ 垂} *doi ``droop''. The WT cognate seems to be yur-ba ``to slumber'' ⪤ g-yur ``sleep''  ⪤ g-yur-ba ``droop, hang or sink down'' , but phonologically, the OC items are closer to a parallel stem in rime *-ol, see {chuí₁ 垂}

GLOSS:"tax" means lit.
GLOSS:"something peeled off the top".
	Alternatively, shuì may be derived from shū 輸 ``to transport, convey to'' (under {yú₁₈ 踰逾}).

ENTRY:3487
HEAD:shǔn₁ 吮
MC:Middle Chinese: dźjuenᴮ 
LH:Later Han: źunᴮ (źuinᴮ) 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *m-l(i)unʔ ?
	[D] PMin *d̯zionᴮ < *Ndź-
GLOSS:"To suck" [Hanfei].
	[E] ST has several stems from a single root (for TB, see also HPTB: 81, 84, 481):
GLOSS:1:*mlyu-n: PTB *m-lyun > Kanauri *myun
GLOSS:"to swallow", JP mə³¹-run³¹
GLOSS:"suck".
GLOSS:2:*mlyu-k: PTB *m-lyuːk > Lushai zuᴸ / zuukᶠ < juʔ/s / juuk
GLOSS:"to drink" (by sucking a tube),
GLOSS:"to bite" (as leech), Ao-Naga ³mɯ³yuk (*m-yuk) ``to swallow'' [Weidert 1987: 457], JP mə³¹-yuʔ³¹ ``throat, swallow'' ⪤ luʔ³¹ < luk ``to drink, suck'', Chepang yok-sa ``to swallow''.
GLOSS:3:PTB *mlyuw: PLB *myuw > WB myui (inscr. mlyui )
GLOSS:"swallow" [Matisoff 1978: 29], Angami Naga me-zu < m-ju
GLOSS:"id.", SChin Daai mjo ``swallow'' [Hatmann ICSTLL 1999: 2], Karen Sgaw ju (STC no. 153; p. 147f).
	The complex proto-initial is prob. responsible for three different reflexes in JP: mə³¹-run³¹ ``suck'', mə³¹-yuʔ³¹ ``throat, swallow'', luʔ³¹ < luk ``to drink, suck''.
	WT ldud-pa, blud < ɴlut ``give to drink, to water'' belongs to the same root.
::WT	ldud-pa, blud < ɴlut	``give to drink, to water''
>:ST has several stems from a single root :
>:

ENTRY:3489
HEAD:shùn₁ 順
MC:Middle Chinese: dźjuenᶜ 
LH:Later Han: źunᶜ (> źuinᶜ) 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *m-luns
GLOSS:"To follow, agree, be agreeable" [BI, Shi].
	[T] Sin Sukchu SR ʐyn (去)
	[T] MGZY cÿun (去) [dʐyn]
	[T] ONW źuin
	[<] *lun + ST m-prefix ({§8.1.3}).
	[E] ST: WT ’čʰun-pa ``be tamed, subdued'' ⪤ ’ǰun-pa, bčun, gžun ``subdue, punish, soften'' (HST: 146). OC *m- ~ *s- is parallel to the TB root for ``follow'' which Matisoff (LTBA 15.1, 1992: 163) has set up for ``Kamarupan'', see {suì₂ 遂} for additional possible cognates.
>:WT ’čʰun-pa ``be tamed, subdued'' ⪤ ’ǰun-pa, bčun, gžun ``subdue, punish, soften'' . OC *m- ~ *s- is parallel to the TB root for ``follow'' which Matisoff  has set up for ``Kamarupan'', see {suì₂ 遂} for additional possible cognates

ENTRY:3507
HEAD:sī₁ 司
MC:Middle Chinese: sɨ 
LH:Later Han: siə 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *sə
	[T]  ONW siə
GLOSS:"Be in charge, manage" >
GLOSS:"regulation, supervisor" [BI, Shu].

	Unger (Hao-ku 30, 1984: 294) sees a possible relationship with WT rdzi-bo ``herdsman, shepherd, keeper'' instead.
	The semantic fields of similar etyma suggest that sī₁ 司 ``act'' and {sī₃ 思} ``think'' are the same word.

ENTRY:3511
HEAD:sī₄ 絲
MC:Middle Chinese: sɨ 
LH:Later Han: siə 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *sə
GLOSS:"Silk" [BI, Shi] is often said to be the source of European words for
GLOSS:"silk", Gr. sērikón. The Western /r/ is then taken as proof that the OC form ended in some kind of consonant.
	However, it is simpler to derive Western words from {Qín₁ 秦}.

ENTRY:3513
HEAD:sī₆,chī 颸
MC:Middle Chinese: tṣʰɨ 
LH:Later Han: tṣʰə 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *tshrə ?
GLOSS:"Cold wind" [SW, Chuci],
GLOSS:"wind" [Guǎngyǎ].
	[E] Etymology not clear. WT rdzi ``wind'' which sī resembles (Unger Hao-ku 30, 1984: 294) belongs to PTB *g-li(y) ``wind'' (STC no. 454): WB le ``air, wind'', Tani rji ``wind''.
	WT prob. derives from earlier *ryi.
	More promising may be a link with PWMiao *tc-ᶜ (tcuaᶜ¹ etc.) ``wind'', especially since the CH word's first textual occurrence is in Chǔcí.
::Tani	rji	``wind''
>:Etymology not clear. WT rdzi ``wind'' which sī resembles  belongs to PTB *g-li ``wind'' :
>:WB le ``air, wind''
>:Tani rji ``wind''

ENTRY:3519
HEAD:sì₄ 兕
MC:Middle Chinese: ziᴮ 
LH:Later Han: ziᴮ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *s-jəiʔ ?
GLOSS:"Wild water buffalo" [OB, Shi, EY] (Lefeuvre MS 39, 1990-91: 131-157). This word was sometimes mistakenly thought to be a variant of {xī₁₁ 犀}
GLOSS:"rhinoceros".
	[E] Area word: NTai *ǰɨəᴬ/ᶜ ``ox, cow'' (Li 1977) or NTai *ǰɨaᴬ ``ox, cow'' (Gedney ICSTLL 1981), the OC and PTai initials are the same as in {xiàng₅ 象} ``elephant''. <> Lushai sialᴴ < sial ``domestic buffalo'' seᴴ-leᴴ ``wild gayal (buffalo)'' (se- is the contracted form of sialᴴ).
	The ultimate source of this word may be AA; note Munda sahil, saili ``wild buffalo'', Gutob (Munda) saail ``wild buffalo, deer'' [Pinnow 1959: 423]. However, the contact with OC would be so remote that a regular phonological history is elusive.
::Munda	sahil, saili	``wild buffalo''
>:Area word:
>:NTai *ǰɨəᴬ/ᶜ ``ox, cow''  or NTai *ǰɨaᴬ ``ox, cow'' , the OC and PTai initials are the same as in {xiàng₅ 象} ``elephant''. < > Lushai sialᴴ < sial ``domestic buffalo'' seᴴ-leᴴ ``wild gayal ''

ENTRY:3520
HEAD:sì₅ 耜
MC:Middle Chinese: zɨᴮ 
LH:Later Han: ziəᴮ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *s-ləʔ
	The usual gloss is ``ploughshare, to plough'' [Shi]; however this implement consisted of a blade-like spade which was attached to a {lěi₁ 耒} digging stick which thus became its handle (Bodde 1975: 233ƒƒ), hence ``spade, to cultivate with a spade''. It originated perhaps in the Yao culture (W. Eberhard Lokalkulturen II: 224).
	Syn. {lí₆ 犁}.

ENTRY:3527
HEAD:sōng₂ 崧嵩
MC:Middle Chinese: sjuŋ 
LH:Later Han: suŋ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *suŋ < *sluŋ ?
GLOSS:"High" (of mountains) 崧 [Shi], 嵩 [Li].
	[D] M-Xiàmén lit. sioŋᴬ¹, col. siŋᴬ¹
	[N] The phonetic implies an OC medial *l in the initial. Sōng is the name of several mountains in Henan, Shandong, Hunan, Jiangxi, Fujian, including the name of the sacred mountain, the axis mundi (D. Pankenier EC 20, 1995: 139), in Henan near Luòyáng which was already venerated during the Xia dynasty.
	[E] MK *sluŋ, *sluuŋ ``high'' (Shorto 2006 #763): PMonic *slooŋ ``be high up, high, tall'' (person, mountain), OMon s-lūŋ ``be high'' ⪤ *s-m-loŋ ``top'' (of something) ⪤ /clɔŋ/ ``highest point, apex, spire'' ⪤ PMK *s-r-luuŋ (Shorto) > OMon sirluŋ ``height''; Khmer /-lóoŋ/ ``high, lofty''; Palaung hløøŋ ``long'', PWa *hloŋ ``high'' ⪤ *ʔṃ-loŋ ``hill''; Kharia ǰhalɔŋ ``high'' ⪤ sɛløŋ ``deep''.
	AA ⇒ SChin Daai msuuŋ ``mountain'' [Hartmann ICSTLL 1999: 2]. Perh. also ⇒ Tai: S. hləŋ ``rise high'' ⪤ tʰa-ləŋ ``to rise, climb'' (Unger Hao-ku 36, 1990: 53), note also S. sa⁴-laŋ³ ``lofty, straight, tall'' (tree).
	Tai: S. suuŋᴬ¹ < *s- ``high'' (Li F. 1976: 42) looks like a Chinese loan.
	A syn. or parallel stem with initial *r- is {lóng₁ 隆}.
::Daai	msuuŋ	``mountain''
>:MK *sluŋ, *sluuŋ ``high'' :
>:PMonic *slooŋ ``be high up, high, tall''
>:OMon s-lūŋ ``be high'' ⪤ *s-m-loŋ ``top''  ⪤ /clɔŋ/ ``highest point, apex, spire'' ⪤ PMK *s-r-luuŋ  >
>:OMon sirluŋ ``height''
>:Khmer /-lóoŋ/ ``high, lofty''
>:Palaung hløøŋ ``long''
>:PWa *hloŋ ``high'' ⪤ *ʔṃ-loŋ ``hill''
>:Kharia ǰhalɔŋ ``high'' ⪤ sɛløŋ ``deep''

ENTRY:3534
HEAD:sǒng₃ 聳
MC:Middle Chinese: sjwoŋᴮ 
LH:Later Han: sioŋᴮ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *soŋʔ
GLOSS:"Be born deaf" [SW], a Han period dialect word from the eastern Huái-Yangtze region, in Chǔ and Chén [FY 6,2].
GLOSS-NOTE:This word has the same meaning and OC rime as {lóng₆ 聾} *rôŋ
GLOSS:"deaf".
	The JY gives a variant reading shuǎng (ṣåŋᴮ) < *sroŋʔ which makes this word look like a s-prefix allofam of lóng, but this reading is late and might have been prompted by a gloss ``deaf on “both” shuāng 雙 (ṣåŋ) ears'' [FY 6] (yet 雙 and 聳 have different tones).

ENTRY:3535
HEAD:sǒng₄ 聳竦
GLOSS:"high"
	{sōng₂} 崧嵩

ENTRY:3536
HEAD:sòng₁ 送
MC:Middle Chinese: suŋᶜ 
LH:Later Han: soŋᶜ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *sôŋh.
GLOSS:"To escort, follow after, go along" [Shi],
GLOSS:"to send" [Zuo],
GLOSS:"to present" [Li].
	[T] Sin Sukchu SR suŋ (去)
	[T] MGZY sung (去) [suŋ]
	[T] ONW soŋ
	[D] M-Xiàmén lit. soŋᶜ¹, col. sɑŋᶜ¹
	[E] Etymology not certain. Note PSBahn. *sɔːŋ ``hand over'', and/or OKhmer jon /ɉoon/ ``to urge, persuade, invite, … drive, … accompany, escort, … bring to, offer, present'' (⇒ Thai chuən ``to urge, persuade … ask, invite …'').
	Association with WT stoŋs-pa, bstaŋs ``to accompany'' (Bodman 1980: 44), or with WT rdzoŋ-ba, (b)rdzaŋ(s) ``to send, expedite, dismiss'' are problematic because the WT vowel a does not agree with OC *o.
	[C] It is not clear if there is an etymological connection with {cóng₁ 從} ``follow''.
::WT	rdzoŋ-ba, (b)rdzaŋ(s)	``to send, expedite, dismiss''
>:Etymology not certain. Note PSBahn. *sɔːŋ ``hand over'', and/or OKhmer jon /ɉoon/ ``to urge, persuade, invite, … drive, … accompany, escort, … bring to, offer, present''

	[E] This wf could be ST and related to WT luŋ ``exhortation, admonition, instruction'' (HST: 36). Alternatively, it may be connected with WT gsuŋs (pf. of gsuŋ) ``to speak'' (resp.) (Unger Hao-ku), but the initials do not agree.
	[C] {xiōng₅ 訩} is probably unrelated.
::WT	gsuŋs 	``to speak''

ENTRY:3541
HEAD:sōu₂ 搜 ⪤ shuài 率

ENTRY:3542
HEAD:sōu₃,sǒu 搜
MC:Middle Chinese: səuᴮ 
LH:Later Han: so(ᴮ) 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *sô(ʔ)
GLOSS:"To move" [JY], Zhèng Xuán
GLOSS:"vigorous and rapid" (Karlgren Gl. 1154).
	[E] ST: PTB *m-sow ``awake'' > Dimasa masau, Lushai tʰoᴿ / tʰɔʔᴸ < soʔ / sɔs, Lai su ``be awake'' ⪤ džə-su ``awaken'' [VanBik LTBA 25.2, 2002: 106], Lakher pətʰeu, Khami əntʰau, Ao Naga meso ``arise, awake'' (STC: 65 no. 295; p. 118); Tamang ²so ``live''; WT gson-pa ``be alive, to wake, rouse, urge on''; WB (ə-)cʰoᴮ ``be quick'' ⪤ cʰo ``to rouse, urge on'', soᶜ ``quick, rapid''.
	This root ``to rouse, move, make move, quicken, quick'' has spawned a prolific wf; as on other occasions, CH etymological connections become clear by way of the larger ST picture.
	Note also the parallelism with the wf {zhèn₂ 振震} ``shake / pregnant / morning''.
	Related words and stems are:
	{sù₆ 速} ``quick'' > caus. ``urge on''
	{sù₇ 蔌} ``vegetables'' <> WT ’tsho-ba, sos ``to live, revive, last; feed, graze'' ⪤ gson-pa ``be alive, to wake, rouse, urge on''
	{sù₃ 夙} (``time when one wakes up'':) ``early morning; pregnant'' <> PLB: *C-sok  ~ *V-sok  ``morning, morrow''
	{zǒu 走} ``run, make run, urge on'' <> WB (ə-)cʰoᴮ ``be quick'' ⪤ cʰo ``to rouse, urge on''
	{sǒng₂ 慫聳} 駷 ``incite, make run'' <> WB cuiŋᴮ ``drive or ride fast''
	{xùn₅ 逡} ``rapid''
	{sāo₂ 騷} ``move, be shaken, hastily''
	
::WB	cuiŋᴮ	``drive or ride fast''
>:PTB *m-sow ``awake'' >
>:Dimasa masau
>:Lushai tʰoᴿ / tʰɔʔᴸ < soʔ / sɔs
>:Lai su ``be awake'' ⪤ džə-su ``awaken''
>:Lakher pətʰeu, Khami əntʰau, Ao Naga meso ``arise, awake''
>:Tamang ²so ``live''
>:WT gson-pa ``be alive, to wake, rouse, urge on''
>:WB cʰoᴮ ``be quick'' ⪤ cʰo ``to rouse, urge on'', soᶜ ``quick, rapid''

ENTRY:3543
HEAD:sōu₄ 獀
MC:Middle Chinese: ṣjəu 
LH:Later Han: ṣu 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *ṣo ? Leibian səuᴮ < *sôʔ
GLOSS:"Dog"; acc. to SW náo-sōu 獿獀 [nɑu-ṣu] is a Southern Yuè word (Mei / Norman 1976: 279). The role of the presyllable náo
GLOSS:"monkey" is not clear.
	[E] MK *cɔʔ ``dog'' (Shorto 2006 #41): Khmuʔ, Palaung-Wa *sɔʔ; PSBahn. *sɔː, but PNBahn. chó, PVM *ʔa-cɔːʔ > Viet. chó, Khmer ckae, PEKatuic *ʔaco. If available MK forms are any guide, the underlying word with its fricative /s/ (not affricate /c/) does, contrary to SW, not seem to belong to the Yuè (Viet) branch of MK. For the initials, see {§5.10.2}.
	This word also appears in TB languages: Limbu kotco ``dog''.
::Limbu	kotco	``dog''
>:MK *cɔʔ ``dog'' :
>:Khmuʔ
>:Palaung-Wa *sɔʔ
>:PSBahn. *sɔː, but PNBahn. chó
>:PVM *ʔa-cɔːʔ >
>:Viet. chó
>:Khmer ckae
>:PEKatuic *ʔaco. If available MK forms are any guide, the underlying word with its fricative /s/  does, contrary to SW, not seem to belong to the Yuè  branch of MK

ENTRY:3549
HEAD:sū₁ 蘇
MC:Middle Chinese: suo 
LH:Later Han: sɑ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *sŋâ 
OCB:Baxter Old Chinese: *sŋa
	[T] ONW so (Baxter 1992: 225)
GLOSS:"Grass, plant", a Han period Chǔ, Huái, Jiāng dialect word [FY 3,8].
	[E] This may be the same etymon as sù 蘇 ``revive'' and belong to the wf {wù₆ 悟寤}. The concepts ``live'' ~ ``fresh, green'' ~ ``plant'' are often connected.
	Although the OC graph needs to be set up with an *sŋ-cluster, an alternative association with WT rtswa (prob. orthographic for *r-tsa < *r-sa) ``grass, plants'' is also possible.
	By mid to late Han when this word appeared first in writing, an OC *sŋ- had simplified to *s- which made the graph then suitable for writing a word *sa.
	The item is not related to WT sŋo-ba ``be green'' ⪤ sŋo ``plant, vegetable, greens''; see {yuè₁ 月}.
::WT	sŋo-ba	``be green''
>:This may be the same etymon as sù 蘇 ``revive'' and belong to the wf {wù₆ 悟寤}. The concepts ``live'' ~ ``fresh, green'' ~ ``plant'' are often connected

ENTRY:3556
HEAD:sù₃ 夙
MC:Middle Chinese: sjuk 
LH:Later Han: suk 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *suk
	[D] M-Xiàmén lit. siokᴰ¹
GLOSS:"Early morning, early, soon" [Shi].
	[E] ST: PLB *C-sok ~ *V-sok ``morning, morrow'' [Matisoff TSR no. 125], Lushai tuukᶠ
GLOSS:"early morning" (< suuk?).
	WB sok-kra ``Venus'' is a loan from Mon /sɯk/ and ultimately from Skt śukrá ``bright, Venus'' (Shorto 1971: 379).
	[WFE] ST *so(w) ``move'' (under {sōu₃,sǒu 搜}), PTB *m-sow ``to stir, waken, move''; sù is ``the time when one wakes up and gets moving''. The OC final *-k in this word has been inherited from ST: *so + ST *-k of uncertain function ({§6.1}).
::PTB	*m-sow	``to stir, waken, move''
>:PLB *C-sok ~ *V-sok ``morning, morrow''
>:Lushai tuukᶠ

ENTRY:3557
HEAD:sù₃ 夙 = sù 夙
MC:Middle Chinese: sjuk 
LH:Later Han: suk 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *suk
GLOSS:"To quicken" >
GLOSS:"become pregnant" [Shi] (Shaughnessy 1991: 103f) is prob. the same word as
GLOSS:"early morning" which is semantically derived from the notion ``rouse, quicken''. Shaughnessy has concluded that in OB and a BI (early Zhou, Wǔ wáng) sù occasionally means ``to rout'' (an enemy).
	This is supported by the semantic range of this wf, but it is not certain if sù was the actual word intended by the graph, rather than a semantically closer cognate under {sù₆ 速}.

ENTRY:3558
HEAD:sù₄ 宿
MC:Middle Chinese: sjuk 
LH:Later Han: suk 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *suk
	[T] ONW suk
GLOSS:"To stay overnight, lodge" [Shi].
	[D] M-Xiàmén lit. siokᴰ¹, col. sikᴰ¹
	[WFE] Prob. AA: OKhmer /sruk/ Proto-Khmer ``shelter, place of security as opposed to forest, settlement, homeland'' ⪤ Khmer jruka /cruk/ ``shelter, refuge, asylum'' < derivatives of /ruk/ ``go down into, take shelter'' [Jenner / Pou 1982: 249]. We should expect a retroflex initial in MC, yet retroflection is occasionally lost, see for ex. {sù₈ 肅鱐}.
	STC (155 n. 419; p. 171 n. 457) relates this word to the TB items noted under {yè₁ 夜}, but the OC vowel *u as well as the initial are difficult to reconcile with TB.
::Khmer	jruka /cruk/	``shelter, refuge, asylum''

>:ST *swa-n :
>:PL *swan¹/² ``onion''
>:WB krak-swan

ENTRY:3572
HEAD:suàn₂ 算

	[T] MGZY son (去) [sɔn]
	[T] ONW suɑn
	[E] Etymology is not clear. A connection with WT ’čʰor-ba, šor ``to count'' has been suggested (Gong Hwang-cherng 1991); but WT š- would derive from earlier *sy-.
::WT	’čʰor-ba, šor	``to count''
>:Etymology is not clear. A connection with WT ’čʰor-ba, šor ``to count'' has been suggested
>:but WT š- would derive from earlier *sy-

HEAD:suī 綏

	[T] ONW sui

	[WFE] ST has *ŋ(w)al ~ *nwal parallel stems ({§5.12.1}) for this etymon:
GLOSS:1:*C-nwal >  綏 *snui, WT rnal
GLOSS:"rest, tranquility of mind" ⪤ mnal
GLOSS:"sleep", perhaps also ⪤ ñal-ba, ñol ``lie, down, sleep'' ⪤ mñel-ba ``get tired'' ⪤ ñel-ba ``be ill'' ⪤ mñald-po ``fall ill'' (Bodman 1980: 70; HST: 124); KN-Lai nuar / noʔr ``be slow'' [LTBA 20.2: 112].

ENTRY:3576
HEAD:suǐ₁ 髓
MC:Middle Chinese: swieᴮ 
LH:Later Han: syɑiᴮ,S tsʰyɑiᴮ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *soiʔ (< *swaiʔ?)
	[T] ONW sue
GLOSS:"Marrow" [Kuoce].
	[D] M-Xiàmén col. tsʰeᴮ¹
	[E] ST *swai is prob. related to ST *s(-)wi ``blood'', see {xuè₁ 血} ``blood'' (Matisoff LTBA 15.1, 1992: 168-177). Some TB languages have a cognate of xuě as well as of suǐ, one meaning ``blood'', the other ``marrow'', but not always the same ones: NNaga-Chang si ``blood'' (⪤ xuě), hai ``marrow'' (⪤ suǐ); JP sai³¹ ``blood'', lə³³-sui³³ ``marrow'' (Matisoff op. cit. p. 169).
::ST	*swi	``blood''
>:ST *swai is prob. related to ST *swi ``blood'', see {xuè₁ 血} ``blood'' . Some TB languages have a cognate of xuě as well as of suǐ, one meaning ``blood'', the other ``marrow'', but not always the same ones:
>:NNaga-Chang si ``blood'' , hai ``marrow''
>:JP sai³¹ ``blood'', lə³³-sui³³ ``marrow''

ENTRY:3577
HEAD:suǐ₂ □
	A Min word: Xiàmén suiᴮ¹ ``pretty, beautiful, lovely''.
	Norman (p.c.) suggests that this word may perhaps be the same as Mand. shuǐ  水 ``water'' which is found in the sense of ``pretty'' (``pretty much'') in certain expressions.
	But note also Tai: Siam suuiᴬ¹ ``beautiful''.
::Siam	suuiᴬ¹	``beautiful''

ENTRY:3578
HEAD:suì₁ 歲
MC:Middle Chinese: sjwäiᶜ 
LH:Later Han: syas 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *swats
GLOSS:"Year" [OB, BI, Shi],
GLOSS:"planet Jupiter" [Zuo] (Shaughnessy 1991: 99),
GLOSS:"year" (of age) [Meng].
GLOSS-NOTE:Shānhǎijīng implies that
GLOSS:"Jupiter" was already named suì at the beginning of the Zhou dynasty.
	[T] Sin Sukchu SR suj (去)
	[T] MGZY sue (去) [suɛ]
	[T] ONW  suei
	[D] PMin *hueᶜ ``year'' (of age) does not agree with the rest of Chinese dialects
	[D] perhaps there is a Tai connection.
	[<] Prob. derived from {yuè₄ 越} ``pass over'' (Mei Tsu-Lin Tsing Hua Journal of Chinese Studies 12.1, 1979: 117-32) with the iterative s-prefix  ({§5.2.3}); the original sense was either ``travelling = passing planet'' = ``Jupiter'' > ``Jovian cycle'' > ``year'' (Takashima 1996 II: 131), or ``passing time period'' = ``year'' > ``year star, Jupiter'' (Mei). Alternatively, suì may be derived from a word like {yuán₅ 員圓圜} *wan < ST *val ``circle'', then lit. ``start the circle again''.
	In CH and many TB languages temporal units are seen as recurrent cycles; note zhōu 周 ``circle'' > ``week''.
	[E] Mei Tsu-Lin relates suì further to WT skyod ``to go, walk; go down, set'', but see {yuè₄ 越}. The connection with PTai *xuap > S. kʰuapᴰ¹ᴸ ``year'' (of age of children) is not clear.
	Acc. to Bodman (1980: 66) Tai could be a loan from Chinese (OC *-ts from *-ts or *-ps).
	Note the Mǐn form which seems closer to Tai.
	Or, contrary to the preceding paragraph, the CH word might have originated in Kam-Tai, but an internal CH etymology is preferable.
::WT	skyod	``to go, walk; go down, set''
>:Mei Tsu-Lin relates suì further to WT skyod ``to go, walk; go down, set'', but see {yuè₄ 越}. The connection with PTai *xuap >
>:S. kʰuapᴰ¹ᴸ ``year''  is not clear

ENTRY:3579
HEAD:suì₂ 遂
MC:Middle Chinese: zwiᶜ 
LH:Later Han: zuis 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *s-wis
	[T] ONW zue
GLOSS:"To advance, accomplish, achieve" [BI, Shi].
	[WFE] ST: PLB *s-yuy  has a grammaticalized function; ``Kamarupan'' *s-yuy ~ *m-yuy ``to follow'' (Matisoff), Kuki-Naga *jwi ``follow'' > Lushai zuiᶠ, Siyin jui.
	[C] An allofam may possibly be {duì₇ 隊} (so Sagart 1999: 85). This wf *wi(t) is distinct from others which all share a root *lu ~ *ju: {lǜ₁ 律}, {yóu₂ 由}, {shùn₁ 順}.
::Kuki-Naga	*jwi	``follow''

ENTRY:3590
HEAD:suǒ₁ 所
MC:Middle Chinese: ṣjwoᴮ 
LH:Later Han: ṣɑᴮ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *sraʔ
GLOSS:"Place, position, situation" [BI, Shi].
GLOSS-NOTE:The function as an indefinite substitute for the post-verbal element (Dobson, LAC: 157), as in yǒu suǒ guī 有所歸
GLOSS:"have a place to return to", or suǒ qù 所去
GLOSS:"what [the subject] rejects", is derived from the noun ``place'' (Pulleyblank 1995: 68). {yōu₁ 攸} provides an exact semantic parallel.
	[T] Sin Sukchu SR ʂu (上), LR ʂwɔ
	[T] MGZY (zhu >) shu (上) [ʂu]
	[T] ONW ṣø < ṣo
	[E] ST *sra > PTB *sra (HPTB: 78): JP ʃə³¹-ra³¹ ``place'' (< *s-ra; Matisoff in STC: 171 n. 457), WB ra ``place, situation, thing, subject'', Mru ra ``place'' [Löffler 1966: 146], Dulong sə̂ɹɑ̀ ``thing'' [LaPolla LTBA 24.2, 2001: 2]. TB cognates to this word and to {shì₁₂ 事} ``affair, thing'' ({shì₂ 士仕}) are difficult to distinguish.
	It is not clear if and how WT sa ``place, earth'' and/or Zhangzhung slas ``earth'' are related; WT sa is also often associated with {shā₁ 沙} *srai ``sand'' – not likely.
::Zhangzhung	slas	``earth''
>:ST *sra >
>:PTB *sra :
>:JP ʃə³¹-ra³¹ ``place''
>:WB ra ``place, situation, thing, subject''
>:Mru ra ``place''
>:Dulong sə̂ɹɑ̀ ``thing'' . TB cognates to this word and to {shì₁₂ 事} ``affair, thing''  are difficult to distinguish

ENTRY:3591
HEAD:suǒ₂ 索
MC:Middle Chinese: sâk 
LH:Later Han: sɑk 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *sâk
GLOSS:"Rope" [BI, Shi].
	[T] Sin Sukchu SR saw (入), PR, LR sawʔ
	[T] MGZY saw (入) [saw]
	[T] ONW sɑk
	[E] AA: PVM *ɉaːk ``rope'' [Ferlus], PMonic *ɉook ``creeper, vine, rope'' > Mon ``string, cord''. AA ⇒ Tai: S. čʰı̈akᴰ²ᴸ < PTai *ǰ- ``rope'', Saek saakᴰ² < z- ``vines, rope''.
	In Mǐn and other southern dialects, this is the common word for ``rope'' (as opposed to {shéng 繩} in the north).
	OC must have borrowed this word because foreign / ST *z- > OC s-, whereas OC *s- is not expected to become a voiced initial elsewhere.
	For a possible parallel development, see {xiāo₂ 消銷}.
	Also the narrowed CH meaning ``rope'' speaks in favor of a foreign origin.
::Saek	saakᴰ² < z-	``vines, rope''
>:AA:
>:PVM *ɉaːk ``rope''
>:PMonic *ɉook ``creeper, vine, rope'' >
>:Mon ``string, cord''. AA ⇒ Tai:
>:S. čʰı̈akᴰ²ᴸ <
>:PTai *ǰ- ``rope''
>:Saek saakᴰ² < z- ``vines, rope''

ENTRY:3599
HEAD:tà₂ 眔遝沓
MC:Middle Chinese: dập 
LH:Later Han: dəp 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *dəp ?
	[T] ONW dɑp
GLOSS:"To touch, adjoin" 眔 [BI],
GLOSS:"together with, and" 遝 [BI];
GLOSS:"join, unite" 沓 [Chuci].
	[E] MC d- can derive from an OC T-like or L-like initial. Baxter (1992; also CVST  3:18) relates tà to WT sleb-pa, (b)slebs ``to arrive, reach, extend'' and sets up an OC initial *l-; he also relates tà to {dài₈ 逮}.
	An OC T-like initial would connect the word with MK *bɗap, *bɗaap ``to touch, adjoin''  (Shorto ɐ1264) with which tà agrees closely in meaning.
	The OC and MK vowels are different, but uncertainty of vowels is often encountered in MK (peruse Shorto 2006) and OC. TB items under {dié₆ 輒} partially overlap with tà.
::MK	*bɗap, *bɗaap	``to touch, adjoin''
>:MC d- can derive from an OC T-like or L-like initial. Baxter  relates tà to WT sleb-pa, slebs ``to arrive, reach, extend'' and sets up an OC initial *l-
>:he also relates tà to {dài₈ 逮}
