HEAD:tān₁ 貪 ⪤ làn 嚂
MC:Middle Chinese: lâmᶜ 
LH:Later Han: lɑmᶜ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *râms < *g-rams
GLOSS:"To stuff (one's face), be gluttonous" [Huainan] may belong here.

ENTRY:3610
HEAD:tān₂ 貪
MC:Middle Chinese: tʰậm 
LH:Later Han: tʰəm 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *rhə̂m
	[T] ONW tʰɑm
GLOSS:"To kill" is a Han-period Chǔ dialect word [FY 1,16], cognate to lán 惏(lậm) which was a Chén-Chǔ dialect word for
GLOSS:"kill" [FY 2, 19].
GLOSS-NOTE:It is doubtful that this root is connected with {kān₄ 戡}
GLOSS:"kill" (a southern Chǔ-Xiāng dialect word), or with cǎn 慘 (tsʰậmᴮ)
GLOSS:"to kill" [FY 1,5], though all these forms could theoretically derive from the same root (so Sagart 1999: 151). The word may be cognate to WB hrumᴮ ``fail, be defeated''.
::WB	hrumᴮ	``fail, be defeated''

ENTRY:3611
HEAD:tān₃ 探
MC:Middle Chinese: tʰậm 
LH:Later Han: tʰəm 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *nhə̂m
GLOSS:"To reach into with the hand, investigate" [Lunyu, Yi, Shu].
GLOSS-NOTE:The initial of the phonet. series is not certain; the word may be related to {shēn₃ 深}
GLOSS:"deep" (provided the initial was OCM *nh-; so Unger Hao-ku 47, 1995).
	Alternatively, the word agrees with Lushai tʰamᴿ ``to feel'' (especially with the hand).
::Lushai	tʰamᴿ	``to feel''

	{jiān₈} 漸瀸湛

ENTRY:3613
HEAD:tān₅ 嘽
	{dān₃} 癉憚

ENTRY:3614
HEAD:tān₆ 灘
MC:Middle Chinese: tʰân 
LH:Later Han: tʰɑn
GLOSS:"To dry up" (of a river) [SW], later
GLOSS:"beach". The graph suggests an OC initial *nh-.
	Yet tān could be compared to PTB *tan > WT tʰan-pa ``dry weather, heat, drought'', WB tʰanᶜ-tʰanᶜ ``nearly dry'' (STC: 190 n.; HPTB: 301), if we assume that the word was written with this phonetic only during the Han period (note its first attestation in SW) when OC *nh- and *th- had merged into tʰ-.
	Syn. {tǎn₂ 坦}.
::WB	tʰanᶜ-tʰanᶜ	``nearly dry''

::PWa	*dɐm	``spread out a mat''

	for yǎn ``sharp''
	{yǎn₄} 剡覃

ENTRY:3618
HEAD:tán₃ 潭
MC:Middle Chinese: dậm 
LH:Later Han: dəm 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *lə̂m
GLOSS:"A pond, pool" [Chu].
	[E] This late OC southern word (Chǔcí) is prob. a foreign loan: PKS *tʰlam¹ (but many KS languages have initial d) <- Malay kolam ``pond, well, pool'' <- Tamil kulam ``pond, tank'' (Thurgood 1988: 199). Perh. {táng₂ 塘} is a variant of this word.
	Alternatively, tán which is glossed as a ``deep pond'' could be the same word as tán 潭 ``deep water, abyss'' [Chuci], and possibly related to {shēn₃ 深} ``deep''. WB thumᴮ ``pond, lake'' differs in initial and vowel.
::WB	thumᴮ	``pond, lake''
>:This late OC southern word  is prob. a foreign loan:
>:PKS *tʰlam¹  < - Malay kolam ``pond, well, pool'' < - Tamil kulam ``pond, tank'' . Perh. {táng₂ 塘} is a variant of this word

ENTRY:3620
HEAD:tán₅ 彈

	[T] ONW dɑn

	[D] PMin *d̯ɑn ~ *dɑnᶜ ``to pluck'' (a lute).
	[E] This etymon is prob. related to PTB *m-dan (STC: 190) or rather *tal > JP n³¹-dan³³ ``crossbow'', Tiddim tʰalᴿ < tʰalʔ ``a bow'', Lushai tʰalᴿ < tʰalʔ ``arrow, dart''.
::Lushai	tʰalᴿ < tʰalʔ	``arrow, dart''
>:This etymon is prob. related to PTB *m-dan  or rather *tal >

ENTRY:3628
HEAD:tán₁₀ □
MC:Middle Chinese: dậm
	A Mǐn dial. word for ``wet'': PMin *dɑm > Fú’ān, Amoy tamᴬ¹.
	Loan from AA: Viet.  ằm,  ãm ``wet, moist'' (Norman / Mei 1976: 298).
	This etymon occurs also in Tai languages: Lóngmíng tomᴬ² ``wet'', Lóngzhōu tumᴬ² < *d- (Yue Hashimoto CAAAL  6, 1976: 1).

ENTRY:3629
HEAD:tǎn₁ 袒襢
MC:Middle Chinese: dânᴮ 
LH:Later Han: dɑnᴮ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *dânʔ
	[T] ONW dɑn
GLOSS:"To bare (to the waist)" 襢 [Shi], 袒 [Zuo].
	[WFE] Etymology not certain. (1) Pulleyblank (in Rosemont 1991: 31) adds dàn 但 ``only'' (under {dān₂ 單} which also could be related), hence the root means ``only, bare''. (2) tǎn could be cognate to {dān₁ 丹} ``red'' because nakedness is associated with ``red'' (Lau 1999: 118). (3) ST: WT star-ba ``to clean, polish'', note also tʰer ``bald, bare'' (so CVST  2: 122). An allofam may be {tú₃ 徒} ``bare'', but see there.
::WT	star-ba	``to clean, polish''

ENTRY:3636

ENTRY:3637
HEAD:tǎn₅ 黮
MC:Middle Chinese: tʰậmᴮ,dậmᴮ 
LH:Later Han: tʰəmᴮ,dəmᴮ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *thə̂mʔ ~ *də̂mʔ
GLOSS:"Dark" [Zhuang].
	[E] Area word: MK *ɗim, *ɗiim, *ɗəm, *ɗu[ ]m ``dark'': Khmer ṭaṃ /-dɑm/ ``be dark'', daṃ /-tum/ ``be ripe, dark'', PSBahn. dum ``ripe, red''. It is not clear how the KT items are related, especially since OC could also have had a cluster with *l in the initial: S. damᴬ¹ < *ʔdl/r- ``dark'', Saek ramᴬ¹ ``black''; PKS *ʔnamᴬ ``black'', Be lam¹³ ``black''.
	Acc. to Thurgood (1994: 358), the KT forms are loans from PAN *qitem ``black'', Dempwolff 1938 PAN ḍəḍəm ``be dark'' ⪤ ləmləm ``be gloomy'' (``düster sein''); note also Khmer /lým/ ``be dark, obscure, dim, unclear'', Wa-Lawa-Bulang *ntɨm ``dark'' (skies).
	<> Lushai hlimᴸ ``shadow, shade''.
	The final -m is sound-symbolic for ``keep in the mouth'' > ``keep hidden'' > ``dark'', see {shèn₄ 葚}, {gàn₂ 紺}, {qián₅ 黔}, {yīn₅ 陰} and {àn₃ 黯}.
	Therefore it is difficult to match the disparate OC syn. with foreign items cited above and under {yīn₅ 陰}.
::Lushai	hlimᴸ	``shadow, shade''
>:Area word:
>:MK *ɗim, *ɗiim, *ɗəm, *ɗum ``dark'':
>:Khmer ṭaṃ /-dɑm/ ``be dark'', daṃ /-tum/ ``be ripe, dark''
>:PSBahn. dum ``ripe, red''. It is not clear how the KT items are related, especially since OC could also have had a cluster with *l in the initial:
>:S. damᴬ¹ < *ʔdl/r- ``dark''
>:Saek ramᴬ¹ ``black''
>:PKS *ʔnamᴬ ``black''
>:Be lam¹³ ``black''

ENTRY:3638
HEAD:tàn₁ 炭
MC:Middle Chinese: tʰânᶜ 
LH:Later Han: tʰɑnᶜ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *thâns
GLOSS:"Charcoal" [Li],
GLOSS:"lime" [Zuo].
	[E] ST: WT tʰal-ba ``dust, ashes'' (STC 173 n. 461), Lushai taalᴿ < taalʔ ``wood ashes, dust''. CH ⇒ Tai: S. tʰaanᴮ¹ and PMY *tʰaanᶜ.
	The CH word is not related to {rán₁ 然} ``burn''.
::Lushai	taalᴿ < taalʔ	``wood ashes, dust''
>:WT tʰal-ba ``dust, ashes''
>:Lushai taalᴿ < taalʔ ``wood ashes, dust''. CH ⇒ Tai:
>:S. tʰaanᴮ¹ and PMY *tʰaanᶜ

ENTRY:3639
HEAD:tàn₂ 窞
MC:Middle Chinese: dậmᴮ 
LH:Later Han: dəmᴮ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *lə̂mʔ
	The earliest occurrence is in the combination kǎn-tàn 坎窞 (kʰậmᴮ-dậmᴮ; {kǎn₁ 坎}) LH kʰəmᴮ-dəmᴮ, *khə̂mʔ-ʔlə̂mʔ ?  ``trap pit'' (Shaughnessy 1996) [Yi]. SW says “tàn is a small pit (kǎn) in a pit (kǎn)”.
	[D] In some dialects tàn means ``pit, puddle'' as in shuǐ-tàn ``puddle'', e.g. Y-Táishān sui⁵⁵-hem²¹
	[N] For the irregular aspiration of tàn, see {§5.8.5}. Except for the above SW entry, tàn occurs by itself only in Post-Han texts and makes therefore the impression of an original reduplicative syllable of *khəmʔ with lateral initial ({§2.7}); but in light of the Tai connection, tàn has prob. been a full word in OC.
	[E] Tàn is of KT origin or an area word (Tai /u/ precludes borrowing from CH): Tai hlum ``pit, ditch, cavity'', Saek lumᴬ¹ < ḷ- ``pit, hole'' (as trap), possibly also Lushai humᴴ ``pitfall'' as trap for elephants etc. Similar CH and foreign comparanda are here tentatively sorted according to connections revealed in {Table K-1} {kǎn₁ 坎埳}.
	The relationship with PTai *th-: S. thamᶜ¹ ``cave'', also Wa tha̱m (Dǒng Wéiguāng et al.
	CAAAL  22, 1984: 110) is not clear.
::Lushai	humᴴ	``pitfall''
>:Tàn is of KT origin or an area word :
>:Tai hlum ``pit, ditch, cavity''
>:Saek lumᴬ¹ < ḷ- ``pit, hole'' , possibly also Lushai humᴴ ``pitfall'' as trap for elephants etc. Similar CH and foreign comparanda are here tentatively sorted according to connections revealed in {Table K-1} {kǎn₁ 坎埳}

ENTRY:3645
HEAD:táng₁ 唐
MC:Middle Chinese: dâŋ 
LH:Later Han: dɑŋ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *lâŋ
GLOSS:"Path in a temple" [Shi 142, 2; EY].
	[T] Sin Sukchu SR daŋ (平)
	[T] MGZY tang (平) [daŋ]
	[T] ONW dɑŋ
	[E] AA or Area word: MK *glɔɔŋ ``path, road'': Aslian gəløŋ, PMonic *glɔɔŋ ``road, track, way, direction''; *g-n-lɔɔŋ ``habitual path''; OKhmer /glɔɔŋ/ ``way, path, passage > channel, canal, watercourse'' (Jenner / Pou 1982: 289) (⇒ Tai: S. kʰlɔɔŋᴬ² < gl- ``canal, watercourse''; Lushai kuaŋᴴ ``channel of a river''); Note also Viet. đường ``road, way, street'', Muong taːŋ [Pulleyblank JCL 22.1, 1994: 82] (⇒ PTai *d-: S. tʰaŋᴬ² ``way, road'').
	The PMonic form is also reminiscent of gèng 堩 (kəŋᶜ) [kəŋᶜ] *kləŋh ? ``road'' [Liji], as well as of {xíng₁ 行}. Wáng Lì (1982: 147) relates this word to {tú₂ 涂途塗} ``path'' (along the bank of a canal; paved path)’.
::PMonic	*glɔɔŋ	``road, track, way, direction''
>:AA or Area word:
>:MK *glɔɔŋ ``path, road'':
>:Aslian gəløŋ
>:PMonic *glɔɔŋ ``road, track, way, direction''
>:*g-n-lɔɔŋ ``habitual path''
>:OKhmer /glɔɔŋ/ ``way, path, passage > channel, canal, watercourse''
>:Note also Viet. đường ``road, way, street''
>:Muong taːŋ

ENTRY:3662
HEAD:tè₂ 特
MC:Middle Chinese: dək 
LH:Later Han: dək 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *də̂k
GLOSS:"Male animal, bull" [OB, Shi, Shu].
	[T] Sin S. SR dəj (入), LR dəjʔ
	[T] MGZY thiy (入) [dəj]
	[T] ONW dək
	[E] <> Tai: S. tʰɨkᴰ¹S < th- (in northern dial. *d-) ``young male animal'' (Li F. 1976: 43). Note also NNaga *teːk ``buffalo'' [French 1983: 367].
	The graph 特 appears first in a Zhanguo (late Zhou) inscription; zhí, tè (next) seems to be its earlier form (Baxter 1992: 338f):
::NNaga	*teːk	``buffalo''
>:Tai:
>:S. tʰɨkᴰ¹S < th-  ``young male animal'' . Note also NNaga *teːk ``buffalo''

ENTRY:3669
HEAD:téng₂ 騰
MC:Middle Chinese: dəŋ

	[T] ONW dəŋ

GLOSS-NOTE:The phon. series GSR 893 implies that the OC initial was L-like which connects it with {chéng₃ 乘}, but semantically and otherwise, this word appears to agree with the wf {dēng₁ 登} with an OC T-like initial.

ENTRY:3670
HEAD:tī₁ 梯
MC:Middle Chinese: tʰiei 
LH:Later Han: tʰei 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *thî or *thə̂i
	[T] ONW tʰėi
	[D] PMin *tʰəi ~ *tʰuəi
GLOSS:"Ladder" [Guoyu].
	[E] Etymology not certain. The word appears to be cognate to PTB *s-lay ⪤ *s-ley (so HPTB: 220): WB hle-kaᴮ ``stairs, ladder'', TGTM *ᴬhli, Chepang hləyʔ (Bodman 1980: 102; 142).
	<> Tai: S. ban-daiᴬ¹, kraʔᴰ¹-daiᴬ¹ < *ʔdl/rəiᴬ ``ladder, stairs''.
	CH ? ⇒ PWMiaoA ntai³, PYao tʰei¹.
	However, the foreign initials do not agree with OC (T vs.
	L); perhaps the OC item has been reinterpreted as an allofam of dì 第 ``sequence'' (under {dì₂ 弟}) (Karlgren 1956: 14). – The elements WB -kaᴮ ⪤ WT skas-ka, skad ``ladder'' and Lao kʰanᶜ¹-daiᴬ²  ``stairs'', S. kʰanᶜ¹ ``steps'' may be related to each other (Manomaivibool 1975: 134).
::Lao	kʰanᶜ¹-daiᴬ² 	``stairs''
>:Etymology not certain. The word appears to be cognate to PTB *s-lay ⪤ *s-ley :
>:WB hle-kaᴮ ``stairs, ladder''
>:TGTM *ᴬhli
>:Chepang hləyʔ

ENTRY:3678
HEAD:tǐ 體
MC:Middle Chinese: tʰieiᴮ 
LH:Later Han: tʰeiᴮ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *rhîʔ 
OCB:Baxter Old Chinese: hrijʔ
	[T] ONW tʰėi
GLOSS:"Body, form, shape, content" [Shi].
	[<] endoactive tone B derivation from the TB stem (``the thing which exists'') ({§4.5.1}).
	[E] ST *sri ``to exist'' (Benedict 1976: 190) > PTB *sri(-t): WT gšis < g-rhyis (?) ``person, body, natural disposition'' ⪤ WT srid-pa ``existence, things existing, the world, life, a single being'', also ``procreate'' (Stein BSOAS 36.2, 1973: 412ƒƒ); WB hriᶜ ``to be (in some place)''.
	From the ST root is also derived {shēng₂ 生} ``give birth, live''.
	It is not clear why a hypothetical ST *sr- shows up as a voiceless *rh in tǐ (regular development from ST? or because of a *k-sr- configuration? Note WT), but as a sr-cluster in shēng (*s- re-analyzed as a caustive prefix ? {§2.8.1}).
::WT	srid-pa	``existence, things existing, the world, life, a single being''
>:ST *sri ``to exist''  >
>:PTB *sri:
>:WT gšis < g-rhyis  ``person, body, natural disposition'' ⪤ WT srid-pa ``existence, things existing, the world, life, a single being'', also ``procreate''
>:WB hriᶜ ``to be ''

ENTRY:3679
HEAD:tì₁ 涕
MC:Middle Chinese: tʰieiᴮ/ᶜ 
LH:Later Han: tʰeiᴮ,tʰeiᶜ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *thîʔ/h 
OCB:Baxter Old Chinese: *thijʔ
GLOSS:"Tears" 涕 [Shi];
GLOSS:"mucus from nose" 洟 [Li], the latter may derive from the original meaning
GLOSS:"tears" (so Wáng Lì 1958: 551), or both may derive directly from ST ``water''. The graph 洟 belongs to an OC initial L-phonetic series, but the graph appears late and is prob. only a loan for 涕 (in a T-series).
	[E] ST: PTB *ti (STC no. 55) and PTB *tui ``water'' (STC: 168) > Chepang tiʔ ``water'', WT mčʰi-ma ``a tear'' (HST: 146), Chepang ma-tiʔ ``river'', Kanauri *ti ``water''. Dhimal hna-thi ``snot''; or Lushai tuiᴿ ``water''; both roots, *ti  and *tui occur in JP and Dhimal (STC no. 55; 168).
	Wáng Lì (1982: 418) connects tì to {sì₂ 泗} ``snivel'' and {lèi₁ 淚} ``tears'' (unlikely).
	Perh. {zhì₆ 膣} ``vagina'' is a cognate.
::Lushai	tuiᴿ	``water''
>:PTB *ti  and PTB *tui ``water''  >
>:Chepang tiʔ ``water''
>:WT mčʰi-ma ``a tear''
>:Chepang ma-tiʔ ``river''
>:Kanauri *ti ``water''. Dhimal hna-thi ``snot''
>:or Lushai tuiᴿ ``water''
>:both roots, *ti  and *tui occur in JP and Dhimal

	It is not clear how the next item relates to these words:

ENTRY:3686
HEAD:tiān₁ 天
MC:Middle Chinese: tʰien 
LH:Later Han: tʰen (tʰein) 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *thîn
GLOSS:"Sky, heaven, heavenly deity" [BI, Shi].
GLOSS-NOTE:The graph shows a person (god) with a head in the shape of a disk like the BI character for dīng 丁 *têŋ
GLOSS:"a cyclical sign" which seems to be phonetic.
	The anthropomorphic graph may or may not indicate that the original meaning was ``deity'', not ``sky''.
	For the *-eŋ ~ *-in variation, see {§6.4.1}.
	[T] Sin Sukchu SR t'jen (平)
	[T] MGZY then (平) [t'ɛn]
	[T] MTang tʰian < tʰɨan, ONW tʰėn
	[D] Y-Guǎngzhōu ⁵³tʰinᴬ¹ ``sky'', Táishān ³³henᴬ¹
	[D] PMin *tʰien, Xiàmén tʰĩᴬ¹
	An old NW dialect variant QY xien, ONW hėn, is also found in Tang-period Guǎngzhōu, written 祆 ``Heaven'' (Coblin 1994: 341).
	An old southern dialect form *tʰɑn survives in Mǐn-Jiānglè tʰãiᴬ¹ ``sky'' (Norman 1979: 271), which is prob. the same etymon as 坦 tʰɑnᴮ which the Shìmíng records for dialects to the east of the central area (Coblin TP 1994: 155f).
	[E] Etymology not certain. Because the deity Tiān came to prominence with the Zhou dynasty (a western state), a Central Asian origin has been suggested, note Mongolian tengri ``sky, heaven, heavenly deity'' (Shaughnessy Sino-Platonic Papers, July 1989, and others, like Shirakawa Shizuka before him).
	Alternatively, Bodman (ICSTLL 1987) connects tiān with Adi taleŋ, Lepcha tă-lyaŋ ``sky''.
	One could add JP mə⁵⁵-len⁵¹ ``sky'', yet these items could belong to {líng₆ 陵} instead.
	Most likely, this word is connected with {diān₁ 顛巔} ``top'' (so SW) and its TB cognates: WT, OTib. steŋ ``above, upper part, that which is above'' (Unger Hau-ku 36, 1990: 48), steŋ-lha ``the upper gods, gods in heaven'' [Hoffmann 1979: 94]; Kachin puŋdiŋ ``zenith, top'' (STC: 180); Zemi (Naga) tiŋ ``sky'', Lushai paᴸ-tʰianᴴ ``god'' (lit. ``father above'') (French 1983: 157f; 374), perhaps also Chepang diŋ ``(helpful) spirits''. For a similar semantic development ``top, high'' > ``sky'', see {líng₆ 陵}, also note the semantic parallel shàngdì 上帝 ``god on high'' (i.e. in heaven).
	If MC aspiration should be a reflex of an earlier *s in the initial ({§5.8.1}), then tiān would agree closely with WT steŋ.
	A common TB syn. for ``sky'' belongs to the root {mào₂ 冒} ``cover''.
::For	a similar semantic development	``top, high''
>:Etymology not certain. Because the deity Tiān came to prominence with the Zhou dynasty , a Central Asian origin has been suggested, note Mongolian tengri ``sky, heaven, heavenly deity''

ENTRY:3687
HEAD:tiān₂ 天
GLOSS:"brand the forehead"
	{diān₁} 顛巔

>:PTai *tl- >
>:S. temᴬ¹ ``full'' . Syn. {yíng₂ 盈嬴}

ENTRY:3689
HEAD:tián₁ 田
MC:Middle Chinese: dien 
LH:Later Han: den (dein) 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *lîn
	[T] MTang dian < dɨan ONW dėn
GLOSS:"Field", a general term [BI; Shi].
	[D] Y-Guǎngzhōu tʰinᴬ² ``wet field''. PMin *dzʰən ``wet field'' is unlikely to be related (Norman 1988: 231), but see {zēng 曾增憎橧}.
	[WFE] ST: WT žiŋ ``field'' < lyiŋ or ryiŋ, Bumthang Zha ᴸleŋ, Lepcha lyaŋ ``field, land'' (Forrest JAOS 82, 1962: 332); Cuona Monpa ¹³leŋ; NNaga *ljiːŋ ``grow(th)'', JP mə³¹-liŋ³³ ``forest'', Dimasa ha-bliŋ ``jhum field in 2nd year of cultivation'' (ha ``earth'') [STC no. 378; French 1983: 254].
	Some ST languages have forms with initial r- (related?): Muoto M. ʔreŋ, Tsangla a-riŋ.
	Kanauri ri[ŋ] ``field''; Lushai riŋᴴ ``jhom, field currently in use''.
	Loaned from CH or TB into other languages: PMY *ɭinᴬ (Wang Fushi), PYao *riŋᴬ (Therapan) ``wet field''; Be leŋᴬ (Haudricourt / Strecker TP 77, 1991: 337).
::Lushai	riŋᴴ	``jhom, field currently in use''

ENTRY:3705
HEAD:tiǎo 窕
MC:Middle Chinese: dieuᴮ 
LH:Later Han: deuᴮ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *liâuʔ
GLOSS:"To perforate, bore a hole" [Huainanzi] is perhaps cognate to {qiào₂ 竅}
GLOSS:"a hole".

ENTRY:3715
HEAD:tīng₂ 聽 ⪤ tìng,tīng 聽

	[E] This etymon is often considered cognate to {shèng₁ 聖} ``wise''. ENTRY:3720
HEAD:tíng₃ 庭
MC:Middle Chinese: dieŋ 
LH:Later Han: deŋ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *lêŋ
GLOSS:"Courtyard, court of a palace, mansion, temple" [OB, BI, Shi].
	[T] MTang dieŋ < dɨŋ, ONW dėŋ
	[D] M-Xiàmén tĩãᴬ²
	[E] ST: Perh. PTB *gliŋ ``ground, land, country, region'': NNaga *C/v-khliŋ ``place'' (e.g. place to sit, abode) [French 1983: 532], WT gliŋ ``island, continent''. In a round-about way, this etymon might have entered the language of the ancient state of Chǔ during the Han period where we find tīng 汀 (tʰieŋ) LH tʰeŋ ``island'' [Chuci]; if true, the word must have been written down at a time (Han or later) when OC *hl- and *th- had merged into tʰ-.
	[C] This is perhaps related to the wf {tǐng₂ 挺} in the sense of ``straight'' > ``level''.
::LH	tʰeŋ	``island''
>:Perh. PTB *gliŋ ``ground, land, country, region'':
>:NNaga *C/v-khliŋ ``place''
>:WT gliŋ ``island, continent''. In a round-about way, this etymon might have entered the language of the ancient state of Chǔ during the Han period where we find tīng 汀  LH tʰeŋ ``island''
>:if true, the word must have been written down at a time  when OC *hl- and *th- had merged into tʰ-

ENTRY:3725

MC:Middle Chinese: dieŋ 
LH:Later Han: deŋ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *lêŋ

GLOSS:"small bamboo rods used for divination" 筳 [Chuci].
	[E] ST: PTB: *bleŋ ``straight'' (STC no. 352). The wf {zhèng₁ 正政} may belong here, but the initials point to *l- vs. *t- respectively which are difficult to reconcile.
	Matisoff (1988) combines this wf with {yíng₂ 盈嬴} ``full'', {píng₁ 平} ``level'' and {zhèng₁ 正政} ``straight''.
	See also {tǐng₃,dìng 梃鋌}.
>:PTB:
>:*bleŋ ``straight'' . The wf {zhèng₁ 正政} may belong here, but the initials point to *l- vs. *t- respectively which are difficult to reconcile

ENTRY:3726
HEAD:tǐng₃,dìng 梃,鋌
MC:Middle Chinese: dieŋᴮ 
LH:Later Han: deŋᴮ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *lêŋʔ
GLOSS:"Stick, staff" tǐng 梃 [Meng];
GLOSS:"metal rod inserted in arrow" dìng 鋌 [Zhouli].
	[WFE] Perh. ST *C-liŋ (originally referring to the tibia bone, hence ``marrow'' as well as the hollowed tube-like piece): PTB *r-kliŋ (STC no. 126) >  Mikir arkleŋ, Lushai tʰliŋᴿ ``marrow'', Mru kliŋ ``id.''; WT gliŋ-bu ``flute'' which is sometimes made of a human femur, lit. bu ``son'' (i. e. ``derivative'') of a ``gliŋ'', PLB *kliŋ > PL *ʔliŋ¹ ~ *hliŋ¹ ``flute'', WB kyañ ``tube'' (Matisoff 1970 no. 98).
	This etymon and the wf {kēng₂ 牼} *khreŋ as well as {xìng₃,jìng 脛} *geŋh tend to converge.
	For an overview, see {Table K-2} under {kēng₂ 牼}.
	Less likely, this wf may be connected with {tǐng₂ 挺} ``straight''.
::WB	kyañ	``tube''

ENTRY:3732
HEAD:tóng₂ 銅
MC:Middle Chinese: duŋ 
LH:Later Han: doŋ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *lôŋ or *d(l)ôŋ ?
GLOSS:"Bronze, copper" 銅 [Zuo].
	[E] Karlgren (1956: 5) relates this word to {tóng₁ 同} ``to join'' (i.e. two metals); but metals are typically associated with color, therefore the word is probably related to tóng 彤 ``red'' (under {hóng₂ 紅}) (this idea is implied by Benedict MKS 18-19, 1992: 1-13). The word ``copper'' occurs in some SE Asian languages with initial l-: Tai-Wuming luːŋ², Palaung məlɔŋ ``copper'' (Sagart 1999: 199).
::Palaung	məlɔŋ	``copper''

>:Palaung məlɔŋ ``copper''

ENTRY:3747
HEAD:tóu₃ 頭
MC:Middle Chinese: dəu 
LH:Later Han: do 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *dô
GLOSS:"Head" [Eastern Zhou BI, Zuo], replaced earlier {shǒu₃ 首}.
	[T] Sin Sukchu SR dəw (平)
	[T] MGZY thiw (平) [dəw]
	[T] ONW dou
	[D] Y-Guǎngzhōu tɐuᴬ²(-hɔkᴰ) 頭(殼)
	[D] K-Méixiàn tʰɛuᴬ²-naᴬ² 頭那, Dànshuǐ tʰiuᴬ²-naᴬ¹-hɔkᴰ¹ (R. Bauer CAAAL  28, 1987: 60f)
	[D] PMin *dʰəuᴬ²: Jiānglè tʰəuᴰ¹, Fúzhōu tʰau⁵², Xiàmén tʰauᴬ²-kʰak
	[D] W-Wēnzhōu dɦeu²¹
	[N] The initial consonant in the phonetic series 豆 could be either *d or *l, but it was prob. *d- as forms for ``skull'' {dú₈-lóu 髑髏} show.
	[E] The late appearance of tóu in the 6th cent BC when it began to replace {shǒu₃ 首} suggests that it is derived from the much earlier attested vessel {dòu₂ 豆} (Sagart 1999: 156), but dòu (tone C) looks like a derivation from tóu instead which may therefore originally have meant ``skull''. An allofam may be {dòu₃ 荳} ``bean''.
	The word tóu has two possible outside connections. (1) ST: Loloish *ʔdu² ``head'' [Matisoff LL 1.2, 2000: 168] where u corresponds directly to OC o. Or (2) MK: Khmer -tūla /-dool/ ``head, to bulge'' which would also be a direct phonological equivalent of OC (for CH loss of final MK consonant, see {§6.9}).
	The MK word belongs to a large wf ``bulge, knoll'' and would thus provide an etymology.
::Khmer	-tūla /-dool/	``head, to bulge''
>:The late appearance of tóu in the 6th cent BC when it began to replace {shǒu₃ 首} suggests that it is derived from the much earlier attested vessel {dòu₂ 豆} , but dòu  looks like a derivation from tóu instead which may therefore originally have meant ``skull''. An allofam may be {dòu₃ 荳} ``bean''

ENTRY:3772
HEAD:tūn₂ 暾
MC:Middle Chinese: tʰuən 
LH:Later Han: tʰuən 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *thûn
GLOSS:"The rising sun" [Chuci].
	[E] This word has two possible sources, although the first appearance in Chǔcí favors a MK connection; perhaps it is a blend of the two: (1) TB: WT ’tʰon-pa, tʰon ``to come out, go out'', WB pɔ-tʰonᴮ ``come out'' (e. g. the sun), Monpa Cuona ⁵³tɕʰuŋ, Motuo tʰoŋ ``to come out'' (sun) (ZM 92 no. 1207). In ST lgs. the notion of sunrise is often associated with ``to come out, rise'' (cf.
	WT šar ``to rise, east'', CH rì chū 日出 ``the sun comes out''), while ``west'' {xī₂ 西棲栖} is associated with ``to go down, rest, nest''.
GLOSS:2:MK: PMon *tun
GLOSS:"go up" (sun, water level etc.) which is phonologically close to the OC word.
	In both TB and MK the word is apparently native (for PMonic, see: Diffloth 1984: 206), although their basic meanings differ (TB ``come out'', MK ``go up'').
	An allofam may be {dōng₂ 東} ``east''.
::WT	šar	``to rise, east''

>:perhaps it is a blend of the two:

>:WT ’tʰon-pa, tʰon ``to come out, go out''
>:WB pɔ-tʰonᴮ ``come out''
>:Monpa Cuona ⁵³tɕʰuŋ

GLOSS:"garrison, station soldiers" [Zuo], ``thick'' (as darkness in a grave) 窀 [Zuo] (also read zhūn [ṭun ~ ṭuin]).

	[WFE] ST: PTB *g-lwat (STC no. 209) > WT hlod-pa ``loose, relax'' ⪤ glod-pa ``loosen, relax, slacken''; PLB *k-lwat > PL *k-lwat⁴ ``free'', WB hlwat ``free, relax'' ⪤ lwat ``be free'' ⪤ kywat < klwat ``loosed, freed'' ⪤ kʰywat < kʰlwat ``release, free''; Mru lot, lon ``loose, let out''; Lushai tʰlɔnᴸ < thlɔns ``to come / fall off'' [Löffler 1966: 123], Lai lot ``free'' ⪤ še-lot ``set free''  [VanBik LTBA 25.2, 2002: 106], JP lat³¹ ``to escape, get lost''. <> Tai: Shan lɔtᴰ² < *dl- ``to be free, to free'' is prob. a TB loan.
	[C] This group belongs to the root {yú₁₇ 愉} *lo ``pleasant'' (< ``relaxed''), see there for allofams. Perh. {róng₁ 容} is related.
	This wf comes close to {chōu₁ 盩抽}.

	[WFE] ST: JP diŋ³¹-loi³³ ``long and narrow'' (CVST 3: 32).
::JP	diŋ³¹-loi³³	``long and narrow''

ENTRY:3794
HEAD:tuò₃ 唾
MC:Middle Chinese: tʰuâᶜ 
LH:Later Han: tʰuɑiᶜ / tʰoiᶜ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *thôih
GLOSS:"Spittle" [SW, Hanshu],
GLOSS:"to spit" [Zuo].
	[D] PMin *tʰoiᶜ
	[D] some dialects in the Yuè area have archaic rimes: Guǎngzhōu col. tʰœᶜ¹ beside tʰɔᶜ¹, Zēngchéng sœyᶜ², Bǎo’ān suiᴮ², Enpíng tsʰuiᴬ²
	[D] K-Dōngguān suiᴮ.
	[E] ST *tol > WT tʰo-le  (i.e. *tol-e) ’debs-pa ``to spit'' (’debs-pa ``to throw'') (HST: 138); WB tʰweᴮ ``spit'' (STC: 30 n. 95) seems to agree with the WT and CH forms. But alternatively, STC connects WB with PTB *twəy (= *tui) ``water''.
	Although tuò looks like a variant of the syn. {tǔ₂ 吐}, the OC and the TB forms are quite distinct.
	CH aspiration is associated with forceful ejection {§5.8.5}.
::PTB	*twəy 	``water''
>:ST *tol >
>:WT tʰo-le   ’debs-pa ``to spit''
>:WB tʰweᴮ ``spit''  seems to agree with the WT and CH forms. But alternatively
>:STC connects WB with PTB *twəy  ``water''

ENTRY:3795
HEAD:tuò₄ 蘀

LH:Later Han: tʰɑk 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *lhâk
GLOSS:"To wither, fallen leaves" [Shi].
	[E] Prob. AA: Khmer sla’ka /slɑk/ ``to fade, wilt, dry up'', from a root -la’ka /-lɑk/ ``to fall'', acc. to Jenner / Pou 1982: 523.
	Alternatively, tuò could possibly be related to {luò₇ 落} *râk ``fall'' (Unger Hao-ku  39, 1992: 92; Sagart 1999: 18), but then one would need to assume OCM *rhâk for tuò which is not supported by the phonetic series.

	[N] In the OB, the graph is a vertical line with a stroke on one side 卜, i.e. ``outside''; the graph is identical to {bǔ₁ 卜}. ``Moon'' yuè 月 LH ŋyɑt  has been added later as phonetic. Bodman (1980: 136) connects this word with WT ŋos ``side, direction'', see {yù₁₇ 禦}.

ENTRY:3817
HEAD:wáng₁ 亡 ⪤ wàng 忘
MC:Middle Chinese: mjwaŋ(ᶜ) 
LH:Later Han: muɑŋ(ᶜ) 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *maŋ (!)
GLOSS:"To forget" [BI, Shi], i.e.
GLOSS:"to lose" (from memory) is the s. w. as wáng 亡 in early OC as revealed by Shījīng rimes, tone C emerged later (``it has disappeared from mind, has escaped me'', a perfective form in *-s / *-h of wáng 亡 ({§3.5}), acc. to Unger Hao-ku 20, 1983).

ENTRY:3818

OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *maŋʔ
GLOSS:"There is no, not have" occurs in Shūjīng and the old parts of Shījīng, but is then replaced by its stem {wú₄ 無} in that meaning.
	The graph 亡 in the OB, BI may perhaps write this word rather than wáng 亡 above.
	[<] wáng 亡 *maŋ with the aux. vb. tone B ({§3.3.2}).

ENTRY:3822
HEAD:wáng₂ 王
MC:Middle Chinese: jwaŋ 
LH:Later Han: wɑŋ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *waŋ
GLOSS:"King" [BI, Shi].
	[T] Sin Sukchu SR waŋ (平)
	[T] MGZY xwang (平) [ɦwaŋ]
	[T] ONW uaŋ
	[E] Etymology not certain. Prob.
	ST: WT dbaŋ ``might, power'' ⪤ dbaŋ-po ``ruler'', WB aŋ ``strength, power'', NNaga *waŋ ``chief'' [French 1983: 389]. The initials present difficulties, though (WT *b- vs.
	OC *w-), unless one assumes that occasionally WT b- can derive from a *w (db- < *dw-); the WB form seems to support this.
	Alternatively, wáng may possibly be connected with an AA homophone: OKhmer vaṅ ~ vāṅ(ṅ) ``royal palace …'' (⇒ Tai: S. waŋ ``palace''), cognate to luəŋ ``king'' (⇒ Tai luaŋ ``royal''); the identification of ``king'' with his palace is perhaps supported by a BI where wáng refers not to the Zhou king but to a place (Shaughnessy 1991: 197).
	Thus wáng would belong to the complex of stems under {yíng₄ 營}; prob. also cognate to {huáng₁ 皇} ``august''.
	Otherwise, speculations have related wáng to wāng 尪 (ʔwâŋ) ``emaciated'' [Zuo] (under {qú₄,jù 臞} ) and {kuáng 狂} (gjwaŋ) ``mad'', based on certain theories on ancient CH kingship and shamanism (see D. Keightley JAS 54.1, 1995: 132).
::Tai	luaŋ	``royal''
>:Etymology not certain. Prob

HEAD:wáng₂ 王 ⪤ wàng 王

LH:Later Han: wɑŋᶜ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *waŋh
GLOSS:"Be king, rule" [Shi 241,4].
	[<] *waŋ + s/h-suffix ({§3.5}).

ENTRY:3824
HEAD:wǎng₁ 往
MC:Middle Chinese: jwaŋᴮ 
LH:Later Han: wɑŋᴮ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *waŋʔ
GLOSS:"To go to, gone, past" 往 [OB, BI, Shi], 迋 [Zuo].
	[T] Sin Sukchu SR waŋ (上)
	[T] MGZY xwang (上) [ɦwaŋ]
	[T] ONW uaŋ
	[<] yú 于 *wa + ST terminative *-ŋ ({§6.5.1}) + endoactive (?) tone B ({§4.5}). Since the terminative implies an end point of the action, the meaning in some languages is ``go to'' > ``arrive'' > ``come''.
	[E] ST: PTB *waŋ (STC no. 218) > Chepang waŋ ``to come'' (Bodman 1980: 81), Barish-Nocte ²vaŋ(ʔ) (Chepang and Barish (= Bodo) disagree in phonation, Weidert 1987: 30), WT ’oŋ-ba ``to come'' ⪤ perhaps also WT soŋ < s-waŋ ``went'', Tamang ¹waŋ ``enter, go in, come in'';  WB waŋ ``to enter, go or come in'' ⪤ swaŋᴮ ``to put into'', PL *waŋ¹ ``to enter''; Mikir wàŋ ``to come'' (HST: 86), NN *woŋ ``come''. It is not clear how Tai luaŋᴮ² ``to pass time, go beyond'' (Bodman 1980: 107) may relate to this ST stem.
::Tai	luaŋᴮ²	``to pass time, go beyond''
>:PTB *waŋ  >
>:Chepang waŋ ``to come''
>:Barish-Nocte ²vaŋ  disagree in phonation
>:Weidert 1987:
>:30)
>:WT ’oŋ-ba ``to come'' ⪤ perhaps also WT soŋ < s-waŋ ``went''
>:Tamang ¹waŋ ``enter, go in, come in''
>:WB waŋ ``to enter, go or come in'' ⪤ swaŋᴮ ``to put into''
>:PL *waŋ¹ ``to enter''
>:Mikir wàŋ ``to come''
>:NN *woŋ ``come''. It is not clear how Tai luaŋᴮ² ``to pass time, go beyond''  may relate to this ST stem

ENTRY:3837
HEAD:wàng₅ 望
MC:Middle Chinese: mjwaŋᴬ/ᶜ 
LH:Later Han: muɑŋ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *maŋ (tone not clear)
GLOSS:"Full moon" [BI, Shu] is considered to be the s. w. as {wàng₄ 望}. If the OC word had the equivalent of later tone C (and the double readings in GY may be a trace of this),
GLOSS:"full moon" may be a regular passive derivation from the above, lit.
GLOSS:"the thing that is gazed at from afar" ({§4.4}).
	Alternatively, Van Auken (JAOS 122.3, 2002: 528) suggests that ``full moon'' is cognate to {liàng 亮} ``light''.

ENTRY:3838
HEAD:wēi₁-tuó 委佗
MC:Middle Chinese: ʔjwie 3-dâ 
LH:Later Han: ʔyɑi-dɑi 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *ʔwai-lâi or *ʔoi-?
GLOSS:"Graceful, compliant" [Shi].
	[WFE] Qiu Xigui (2000: 374) lists over 20 graphic variants of this sound-symbolic word. The etymology is not clear.
	The first syllable may be related to Lushai vialᴴ < vial ``to writhe'', although the item could also be linked to either {wēi₂ 逶} Lushai vaiᶠ < vaiʔ; or it could be an *-i final cognate of {yāo₂ 妖} or {yǎo₁ 夭殀}.
	Lushai cognates show that this etymon is not related to {wēi₂ 逶} ``fluttering''.
	The second syllable tuó / yí / chí reflects an area etymon: Chepang kloyʔ ``be winding'' (path or stream).
	<> Khmer /-lée/ as in  /rlée/ ``to snake, move sinuously (as through water)''.
	Khmer final /ē/ corresponds also in other words to OC *-ai.
	TB languages have a similar item whose initial t is irreconcilable with OC l: Lushai taalᴿ < taalʔ ``to struggle, wriggle, writhe'', or Chepang toy- ``to circle or spiral upwards''.
	[C] An allofam of the first syllable is prob. {yuān₃ 蜎肙} ``worm'', of the second syllable {shé₂ 蛇} ``snake''.
::Chepang	toy-	``to circle or spiral upwards''

ENTRY:3839
HEAD:wēi₁-tuó 委佗 ⪤ wēi-yí 委佗
MC:Middle Chinese: ʔjwie 3-jie 
LH:Later Han: ʔyɑi-jɑi 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *ʔwai-lai or *ʔoi- ?
GLOSS:"Be graceful, compliant, be winding" (as road) [Shi].

ENTRY:3840
HEAD:wēi₁-tuó 委佗 ⪤ wēi-chí 委遲

ENTRY:3841
HEAD:wēi₂ 逶
MC:Middle Chinese: ʔjwie 3 
LH:Later Han: ʔyɑi 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *ʔwai or *ʔoi ?
GLOSS:"Tortuous movement, fluttering" (of a flag) [Chuci].
GLOSS-NOTE:TB (Lushai) cognates show that this etymon is not related to {wēi₁-tuó 委佗}
GLOSS:"be winding".
	[WFE] ST: PTB *waːy (STC no. 90; HPTB: 210) > Kachin wai ``whirl, as a whirlpool, stir, strike out with a sweeping motion''; WB waiᴮ ``whirlpool, brandish'' a sword …, ``soar around'' as a bird; Lushai vaiᶠ < vaiʔ ``to wave'' with the hand, arm, or anything horizontally, ``brandish'' (a sword) ⪤ huiᶠ ``to beckon'' with hand. Acc. to Shorto 1972 likely derived from PMK *wa(a)y(-s): Palaung vay ``to vawe hand, beckon'', Viet. vãy ``to wave''.
	[C] For an overview of synonyms for ``turn, rotate'', see under {huí 回}.
::Palaung	vay	``to vawe hand, beckon''

ENTRY:3842

OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *hwai
GLOSS:"To signalize, manifest" [Yi] is an iterative derivation ({§5.2.3}) from wēi. A variant or syn. is {huī₄ 麾}.

ENTRY:3848
HEAD:wéi₂ 惟唯隹維
MC:Middle Chinese: jiwi 
LH:Later Han: wi 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *wi
GLOSS:"To be" 隹 [OB, BI], 惟 [Shu], 維 [Shi]; (``it is'' >
GLOSS:"it is only" >)
GLOSS:"only" 唯 [Shi and subsequent classical Chinese]; (``to consider to be'' >) ``to think'' [Shi and later] (GSR 575n; Dobson EAC; {§2.10}). Syn. of ``to be'': {shì₁₄ 是}, {yě₁ 也}; syn. of ``only'': {zhǐ₃ 只}, dàn 但 (under {dān₂ 單}).
	[T] Sin Sukchu SR vi (平)
	[T] MGZY ywi (平) [yi]
	[T] ONW iui
	[E] ST: PTB *wəy > PLB *wəy ``to be'' (Thurgood 1982, CLAO XI. 1: 65-81); Lushai eᶠ < ʔeeʔ, ve, JP we pres. tense particle; perhaps WT yin ``to be'' < *wi-n (?) (earlier *w disappears before i in WT).
	[C] The negative copula {fēi₁ 非} incorporates this word.
::WT	yin	``to be''
>:PTB *wəy >
>:PLB *wəy ``to be''
>:Lushai eᶠ < ʔeeʔ, ve

ENTRY:3849
HEAD:wéi₂ 惟唯隹維 ⪤ huì 惠
MC:Middle Chinese: ɣiweiᶜ 
LH:Later Han: ɣwes 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *wî(t)s
GLOSS:"It should be" [OB, Shu].
GLOSS-NOTE:The OC reading is not certain.
	The usual meaning ``be kind, compliant'' [BI, Shi] could possibly be a semantic extension (``should be'' > ``to consider / treat as it should / ought to be, as expected'' ?) since there is a tendency for copulas to expand to full verbs, note ``to be'' > ``to think'' above (Dobson EAC; {§2.10}).
	[<] See {§6.2.2} for the ``irrealis'' role of the OC final consonants.

ENTRY:3850
HEAD:wéi₃ 為
MC:Middle Chinese: jwie 
LH:Later Han: wɑi 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *wai
GLOSS:"To make, do, (function as:) be" [BI, Shi].
GLOSS-NOTE:Note that in general words meaning
GLOSS:"do, make" also develop the meaning
GLOSS:"function as, act as, to be"; see {yì₆ 役}, {zuò₃ 作}.
	[T] Sin S. SR uj (平)
	[T] MGZY xue (平) [ɦuɛ]
	[T] MTang ui, ONW ue
	[E] Etymology not clear. Some languages have similar looking words: Mikir iŋhóy < m-hol ``to do, make''.
	<> MK: Khm ʔaoy (spelled oːy) ``give'', resultative marker; MK lgs. on the Malay peninsula ``to make, do'': Semai ʔuuy, Jah Hut mʔoy, Semelai j-ʔɔy [Diffloth 1975]. Khmer /-wə́ə/ ``do, make'' ⪤ OKhmer thve ~ tve /tʃəə/ ``to do, make, perform, act, serve as, carry out funtion of, act as if, pretend to be …'' (Jenner / Pou 1982: 349).
	The OC and AA vowels are rather different, though.
	A derivation is perhaps {yì₆ 役}.
::OKhmer	thve ~ tve /tʃəə/	``to do, make, perform, act, serve as, carry out funtion of, act as if, pretend to be …''
>:Etymology not clear. Some languages have similar looking words:
>:Mikir iŋhóy < m-hol ``to do, make''

GLOSS:"elephant" is puzzling in this graph for
GLOSS:"to do", it has been suggested that an obsolete area word for this animal had once served as phonetic, note PVM *hwɔyᴬ, PSBahn. *ruəs, PTB *m-gwi(y) > JP gui³¹ ``elephant'' (Matisoff LTBA 15.1, 1992: 169; HPTB: 200).

ENTRY:3853
HEAD:wéi₅ 圍
MC:Middle Chinese: jwei 
LH:Later Han: wui 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *wəi ?
	[T] ONW ui
GLOSS:"To surround, encircle" [Li],
GLOSS:"besiege" [Zuo] (Yates EC 19, 1994: 112) is prob. cognate to {wèi₇ 衛} even though the finals differ. The basic meaning of the etymon is
GLOSS:"to walk around something in order to watch it".
	[E] Area etymon which is widely attested in TB and AA languages. Lushai veelᶠ ``go round, surround, encircle, around, round about'' ⪤ veelᴿ ``to keep coming or walking near'' (as those who want to steal, see what one is doing …); Siyin vil ``watch'' [Stern AM X.2, 1963: 244]; WB weᶜ ``to run around (an object), veer''. For additional Lushai allofams, see the cognates {wèi₇ 衛}, {xiàn₁₀ 縣}.
	Since both WB and KN languages have MK loan words, the ultimate source of this etymon is prob.
	AA. PMK *wìəl  basic meaning ``surround, be around, make rounds'', occurs in Mon and Khmer with many prefixed derivatives (Shorto AA Studies 1976: 1065): PMonic *wiil ``to go around'' ⪤ *tr-wiil ``to attend on, surround'' [Diffloth 1984: 239]; Khmer viala /wíiəl/ ``to turn, move round'' ⪤ /rwíiəl/ ``make one's rounds, patrol''. MK ⇒ Tai: S. kra⁴-ween (McFarland: 45: gkra⁴-wane), Saek vianᴬ² ``go around, make a circuit''.
	Perh. related is PVM: *veːl ``return'' ⪤ *k-veːl ``village'' [Ferlus]; the last word brings to mind {guī₃ 歸} ``return to a place where one belongs''.
::Saek	vianᴬ²	``go around, make a circuit''
>:Area etymon which is widely attested in TB and AA languages. Lushai veelᶠ ``go round, surround, encircle, around, round about'' ⪤ veelᴿ ``to keep coming or walking near''
>:Siyin vil ``watch''
>:WB weᶜ ``to run around , veer''. For additional Lushai allofams, see the cognates {wèi₇ 衛}, {xiàn₁₀ 縣}

ENTRY:3871
HEAD:wèi₃ 味
MC:Middle Chinese: mjweiᶜ 
LH:Later Han: mus 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *məts
	[T] ONW mui
GLOSS:"Taste" [Yili].
	[E] This word is perhaps of MK origin: PMonic *[ʔ]məp ``good tasting, have a pleasant flavor, be pleasant'' (the QY rime can derive from Proto-Chinese *-s, *-ts  and *-ps). Unger (Hao-ku 39, 1992: 89) connects wèi with WT brod ``taste''.
	The meaning of KN-Lushai hmuiᴴ ``savory smelling'', Lai hmuj / hmuʔj  ``be fragrant'' is somewhat removed from ``taste''; however, these items are phonologically close to Chinese.
	Boltz (JAOS 99, 1979: 432) draws attention to binomes for ``taste'': zī-wèi 嗞味 LH tsiə-mus [Shiji, Lie] and cǎn-wèi 噆味 LH tsʰəmᴮ-mus [Huainan], apparently with two different ways to write the first syllable.
::Lai	hmuj / hmuʔj 	``be fragrant''
>:This word is perhaps of MK origin:
>:PMonic *məp ``good tasting, have a pleasant flavor, be pleasant'' . Unger  connects wèi with WT brod ``taste''

ENTRY:3874
HEAD:wèi₆ 蜼
MC:Middle Chinese: jiwiᶜ,ljwiᴮ,jiəuᶜ 
LH:Later Han: wiᶜ ~ luiᴮ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *wih ~ *ruiʔ (< *r-wiʔ) 
OCB:Baxter Old Chinese: *lŭjs
GLOSS:"Kind of monkey-like animal" [Zhouli].
	[E] MK *[s]ryuul, *[s]ryuəl ``gibbon'' (Shorto 2006 #1784): Wa-Lawa-Bulang *rəyol ``white-handed gibbon''; in the variant *wih, the AA initial *r- was lost, see {§10.1.3}.
	Matisoff (1995: 71) suggests that the final *-i in wèi is a ST diminutive suffix added to {yóu₈ 猶}, but wèi and yóu differ in initials as well (*j- vs. *w-).
>:MK *ryuul, *ryuəl ``gibbon'' :
>:Wa-Lawa-Bulang *rəyol ``white-handed gibbon''
>:in the variant *wih, the AA initial *r- was lost, see {§10.1.3}

ENTRY:3875
HEAD:wèi₇ 衛
MC:Middle Chinese: jwäiᶜ 
LH:Later Han: was (wes?) 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *we(t)s 
OCB:Baxter Old Chinese: *wrjats
	[T] ONW uei
GLOSS:"To guard, patrol" [BI, Shu].
GLOSS-NOTE:The graph shows feet walking around an enclosure.
	Wèi is related to {wéi₅ 圍} ``surround, encircle'' even though the vowels differ and the final *-s is unusual in an etymon with ST *-l, but note the parallel word Lushai veetᶠ / veʔᴸ (< *wes) ``to put round or on, cause to encircle; a single encircling'' (under {wéi₅ 圍}).
	For synonyms, see under {huí 回}.
	See {wéi₅ 圍} for outside cognates.
::Lushai	veetᶠ / veʔᴸ (< *wes)	``to put round or on, cause to encircle; a single encircling''

	[E] Perhaps ST *ur: Lushai urʔᴸ ``to burn'' (in cooking), ``get smoky'', uurᴴ ``to smoke, to heat, distill; to warm'' ⪤ uutᶠ / uʔ ``to burn, char, scorch'' ⪤ urᴴ roᴴ ``to dry'' (at a fire); Mikir ur ``to dry over the fire'' (Benedict HJAS 5, 1940: 122 no. 62). ENTRY:3887
HEAD:wén₁ 文
MC:Middle Chinese: mjuən 
LH:Later Han: mun 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *mən
GLOSS:"Be striped, patterned" [BI, Shi],
GLOSS:"written character" [Zuo] >
GLOSS:"literature" [Lunyu] > ``refined, accomplished, cultured'' [BI, Shi].
	[T] Sin  S. SR vun (平), PR, LR vən
	[T] MGZY wun (平) [vun]
	[T] MTang mvun, ONW mun
	[<] Prob. a nominal n-derivation ({§6.4.3}) from {méi₉ 煤} *mə ``soot'', hence lit. ``black marks, dark patterns'' (as tattoos on body etc.), ``writing'' (with ink). At least some of the black paints were, like ink, made from soot.

	MK *muuys, *muə[y]s ``mosquito, gnat'' (Shorto 2006 #1496): PSBahn., PVM *mɔːs [Ferlus], Khmer muuh, Stieng mɔɔh, Bahnaric *mɔɔs [Diffloth 1976: 223]. CH added the nominal n-suffix ({§6.4.3}).

ENTRY:3889
HEAD:wén₃ 聞
MC:Middle Chinese: mjuən 
LH:Later Han: mun 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *mən 
OCB:Baxter Old Chinese: *mjun
GLOSS:"To hear about, hear" [BI, Shi],
GLOSS:"to smell" [Shu].
GLOSS-NOTE:Baxter's (1992: 352f) reconstruction *mjun
GLOSS:"to hear" is based on Shījīng rimes and an earlier form of the graph.
	[T] Sin Sukchu SR vun (平), PR vən
	[T] MGZY wun (平) [vun]
	[T] MTang mvun < mun,  ONW mun

ENTRY:3890
HEAD:wén₃ 聞 ⪤ wèn 問
MC:Middle Chinese: mjuənᶜ 
LH:Later Han: munᶜ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *məns 
OCB:Baxter Old Chinese: *mjuns
GLOSS:1:``Be heard about, renowned, fame'' [Shi].
	[<] *mən + passive s-suffix ({§4.4}).
GLOSS:2:``To ask about, inquire'' [Shi].
	[<] *mən + exoactive s-suffix ({§4.3}), lit. ``let (me) hear'' (?) (cf. Baxter 1992: 431).
	[E] The step from ``hear'' to ``ask'' is not easy to understand, but it occurs also in TB languages, e.g. PLB *ʔna ``listen'' ⪤ *na ``ask'' (Matisoff D. of Lahu: 726f), also in Tani (J. Sun LTBA 16.2, 1993: 152).
	Perh.
	AA had some paronomastic influence on OC, note PMonic *smaaɲ ``inquire'' > Mon hman, Wa-Lawa-Bulang *hmaɲ ``to ask for, ask a question''. ⇒ Tai: Saek maanᶜ² ``ask for help''.
	[E] ST *m-nəm: PTB *m/s-nam ``smell'' (HPTB: 250f), WT mnam-pa ``to smell of'' ⪤ snom-pa (> snum-pa) ``smell'' (Tib. ⇒ Spilo Kanauri mun- ``to smell'' – recorded by N. C. Bodman); WB nam ``stink'' ⪤ namᴮ/ᶜ ``smell'', Mru nam, Lushai namᴴ < nam ``smell of'', JP mə³¹-nam⁵⁵ ``to hear, smell''. CH ⇒ PMY *nhoMᴮ ``to hear, smell''.
	The meanings hear ~ smell are paralleled by ST *nə ``ear ~ nose'', see {ěr₁ 耳}.
	However, in almost all languages, *nəm means only ``to smell'', while ``to hear'' is often expressed by the stem for ``ear''.
	The inversion of n and m in CH is the result of labial dissimilation or prefix-preemption.
::ST	*nə	``ear ~ nose''
>:The step from ``hear'' to ``ask'' is not easy to understand, but it occurs also in TB languages, e.g.
>:PLB *ʔna ``listen'' ⪤ *na ``ask'' , also in Tani
>:ST *m-nəm:
>:PTB *m/s-nam ``smell''
>:WT mnam-pa ``to smell of'' ⪤ snom-pa  ``smell''
>:WB nam ``stink'' ⪤ namᴮ/ᶜ ``smell''
>:Mru nam
>:Lushai namᴴ < nam ``smell of''
>:JP mə³¹-nam⁵⁵ ``to hear, smell''. CH ⇒ PMY *nhoMᴮ ``to hear, smell''

::Khmer	mɔ̀ət	``mouth, edge''

ENTRY:3905
HEAD:wū₂ 巫
MC:Middle Chinese: mju 
LH:Later Han: muɑ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *ma
	[T] ONW muo
GLOSS:"Spirit medium, witch, shaman" [OB, Yi, Shu, Lunyu], both male and female, but later restricted to females [SW] while the male is called xí 覡 (ɣiek) [Guoyu].
GLOSS-NOTE:Wū were associated with chaotic and negative aspects of nature and life, e.g. natural disasters, and often killed in order to eliminate such disasters.
	They had little to do with ritual. (Boileau BSOAS 65.2, 2002: 350ƒƒ).
	[E] ST: Western Tib. ’ba-po < ɴba ``shaman(ess), sorcerer'' (HST: 107). As to foreign initial b- for CH m-, see {§5.12.2}.
	However, the usual WT word for ``shaman'' is gšen.
	<> Tai: S. mɔɔᴬ¹ < PTai *hmɔᴬ ``doctor, sorcerer'' is usually considered a CH loan (Li 1976: 40) and has been cited as evidence for an OC voiceless initial.
	PWa *səmaŋ ``shaman'' may also be connected.
	Several alternative etymologies have been proposed: (1) Perh. {wū₃ 誣} ``to deceive'' is the same word.
	Note a WT semantic parallel ``deceive'' ~ ``magical power'': sprul-ba ``to juggle, make phantoms, miraculous power'' ⪤ ’pʰrul ``magical deception''. (2) Wū could be cognate to wǔ 舞 ``to dance'' [Shi] (Lau 1999: 87). (3) Wū could in addition to ``dance'' be cognate to {mǔ₂ 母} ``mother'' as wū were female acc. to late Zhou and Han texts (E. Schafer, see Jensen EC 20, 1995: 422). (4) V. Mair (EC 15, 1990: 27-47) has proposed that wū is a loan from Iranian *maghu or *maguš ``magician'', i.e. an ``able one'' (specialist in ritual).
::WT	semantic parallel	``deceive''
>:Western Tib. ’ba-po < ɴba ``shaman, sorcerer'' . As to foreign initial b- for CH m-, see {§5.12.2}

ENTRY:3906
HEAD:wū₃ 誣
MC:Middle Chinese: mju 
LH:Later Han: muɑ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *ma
GLOSS:"To deceive" [Lunyu],
GLOSS:"slander, accuse falsely" [Zuo].
	[E] ST: Chepang maʔ- ``to lie, deceive, pretend, secretly do''.
	[WFE] This wf converges and overlaps with {wàng₂ 妄} ``reckless, false''. Perh. related to {wū₂ 巫} ``spirit medium''.
>:Chepang maʔ- ``to lie, deceive, pretend, secretly do''

ENTRY:3907

	The Tai form throws doubt on the possibility that wǎng is the s. w. as {wǎng₃ 罔網} ``net, to snare''.
>:Tai:

ENTRY:3909
HEAD:wū₄ 屋
MC:Middle Chinese: ʔuk 
LH:Later Han: ʔok 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *ʔôk
GLOSS:"Roof" [Shi, Zuo],
GLOSS:"house, room" [Shi].
	[T] Sin Sukchu SR ʔu (入)
	[T] MGZY 'u (入) [ʔu]
	[T] ONW ʔok
	[E] Etymology not clear. The basic meaning of this word is apparently ``roof'', yet comparanda all mean ``house''.
	It is sometimes associated with Tai: Po’ai lukᴰ²S < *dl- ``room'' whose initial l- is difficult to reconcile with OC, see {§5.11}.
	Alternatively, note PTai *ʔj-: S. jauᶜ¹ ``home, house''.
	But wū may be closer to AA forms: PVM *k-rn-ɔʔ ``house'' (with infixes and separated initial omitted in CH), and/or Kharia oʔ, Munda oɽaʔ.
	Wáng Lì (1982: 293) believes that wū was originally the same etymon as wò 幄 (ʔåk) ``tent''.
::PVM	*k-rn-ɔʔ	``house''
>:Etymology not clear. The basic meaning of this word is apparently ``roof'', yet comparanda all mean ``house''

ENTRY:3910
HEAD:wū₅ 惡
MC:Middle Chinese: ʔuo 
LH:Later Han: ʔɑ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *ʔâ
	[T] ONW ʔo
GLOSS:"How" [Lun],
GLOSS:"to what place, where" [Meng], also wū hu 惡乎. This and the following interrogatives occur before the vb, basically asking
GLOSS:"at / to which place" (Dobson LAC: 146f).

ENTRY:3911
HEAD:wū₅ 惡 ⪤ ān 安
MC:Middle Chinese: ʔân 
LH:Later Han: ʔɑn 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *ʔân
	[T] ONW ʔɑn
GLOSS:"To / at what place, in what respect?" [Shi, Zuo] (Dobson). The final -n in this and the next item is probably the same demonstrative morpheme encountered in {rán₂ 然} and other grammatical words ({§6.4.5}).

ENTRY:3912
HEAD:wū₅ 惡 ⪤ yān 焉
MC:Middle Chinese: ʔjän 3 
LH:Later Han: ʔɨɑn 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *ʔan
GLOSS:"To what place, at which place?" [Shi] (Dobson). Probably a (sandhi?) variant of ān above.
	[T] Sin Sukchu SR ʔjen, jen (平)
	[T] ONW ʔan

ENTRY:3913
HEAD:wū₆ 烏
MC:Middle Chinese: ʔuo 
LH:Later Han: ʔɑ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *ʔâ
GLOSS:"Crow, raven" [Shi].
	[T] Sin Sukchu SR ʔu (平)
	[T] MGZY 'u (平) [ʔu]
	[T] ONW ʔo
	[E] This onomatopoetic word could perhaps be cognate to PL *akᴸ/ a³.
>:This onomatopoetic word could perhaps be cognate to PL *akᴸ/ a³

ENTRY:3914
HEAD:wū₆ 烏 ~ yā 鴉
MC:Middle Chinese: ʔa 
LH:Later Han: ʔa 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *ʔa
GLOSS:"Crow, raven" [Zhuang], a later variant of the above which for reasons of sound symbolism preserves the earlier vowel, see {§7.2.2} (Pulleyblank AM  n.s. 9.1, 1962: 103; Unger Hao-ku 22, 1983).

ENTRY:3915
HEAD:wú₁ 毋
MC:Middle Chinese: mju 
LH:Later Han: muɑ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: ≠ *mə ?
GLOSS:"Should not, don't!" Injunctive and imperative negative [OB], already in Zhou time phonetically confused with, and read like, {wú₄ 無} (DEZC: 48, 647).

ENTRY:3916
HEAD:wú₁ 毋 ⪤ wù 勿
MC:Middle Chinese: mjwət 
LH:Later Han: mut 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *mət
	[T]  ONW mut
GLOSS:1:``Should not, don't!'' Injunctive negative [OB, Shi] (DEZC: 48, 650; {§6.2.2}).
GLOSS:2:``Don't vb. him / her / it!'', fusion of wú with zhī 之 [Meng et al.] (Pulleyblank 1995: 108). The OB graph is distinct from that for {wù₅ 物}
GLOSS:"thing" which was therefore not a graphic loan.

ENTRY:3917
HEAD:wú₁ 毋 ⪤ méi 沒
MC:Middle Chinese: muət
	沒 ``not have, there is no, not yet'' Mand.; MC muət may be a col. (j-less) variant of wú 勿 or wèi 未, which later fused with, or was contaminated by, {yǒu₂ 有} (Norman 1988: 126).
	An alternative etymology derives the meaning ``not have'' from ``submerge'' (e.g.
	Norman: Ohta).
	The following belong to a different stem *ma: {mǐ₆ 靡}, {mò₂ 末}, {wáng₁ 亡} (including sāŋ 喪), {wú₄ 無} (including mò 莫).
	Pulleyblank (1973: 121) combines all these words in one large wf.

ENTRY:3918
HEAD:wú₂ 吾
MC:Middle Chinese: ŋuo 
LH:Later Han: ŋɑ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *ŋâ
GLOSS:"I, my" [BI, Zuo] is a dependent pronoun and therefore functions as a subject or possessive, not the sentence-final object ({§3.3.3}). The BI graph is yú 虞 *ŋa, or with yú 魚 *ŋa under the
GLOSS:"tiger".
	During the Nanbeichao and Tang periods, there is no distinction between wǒ and wú, and wú disappears from the col. lg. (Norman 1988: 118).
	Wú is directly cognate to the TB forms below, even though it is missing in the earliest texts.
	[T] Sin Sukchu SR ŋu (平)
	[T] MGZY u (平) [u]
	[T] ONW ŋo
	[E] ST: PTB *ŋa (STC no. 406): WT ŋa; WB ŋa ``I'' ⪤ ŋaᶜ obj. and poss. of ŋa ``I'', PL *C-ŋa. Many TB languages have different etyma for this pronoun.
>:PTB *ŋa :
>:WT ŋa
>:WB ŋa ``I'' ⪤ ŋaᶜ obj. and poss. of ŋa ``I''
>:PL *C-ŋa. Many TB languages have different etyma for this pronoun

ENTRY:3919
HEAD:wú₂ 吾 ⪤ wǒ 我
MC:Middle Chinese: ŋâᴮ 
LH:Later Han: ŋɑiᴮ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *ŋâiʔ
	Independent pronoun ``I, we'' [OB, BI, Shi], in classical texts ``I (stressed), we'' ({§3.3.3}). Originally, the graph for wǒ seems to have been created to write the name of a Shang period people / country, ``sheep'' 羊 was later added 義 (prob. signifying pastoralists) in order to distinguish the name from the pronoun (Sagart TP 81. 4-5, 1995: 328-342).
	[T] Sin S. SR ŋɔ (上), PR, LR ɔ
	[T] MGZY ngo (上) [ŋɔ]
	[T] ONW ŋɑ
	[D] Mand. wǒ is a col. archaism, some northern dialects have the expected ě (Demiéville 1950: 5; Stimson 1972: 177)
	[D] some southern dialects have preserved the OC rime: Y-Fóshān ¹³ŋɔiᴮ²
	[D] K-Méixiàn ŋaiᴮ, PMin *ŋɑiᴮ (Norman 1988: 223).
	[<] *ŋa + independent marker *-i; this final is also a suffix in TB, see below. The OC glottal element may have resulted from *ŋa + ʔi > *ŋaʔi > *ŋaiʔ.
	In OC, wǒ occurs in all sentence positions, unlike the dependent wú 吾, see {§3.3.3} for more details.
	[E] ST: PTB *ŋai (STC no. 285): JP ŋai³³ ``I'', WT ŋed (< *ŋai-t), Mikir ne, Chepang ŋi ~ ni ``we'', Phom (Chang-Tangsa = Konyak) ŋei ``I'' (Benedict 1995: 31); Lushai ŋeiᴸ ``self'', JP ŋai³³ ``I''. The final *-i is a suffix (Matisoff 1995: 76f).
::JP	ŋai³³	``I''
>:PTB *ŋai :
>:JP ŋai³³ ``I''
>:WT ŋed
>:Mikir ne
>:Chepang ŋi ~ ni ``we'', Phom  ŋei ``I''
>:Lushai ŋeiᴸ ``self''
>:JP ŋai³³ ``I''. The final *-i is a suffix

ENTRY:3920
HEAD:wú₂ 吾 ⪤ áng 卬
MC:Middle Chinese: ŋâŋ 
LH:Later Han: ŋɑŋ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *ŋâŋ
GLOSS:"I, we" is perhaps a stressed form [Shi] (Sagart 1999: 135).
	[C] For possible wider connections, see {yà₂ 御迓訝}. Syn. {yú₅ 余予}.

ENTRY:3921
HEAD:wú₃ 吳
MC:Middle Chinese: ŋuo 
LH:Later Han: ŋuɑ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *ŋwâ
GLOSS:"To shout" [Shi].
	[E] Perh. related to WT ŋar-skad ``roaring of a tiger'' ⪤ ŋa-ro ``be loud''. WT does not preserve earlier medial *w ({§12.9}, {§10.2}).
::WT	ŋar-skad	``roaring of a tiger''
>:Perh. related to WT ŋar-skad ``roaring of a tiger'' ⪤ ŋa-ro ``be loud''. WT does not preserve earlier medial *w

ENTRY:3922
HEAD:wú₄ 無
MC:Middle Chinese: mju 
LH:Later Han: muɑ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *ma
GLOSS:"There is no, not have" [later Western Zhou texts and since].
	[T] Sin Sukchu SR, LR vu (平)
	[T] MGZY wu (平) [vu]
	[T] MTang mvu < muo, ONW muo
	[N] The classical meaning ``there is no, not have'' emerged only later during the Western Zhou period and eventually replaced earlier forms with this meaning and grammatical function; the OB have only {wáng₁ 亡} for ``not have, there is no'', the Shūjīng has both wǎŋ 罔 (under {wáng₁ 亡}) and wú 無, the Shījīng both wú₄ 無 and {mǐ₆ 靡}.
	In the OB, negatives with initial *m- negate actions which are controllable by living persons (Takashima 1996: 370ƒƒ).
	[D] Wú is the common ST negative ``not'' which has survived as such in southern dialects: W-Shanghai mᴬ², Y-Guǎngzhōu, Kèjiā mᴬ², M-Xiàmén mᶜ² (Norman 1988: 199), also sporadically in Zhou texts as some investigators claim, but the instances are ambiguous.
	In many dialects, this etymon fused with {yǒu₂ 有} ``to have, there is'' for ``not have, there is no'': G-Nánchāng, Fèngxīn mauᴬ⁶, Línchuān mauᴬ²; X-Chángshā mɑɤᶜ², Shuāngfēng məᶜ²; Y-Guǎngzhōu mouᴮ²  冇(Mand. mǒu), Táishān moᴬ¹; K-Méixiàn moᴬ² (Norman 1988: 213 etc.).
	[E] ST *ma: PTB *ma ``not'', widely represented in TB languages, e.g. WT ma ``not'', WB maᶜ, PL *ma² ``not''.
::PL	*ma²	``not''
>:ST *ma:
>:PTB *ma ``not'', widely represented in TB languages, e.g.
>:WT ma ``not''
>:WB maᶜ
>:PL *ma² ``not''

ENTRY:3923
HEAD:wú₄ 無 ⪤ mò 莫
MC:Middle Chinese: mâk 
LH:Later Han: mɑk 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *mâk
GLOSS:"None, nothing" [Shi].
	[T] Sin Sukchu SR maw (入), LR mawʔ
	[T] MGZY maw (入) [maw] ONW mɑk
	[<] *ma + distributive suffix *-k ({§6.1.2}).
	[C] Derivatives from the stem *ma are: {mǐ₆ 靡}, {mò₂ 末}, {wáng₁ 亡} (including sāŋ 喪), as well as prob. the wf under {wú₁ 毋}; {ma₂ 嗎} interrogative particle. Pulleyblank (1973: 121) used this large wf to show that allofams can have different rimes.

ENTRY:3954
HEAD:wù₁₂ 霧
MC:Middle Chinese: mjuᶜ 
LH:Later Han: muoᶜ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *moh
GLOSS:"Fog, mist" [Shu].
	[D] This word survives in almost all dialects: Y-Guǎngzhōu mou²², M-Xiàmén bu³³, bɔ²⁴, Fúzhōu muɔ⁵². In Y-Yángjiāng it means ``dew'' mou⁵⁴-ʃui²¹ 霧水.
	[E] ST: PTB *r-muw (STC no. 488) > WT rmu-ba ``fog'' ⪤ rmus-pa ``foggy''; WB mru ``floating dust particles''.
	With final *-k: PTB *muːk (STC no. 357) > WT rmugs-pa ``dense fog'' ⪤ mug-pa ``overcast, troubled'' ⪤ smug-po ``dark red, purple-brown''; Chepang mus ``cloud, fog''; Lepcha muk ``foggy, misty''; JP muʔ³¹ ``overcast''; WB muik ``dark, ignorant'', Lushai muukᶠ ``dull'' (color).
	OC ⇒ Tai S. mɔɔkᴰ¹ᴸ < *hm- ``fog, mist'' (Li F. 1976: 41), KS: Mulam mɔk⁸.
	[C] Possible allofams may be {mòu 瞀} (so HST: 82), {mài₃-mù 霢霂} ``drizzle''. Words meaning ``dark, covered, obscure, dull'' and the like tend to have initial *m- followed by a back vowel.
::Lushai	muukᶠ	``dull''
>:PTB *r-muw  >
>:WT rmu-ba ``fog'' ⪤ rmus-pa ``foggy''
>:WB mru ``floating dust particles''

ENTRY:3955
HEAD:wù₁₃ 鋈
	{wò₁} 沃

ENTRY:3956
HEAD:xī₁ 夕
MC:Middle Chinese: zjäk 
LH:Later Han: ziak 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *s-jak
	[T] ONW ziek
GLOSS:"Evening" [Shi, Zhuang];
GLOSS:"evening tide" 汐 [Lèipiān], opp. cháo 潮 (under {zhāo₄ 朝}).
	[E] ST: PTB *s-r(y)ak  ``spend the night, full day and night, 24 hrs'' (HPTB: 323; STC p. 171; no. 203) > WT žag < ryak ``day'' (24 hrs from sunrise to sunrise); Kanauri hrak ``day'', Lahul gyag ``day''; Lepcha ayak ``day'' (i.e. 24 hrs.); PLB *ʔrak > WB rak, ə-rak ``a complete day of 24 hrs.'', Lahu há ``spend the night'', ɔ̀-há ``night''; Lushai riakᶠ / riaʔᴸ ``put up for the night, stay the night'' (STC no. 203, 417; n. 487; CVST 2: 84); JP yaʔ⁵⁵ < yak⁵⁵ ``day''; Limbu yaːkt- ``to stay'' (especially overnight). CH preinitial *s- for other languages’ *r- and vice versa is not uncommon, see {§5.3}.
	In the OB, the 24 hr. day started and ended some time in the evening or night.
	Since {rì 日} ``sun'' had acquired the meaning ``24 hr. day'' already in OC, xī was then restricted to the time of the day's end.
	This word is thought to be cogn. to {yè₁ 夜}, but TB keeps the etyma *ryak ``24 hr day'' and *ya ``night'' strictly separate. {xī₆ 昔} is prob. related; {lǚ₃ 旅} ``lodge'' may possibly be another manifestation of this stem.
::Lahu	há	``spend the night''
>:PTB *s-rak  ``spend the night, full day and night, 24 hrs''  >
>:WT žag < ryak ``day''
>:Kanauri hrak ``day''
>:Lahul gyag ``day''
>:Lepcha ayak ``day''
>:PLB *ʔrak >
>:WB rak, ə-rak ``a complete day of 24 hrs.''
>:Lahu há ``spend the night'', ɔ̀-há ``night''
>:Lushai riakᶠ / riaʔᴸ ``put up for the night, stay the night''
>:JP yaʔ⁵⁵ < yak⁵⁵ ``day''
>:Limbu yaːkt- ``to stay'' . CH preinitial *s- for other languages’ *r- and vice versa is not uncommon, see {§5.3}

ENTRY:3957
HEAD:xī₂ 西棲栖
MC:Middle Chinese: siei 
LH:Later Han: sei (also sen ?) 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *s(n)ə̂i 
OCB:Baxter Old Chinese: *səj
GLOSS:"Nest" n. [Shi] >
GLOSS:"to roost, rest" 棲 [Shi]
GLOSS:"keep still" 栖 [Lunyu]; ``west'' 西 [Shi] > ``turn or go west'' [Shu].
	[T] Sin S. SR sjej (平), PR, LR si
	[T] MGZY si (平) [si]
	[T] ONW sėi
	[E] Xī has several possible etymologies. (1) Because 西 appears to be the phonetic in the graph nǎi 迺 (nậiᴮ) *nə̂ʔ, some investigators assume an OC *sn- cluster. Unger (Hao-ku 36, 1990: 60) relates xī to WT ner-ba ``to sink, go down''; or (2) it is related instead to Chepang nelʔ- ``go down, set'' (sun) (same etymon as WT?). (3) A MK nominal n-infix derivative from the root ``go down'' as in OMon cnis ``ghat'' < cis ``go down'' (to the river, and generally), with PAA *tsn- > PCH *sn-, see {§2.6.1}.
	Therefore this etymon meant lit. ``the place where one goes down to'' > Mon ``ghat'' > OC ``nest, west''.
	The base form is {jì₁₅ 濟} ``to ford'' via AA. (4) CVST 4: 24 relates this word to WT gze-ba ``home, habitation, nest'', which would be the simplest explanation if it were not for the possible OC medial *n.
::WT	gze-ba	``home, habitation, nest''
>:Xī has several possible etymologies.  Because 西 appears to be the phonetic in the graph nǎi 迺  *nə̂ʔ, some investigators assume an OC *sn- cluster. Unger  relates xī to WT ner-ba ``to sink, go down''
>:or  it is related instead to Chepang nelʔ- ``go down, set''  .  A MK nominal n-infix derivative from the root ``go down'' as in OMon cnis ``ghat'' < cis ``go down'' , with PAA *tsn- >
>:PCH *sn-, see {§2.6.1}

ENTRY:3958
HEAD:xī₃ 吸
MC:Middle Chinese: xjəp 
LH:Later Han: hɨp 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *hŋəp or *həp
	[D] Mǐn: Xiàmén kʰipᴰ¹
GLOSS:"To inhale" [Zhuang].
	[E] ST: the OC initial is not clear, therefore xī could be cognate either to WT rŋub-pa, brŋubs ``to draw in (air), breathe'', or, more likely, to Lushai inᴸ-hipᴴ ``draw in'' (as air). An allofam may be {hē 喝欱} ``drink'' (Lushai hupᴴ); for the *u ~ *i alternations, see {§11.5.1}.
::Lushai	inᴸ-hipᴴ	``draw in''
>:the OC initial is not clear, therefore xī could be cognate either to WT rŋub-pa, brŋubs ``to draw in , breathe'', or, more likely, to Lushai inᴸ-hipᴴ ``draw in'' . An allofam may be {hē 喝欱} ``drink''
>:for the *u ~ *i alternations, see {§11.5.1}

ENTRY:3959
HEAD:xī₄ 析
MC:Middle Chinese: siek 
LH:Later Han: sek 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *sêk
GLOSS:"To cleave, split" [Shi],
GLOSS:"disperse" [Shu].
	[E] Area word: ST *sek: Mikir iŋsèk < m-sèk ``to split'' (Mikir -ek can also derive from -ik), JP seʔ⁵⁵ < sek ``cut''. <> MK *saik, *siək ``to split, cleave, tear'' (Shorto 2006 #465).
	TB cognates show that {sī₅ 斯} ``cleave'' is prob. not (directly) related.
	This word does not belong to any of the stems listed under {lí₁₀ 離}.
	Cf. {chā₁ 叉} ``fork''.
::MK	*saik, *siək	``to split, cleave, tear''
>:Area word:
>:ST *sek:
>:Mikir iŋsèk < m-sèk ``to split''
>:JP seʔ⁵⁵ < sek ``cut''. < > MK *saik, *siək ``to split, cleave, tear''

ENTRY:3960
HEAD:xī₅ 淅
	{shì₂₆} 釋 ``wash rice''

ENTRY:3961
HEAD:xī₆ 昔
MC:Middle Chinese: sjäk 
LH:Later Han: siak 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *sak or sjak ?
	(Past time separated by at least one night:) ``Earlier, formerly, former times'' [BI, Shi], ``yesterday'' [Zuo]; ``night'' [Zuo, Zhuang] is rare, perhaps a later development, possibly derived from the implied notion ``intervening night''. Since in Zuǒzhuàn [Ai 4] 昔 means clearly ``night'', it cannot be a graphic substitution for {xī₁ 夕} ``evening''. xī 腊 [Yi] ``dried meat'' (i.e. ancient meat) is the same word according to Karlgren GSR 798a.
	[T] Sin Sukchu SR si (入)
	[T] MGZY si (入) [si]
	[E] This word *s(j)ak is prob. cognate to {xī₁ 夕} *s-jak ``evening'' (Wáng Lì 1982: 286). They look like variants of the same PCH or ST form *s-jak (~ *r-jak) ``24 hr. period''; in 昔 the *s- was treated like the root initial, in 夕 it was treated like a prefix; this bifurcation with doublets occurs also in roots which have initial *j- and pre-initial *r-, see {§9.2.1}.
	The development night - yesterday has parallels in TB: *ya ``night'' > Chepang yoh ``yesterday''.
	[C] This word has been connected with {yè₁ 夜} ``night'' (Wáng Lì), but see there. Sagart (1999: 67, 160) relates xī to {zuó 昨} ``yesterday'', among others.
::Chepang	yoh	``yesterday''
>:This word *sak is prob. cognate to {xī₁ 夕} *s-jak ``evening'' . They look like variants of the same PCH or ST form *s-jak  ``24 hr. period''
>:in 昔 the *s- was treated like the root initial, in 夕 it was treated like a prefix
>:this bifurcation with doublets occurs also in roots which have initial *j- and pre-initial *r-, see {§9.2.1}

ENTRY:3962
HEAD:xī₇ 腊
	{xī₆} 昔

ENTRY:3966
HEAD:xī₁₁ 犀
MC:Middle Chinese: siei 
LH:Later Han: sei 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *sə̂i
	[T] ONW sėi
GLOSS:"Rhinoceros" [Shi]; this word is not the same as {sì₄ 兕}
GLOSS:"wild buffalo".
	[E] ST *səj refers to a large animal: WT bse ``rhinoceros'' (HST: 125); Kuki-Naga *k-saj, Lushai saaiᴴ (Lushai s- is unexpected), Newari kisii ``elephant'', Tangkhul Naga (Bhat) səy ``cattle'', Bodo kísi ``deer''; perhaps also PLB *dzay² ``animal'': Lahu cê-cà ``domestic animals, cattle'', etc. [Matisoff 1988b]. Like other animal names, this is an area word, note MK: PMon ksɛh, PNB *aseh ``horse''.
	See also {cái₁ 才材財}
::PNB	*aseh	``horse''

ENTRY:3976
HEAD:xí₁ 席
MC:Middle Chinese: zjäk 
LH:Later Han: ziak ~ ziɑk 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *s-lak
	[T] ONW ziek
	[D] PMin *dzʰiɔkᴰ²
GLOSS:"Mat" for sitting or lying on [Shi].
	[E] Because commentators suggest that xí is made of grass (薦) or rushes, and because the syn. {jiàn₁₃ 薦} means both ``grass'' and ``mat'', it is possible that this word is cognate to {mǎng₁ 莽} ``grass, weeds'' (*mlaʔ ~ mlaŋʔ). We would have here an example of the TB-like m-/s- alternation in prefixes: *mlaʔ (< *mlak?) ~ *s-lak.
	Wáng Lì (1982: 289) associates xí with other words, including {jiàn₁₃ 薦}, zū 蒩 ``bedding or packing of straw'' (under {jū₅ 苴} — unlikely).
>:Because commentators suggest that xí is made of grass  or rushes, and because the syn. {jiàn₁₃ 薦} means both ``grass'' and ``mat'', it is possible that this word is cognate to {mǎng₁ 莽} ``grass, weeds'' . We would have here an example of the TB-like m-/s- alternation in prefixes:
>:*mlaʔ  ~ *s-lak

ENTRY:3980
HEAD:xí₄ 錫
MC:Middle Chinese: siek 
LH:Later Han: sek

	[T] MTang sɨk ONW sėk
GLOSS:"Tin" [Shi].
	[E] Area word: MK: Late OMon slāk /slaik/ ``bronze''. <> Tai: Longzh hikᴰ¹S, Po’ai liik < *tʰr- ``tin'' (reconstruction of this initial as *tʰr- is uncertain, HCT: 124); Nung xlek <- Chinese.
	Some Tai forms for ``tin'' listed in HCT: 124 are closer to CH forms for ``iron'' ({tiě 鐵}).
	Both OCM *slêk ``tin'' and *lhît ``iron'' prob. derive from the same foreign etymon which would have entered CH at different times.
	Mahdi (1994: 186) draws attention to the similarity with the AA word for ``leaf'': Khasi slak, Khmer slik, Mon slaʔ; leaves of silver have been used as money in Java acc. to the Sòngshǐ (History of the Song Dynasty), but this is much later.

ENTRY:3986
HEAD:xí₁₀ □

ENTRY:3987
HEAD:xǐ₁ 洗洒
MC:Middle Chinese: sienᴮ,sieiᴮ 
LH:Later Han: seiᴮ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *sə̂iʔ or *sî(n)ʔ,*sə̂nʔ ?
	[T] ONW sėi
GLOSS:"To wash" 洗 [Shi 246],
GLOSS:"wash clean" 洒 [Shi 43].
	[E] ST *sil: PTB *(m-)sil ~ *(m-)syal ``to wash''> WT bsil-ba ``to wash'', Lushai silᴿ (STC: 173 n. 462; HST: 158), WB tsʰeᴮ, Mikir iŋtʰī(ʔ), JP gə³¹-šin³¹. Prob. not cognate to sǎ, shǎi 洒 (ṣăiᴮ) ``to sprinkle'' (under {shāi,shī 篩}; so Karlgren 1956: 16).
	The root of this word is the same as that for ``cool'' {qī₄ 淒悽} in CH as well as TB. Because of the OC vowel *ə, Baxter related xǐ to WT sel-ba, bsal ``to cleanse, clear, remove'' (impurities etc.).
::WT	sel-ba, bsal	``to cleanse, clear, remove''

ENTRY:3991
HEAD:xǐ₅ 狶
MC:Middle Chinese: xjei[ᴮ]  <wow value=' LH:' color='invert' gloss='Later Han'/> hɨi(ᴮ) 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *həi(ʔ) (< *hləi(ʔ) ?)
GLOSS:"Swine" [Zhuang] is a Han period dialect word of S Chǔ [FY 8, 5].
GLOSS-NOTE:This word looks like a dialect variant (*lh- > *hl > *h) of {shǐ₇ 豕}
GLOSS:"pig" ({§5.6}).

ENTRY:3992
HEAD:xǐ₆ 纚屣
MC:Middle Chinese: ṣjeᴮ 
LH:Later Han: ṣieᴮ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *sreʔ
GLOSS:"Band wound round the hair" 纚 [Li], also 縰 [Li];
GLOSS:"sandal" 屣 [Lü],
GLOSS:"straw sandal" 躧 [Guoce].
	[WFE] ? ST: This word is thought to be connected with WT sle-ba, bsles ~ hle-ba, hlas ``to twist, plait, braid'' (Bodman 1980: 71; HST: 47), OC *r  for foreign *l has parallels ({§7.3}). Prob. no connection with {liè₃ 茢}.
::WT	sle-ba, bsles ~ hle-ba, hlas	``to twist, plait, braid''

ENTRY:3994
HEAD:xì₁ 系繫
MC:Middle Chinese: ɣieiᶜ 
LH:Later Han: geᶜ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *gêh 
OCB:Baxter Old Chinese: *N-keks
	[T] ONW ɣėi
GLOSS:"To be attached, connected" [Yi] (Baxter and Sagart 1998: 46).
	[<] endopass. of xì 係繫 (kieiᶜ) ({§4.6}).
	[D] Norman (1988: 223) suggests that this word is the source of the Kèjiā and Yuè copula ``to be'': K-Méixiàn hɛᶜ, Huayáng xieᶜ. The OC initial consonants in this and the following xì 繫 and xī 係 is not certain (*g- or *k-?).
	[WFE] Other lg. families have words which may be connected: PMY *kr-: Anc. Miao *qʰeiᴬ ``to tie up'' (Strecker 1989: 30); AA: Kharia kɛ’ǰ ``to fasten'' ⪤ kɛkɛ’ǰ ``rope''.
	[C] Perh. {jī₁₀ 績} ``to twist'' is an interative s-prefix derivation.
::Kharia	kɛ’ǰ	``to fasten''

ENTRY:3995

OCB:Baxter Old Chinese: *keks
	[T] ONW kėi
GLOSS:"To bind, tie up, attach" tr. 係 [OB], 繫 [Yi];
GLOSS:"continue, perpetuate" 繼 [Shi] (read Mand. jì).

ENTRY:4003
HEAD:xiá₁ 呷
MC:Middle Chinese: xap 
LH:Later Han: hap 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *hap
GLOSS:"To drink with a sucking movement" [SW], in some southern dialects it is the word for
GLOSS:"to drink": Y-Guǎngzhōu hap³³, W-Sūzhōu haʔ⁴⁴. The QY vocalism may be due to sound symbolism or archaistic colloquialism and not go back to OCM  *-r-.
	This word may be related to {hē 喝欱} ``trink''.
	[<] Onomatopoetic area word: ST: WT hab ``mouthful'', WB hap ``bite at'', Lushai hapᴴ ``bite, snap'' (HST: 43). <> AA: Santali ha’b ``take into the mouth'', Munda ha’b ``bite'', PMonic *haap in caaʔ-haap ``to eat, esp. with fingers'' [Diffloth 1984: 214].

ENTRY:4008
HEAD:xià₁ 下
MC:Middle Chinese: ɣaᴮ 
LH:Later Han: gaᴮ 
OC:Old Chinese: *graʔ
GLOSS:"To descend, down, below" [OB, Shi].
	[T] Sin Sukchu SR ɣja (上去)

	[T] ONW ɣäᴮ
	[WFE] AA: Khmer gra’ka /kruk/ (vowel /u/ instead of /a/ because of the voiced initial) ``be low, debased''; for CH tone B, see {§3.2.2}, weakening of final -k to OC *-ʔ is perhaps due to ST influence: PTB *gla ⪤ *kla ``to fall'', see forms under {luò₇ 落}.
	<> Tai: S. laaᶜ¹ < *hl- ``underneath, below'' seems to have a TB origin.
	<> CH ⇒ PMiao *ɴGaᴮ ``to go down'' (Wáng Fúshì 1979). — [C] Allofam {luò₇ 落} ``to fall''.

ENTRY:4015

ENTRY:4016
HEAD:xiān₂ 仙僊
MC:Middle Chinese: sjän 
LH:Later Han: sian 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *san
GLOSS:"An immortal" [Lie], a relatively late word. Xiān are men and women who attain supernatural abilities, after death they become immortals and deities who can fly through the air.
	For example, Lǎozi, the founder of Taoism, is called a xiān.
	Xiān can also refer to living persons who have unusual skills in their profession (Eberhard 1983: 287).
	[N] The original graph was 僊, the simplified form 仙 has been partially inspired by the notion that xiān live as recluses in the mountains shān 山.
	[E] Perh. ST: WT gšen < g-syen (?) ``shaman'', one who has supernatural abilities, including travel through the air; Gšen-rab(s) was the founder of the ancient Tibetan Bon religion, sometimes thought to be identical with Lǎozi.
	The vocalic discrepancy, though rare, has parallels ({§11.1.3}). – Or is WT gšen a CH loan?
::WT	gšen < g-syen 	``shaman''
>: WT gšen < g-syen  ``shaman'', one who has supernatural abilities, including travel through the air
>:Gšen-rab was the founder of the ancient Tibetan Bon religion, sometimes thought to be identical with Lǎozi

ENTRY:4017
HEAD:xiān₃ 秈
MC:Middle Chinese: sjän
GLOSS:"Non-glutinous rice" is a dialect word south of the Yangtze River [JY] which is shared with PTai *s-: S. saanᴬ¹
GLOSS:"husked rice".

::Lushai	tʰarᴴ	``new''
>:PTB *sar >
>:WT gsar-ba ``new, fresh''
>:WB saᶜ ``make anew''
>:Rawang angsar

ENTRY:4027

ENTRY:4028
HEAD:xián₅ 閑閒

	[T] ONW ? kän

ENTRY:4041
HEAD:xiǎn₃,hǎn 闞
MC:Middle Chinese: xămᴮ,xamᴮ,xâmᴮ 
LH:Later Han: hamᴮ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *hâmʔ or *hrə̂mʔ ?
GLOSS:"Roaring, enraged" (of a tiger) [Shi].
	[E] Area word: PMonic *grəəm > Nyah-Kur ``to growl'' (of tiger or dog), Khmer gamrāma /kumríiəm/ ``to roar, shout, to cow, awe, intimidate''; Viet sấm (< kr-?) ``thunder'' ⪤ râm ``noise of thunder'', Bahn. grâm ``thunder'', Cham gram ``id'' [Maspero 1912: 83]. Note also Mon krə̣m ``to cheer''.
	<> Lai hraam ``to growl, groan'' [LTBA 21.1: 160]. Though onomatopoetic, these forms are probably cognates because the roaring of an animal could be expressed in many different ways, note for example Limbu uːkt- ``to roar'' (of tiger), ``thunder'', or English ``roar'', for that matter.
::Limbu	uːkt-	``to roar''
>:Area word:
>:PMonic *grəəm >
>:Nyah-Kur ``to growl''
>:Khmer gamrāma /kumríiəm/ ``to roar, shout, to cow, awe, intimidate''
>:Viet sấm  ``thunder'' ⪤ râm ``noise of thunder''
>:Bahn. grâm ``thunder''
>:Cham gram ``id'' . Note also Mon krə̣m ``to cheer''

OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *senʔ ? 
OCB:Baxter Old Chinese: *sjenʔ (Baxter 1992: 385)
GLOSS:"Be rare, few" 鮮 [Shi], 尟 [Yijing].
GLOSS-NOTE:Etymology not clear.

GLOSS:"Small pit" (as a trap),

	[D] Y-Guǎngzhōu ham²²

	Since OC *-əm can reflect any foreign rime other than *-am, it is difficult to relate the various CH and foreign comparanda to each other.
::JP	gyam	``lie in wait for, hunt''

ENTRY:4050
HEAD:xiàn₆ 線

	[D] PMin *siɑnᶜ
GLOSS:"Thread"  線 [Zhouli].
	[E] The ambiguities of monosyllables is quite apparent in this etymon which can be compared to several TB items: (1) Unger (Hao-ku 35, 1986: 29) relates this word to WT snal-ma ``thread'', but (2) WT sran-bu is a possible alternative; (3) note also Lushai tʰilᴴ < sil ``thread''. ::Khmer	-sai /-saj/	``line, thread''

OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *hŋans
	The basic meaning seems to be ``elevate, elevated'': ``to display, present'' 獻 [BI, Shi] > ``eminent men'' 獻 [Shu], ``illustrious'' 憲 [Li] > ``exemplary, model, law'' 憲 [BI, Shi].

ENTRY:4056
HEAD:xiàn₁₀ 縣
MC:Middle Chinese: ɣienᶜ 
LH:Later Han: genᶜ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *wêns
GLOSS:"District, county" [Zhouli].
GLOSS-NOTE:The graph was originally intended for {xuán₄ 縣懸}
GLOSS:"to suspend" which supports an OC *w in the initial for
GLOSS:"county" (for the occasional loss of *-w-, see {§10.2.1}).
	[T] Sin Sukchu SR ɣjen (去)
	[T] MGZY Xwÿan (去) [ɣyɛn]
	[E] Etymology not clear. Perh.
	AA and related to {yíng₄ 營} because in the expression huán nèi 寰內 ``imperial domain'', huán 寰 can be read xiàn 縣; this graphic substitution also indicates that there once was a *w in the OC initial.
	Alternatively, xiàn can derive from similar looking ST words and roots, for example note Lushai veelᶠ ``surroundings, neighborhood, environs, suburbs'' ({wéi₅ 圍}).
	Many of these words and wf are difficult to disentangle.
::Lushai	veelᶠ	``surroundings, neighborhood, environs, suburbs''

ENTRY:4057
HEAD:xiāng₁ 相
MC:Middle Chinese: sjaŋ 
LH:Later Han: siɑŋ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *saŋ
GLOSS:"Each other, mutually" [Shi] is classical for the preclassical allofam {xū₁ 胥} (Pulleyblank 1962: 233; 1996: 137). It is not only used when the action “is strictly reciprocal, but there is a mutual bond of some kind between subject and object” as in xiāng cóng 相從
GLOSS:"(you) follow me" [Shu], later xiāng functions as object pronoun (Pulleyblank 1996: 137).
	[T] Sin Sukchu SR sjaŋ (平)
	[T] MGZY (sÿang >) syang (平) [sjaŋ]
	[T] MTang siaŋ < saŋ, ONW saŋ

ENTRY:4058
HEAD:xiāng₁ 相 ⪤ xiàng 相
MC:Middle Chinese: sjaŋᶜ 
LH:Later Han: siɑŋᶜ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *saŋh
GLOSS:"Look at, inspect" [Shu] > (``supervise'':)
GLOSS:"assist, help" [Shi, Shu] >
GLOSS:"assistant" [Shi] > ``minister''. Boltz (JAOS 99.3, 1979: 431) defines xiàng as ``observe, vision, image, fantasy''.
	[<] extrovert of xiāng 相 (sjaŋ) ({§4.3}).

ENTRY:4059
HEAD:xiāng₁ 相 ⪤ xiǎng₁ 想
MC:Middle Chinese: sjaŋᴮ 
LH:Later Han: siɑŋᴮ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *saŋʔ
	[T] MTang siaŋ < saŋ ONW saŋ
GLOSS:"To think, imagine" [Zhouli].
	[<] endoactive of xiàng 相 ``observe'' ({§4.5}); Boltz: ``to draw up a mental image, vision'' > ``to think''. This word is prob. also related to {xǔ₂ 諝} ``discriminate, knowledge''.
	[C] A further allofam is {xū₁ 胥} ``each other'' (Pulleyblank 1962: 233) which also supports the semantic connection between ``mutual'' and ``help''.

ENTRY:4060

GLOSS:"be fragrant" (Wáng Lì 1982: 323). For a ~ i variation, see {§11.1.3}.
	For an overview of related ST etyma, see {Table X-1} [ Strong smell, odor, fragrance ] .
	[T] Sin Sukchu SR xjaŋ (平)
	[T] MGZY (hÿang >) hyang (平) [xjaŋ]
	[T] MTang hiaŋ < haŋ, ONW haŋ
	[E] A derivation is prob. {xiǎng₃ 鄉饗享}. Pulleyblank (1962: 140) relates this word to {fāng₅ 芳} ``fragrant''. ◇

	It is not clear how PY *ḷɑːŋ¹ ~ PM *ḷɑː⁵ ``rope, sash'' [Wáng F.] is connected.

ENTRY:4064
HEAD:xiáng₁ 庠祥
MC:Middle Chinese: zjaŋ 
LH:Later Han: ziɑŋ

GLOSS:"Fortune" (good or bad) [Zuo] >
GLOSS:"happy omen, auspicious, lucky day" [Shi] (Wáng Lì 1958: 549). Many different etymologies are theoretically possible: xiáng may belong to {yù₈ 悆譽豫}
GLOSS:"happy"; and/or be related to WT g-yaŋ ``happiness, blessing'' (so Bodman 1980: 95), but see {qìng₂ 慶}; or note Tai-Saek laaŋᴬ¹ ``luck''.

ENTRY:4065

LH:Later Han: ziɑŋ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *s-jaŋ or *s-laŋ ?
GLOSS:"School" [Meng] is perhaps the same word as xiáng
GLOSS:"manage the support for the elderly" (under {yǎng₂ 養}; s-prefix caus. of {yáng₇ 揚}
GLOSS:"rise"), both imply ``make rise, raise'' (then > ``educate'' / ``take care of''). Alternatively, this word could also be the same etymon as {xiáng₄ 詳} ``explain in detail''.
	[C] An allofam is perhaps {xù₁ 序} ``school'' (Pulleyblank 1962: 233).

HEAD:xiǎng₂ 饟餉

	[T] ONW śaŋ

GLOSS:"to eat" tr. [Hanfei],
GLOSS:"pay for soldiers" n. [Hanshu].
	[E] MY: Anc. Miao ɳ̇onᶜ [Wáng Fúshì] ``cooked rice, food'', Yao: Biao Mǐn ṇaŋ⁵, Mien (Chiang Rai dial.) ṇhaaŋ⁵, Dzao Men nɔŋ⁵ [Haudricourt / Strecker, TP 77, 1991: 339].

::Miao	ɳ̇onᶜ 	``cooked rice, food''
