ENTRY:4073
HEAD:xiǎng₃ 鄉饗享
MC:Middle Chinese: xjaŋᴮ 
LH:Later Han: hɨɑŋᴮ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *haŋᴬ !
GLOSS:"To feast" [BI];
GLOSS:"enjoy the use of something" [BI, Shi],
GLOSS:"feast, enjoy" 享 [Zuo].
GLOSS-NOTE:Tone A in Shījīng (Mattos 1971: 309); acc. to Downer (1959: 283) commentators read
GLOSS:"to feast, to present" [Zuo] in tone C.
	[E] Etymology not certain. SW glosses this word as ``fragrance of grain''; the basic meaning may therefore have been to enjoy the fragrance of food; consequently, this word is perhaps a tone B endoactive / introvert derivation from {xiāng₂ 香} ``fragrance'' ({§4.5}).
	The semantics are supported by the TB cognates: Lushai haŋᴴ / hanᶠ (< haŋ) ``be tasty, nice, cooked'' (vegetables), PLB *haŋ² which variously means ``cooked rice, a meal, curry'' in LB languages > WB haŋᴮ ``curry'' [Matisoff D. of Lahu: 220]. Popular perception may have connected this word with ``to face'' {xiàng₁ 向嚮卿}.
	Semantically more plausible would be a basic meaning ``to eat'' for this word, hence it may be a variant of {xiǎng₂ 饟餉}; in some non-ST etyma an initial voiceless continuant shows up as a simple OC initial *h- (MC x-; {§5.6}; {§1.3.1}).
	The ultimate source   would be MY.
::WB	haŋᴮ	``curry''
>:Etymology not certain. SW glosses this word as ``fragrance of grain''
>:the basic meaning may therefore have been to enjoy the fragrance of food
>:consequently, this word is perhaps a tone B endoactive / introvert derivation from {xiāng₂ 香} ``fragrance''

ENTRY:4074
HEAD:xiǎng₄ 響
	{xiàng₁} 向嚮卿

ENTRY:4075
HEAD:xiàng₁ 向嚮卿
MC:Middle Chinese: xjaŋᶜ 
LH:Later Han: hɨɑŋᶜ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *haŋh < *hnaŋh?
GLOSS:"To face, approach" 嚮 [Shi],
GLOSS:"turn towards" 向 [Zhuang] >
GLOSS:"direction" 卿 [Hanfei], (``facing side'':) ``south side, north side'' 卿 = 嚮 [Shi], ``before, previously'' 卿 [Meng].
	[T] Sin S. SR xjaŋ (去)
	[T] MGZY (hÿang >) hyang (去) [xjaŋ]
	[T] MTang hiaŋ < ONW haŋ
	[D] Mǐn has an unexpected vowel: Xiàmén col. hiãᶜ¹, ŋᶜ¹
	[E] Etymology not certain, possibly an area word: PLB *ʔna² ``side'' > WB ə-naᴮ ``side, vicinity'' ⪤ Lahu nā ``forehead, brow''; Limbu na ``face'' (also in expressions ``turn the face'' in a direction). <> PKS *k-naᶜ [Edmondson / Yang] or *ʔnaᶜ [Thurgood 1988] ``face, in front'', PTai *hnaᶜ¹ ``face, front''.
	Although CH has no trace of an initial *n (餉 [Meng] may only be a late graphic variant of 饟 *nhaŋh; see {xiǎng₂ 饟餉}), xiàng agrees with a pattern of occasional loss of sonorants in devoiced initials ({§5.6}). Final -ŋ alternates with open vowels in cognate sets ({§6.5.2}), especially in glottalized syllables (KT tone C corresponds to CH tone B < *ʔ).
	[C] An allofam may also be {rú₂ 如} ``go to''.
::PTai	*hnaᶜ¹	``face, front''
>:Etymology not certain, possibly an area word:
>:PLB *ʔna² ``side'' >
>:WB ə-naᴮ ``side, vicinity'' ⪤ Lahu nā ``forehead, brow''
>:Limbu na ``face'' . < > PKS *k-naᶜ  or *ʔnaᶜ  ``face, in front''
>:PTai *hnaᶜ¹ ``face, front''

ENTRY:4076
HEAD:xiàng₁ 向嚮卿 ⪤ xiāng 卿
MC:Middle Chinese: xjaŋ 
LH:Later Han: hɨɑŋ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *haŋ
GLOSS:"Region" [Shi] >
GLOSS:"village" [Lunyu],
GLOSS:"old home village" [Hanshu].
	[<] nominalizing tone A back formation of xiàng ({§3.1}). For the semantic connection ``facing side, side'' > ``region'', note the parallel {fāng₁ 方} ``side'' > ``area, region''.

ENTRY:4077
HEAD:xiàng₁ 向嚮卿 ⪤ xiǎng 響
MC:Middle Chinese: xjaŋᴮ 
LH:Later Han: hɨɑŋᴮ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *haŋ !
GLOSS:"Echo" [Zhuang, Lie].
	[<] endoactive / reflexive of {xiàng₁ 向嚮卿} ``to face, turn towards'', i.e. something that turns in (toward) itself ({§4.5}).
	[E] Bodman (1980: 155) relates this word to Chepang mraŋh ``echo'' ~ mryaŋh ``to echo'', Pulleyblank (1962: 140) to WT brag ``echo'', but the TB initials are difficult to reconcile with Chinese.
::WT	brag	``echo''
>:Bodman  relates this word to Chepang mraŋh ``echo'' ~ mryaŋh ``to echo''
>:Pulleyblank  to WT brag ``echo'', but the TB initials are difficult to reconcile with Chinese

ENTRY:4078
HEAD:xiàng₂ 相
	{xiāng₁} 相

ENTRY:4079
HEAD:xiàng₃ 巷
MC:Middle Chinese: ɣåŋᶜ 
LH:Later Han: gɔŋᶜ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *grôŋh
GLOSS:"Lane, street" [Shi].
	[D] {lòng₂ 弄} ``alley, lane'' is a Wú dialectal variant which supports the OC initial cluster, as do forms like Jìn-Tàiyuán xəʔᴰ²-l-ᶜ 黑浪 (Zhāng Xīng-yà YWYJ 1996.4: 12). Cf. also Beijing hú-túng 胡同.
	[E] Etymology not clear, perhaps ST: WT groŋ ``houses, village, town'', Bumthang kroŋ ``village'' (Bodman 1980: 143; HST: 156); LaPolla (1994: 171) sets up PTB *g-rwa-ŋ (then perhaps related to {lǐ₃ 里}). <> PMiao *roNᴮ, PYao *raaŋ⁴ ``village'' could either belong here, or it could be related to Tai {chán₃ 廛}.
	<> AA is prob. unrelated: Khmer kruṅa /krong/, OKhmer kuruṅ /kruŋ/ ``to cover, shelter, protect … manage, administer, rule, realm, kingdom, royal seat, capital'' (⇒ Tai: S. kruŋ ``capital city'').
::OKhmer	kuruṅ /kruŋ/	``to cover, shelter, protect … manage, administer, rule, realm, kingdom, royal seat, capital''
>:Etymology not clear, perhaps ST:
>:WT groŋ ``houses, village, town''
>:Bumthang kroŋ ``village''
>:LaPolla  sets up PTB *g-rwa-ŋ . < > PMiao *roNᴮ
>:PYao *raaŋ⁴ ``village'' could either belong here, or it could be related to Tai {chán₃ 廛}

ENTRY:4080
HEAD:xiàng₄ 項
MC:Middle Chinese: ɣåŋᴮ 
LH:Later Han: gɔŋᴮ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *grôŋʔ
	[T] ONW ɣäŋᴮ
GLOSS:"Neck" [Zuo],
GLOSS:"stretch the neck" [Shi 191], occurs in a few Mand. dialects: Chéngdū ⁵³tɕin-¹³xaŋ 頸項, Yángzhōu ⁴²tɕiŋ-⁵⁵xɑŋ (col.).
	[E] ST: Chepang groŋ-ko ``stretch the neck'' (downward to eat, of cattle); OBurm. kʰloŋ, WB kʰyoŋᴮ ~ kʰroŋᴮ ``throat'' > PWa *kroŋ ``throat''. Similar looking words are {háng₃ 頏} ``stretch the neck'', {gāng₁ 亢} ``neck''.
::WB	kʰyoŋᴮ ~ kʰroŋᴮ	``throat''
>:Chepang groŋ-ko ``stretch the neck''
>:OBurm. kʰloŋ
>:WB kʰyoŋᴮ ~ kʰroŋᴮ ``throat'' >
>:PWa *kroŋ ``throat''. Similar looking words are {háng₃ 頏} ``stretch the neck'', {gāng₁ 亢} ``neck''

ENTRY:4081
HEAD:xiàng₅ 象
MC:Middle Chinese: zjaŋᴮ 
LH:Later Han: ziɑŋᴮ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *s-jaŋʔ ? or *ziɑŋ ? 
OCB:Baxter Old Chinese: *zaŋʔ
GLOSS:"Elephant, ivory" [OB, Shi].
	[T] MTang ziaŋ < ONW zaŋ  —
	[D] M-Xiàmén lit. tsʰiũᶜ², col. sioŋᶜ²
	[E] Area word (Norman 1988: 19): PTai *ǰaŋᶜ, Saek saaŋᶜ² < z- ``elephant''. <> MK *[ ]ciiŋ ``elephant'' (Shorto ɐ520) > PMonic *ciiŋ, PSemai *ciigŋ (-ii- instead of -a- is unexpected: Diffloth 1984: 63); the word has only limited distribution in MK. <> PLB *tsaŋ ``elephant'' > WB chaŋᴬ (⇒ Haka Chin siaŋ ``royal, governmental'' from WB siaŋ-pahraŋ ``elephant lord'', a royal title [F. K. Lehman 1963, The Structure of Chin Society, Illinois Stud. in Anthrop. no. 3: 39]); Lepcha tyaŋ-mo, Yidu Luoba ɑ³³-tɑŋ⁵⁵ [Zang-Mian no. 309].
	Since it is hard to believe that people all over SE Asia and as far away as the Himalayan foothills would borrow a word for an indigenous animal from Northern China, the Chinese must have been the ones who borrowed this general area word like {hǔ₁ 虎} ``tiger and {sì₄ 兕} ‘wild buffalo''; the latter has the same rare OC initial as xiàng.
	Under these circumstances, xiàng prob. did not have an OC L-like initial.
	Furthermore, Boodberg (1937: 363) cites variants which may confirm this: an alternative word for ``elephant'' zāng-yá 藏牙 [tsɑŋ-ŋa] (lit. ``bury tooth''), and a place name associated with elephants qiāng-wú 槍吾 [tsʰiɑŋ-ŋɑ] (lit. ``pointed tooth''?). Xiàng is not cognate to {yù₂₅ 豫} ``elephant'', nor is WT glaŋ ``ox'' related which is cognate to {gāng₅ 犅}.
::WT	glaŋ	``ox''
>:Area word :
>:PTai *ǰaŋᶜ
>:Saek saaŋᶜ² < z- ``elephant''. < > MK *ciiŋ ``elephant''  >
>:PMonic *ciiŋ
>:PSemai *ciigŋ
>:the word has only limited distribution in MK. < > PLB *tsaŋ ``elephant'' >
>:WB chaŋᴬ
>:Lepcha tyaŋ-mo
>:Yidu Luoba ɑ³³-tɑŋ⁵⁵

ENTRY:4082
HEAD:xiàng₆ 象
MC:Middle Chinese: zjaŋᴮ 
LH:Later Han: ziɑŋᴮ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *s-jaŋʔ ? 
OCB:Baxter Old Chinese: *zaŋʔ
GLOSS:"To interpret, translate" (a foreign language) [Liji, Huainan], xiàng-xū 象胥
GLOSS:"interpreter" [Zhouli] (Behr 2000). This word may be cognate to {xiáng₄ 詳}
GLOSS:"explain in detail", in which case xiàng may be an endoactive derivation of xiáng.
	Behr considers this the s. w. as {xiàng₇ 像象} ``outline, represent''.

ENTRY:4083
HEAD:xiàng₇ 像象
MC:Middle Chinese: zjaŋᴮ 
LH:Later Han: ziɑŋᴮ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *s-jaŋʔ
GLOSS:"To be / look like" 象 [Zuo], resemble’ 像 [Xun] >
GLOSS:"image" [Huainan],
GLOSS:"to delineate, outline, appearance, symbols" 象 [Shu].
	[T] Sin Sukchu SR zjaŋ (上)
	[T] MGZY (zÿang >) zyang (上) [zjaŋ]
	[T] ONW zaŋ
	[E] This word is usually considered the same as {xiàng₅ 象} ``elephant, ivory'' > ``(ivory) image, resemble'' (so Karlgren GSR 728), but ivory was not the only sculpture material. Although the OC initial in ``elephant'' was probably not L-like, OCB *z- and *s-l- / *s-j- might have merged in the Zuǒzhuàn; if so, xiàng ``image'' may possibly derive from a ST root *la: WT lad-mo ``imitation, to imitate, mimic'', WT lha ``gods, image of a deity''; Lepcha klan ``similar'' ⪤ klan-lă ``imitation'' (Geilich 1994: 55, 123); JP sum³¹-la³³ ``picture, image'', num³¹-la³³ ``ghost'' (for correspondence of finals, see {§6.5.2}).
	Geilich adds WT ldem ``statue, idol'', but connects the TB items with {sì₃ 似}.
::WT	ldem	``statue, idol''
>:This word is usually considered the same as {xiàng₅ 象} ``elephant, ivory'' > `` image, resemble'' , but ivory was not the only sculpture material. Although the OC initial in ``elephant'' was probably not L-like
>:OCB *z- and *s-l- / *s-j- might have merged in the Zuǒzhuàn
>:if so, xiàng ``image'' may possibly derive from a ST root *la:
>:WT lad-mo ``imitation, to imitate, mimic''
>:WT lha ``gods, image of a deity''
>:Lepcha klan ``similar'' ⪤ klan-lă ``imitation''
>:JP sum³¹-la³³ ``picture, image'', num³¹-la³³ ``ghost''

LH:Later Han: jɑŋ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *jaŋ or *laŋ
GLOSS:"To pretend, deceive" [Hanfei] (Geilich 1994: 283).
	[E] ⇒ Tai: S. klɛɛŋ³ ``to pretend'' (Gòng Qúnhǔ MZYW 2, 2000).
>:⇒ Tai:
>:S. klɛɛŋ³ ``to pretend''

ENTRY:4087
HEAD:xiāo₂ 消銷
MC:Middle Chinese: sjäu 
LH:Later Han: siau 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *siau
	[T] ONW siau
GLOSS:"To melt, dissolve" 消 [Shi],
GLOSS:"annihilate, disappear" [Yi];
GLOSS:"melt, reduce, diminish"  銷 [Li]; ``disperse'' 肖 [Zhuang]; ``sleet'' (= melting snow) 霄 [SW].
	[WFE] Etymology is uncertain. Perh. (1) WT ’džu-ba ~ žu-ba ``to melt'' (STC p. 52); WT and OC can perhaps be reconciled if we assume a ST *zjau ~ *zju. (2) Alternatively, this word may belong to the wf {xiǎo₁ 小} ``small''. (3) Or related to PTai *ɉuakᴰ²ᴸ ``to melt, dissolve'' [Luo Yongxian MKS 27, 1997: 285]; for loss of final -k in CH, see {§6.9}; the initial correspondence has parallels; see {suǒ₂ 索}.
	[C] {shuò₆ 爍鑠} (śjak) LH śiɑk < śiɑuk ``melt'' may belong to this wf (so Wáng Lì 1982: 222), but the initials are difficult to reconcile (MC śj- < *hl- or *hj- vs. sj-).
::LH	śiɑk < śiɑuk	``melt''

ENTRY:4093
HEAD:xiǎo₂ 曉
MC:Middle Chinese: xieuᴮ 
LH:Later Han: heuᴮ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *hiâuʔ ?
GLOSS:"Clarity" [Zhuang],
GLOSS:"clear, understand" [Xun],
GLOSS:"to know" is a Han period Chǔ dialect word [FY 1,1]; it is the word for ``to know'' (in some places ``to understand'') in all modern dialects from Héféi south, except in Mǐn whose word corresponds to northern zhī 知 (e.g. Xiàmén tiᴬ¹).
	[T] Sin Sukchu SR xjew (上), PR xjaw
	[T] MGZY hÿaw (上) [xjɛw]
	[E] Area word: MY: PYao hiu³ ``to know''; Viet. hièu ``to know''. Kadai lgs. have a word which looks similar: Be hu²¹ ``to know, see'', PHlai ɣweɯ¹ ``to know, recognize'' [Matisoff 1988c: 306]. A KT etymon with initial r- could possibly be related: PTai *ruoᶜ² ``to know'' (in many Tai dial. *r- > h-, but not in the north within China), PKS *h-roᶜ ``to know (how)'' (Edmondson / Yang 1988).
	If all these words should be related, the ultimate source might have been KT with a voiceless r- (rh-) initial > h-.
	For another word where Tai has *hr-, but OC *h-, see {xuè₄,hù 嗀} ``vomit''.
::PKS	*h-roᶜ	``to know ''
>:Area word:
>:MY:
>:PYao hiu³ ``to know''
>:Viet. hièu ``to know''. Kadai lgs. have a word which looks similar:
>:Be hu²¹ ``to know, see''
>:PHlai ɣweɯ¹ ``to know, recognize'' . A KT etymon with initial r- could possibly be related:
>:PTai *ruoᶜ² ``to know''
>:PKS *h-roᶜ ``to know ''

	PTB *gyap (HPTB: 338) > WT kʰyab-pa ``be filled with, embrace, comprise'' ⪤ skyob-pa, bskyabs ``protect, defend, preserve'', skyabs ``protection, help'' (HST: 71; Bodman 1980: 64), PLB *gyap > WB kyap ``tight, close, crowded'', Lahu còʔ ``be narrow'' (of an opening).

GLOSS:"ribs".
	Tiddim gaapᴿ < raap ``pod''.
GLOSS:4:{jiā₄ 挾} *tsep

ENTRY:4110
HEAD:xiě₂ 寫
MC:Middle Chinese: sjaᴮ 
LH:Later Han: siaᴮ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *saʔ (< *slaʔ or *sjaʔ ?)
GLOSS:"To depict" [Guoyu],
GLOSS:"to write" [Shiming, Hou Hanshu].
	[E] Etymology not clear. Similar-looking words in other languages are unrelated; Lushai ziakᶠ / ziaʔᴸ < jak / jaks ``to write, draw, inscribe, engrave''; Lushai lehk’a (cited from Geilich 1994: 184) is a Pali loan; WB ca ``writing, document'' (<- CH zì 字?), JP tʃa³³ ``paint, daub, dye'' [Matisoff 1974: 161]. Alternatively, one may compare the word with Khmer /saak/ ``to mark, brand, duplicate, copy'' ⪤ /sak/ ``to tattoo''; the semantics would be parallel to {wén₁ 文}.

ENTRY:4124
HEAD:xīn₁ 心
MC:Middle Chinese: sjəm 
LH:Later Han: sim 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *səm 
OCB:Baxter Old Chinese: *sjəm
GLOSS:"Heart > mind" [Shi, Shu],
GLOSS:"emotions" (between people) [Shi]; >
GLOSS:"center" [Liji].
	[T] Sin Sukchu SR sim (平), PR, LR sin
	[T] MGZY sim (平) [sim]
	[T] ONW sim.
	[D] PMin *sim
	[D] Y-Guǎngzhōu ⁵⁵sɐmᴬ¹
	[E] ST: PTB *sam (STC: 51) or *səm (STC: 126) > Bahing sam ``breath, life''; Limbu sam ``soul''; Thakali sam ``heart'', WT sem(s) ``soul, spirit, mind'' ⪤ sem(s)-pa, bsams ``to think'' ⪤ bsams ``thought'', Lepcha a-sŏm ``spirit, breath'', WB ə-sam ``sound, voice'' (STC: 183 n. 482; HST: 93). A ST synonym is {rén₂ 仁}.
	MK has a similar word: PMK *-TSəm ``heart'' [Ferlus MKS 7, 1978: 18], PPalaung seːm ``breath, heart, mind'', Khmer ŋhaəm, Semai ləhəm, Wa-Lawa-Bulang *rhom ``heart, mind''. However, the s- may be secondary.
::Wa-Lawa-Bulang	*rhom	``heart, mind''
>:PTB *sam  or *səm  >
>:Bahing sam ``breath, life''
>:Limbu sam ``soul''
>:Thakali sam ``heart''
>:WT sem ``soul, spirit, mind'' ⪤ sem-pa, bsams ``to think'' ⪤ bsams ``thought''
>:Lepcha a-sŏm ``spirit, breath''
>:WB ə-sam ``sound, voice'' . A ST synonym is {rén₂ 仁}

HEAD:xín 尋爓

	[T] ONW zim
GLOSS:"To warm up" 尋 [Guoyu] >
GLOSS:"sacrifice of boiled meat" 爓 [Li], perhaps also
GLOSS:"large boiler" 鬵 [Shi] which is also read qián (QYS dzjäm).
	[E] ST: PTB *lumᴬ ``warm'' (STC no. 381) > WT gtum-po < gḷum ``heat'' (in meditation), gtum-pa ``ferocity, rage''; WB lum ``warm'' ⪤ hlum ``warm oneself by fire'' ⪤ hlumᶜ  ``heat again, warm over''; PL *lum¹ ; JP lum³³ ``warm'' ⪤ ma³¹-lum³³ ``to simmer, heat'' ⪤ ʃa³¹-lum³³ ``to heat, warm'' (food), Dimasa lim ~ lum ``be hot, have fever''.
	Labial dissimilation of the final nasal rather than the vowel perhaps took place in {sūn₂ 飧} ``cooked rice''; this could also be the case in {róng₄ 融} ``to heat''.
	Perh. {xián₁₂ 燅} may be related, yet TB distinguishes *-lam from *-lum.
::Dimasa	lim ~ lum	``be hot, have fever''

>:WT gtum-po < gḷum ``heat'' , gtum-pa ``ferocity, rage''

>:PL *lum¹
>:JP lum³³ ``warm'' ⪤ ma³¹-lum³³ ``to simmer, heat'' ⪤ ʃa³¹-lum³³ ``to heat, warm''
>:Dimasa lim ~ lum ``be hot, have fever''

ENTRY:4136
HEAD:xīng₂ 星 ⪤ qíng 星
MC:Middle Chinese: dzjäŋ 
LH:Later Han: dzieŋ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *dzeŋ 
OCB:Baxter Old Chinese: *ɦtshjeŋ
GLOSS:"Weather clearing during the night" [Shi] is perhaps a derivation from
GLOSS:"star": <
GLOSS:"become starry" (so SW); this word is written [``night'' + phonetic] as late as SW, but takes on the meaning of ``clearing with the sun coming out'' only in post-classical literature, since then written 晴 [Yupian].
GLOSS-NOTE:Alternatively, this word may be directly derived from {qīng₂ 清}
GLOSS:"clear" (so Baxter 1992: 219).

ENTRY:4138
HEAD:xīng₄ 腥

GLOSS:"Raw meat" [Lunyu],
GLOSS:"offensive smell" [Shu].
	[E] This word belongs to a ST *saŋ ~ *s(r)iŋ set ({§11.1.3}) which is parallel to a ST *haŋ ~ *hiŋ pair, see {Table X-1} under {xiāng₂ 香} for an overview.
	ST *se/iŋ: JP siŋ³³ ``smell, scent, odour of fresh, raw food'' (Benedict 1940: 105 no. 17), Chepang səyŋ- ``emit smell, odour, be rotten'', Lepcha mŭŋ-šiŋ, Rawang pušëːŋ ``stench'' [Bodman ICSTLL 1987: 12].
	~ PTB *sriŋ: NNaga *sriŋ ``to smell'', Lushai ṭeeŋᴸ / ṭeenᴸ < treeŋh ``ill-smelling'' seem to represent a separate root; Lushai vowel shows that this stem is unrelated to {shēng₂ 生} ``fresh''.
	~ PTB *saŋ: WB saŋᴮ ``emit pleasant odour'', Lushai tʰaaŋᴿ / tʰaanᴸ ``have smell or odour like raw flesh'' (Peiros / Starostin 1996, IV: 101), tʰaŋᴸ / tʰanᶠ  ``be greasy, oily''.
::Lushai	tʰaaŋᴿ / tʰaanᴸ	``have smell or odour like raw flesh''
>:This word belongs to a ST *saŋ ~ *siŋ set  which is parallel to a ST *haŋ ~ *hiŋ pair, see {Table X-1} under {xiāng₂ 香} for an overview

ENTRY:4151
HEAD:xìng₂ 性姓
MC:Middle Chinese: sjäŋᶜ 
LH:Later Han: sieŋᶜ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *seŋ > *seŋh
	(``What is inborn'':) ``nature'' 性 [BI, Shi] > ``surname, clan name'' (< ``birth'') 姓 [Shi], ``offspring'' [Zuo] (Pulleyblank EC 25, 2000: 12). ``Surname'' 姓 has tone A in older parts of Shījīng (Mattos 1971: 309).
	[T] Sin Sukchu SR siŋ (去)
	[T] MGZY sing (去) [siŋ]
	[T] ONW sieŋ
	[E] ST: this word belongs to the ST *siŋ stem of the groups listed under {shēng₂ 生} and is therefore directly related to the items under {qīng₁ 青}, but only indirectly cognate to shēng (parallel stem ST *sriŋ). Alternatively, the medial *r of shēng might have been felt to be a causative infix and was thus dropped in allofams.
	The JP word n⁵⁵-teŋ⁵¹ ``name'' could possibly be related, but there are phonological difficulties.
>:this word belongs to the ST *siŋ stem of the groups listed under {shēng₂ 生} and is therefore directly related to the items under {qīng₁ 青}, but only indirectly cognate to shēng . Alternatively, the medial *r of shēng might have been felt to be a causative infix and was thus dropped in allofams

LH:Later Han: wəm 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *wəm
GLOSS:"A bear" [Shi].
GLOSS-NOTE:Acc. to SW, yán 炎 OCM *wam is phonetic; if true, yán would confirm the final *-m in xióng, and xióng the initial *w- in yán.
	[T] Sin Sukchu SR ɣjuŋ (平)
	[T] MGZY Hÿung (平) [ɣjuŋ]
	[T] ONW ɣuəm?? > ɣuŋ (?) > huŋ
	[D] The OC final *-m is preserved in Mǐn dialects: Amoy himᴬ², Fú’ān hemᴬ², Yǒng’ān hamᴬ² ``bear''.
	[E] ST: PTB *d-wam > WT dom ``bear'', Tebor hom, Jiarong twŏm; PL *k-d-wam, WB (wak-) wam; Bahing wam; Digaro təham ~ təhum (HST: 40); Kuki-Naga *d-wam, Lushai saᴸ-vɔmᴴ; Mru tom. Other languages in East Asia have words which look similar: Middle Korean kwom, Old Japanese kuma (Miyake 1997: 197), Ainu kamuy ``bear''; on Taiwan AN languages inlcude cumai / cumay.
	Note also AA: PMonic *kmum ``Himalayan black bear''.
::PMonic	*kmum	``Himalayan black bear''

>:WT dom ``bear''

GLOSS:"To rest" [Shi].
	[E] The original meaning may have been ``shade'' > ``to shade onself'', i.e. ``rest in the shade'' > ``rest'' (Wáng Lì 1982: 230; Qiu Xigui 2000: 210).
>:The original meaning may have been ``shade'' > ``to shade onself'', i.e. ``rest in the shade'' > ``rest''

ENTRY:4166
HEAD:xiū₃ 羞
MC:Middle Chinese: sjəu 
LH:Later Han: su 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *snu
GLOSS:"Shame" [Shu],
GLOSS:"diffidence" [Zuo], Mand.
GLOSS:"shy, bashful".
	[WFE] The vacillation between pre-initial *s- and *r- is also observed in TB wfs ({§5.3}). The role of the final *-k in niǔ is not clear; alternatively, xiū may be a tone A derivation from a root in final *-k to form a noun ({§3.1}).
	Pulleyblank (1973: 121) relates this wf to other words meaning ``shame'' with initial *n- but different rimes: {chǐ₅ 恥}; {ní₃ 怩} (which, however, is prob. unrelated).
	Eberhard (1967: 12) derives the notion ``shame'' from ``dirty''.

ENTRY:4169
HEAD:xiū₄ 羞
MC:Middle Chinese: sjəu 
LH:Later Han: su 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *snu
GLOSS:"To nourish" [Shu],
GLOSS:"viands" [Zuo].
	[E] Prob. related to JP noʔ³¹ < nok³¹ ``to eat''; WT ñod-pa ``food'' (lex.); cf. {rú₃ 茹} ``to swallow'', in dialects ``eat''; as for the initial *s-, note there the PVM form under rú. Xiū appears to represent a *u variant ({§11.9.3}), as well as the non-standard preservation of the causative as *s.
	Syn. {yù₂₂ 育毓鬻} {chù₄,xù 畜}.

ENTRY:4185
HEAD:xū₁ 胥
MC:Middle Chinese: sjwo 
LH:Later Han: siɑ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *sa
GLOSS:"Together, mutually, each other" [Shi] is pre-classical for the classical allofam {xiāng₁ 相} (Pulleyblank 1962: 233; 1995: 137) >
GLOSS:"to aid, assist" [BI, Guan] > ?
GLOSS:"foreman" in charge of ten men [BI].
	[E] Acc. to FY 6, xū is a Wú-Yuè dial. word for ``assist'', which is prob. derived from ``mutual'' as in the parallel and cognate wf {xiāng₁ 相} (Pulleyblank 1962: 233). The Han period (FY) association with the language of Wú and Yuè (Viet) seems to strengthens the possibility that this is originally a MK etymon: Pearic saː ``each other''.
	However, xū is well attested as a CH word already in Shījīng.
	[C] A derivation is perhaps {xǔ₂ 諝}.
>:Acc. to FY 6, xū is a Wú-Yuè dial. word for ``assist'', which is prob. derived from ``mutual'' as in the parallel and cognate wf {xiāng₁ 相} . The Han period  association with the language of Wú and Yuè  seems to strengthens the possibility that this is originally a MK etymon:
>:Pearic saː ``each other''

ENTRY:4188
HEAD:xū₄ 須鬚
MC:Middle Chinese: sju 
LH:Later Han: sio, S tsʰio 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *sno
GLOSS:"Beard of chin" 須 [Yi], 鬚 [Zuo].
GLOSS-NOTE:This word survives in Yuè and Mǐn dialects, elsewhere it has been replaced by húzi 鬍子.
	[T] Sin S. SR sy (平)
	[T] MGZY sÿu (平) [sy]
	[T] MTang sy, ONW  suo
	[D] PMin *tsʰiuᴬ¹ ~ *siuᴬ¹
	[E] This word appears to be ST *sno ``mouth'' with a semantic shift from ``mouth'' to its defining edge and surrounding area: PTB *sno(w) ~ *sno(t)  (Benedict LTBA 1976: 16) (perhaps ``a cavernous opening'') > WT snod ``vessel'', bu-snod ``womb'', Motuo Monpa no-waŋ ``mouth'', Kanauri sto ``face'', Lepcha (a-)so ``vessel for body-fluid'' [HPTB: 107], WB hnut (see {huì₁₀ 顪喙}) ``mouth, womb''; Pwo, Sgaw Karen noʔ ``mouth'' (STC: 144f); Achang ṇot⁵⁵-mui³¹ ``beard'' (``mouth hair''), Leqi nuat⁵⁵-mə³³; Jiarong tə ʃnos ``lips''. In light of the ST etymology, xū has prob. no connection with PAA ʃɲu ``hair'': Khasi ʃɲuʔ ``hair'' (ɲ is infix), Khmer /s-ʔ/, Palaungic *s- > h-: Lawa haɨk ``hair''.
	[C] Xǔ is prob. distantly related to {huì₁₀ 顪喙}, perhaps also to {xǔ₄ 盨}. Pulleyblank (EC 16, 1991: 43) relates it to {ér₁ 而} ``whiskers''.
::PAA	ʃɲu	``hair''

>:PTB *sno ~ *sno    >
>:WT snod ``vessel'', bu-snod ``womb''

>:Kanauri sto ``face''

>:Pwo

>:Achang ṇot⁵⁵-mui³¹ ``beard''
>:Leqi nuat⁵⁵-mə³³

>:Khasi ʃɲuʔ ``hair''

>:Palaungic *s- > h-:
>:Lawa haɨk ``hair''

ENTRY:4197
HEAD:xù₁ 序
MC:Middle Chinese: zjwoᴮ 
LH:Later Han: ziɑᴮ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *s-laʔ
GLOSS:"School" [Meng] has two possible etymologies: (1) it is the same word as
GLOSS:"north-south (east-west) running walls at sides of a hall, space or galleries close to such walls" [Shi] (under {xù₂ 序敘緒}) (Wáng Lì 1982: 170). (2) It is an allofam of {xiáng₂ 庠}
GLOSS:"school" (Pulleyblank 1962: 233) which is perhaps derived from {yáng₇ 揚} ``rise, raise''. In fact, xù may be parallel to xiáng in being derived from {yú₁₁ 舁譽} ``to lift''.
	It must be pure coincidence that Modern Khmer ``school'' səlaa is nearly identical to OC.

ENTRY:4198
HEAD:xù₂ 序敘緒
MC:Middle Chinese: zjwoᴮ 
LH:Later Han: ziɑᴮ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *s-laʔ
GLOSS:"Continue, remains" 緒 [Zhuang];
GLOSS:"arrange in order, continue, succeed" [Shi],
GLOSS:"north-south (or east-west) running walls at sides of a hall, space or galleries close to such walls" [Shi], ``order, sequence'' 序 [Mand.]; 敘 [Shi, Shu] > ``line of work, work'' (which is continued) 緒 [Shi]; perhaps {xù₁ 序} ``school'' is the same word, i.e. place along the galleries. (SW and the Chinese commentaries say ``east-west running walls'', Karlgren in GSR 83h says ``north-south running walls'').
	Based on his theories, Pulleyblank (1973: 120) finds cognates of xù in different directions: sì 嗣 (zɨᶜ) ``continue, succeed, inherit'' (under {yí₂ 貽詒}), and xù 續 (zjwok) ONW zuok, LH ziok ``continue'' [Shi].
	[C] A paronym is {yì₃₅ 繹} [jak ~ jɑk] *lak.
::LH	ziok	``continue''

ENTRY:4199
HEAD:xù₃ 卹
MC:Middle Chinese: sjuet 
LH:Later Han: sut (suit) 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *sut ?
GLOSS:"To rub, brush" [Li].
GLOSS-NOTE:The phonetic {xuè₁ 血} implies an OC *swit, but the likely cognate {sāo₁ 搔} *su
GLOSS:"to scratch" as well as the TB cognate require an OC *sut.
	Since Lǐjì is a relatively late text, OC *swit and *sut may already have merged into *suit and have made the phonetic suitable for this word.
	[E] ST: PLB *sut ``wipe, sweep'' [Matisoff, Variational Semantics] > WB sut ``wipe'', Lahu šìʔ < *sit.
>:PLB *sut ``wipe, sweep''  >
>:WB sut ``wipe''
>:Lahu šìʔ < *sit

ENTRY:4200
HEAD:xù₄ 旭
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *ho (or *hwo)
GLOSS:"Brilliance of the rising sun" [Shi] has several readings, hence the etymology is not clear: (1) It seems to write the word also written xǔ 煦昫 [hɨoᴮ/ᶜ]
GLOSS:"to warm" (as the rising sun). (2) The reading (xjwok) [hɨok] goes with a meaning
GLOSS:"noisy" as in xióng-xióng xù-xù 洶洶旭旭 LH hɨoŋ-hɨoŋ hɨok-hɨok [Han: Yáng Xióng], from there the reading may have extended to the graph in general, including ``rising sun''. (3) The reading LH huᴮ, glossed in SW as hǎo 好 [houᴮ] < *hûʔ, is possibly inspired by the phonetic jiǔ 九 [kuᴮ] *kuʔ.
	[WFE] All the items in the wf prob. belong to the same root *ho or perhaps *hwo ``warm in the sun''; the latter would logically result in the OC / MC forms above: *hwo and *hwoŋ are impossible, they would become OC *ho, *hoŋ; *hwon would have to dissimilate to OC *hwan. This wf coalesces partially with {yù₂₀,yǔ 嫗}, perhaps together they belong to a single wf.

ENTRY:4201
HEAD:xù₄ 旭 ⪤ xǔ 煦
MC:Middle Chinese: xjuᴮ/ᶜ 
LH:Later Han: hɨoᴮ/ᶜ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *hoʔ/h
GLOSS:"To warm" (with breath or air, e.g.
	Heaven's warm breeze to make things grow) tr.
	[Liji] which is what SW apparently means by zhēng 烝 ``to steam''; also xù 昫 ``incubate eggs''. See also {xù₄ 旭}.

ENTRY:4202
HEAD:xù₄ 旭 ⪤ xiǒng 煦
MC:Middle Chinese: xjwoŋᴮ 
LH:Later Han: hɨoŋᴮ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *hoŋʔ
GLOSS:"Become warm, balmy" (of the rising sun) [Shi], also read xǔ 煦 (xjuᴮ/ᶜ); the reading xiǒng is listed in the late JY, but final -ŋ agrees with the semantics:
	[<] terminative -ŋ of xǔ 煦 (xjuᴮ/ᶜ) ({§6.5.1}), ``become'' warm thanks to the rising sun.

ENTRY:4203
HEAD:xù₄ 旭 ⪤ xuǎn 烜
MC:Middle Chinese: xjwɐnᴮ 
LH:Later Han: hyɑnᴮ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *hwanʔ or *honʔ ?
GLOSS:"To sun, dry in the sun" [Yi],
GLOSS:"sunlight" [Zhouli].
GLOSS-NOTE:The QY reading xjwieᴮ
GLOSS:"sunlight" prob. belongs to the syn. {huī₂ 煇輝暉}.

ENTRY:4204
HEAD:xù₄ 旭 ⪤ xuān 煖
MC:Middle Chinese: xjwɐn 
LH:Later Han: hyɑn 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *hwan
GLOSS:"Warm" [Li].
GLOSS-NOTE:This word is not related to {nuǎn 煖}.

ENTRY:4205

	[D] Southern dialects typically have this latter form: PSMin *saiᶜ (Bodman 1980: 178): M-Xiàmén col. saiᶜ, lit. seᶜ, Cháozhōu saiᶜ, Fúzhōu saᶜ
	[D]  W-Wēnzhōu seiᶜ, K-Méixiàn sɛᶜ, Guǎngzhōu ʃaiᶜ². The word is reminiscent of AA: PSBahn. *saːj ``marry, spouse''.

ENTRY:4220
HEAD:xuán₄ 縣懸
MC:Middle Chinese: ɣiwen 
LH:Later Han: guen 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *gwîn
	[T] MTang ɣuian(?) ONW ɣuėn
GLOSS:"To suspend, hang up" 縣 [Shi], 懸 [Meng] is today the word for
GLOSS:"high" in Mǐn: PMin *guen > Fúzhōu keiŋᴬ²
GLOSS:"high" ⪤ heiŋᴬ² ``hanging down'' (Norman 1979: 271). Tai has borrowed the word ``suspend'': S. kʰwɛɛnᴬ¹ < *xw- (Manomaivibool CAAAL 6, 1976: 16).
	Prob. related to {guà 挂} ``suspend'' (for final -n, see {§6.4.4}), perhaps also to {qìng₃ 磬} ``id''.

ENTRY:4222
HEAD:xuàn₁ 泫
MC:Middle Chinese: ɣiwenᴮ 
LH:Later Han: ɣuenᴮ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *wînʔ
GLOSS:"To flow" [Lun] may derive from the same ST root *lwi
GLOSS:"to flow" as {shuǐ 水}
GLOSS:"water"; earlier *r- and *l- often leave no trace in MC before initial *j- and *w-.

ENTRY:4223
HEAD:xuàn₁ 泫 ⪤ quǎn 畎甽
MC:Middle Chinese: kiwenᴮ 
LH:Later Han: kuenᴮ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *kwînʔ
GLOSS:"Watering channels in fields" 甽 [Zhouli], 畎 [Shu].
	[<] nominalizing k-prefix derivation from xuàn ({§5.4}). The aspirated Mand. reading is probably an analogy to 犬 ``dog''.
	JY gives additional readings: xún (MC zjwən and zhùn, tśjuenᶜ).
	Mǐn: Gùtiān kyeŋᶜ¹ (Branner 1995: 268) is similar to the MC form kiwenᴮ; Xiàmén tsunᶜ¹ < MC tśjuenᶜ (?).

ENTRY:4225

GLOSS:"flow" could also point to OC *lut which would connect the word with {yóu₄ 油}
GLOSS:"flow").

ENTRY:4239
HEAD:xūn 熏燻焄
MC:Middle Chinese: xjuən 
LH:Later Han: hun 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *hwən < *C-un ?
	[T] ONW hun
GLOSS:"To make smoke, befumed" 熏 [Shi], 燻 [Hanfei];
GLOSS:"vapour, odour" 焄 [Li],
GLOSS:"be pungent" [Yi] > ``strong smelling vegetables'' 葷 [Li] (Mand. hūn), ``a fragrant herb'' 薰 [Zuo].
	[E] This word is prob. ST, but its TB counterpart is difficult to pinpoint: perhaps *(C-)wu ``smoke'' (STC: 159 n. 429: *kəw; HPTB: 451), in CH with the addition of the nominal final -n ({§6.4.3}): Dulong mɯ³¹-ɯ⁵⁵ < *-u (?) ``smoke'' (mɯ³¹ ``sky''), WT du-ba ⪤ dud-pa ``smoke'' (a few other words have WT d- for a velar initial elsewhere, note {liù₁ 六} – Matisoff 1974: 195 n. 119), WB kʰuiᴮ, Bahing kuni, Sunwar kun.
	Alternatively, or in addition, xūn may belong with Kanauri wən ``steam''.
	CVST 5: 180 relates xūn to Lushai huᴸ < huh (< hus) ``vapour, gas'' and by implication to WT hus ``moisture, humidity''.
::WT	hus	``moisture, humidity''

ENTRY:4265
HEAD:yà₂ 御迓訝 ⪤ yán 顏

OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *ŋrân 
OCB:Baxter Old Chinese: *ngran

GLOSS:"color", yán acquired later the connotation
GLOSS:"sex" (Eberhard 1967: 12).
	[D] From northern Chǔ eastward to the Huái region it was a Han period dialect word for ``forehead'' [FY 10, 34].
	[E] This noun is either derived with the nominalizing n-suffix from yà 御迓訝 (above), and/or it could be related to WT ŋar ``front-side'', in the expression ``go against, instigate'' (so IST: 37).
::WT	ŋar	``front-side''
>:This noun is either derived with the nominalizing n-suffix from yà 御迓訝 , and/or it could be related to WT ŋar ``front-side'', in the expression ``go against, instigate''

ENTRY:4266
HEAD:yà₂ 御迓訝 ⪤ é 詻

ENTRY:4267
HEAD:yà₂ 御迓訝 = é 額
MC:Middle Chinese: ŋɐk 
LH:Later Han: ŋak 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *ŋrâk
GLOSS:"Forehead" is only attested during Han and later [SW, Shiming, FY, Hou Hanshu]; it is a semantic extension of the homophone 詻
GLOSS:"to face" (lit.
GLOSS:"confront").
	[D] PMin *ŋ̇iak: Xiàmén giɑʔᴰ², hiɑʔᴰ², lit. gikᴰ²
	[E] ST, indirectly related to TB items: Tamang-Gurung, Thakali ŋoh ``forehead''. The connection with Khmer thŋaːh ``forehead'' is not clear.
	Wáng Lì (1982: 280) and LaPolla (1994: 141) have pointed to cognation with yán 顏 (above).
	Syn. {dìng₂ 定顁}, {sǎng 顙}, {yáng₈ 揚鍚}.
	[C] For a synopsis of related words, see {Table Y-1} and comments. Cognates are {àn₂ 岸} ``river bank'', {nì₆ 逆} ``go against'', {yíng₁ 迎} ``go to meet'', {yù₁₇ 禦} ``defend''.
	Prob. unrelated is {yá₃,ái 崖涯睚} ``river bank''.
	Benedict (1995: 33) includes in this wf wǒ 我 ``I'' via ``self'' (under {wú₂ 吾}), as well as WT dŋos ``reality''; see however {yí₁₀ 儀宜} ``proper''.
::WT	dŋos	``reality''
>:ST, indirectly related to TB items:
>:Tamang-Gurung
>:Thakali ŋoh ``forehead''. The connection with Khmer thŋaːh ``forehead'' is not clear

ENTRY:4274
HEAD:yán₁ 沿
MC:Middle Chinese: jiwän 
LH:Later Han: juan ~ jon 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *lon ? or *jon ?
GLOSS:"Go along a river" [Shu],
GLOSS:"follow, imitate" [Li].
	[WFE] Etymology not clear. There are several possible etymologies, but the MC rounded element does not agree with the first two: (1) Tai: S. lianᴬ² ``imitate, follow'' (Manomaivibool 1975: 235). (2) ST: Lushai zeelᴸ < jeel ``a road or path along the side of a hill or range, to walk along'' (such a road); JP mə³¹-jan³³ ``(flow) along a cliff''. (3) Or it could be derived from {yóu₂ 由} ``go along, follow''. ({yuán₂ 㕣})
::JP	mə³¹-jan³³	``(flow) along a cliff''

ENTRY:4277
HEAD:yán₂ 炎
MC:Middle Chinese: jiäm 4 [JY]  <wow value=' LH:' color='invert' gloss='Later Han'/> jam 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *lam, prob. *liam
	[T] ONW iam
GLOSS:"To blaze, burn" [Shi].
GLOSS-NOTE:The graph 炎 had two different ancient readings, LH jam and wam {yán₃ 炎}.
	Both forms are supported by outside connections; yán₂ 炎 transcribes Indic yāma.
	The same doublet *l- ~ *w- (Tai *w-, PTB *l-) is found in the cognate {yè₆ 燁}.
	[E] ST and area word: PTB *(s-)lyam > Tamang me-lahm ``flame'' (me ``fire''), Lepcha lim ``to flame up'' ⪤ ă-lim ``flame''; JP lam³¹ ``to flash, as bright as steel'' ⪤ gə³¹-lam³¹ ``flutter'' ⪤ pə⁵⁵-lam⁵¹-laʔ⁵⁵ ``butterfly'' ⪤ pram³¹ ``flashing''; WT lčam-me-ba < lhyam ``shining, dazzling'' ⪤ pʰyam-pʰyam-pa ``glittering''; WB ə-hlyam ``coruscation of flame'' ⪤ pʰə-lam ``moth''. The first syllable in the WT pʰyi-ma-leb < pyim-a-lep ``butterfly'' may be related, hence lit. the ``glittering flat thing''.
	<> Also AA: Khmer lāma /líiəm/ ``to flare, flame'' ⪤ bhlāma /plíiəm/ ``move like a flash, immediately, next moment'' ⪤ babhlāma /pplíiəm/ ``to gleam, glitter, glisten''.
	[C] Allofams are {tán₇ 炎惔}, {tiǎn₂ 煔𤈛}, {xián₁₂ 燅}, {yè₆ 燁}. Words meaning ``flame'', ``tongue, lick'' ({tiǎn₁ 舔}) and ``sharp'' ({yǎn₄ 剡覃}) are near homophones and may derive from the same root.
::Khmer	lāma /líiəm/	``to flare, flame''
>:ST and area word:
>:PTB *lyam >
>:Tamang me-lahm ``flame''
>:Lepcha lim ``to flame up'' ⪤ ă-lim ``flame''
>:JP lam³¹ ``to flash, as bright as steel'' ⪤ gə³¹-lam³¹ ``flutter'' ⪤ pə⁵⁵-lam⁵¹-laʔ⁵⁵ ``butterfly'' ⪤ pram³¹ ``flashing''
>:WT lčam-me-ba < lhyam ``shining, dazzling'' ⪤ pʰyam-pʰyam-pa ``glittering''
>:WB ə-hlyam ``coruscation of flame'' ⪤ pʰə-lam ``moth''. The first syllable in the WT pʰyi-ma-leb < pyim-a-lep ``butterfly'' may be related, hence lit. the ``glittering flat thing''

ENTRY:4303
HEAD:yǎn₅ 偃

OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *ʔanʔ

	[WFE] ? ST: Lushai zaalᴴ < jaal ``to lie down, recline ⪤ zalʔᴸ < jalʔ/h ‘lay on the back''. The TB initial *j- is expected to correspond to MC div.
	IV (ʔjiänᴮ), not III. This casts doubt on the genetic relationship.
	On the other hand there are no syllables of the corresponding div.
	IV type in MC, hence they might have merged with div.
	III, perhaps under the influence of the similar etymon {ān₁ 安} ``press down''.

ENTRY:4343
HEAD:yǎng₂ 養
MC:Middle Chinese: jiaŋᴮ 
LH:Later Han: jɑŋᴮ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *jaŋʔ or *laŋʔ ? 
OCB:Baxter Old Chinese: *(l)jangʔ
	[T] ONW iaŋ
GLOSS:"To nourish, feed, rear" [Shi].
	[<] perhaps *laŋ + endoactive tone B derivation from {yáng₇ 揚} ``raise'' ({§4.5}).
	[E] Two genetic connections are possible: (1) OC *jaŋʔ, PTB *s-gyoŋ (HPTB: 294): WB kyoŋᴮ ``feed, tend cattle''; the vowel *o does not agree with OC, but WT skyoŋ-ba, bskyaŋs ``to guard, keep, tend'' (cattle) has the vowel *a. The TB etymon is also reflected in the ethnic name {Qiāng₁ 羌} and the clan name Jiāng 姜.
	This is the preferred affiliation because it is with a genetically related TB language, and the phonetic series implies OC *j- rather than *l-. (2) Or OC *l(j)aŋʔ <> Tai: S. liaŋᶜ² ``feed, nourish'', Ahom liŋᶜ² (Bodman 1980: 106), see also {yáng₁ 羊}.
	WT and Tai could be reconciled by assuming an earlier *lj-. {yáng₁ 羊} ``goat, sheep'' is perhaps also related.
::WT	skyoŋ-ba, bskyaŋs	``to guard, keep, tend''
>:Two genetic connections are possible:
>:OC *jaŋʔ
>:PTB *s-gyoŋ :
>:WB kyoŋᴮ ``feed, tend cattle''
>:the vowel *o does not agree with OC, but WT skyoŋ-ba, bskyaŋs ``to guard, keep, tend''  has the vowel *a. The TB etymon is also reflected in the ethnic name {Qiāng₁ 羌} and the clan name Jiāng 姜

ENTRY:4344
HEAD:yǎng₂ 養 ⪤ yàng 養
MC:Middle Chinese: jiaŋᶜ 
LH:Later Han: jɑŋᶜ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *jaŋh or *laŋh ?
GLOSS:"To keep, support" [Shu].
	[<] *laŋ + the generic tone C derivation from yǎng ({§3.5}).
	[N] In earlier times, ``to manage the support for the elderly'' was called xiáng 庠 (zjaŋ) (during the Yin dyn. acc. to SW, the Zhou dyn. acc. to Mengzi) – a PCH caus. s-prefix derivation from *laŋ ({yáng₇ 揚}).

	[D] PMin *d̯ziɔŋᴮ
GLOSS:"To itch" [Li].
	[E] ST: open vowel finals and final -ŋ do occasionally alternate within a wf ({§6.5.2}): WT g-ya-ba ``to itch'', Kachin kəja, WB yaᴮ, yaᴮ-yam ``itch'' (STC no. 451), Lushai zaᴿ < jaʔ, also WT za-ba ``to itch'' must be related; Lepcha yak ``itch'', PLB *ʔzak [Matisoff D. of Lahu: 1252], Lepcha ǰak [zyak] ``tickle'' [Bodman ICSTLL 1987: 15].

ENTRY:4350
HEAD:yāo₂ 妖
MC:Middle Chinese: ʔjäu 3 
LH:Later Han: ʔɨɑu 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *ʔau
	[T] ONW ʔau
GLOSS:"Be delicate, slender" [Shi],
GLOSS:"good-natured"  [Meng];
GLOSS:"beautiful, charming" 妖 [Zhuang] > ``remarkable, supernatural, ominous'' 妖 [Zuo] > ``inauspicious, unlucky'' 祆 [Guoyu], 訞 [Dadai Liji].
GLOSS-NOTE:``Small'' [SW] is prob. the same word.

ENTRY:4363
HEAD:yǎo₆-tiǎo 窈窕 ⪤ yǎo-jiǎo 窈糾
MC:Middle Chinese: ʔieuᴮ-gjäuᴮ 3,-kjäuᴮ 3 
LH:Later Han: ʔeuᴮ-kɨauᴮ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *ʔiûʔ-kauʔ
GLOSS:"Be elegant, beautiful" [Shi]; for the second syllable see {jiǎo₂ 姣佼}. The phonetic of jiǎo suggests that originally this syllable might have rimed with yǎo, i.e.
	OCM *kiuʔ.
	Liú Yùqìng (ZGYW 2, 2002: 156f) concludes that the term yǎo-jiǎo was originally referring to something cave-like, ``dark, deep'' [SW] of the interior of a house, then also in a metaphorical sense, finally of the beauty of a woman. The first syllable is prob. cognate to {yōu₄ 幽} ``dark''.

ENTRY:4367
HEAD:yào₄ 藥
MC:Middle Chinese: jiak 
LH:Later Han: jɑk < jɑuk 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *jauk < *r-jauk 
OCB:Baxter Old Chinese: *rawk
	[T] ONW iak
GLOSS:"To cure" [Shi],
GLOSS:"medicinal plant" [Zhouli],
GLOSS:"medicine" [Zuo].
GLOSS-NOTE:Yào is prob. cognate to {liào₃ 療樂}.
	In addition, yào (and liào) may belong to the group of wfs ``cleanse, drain, melt, shine'' mentioned under {shuò₆ 爍鑠} ``melt''.
	In fact, yào may be the same etymon as yuè 瀹 ``to drain off, clear the course (of a river), purify (the heart)'', hence 藥 ``to cure, heal'' < ``drain away, purify, cleanse''.
	On the other hand, the word may be connected with Lushai hlo ``a weed, drug, medicine''.
::Lushai	hlo	``a weed, drug, medicine''

ENTRY:4371
HEAD:yē 噎 ⪤ yì 殪

ENTRY:4372
HEAD:yě₁ 也
MC:Middle Chinese: jiaᴮ 
LH:Later Han: jaᴮ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *laʔ ?
	[T] Sin Sukchu SR je (上)
	[T] ONW ia
	A phrase or sentence final particle which occurs first late in Shījīng [Guofeng], ``a particle of noun predication'' (Pulleyblank 1995: 16), i.e. yě is used like the copula ``to be''; it replaces the early copula {wéi₂ 惟}.
	[E] Etymology not clear. The similarity with Mon ra is interesting: ra “especially at closing sentence, marking unqualified character of assertion,” perhaps originally the weak form of das ``to be'' (Shorto 1971).
	Alternatively, yě may be of ST origin, being connected with the WT suffix -la which usually marks the dative case, but is also used as a topicalizer like ni ``as for ….'' (Beyer 1992: 278).
>:Etymology not clear. The similarity with Mon ra is interesting:
>:ra “especially at closing sentence, marking unqualified character of assertion,” perhaps originally the weak form of das ``to be''

OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *laʔ
	[T] ONW ia
GLOSS:"To smelt, fuse, cast" [Meng] occurs also in Tai: S. hlɔɔᴮ
GLOSS:"cast" (metal) (Unger Hao-ku 36, 1990: 55).

ENTRY:4374
HEAD:yě₃ 野
MC:Middle Chinese: jiaᴮ 
LH:Later Han: jaᴮ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *laʔ 
OCB:Baxter Old Chinese: *ljAʔ
	[T] ONW ia
GLOSS:"Uncultivated land, grassland" 野 [Shi], 埜 [Lü] >
GLOSS:"rustic, wild" 野 [Lunyu],
GLOSS:"open country" [Chuci].
GLOSS-NOTE:GY has an additional reading: QYS źjwoᴮ, LH dźiɑʔ
GLOSS:"fields, open country", 墅
GLOSS:"field hut, detached residence, villa" [GY], ``field'' [QY ms.] (Coblin AO 1986: 107). It is not clear if this is cognate to yě.
	[E] Etymology not certain, yě may have one of two possible etymological connections. (1) ST: In Tibet and the Himalayas exists a common word *la which originally might have referred to an area far from settlements, i.e. ``wilderness'': WT la ``mountain pass, hillside, mountain slope''; SWTib.: Dzongkha, Gloskad laᴸ ``mountain''; Western Tib.: Zangskar la ``border, frontier''; Kanauri: Pat. lha, Kaike la ``mountain''; Tamang lah²¹ ``hill''.
	[E] Or (2) the word belongs to the same AA root to which also belongs {yì₃₅ 繹}: OKhmer lā [laa] ``to open, unfold, extend …'' ⪤ dalā [dlaa] ``to be open, extensive, broad'' (of space); PMonic *lah > OMon ``to extend'' > Mod. Mon ``be level, flat, extensive''.
::Kaike	la	``mountain''
>:Etymology not certain, yě may have one of two possible etymological connections.  ST:
>:In Tibet and the Himalayas exists a common word *la which originally might have referred to an area far from settlements, i.e. ``wilderness'':
>:WT la ``mountain pass, hillside, mountain slope''
>:SWTib.:
>:Dzongkha
>:Gloskad laᴸ ``mountain''
>:Western Tib.:
>:Zangskar la ``border, frontier''
>:Kanauri:
>:Pat. lha
>:Kaike la ``mountain''
>:Tamang lah²¹ ``hill''
>:Or  the word belongs to the same AA root to which also belongs {yì₃₅ 繹}:
>:OKhmer lā  ``to open, unfold, extend …'' ⪤ dalā  ``to be open, extensive, broad''
>:PMonic *lah >
>:OMon ``to extend'' >
>:Mod. Mon ``be level, flat, extensive''

ENTRY:4375
HEAD:yè₁ 夜
MC:Middle Chinese: jiaᶜ 
LH:Later Han: jaᶜ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *jah > jakh 
OCB:Baxter Old Chinese: *(l)jAks
GLOSS:"Night" [OB, Shi].
	[T] Sin Sukchu SR je (去)
	[T] ONW ia < ja
	[N] OC initial *j- is likely in the phonetic series 亦. The final OC *-k is not certain.
	In the oldest parts of Shījīng (Dàyǎ 278; 255.5, and in 124.4) the rime words had no *-k (Baxter 1992: 311f).
	In later parts it rimes with words in *-akh (OCB *-aks) (Shi 17.1; 100.3); in one older ode (Xiǎoyǎ 194.2) yè rimes with words in *-ak.
	This distribution suggests that in early Zhou times one strain of OC was lacking the *-k.
	In any case, OC often adds a final *-k to words which in TB have open vowels ({§6.1}), therefore this is the ST etymon for ``night''.
	[E] ST: PTB *ya ``night'' (STC no. 417) > Chepang yaʔ-diŋ ``night'', yoh ``yesterday'', yoh-dyah-may ``last night''; WB ñaᶜ ``evening'' < ne-ja ``sun-night'', JP naʔ⁵⁵ < nak⁵⁵ ``evening''; Dulong ɉɑʔ ``night'', Karen hja (STC p. 188). Lushai zaanᴸ ~ zanᶠ < jaŋ (?) ``night'', niᶠ-zaanᴸ < jaanh < jaans ``last night'', Areng (Khami/Kuki-Chin) jaŋ ``yesterday'' (Löffler Anthropos 55, 1960: 553); Limbu yaːn ``day'' (24 hrs) (quantifier suffix). {xī₁ 夕} is usually thought to be cognate, but TB keeps the etyma ST *rjak ``24 hrs., day, night'' and *ja ``night'' strictly separate, and there is no reason why this should not be done in OC.
::ST	*rjak	``24 hrs., day, night''
>:PTB *ya ``night''  >
>:Chepang yaʔ-diŋ ``night'', yoh ``yesterday'', yoh-dyah-may ``last night''
>:WB ñaᶜ ``evening'' < ne-ja ``sun-night''
>:JP naʔ⁵⁵ < nak⁵⁵ ``evening''
>:Dulong ɉɑʔ ``night''
>:Karen hja . Lushai zaanᴸ ~ zanᶠ < jaŋ  ``night'', niᶠ-zaanᴸ < jaanh < jaans ``last night''
>:Areng  jaŋ ``yesterday''
>:Limbu yaːn ``day''  . {xī₁ 夕} is usually thought to be cognate, but TB keeps the etyma ST *rjak ``24 hrs., day, night'' and *ja ``night'' strictly separate, and there is no reason why this should not be done in OC

	[T] Sin Sukchu SR ʂi (去)

	[T] ONW śei
	[<] iterative devoicing of *lap ({§5.2.3}), + s/h-suffix ({§4.2}), meaning successive foliages of a tree > generations.
	[E] The relationship with WT rabs ``lineage, succession of families, generation'' is not clear because the initial correspondence is unusual (OC *l = WT r).
::WT	rabs	``lineage, succession of families, generation''

	[E] ST: WT yab-pa ~ g-yab-pa < g-ʔyap ``to lock, cover over'', yab-yab-pa ``hide, conceal'' ⪤ skyob-pa, (b)skyabs ``to protect, defend, preserve'', skyob(s) ``help, assistance'', skyabs ``protection, defense''.

ENTRY:4382
HEAD:yè₆ 燁
MC:Middle Chinese: jäp 3,jiəp 
LH:Later Han: either jap or wap or both 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *lap,*wap
GLOSS:"Gleaming" [Shi].
	[E] A widely distributed phonaesthetic etymon in East and SE Asia, including AN, with the rime *-ap and initial *r-, *l-,*w-,*j- etc., often with pre-syllables (see R. Bauer LTBA 15.2: 151-184). The L-initial variant is widely encountered in the area: PTB *s-lyap (HPTB: 338), WT lhab-lhab-pa, lhab-se-lhabs ``to flutter to and fro, to glimmer, glisten'', Lepcha lyóp [ljɔːp] ``flap'', Adi lip-lop ``to flash'' [Bodman ICSTLL 1987: 10]; WB lyap-lyap ``wavingly (as flag)'' ⪤ hlyap ``lightning''; Lushai inᴸ-hlapᴴ ``to flick, flap'' (someone with cloth etc.), JP prap⁵⁵ ``a flash''. <> KT: Siam. lɛɛpᴰ²ᴸ ~ ma-lɛɛp ``to flash'' (as lightning); PHlai ɬjip⁷ ``lightning''.
	The W-initial variant also occurs in Tai: S. wɛɛpᴰ²-wapᴰ² ``glittering, flashing'' (Manomaivibool 1975: 180).
	The Tai form looks like the equivalent of a hypothetical CH compound yè-yì 燁熠 *wap-wəp.
	A Y-initial variant is common in TB: *yaːp ``wave, fan, paddle'' (HPTB: 339) > Lushai zaap, Garo tśo, Tangkhul Naga kʰəyap ``fan'', WB yap; WT (g-)yab-mo ``the act of fanning'' ⪤ g-yob-pa ``tomove about, swing, brandish''.
	A variant is {yì₂₇ 熠} ``be flashing''; perhaps related to ``butterfly'' {hú₆-dié 胡蝶}.
	This etymon perhaps cognate to {yán₂ 炎} ~ {yán₃ 炎} where we also find the *w- ~ *l- doublets.
::WT	(g-)yab-mo	``the act of fanning''
>:A widely distributed phonaesthetic etymon in East and SE Asia, including AN, with the rime *-ap and initial *r-, *l-,*w-,*j- etc., often with pre-syllables . The L-initial variant is widely encountered in the area:
>:PTB *s-lyap
>:WT lhab-lhab-pa, lhab-se-lhabs ``to flutter to and fro, to glimmer, glisten''
>:Lepcha lyóp  ``flap''
>:Adi lip-lop ``to flash''
>:WB lyap-lyap ``wavingly '' ⪤ hlyap ``lightning''
>:Lushai inᴸ-hlapᴴ ``to flick, flap''
>:JP prap⁵⁵ ``a flash''. < > KT:
>:Siam. lɛɛpᴰ²ᴸ ~ ma-lɛɛp ``to flash''
>:PHlai ɬjip⁷ ``lightning''

ENTRY:4384
HEAD:yè₈ 業
MC:Middle Chinese: ŋjɐp 
LH:Later Han: ŋɨɑp 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *ŋap
GLOSS:"Be awe-inspiring, terrifying, terrific" [Shi] belongs to the wf {yán₈ 巖}.

ENTRY:4385
HEAD:yī₁ 一
MC:Middle Chinese: ʔjet 
LH:Later Han: ʔit 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *ʔit
GLOSS:"Be one, single, whole" [OB, Shi].
	[T] Sin S. SR ʔi (入)
	[T] MGZY Yi (入) [ʔji]
	[T] MTang ʔir, ONW ʔiit.
	[D] M-Xiàmén lit. itᴰ¹
	[D] Fúzhōu eiʔᴰ¹
	[D] K-Méixiàn jitᴰ¹
	[D] Y-Guǎngzhōu jatᴰ¹
	[E] ST: PTB *ʔit (STC: 94): Chepang yat ``one'', Kanauri ʔit ``one'', and WB ac ``unit, one'' (HST 114), Lushai zetᴴ ``first, previous''. This word is found only at the periphery of the ST area and must therefore be old.
	<> Tai ʔet occurs only in compounds and is clearly a CH loan, the native Tai word for ``one'' is nɨŋᴬ²/ᴮ¹.
::Lushai	zetᴴ	``first, previous''
>:PTB *ʔit :
>:Chepang yat ``one''
>:Kanauri ʔit ``one'', and WB ac ``unit, one''
>:Lushai zetᴴ ``first, previous''. This word is found only at the periphery of the ST area and must therefore be old

ENTRY:4386
HEAD:yī₂ 伊
MC:Middle Chinese: ʔi 4 
LH:Later Han: ʔi 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *ʔi
GLOSS:"This" [Shi], starting in the 4th ~ 5th cent. AD
GLOSS:"he, she, it", survives as a 3rd person pron. in Wú dialects (Norman 1988: 118).
	[T] Sin Sukchu SR ʔi (平)
	[T] MGZY Yi (平) [ʔji]
	[T] STCA ʔɨ, ONW ʔii
	[E] ST: Lushai ʔiᴸ ``this, that'', Chepang ʔiʔ ``he'', WB i ``this''. Perh. this is a widespread sound-symbolic area word, note the AA demonstrative *i / e [Pinnow 1965: 32].
::WB	i	``this''
>:Lushai ʔiᴸ ``this, that''
>:Chepang ʔiʔ ``he''
>:WB i ``this''. Perh. this is a widespread sound-symbolic area word, note the AA demonstrative *i / e

ENTRY:4387
HEAD:yī₃ 衣
MC:Middle Chinese: ʔjei 
LH:Later Han: ʔɨi 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *ʔəi ? 
OCB:Baxter Old Chinese: *ʔjəj
GLOSS:"Garment, clothes" [Shi].
	[T] Sin Sukchu SR ʔi (平)
	[T] MGZY ʔi (平) [ʔi]
	[T] ONW ʔi
	[D] PMin *ʔəi ``afterbirth'' is the analog to a MC div. I  ʔậi
::PMin	*ʔəi	``afterbirth''

ENTRY:4388
HEAD:yī₃ 衣 ⪤ yì 衣
MC:Middle Chinese: ʔjəiᶜ 
LH:Later Han: ʔɨiᶜ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *ʔəih 
OCB:Baxter Old Chinese: *ʔjəjs
GLOSS:"To wear" [Shi].
	[<] exoactive of yī 衣 ({§4.3.2}).
	[N] This character writes on occasion the dynastic name Yīn 殷 LH ʔɨn (OCB *ʔjən) which points therefore to denasalization of a final consonant that seems to have originated in an early dialect such as Shandong (Baxter 1992: 295). Consequently, the family name Yī  may be derived from an original Yīn.
	[E] Yī ``clothes'' may belong to a wf whose basic meaning is ``to envelop, conceal'' and hence is cognate to {yī₅ 翳}, {yǐn 隱} (Karlgren 1933: 28; Lau 1999: 69).
	Prob.
	ST: PTB *wit ⪤ *w(y)at ``wear clothes'' [HPTB: 333, 508] > PLB *wit ~ *ʔwit ``wear clothes, cause to wear'' [Matisoff 2002 no. 181]: open vowel forms of etyma alternate often with closed syllables in ST languages ({§6.1}); ST medial w often disappears in CH ({§10.2.1}), thus the ST proto-form might have been *ʔwəi(k/t).
::PLB	*wit ~ *ʔwit	``wear clothes, cause to wear''
>:Yī ``clothes'' may belong to a wf whose basic meaning is ``to envelop, conceal'' and hence is cognate to {yī₅ 翳}, {yǐn 隱}

ENTRY:4397
HEAD:yí₂ 貽詒
MC:Middle Chinese: jiɨ 
LH:Later Han: jə 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *lə
	[T] ONW iə
GLOSS:"To transmit, bequeath, hand down, give" [Shi].
GLOSS-NOTE:This word appears to form an introvert - extrovert pair with {yǐ₂ 以}
GLOSS:"take", like
GLOSS:"buy - sell", ``borrow - lend''; however, the extrovert form ought to have tone C. Here, yí ``give'' appears to be primary while yǐ  would be a tone B derivation.
	Because of what would be an unusual morphology, the two are prob. not cognate after all.

ENTRY:4398
HEAD:yí₂ 貽詒 ⪤ sì 嗣

LH:Later Han: ziəᶜ

	[E] ST: Lushai tʰlaʔᴸ < tʰlaʔ/h < s-laʔ/h (?) ``descendant, offspring, posterity'' (CVST 3: 5), WT slas ``retinue, train, attendants'' ⪤ slar < sla-ru ``afterwards, hereafter, again'', the WT root *sla means ``late, later, after'' (Geilich 1994: 48).
::WT	slas	``retinue, train, attendants''

ENTRY:4399

ENTRY:4400
HEAD:yí₂ 貽詒 ⪤ yìng 賸
MC:Middle Chinese: jiəŋᶜ 
LH:Later Han: ʔɨŋᶜ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *ləŋh
GLOSS:"To make a present, exchange presents, to present (someone) to serve, concubine" [BI];
GLOSS:"concubine" 媵 [Zuo].
	[<] terminative of yí 貽詒 *lə ({§6.5.1}) + exoactive ({§4.3}). A gloss for this word includes ``a girl who follows the principal wife to her husband and becomes his concubine'' (GSR 893k); this implies a goal with finality, hence perhaps the terminative morpheme.

ENTRY:4401
HEAD:yí₃ 夷
MC:Middle Chinese: ji 
LH:Later Han: ji 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *l(ə)i 
OCB:Baxter Old Chinese: ljəj
	[T] ONW i < ji
	The name of non-Chinese tribes, prob.
	Austroasiatic, to the east and south-east of the central plain (Shandong, Huái River basin), since the Spring and Autumn period also a general word for ``barbarian'' (Pulleyblank 1983: 440).
	Since the ancient Yuè (= Viet) word for ``sea'' is said to have been yí [Yuèjuèshū 3.8], the people's name might have originated as referring to people living by the sea (as can be observed elsewhere, e.g. the ``Morini'' in Caesar's Gaul, or ``Pomerania'' along the Baltic coast in Poland, cf. Lat. mare, Russian morie ``sea'').
	The Yuè word yí ``sea'' can be connected with MK *d[n]liʔ ``large river, sea'' (Shorto 2006 #210): Khmer dhle /tlé/  ``expanse of water'' ⪤ OKhmer danle(y) /dənlee/ ``lake, sea''. <> Miao languages have forms like tḷi, tḷe ``river'' which, however, can instead (or also) be associated with {xī₁₀ 溪}.
::OKhmer	danle(y) /dənlee/	``lake, sea''

ENTRY:4402
HEAD:yí₄ 夷
MC:Middle Chinese: ji 
LH:Later Han: ji 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *l(ə)i 
OCB:Baxter Old Chinese: ljəj
GLOSS:"Be level" (road), (make level:)
GLOSS:"pacify, at ease" [Shi];
GLOSS:"rule, norm" [BI, Shi] > ``normally'' 彝 [BI].
GLOSS-NOTE:This word
GLOSS:"level" is unrelated to {yì₉ 易}
GLOSS:"easy".

ENTRY:4403
HEAD:yí₄ 夷 ⪤ sì 肆
MC:Middle Chinese: siᶜ 
LH:Later Han: siᶜ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *sih < *slih ?
GLOSS:"To be lax" [Shu],
GLOSS:"unrestrained" [Lun] > caus.
GLOSS:"to relax, pardon" [Shu].
	[<] caus. of yí  夷 (ji) *li ``easy'' ({§5.2.2}; {§4.3}). The meaning may have evolved under the influence of shè 舍 (under {shě₂ 舍捨}); at any rate shě demonstrates semantic parallelism between ``easy, relax'' and ``let go''.
	[C] This is prob. the same etymon as {yí₃ 夷侇} ``set out, spread''.

ENTRY:4404
HEAD:yí₅ 夷侇

ENTRY:4405
HEAD:yí₅ 夷侇 ⪤ shī 尸
MC:Middle Chinese: śi 
LH:Later Han: śi 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *lhi
	[T] ONW śi
GLOSS:"To spread out, lie down flat" (in order to sleep) [Lun] (Geilich 1994: 277);
GLOSS:"motionless, to set forth" (sacrificial dishes) [Shi] >
GLOSS:"personator of a dead ancestor" [Shi] > ``corpse'' (Carr, CAAAL 24, 1985: 1ƒƒ).
	[N] In Old Korean 尸 is used to transcribe what is prob. a lateral like l (Vovin 1999).
	[E] The common assumption that shī is cognate to {sǐ 死} (siᴮ) LH siᴮ, *siʔ ``to die'' must be rejected because MC initial ś- (< *lh-, *nh-, *hj-) never derives from an *s-, except when they share an initial *l or *n (such a case is sì below). Perh. cognate to {shēn₂ 身} ``body'' (Geilich 1994: 277).
::LH	siᴮ, *siʔ	``to die''
>:The common assumption that shī is cognate to {sǐ 死}  LH siᴮ, *siʔ ``to die'' must be rejected because MC initial ś-  never derives from an *s-, except when they share an initial *l or *n . Perh. cognate to {shēn₂ 身} ``body''

HEAD:yí₈ 移

This etymon is distinct from {yí₉ 移} as Tiddim Chin shows.
	[WFE] Shorto 1972 relates the TB items to PMK *kla(a)y > Mon klai ``translate'', Khmer khlaːy ``change, dissolve''. ⇒ PTai *klaiᴬ¹ ``to pass by, change into''. The connection with {gǎi 改} ``change'' if any is not clear.

ENTRY:4416

ENTRY:4422

ENTRY:4425

	[E] ST *lə: Lushai laᴸ / laak < laah ``to take, get'', Tiddim laaᴿ / laakᴿ < laaʔ / laak ``to take'', Newari laa- (Unger; Geilich 1994: 137). But the TB items have also been associated with CH {yǔ₉ 與} ``give''.
	Prob. related to {shì₉ 式} ``use''; a possible derivation may be {yì₁ 弋}; see also {yí₂ 貽詒}.

ENTRY:4430
HEAD:yǐ₆ 蟻 ~ yǐ 螘

LH:Later Han: ŋɨiᴮ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *ŋəiʔ
GLOSS:"Ant" [Chuci], a phonological variant of the above (Baxter 1992: 417; {§11.1.2}).
	[E] ST: KN-Lai hŋeʔr-tee ``ant'' (tee ``small''). This implies that both forms show the change of ST *-r > OC *-i ({§7.7.4}).
	Folk etymology derives yí 蟻 from 義 ``orderly''.
>:KN-Lai hŋeʔr-tee ``ant'' . This implies that both forms show the change of ST *-r >
>:OC *-i

ENTRY:4431
HEAD:yì₁ 弋
MC:Middle Chinese: jiək 
LH:Later Han: jək 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *lək
	(``To take / seize birds'':) ``to shoot (birds) with stringed arrow'' [Shi], (``taker / seizer'' of birds etc.:) ``bird of pray'' [Dadai Liji]. The word is supposed to mean ``take'' in a Shūjīng passage which would be the obvious semantic communality with ``arrow'' and ``eagle''.
	It may then be a derivation from {yǐ₂ 以} ``take''.
	[E] If this etymology holds, yì would not be related to WT mda’ etc. (mentioned under {shí₉ 射} ``shoot''). However, it could still be related to WT glag ``eagle, vulture'' (CVST 3: 8).
::WT	glag	``eagle, vulture''
>:If this etymology holds, yì would not be related to WT mda’ etc. . However, it could still be related to WT glag ``eagle, vulture''

ENTRY:4432
HEAD:yì₂ 艾刈
MC:Middle Chinese: ŋjɐiᶜ 
LH:Later Han: ŋɨɑs 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *ŋa(t)s
GLOSS:"To mow, cut, reap" 艾刈 [Shi];
GLOSS:"regulate, govern, orderly" 艾 [Shi].
	[E] ST: WT rŋa-ba, brŋas ``to mow, cut, reap'', West Tib. col. rŋab-pa (HST: 111). The origin of the meanings ``regulate'' is ambiguous, it could be derived from ``to cut'' (> ``trim'' etc.?), or it could be derived from {yù₁₆ 禦}.
>:WT rŋa-ba, brŋas ``to mow, cut, reap''
>:West Tib. col. rŋab-pa . The origin of the meanings ``regulate'' is ambiguous, it could be derived from ``to cut'' , or it could be derived from {yù₁₆ 禦}

ENTRY:4434
HEAD:yì₄ 腋掖亦
MC:Middle Chinese: jiäk 
LH:Later Han: jak 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *jak
GLOSS:"Armpit" 亦 [OB], 腋 [Zhuang], 掖 [Li],
GLOSS:"lift under the arms" [Zuo].
	[E] ST and area word: Mru yak ``armpit'' (Löffler 1966: 119), Lushai zakᴸ < jak ``armpit''; Newari jaːk-wa ``armpit'', Lepcha yak ``tickle'' (L. Hayes LTBA 15.2, 1992: 186); JR təjăk ``hand''; PTB *(g-)yak > WB gyak-kali ``armpit'' (STC: 167; 170), PLB *ʔjak ``tickle'', and *ʔgjak ``cubit'' (i.e. ``arm''). STC: 34 interprets the WB form as ``arm'' (PTB *(g-)yak); Shī Xiàngdōng (2000: 127) related this word to PTB *lak ``hand, arm''.
	<> PKS *kʰjaːk⁷ ``armpit'' (Thurgood), *h-jakᴰ (Edmondson / Yang 1988).
	Tai: S. rakᴰ² ``the arm-pits'' is perhaps connected (Manomaivibool 1975: 252).
	The syn. {gē₄ 胳} may represent a different root.
::PKS	*kʰjaːk⁷	``armpit''
>:ST and area word:
>:Mru yak ``armpit''
>:Lushai zakᴸ < jak ``armpit''
>:Newari jaːk-wa ``armpit''
>:Lepcha yak ``tickle''
>:JR təjăk ``hand''
>:PTB *yak >
>:WB gyak-kali ``armpit''
>:PLB *ʔjak ``tickle'', and *ʔgjak ``cubit'' . STC:
>:34 interprets the WB form as ``arm'' yak)
>:Shī Xiàngdōng  related this word to PTB *lak ``hand, arm''

ENTRY:4436

GLOSS:"to serve" [Meng],
GLOSS:"to toil" [Zhuang], ``affair, matter'' [Guoyu]; > ``to function as, to be'' [Guoyu].
GLOSS-NOTE:Often words meaning
GLOSS:"do, make" also develop the meaning
GLOSS:"function as, act as, to be", see {wéi₃ 為}, {zuò₃ 作}.
	[T] Sin Sukchu SR ŋyj (入)
	[T] MGZY ywi (入) [yi]
	[E] The word could be derived from wéi 為 *wai ``to do'' + k-extension ({§6.1}) and have spread to neighboring SEAsian languages because Chinese and other populations were required by CH governments to perform military or other service yì 役: MK and Tai languages: Viet. việc, Muong [wiək] ``work, job'' (Pulleyblank JCL 22.1, 1994: 83). <> Tai: Saek viakᴰ²ᴸ ``work'', S. wiek³ [Maspero 1912: 73]. Perh.
	LB forms like Lahu vêʔ < s-wat ``work, toil, a job'' (archaic) may also be connected (Benedict LTBA 14.2, 1991: 149).
::Lahu	vêʔ < s-wat	``work, toil, a job''

>:MK and Tai languages:
>:Viet. việc
>:Muong  ``work, job'' . < > Tai:
>:Saek viakᴰ²ᴸ ``work''
>:S. wiek³ . Perh

ENTRY:4438
HEAD:yì₈ 邑
MC:Middle Chinese: ʔjəp 
LH:Later Han: ʔip 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *ʔəp 
OCB:Baxter Old Chinese: *ʔ(r)jup
GLOSS:"Settlement, town" [OB, BI, Shi],
GLOSS:"to take up residence" [Shi]; a general term for a place where people dwell, i.e. no implied reference to wall, market, administrative function and the like.
	[E] Etymology not certain, but prob. ST and related to the root *ʔip ``shelter'' which is cited under {qì₇ 葺} ``thatch'' with which yì is prob. related.
	Alternatively, yì could be connected with PTB *ʔim ``house as a home'': Magar im ~ jum, WB im, Lushai ʔinᴿ < ʔinʔ ``dwelling house, home'', TGTM *ᴮdim, Kaike jim, WT kʰyim ``h.i.ouse;, dwelling place, home, residence''.
::WT	kʰyim	``h.i.ouse;, dwelling place, home, residence''
>:Etymology not certain, but prob. ST and related to the root *ʔip ``shelter'' which is cited under {qì₇ 葺} ``thatch'' with which yì is prob. related

ENTRY:4439
HEAD:yì₉ 易
MC:Middle Chinese: jieᶜ 
LH:Later Han: jeᶜ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *lekh 
OCB:Baxter Old Chinese: *ljeks
GLOSS:"Be easy, at ease, neglect" [Shi].
GLOSS-NOTE:易 was borrowed to write {yì₆ 役} (jiwäk) LH wiek in some pre-Han texts as if there might still have been a *w  element in the initial as in the TB cognate.
	[T] Sin Sukchu SR i (去)
	[T] MGZY yi (去) [ji]
	[T] Sui-Tang i, ONW ie
	[E] ST: PTB *lway ``easy'' (STC no. 302): WB lwai ``easy, yielding'', JP loi³¹ ``easy''; WT legs ``good, happy, comfortable'' is phonologically / morphologically identical with OC; note also WT yag-po ~ ’ǰag-po ``good'' (STC: 54). This word is sometimes thought to be related to yì 易 ``change'' (under {yí₈ 移}), i.e. < ``changeable'' (so Karlgren 1956: 12), but the TB cognates show that these are different etyma.
::WT	yag-po ~ ’ǰag-po	``good''
>:PTB *lway ``easy'' :
>:WB lwai ``easy, yielding''
>:JP loi³¹ ``easy''
>:WT legs ``good, happy, comfortable'' is phonologically / morphologically identical with OC
>:note also WT yag-po ~ ’ǰag-po ``good'' . This word is sometimes thought to be related to yì 易 ``change'' , i.e. < ``changeable'' , but the TB cognates show that these are different etyma

ENTRY:4449

ENTRY:4450

ENTRY:4462
HEAD:yì₂₈ 藝
MC:Middle Chinese: ŋjiäiᶜ 4 
LH:Later Han: ŋias 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *ŋets 
OCB:Baxter Old Chinese: *ŋJets
	(``To establish'':) ``to plant, cultivate'' (a crop, land) 埶蓺[Shi], 藝 [Shu] > ``accomplished, skill'' 藝 [Shu], ``art, method, rule, regular'' 藝 [Zuo], 帠 [Zhuang].
	[T] Sin Sukchu SR i (去)
	[T] MGZY yi (去) [ji]
	[T] ONW ŋiei,
	[E] CH ⇒ Tai: S. kra⁴-net⁴ ``tactics, methods, strategy''.
	[WFE] ST: The basic meaning of the ST root is ``certain, firm, make firm > establish'': PTB *ŋeis > WT ŋes-pa ``certain, true, firm'', Lushai ŋeiᴸ < ŋeih < ŋes ``really, truly, verily'', Tiddim ŋɛːiᶠ < ŋɛːih < ŋeːis ``certainly, be sure''; Limbu nɛma < nɛss- ``to lie'' (including of geographical features, fields etc.) The CH meaning ``to cultivate'' is therefore derived.
::Limbu	nɛma < nɛss-	``to lie''
>:CH ⇒ Tai:
>:S. kra⁴-net⁴ ``tactics, methods, strategy''

ENTRY:4463
HEAD:yì₂₈ 藝 ⪤ shè 設
MC:Middle Chinese: śjät 
LH:Later Han: śat 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *nhet < *ŋhet ? > nhets 
OCB:Baxter Old Chinese: *h(l)jet
	[T] ONW śat
GLOSS:"To set up, establish" [Shi].
GLOSS-NOTE:The OC initial is assumed on the basis of its relationship with yì 藝.
	MC śj- from *hŋi/e- via *hńi- is a regular development.
	[<] valence increase devoicing of yì 藝 ({§5.2.2}).
	[E] ST: Lushai ŋhetᴸ / ŋheʔᴸ < ŋhets ``be firm, establish'' ⪤ ŋheetᶠ  intr. ``to settle or get firm'' (as earth, cooked rice). It is not clear if or how WT gñod ``strength, durability'' (< g-nyot or g-ŋyot ?) may be related.
::WT	gñod	``strength, durability''
>:Lushai ŋhetᴸ / ŋheʔᴸ < ŋhets ``be firm, establish'' ⪤ ŋheetᶠ  intr. ``to settle or get firm'' . It is not clear if or how WT gñod ``strength, durability''  may be related

ENTRY:4465
HEAD:yì₂₉ 豙
MC:Middle Chinese: ŋjeiᶜ 
LH:Later Han: ŋɨs or ŋɨiᶜ ? 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *ŋəs ? or *ŋəih (< *ŋəls) ?
GLOSS:"Enraged boar" 豙 [SW] >
GLOSS:"bold, resolute" 毅 [Shu], note the Lushai parallel for this semantic extension.
	[T] Sin Sukchu SR i (去)
	[T] MGZY ngi (去) [ŋi]
	[E] ST: KN: Lushai (saᴸ-)ŋhalᴸ < ŋhalh < ŋhals ``wild pig'' ⪤ ŋhalᴿ < ŋhalʔ ``ill-behaved, unruly, over-bold''; Paangkhua maŋàl ~ raŋàl ``wild boar'', Tiddim Chin ŋalᶠ < ŋalh < ŋals ``wild pig''.
::Chin	ŋalᶠ < ŋalh < ŋals	``wild pig''
>:KN:
>:Lushai ŋhalᴸ < ŋhalh < ŋhals ``wild pig'' ⪤ ŋhalᴿ < ŋhalʔ ``ill-behaved, unruly, over-bold''

ENTRY:4472
HEAD:yì₃₅ 繹 ⪤ shì 釋
MC:Middle Chinese: śjäk

OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *lhak
GLOSS:"Unloose" [Yili],
GLOSS:"dissolve" [Li],

ENTRY:4473
HEAD:yì₃₅ 繹 ⪤ shè 赦
MC:Middle Chinese: śjaᶜ 
LH:Later Han: śaᶜ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *lhakh
GLOSS:"Let go" [Shi],
GLOSS:"let off, liberate" [Zuo],
GLOSS:"pardon" [Shu] (paronym of shè 舍 under {shě₂ 舍捨}). The phonetic element implies an OC final *-kh, thus the word is formally different from the homonym shè 舍 (under {shě₂ 舍捨}).
	[<] exoactive (caus.) of shì 釋 *lhak ({§4.4}).

ENTRY:4474
HEAD:yì₃₅ 繹 ⪤ cì 赤
MC:Middle Chinese: tsʰjäk 
LH:Later Han: tsʰiak 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *s-lhak ?
GLOSS:"To expel" [Zhouli], lit.
GLOSS:"cause to let go, make go away".
	[<] caus. of shè 赦 *lhakh ({§5.2.2}).
	Three different valence-increasing morphemes are added to the root *lak: (1) causative devoicing *lhak, (2) final s/h: *lhakh, (3) s-prefix: *s-lhak.
	A similar profusion of forms is seen in the wf {yù₂₅ 豫}.
	[E] Apparently this wf has expanded as a result of convergence with several paronyms, i.e. nearly homophonous synonyms which feel somehow related: {shě₂ 舍捨} *lhaʔ ``let go > pardon''; (2) *la {yù₈ 悆譽豫} ``happy''; (3) *la {xù₂ 序敘緒} ``a line, succession''. A further derivation from the same AA root may be {yě₃ 野}.
	Sagart (in Ancestry of the CH Lg. 1995: 369) considers {shí₉ 射} ``shoot'' to belong to this group.
	This root is possibly shared with MK: OKhmer lā [laa] ``to open, unfold, extend …'' ⪤ dalā [dlaa] ``to be open, extensive, broad'' (of space); PMonic *lah > OMon ``to extend''. CH has added a final *-k ({§6.1}).
::OKhmer	lā [laa]	``to open, unfold, extend …''
>:Apparently this wf has expanded as a result of convergence with several paronyms, i.e. nearly homophonous synonyms which feel somehow related:
>:{shě₂ 舍捨} *lhaʔ ``let go > pardon''
>:*la {yù₈ 悆譽豫} ``happy''
>:*la {xù₂ 序敘緒} ``a line, succession''. A further derivation from the same AA root may be {yě₃ 野}

ENTRY:4480
HEAD:yīn₁ 因
MC:Middle Chinese: ʔjien 4 
LH:Later Han: ʔin 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *ʔin
GLOSS:"Rely on, depend on, follow, therefore" [BI, Shi].
	[T] Sin Sukchu SR ʔin (平)
	[T] MGZY Yin (平) [ʔjin]
	[T] ONW ʔiin
	[N] This is prob. the s. w. as yīn 茵 (ʔjien) ``floor-mat'' [Shi] (Karlgren GSR 370a). Perh. the homophone yīn 姻 *ʔin ``relative by marriage'' [Shi] is the s. w., lit. ``dependent(s)''. {yī₄ 依} could be an allofam (Pulleyblank in Rosemont 1991: 32), but the vowels do not agree.

ENTRY:4483
HEAD:yīn₄ 湮堙闉
MC:Middle Chinese: ʔjien 4 
LH:Later Han: ʔin 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *ʔin
GLOSS:"To dam up, obstruct" (floods) 陻 [Shu];

ENTRY:4484
HEAD:yīn₅ 陰
MC:Middle Chinese: ʔjəm 
LH:Later Han: ʔim 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *ʔəm 
OCB:Baxter Old Chinese: *ʔ(r)jum
	[T] ONW ʔim
GLOSS:"Overcast, cloudy, dark" [BI, Shi].
	[WFE] ST: WB ʔuṁᶜ ``overcast, cloudy''; Adi muk-jum ``shade'', Lepcha so’yŭm ``shade''. Different TB and foreign etyma with the sound-symbolic final -m for ``dark'' have been associated with yīn, although none seem to be cognate (see also {tǎn₅ 黮}): (1) PL *c-dim¹, WB tim ``cloud''. (2) Bodman (1980: 87) suggests PTB *rum ~ *rim (STC no. 401) > WT rum ``darkness, obscurity'', JP rim³¹ ``be dusk, dark'' ⪤ n³³-rim³³ ``evening''. (3) Lushai hlimᴸ ``shadow, shade, be shady''. (4) Tai: S. klumᶜ² ``dark, cloudy''.
	Wáng Lì (1982: 602) considers yǐn 隱 (ʔjənᴮ) LH ʔɨnᴮ ``conceal'' to be related (under {yī₅ 翳}), but the difference in final nasals remains unexplained.
	[C] A probable allofam is {àn₃ 黯}. A derivation is perhaps {qīn₃ 衾} ``a blanket''.
::LH	ʔɨnᴮ	``conceal''

ENTRY:4485
HEAD:yīn₅ 陰 ⪤ yìn 陰蔭

OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *ʔəms
GLOSS:"To shelter" 陰 [Shi],
GLOSS:"shade" 蔭 [Zuo].
	[<] exoactive of yīn 陰 *ʔəm ``cause to cover'' ({§4.3.2}).

ENTRY:4486
HEAD:yín₁ 冘
MC:Middle Chinese: jiəm 
LH:Later Han: jim 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *ləm
GLOSS:"To walk" [SW, Hanshu].
	[E] ST: The basic meaning of the PTB root *lam ``to trample'' raises the possibility that this is its OC cognate: Tiddim Chin laamᴹ / laamᶠ ``to dance'' ⪤ lamᴿ ``way, road'', Lai laam / laʔm ``to trample, dance''; WT ’čʰam-pa < ɴ-lhyam ``to dance'' ⪤ lam ``path, road''. The latter ``path, road'' is derivable from the meaning ``to trample''.
::Lai	laam / laʔm	``to trample, dance''
>:The basic meaning of the PTB root *lam ``to trample'' raises the possibility that this is its OC cognate:
>:Tiddim Chin laamᴹ / laamᶠ ``to dance'' ⪤ lamᴿ ``way, road''
>:Lai laam / laʔm ``to trample, dance''
>:WT ’čʰam-pa < ɴ-lhyam ``to dance'' ⪤ lam ``path, road''. The latter ``path, road'' is derivable from the meaning ``to trample''

ENTRY:4490

ENTRY:4491
HEAD:yǐn₂ 引
MC:Middle Chinese: jienᴮ 
LH:Later Han: jinᴮ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *linʔ ?
GLOSS:"Pull, draw" [Zuo] >
GLOSS:"draw the bow" [Meng] >
GLOSS:"to pull, lead on, encourage, prolong" [Shi] > ``stretch'' [Lunyu].
	[T] Sin Sukchu SR in (上)
	[T] MGZY yin (上) [jin]
	[T] ONW in
	[E] The word yǐn is sometimes compared with WB ə-hrañ ``length'' (recently Pān 2000: 73), WT riŋ ``long'', but the initials do not agree.
	[WFE] ? ST: Perh. related to Lushai ʔinᴴ ``to drink, imbibe'', Kukish im ``drink'' (Löffler 1966: 141) (Lushai has on occasion final -n for TB -m). Alternative connection: PTB *am (STC no. 481) > Nung am ``eat'', Dhimal am ``drink'' (STC p. 143).
	Bodman (1980: 60) suggests also a possible link with {kǎn₆ 顑} and WT skyem-pa ``be thirsty'' (resp.) ⪤ skyems ``thirst, a drink'' (respect expression).
	Note also {lín₆ □} ``to drink'', and the Hlai form ʔjoːm² ``to swallow'' (Matisoff in Edmondson 1988: 298).
	A final -m in words with these meanings is natural sound symbolism.
::Hlai	form ʔjoːm²	``to swallow''
>:The word yǐn is sometimes compared with WB ə-hrañ ``length''
>:WT riŋ ``long'', but the initials do not agree

ENTRY:4497

ENTRY:4498
HEAD:yǐn₄ 螾蚓
MC:Middle Chinese: jienᴮ 
LH:Later Han: jɨnᴮ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *lə/inʔ or *jə/inʔ
	[D] Mǐn *unᴮ
GLOSS:"Earthworm" 螾 [Xun], 蚓 [Meng].
GLOSS-NOTE:The Mǐn form derives from an earlier rime *-ən    (螾); the following bisyllabic variants point to an OC rime *-in (蚓): qiū-yǐn 蚯蚓 (kʰjəu-) [Liji, Yuè-lìng] = qǐn-yǐn 螼蚓 (kʰjienᴮ 4-) [EY] = qǐn-tiǎn 蜸蚕 (kʰienᴮ-tʰienᴮ) [EY] (Bodman 1980: 77).
	[E] Tai and TB words look similar and are sometimes considered related, but the initials are difficult to reconcile: Tai: S. dɨanᴬ¹ < *ʔdl/r- ``earthworm'' (Li 1976: 45). STC (p. 37 n. 121; p. 171 n. 457; also HPTB: 78) relates yǐn to PTB *zril ~ *zrin > WT srin ``worm'', Kuki-Chin *til (CVST 2: 160).
	Theoretically, the MC form could derive from a PCH *r-jil > jil ({§9.2.1}).
>:Tai and TB words look similar and are sometimes considered related, but the initials are difficult to reconcile:
>:Tai:
>:S. dɨanᴬ¹ < *ʔdl/r- ``earthworm'' . STC  relates yǐn to PTB *zril ~ *zrin >
>:WT srin ``worm''
>:Kuki-Chin *til

ENTRY:4504
HEAD:yīng₁ 英
MC:Middle Chinese: ʔjɐŋ 
LH:Later Han: ʔɨaŋ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *ʔ-aŋ ? 
OCB:Baxter Old Chinese: *ʔrjaŋ
GLOSS:"Brilliant" >
GLOSS:"ornament; flower, blossom" [Shi].
	[T] Sin Sukchu SR ʔiŋ (平)
	[T] MGZY 'ing (平) [ʔiŋ]
	[T] ONW ʔeŋ (ʔ%ŋ?)
	[E] Etymology not certain. Most likely is a ST connection: Lushai aaŋᴴ / aanᴸ ``to open (mouth), gape with open mouth'' ⪤ aanᴸ tr. ``to open the mouth to receive food, to open to'' (as flowers to the sun, dew etc.); hence yīng may derive from the notion of an open flower.
	Alternatively, note an AA word: PSBahn. *ʔaːŋ ``bright light'', Bahn. ʔaːŋ ``shine''.
	Or Lushai eeŋᴿ ``light'' n. ⪤ eeŋᴿ / eenᴸ ``to shine, give light, bright, brilliant''.
	[C] Perh. related to {yǐng₁ 影} ``shadow''.
::Lushai	eeŋᴿ	``light''
>:Etymology not certain. Most likely is a ST connection:
>:Lushai aaŋᴴ / aanᴸ ``to open , gape with open mouth'' ⪤ aanᴸ tr. ``to open the mouth to receive food, to open to''
>:hence yīng may derive from the notion of an open flower

ENTRY:4505
HEAD:yīng₂ 鷹
MC:Middle Chinese: ʔjəŋ 
LH:Later Han: ʔɨŋ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *ʔəŋ
	[T] ONW ʔiŋ
GLOSS:"Eagle, falcon" [Shi].
	[E] ST: This etymon agrees phonologically with WT skyiŋ-ser ``eagle, vulture'' (Benedict MKS 18-19, 1992: 8), if one assumes derivation from *s-ʔyiŋ. Alternatively, in spite of the difference in the initials, yīng is widely held to be related to a ubiquitous area word: PMK *knleeŋ ``hawk'' or *k(a)laaŋ ``bird of prey, hawk, eagle'' [Diffloth 1980] > Khm klɛŋ [Haudricourt 1950: 566], PMonic *liŋ-liəŋ ``hawk'' (in Nyah-Kur), Mon kəniə̯ŋ ``kite'' [Diffloth 1984: 69]. PTB *g-laŋ (STC no. 333) > WB laŋᴮ-taᶜ ``vulture'', Kachin laŋ ``bird of the falcon family''; Garo do-reŋ ``falcon, kite'', Bodo dau-laŋ-a ``eagle'', Dimasa dau-liŋ ``kite'' (HST: 76) (do ~ dau ``bird'').
	PMY *klâŋ² (Downer 1982).
	The initial l- in these languages is difficult to reconcile with OC, see {§5.11}.
::Dimasa	dau-liŋ	``kite''
>:This etymon agrees phonologically with WT skyiŋ-ser ``eagle, vulture'' , if one assumes derivation from *s-ʔyiŋ. Alternatively, in spite of the difference in the initials, yīng is widely held to be related to a ubiquitous area word:
>:PMK *knleeŋ ``hawk'' or *klaaŋ ``bird of prey, hawk, eagle''  >
>:Khm klɛŋ
>:PMonic *liŋ-liəŋ ``hawk''
>:Mon kəniə̯ŋ ``kite'' . PTB *g-laŋ  >
>:WB laŋᴮ-taᶜ ``vulture''
>:Kachin laŋ ``bird of the falcon family''
>:Garo do-reŋ ``falcon, kite''
>:Bodo dau-laŋ-a ``eagle''
>:Dimasa dau-liŋ ``kite''

ENTRY:4506
HEAD:yīng₃ 膺
MC:Middle Chinese: ʔjəŋ 
LH:Later Han: ʔɨŋ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *ʔəŋ
GLOSS:"Breast, chest, breastplate, belt across breast of a horse" [BI, Shi];
GLOSS:"to resist" [Shi].
GLOSS-NOTE:In contrast to the root yì 臆
GLOSS:"one's breast, thoughts" (i.e. the inside of the chest; under {yì₂₄ 憶臆}), yīng and its cognates represent the exterior aspect of the
GLOSS:"chest, breast".
	Wáng Lì (1982: 312) relates this word yì 意 ({yì₂₄ 憶臆}).
	[E] ST: Prob. related to Lushai eŋᴴ ``the breast''.
::Lushai	eŋᴴ	``the breast''
>:Prob. related to Lushai eŋᴴ ``the breast''

ENTRY:4511
HEAD:yíng₁ 迎
MC:Middle Chinese: ŋjɐŋ 
LH:Later Han: ŋɨaŋ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *ŋraŋ
	[T] ONW ŋeŋ
GLOSS:"To meet" [Zuo]; Mand.
GLOSS:"go to meet, greet, welcome, receive".
	[D] PMin *ŋiaŋ > Jiànyáng ŋiaŋᴬ¹
	[D] Xiàmén col. ŋiãᴬ² / giã, lit. geŋᴬ² / giŋ ``to receive ceremoniously''.

ENTRY:4512
HEAD:yíng₁ 迎 ⪤ yìng 迎
MC:Middle Chinese: ŋjɐŋᶜ 
LH:Later Han: ŋɨaŋᶜ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *ŋraŋh
GLOSS:"Go to meet, receive" [Shi].
	[E] ST *ŋraŋ: PTB *ŋraŋ (STC no. 155) > WB ŋraŋᴮ ``contradict, deny'', Nung ŋjeŋ ``deny''. Cognate is ST *ŋraᴮ; see under {yà₂ 御迓訝} for an overview over this large wf; the alternation between open syllable and final -ŋ is common in Sino-Tibetan languages ({§6.5.2}).
::Nung	ŋjeŋ	``deny''
>:ST *ŋraŋ:

ENTRY:4513
HEAD:yíng₂ 盈嬴

LH:Later Han: jeŋ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *leŋ 
OCB:Baxter Old Chinese: *(l)jeng
GLOSS:"To fill, satisfy" 盈 [Shi];
GLOSS:"surplus" [Shi],
GLOSS:"profit" 嬴 [Zuo].
	[E] ST: PTB *bliŋ, *pliŋ ``fill'' > TGTM *¹pliŋ, Bumthang Zha bleŋ, Chepang bliŋh-ʔo ``full'' ⪤ leŋʔ- ``be full'', PL-B *m-bliŋ³  > OBurm plañ [IST: 351], WB prañᶜ ``full'' ⪤ pʰrañᶜ ``to fill'' (STC: 176). Matisoff (1988b) combines this etymon with {píng₁ 平坪} ``level'', {tǐng₂ 挺} ``straight'' and {zhèng₁ 正政} ``straight''. – Syn. {tiān₃ 添}.
	[C] An allofam is perhaps {yùn₁ 孕} ``pregnant'', as well as {tián₄ 填顛}.

ENTRY:4514
HEAD:yíng₃ 熒
MC:Middle Chinese: ɣiweŋ[ᴬ/ᴮ/ᶜ]  <wow value=' LH:' color='invert' gloss='Later Han'/> ɣueŋ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *wêŋ
GLOSS:"The light" (of a lamp, fire) 熒 [SW] >
GLOSS:"glow-worm" 螢 [Li] >
GLOSS:"dazzle, confuse, delude" 熒 [Zhuang].
	[WFE] This wf's stem is *weŋ ``bright, dazzle''; it converges with {shùn₃ 瞬} *win ``move the eyes''. For the difference in finals, see {§6.4.1}.
	Perh.
	ST: This wf could be related to Lushai veŋᴴ / venᴸ ``be open, unobstructed by trees, clouds, be clear, be bright (weather)''.
::Lushai	veŋᴴ / venᴸ	``be open, unobstructed by trees, clouds, be clear, be bright (weather)''

ENTRY:4520
HEAD:yíng₄ 營
MC:Middle Chinese: jiwäŋ 4 
LH:Later Han: weŋ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *weŋ
GLOSS:"To lay out, plan, build" [BI, Shi],
GLOSS:"to encamp" [Zuo],
GLOSS:"to surround" [Gongyang].
	[T] Sin Sukchu SR jujŋ (平), PR juŋ, iŋ, LR iŋ
	[T] MGZY  yÿung (平) [juŋ]
	[T] ONW iueŋ
	[WFE] This is a prolific AA or area etymon with vocalic variants (Shorto 1971: 345; 1973):
GLOSS:1:*wiŋ: OMon wiṅ [wøŋ]
GLOSS:"surrounding, round about", tuṁwīṅ /təmwiŋ/
GLOSS:"enclosure, enclosing hedge", Lit. Mon wuiŋ ⇒ WB wuiŋᴮ ``surround, circle of people, do by joint effort'' ⪤ ə-wuiŋᴮ ``circle, anything round''.
	The source of Chepang wiŋh ``around'' (Bodman 1980: 60) is not clear, but may also be AA, note Khasi rwiŋ ``to go and return the same day''.
GLOSS:2:*weŋ: Khmer viaṅa /wíiəŋ/ (OKhmer vyaṅ)
GLOSS:"be enclosed, encircled, walled town, enceinte".
	MK ⇒ Tai: Shan vēŋ (v–ɛŋ), S. wiəŋ ``town''.
	AA ⇒ Limbu wɛŋ- ``to enlarge in a circle, to amass land''; Lushai veeŋᴴ ``village, hamlet''.
GLOSS:3:*waŋ: Mon /waŋ/
GLOSS:"enclosure around official building", Khmer vāṃṅa /weəŋ/ (OKhmer vaṅ ~ vāṅ(ṅ])
GLOSS:"to encircle … enclose … encircling wall, walled citadel, royal palace, walled town" (⇒ Tai: S. waŋ, Shan vāŋ ``palace''), Bahn.-Sre waaŋ ``cattle yard, pound'', PVM wɔŋᴬ circle’ (Thompson).
	<> PTB *hwaŋ (STC no. 217) > WB waŋ ``fence''; Lushai huaŋᴴ ``yard, enclosure'' ⪤ huan¹¹ ``a garden, yard''; JP waŋ³³ ``surround, encircle, enclosure'', Kiranti waŋ-waŋ ``circular''.
	[C] Possible allofam {yǒng₇ 禜}, {xiàn₁₀ 縣}, {yuán₅ 員圓圜}, {guī₁ 規}; {huáng₁ 皇}, {wáng₂ 王}. Many of these words and wf ``round, turn'' are difficult to disentangle.
::Kiranti	waŋ-waŋ	``circular''

ENTRY:4527

	[E] This word may be a cognate of {yīng₁ 英} ``bright''; the semantic association of ``shadow'' with ``light'' is paralleled in the wf {jǐng₃ 景}. Alternatively, yǐng may be connected with {yuàn₁ 苑} ``shady''.

ENTRY:4537
HEAD:yōng₂ 癰
MC:Middle Chinese: ʔjwoŋ 
LH:Later Han: ʔɨoŋ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *ʔoŋ
GLOSS:"Ulcer" [Meng] (<
GLOSS:"swelling") is cognate to {wèng 瓮甕罋}
GLOSS:"jar, swollen". {yǐng₂ 癭} LH ʔieŋᴮ ``tumor'' is related to yōng by the OC *e ~ *o ablaut relationship ({§11.3.5}).
	[E] ST: WB uiŋᶜ ``bulge of anything'' ⪤ uiŋᴮ ``collection of humors'' (boil). Perh. the PTB form *um is a variant (for the final, see {§6.7}): WB uṁ ``protuberance, bulge'', Mru um ``female breast, protuberance'', Lushai um⁵⁵ < uum ``swell, become prominent'' (fem. breast).
	Another etymon ``swollen'' has the same rime: {zhǒng₃ 腫踵}.
::Lushai	um⁵⁵ < uum	``swell, become prominent''
>:WB uiŋᶜ ``bulge of anything'' ⪤ uiŋᴮ ``collection of humors'' . Perh. the PTB form *um is a variant :
