ENTRY:4542
HEAD:yǒng₁ 永
MC:Middle Chinese: jwɐŋᴮ 
LH:Later Han: waŋᴮ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *wraŋʔ ? 
OCB:Baxter Old Chinese: *wrjaŋʔ
GLOSS:"Long time, eternal" [BI, Shi].
GLOSS-NOTE:This is the original graph for {yǒng₂ 泳}
GLOSS:"swim".
	[T] Sin Sukchu SR jujŋ (上), PR, LR juŋ
	[T] MGZY xÿung (上) [ɦjuŋ]
	[T] ONW ueŋ
	[E] An outside cognate is difficult to identify. Bodman (1980: 88) suggests WT rgyoŋ-ba ``extend, stretch'' ⪤ rgyaŋ-ma ``distance'', Lepcha hryăn ``length, distance'', all from a hypothetical ST *wrjaŋ (with WT metathesis of the r and regular loss of medial w).
	The connection with WT riŋ ``long, tall'' (of space, time), Tamang ¹reŋ-pa ``long'', WB hre < hrañ ``be long'', hreᴮ ``former time'', PL *s/m-riŋ¹ ``be long, length'', s/m-riŋ² ``long'' adv. [TB: STC no. 433], or with {jiǒng₂ 泂} ``distant'', if any, is not clear. Bodman associates the last TB items with Kanauri rwi ``high''.
	However, phonetically less complicated and semantically closer to OC is MK *waiŋ ``long'' (Shorto 2006 #768): Khmer /vɛːɲ/ (< -ŋ) ``long'', Kammu-Yuan wàːŋ ``long'' (space, time).
::Kammu-Yuan	wàːŋ	``long''
>:An outside cognate is difficult to identify. Bodman  suggests WT rgyoŋ-ba ``extend, stretch'' ⪤ rgyaŋ-ma ``distance''
>:Lepcha hryăn ``length, distance'', all from a hypothetical ST *wrjaŋ

ENTRY:4543
HEAD:yǒng₁ 永 ⪤ yǒng 詠
MC:Middle Chinese: jwɐŋᶜ 
LH:Later Han: waŋᶜ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *wraŋh ?
GLOSS:"To chant" [Shu] (Karlgren 1956: 8).
	[<] exoactive of yǒng 永, lit. ``make long'' ({§4.3}).

ENTRY:4544
HEAD:yǒng₂ 泳
MC:Middle Chinese: jwɐŋᴮ 
LH:Later Han: waŋᴮ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *wraŋʔ ?
GLOSS:"To wade, swim" [Shi].
	This word may be connected with Tai: PT *hwaiᶜ¹ > S. waaiᴮ² ``to swim'' (tone B2 is spurious, Li 1977: 82), occasionally words with open finals in a tone which is suspected to go back to a final glottal stop (tone C in Tai languages) alternate with final -ŋ ({§3.2.4}).

ENTRY:4551
HEAD:yōu₁ 攸
MC:Middle Chinese: jiəu 
LH:Later Han: ju 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *ju
GLOSS:"Place" [Shi].
GLOSS-NOTE:The function as an indefinite substitute for the post-verbal element (Dobson’ term, LAC: 157), as in fēi tiān yōu ruò 非天攸若
GLOSS:"this is not what Heaven approves of", is derived from the meaning
GLOSS:"place" (Pulleyblank 1995: 68); {suǒ₁ 所} is a semantic parallel.

ENTRY:4553
HEAD:yōu₂ 悠 = yóu 由

ENTRY:4554
HEAD:yōu₂ 悠 ⪤ tiáo 條
MC:Middle Chinese: dieu 
LH:Later Han: deu 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *liû 
OCB:Baxter Old Chinese: *liw
	[T] ONW dėu
GLOSS:"Branch, to be extending branches, extend, long" [Shi] > measure for long, slender objects [starting in Han]; since documents were written on slender wooden or bamboo strips, tiáo became a measure for
GLOSS:"matters, items of business, affairs" (Norman    1988: 116).

ENTRY:4572
HEAD:yóu₆ 游遊
MC:Middle Chinese: jiəu 
LH:Later Han: ju 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *ju 
OCB:Baxter Old Chinese: *ju.
GLOSS:"Float, swim, wander" 游 [Shi];
GLOSS:"to wander about" 遊 [Shi], leisure’ [Li],
GLOSS:"freely, unrestrained" 逌 [Lie]; ``pendants of a banner'' 斿 [Zhouli].
	[T] Sin Sukchu SR iw (平)
	[T] MGZY yiw (平) [jiw]
	[T] ONW iu  —
	[D] PMin *ziu
	[E] ST: WT rgyu-ba < r-yu ``to go, walk, move, wander, range'' (of men, animals etc.), Lepcha yŭ, Rawang yɨ ``to flow'' [Bodman ICSTLL 1987: 13]. For the pre-initial *r-, see {§9.2.1}.
	Cognates are {liú₃ 流} (so Sagart 1999: 127), {qiú₆ 泅}; prob. unrelated to {yóu₄ 油} and {yóu₁₀ 滺油}.
::Rawang	yɨ	``to flow''
>:WT rgyu-ba < r-yu ``to go, walk, move, wander, range''
>:Lepcha yŭ
>:Rawang yɨ ``to flow''

ENTRY:4574
HEAD:yóu₈ 猶
MC:Middle Chinese: jiəu 
LH:Later Han: ju 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *ju 
OCB:Baxter Old Chinese: *lŭ or *jŭ
GLOSS:"Kind of monkey" [Shizi].
	[T] Sin Sukchu SR iw (平)
	[T] MGZY yiw (平) [jiw]
	[T] ONW iu
	[E] Several other Chinese and TB words for one or other kind of monkey look similar, but direct phonological equivalence is elusive. These items include:
	•  PTB *myuk or *mruk [ STC: 112, n. 314]: WB myok (myuk), Mru yuk ``monkey'' could possibly be reconciled with yóu 猶 which may represent the bare root of this etymon, but see {hóu₅ 猴}.
	•  Yuè dialects have a form which is reminiscent of TB: Guǎngzhōu maᴮ²-lɐuᴬ¹ 馬騮 ``monkey''.
	•  PL *C-lwaj² ``monkey, gibbon'' > WB hlwaiᴮ (Matisoff LL 1.2, 2000: 169).
	•  MK: PNBahn. *hwa ``gibbon'', Wa-Lawa-Bulang *hwaʔ ``leaf-monkey'', but see {yuán₆ 猿},
	•  Additional words for ``monkey'' are {wèi₆ 蜼}, {yù₉ 禺}, {náo₂ 猱}, {hóu₅ 猴}.
::Wa-Lawa-Bulang	*hwaʔ	``leaf-monkey''
>:Several other Chinese and TB words for one or other kind of monkey look similar, but direct phonological equivalence is elusive. These items include:
>:

ENTRY:4576
HEAD:yóu₁₀ 滺油
MC:Middle Chinese: jiəu 
LH:Later Han: ju 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *liu 
OCB:Baxter Old Chinese: *ljiw (滺 only)
GLOSS:"To be flowing" 滺滺 [Shi], 油油 [Chuci].
	[T] Sin Sukchu SR iw (平)
	[T] MGZY yiw (平) [jiw]
	[N] This word seems to be distinct from {yóu₆ 游遊} *ju ``to float'' (not ``flow'') which is suspected to have had OC initial *j-. It is also distinct from {yóu₄ 油} *lu ``overflowing'' which had apparently no medial *-i-.
	By the time of the Chǔcí, OCM  *liu and *lu had prob. merged. {dí₇ 滌} could possibly be related.

ENTRY:4578
HEAD:yǒu₂ 有
MC:Middle Chinese: jəuᴮ 
LH:Later Han: wuᴮ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *wəʔ
	[D] M-Xiàmén uᶜ²
GLOSS:"Have, there is, some" (“definite existential quantifier” – Harbsmeier 1981: 88) [OB, Shi] >
GLOSS:"to possess, take possession" [BI, Shi] >
GLOSS:"rich" [Shi] (Karlgren GSR 995o).
	[T] Sin Sukchu SR iw (上)
	[T] MGZY ngiw (上) [ŋiw]
	[T] MTang eu < u, ONW u
	[N] The element ``meat'' in the graph has occasioned much speculation; perhaps the graph was originally intended for the word hǎi 醢 (xậiᴮ) LH həʔ ``dried meat'' [Shi] which also has the 又 element as phonetic.
	[E] ? ST: Possibly cognate to WT yod-pa ``to be, to have'' (for the WT initial, see {§12.9} [2]); WT o can derive from ST a, ə, o, even u, as well as wa and wə; WT final -d has its counterpart in CH tone B in a few grammatical words: WT ŋed ``I'' ⪤ wǒ 我 *ŋâiʔ, WT med ``not have'' ⪤ mǐ 靡 *maiʔ, hence WT yod ``be, have'' could be the exact equivalent of *wəʔ ``have''.
::WT	yod	``be, have''
>:Possibly cognate to WT yod-pa ``to be, to have''
>:WT o can derive from ST a, ə, o, even u, as well as wa and wə
>:WT final -d has its counterpart in CH tone B in a few grammatical words:
>:WT ŋed ``I'' ⪤ wǒ 我 *ŋâiʔ
>:WT med ``not have'' ⪤ mǐ 靡 *maiʔ, hence WT yod ``be, have'' could be the exact equivalent of *wəʔ ``have''

ENTRY:4581
HEAD:yǒu₃ 酉
MC:Middle Chinese: jiəuᴮ 
LH:Later Han: juᴮ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *juʔ
	The 10th of the Earthly Branches, identified with the chicken [OB].
	[E] ? MK: Acc. to Norman (1985: 88) this is possibly a loan from MK: Ruc rəka, Arem lak, however PVM *r-kaː ``chicken'' > Viet. gà. In Tai, the initial is r-, e.g.
	Ahom raoᶜ² (Li Fang Kuei HJAS 8, 1945: 336), also the Shìmíng associates the initial with a lateral (lǎo 老).
	The graph was apparently originally intended to write ``wine'' [OB, BI], presumably {jiǔ₅ 酒}, but see there.
::PVM	*r-kaː	``chicken''
>:Acc. to Norman  this is possibly a loan from MK:
>:Ruc rəka
>:Arem lak, however PVM *r-kaː ``chicken'' >
>:Viet. gà. In Tai, the initial is r-, e.g

ENTRY:4582

ENTRY:4586
HEAD:yòu₁ 又
MC:Middle Chinese: jəuᶜ 
LH:Later Han: wuᶜ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *wəh
GLOSS:"To repeat, again, still, also" [BI, Shi].
	[T] Sin Sukchu SR iw (去)
	[T] MGZY ngiw (去) [ŋiw]
	[<] adverbial derivation ({§3.5.1}) of {yǒu₂ 有} acc. to Downer (1959: 289); in fact, in a phrase like shí yǒu èr yuè  十有二月 (ten / have / two / month) ``in the 12th month'' (lit. ten having two) yǒu is synonymous with yòu. Alternatively, the word may derive from ST *wə-: WT yaŋ ``again, also, once more'', but see {cháng₂ 常}.
	For the WT initial, see {§12.9} (2]); for the finals, see {§6.5.2}.
::WT	yaŋ	``again, also, once more''

ENTRY:4587
HEAD:yòu₂ 右
MC:Middle Chinese: jəuᴮ,jəuᶜ 
LH:Later Han: wuᴮ,wuᶜ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *wəʔ,*wəh
GLOSS:"Right (side), be to the right" [OB].
GLOSS-NOTE:The OB graph is a drawing of the right hand of oneself, from one's own perspective to which
GLOSS:"mouth" was later added to distinguish it from yòu 又 which was commonly used to write
GLOSS:"repeat, again".
	[T] Sin Sukchu SR iw (去)
	[T] MGZY ngiw (去) [ŋiw]
	[T] MTang eu < u, ONW u
	[E] ST *wəs > WT g-yas ``right'' (side) (for the WT initial, see {§12.9} (2]; HPTB: 46). <> PTai *kʰwaᴬ¹ ``right side'', PNTai *gwaᴬ²; PKS *h-waᴬ ``right''.
	The semantics in this wf are parallel to {zuǒ 左}. ``Right'' and ``left'' are metaphors for two different concepts in OC: (1) ``to be on the right and left side of a person'' > ``aid, help, support''; (2) ``left'' > ``unfavorable'', ``right'' > ``favorable''; note the similar notion implied by Mǐn-Xiàmén 正手 tsĩã¹¹/⁵¹-tsʰiu⁵¹ ``right hand'', lit. ``correct hand'' vs. 倒手 to²¹²/⁵³-tsʰiu⁵³/²¹ ``left hand'', lit. ``upside down / wrong hand''.
	This second metaphor explains the OB meaning ``left'' > (``consider or treat as left = unfavorable'' >) ``not approve, to oppose''.
	If this interpretation of ``left'' is valid, then ``right'' should also have meanings which are derivable from ``consider or treat favorably'' (Takashima 1996: 314ƒƒ), like the following word:
::PTai	*kʰwaᴬ¹	``right side''
>:ST *wəs >
>:WT g-yas ``right''  . < > PTai *kʰwaᴬ¹ ``right side''
>:PNTai *gwaᴬ²
>:PKS *h-waᴬ ``right''

LH:Later Han: wuᴮ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *wəʔ 
OCB:Baxter Old Chinese: *wjəʔ
GLOSS:"Be friendly" >
GLOSS:"friend, companion" [BI, Shi] (<
GLOSS:"consider right" = ``favorably'').

	[E] ST *wə: WT ya ``associate, companion, assistant'' (for the WT initial, see {§12.9} (2]).
>:ST *wə:
>:WT ya ``associate, companion, assistant''

ENTRY:4598

ENTRY:4599
HEAD:yū₁ 迂紆 ⪤ wàn 腕
MC:Middle Chinese: ʔuânᶜ 
LH:Later Han: ʔuɑnᶜ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *ʔwâns
GLOSS:"Wrist" [Zuo, Guoce].
	[<] *ʔwa + the nominalizing n-suffix ({§6.4.3}), lit. ``the thing that bends''; for a semantic parallel, see {zhǒu₁ 肘} ``wrist, elbow''. It is not clear if Naga-Khoirao wan ``hand'', Lotha ewon ``arm'' are related (so Matisoff 1985a: 434).
	There are words with similar meaning and initial, but different final consonants which may perhaps be related: wǎng 枉, kuāng 匡, yuān 冤
::Lotha	ewon	``arm''

ENTRY:4600

ENTRY:4601
HEAD:yū₁ 迂紆 ⪤ kuāng 匡
MC:Middle Chinese: kʰjwaŋ

ENTRY:4603

OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *ʔa
GLOSS:"Withered" [Chuci] is said to be an ancient Guānxī (NW) dialect word.

ENTRY:4604
HEAD:yū₂ 菸 ⪤ yān 蔫
MC:Middle Chinese: ʔjän 3 
LH:Later Han: ʔɨɑn 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *ʔan
GLOSS:"Withered" [SW] is said to be an ancient Shandong (eastern) dialect word (Unger Hao-ku 33, 1986) which Pulleyblank (JCL 22.1: 95) relates to Viet. uon
GLOSS:"languid, listless". These etyma could be ancient dialect variants of {wēi₃ 萎}
GLOSS:"wither".

ENTRY:4605
HEAD:yú₁ 于
MC:Middle Chinese: ju 
LH:Later Han: wɑ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *wa
GLOSS:"Go to (a place / do someth.), in, at, on, to", general locative link vb. or
GLOSS:"preposition" [OB, BI, Shi], indicating motion to, or inceptive action (``go flying'') (Pulleyblank 1995: 53). This etymon is distinct from {yú₈ 於}.
	[T] Sin Sukchu SR y (平)
	[T] MTang y < uo, ONW uo
	[E] ST: PTB *wa, *s-wa: Newari wa ``to come'', JP wa³¹ ``to go back''; Chepang wah-ʔo ``moving'', wah-sa ``walk''; WB swa ``to go'', Magari, Chepang hwa ``to walk'' (HST: 86).
::Chepang	hwa	``to walk''
>:PTB *wa, *s-wa:
>:Newari wa ``to come''
>:JP wa³¹ ``to go back''
>:Chepang wah-ʔo ``moving'', wah-sa ``walk''
>:WB swa ``to go''
>:Magari
>:Chepang hwa ``to walk''

ENTRY:4606
HEAD:yú₁ 于 ⪤ yuán 爰
MC:Middle Chinese: jwɐn 
LH:Later Han: wɑn 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *wan
GLOSS:"There" [Shi] stands for the ungrammatical *于之 and is a fusion of yú 于 *wa plus an *-n with a demonstrative meaning, see {§6.4.5} (Norman 1988: 86).
	[C] Additional cognates: {wǎng₁ 往}, {qú₅ 衢}.

ENTRY:4610
HEAD:yú₅ 余
MC:Middle Chinese: jiwo 
LH:Later Han: jɑ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *la (or *ja?)
GLOSS:"I, we" 余 [OB, BI].
GLOSS-NOTE:Chǔcí has both 予 and  余 where the former is used mostly in a post-verbal position (Pulleyblank 1995: 76), this suggests that 予 was perhaps read LH  jɑʔ; see {§3.3.3}.
	[WFE] The etymology of yú is obscure. Li F. (1976: 40) who reconstructs OC *rag, relates yú to PTai *r-: S. raaᴬ² ``we two'' (inclusive?), Shan ha ``we two'', Lü hra ``I''.
	However, the Tai etymon prob. belongs to CH {liǎng 兩} ``two''.
	Syn. {wú₂ 吾}.
::Shan	ha	``we two''

ENTRY:4611
HEAD:yú₅ 余 ⪤ yú 予
MC:Middle Chinese: jiwo 
LH:Later Han: jɑᴮ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *laʔ (or *jaʔ?)
GLOSS:"I, we" 予 [Shi] is usually considered a graphic variant of 余 (Qiu Xigui 2000: 392), but Shījīng rimes indicate that this graph was read in tone B (Mattos 1971: 309).

ENTRY:4612
HEAD:yú₅ 余 ⪤ yí 台
MC:Middle Chinese: jiɨ 
LH:Later Han: jə 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *lə
GLOSS:"I, my" [Shu].
	[<] Unstressed derivation from yú 予余 ``I, we'' (Pulleyblank 1995: 76), see {§3.3.3}.

	[T] MTang iy < iø < ONW io

>:S. liaᴬ¹ < *hl- ``to be left over''

ENTRY:4616
HEAD:yú₈ 於
MC:Middle Chinese: ʔjwo 
LH:Later Han: ʔɨɑ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *ʔa
GLOSS:"Be in, at, on, to …", general locative link vb. or
GLOSS:"preposition" [Shi].
GLOSS-NOTE:Yú 於 begins to appear occasionally in Shījīng, but over time competes with, and gradually replaces, the older yú 于.
	The irreg.
	Mand. tone 2 has been transferred from {yú₁ 于} (QY would predict tone 1).
	[T] Sin Sukchu SR ʔy (平)
	[T] MGZY 'ÿu (平) [ʔy]
	[T] MTang ʔy < ʔø, ONW  ʔio (?) > ʔø
	[E] ? ST: PTB *ʔay ``to go, directional particle'' [HPTB: 209; -y may be a suffix], Lushai locative, ablative etc. suffix a / aʔᴸ ``in, into, on, to …'' Alternatively, note the similarity with MK: PMonic *ʔa(a)r ``to go'', post-verb after verbs of motion and vbs. with ingressive force [Diffloth 1984: 227], PVM *ʔëᶜ ``at, located''.
::PVM	*ʔëᶜ	``at, located''
>:PTB *ʔay ``to go, directional particle''
>:Lushai locative, ablative etc. suffix a / aʔᴸ ``in, into, on, to …'' Alternatively, note the similarity with MK:
>:PMonic *ʔar ``to go'', post-verb after verbs of motion and vbs. with ingressive force
>:PVM *ʔëᶜ ``at, located''

ENTRY:4617
HEAD:yú₈ 於 ⪤ hū 乎
MC:Middle Chinese: ɣwo 
LH:Later Han: ɣɑ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *ɦâ or *â
GLOSS:"In, at, on, to", general locative particle [Shi], an attrited or unstressed form of yú 於 (Pulleyblank 1995: 56).
	[T] Sin Sukchu SR ɣu (平)
	[T] MGZY Xu (平) [ɣu]
	[T] ONW ɣo,
	[D] The irreg. Mand. tone 1 instead of the expected tone 2 comes from another reading for this graph, MC xwo.
	Because hū is always placed between the vb. and the n. which it modifies (N hū V, V hū N), it often functions as a postposition.

ENTRY:4618
HEAD:yú₈ 於 ⪤ yān 焉
MC:Middle Chinese: jän 3 -irregular 
LH:Later Han: ʔɑn,-ɑn 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *ʔan > an
	[T] ONW ʔan -an
GLOSS:"In it, on it, there" [Shi] stands for *於之 which is a fusion of yú 於 with an element *-n with a demonstrative meaning; see {§6.4.5} (Norman 1988: 86; Pulleyblank 1995: 80). The Mand. tone 1 derives from MC ʔjan.
	This word's initial div.
	III j- is exceptional.
	The word is parallel to yuán 爰 (under {yú₁ 于}).

ENTRY:4619
HEAD:yú₈ 於 ⪤ yāng 央
MC:Middle Chinese: ʔjaŋ 
LH:Later Han: ʔɨɑŋ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *ʔaŋ
GLOSS:"To hit the center" (of a target), get into the middle (of a stream, of the night) vb. > middle, center’ [Shi] (Pulleyblank 1995: 171).
	[T] Sin Sukchu SR ʔjaʔ (平)
	[T] MGZY ('ÿang >) 'yang (平) [ʔjaŋ]
	[<] *ʔa + terminative *-ŋ ({§6.5.1}) hence lit. ``to get to be in the middle''. This etymology is phonologically more straightforward than the traditional association with PTai *klaŋᴬ¹ ``middle''.
	[N] The near-synonyms / homophones 於 *ʔa and {yú₁ 于} *wa are distinct etyma (Pulleyblank 1995: 53f), and their derivations with the terminative suffix *-ŋ result in quite different words which cannot be phonological variants.
::PTai	*klaŋᴬ¹	``middle''

GLOSS:"to praise" 譽 [Shi].

ENTRY:4626
HEAD:yú₁₄ 俞
MC:Middle Chinese: jiu 
LH:Later Han: jo 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *lo
GLOSS:"Make a boat by hollowing the log" [SW], 窬木
GLOSS:"hollowed tree, canoe"; lú 艫 (luo)
GLOSS:"boat" [Xin Tangshu] is perhaps a variant of this word.
	[E] This is an ancient area word: WB hlo- ``boat''. <> PKS *lwaᴬ ``boat'' (Edmondson / Yang 1988: 157 *s-lwa(n) on the basis of Ai-Cham zuːn²), PTai *drɨoᴬ², Be lua⁵⁵.
	The meaning of this wf is ``to hollow out, make hollow'' (Huáng Jīn-guì and Shěn Xí-róng YYWZX 1987.8: 41ƒƒ).
	Allofams are {dú₄ 櫝韇} ``container'', perhaps also {yú₁₉ 窬俞} ``hole'', {dú₃ 瀆} ``drain'', {yú₁₆ 揄} ``scoop''; {chuán₁ 船} ``boat'' may also be remotely related (see there for cognates); {zhōu₁ 舟} ``boat'' is not.
::PKS	*lwaᴬ	``boat''
>:This is an ancient area word:
>:WB hlo- ``boat''. < > PKS *lwaᴬ ``boat''  on the basis of Ai-Cham zuːn²)
>:PTai *drɨoᴬ²
>:Be lua⁵⁵

ENTRY:4647
HEAD:yú₂₅ 愚
MC:Middle Chinese: ŋju 
LH:Later Han: ŋɨo

	[T] MTang ŋy < ŋuo ONW ŋuo
GLOSS:"Stupid, ignorant" 遇 [Shi], 愚 [Lunyu].
	[E] Tai: PTai *ʔŋuaᴮ²/ᶜ² ``stupid, idiot, ignorant'' (Luo Yongxian MKS 27, 1997: 291), S. ŋooᶜ¹ ``stupid''. <> MK *[t1]ŋuul, *[t1]ŋul ``stupid'' (Shorto 2006 #1723a): Viet. ngu ``foolish, stupid'', Lawa Umphai ŋau ``stupid'', Khmer lŋɤ̀ː ``stupid''.
::Khmer	lŋɤ̀ː	``stupid''
>:PTai *ʔŋuaᴮ²/ᶜ² ``stupid, idiot, ignorant''
>:S. ŋooᶜ¹ ``stupid''. < > MK *ŋuul, *ŋul ``stupid'' :
>:Viet. ngu ``foolish, stupid''
>:Lawa Umphai ŋau ``stupid''
>:Khmer lŋɤ̀ː ``stupid''

ENTRY:4651
HEAD:yú₂₇ 輿
MC:Middle Chinese: jiwo 
LH:Later Han: jɑ

	[T] MTang iy < iø < ONW io

	This is prob. the same etymon as {yú₁₁ 舁譽} ``lift''.
	Baxter / Sagart (1998: 48) suggest that yú is also related to {chē 車} and {jǔ₆ 舉}.

ENTRY:4654
HEAD:yǔ₃ 雨
MC:Middle Chinese: juᴮ 
LH:Later Han: wɑᴮ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *waʔ
GLOSS:"Precipitation, rain" [OB, Shi].
	[T] Sin Sukchu SR y (上)
	[T] MGZY xÿu (上) [ɦy]
	[T] MTang y < uo, ONW uo
	[WFE] ST *waʔ > PTB *r-wa > Khambu kəwa, Bahing rja-wa; Chepang waʔ-ʔo; PL *r-jwa/we¹, WB rwa, Lushai ruaʔᴸ (HST: 122). A rare ST parallel stem *(r)we is represented in CH by the wf {yǔn₂ 隕殞霣}.
	It is not clear if or how PT *xr-: S. haaᴮ¹ ``shower'', classifier for rain etc. could be related.
	Syn. {dōng₃ 涷}, {fēn₂ 雰氛}, {líng₈ 霝零}.

ENTRY:4657
HEAD:yǔ₄ 禹
MC:Middle Chinese: juᴮ 
LH:Later Han: wɑᴮ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *waʔ
	[T] MTang y < uo ONW uo
GLOSS:"Insect, reptile" [SW] has been compared to PTB *was
GLOSS:"bee, honey" (STC p. 17 n. 62). However, PWa *wak
GLOSS:"insect" is semantically closer (for the finals, see {§3.2.2}).

ENTRY:4662
HEAD:yǔ₆ 語 ⪤Perh. yàn 唁諺
MC:Middle Chinese: ŋjänᶜ 3

OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *ŋans
GLOSS:"To console" 唁[Shi];
GLOSS:"saying, proverb" 諺 [Zuo] are cognates of yán acc. to Wáng Lì (1982: 138). Although the two words look identical in most dialects except for the tone, including LH, the QYS makes a fine vocalic distinction.

ENTRY:4672
HEAD:yù₄ 浴
MC:Middle Chinese: jiwok 
LH:Later Han: jok 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *lok
GLOSS:"To bathe, wash" [Lunyu].
	[T] Sin Sukchu SR y (入)
	[T] MGZY yÿu (入) [jy]
	[E] Area word. Chinese and WT share a final *-k, the other TB languages have open syllables: WT ldug(s)-pa, ldugs < ɴluk ``to pour'' (water into vessel, on hands) > ``cast, found'' (STC: 110).
	Also Pearic kluːk ``to pour''.
	<> PTB *(r-)lu(w) ~ *(m-)lu(w) > Angami Naga rəlu ``bathe'', NNaga *C/V-ru [French 1983: 334]. Mikir iŋlu < m-lu, Dimasa lu ``to pour'', Karen lu ``to pour''.
	Also Mru lu, WB kʰyuiᴮ ``wash, bathe'' [Löffler 1966: 130]. There is a similar but unrelated item zhù 鑄 ``to cast, pour'' (under {zhù₅ 注}) whose initial is a dental stop.
	The relationship with {yě₂ 冶} ``smelt, cast'', if any, is not clear.
::WB	kʰyuiᴮ	``wash, bathe''
>:Area word. Chinese and WT share a final *-k, the other TB languages have open syllables:
>:WT ldug-pa, ldugs < ɴluk ``to pour''  > ``cast, found''

ENTRY:4677
HEAD:yù₈ 悆譽豫
MC:Middle Chinese: jiwoᶜ 
LH:Later Han: jɑᶜ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *lah
	[T] MTang iy < iø ONW io
GLOSS:"Pleased" 悆 [SW: Shu];
GLOSS:"joy" 豫譽 [Shi];
GLOSS:"happy" 豫 [Shu], ``amusement, recreation'' [Meng].
	[C] This is prob. the same word as {yù₂₅ 豫} ``slow'' (< ``relaxed''). A derivation may be {xiáng₁ 庠祥} ``happy omen''.
	A cognate and paronym is {yì₃₅ 繹} ``pleased''.
	[E] The related AA root under the cognate {yì₃₅ 繹} ``pleased'' also has the semantic range ``open up'' > ``carefree, happy'': OKhmer lā [laa] ``to open, unfold, extend …'' ⪤ klā [klaa] ``be free of restraint, be lively, merry, gay''. Gòng Qúnhǔ (MZYW 2, 2000) compares this word to Tai raaᴮ² ``happy''.
::Tai	raaᴮ²	``happy''
>:The related AA root under the cognate {yì₃₅ 繹} ``pleased'' also has the semantic range ``open up'' > ``carefree, happy'':
>:OKhmer lā  ``to open, unfold, extend …'' ⪤ klā  ``be free of restraint, be lively, merry, gay''. Gòng Qúnhǔ  compares this word to Tai raaᴮ² ``happy''

ENTRY:4678
HEAD:yù₉ 禺
MC:Middle Chinese: ŋjuᶜ 
LH:Later Han: ŋɨoᶜ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *ŋoh
GLOSS:"Monkey" [Li, N. Pr.].
	[E] ST: Kuki-Naga branch of PTB: *ŋaːw ``ape'' > Lushai ŋauᴴ < ŋau ``grey monkey'' (STC: 192 n. 491). Note also {náo₂ 猱獶} *nu ``monkey''; if related, inter-lingual borrowing is probably responsible for the variants.
	The word {hóu₅ 猴} may be a denasalized relation.
	For other similar-looking words for ``monkey'', see {yóu₈ 猶}.
>:Kuki-Naga branch of PTB:
>:*ŋaːw ``ape'' >
>:Lushai ŋauᴴ < ŋau ``grey monkey'' . Note also {náo₂ 猱獶} *nu ``monkey''
>:if related, inter-lingual borrowing is probably responsible for the variants

ENTRY:4685
HEAD:yù₁₆ 禦

LH:Later Han: ŋɨɑᴮ

	[E] ST: WT mŋa’  ``might, dominion'', mŋa’-ba ``having, owning, to be''; the fundamental ST meaning might have been ``be in control''.

ENTRY:4687

ENTRY:4693
HEAD:yù₂₀,yǔ 嫗
MC:Middle Chinese: ʔjuᴮ 
LH:Later Han: ʔɨoᴮ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *ʔoʔ
	(Of birds:) ``to sit on eggs, incubate'' 嫗伏 [Liji] > ``to warm with body'' (as mother a child, or the earth all things to make them grow) [Liji].
	[E] ST *ʔo: PLB *ʔu³ > WB uᴮ (i.e. /ʔuᴮ/) ``lay an egg'' ⪤ ə-uᴮ ``egg'' (HPTB: 180).
	[C] This wf coalesces partially with {xù₄ 旭}, perhaps they together form a single wf. {wēn 溫} ``warm'' could be an allofam, but it prob. belongs to a ST root *ʔur, while the above items belong to ST *ʔo.

ENTRY:4694

ENTRY:4695
HEAD:yù₂₀,yǔ 嫗 ⪤ yòu 蓲
MC:Middle Chinese: ʔjəuᶜ 
LH:Later Han: ʔuᶜ
GLOSS:"To brood, hatch (eggs)" is acc. to Guō Pú's commentary to FY 8, 4 a Jiāngdōng (lower Yangtze) dialect word; it survives today in Mǐn dialects: Jiàn’ōu iuᶜ¹, Chóngān ieuᶜ¹ (Norman 1983: 206).

ENTRY:4696
HEAD:yù₂₀,yǔ 嫗 ⪤ yù 燠
MC:Middle Chinese: ʔjuk 
LH:Later Han: ʔuk
GLOSS:"Warm" (of season, house, clothing) [Shi].
	[E] ST: WB uik (i.e. ʔuik) ``feel warm, close''.
>:WB uik  ``feel warm, close''

ENTRY:4697

	[E] ? ST: Perh. WT myo-ba, myos ~ smyo-ba, smyos ``insane, mad, drunk'', if Tib. m- is a prefix.

ENTRY:4699
HEAD:yù₂₁ 饇 ⪤ xù 酗

ENTRY:4700

	[<] *ʔoh + terminative -ŋ ({§6.5.1}), lit. ``(something for) getting to be full''.

ENTRY:4701

GLOSS:"rice gruel" from this word. {jú₅ 鞠}

ENTRY:4704
HEAD:yù₂₂ 育毓鬻 ⪤ yù 谷
MC:Middle Chinese: juk 
LH:Later Han: jok 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *lok
GLOSS:"To nourish" [Lao] a vocalic variant.
	[C] {Table C-2} (under {chù₄,xù 畜}) shows the phonological and semantic connections among similar looking words. This etymon is not related to any of the other stems in that table, nor to {xiū₄ 羞}.
	Perh. connected with chōu 抽 (under {yóu₂ 由}).

ENTRY:4705
HEAD:yù₂₃ 賣𧶠
MC:Middle Chinese: jiuk 
LH:Later Han: juk 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *luk
GLOSS:"To sell" [BI].
GLOSS-NOTE:Originally, this graph (𧶠) was distinct from the one for mài
GLOSS:"sell" ({mǎi 買}), see SW 2776.
	[E] MK: OKhmer /lɔk/, Khmer /luk/ ~ /ruk/ ``to sell, to fine''. Yù looks like a cognate of {shú₆ 贖} *m-lok ``ransom'' (Sagart 1999: 82), but the vowels should be identical in a closely related introvert / extrovert pair; also, simultaneous close connections with both WT ({shú₆ 贖}) as well as MK are difficult to explain, therefore these words may not be related.
	Syn. {dí₆ 糴}; {gǔ₁₁ 賈}; {mǎi 買}; {shòu₂ 售}.
::Khmer	/luk/ ~ /ruk/	``to sell, to fine''
>:OKhmer /lɔk/
>:Khmer /luk/ ~ /ruk/ ``to sell, to fine''. Yù looks like a cognate of {shú₆ 贖} *m-lok ``ransom'' , but the vowels should be identical in a closely related introvert / extrovert pair
>:also, simultaneous close connections with both WT  as well as MK are difficult to explain, therefore these words may not be related

ENTRY:4706
HEAD:yù₂₄ 豫
MC:Middle Chinese: jiwoᶜ
	Supposedly ``large elephant'' [SWJZGL 4277] (Karlgren GSR 83e). There is prob. no such word. (1) There is no early text in which this word means ``elephant''; (2) the ancient graph (gǔwén 古文) did not have xiàng 象 ``elephant'' as a graphic element.
	SW was guessing at the original meaning of the graph.

ENTRY:4707
HEAD:yù₂₅ 豫
MC:Middle Chinese: jiwoᶜ 
LH:Later Han: jɑᶜ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *lah
	[T] MTang iy < iø < ONW io
GLOSS:"Slow and deliberate" [Lao],
GLOSS:"think beforehand" [Li],
GLOSS:"anticipate" [Zuo].
	[E] Karlgren GSR 83e derives this word from the homophone ``elephant'' {yù₂₄ 豫} [SW] (< ``elephant-like'') which is unlikely. This is prob. the s. w. as {yù₈ 悆譽豫}
GLOSS:"pleased" (both from <
GLOSS:"relaxed") (so Wáng Lì 1982: 162).
	A semantic parallel is {yú₁₇ 愉}.
	[WFE] Three different valence-increasing morphemes are added to the root *la: (1) final s/h: *la-h, (2) causative devoicing *lha, (3) s-prefix: *s-la. A similar profusion of forms is seen in the wf {yì₃₅ 繹}.
>:Karlgren GSR 83e derives this word from the homophone ``elephant'' {yù₂₄ 豫}   which is unlikely. This is prob. the s. w. as {yù₈ 悆譽豫}

ENTRY:4722
HEAD:yuán₁ 元
MC:Middle Chinese: ŋjwɐn 
LH:Later Han: ŋyɑn ~ ŋon 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *ŋon
GLOSS:"Head" [Zuo, Xi 33] (Unger Hao-ku 28, 1984: 251; Mei 1985: 335),
GLOSS:"to be at the head, first, eldest, principal, great" [BI, Shi].
	[T] Sin Sukchu SR ŋyen (平)
	[T] MGZY xwÿan (平) [ɦyɛn]
	[T] ONW ŋuan
	Yuán is perhaps related to PTB *m-gaw ~ *(s-)gaw (STC no. 490) > WT go ``headman, beginning, source'' ⪤ mgo ``head, summit, beginning'' ⪤ mgon-po ``protector, master, lord''.
	WT mg-, mb- = CH ŋ-, m- does occur elsewhere, but is rare.
	Alternatively, the WT etyma could be related to {gāo₁ 高} (kâu) (so HST: 93), yet yuán's semantic agreement with WT is significant.
	Mei Tsu-Lin (in Thurgood etc. 1985: 335f) considers both yuán and {jūn₃ 君} (kjuən) ``lord, prince'' variants which are related to WT mgon.
::WT	go	``headman, beginning, source''

ENTRY:4728
HEAD:yuán₅ 員圓圜
MC:Middle Chinese: jwän 
LH:Later Han: wian or wen 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *wen (?) 
OCB:Baxter Old Chinese: *wjən
GLOSS:"Circle" 員 [Shi];
GLOSS:"round" 圜 [Yi], 員 [Meng], 圓 [Hanfei];
GLOSS:"return" 員 [Shu]; yuán ``circle'' is symbolic for ``sky, heaven'', fāng 方 ``square'' for ``earth'' [Huainan].
	[T] Sin Sukchu SR yen (平)
	[T] MGZY xwÿan (平) [ɦyɛn]
	[T] ONW uan
	[WFE] Area word: PMK *wail ``turn around'' (Shorto 1972: 4; 1973: 380) ⪤ *wal ``bend, return, halo''. <> ST *w(i)al: PTB *wal (STC no. 91) > WB wanᴮ ``circular'', Kachin wan, Lushai valᴿ ``be in the form of a ring or circle'' (HST: 55) ⪤ hualᴸ ``to surround, encircle''.
	CH ⇒ Tai: S. wianᴬ² ``revolve, encircle, circle'' (Manomaivibool 1975: 179).
	MC -jä- suggests that the OC vocalism was not /a/ but frontish (e, ia?), therefore prob. not (directly?) related to {huán₁ 桓垸}.
	Or this CH wf, or some of its members, belong to {yíng₄ 營}.
	Most likely, the area roots *weŋ ~ *wen and *wial ~ *wel have converged in OC. For synonyms, see {huí 回}.
::Lushai	valᴿ	``be in the form of a ring or circle''

ENTRY:4731
HEAD:yuán₆ 猿

ENTRY:4732
HEAD:yuán₇ 園
MC:Middle Chinese: jwɐn 
LH:Later Han: wɑn 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *wan 
OCB:Baxter Old Chinese: *wjan
	[T] ONW uan
GLOSS:"Garden, park" [Shi].
	[E] This word is prob. derived from one or other root *wan ``round, encircle'' (see {huí 回}), semantically like yuàn 院瑗 ``wall round courtyard'' ({yuán₅ 員圓圜}), see {yíng₄ 營}. Therefore, the following are unrelated: KN-Kom ra-hụn ``garden''; Khmer swna /sùuən/ ``care for, look after > flower / pleasure garden'' (Jenner / Pou 1982: 373) ⇒ KT *swjaan (Li acc. to Benedict AT: 37; 1976: 90) > S. suanᴬ¹ ``garden''.
	<> PMY *weŋ² ``garden'' agrees phonologically with CH (M. Ratliff, p.c.).
::PMY	*weŋ²	``garden''
>:This word is prob. derived from one or other root *wan ``round, encircle'' , semantically like yuàn 院瑗 ``wall round courtyard'' , see {yíng₄ 營}. Therefore, the following are unrelated:

ENTRY:4749
HEAD:yuē₂ 約

GLOSS:"restrain, restrict" [Lunyu] > ``abbreviate, condensed, essential'' [Li, Meng].
	[E] ST: WB yok ``wind round, as thread''.
>:WB yok ``wind round, as thread''

ENTRY:4751
HEAD:yuē₃ 噦
MC:Middle Chinese: ʔjwɐt,ʔjwät 
LH:Later Han: ʔyɑt ~ ʔɨot 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *ʔwat or *ʔot
GLOSS:"Sound of vomiting" [Li].
	[E] This is an onomatopoetic expression, other languages in the area have similar words: PTB *ʔaw ``vomit'' (HPTB: 227), PLB *ut ``to belch''; Lushai uakᴿ; PMonic *tl-ʔɔɔʔ, Mon həʔɔʔ ``to vomit, regurgitate'' [Diffloth 1984: 151]; also WB an ``vomit''; WT skyug-pa (< s-ʔyuk ?) ``vomit, eject''.
::WB	an	``vomit''
>:This is an onomatopoetic expression, other languages in the area have similar words:

ENTRY:4753
HEAD:yuè₁ 月
MC:Middle Chinese: ŋjwɐt 
LH:Later Han: ŋyɑt, S ŋiot 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *ŋot
GLOSS:"Moon > month" [OB, Shi].
	[T] Sin Sukchu SR ŋye (入)
	[T] MGZY xwÿa (入) [ɦyɛ]
	[T] MTang ŋuar, ONW ŋuat,
	[D] Mand. yuè ``month'', yuè-liáng 月亮 ``moon''
	[D] Gàn ŋyœʔᴰ²-kwɔŋᴬ¹ 月光 ``moon'' (in Mand. ``moonlight'')
	[D] Y-Guǎngzhōu jytᴰ²-kuɔŋᴬ¹ 月光 ``moon'', Táishān ŋgutᴰ²-kɔŋᴬ¹
	[D] PMin *ŋyot: Xiàmén col. geʔᴰ², lit. guatᴰ²
	[E] ST: Unger (Hao-ku 39, 1992) proposes as cognate WT ŋo(s) ``waxing and waning moon, half moon'', Lepcha ñóm. These belong to PTB *ŋow (STC no. 296) > WT sŋo ``blue-green'', Lushai ŋoᴴ ``white, fair'', Thado ŋou ``clean'', Lepcha ta-ŋot ``white hair, old'' ⪤ ŋo ``old'' (Bodman 1980: 136).
	The widespread semantic association of ``moon'' with ``white'' would support this etymology; see {bái₁ 白}, {pò₄ 魄} , {pò₅ 霸魄} for a parallel.
	There may possibly be a connection with {ài₁ 艾} ``white-haired'', but that is phonologically problematic.
	Matisoff sets up PTB *s-ŋᵂ(y)at ``moon, star'' (HPTB: 24; 85).
	<> Tai ŋuatᴰ² ``recurring period'' (Manomaivibool 1975: 330) would be a CH loan if the ST etymology is correct.
	Alternatively, HPTB (24; 26) reconstruct PTB *s-ŋwa-t ``star / moon'' (from the above root?).
::PTB	*s-ŋwa-t	``star / moon''
>:Unger  proposes as cognate WT ŋo ``waxing and waning moon, half moon''
>:Lepcha ñóm. These belong to PTB *ŋow  >
>:WT sŋo ``blue-green''
>:Lushai ŋoᴴ ``white, fair''
>:Thado ŋou ``clean''
>:Lepcha ta-ŋot ``white hair, old'' ⪤ ŋo ``old''

ENTRY:4754
HEAD:yuè₂ 刖
	{wù₁} 兀

ENTRY:4755
HEAD:yuè₃ 戉鉞
MC:Middle Chinese: jwɐt 
LH:Later Han: wɑt 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *wat
GLOSS:"Battle-ax" [BI, Shu, Shi].
GLOSS-NOTE:Mahdi (1994: 177) points out that the yuè type ax has been found in archeological sites south of the Yangtze and in the Austronesian speaking areas (Chang Kwang-chih 1963; Chén Zhōngmǐn LTBA 22.2: 42) where the word for
GLOSS:"iron", in places
GLOSS:"ax", is reconstructed PAN *bari > *basi, in some languages wasi and the like.
	Yuè < *wat could therefore perhaps be an AN loan.
	The etymon also occurs in AA: MK *wac, *waac ``knife, sword'' (Shorto 2006 #864), PWa *wac ``knife, sickle, sword'', OMon rwas /rwɔs/ ``weapon'', perhaps ⇒ JP n³¹-waʔ⁵⁵ < n³¹-wak⁵⁵ notched knife.
	Curiously, some Taiwanese tribes have the tradition that they originally came from ``Vasai'' across the Taiwan straits on the mainland, i.e. the area which has been known as Yuè 越 < *wat since mid-Zhou times.
::OMon	rwas /rwɔs/	``weapon''

ENTRY:4756
HEAD:yuè₄ 越
MC:Middle Chinese: jwɐt 
LH:Later Han: wɑt 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *wat
	[T] ONW wat
GLOSS:"To go on, go beyond, transgress" [Shi, Shu] >
GLOSS:"furthermore, and now, later on" [BI, Shi, Shu],
GLOSS:"far away" [Guoyu].
	[<] yuè may be derived from {yú₁ 于} ``to go'' with a t-suffix of unknown function.
	[C] A derivation is prob. {suì₁ 歲} ``year''. Baxter / Sagart (1998: 60) relate yuè to {yuǎn₁ 遠} ``far away''; Matisoff (ICSTLL 1978: 16) relates kuò 闊 ``far apart'' (under {kuān 寬} ) to this word.

ENTRY:4761
HEAD:yuè₉ 樂
MC:Middle Chinese: ŋåk 
LH:Later Han: ŋɔk 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *ŋrâuk
	[T] ONW ŋäk
GLOSS:"Music" [Shi].
	[E] The etymological relationship with {lè₃ 樂} ``joy'' has been much debated, extensively by K. Wulff (Det Kgl. Danske Videnskabernes Selskab, historisk-filologiske meddelelser XXI,2,1935, København), more recently by Unger (Hao-ku 19, 1983) who suggests something like OCM *grak ``joy'' from which is derived *ɴ-grak ``music''.
	For the semantics Unger draws attention to WT rol-ba ``to enjoy'' vs. rol-mo ``music''.
	On the other hand, there is no other example of QY initial ŋ- ~ l- in a wf.
	In the popular mind, the concept ``music'' can easily be connected with ``joy'', hence perhaps the same graph for these near homophones.
	The graph 樂 originally wrote ``oak'' lì 櫟 (liek), OCM *riâuk which is therefore the actual phonetic.
::WT	rol-ba	``to enjoy''
>:The etymological relationship with {lè₃ 樂} ``joy'' has been much debated, extensively by K. Wulff , more recently by Unger  who suggests something like OCM *grak ``joy'' from which is derived *ɴ-grak ``music''

ENTRY:4770
HEAD:yún₅ 雲
MC:Middle Chinese: jwən 
LH:Later Han: wun 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *wən
GLOSS:"Cloud" [OB, Shi].
	[T] Sin Sukchu SR yn (平)
	[T] MGZY xwin (平) [ɦwin]
	[D] PMin *hiun, W-Wēnzhōu ɦyoŋᴬ², Guǎngzhōu wanᴬ²
	[E] This word has no obvious outside connection, except possibly Mikir iŋhùn < m-hùn ``clouds''; or alternatively KN vaan > Lushai vaanᴸ < vaanh ``sky'' (in some languages, ``sky'' and ``cloud'' are the same word).
	However, ``cloud'' is possibly cognate to {yùn₂ 運暈} ``revolve'', thus yún was lit. a ``whorl'' or ``swirl'' in the sky (the OB graph for yún shows a whorl).
	Therefore one or other of the numerous synonymous and similar-looking roots in the area (see under {huí 回}) is probably represented here.
	Closest is perhaps Khmer /wul/ ``to turn (around), revolve, rotate, spin, whirl, eddy, swirl''.
	From *wul to *wun is only one phonological step; an equally appropriate root PTB *wir would instead require two steps, in addition to -r > -n also the change u > i ({§11.5.1}): Lushai virᴿ < virʔ ``rotate, revolve, spin'' ⪤ virᴸ < virh (< -s) ``a whorl'', Mru wir ``rotate, spin'', WT ’kʰyir-ba ``to turn round in a circular course'', JP-Hkauri kə-wīn ``rotate'' [Matisoff 1974: 166]; WB ə-kʰyin ``a time period, season'' (for semantics, note xún 旬 under {jūn₂ 鈞}).
::WB	ə-kʰyin	``a time period, season''
>:This word has no obvious outside connection, except possibly Mikir iŋhùn < m-hùn ``clouds''
>:or alternatively KN vaan >
>:Lushai vaanᴸ < vaanh ``sky''

ENTRY:4771
HEAD:yǔn₁ 允
MC:Middle Chinese: jiuenᴮ 
LH:Later Han: junᴮ (juinᴮ) 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *junʔ or *winʔ
GLOSS:"To trust, be true, sincere" [Shi] seems to be related to {xìn₁ 信}
GLOSS:"believe, trust"; if so, OC should be expected to be *winʔ (not *junʔ). On the other hand, the word may be related to WB yum
GLOSS:"believe, trust" (for the final nasal, see {§6.7}).
	[T] Sin Sukchu SR yn (上)
	[T] MGZY yÿun (上) [jyn]

ENTRY:4772
HEAD:yǔn₂ 隕殞霣
MC:Middle Chinese: jiwenᴮ 
LH:Later Han: winᴮ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *w(r)in(ʔ) ? 
OCB:Baxter Old Chinese: *wrjɨn(ʔ)
GLOSS:"To drop, fall" 隕 [Shi];
GLOSS:"fall to the ground" [Zuo],
GLOSS:"to rain, fall down like rain" 霣 [Gongyang];  ``to drop, lose'' (one's life) 殞 [Guoyu]; ``lose'' 隕 [Zuo] > caus. ``to overthrow'' 隕 [Zuo], ``destroy'' 殞 [Xun].
	[WFE] ST *(r)we is a rare parallel stem of ST *(r)wa ``rain'' ({yǔ₃ 雨}): Mikir arwè ~ ruwè < r-weᴸ ``rain'', also in Lolo lgs. *we (?) (but HPTB: 128 derives these forms from *r-wa). For CH final -n, see {§6.4.4}.
	Syn. include {yǔ₃ 雨}, {líng₈ 霝零} ``rain, fall''.
::Mikir	arwè ~ ruwè < r-weᴸ	``rain''

ENTRY:4774
HEAD:yùn₁ 孕
MC:Middle Chinese: jiəŋᶜ 
LH:Later Han: jɨŋᶜ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *ləŋh
	[T] ONW iŋ
GLOSS:"Pregnant" [Zuo, GY] is prob. the s. w. as yìng 繩
GLOSS:"full" (of ears of grain)  [Zhouli].
	[D] Medieval dictionaries and non-Mandarin modern dialects reflect a reading which is the equivalent of QY jiəŋᶜ: W-Wēnzhōu ɦiaŋᶜ², M-Xiàmén lit. jiŋᶜ², Fúzhōu eiŋᶜ², Cháozhōu eŋᴬ. Occasional forms with the equivalent of QYS rime -jen prob. represent secondary developments: Guǎngzhōu janᶜ² (but northern Yuè dialects point to -jəŋ), M-Xiàmén col. jinᶜ².
	Mand. dialects have forms riming in -un which may possibly reflect the ancient (LH and OC) form jun as opposed to LH win.
	Many modern dialects have replaced this word with other expressions.
	[WFE] This etymon is perhaps related to {yíng₂ 盈贏} (jiäŋ) ``full'' because the two words differ only in the vowels (as can occasionally be observed within wfs), and because the phrase 孕育 ``to conceive and give birth'' is rendered as 贏育 (*-eŋ) in Guǎnzǐ. More tenuous would be identification with the WT dictionary word liŋs-pa ``quite round or globular''.

LH:Later Han: źɨŋᶜ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *m-ləŋh
GLOSS:"Pregnant" [Guanzi; GY] (GY 432; GYSX 884).

ENTRY:4781
HEAD:zá 噆
MC:Middle Chinese: tsập 
LH:Later Han: tsəp 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *tsə̂p
GLOSS:"To bite, sting and suck" (as a mosquito) [Zhuang].
	[E] Sound symbolic area word: PTB *dzoːp (STC no. 69) > PLB *ʔcup ~ ʔɉup ~ *C-cup ``suck, milk''; Thado tsop, Siyin tuop, Dimasa dźop; Lushai fɔɔpᶠ (Lorrain fâwp) / fɔʔᴸ ``to kiss, suck''; WT ’ǰo-ba, bžos ``to milk'' derives from a form with medial *j (PTib. *-op > WT *-o, see {§12.9}); JP mə³¹-sup³¹ ``to suck'', tʃup³¹ ``suck''. HPTB: 382 list many TB variants.
	Note also AA: Kharia jo’b ``to suck'', Munda cɛpɔ’d, Khmer -jāpa /-cíiəp/ ``to take in, suck''.
	Foreign words with the rime -op, -up usually become MC -əp (via earlier -wəp, with the medial w lost due to dissimilation); occasionally, such words appear in OC as *-ot, *-ut, thus {chuò₂ 啜歠} ``drink'' may be related.
	Karlgren (1956: 18) relates this word to {cǎn 噆} ``hold in the mouth''.
::Khmer	-jāpa /-cíiəp/	``to take in, suck''

ENTRY:4783
HEAD:zāi₁ 災
MC:Middle Chinese: tsậi 
LH:Later Han: tsə 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *tsə̂
	[T] ONW tsɑi
GLOSS:"Natural disaster" (fire, drought, flood, locusts, eclipse, pestilence etc.),
GLOSS:"accident, injury" 災 [OB, Shi], 烖 [Li],
GLOSS:"conflagration" [Zuo, SW, Hanshu].
	[E] ? ST *tsə > TB: JP tsa³¹ ``be damaged'' ⪤ ʃə³¹-tsa³¹ ``to destroy''. This root blends into a homophone meaning ``warm, heat, fever, pain'': PTB *tsa ``be hot'' (STC no. 62) > WT tsʰa-ba ``hot, heat, sharp (spices), illness'' ⪤ tsʰad-pa ``heat, fever'' ⪤ tsʰan-ma ``hot, warm''; TGTM *¹tshawa ``fever'', ²tsha ``be in pain''; Chepang ca ``sore, wound'' ⪤ ca- ``have sores'', Mikir sò- ``hot, excessive, be ill, sore''; NNaga dzat ``suffer'' [French 1983: 223], Garo sa ``ache, pain''; WB ə-cha ``hunger, something faulty or hurtful'', Lahu cha ``to shine, be bright'' (of the sun). STC (170 n. 455) relates PTB *tsa ``hot, pain'' to {jí₆ 疾}, but see there.
	[C] Prob. cognate to {zī₈ 菑} ``slash and burn'', and possibly to {zéi 賊}.
::PTB	*tsa	``hot, pain''
>:? ST *tsə >

ENTRY:4784
HEAD:zāi₂ 栽哉
MC:Middle Chinese: tsậi 
LH:Later Han: tsə 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *tsə̂
GLOSS:"To plant" 栽 [Li];
GLOSS:"to begin" 哉 [Shu].
	[T] Sin Sukchu SR tsaj (平)
	[T] MGZY dzay (平) [tsaj]
	[T] ONW tsɑi
	[WFE] The basic meaning of this wf is ``to be at a place > to put at a place > put into place > plant / initiate''. The word {zài₁ 在} ``to be in, at'' is prob. related; this wf belongs perhaps to ST *tsə ``come forth'' from which {zǐ₁ 子} (tsɨᴮ) is derived.
::ST	*tsə	``come forth''

ENTRY:4785
HEAD:zāi₂ 栽哉 ⪤ zài₃ 載

LH:Later Han: tsəᶜ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *tsə̂h
	[T] ONW tsɑiᶜ

ENTRY:4809

	[E] Zǎo is prob. derived from {zào₃ 造} ``do, make, begin'' and thus semantically similar to other words for ``morning'' ({chén₅ 晨}, {sù₃ 夙}). WB coᴮ ``early, pre-mature'' ⪤ cʰoᶜ ``be early'' (as rains), JP tʃau³³ are prob.

ENTRY:4815
HEAD:zào₃ 造
MC:Middle Chinese: dzâuᴮ 
LH:Later Han: dzouᴮ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *dzûʔ
	[T] ONW dzɑu
GLOSS:"To do, make, build" (boats, bridges),
GLOSS:"be active, begin" [Shi];
GLOSS:"to achieve" [Shi], ``perfected'' [Shu].
	[N] The element {gào 告} ``report'' with initial k- is not phonetic, it was part of the original word 造 *tshûh ``to go and offer'' (a sacrifice), ``go and appear in court'' which usually would involve some announcement or report. Therefore, there is no need to postulate an *sk-like initial.
	[E] ST: PTB *tsuk > WT ’tsʰugs-pa ``go into, commence, take root'' ⪤ ’dzugs-pa ~ zug-pa ``to stick into, set, erect, put down, begin'' ⪤ ’tsʰud-pa ``be put into, enter'', PLB *tsukᴴ ``build'' (a house). An allofam is prob. {zǎo₁ 早} ``early''.
	This wf is perhaps related to {zào₂ 造}, {zú₁ 卒}.
::PLB	*tsukᴴ	``build''
>:PTB *tsuk >
>:WT ’tsʰugs-pa ``go into, commence, take root'' ⪤ ’dzugs-pa ~ zug-pa ``to stick into, set, erect, put down, begin'' ⪤ ’tsʰud-pa ``be put into, enter''
>:PLB *tsukᴴ ``build'' . An allofam is prob. {zǎo₁ 早} ``early''

ENTRY:4829
HEAD:zhā 奓
MC:Middle Chinese: ṭa 
LH:Later Han: ṭai 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *trâi
GLOSS:"To open" (a door) [Zhuang], the graph shows a person with the legs opened.
	This word's final -k variant is {zhé₆ 磔}.
	OC rimes *-e  and *-ai do occasionally mix in wfs, the initial OC *tr-  could derive from some consonant + medial r as is also seen in the allofam {bò₃ 擘} and its Tai cognates.
	Therefore this word may be cognate to {bǎi₂ 捭} OC *breʔ ``to open''.
	For an overview of similar items, see {Table P-1} under {pī₃ 披}.
	For a listing of similar words and possible allofams, see {lí₁₀ 離}.
::OC	*breʔ	``to open''

ENTRY:4830
HEAD:zhá 札
MC:Middle Chinese: tṣăt 
LH:Later Han: tṣɛt 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *tsrə̂t
GLOSS:"To die (i.e., in an epidemic)" [Zuo],
GLOSS:"pestilence" [Zhouli].
	[WFE] MK: Zhèng Xuán (commentary to Zhōulǐ) says that zhá means ``to die'' in the ancient Yuè (Viet) language (Pulleyblank 1983: 438), which however does not necessarily mean that zhá is a loan from PVM. MK *kc[ə]t ``to die'' (Shorto 2006 #987): PVM *k-ceːt > Viet. chêt ``to die'' (Norman / Mei 1976: 277); PMonic kcət ``to die'' ⪤ k-r-cet ``to kill''; Khmer /sə̀t/ ``to die'' ⪤ /bɑnsìiət/ ``to kill'' (ban- is caus. prefix). For the initials, see {§10.5.2}.
::Khmer	/sə̀t/	``to die''

ENTRY:4833
HEAD:zhái 宅
MC:Middle Chinese: ḍɐk 
LH:Later Han: ḍak 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *drâk

	[T] MGZY cay (入) [dʐaj]
	[T] MTang ḍëk, ONW dëk
	[E] MK: Khmer dak ``put down, settle, lodge …'' ⪤ dɔmnak (i.e. d-mn-ak) ``residence''. As in many words, OC has an assumed *r in the initial which is absent in other languages ({§7.6.2}).

>:Khmer dak ``put down, settle, lodge …'' ⪤ dɔmnak  ``residence''. As in many words

ENTRY:4837

MC:Middle Chinese: tśjäm 
LH:Later Han: tśam 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *tem 
OCB:Baxter Old Chinese: *tjem (占) (Baxter 1992: 541)
	(``To look at, gaze, look at omens, dreams'':) ``prognosticate, interpret'' [OB, BI, Shi].
	[WFE] ? MK: OKhmer /cam/ ``to watch over, watch for, keep in mind'' [Jenner / Pou 1982: 67], Viet xem [sem] < *tśʰj- (and also *ṭʰj-?) ``to see, look at, watch''. The initial correspondance is not clear, though.
::OKhmer	/cam/	``to watch over, watch for, keep in mind''

ENTRY:4853
HEAD:zhàn₂ 戰
MC:Middle Chinese: tśjänᶜ 
LH:Later Han: tśanᶜ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *tans
GLOSS:"War, battle" [Lunyu].
	[T] Sin Sukchu SR tʂjen (去)
	[T] MGZY jÿan (去) [tʂjɛn]
	[T] ONW tśan
	[E] This word is commonly thought to be cognate to WT ral ``fight, war'' (so STC: 155 n. 419; p. 173 n. 461), Lushai raalᴴ ``enemy'', or to rgyal ``victory, victorious''. However, TB initial *r for OC *t- is unlikely.
	As in many languages, the word for ``war, battle'' zhàn may be a semantic extension zhàn 戰 ``tremble, fear'' (under {dàn₇ 憚}) (Geilich 1994: 238).
	The semantics are identical to Greek pólemos ``war'' which is derived from a root ``tremble, fear'' (Buck 1949, no. 20.13).
	The TB word *raːl belongs to the root ``separate'' which is cognate to CH {lí₁₀ 離} ``depart from, divide'' which has a semantic parallel in Skt. vigraha- ``strife, war'' (Buck ibid.).
	The word is probably unrelated to MK *jəl ``to charge, fight'' (Shorto 2006 #1728): Old Khmer jɑl, because MC initial tś- (< *t-) is otherwise not known to correspond to a foreign affricate.
::MK	*jəl	``to charge, fight''
>:This word is commonly thought to be cognate to WT ral ``fight, war''
>:Lushai raalᴴ ``enemy'', or to rgyal ``victory, victorious''. However
>:TB initial *r for OC *t- is unlikely

ENTRY:4854
HEAD:zhàn₃ 戰
GLOSS:"tremble fear"
	{dàn₇} 憚

HEAD:zhàn₄ 棧
MC:Middle Chinese: dẓănᴮ/ᶜ,dẓanᴮ 
LH:Later Han: dẓanᴮ (or dẓɛnᴮ/ᶜ ?) 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *dzrânʔ ?
GLOSS:"A shed made of intertwined branches" [Zhuang],
GLOSS:"carriage box made of lath or bamboo" [Shi].
	[E] Manomaivibool (1975: 157) relates zhàn to Tai: S. raanᶜ² ``machan, booth, stall, shop''. For the initials, see {§7.1.5}.
>:Manomaivibool  relates zhàn to Tai:
>:S. raanᶜ² ``machan, booth, stall, shop''

ENTRY:4862
HEAD:zhāng₁ 張 ⪤ cháng 長
MC:Middle Chinese: ḍjaŋ 
LH:Later Han: ḍɑŋ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *draŋ 
OCB:Baxter Old Chinese: *ɦtrjaŋ
	[T] MTang ḍaŋ ONW daŋ
GLOSS:"Be long, tall, long-lasting" [BI, Shi].
	[D] PMin *d̯ɔŋ
	[<] endopass. ({§4.6}) of *traŋ 張, lit. ``be extended, stretched'' (intr. voicing; Baxter and Sagart 1998: 46). The lack of TB cognates indicates that this word is a CH innovation.

ENTRY:4863
HEAD:zhāng₁ 張 ⪤ zhàng₅ 長
MC:Middle Chinese: ḍjaŋᶜ 
LH:Later Han: ḍɑŋᶜ 
OC:Old Chinese: *draŋh
GLOSS:"Length, measure of length" [Li].
	[<] LOC general derivation *draŋ ({§3.5.2}) (Baxter / Sagart 1998: 55: a noun derived from a ``gradable adjective'').
	[E] ST: WT ’dren-ba, draŋ(s)  ``to draw, drag, pull, draw tight'' (a rope), PLB *raŋ ``draw, pull, drag''; Lushai ṭaŋᴴ / ṭanᴸ ``be distented'' (as breasts w. milk), ṭʰaŋᴴ / ṭʰanᴸ ``to grow'', perhaps also WB kraŋᶜ ``tense, tight'' (see {§12.9} WT (5) for the TB initial correspondences).
	Several languages in the area have a syn. with simple initial t-, MK *taaŋ ``extend, stretch'' (Shorto 2006 #544a): Khmer /-daaŋ/ ⪤ /trɑdaaŋ/ ``stretch out, extend'' ⪤ /taaŋ/ ``draw out, prolong, lengthen''; Mon dāŋ, Bahnar tăŋ ``stretch out''.
	AA ⇒ Lepcha daŋ (Forrest JAOS 82, 1962: 334); WB taŋᴮ ``tighten, become tense, stiff'' (from *tr-?); WT tʰaŋ-po ``hardy, strong, tense'' (HST: 150). {Table Z-1} provides an overview of the ST items. ◇
::WT	tʰaŋ-po	``hardy, strong, tense''
>:WT ’dren-ba, draŋ  ``to draw, drag, pull, draw tight''
>:PLB *raŋ ``draw, pull, drag''
>:Lushai ṭaŋᴴ / ṭanᴸ ``be distented'' , ṭʰaŋᴴ / ṭʰanᴸ ``to grow'', perhaps also WB kraŋᶜ ``tense, tight''  for the TB initial correspondences)

ENTRY:4868
HEAD:zhàng₁ 丈
MC:Middle Chinese: ḍjaŋᴮ 
LH:Later Han: ḍɑŋᴮ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *draŋʔ
GLOSS:"Old man" 丈 [Lunyu], 杖 [Yi].
	[T] Sin Sukchu SR dʐjaŋ (上)
	[T] MGZY cang (上) [dʐaŋ]
	[T] MTang ḍaŋ, ONW daŋ
	[E] ST: PTB *źraŋ (STC no. 205) (or rather *ryaŋ ?) > WT žaŋ an honorific: žaŋ-žaŋ ``chief uncle'', WB ə-hraŋ ``master, lord'', Kuki *r(j)aŋ ~ *traŋ ``father's sister's husband'', Mru taraŋ ``uncle'' (Löffler 1966: 140). This may be an old area word: PAN guDaŋ ``adult, grown up'' (Sagart JCL 21.1, 1993: 32 associates AN with items under {zhāng₁ 張}).
	This word is sometimes thought to be the same as {zhàng₃ 杖} ``staff'', i.e. someone who walks with, or leans on, a staff (unlikely).
::Mru	taraŋ	``uncle''
>:PTB *źraŋ   >

ENTRY:4887
HEAD:zhào₁ 召 ⪤ zhāo 招
MC:Middle Chinese: tśjäu 
LH:Later Han: tśau 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *tau
	[T] ONW tśau

ENTRY:4893
HEAD:zhē 著
MC:Middle Chinese: ṭjak,ḍjak
	[T] Sin Sukchu SR tʂjaw, dʐjaw (入), LR tʂjawʔ
	[T] MGZY jew, cew  (入) [tʂɛw ~ dʐɛw]
	A Mand. progressive suffix, first appears in the 9th cent.
	AD; in Wú dial.: tsɨ (< Southern MC ṭjɤ), it has now also assumed the function of the perfective aspect marker (Mei Tsu-Lin CAAAL 9, 1978: 39ƒƒ.).

ENTRY:4895
HEAD:zhé₂ 折
MC:Middle Chinese: tśjät 
LH:Later Han: tśat 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *tet 
OCB:Baxter Old Chinese: *tjet
	[T] ONW tśat (Baxter 1998)
GLOSS:"To break off" tr. [Shi],
GLOSS:"destroy" [Yi],
GLOSS:"decide" [Shu].
	[WFE] ST *tet ~ *tjat (for the vowels, see {§11.3.2}): Chepang tet- ``break or snap a rope, tear cloth''. PTB *tsyat (STC no. 185), or rather *tyat (Baxter / Sagart 1998: 43f): PLB *tsat ~ *C-tsat ``break in two, cut through, conclude''; WT ’čʰad-pa, čʰad ``to cut, explain'' ⪤ gčod-pa, bčad ``to cut''.
	Lushai čatᴸ / čaʔᴸ (Lorr. chat) ``to break or snap'' (as rope, string), ``asunder, apart'' ⪤ čʰatᴸ / čʰaʔᴸ ``to fetch or cut'' (long pieces of cane etc.).
	[C] Karlgren 1956: 16 relates {zhé₃ 哲} ``wise'' (< ``penetrating'') to this wf.
::WT	’čʰad-pa, čʰad	``to cut, explain''

ENTRY:4896
HEAD:zhé₂ 折 ⪤ shé 折
MC:Middle Chinese: źjät 
LH:Later Han: dźat 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *det 
OCB:Baxter Old Chinese: *N-tjet
	[T] ONW dźat (Baxter 1998)
GLOSS:"To bend" intr. [Li],
GLOSS:"be cut off, broken off > to die prematurely" [Shu].
	[<] endopass. of zhé 折 (tśjät) ({§4.6}) (Baxter and Sagart 1998: 43). For a semantic parallel, see {yǎo₁ 夭殀}.

ENTRY:4897
HEAD:zhé₃ 哲
MC:Middle Chinese: ṭjät 
LH:Later Han: ṭɑt 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *trat
	[T] ONW tat
GLOSS:"Be intelligent, wise, clever" sv [Shi]; a Han period Qí-Sòng (eastern) dialect word for
GLOSS:"know" [FY 1.1].
	[WFE] Several etymological suggestions have been made: Karlgren (1956: 16) relates 哲 to {zhé₂ 折} ``break, decide'' (hence 哲 ``penetrating''). Or it may be connected with {zhī₅ 知} ``to know'' (so Pulleyblank in Rosemont 1991: 32).

ENTRY:4898
HEAD:zhé₃ 哲 ⪤ chè 徹
MC:Middle Chinese: ḍjät,ṭʰjät 
LH:Later Han: ḍat,ṭʰat 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *drat,*thrat 
OCB:Baxter Old Chinese: *ɦthrjet,*thrjet
GLOSS:"To understand" tr.  [BI, Shi].
	[T] ONW tʰat
	[<] The form LH ḍat is perhaps endopass. of zhé ({§4.6}); LH ṭʰiat may reflect a transitive / caus. form ({§5.8.2}).
	However, the most likely connection is with TB, although the OC initial seems more complex: WB tat ``to know, be skilled in'', JP mə³¹-tat³¹ ``to listen'', Tani *tas ``to listen / hear'' (also ``to ask'') (Sun LTBA 16.2, 1993: 180), WT tʰos-pa ``to hear''.
::WT	tʰos-pa	``to hear''

ENTRY:4903
HEAD:zhé₇ 摺

	[T] ONW tśap

HEAD:zhèn₂ 振震

LH:Later Han: tśinᶜ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *təns ONW tśin
GLOSS:"To shake, rouse, quake" 振 [Shi] >
GLOSS:"to alarm, fear" 震 [OB, Shi],

ENTRY:4929
HEAD:zhèn₂ 振震 ⪤ zhēn₅ 振
MC:Middle Chinese: tśjen 
LH:Later Han: tśin 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *tən
GLOSS:"Majestic" [Shi] is prob. related because of the frequent semantic connection between
GLOSS:"shake" and
GLOSS:"fear, fearsome".
	[E] The semantic field of this wf is parallel to {sōu₃,sǒu 搜}: ``move / stir > pregnant, morning''. Therefore {chén₅ 晨} ``morning'' belongs also to this root, perhaps also {zhèn₃,shēn 娠} ``pregnant''.
	Perhaps {zhèn₂a 震} ``thunder'' belongs to this wf.
	Probably connected with MK *gt₁ar (& *gt₁ər ?) ``to shiver'' (Shorto 2006 #1623): Bahnar tar-[war] ``to shake with fear'', Central Nicobarese kətɤə ``to tremble, vibrate'', Mon hətɔ ``to shiver'', Khasi kynther ``to shake off, shed, flutter''.
::Khasi	kynther	``to shake off, shed, flutter''
>:The semantic field of this wf is parallel to {sōu₃,sǒu 搜}:
>:``move / stir > pregnant, morning''. Therefore {chén₅ 晨} ``morning'' belongs also to this root, perhaps also {zhèn₃,shēn 娠} ``pregnant''

	[E] Perhaps related to {zhèn₂ 振震}.

ENTRY:4931
HEAD:zhèn₃,shēn 娠
MC:Middle Chinese: tśjenᶜ,śjen 
LH:Later Han: tśin 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *təns
GLOSS:"Pregnant" 娠 [Zuo],
GLOSS:"become pregnant" 震 [Shi].
GLOSS-NOTE:The reading shēn has prob. been transferred from {shēn₂ 身}
GLOSS:"body" with which it is unrelated.
	[E] The etymology is not certain. It is prob. the s. w. as {zhèn₂ 振震} and therefore semantically derived from ``to shake, rouse, excite'' (e.g. a grasshopper from hibernation, i.e. coming to life), hence lit. ``start stirring, moving'' (of an embryo).
	Alternatively, this could be the s. w. as {zhèn₄ 侲娠} (tśjenᶜ) LH tśienᶜ, OCM *təns ``child, boy or girl'' [Han texts]; in the ancient Yān-Qí region (NE and eastern China) the word meant ``someone who raises horses'' (stable boy / girl?), 娠 also refers to a ``maid'' of an official's wife [FY 3,3]. Zhèn ``pregnant'' means then lit. ``with child''.
::OCM	*təns	``child, boy or girl''
>:The etymology is not certain. It is prob. the s. w. as {zhèn₂ 振震} and therefore semantically derived from ``to shake, rouse, excite'' , hence lit. ``start stirring, moving''

>:PTB *taŋ  >
>:WT tʰaŋ ``pine, fir, evergreen tree''
>:WB tʰaŋᴮ ``fuel, firewood'', in compounds also ``pine, fir''

ENTRY:4943
HEAD:zhēng₇ 蒸

	{chéng₂} 丞承

	{zhèng₂} 證

ENTRY:4948
HEAD:zhèng₁ 正政
MC:Middle Chinese: tśjäŋᶜ 
LH:Later Han: tśeŋᶜ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *teŋh
GLOSS:"Be straight, correct > govern, determine" 正 [Shi, Shu];
GLOSS:"to govern, government" 政 [BI, Shi, Shu],
GLOSS:"remonstrate" 証 [Guoce].
	[T] Sin Sukchu SR tʂiŋ (去)
	[T] MGZY jing (去) [tʂiŋ]
	[T] ONW tśeŋ
	[<] exoact. / tr. derivation of zhēng ({§4.3.2}).

ENTRY:4949
HEAD:zhèng₁ 正政 ⪤ zhēng 正征
MC:Middle Chinese: tśjäŋ 
LH:Later Han: tśeŋ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *teŋ
GLOSS:"Center of target; first (month)" [BI, Shi] > (``to target, make straight for'':)
GLOSS:"to march on / against, campaign" 征 [BI, Shi].
GLOSS-NOTE:Contrary to traditional belief (GSR 833o), the basic meaning is not
GLOSS:"to correct" >
GLOSS:"punish by military expedition", although the (royal, imperial) attacker likes to see his action thus morally justified.

ENTRY:4950
HEAD:zhèng₁ 正政 ⪤ zhěng₂ 整
MC:Middle Chinese: tśjäŋᴮ 
LH:Later Han: tśeŋᴮ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *teŋʔ
GLOSS:"Be orderly" [Zuo] > causative
GLOSS:"to arrange, dispose" (troops) [Shi] (Unger Hao-ku 36, 1990: 50)
	[<] endoactive of zhēng 正征 (tśjäŋ) ({§4.5}).
	[WFE] ST or area word: Lushai diiŋᶠ ``to go straight or direct, go straight through without breaking the journey'' etc.; Chepang dʰeŋ- ``be straight''; JP teŋ³¹ ``right, correct'', Lepcha atʰáŋ ``right, correct'', WB tañᶜ ``straightforward, direct''. <> MK: Khmer diaṅa /tíiəŋ/ ``be true, accurate, correct, right''.
	This wf could be related to {tíng₁ 亭} (so Karlgren 1956: 16), but prob. not to {tǐng₂ 挺} because the initials are different (*l- vs. *t-).
	Matisoff (1988) combines this wf with {yíng₂ 盈嬴} ``full'', {píng₁ 平} ``level'', {tǐng₂ 挺} ``straight''.
::Khmer	diaṅa /tíiəŋ/	``be true, accurate, correct, right''

ENTRY:4951

GLOSS-NOTE:The wf {zhēn₄ 貞} is similar to this one.
	[T] Sin Sukchu SR tʂiŋ (去)
	[T] MGZY jing (去) [tʂiŋ]

ENTRY:4952
HEAD:zhèng₂ 證 ⪤ zhēng 徵
MC:Middle Chinese: ṭjəŋ 
LH:Later Han: ṭəŋ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *trəŋ ?
	[T] MTang ṭiŋ ONW tiŋ
GLOSS:"To examine, verify, summon" [Shu],
GLOSS:"test, testify, prove" [Zuo].

ENTRY:4953
HEAD:zhī₁ 之
MC:Middle Chinese: tśɨ 
LH:Later Han: tśə 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *tə
	[T] Sin S. SR tʂi (平), PR, LR tʂʅ
	[T] MGZY ji (平) [tʂi]
	[T] ONW tśə
GLOSS:1:Demonstrative pronoun
GLOSS:"this, he, she, it".
	As a subject it is common in OB, sporadic in Shījīng and subsequent classical texts, but it is everywhere the normal object pronoun ``him, her, it''.
	Placed after the negatives bù 不 and wú 毋, the obj. pronoun is reduced to its initial t- and fused with the preceding negatives yielding fú 弗 (pjuət) ``not it'' and wù 勿 (mjuət) ``don't … it'', see under {bù₁ 不} and {wú₁ 毋}.
GLOSS:2:Derived from the pronoun is the use as the common genitive marker.
	A medieval colloquial genitive marker was written {dǐ₂ 底}; subsequently {de₃ 的} appears for the first time in a Song document (Coblin p.c.) and later in a Yuan inscription of 1238 (Mei Tsu-Lin BIHP 59.1, 1988).
	However, these forms may be unrelated to zhī because they imply a final -k.
	[WFE] ST: WT da ``there''.
::WT	da	``there''

ENTRY:4954
HEAD:zhī₁ 之 ⪤ shí 時
MC:Middle Chinese: zɨ 
LH:Later Han: dźə 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *də
	Demonstrative pronoun ``this, now, then'' [Shi]. Pulleyblank (1995: 89) considers shí a relatively unemphatic form of {shì₁₄ 是}.
	See also {§3.3.3}.
	[T] Sin S. SR ʐi (平), PR, LR ʐʅ
	[T] MGZY zhi (平) [ʐi]
	[T] ONW dźə
::Demonstrative	pronoun	``this, now, then''

ENTRY:4955

OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *tə (= *tiə ?)

	[T] Sin S. SR tʂi (平), PR, LR tʂʅ
	[T] MGZY ji (平) [tʂi]
	[T] ONW tśə
	[E] ST *tjə ?: WT čʰa-ba ``to go, become, be going to''; WB caᶜ ``begin, at first'' ⪤ ə-caᶜ  ``beginning''. These TB items do not belong to {chū₃ 初} as has been suggested.
>:ST *tjə ?:
>:WT čʰa-ba ``to go, become, be going to''
>:WB caᶜ ``begin, at first'' ⪤ ə-caᶜ  ``beginning''. These TB items do not belong to {chū₃ 初} as has been suggested

ENTRY:4956
HEAD:zhī₂ 之 ⪤ shí 時旹
MC:Middle Chinese: źɨ 
LH:Later Han: dźə 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *dəʔ (tone!)
GLOSS:"Time, season" [BI, Shi].
GLOSS-NOTE:OC ⇒ Tai: S. tii¹ < d-
GLOSS:"time, favorable occasion".
	[<] *tə + endopassive devoicing ({§4.6}) + endoactive tone B ({§4.5}) forming an introvert noun, ``what is proceeding''.

ENTRY:4957
HEAD:zhī₂ 之 ⪤ zhì 志
MC:Middle Chinese: tśɨᶜ 
LH:Later Han: tśəᶜ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *təh
GLOSS:"Goal, purpose, will, wish" [Shu] >
GLOSS:"spirit, mind, record, treatise" [Zuo].
GLOSS-NOTE:Note the semantic proximity with the root in the phrase 不如我所之
GLOSS:"[My thoughts] are not equal to (where I am going:) my purpose" [Shi 54, 5].
	[<] *tə + exopass. s/h-suffix ({§4.4}), lit. ``what is being proceeded to''. This word is unrelated to {shì₃₂ 識} (suggested by Wáng Lì 1982: 95).

ENTRY:4958
HEAD:zhī₂ 之 ⪤ zhǐ 止趾
MC:Middle Chinese: tśɨᴮ 
LH:Later Han: tśəᴮ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *təʔ
GLOSS:"Foot > heel" [BI, Shi]; >
GLOSS:"to settle, stop" 止 [Shi].
	[<] *tə + endoactive tone B noun derivation ({§4.5}). This word is not related to the TB items under {jǐ₁ 几机}.

ENTRY:4959
HEAD:zhī₂ 之 ⪤ chén 辰
MC:Middle Chinese: źjen 
LH:Later Han: dźɨn 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *dən
	[T] ONW dźin
GLOSS:"Date, point in time, season" [BI, Shi].
	[<] *də 時 + the nominal n-suffix ({§6.4.3}), lit. ``what is proceeding''. Chén partially converges with {chén₅ 晨辰}.
	It replaces its simplex shí 時 in southern dialects as the word for ``time'': M-Fúzhōu seiŋᴬ²-ŋauᶜ² 辰候, Y-Guǎngzhōu siᴬ²-sɐnᴬ² 時辰.

ENTRY:4960
HEAD:zhī₃ 汁
MC:Middle Chinese: tśjəp 
LH:Later Han: kip 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *kip
	[T] ONW tśip
GLOSS:"Juice, sap, melting snow" [Li].
	[D] PMin *tšep
	[WFE] Etymology not certain. Perh. related is PLB *ʔgrip ``lac, pine resin'': WB kʰrip, kʰyip [STC: 38] (CVST 5: 65); or to Kachin məgyep ``liquor'' (STC: 38); or HST: 99 relates zhī to WT čʰab ``water'', but initial velars do not palatalize in WT. Prob. not related to {chěn₂ 瀋沈} ``a liquid''.
::WT	čʰab	``water''

ENTRY:4966

ENTRY:4968

ENTRY:4973
HEAD:zhī₁₀ 脂
MC:Middle Chinese: tśi 
LH:Later Han: tśi 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *ki ?
	[T] ONW tśi
GLOSS:"Grease" (for lubrication) [Shi].
GLOSS-NOTE:SW says that zhī belongs to animals with horns, {gāo₃ 膏}
GLOSS:"grease, fat" to animals without horns (e.g. pigs).
	The OC initial is not certain, the phonetic implies an OC *k-, but palatalization of 旨 may have occurred so early in the Zhou period that it could also be used for words with original dental initials.
	[E] The TB area has words for ``grease, fat'' with the final -il, but with initial consonants which are difficult to reconcile with the CH word: PTB *tsil (STC: 168f.) > WT tsʰil ``fat'' n.; Kanauri tsil ``marrow''; PL *tsi¹ ``fat'', WB cʰi ``oil'', kʰraŋ-cʰi ``marrow'' [Matisoff 1978: 183f] (STC: 169 n. 452). Also, note AA: Santali itil ``be fat'', Khmer kɔn-ʈul.
::WB	cʰi	``oil''
>:The TB area has words for ``grease, fat'' with the final -il, but with initial consonants which are difficult to reconcile with the CH word:
>:PTB *tsil  >
>:WT tsʰil ``fat'' n.
>:Kanauri tsil ``marrow''
>:PL *tsi¹ ``fat''

>:Santali itil ``be fat''
>:Khmer kɔn-ʈul

	[WFE] Some TB languages have a variant, or different etymon, with initial *r: PLB *rak, *k-rak, also Mutwang (Rawang - Nung) raʔ ``weave'' [Matisoff TSR: 70]; Lushai ṭahᴸ < traʔ or trah ``to weave, woven''. 	Tibetan and Chinese (where applicable) have the T-variant, Burmese the R-variant.

ENTRY:4981
HEAD:zhí₂ 直

LH:Later Han: ḍɨk 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *drək

GLOSS:"set up", or to {zhí₁ 直}
GLOSS:"single" (so Karlgren GSR 919a). Probable allofam {dé₂ 德}.

ENTRY:4983
HEAD:zhí₄ 姪
MC:Middle Chinese: diet,ḍjet 
LH:Later Han: det,ḍet 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *lît or *d-lit ? 
OCB:Baxter Old Chinese: *dīt
	[T] ONW dėt
GLOSS:"Nephew, niece" [Zuo].
	[E] ST: PTB *b-ləy ``nephew, grandchild'' (STC no. 448; Matisoff 1995a: 52), OBurm. mliy, WB mreᴮ ``grandchild'' [IST: 337]. For the initials, see {§8.1.1}; {§8.1.5}; for the final *-t, see {§6.2}.
::WB	mreᴮ	``grandchild''
>:PTB *b-ləy ``nephew, grandchild''
>:OBurm. mliy
>:WB mreᴮ ``grandchild''

ENTRY:5000
HEAD:zhǐ₈ 紙
MC:Middle Chinese: tśieᴮ 
LH:Later Han: tśɑiʔ or kiɑiʔ ? (MHan)
	[T] ONW tśe
GLOSS:"Paper" [Hou Hanshu].
	[E] Bodman (1980: 184) relates this to Viet. giâý, PVM *k-cajʔ [Ferlus] ``paper'' which, like the PMin form *tšiɑiᴮ, presupposes an OC rime *-ai rather than the QY's *-e. When this word was committed to writing, the rimes OC *-ai and *e had already merged in some dialects, a process which is observed already in late Zhou texts (Pulleyblank 1962: 216).
::PVM	*k-cajʔ 	``paper''
>:Bodman  relates this to Viet. giâý
>:PVM *k-cajʔ  ``paper'' which, like the PMin form *tšiɑiᴮ, presupposes an OC rime *-ai rather than the QY's *-e. When this word was committed to writing, the rimes OC *-ai and *e had already merged in some dialects, a process which is observed already in late Zhou texts

ENTRY:5001
HEAD:zhǐ₉ 黹
MC:Middle Chinese: ṭiᴮ 
LH:Later Han: ṭiᴮ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *triʔ
GLOSS:"Embroidery" [BI, Zhouli].
	[WFE] Etymology not certain. Possibly from ST *C-rwi: Lushai ṭʰuiᴴ ``to sew'', JP ri³¹ ``thread''; for absence of the medial w in CH, see {§10.2.1}.
	Alternatively, this wf could be related to MK: Khmer tir ``to sew clothes or tree-leaves'' [S. Lewitz AA Studies 2, 1976: 742]; the metathesis of the MK final *-r may have been occasioned by the final consonant forms in this wf (-irt > -rit), but can also occur in words with simple final *-r, see {§7.7.3} and {§6.1}.
::Khmer	tir	``to sew clothes or tree-leaves''

ENTRY:5007

ENTRY:5008
HEAD:zhì₂ 蛭
MC:Middle Chinese: tśjet,ṭjet,tiet,ṭjäiᶜ 
LH:Later Han: tet ?,tśit ?,ṭit ? 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *tit 
OCB:Baxter Old Chinese: *tĭt,*tīt (PCH *m-lhit ?)
GLOSS:"Water leech" [SW, GY].
	[E] ST etymon, although the correspondence of the initial consonants is unusual ({§8.1.5}): PTB *m/s-liːt ``water leech'' (STC no. 396; HPTB: 350), but KN *m-hliit (IST: 27) Lushai hliit < C-lit; Lepcha hlet-bŭ, Karen Pho *səli, Chepang lit. TB cognates to words in GSR 413 have pre-initial *m- ({§8.1.5}).
	The unrelated Mand. word for ``leech'' also has the *m-prefix: mǎ-huáng 螞蟥, so do old dialect words mǎ-qí 馬蜞, mǎ-qí 馬耆.
	Alternatively, CVST 2: 129 connects zhì with WT sdig ``scorpion''.
	[C] The word may possibly be related to {dié₂ 咥} *lit ``to bite''.
::WT	sdig	``scorpion''
>:ST etymon, although the correspondence of the initial consonants is unusual :
>:PTB *m/s-liːt ``water leech'' , but KN *m-hliit  Lushai hliit <
>:C-lit
>:Lepcha hlet-bŭ
>:Karen Pho *səli
>:Chepang lit. TB cognates to words in GSR 413 have pre-initial *m-

	[T] ONW tiᶜ
GLOSS:"Be weighed down" [Shi].

ENTRY:5010
HEAD:zhì₄ 銍
MC:Middle Chinese: ṭjet 
LH:Later Han: ṭit 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *trit
GLOSS:"Sickle, cut with a sickle" [Shi] >
GLOSS:"ears of grain" [Shu]
	[E] Perh. ST: WT gri ``knife'', WB kreᴮ ``copper'', JP mə³¹-gri³³ ``brass'', Lushai hreiᴸ < hreih ``axe, hatchet''; for the initial correspondence see {§7.1.4}; {§8.1.5}; for final *-t see {§6.2.1}.
	Alternatively, Luo Yongxian (ICSTLL 2002) suggests that zhì is related to Tai: Po-ai liipᴰ¹ᴸ < *tʰr- ``small knife used to cut or reap glutinous rice'', Wuming rep, Yay (Dioi) tʰep, but the Tai and CH final consonants do not agree.
	Alternatively, the TB items may belong to {qí₁₄ 鰭鬐} ``fin'' (semantically less likely).

ENTRY:5012
HEAD:zhì₆ 膣
MC:Middle Chinese: ṭjet,tiet [Yupian 6th cent. AD] (the reading may simply be that of the phonetic)
GLOSS:"Vagina" (ZWDCD),
GLOSS:"vulva" (Sino-Japanese acc. to Benedict); the meaning is only later attested (Benedict LTBA 14.1, 1991: 143).
	[E] ST *tey (Benedict): PTB *teyᴮ, PKaren *ʔteᴮ (Benedict LTBA 5.1, 1979:22). The CH form goes back to a hypothetical OC *tit which brings it close to the TB / ST etymon *ti ``water'' as in {tì₁ 涕} *thiʔ/h ``tears'': JP mə³¹-di³³ ``be moist, be wet'' ⪤ mə³¹-dit³¹ ``to moisten, be wet''; PLoloish *Ntit ``soak in water'' ⪤ *ʔtit ``to immerse'' (or *Ntik ⪤ ʔtik) ⪤ Lahu dì (< *Ndi) ``ejaculate'' (of a man), ``moisten due to sexual excitement'' (of a woman) (Matisoff 1978: 33; 2002: 53 no. 109).
	Apparently zhì has the nominal t-suffix for natural objects, lit. ``the moist thing'' ({§6.2.1}).
	The etymon is also reminiscent of PVM *k-cɛːʔ ``vagina''.
	Syn. {bī₁ 屄}.
::PVM	*k-cɛːʔ	``vagina''
>:ST *tey :
>:PTB *teyᴮ
>:PKaren *ʔteᴮ . The CH form goes back to a hypothetical OC *tit which brings it close to the TB / ST etymon *ti ``water'' as in {tì₁ 涕} *thiʔ/h ``tears'':
>:JP mə³¹-di³³ ``be moist, be wet'' ⪤ mə³¹-dit³¹ ``to moisten, be wet''
>:PLoloish *Ntit ``soak in water'' ⪤ *ʔtit ``to immerse''  ⪤ Lahu dì  ``ejaculate'' , ``moisten due to sexual excitement''

ENTRY:5027
HEAD:zhì₁₈ 質
MC:Middle Chinese: tśjet 
LH:Later Han: tśit (tśɨt ?) 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *tət
	[T] ONW tśit
GLOSS:"Natural qualities" [Li],
GLOSS:"substance" [Yi],
GLOSS:"essential" [Lunyu].
	[E] Unger (Hao-ku 39, 1992: 88) relates this word to WT gšis ``nature, temper, natural disposition'' (the correspondence of the initials is unusual), while Baxter / Sagart (1998: 52) derive this word by t-prefix from {shí₁₂ 實} ``fruit, solid, really''. Karlgren (1956: 16) connects this word with zhì 質 (ṭiᶜ) LH ṭis, *trəts ``pledge, security give, hostage'' [Zuozhuan].
::LH	ṭis, *trəts	``pledge, security give, hostage''
>:Unger  relates this word to WT gšis ``nature, temper, natural disposition'' , while Baxter / Sagart  derive this word by t-prefix from {shí₁₂ 實} ``fruit, solid, really''. Karlgren  connects this word with zhì 質  LH ṭis, *trəts ``pledge, security give, hostage''

ENTRY:5038
HEAD:zhì₂₅,zhài 廌
MC:Middle Chinese: ḍjeᴮ,ḍaɨᴮ 
LH:Later Han: ḍɛᴮ ? 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *dreʔ
GLOSS:"Some kind of small deer" [OB, SW].
GLOSS-NOTE:When hunting, Shang dynasty kings would often kill this animal in great numbers [OB], but later its identity was mostly forgotten. SW has the variant xiè-zhì  解廌 or 解豸 LH gɛʔ-ḍɛʔ.
	This riming binome makes it likely that the LH reading was ḍɛʔ rather than ḍieʔ.
	Curiously, in a passage in Zuǒzhuàn (Xuan 17) 豸 is supposedly a graphic loan for 解 which raises the suspicion that the latter ended up as a pre-syllable in the animal name due to a misunderstood gloss.
	Be that as it may, the element xiè 解 ``distinguish, understand'' may be responsible for the belief that this animal could tell straight from crooked, right from wrong.
	[E] MK *draay ``kind of deer'' (Shorto 2006 #1508) > OMon *drāy ``hog deer'' (⇒ WB darai ``hog deer''), Biat ɗraai ``swamp deer'', PVM *k-ɗeː ``deer'' [Ferlus], Khmer trìəːy ``stag''. <> PYao *djai² ``deer'' [Purnell].
::PYao	*djai²	``deer''
>:MK *draay ``kind of deer''  >
>:OMon *drāy ``hog deer''
>:Biat ɗraai ``swamp deer''
>:PVM *k-ɗeː ``deer''
>:Khmer trìəːy ``stag''. < > PYao *djai² ``deer''

ENTRY:5039
HEAD:zhì₂₆ 雉
MC:Middle Chinese: ḍjiᴮ 
LH:Later Han: ḍiᴮ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *driʔ
GLOSS:"Pheasant" [Shi].
	[E] ST: WB rac ``pheasant'', WT sreg-pa ``partridge'', Lushai vaᴸ-hritᴸ, SChin-Areng tari’ (Löffler Anthropos 55, 1960: 529), Mru rik, Garo grit ``pheasant'' (STC no. 403; HPTB: 507), perhaps also Chepang rut-waʔ. OC *-ʔ for PTB *-k is regular, see {§3.2.2}; for the initials, see {§7.1.4}.
::Garo	grit	``pheasant''
>:WB rac ``pheasant''
>:WT sreg-pa ``partridge''
>:Lushai vaᴸ-hritᴸ
>:SChin-Areng tari’ , Mru rik, Garo grit ``pheasant'' , perhaps also Chepang rut-waʔ. OC *-ʔ for PTB *-k is regular, see {§3.2.2}
>:for the initials, see {§7.1.4}

GLOSS:"sincere".

>:OC ⇒ Tai:

ENTRY:5050
HEAD:zhōng₁ 中 ⪤ zhòng 仲
MC:Middle Chinese: ḍjuŋᶜ 
LH:Later Han: ḍuŋᶜ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *druŋh
GLOSS:"The 2nd (middle) of three or more brothers" [Shi],
GLOSS:"second of the month" [Shu].
	[E] The etymology is not certain. PMiao *ntrɔŋᴬ ``middle'' is close to the OC form.
	Perh. related to WT gžuŋ < glyuŋ or gryuŋ (?) ``middle'' (<> HST: 53).
	But other etyma may be related instead: STC: (182 n. 479) relates zhōng to PTB *tuːŋ ``inside'' (STC no. 390) > Manchati toŋ(-riŋ) ``inside'', Chepang duŋ ``inside'' (esp. of a dwelling) ⪤ duŋʔ- ``push to the center''; WB ə-twaŋᴮ ``inside, inner part of a thing'', Lushai čʰuŋᴴ ``inside of anything'' (<> CVST 2: 3); Rawang ă-duŋ ``middle'' (IST: 55).
	The basic meaning of both these TB etyma is ``inside'', not ``middle'', however.
	Finally, there is yet another root meaning ``inside'' < ``excavate'' in AA, see under {chuán₁ 船} ``boat''.
::Rawang	ă-duŋ	``middle''
>:The etymology is not certain. PMiao *ntrɔŋᴬ ``middle'' is close to the OC form

ENTRY:5071
HEAD:zhōu₃ 周
MC:Middle Chinese: tśjəu 
LH:Later Han: tśu 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *tiu
	[T] ONW tśu
GLOSS:"To surround, encircle, circle, everywhere, curve (in the road)" [Shi].
	[WFE] Etymology not certain. Perh. connected with WT gču-ba ~ lču-ba ``screw'' ⪤ gčud-pa ~ lčud-pa ``to turn, twist, plait, braid''.
	Alternative: Tai: S. diw³ ``strips of rattan or bamboo bent in a circle to which ribs of a cage are fastened'' (McFarland: 330).
	Other alternative: note AA: Khmer jwta /cúuət/ ``to encircle or wrap (the head) in a length of cloth'', the final -t would be lost in OC after a long vowel ({§6.9}); the initials could be reconciled if the source had tj- or tšj- (as opposed to ts-); a parallel case may be {zhōu₄ 周}.
	A doubtful comparandum is {tāo₁ 綢}.
::Khmer	jwta /cúuət/	``to encircle or wrap (the head) in a length of cloth''

	[T] MTang ḍeu < ḍu ONW du

ENTRY:5074
HEAD:zhōu₄ 周
MC:Middle Chinese: tśjəu 
LH:Later Han: tśu 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *tiu
GLOSS:"To have aid, help" [Shi],
GLOSS:"relieve, succour" 賙 [Zhouli].
	[E] Etymology not clear. Perh. the s. w. as {zhōu₃ 周} ``surround'' as words for ``help, aid'' are often derived from the notion ``next to, or around, a person'' (see under {zuǒ 左} and {yòu₂ 右}).
	Alternatively, note AA: Khmer jwya [ɉuuj] /cúuəj/ ``to aid, help, succour, rescue, save'', the final -j would be lost in OC after the long vowel ({§6.9}). For the initials, see the comment under {zhōu₃ 周}.
::Khmer	jwya [ɉuuj] /cúuəj/	``to aid, help, succour, rescue, save''
>:Etymology not clear. Perh. the s. w. as {zhōu₃ 周} ``surround'' as words for ``help, aid'' are often derived from the notion ``next to, or around, a person''

ENTRY:5075
HEAD:zhōu₅ 粥鬻
MC:Middle Chinese: tśjuk 
LH:Later Han: tśuk 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *tuk
	[T] ONW tśuk
	[D] PMin *tšyk
GLOSS:"Rice gruel" [Zuo, Li].
	[E] ST: Association with WT tʰug-pa ``soup, broth'' (Bodman 1980: 172; HST: 137) is more straightforward than Karlgren's (1956: 17) derivation from {yù₂₂ 育毓鬻} ``produce''.
::WT	tʰug-pa	``soup, broth''
>:Association with WT tʰug-pa ``soup, broth''  is more straightforward than Karlgren's  derivation from {yù₂₂ 育毓鬻} ``produce''

ENTRY:5077
HEAD:zhōu₆ 皺 ⪤ zhòu 縐

ENTRY:5078
HEAD:zhǒu₁ 肘
MC:Middle Chinese: ṭjəuᴮ 
LH:Later Han: ṭuᴮ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *truʔ
GLOSS:"Wrist, elbow" [OB, Zuo].
	[<] This is a tone B endoactive body part derivation ({§3.3.2}) from a root *tru which also underlies {chù₂ 絀}, hence lit. ``the thing that is bending''. The phonetic in the latter may indicate some sort of velar in the complex initial, hence the word may be related to WB kruiᶜ ``bow down, stoop'', and perhaps also to WT gru-mo ``elbow'' (HST: 70) is related, which lit. means ``corner, angle'', however.
	Note also PTai *x-: S. kʰɔɔᶜ¹ (loan?).
	The Lushai word for ``elbow'' kiuᴸ < kiuʔ/h may belong to the root {jiǔ₃ 糾}.
	For a semantic parallel, see wàn 腕 (under {yū₁ 迂紆}).
::WT	gru-mo	``elbow''

	[D] more archaic forms are preserved in southern dialects: M-Fúzhōu tyᴬ¹, Cháozhōu tɯᴬ¹, Xiàmén tiᴬ¹
	[D] X-Chángshā tyᴬ¹
	[D] W-Kāihuà tɑᴬ¹
	[E] Perh. a ST word: Mru tia ``(wild) pig'' (Löffler 1966: 146). Alternatively, {jiā₈ 豭} is said to be a dialect form of zhū [FY]; but since jiā appears to be much older than zhū, the latter could have developed *Cr- > tr- > ṭ which seems to be associated with rural words ({§1.3.1}; {§7.1.4}).

LH:Later Han: tśok 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *tok

::JP	məcɔ́ʔ	``socket, vagina''

>:MK *tɔk ``to copulate ''  appears to be the same word

ENTRY:5120

GLOSS:"To cast" (metal) [BI, Zuo].

ENTRY:5122
HEAD:zhù₅ 注 ⪤ zhǔ 斗
MC:Middle Chinese: tśjuᴮ 
LH:Later Han: tśoᴮ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *toʔ
GLOSS:"Ladle" [Zhouli] is a tone B noun derived from zhù, lit.
GLOSS:"the thing which does the pouring".

ENTRY:5123
HEAD:zhù₅ 注 ⪤ dǒu 斗

ENTRY:5124
HEAD:zhù₆ 注
MC:Middle Chinese: tśjuᶜ,ṭjuᶜ 
LH:Later Han: tśoᶜ,ṭoᶜ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *toh,*troh
GLOSS:"To flow into, join, meet" intr. (as a river flows into another / the ocean) [Meng 3A, 4; Shanhaijing 5].
GLOSS-NOTE:``To conduct water'' [Shi] may be this word or belong to {zhù₅ 注}
GLOSS:"to pour".
	[E] Etymology not certain. On the one hand, this word seems to be the cognate of WT mdo ``point where two valleys / rivers meet'', i.e. ``confluence, lower part of valley''; it could be the s. w. as {zhù₇ 注} ``be touched''.
	On the other hand, this may be the same word as {zhù₅ 注} ``to pour'' which, however, has a different WT cognate.
::WT	mdo	``point where two valleys / rivers meet''
>:Etymology not certain. On the one hand, this word seems to be the cognate of WT mdo ``point where two valleys / rivers meet'', i.e. ``confluence, lower part of valley''
>:it could be the s. w. as {zhù₇ 注} ``be touched''

GLOSS:"To apply" [Zuo],
GLOSS:"be touched" [Zhuang],
GLOSS:"bring together" [Zhouli].
	[WFE] ST: WB tuiᶜ ``touch lightly'', Lushai tuukᶠ ``to touch'' (as in a game). This stem may be related to {zhǔ₈ 屬} ``attach, connect''.
::Lushai	tuukᶠ	``to touch''

OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *tots

	[E] ST: WT: gtod-pa, btod-pa ``to tether, tie up, stake'' ⪤ rtod-pa ``to tether, a stake or peg'' (Bodman 1980: 175; HST: 150). Bodman adds zhuó 錣 (ṭwat) LH ṭuat ~ ṭiot ``sharp point at end of whip''.

ENTRY:5183
HEAD:zhuó₁₁ 濯 ⪤ dí 翟
MC:Middle Chinese: diek 
LH:Later Han: dek < deuk 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *liâuk 
OCB:Baxter Old Chinese: *lewk
	A long-tailed pheasant which lives in the mountains [Shi, SW], ``feather'' of such a pheasant [Shi]. This animal is possibly related to the above words because if it had no striking shiny feathers, it would have been of no interest.
	For a semantic parallel (shiny ~ bird), see {hè₂ 鶴} ``crane''.
	In this phonetic series 翟, MC ḍ- seems to derive from some OC L-like initial.
	Perh. {shuò₇ 爍} and {dí₇ 滌} ``to clean'' are related.

ENTRY:5201
HEAD:zǐ₁ 子
MC:Middle Chinese: tsɨᴮ 
LH:Later Han: tsiəᴮ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *tsəʔ 
OCB:Baxter Old Chinese: *tsjəʔ
GLOSS:"Offspring" (Sagart 1999: 164): Child, son’ [OB, Shi],
GLOSS:"young of animals" [Shi],
GLOSS:"plant seeds, eggs". Syn. {ér₄ 兒}, {jiǎn₁ 囝}.
	[T] Sin Sukchu SR tsɿ (上)
	[T] MGZY dzhi (上) [tsɿ]
	[T] ONW tsiə
	[D] In Mand. suffixed to nouns as diminutive marker, to persons, animals, things in general (Norman 1988: 114). Acc. to FY 10.4, zǎi 崽 is a southern dialect form of the Han period, still used today ({§9.1.1}).
	[<] endoactive noun ({§4.5.1}), lit. ``one who has come forth'' (i.e. offspring).
	[E] ST *tsə ``to come forth'' (as child at birth). In this ST root the ``offsping, child'' is the agent, note WT čʰuŋ-ma-la bu btsas ``a son (bu [subj.]) has come forth (btsas) for (-la) the wife (čʰuŋ-ma)'', i.e. ``the wife has given birth to a son'' (Jaeschke p. 434). By contrast, with the verb {shēng₂ 生} ``give birth'', the woman is the agent.
	ST: PTB *tsa (STC no. 59) > WT tsʰa-bo ``grandchild'', Atsi tso, Maru tsō, PBurm. *tsaᴮ; Lushai faᶠ  ``child, son, daughter'', JP gə³¹-ʃa³¹ ``child''.
	[WFE] ST *tsə: WT btsa’-ba, btsas ``to come forth'' (as child at birth).
	[C] To the same root may belong the wfs {zāi₂ 栽哉} ``to plant'', {cái₁ 才材財} ``be well endowed, ability, talent''; possibly also {cǎi₁ 采} ``harvest''.
::WT	btsa’-ba, btsas	``to come forth''
>:ST *tsə ``to come forth'' . In this ST root the ``offsping, child'' is the agent, note WT čʰuŋ-ma-la bu btsas ``a son  has come forth  for  the wife '', i.e. ``the wife has given birth to a son'' . By contrast, with the verb {shēng₂ 生} ``give birth'', the woman is the agent

	<> WB ca ``writing, letter'' is apparently a CH loan (Sagart 1999: 211).
::WB	ca	``writing, letter''

ENTRY:5211
HEAD:zì₁ 自
MC:Middle Chinese: dziᶜ 
LH:Later Han: dziᶜ 
OCM:Minimal Old Chinese: *dzih ?
GLOSS:"Self" [OB, Shi] is used adverbially, the near syn. jǐ 己 is a personal pronoun (Pulleyblank 1995: 83). The original graph is the drawing of a nose, and SW says that this graph is “read like {bí 鼻}
GLOSS:"nose".” This has occasioned much speculation about a possible phonetic and etymological relationship with bí (e.g.
	MC dziᶜ < OC *sb-?, note also WT sbrid-pa ``sneeze''), but phonologically these two syllables are difficult to reconcile (as often, Xǔ Shèn may just have made a guess based on the appearance of the graph).
	Perh. there was a mental association between graph and meaning as one customarily points to one's nose when pointing to oneself.
	[T] Sin Sukchu SR dzɿ (去)
	[T] MGZY tshi (去) [dzɿ]
	[T] ONW dzi
	[E] The homophone zì 自 ``from'' [OB, Shi] is written with the same graph; perhaps ``from'' and the adverbial ``self'' are the same word, ``self'' is the source location from where the action originates. (Note German ``er hat das von sich aus gemacht'' [lit. ``he did this out from self''] = ``er hat das selbst gemacht'' [``he did it himself'']).
::WT	sbrid-pa	``sneeze''
>:The homophone zì 自 ``from''  is written with the same graph
>:perhaps ``from'' and the adverbial ``self'' are the same word, ``self'' is the source location from where the action originates.
